Title: Germany's Coronavirus Death Rate Remains Low Despite High Case Count

Article:

As of March 25, Germany has reported 175 deaths and 34,055 cases of the coronavirus, making it the fifth-highest number of cases globally. However, Germany's fatality rate from COVID-19, at 0.5%, is the world's lowest. Christian Drosten, director of the Institute of Virology at Berlin's Charité hospital, attributes this to Germany's ability to test early and often.

Drosten, who led the team that developed the first COVID-19 test used in the public domain, estimates that Germany has been testing around 120,000 people a week for COVID-19 during the month-long period from late February to now. This extensive testing regimen is believed to be the most extensive in the world.

Germany's low fatality rate is due to its ability to test early and often, according to Drosten. He suggests that Germany's lower number of undetected cases compared to other countries with less prevalent testing could be a factor. Germany's culture, Drosten explains, does not support a centralized diagnostic system, allowing for a more open market for testing.

Lothar Wieler, head of the Robert Koch Institute, Germany's federal agency responsible for disease control and prevention, stated that Germany's testing infrastructure provides a more accurate read of confirmed cases of the virus. However, some Berlin residents have expressed concerns about access to testing.

Nizana Nizzi Brautmann, a Berlin resident, shared her experience of being unable to get tested when a teacher at her son's school tested positive for COVID-19. She was eventually able to speak to a doctor on the phone, who advised her to wait in line outside a local hospital for testing but did not have a mask for herself or her son, and did not want to infect others in line.

Despite these concerns, Drosten believes such experiences are probably an exception rather than the rule. He states that the supply of tests in Germany is still good, and the country has had a robust response to the coronavirus pandemic. However, he expresses concern for countries in Africa that are not well-equipped to handle the pandemic.

Title: Black Lives Matter Global Network's Funding Structure and Transparency

Article:

FactCheck.org and Politifact have confirmed that the Black Lives Matter Global Network is not a recognized Internal Revenue Service (IRS) charity. Instead, the organization raises funds through a fiscal sponsor, global nonprofit Thousand Currents. This arrangement, according to some critics, may block full transparency.

ActBlue, a fundraising platform, helps to raise funds for Black Lives Matter Global Network by directing donations to Thousand Currents, their fiscal sponsor. The partnership between ActBlue and Thousand Currents was announced in 2016, with the latter providing "fiduciary oversight, financial management, and other administrative services to BLM."

Caleb Cade, a spokesperson for ActBlue, confirmed to the fact-checking site that "donations made through ActBlue go to Thousand Currents for Black Lives Matter." Jenesha de Rivera, director of finance and administration at Thousand Currents, reportedly stated that the foundation has applied to become its own 501(c)(3), but Black Lives Matter never returned their request for a Form 1023, the form used to apply for 501(c)(3) status.

Fiscal sponsorships are common, according to the National Council on Nonprofits. These arrangements offer a way for a cause to attract donors even when it is not yet recognized as tax-exempt under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3). In essence, the fiscal sponsor serves as the administrative "home" of the cause, with charitable contributions given to the fiscal sponsor, which then grants them to support the cause.

Benjamin Leff, a professor who specializes in nonprofits, told the fact-checking site that based upon his general understanding of fiscal sponsorships, "both ActBlue Charities and Thousand Currents have a legal obligation to make reasonable efforts to ensure that the funds they receive are spent consistent with 501(c)(3) restrictions."

However, Tom Fitton, president of Judicial Watch, suggested that the fiscal sponsorship route blocks full transparency, particularly when it comes to its partnership with ActBlue. "Transparency?" he posted, linking to Politifact. "So if you want to make a tax-deductible charitable donation directly to Black Lives Matter, you can't. You donate to Act Blue Charities. Act Blue Charities sends this money, allegedly, to another charity, Thousand Currents, which runs BLM as a 'fiscal sponsorship.'"

According to FactCheck.org, "A Thousand Currents audit for 2019 shows that, as of June 2019, the organization held nearly $3.4 million in net assets for Black Lives Matter. It had released nearly $1.8 million to the group in the last fiscal year." The fact-check adds that the audit provides a breakdown of how the foundation spent that $1.8 million, including on consultants and salaries.

Title: An Analysis of Racism Accusations in American Politics: A Neutral Perspective

Article:

In the Gospel according to St. Matthew, Saint Peter asks Christ how often a person should be forgiven. Christ responds, "Not seven times, but seventy times seven." If taken literally, this would imply that the 491st sin is unforgivable.

In American politics, the accusation of racism, often referred to as the "491st sin," is a potent and divisive charge. It is a term that, when levied, demands ostracization and labels the accused a moral pariah. This is evident in the recent political discourse, with figures such as Hillary Clinton employing such accusations, particularly in the context of courting support from African-American and Hispanic communities.

Clinton's rhetoric has been criticized for dipping into McCarthyite smears, implying guilt by association. While she did not explicitly label Donald Trump a racist, she suggested that those aligned with the "alt-right" movement, who support him, are racist.

The "alt-right" is a term that is not clearly defined, and opinions on the group's ideology vary widely. From casual observation, a few members may hold racist views, while most do not. If one is looking for racism, the Black Lives Matter movement or Hillary Clinton herself could be potential sources.

On the right, some argue that the biggest racists are libertarians, who, despite their supposed meritocratic beliefs, may harbor an unhealthy fascination with IQ scores and racial hierarchies, as suggested by works like "The Bell Curve" by Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein.

However, it is important to note that not all nationalists are racists. Nationalists accept all fellow citizens as their peers, and their primary concern is the well-being of their own country and its citizens. They may be chauvinistic or xenophobic, but they do not necessarily hold racist views.

In this context, Donald Trump and his supporters can be considered nationalists, not racists. The accusation that Trump supporters are racists, especially among Trump-haters on the right, remains to be seen.

In conclusion, the accusation of racism in American politics is a complex and sensitive issue. It is crucial to approach such discussions with a nuanced understanding of the various ideologies and perspectives at play, and to avoid making sweeping generalizations or assumptions about individuals or groups based on their political affiliations or beliefs.

Title: Four Cities Legalize Marijuana in Tuesday's Elections: A Milestone in the Marijuana Legalization Movement

Article:

Four cities in the United States voted to legalize marijuana in Tuesday's elections, marking a significant milestone in the ongoing marijuana legalization movement. The cities include three in Michigan and the first on the East Coast, Portland, Maine. However, these votes are largely symbolic as the states of Michigan and Maine still consider marijuana illegal.

The latest Gallup Poll, released in October, found that 58% of Americans support marijuana legalization, a 10-point increase from a year earlier. This represents the highest level of support for marijuana legalization in American history, with a majority of Americans backing it for the first time, according to both the Gallup and Pew studies.

Analysts and advocates attribute the sudden surge in support to several factors. One reason is the legalization of marijuana in Colorado and Washington, which has brought the issue to the forefront of a national conversation. Additionally, during a time of tight federal budgets, people are increasingly disagreeing with robust law enforcement spending, which experts say leads to high incarceration rates. Furthermore, the federal government is allowing states to move forward with legalization and is not aggressively enforcing federal marijuana crime laws.

Allen St. Pierre, executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Law, believes the country is moving closer to legalization. In addition to the two states that have legalized it, 21 states allow medical marijuana, and 17 have decided to decriminalize it, St. Pierre said. In the next two elections, voters in five states are expected to have a say in the issue, with ballot initiatives expected in California, Maine, Oregon, Massachusetts, and Alaska.

The issue of marijuana legalization has taken a similar trajectory as same-sex marriage, which has also seen a flood of public support in recent years. In both cases, the same groups of people are opposed: those who are most religious and those over 55. Additionally, in both cases, liberals and young people are most likely to support the issues. However, William Galston, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, cautions against too closely linking the two issues, as Republicans and conservatives are much more likely to oppose same-sex marriage, and those against are strongly opposed.

Despite the differences in the two issues, support is growing for both. Interestingly, the liberalization of the issues comes at a time when the country remains mostly conservative. In 2012, a Gallup survey found that 40% of Americans identify as conservative, while 35% identify as moderate. Only 21% call themselves liberals. Moderates have been declining since the poll began asking the question in 1992 as more are identifying as either liberal or conservative.

Galston suggests that the increase in support for marijuana legalization could be an example of an issue where the liberal and libertarian-minded conservatives are on the same page. "It's perfectly possible for a country to become more conservative about economic policy and more liberal on issues affecting personal liberty," Galston said. "I just described libertarianism to you."

Title: Four Key Insights from New Hampshire Primary Elections

Article:

The New Hampshire primary elections took place on Tuesday, providing valuable insights into the ongoing U.S. presidential race. Here are four significant takeaways from the first-in-the-nation primary:

1. The impact of Marco Rubio's debate performance:
Marco Rubio entered New Hampshire with a strong momentum, moving into second place in the polls. However, his performance during the ABC debate on Saturday was criticized, potentially damaging his campaign. Rubio's campaign has since downplayed the debate's impact, lowering expectations. The results of the New Hampshire primary will reveal the extent of the damage to Rubio's campaign following his debate performance.

2. Hillary Clinton's expected margin of victory over Bernie Sanders:
Clinton's narrow victory in Iowa provided her no momentum in New Hampshire. A significant win for Sanders in New Hampshire could boost his campaign ahead of the Nevada caucuses, where the Clinton campaign is relying on its union-based support. A close race between Clinton and Sanders in New Hampshire would indicate Clinton's ability to maintain her campaign, while a double-digit win for Sanders would suggest a strong momentum for his campaign.

3. The potential shrinkage of the GOP field:
Before the primary, it was expected that the Republican field would consist of three candidates post-New Hampshire: Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio. However, the results of the New Hampshire primary could determine whether one or more governors place in the top three or four, potentially leading them to continue their campaigns until the South Carolina primary.

4. The fate of candidates with lower polling numbers:
Ohio Governor John Kasich, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie have all stated their intentions to continue to South Carolina. However, if they do not place in the top tier, their fundraising could dwindle, and there may be pressure on them to withdraw from the race. The New Hampshire primary results will determine the extent to which the GOP field will be reduced.

Title: Trump Delays Immigration Overhaul Vote, Citing Need for More Congressional Seats

Article:

WASHINGTON—President Donald Trump has advised Republicans to postpone an immigration overhaul until after the November midterm elections, effectively delaying a House bill that was initially scheduled for next week.

In a tweet on Friday, President Trump stated, "Republicans should stop wasting their time on Immigration until after we elect more Senators and Congressmen/women in November." He further added, "Dems are just playing games, have no intention of doing anything that solves this decades-old problem. We can pass great legislation after the Red Wave!"

Currently, Republicans hold majorities of 51-49 in the Senate and 235-193 in the House. Some election watchers predict Democrats may gain seats in the House in the midterm elections this fall, potentially regaining majority control.

Despite the flagging support for the effort, Rep. Patrick McHenry (R-NC), the chief deputy whip, stated on Friday that the planned immigration vote will move ahead. He cited party leaders' promise to GOP moderates.

Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) had agreed to hold a vote on what Republicans called a compromise bill to head off a special maneuver called a discharge petition that would have allowed centrist Republicans to join with Democrats to bring their own immigration bills to the floor.

"There’s no significant dynamic shift in our conference on immigration," Mr. McHenry said when asked if there was sufficient support to pass the consensus bill. He added, "The president is speaking truth. If you want to fix immigration crisis in a holistic way, you’re going to need Democrats to participate in this process."

Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-CA), the Democratic leader, has rejected labeling the bill a compromise, stating its provisions on Dreamers—young immigrants brought to the country as minors and living in the U.S. without authorization—and the zero-tolerance policy of charging adult illegal immigrants are too harsh for her party to accept. No Democrats were expected to support the measure.

House Republican leaders had seen President Trump's salesmanship as essential to pushing an immigration plan through the House. The Republican president's position on the compromise bill has shifted several times over the past week, first rejecting it, then supporting it, and now suggesting it should be put off until after the November election.

President Trump also changed a policy this week that resulted in thousands of children being separated from their parents at the border. He issued an executive order that keeps his zero-tolerance stance on arresting illegal border crossers in place but directs that families be kept together.

The president's support of the compromise bill had given some Republicans political cover, particularly from conservative critics who charged that granting protected status to young immigrants amounted to amnesty. With that support now gone, the bill's future is more in doubt.

"I would say his tweet doesn't help," said Rep. Don Bacon (R-NE) who is supporting the compromise bill. "I just feel like this is an opportunity to get something done and I feel like we owe it to do our part in the House."

Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-TX) said the president was under pressure to back the compromise bill to bring hard-line immigration conservatives like himself on board and was glad to see Mr. Trump push back.

"The president realized that this is not a bill that we ought to be dying on because it’s time to move on. We’ll get a better bill later," he said.

The compromise immigration bill would provide $23.4 billion for border security—including a wall and surveillance technology—and would cut family-based immigration and eliminate a diversity-visa lottery program. It would also provide six years of legal status to the young immigrants.

The vote on that plan was delayed on Thursday after rank-and-file House Republicans pressed leaders to make additional changes to the measure. Some conservatives complained that the compromise omitted a requirement that employers use the E-Verify system to check workers' immigration status, while other lawmakers wanted reassurances on how the legislation addressed the parents of Dreamers.

Several Senate Republicans have introduced their own, narrow, legislation that focuses on how asylum cases are handled at the border. That bill would codify President Trump's zero-tolerance policy for border crossers and keep families seeking asylum united in detention centers. It would authorize 225 new immigration judges and require the Department of Homeland Security to prioritize resolving family cases. Sens. Ted Cruz (R-TX) and Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) are also working on bipartisan legislation.

Title: "Dennis Prager Challenges Leftist Belief of Conservative Racism with Three Questions"

Article:

In a recent column, conservative talk-show host and columnist Dennis Prager questions the labeling of Trump supporters and conservatives as "racist" by leftists. Prager argues that this label is a "big lie" and presents a challenge to leftists by asking three questions designed to demonstrate the fallacy of this label.

Prager's questions are:
1. Do you have more in common with, and are you personally more comfortable in the company of, a white leftist or a black conservative?
2. Would you rather have nine white leftists or nine black conservatives on the U.S. Supreme Court?
3. Would you rather your child marry a black Christian conservative or a white non-Christian liberal?

Prager claims that he has asked these questions of thousands of Trump supporters and has never received answers indicating a preference for white over black, or for a white liberal Supreme Court over a black conservative one. He suggests that these questions can help conservatives come to see the left's charge of conservative racism as a lie, in the same way that the blood libel charge against Jews was a lie.

Prager concludes by stating that conservatives know their responses to these questions are heartfelt and true, and that these questions can help conservatives see the left's charge of conservative racism as a lie. He also notes that his latest book, "The Rational Bible," is a commentary on the book of Exodus, and that he may be contacted at dennisprager.com.

Title: Trump Reverses Campaign Pledge, Says He Will Not Pursue Prosecution of Hillary Clinton

Article:

During the presidential campaign, President-elect Donald Trump pledged to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Hillary Clinton and joined crowds of his supporters in chants of "lock her up!" and said to her face during a debate that if he were president, "you'd be in jail." However, now that he will be president, Trump has stated he will not recommend prosecution of Clinton, who he told New York Times reporters has "suffered greatly."

In a meeting between the President-elect and reporters and editors at the paper, Trump said, "I do not want to hurt the Clintons. I really do not. She went through a lot and suffered greatly in many different ways."

The about-face on his formal rival and the suggestion that the Trump administration will not pursue further investigations of Clinton related to her private email server or the Clinton Foundation first came Tuesday morning from Trump's former campaign manager Kellyanne Conway.

Conway said Clinton "still has to face the fact that a majority of Americans do not find her to be honest or trustworthy," but added that "if Donald Trump can help her heal, then perhaps that's a good thing to do."

Steve Vladeck, CNN legal contributor and professor at the University of Texas School of Law, said it was unusual for a President-elect to take such a public position on whether to pursue an investigation.

"Even though the attorney general reports to the president, the Department of Justice is meant to exercise a degree of independence from the White House entirely to avoid the perception that political considerations, rather than legal ones, are behind decisions to (or not) prosecute," Vladeck said in an email. "Indeed, we've seen plenty of scandals throughout American history in which presidents have wrongly politicized the Justice Department's role, and President-Elect Trump's comments do not exactly augur well for preservation of the line between law and politics over the next four years."

Despite Trump breaking a campaign promise to some of the most fervent anti-Clinton supporters, Democrats also took issue with the decision as a sign of the President-elect's executive overreach.

"That's not how this works. In our democracy, the President does not decide who gets prosecuted and who does not," Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut wrote on Twitter.

During Trump's election fight with Clinton, chants of "lock her up" - referring to Clinton - became a refrain of the Republican's campaign, as he hammered the Democratic presidential nominee over her decision to use a private email server as secretary of state, and lobbed accusations of corruption and "pay to play" politics at the Clinton Foundation. Trump's choice for national security advisor, Michael Flynn, also led a high-profile chant at the Republican National Convention of "lock her up."

Trump repeatedly brought up jailing Clinton on his own, often at raucous campaign rallies over the summer and into the fall. However, in interviews with the Wall Street Journal and CBS' "60 Minutes" after the election, Trump refused to say if he would fulfill that commitment to appoint a special prosecutor.

"I'm going to think about it," he told "60 Minutes." "I feel I want to focus on jobs. I want to focus on health care, I want to focus on the border and immigration and doing a really great immigration bill. And I want to focus on -- all of these other things that we've been talking about." He told the program she "did some bad things" but added the Clintons are "good people."

Title: San Francisco Mayor Edwin Lee Dies at 65

Article:

San Francisco Mayor Edwin Lee, the city's first Asian-American mayor, passed away early Tuesday at a city hospital at the age of 65, his office announced. Lee had suffered a heart attack while shopping at a Safeway grocery store on Monday night, according to US House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who represents San Francisco in Congress.

Lee's office did not release his cause of death. London Breed, president of San Francisco's Board of Supervisors, became acting mayor upon Lee's death, the mayor's office said, citing succession rules in the city's charter. Breed is the city's first black female chief executive.

Board of Supervisors President London Breed has become acting mayor.

"Our mayor was a good man with a good heart," Breed said Tuesday morning. "He believed above all else in building bridges and solving problems."

Lee had been expected to conduct meetings Tuesday at City Hall, according to his official schedule. On Monday, he attended a city event promoting a recycling program and was seen smiling and shaking hands, CNN affiliate KGO reported.

Born in Seattle and the son of Chinese immigrants, Lee graduated from Maine's Bowdoin College in 1974 and earned his law degree at the University of California, Berkeley, in 1978. After becoming a civil rights attorney, he began decades of work in city government in the late 1980s, when he was named investigator for the city's first whistleblower's ordinance.

Serving under four mayors, he would become human rights commission director, city purchaser, and public works director. In 2011, the Board of Supervisors appointed Lee, then the city administrator, to fill the rest of the term of Mayor Gavin Newsom, who left to become California's lieutenant governor. Lee was elected to his own term later in 2011 and re-elected in 2015 as mayor of the consolidated city-county government.

Lee unabashedly trumpeted San Francisco as a sanctuary city for undocumented immigrants and opposed President Donald Trump's executive order aimed at stripping such cities of federal funding. After a US district court judge blocked the order in November, Lee issued a statement saying the city was "vindicated once again," and that San Francisco "is proud to be a sanctuary city today, tomorrow, and always."

Pelosi told CNN on Tuesday that Lee was a "man of the people," and that his death was heartbreaking.

"All who knew Mayor Lee understood him as a true gentleman of great warmth, positivity, and kindness," Pelosi said in an official statement. "His passing is not only a tragic official loss for our city but also a profound personal loss for all who were fortunate enough to call him friend."

Laurence M. Baer, the CEO of the San Francisco Giants, saluted Lee's service and called him the professional baseball team's top fan.

"He was a true San Franciscan who devoted his life to serving our great city and to supporting those most in need," Baer said. "He was the Giants' No. 1 fan, and we are blessed to have shared so many wonderful memories together."

Voters will elect someone to fill the rest of Lee's term on June 5, City Attorney Dennis Herrera said. The term expires January 8, 2020. Until the vote, Breed would remain acting mayor unless the board of supervisors decides to replace her with an interim mayor, Herrera said. Breed still retains the board presidency, Herrera said. The board does not have to replace Breed as acting mayor, and the panel had no plans to address the matter on Tuesday, Herrera said.

Title: State Department Delays Release of Hillary Clinton's Daily Meeting Schedules Until After the Election

Article:

The State Department has announced that it will not release all of Hillary Clinton's daily meeting schedules from her tenure as Secretary of State by the time of the upcoming election. According to the Associated Press (AP), the State Department lawyers have stated that all the schedules will be released by December 30 of this year, but this is more than a month after the country decides upon its next leader.

The schedules have been in the news this week following the AP's analysis of the available data, which found that most of the meetings with private individuals in the sample involved people who had in some way contributed to the Clinton Foundation. The AP, which initially requested the schedules in 2010 and again in 2013, and then sued the State Department to obtain them, has been criticized by media reporters for publishing its report based on a small data set. The AP analyzed only those meetings with individuals outside the government.

Hillary Clinton has responded to the AP's analysis, stating that the meetings were with people she would be proud to meet with to discuss their work and insights. Clinton also noted that whether or not these individuals were going to give money was not a factor in her decision to meet with them. Clinton's campaign spokesman, Brian Fallon, criticized the AP for only looking at "a limited subset" of the data, arguing that the analysis is flawed because it does not consider the full picture.

Jason Miller, a spokesman for the Trump campaign, released a statement on Friday, stating, "It is unacceptable that the State Department is now refusing to release her official schedule before the election in full. Voters deserve to know the truth before they cast their ballots."

According to the Clinton Foundation's official website, the charity "convenes businesses, governments, NGOs, and individuals to improve global health and wellness, increase opportunity for girls and women, reduce childhood obesity, create economic opportunity and growth, and help communities address the effects of climate change." Bill Clinton stated last week that if Hillary is elected president, the foundation will stop accepting foreign or corporate donations.

Title: Treasury Department Warns of Debt Ceiling Hit in Mid-October

Article:

The Treasury Department has announced that it will reach the debt ceiling in the middle of October, marking the end of various short-term deals on the legal debt limit that have been extended since the significant debt ceiling fight in 2011. In a letter to Speaker John Boehner, Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew stated that the government is running out of accounting maneuvers to avoid hitting the borrowing limit. He urged Congress to act promptly to enable the Treasury to continue paying the government's bills.

Lew warned that it is impossible to predict the exact date when the borrowing limit will be reached, but he cautioned that if action is not taken soon, the government could be left with approximately $50 billion in cash by mid-October. This amount would not be sufficient to cover Social Security payments, military personnel salaries, Medicare, and other programs for an "extended period."

The Bipartisan Policy Center, after the last short-term debt ceiling deal, predicted a similar scenario. Forecasting government cash flows is inherently uncertain, especially many months in advance. Unexpected changes in economic conditions or policy changes could affect the estimate. One unknown factor is whether Freddie Mac will release its $30 billion deferred tax asset, which would result in a larger-than-usual dividend payment to the U.S. Treasury by September 30. However, a $30 billion increase in federal revenues would not be enough to change the BPC's projected "X-Date" window.

House Speaker John Boehner has signaled a willingness to use the debt ceiling as a negotiating tool for spending cuts, potentially in the mold of a "grand bargain" with the White House. President Obama, on the other hand, has repeatedly stated, "We are not negotiating on the debt ceiling."

In a possible indication that Republicans may not be as serious about trying to extract concessions from Democrats on the debt ceiling, the significant push to defund Obamacare is being tied to a budget resolution rather than the debt ceiling. In general, the debt ceiling is not a matter to be taken lightly - while it is not true that the government would default if we hit the debt ceiling, markets would react as if we did.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Cases on Defunding Planned Parenthood

Article:

The Supreme Court declined on Monday to consider efforts by Republican-led states to defund Planned Parenthood, allowing federal appeals court rulings that allowed the reproductive health organization's patients to contest laws in Louisiana and Kansas that stripped its Medicaid funds.

The court's refusal to hear the case represents a setback for conservative interest groups in many states that have sought aggressive action against Planned Parenthood and abortion providers in general. Three of the court's conservatives – Associate Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, and Neil Gorsuch – dissented and said the court should have taken up the issue.

Associate Justice John Roberts and new Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh did not join the dissent. In a statement, Justice Thomas questioned the court's decision, stating, "I suspect it has something to do with the fact that some respondents in these cases are named 'Planned Parenthood.' That makes the court's decision particularly troubling, as the question presented has nothing to do with abortion."

Similar defunding efforts have been blocked in Arizona and Indiana and are being contested in Ohio and Texas. Only in Arkansas has a federal court allowed the state to deny funds. The laws were passed by state legislatures opposed to Planned Parenthood's provision of abortions. Abortions are already denied federal Medicaid funds. The laws blocked funding for other services, from contraception to cancer screenings.

The federal Medicaid Act allows patients to seek out any qualified provider – the key word being "qualified." Louisiana and Kansas sought to block Planned Parenthood's funding based on a variety of allegations, including disputed claims that the group sold fetal tissue and body parts for profit.

Opponents of abortion rights expressed disappointment at the high court's inaction, but noted that other cases are percolating in lower courts that could give the justices another chance. Catherine Glenn Foster, president of Americans United for Life, said the group "will continue to fight to protect states from being forced to use their limited public funds to subsidize abortion businesses."

Dr. Leana Wen, president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, hailed the court's decision to leave lower court rulings alone. "As a doctor, I have seen what's at stake when people can not access the care they need and when politics gets in the way of people making their own health care choices," Wen said.

The Supreme Court has upheld abortion rights in a series of decisions dating back to 1973. Its most recent ruling struck down restrictions on abortion clinics and providers in Texas two years ago. Planned Parenthood is the nation's largest provider of abortions. More than 2 million women use its clinics for a variety of reproductive services, including many on Medicaid. More than 70 million people – 1 in 5 Americans – are enrolled in Medicaid.

Title: New Inflammatory Syndrome Affecting Children Emerges Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

A mysterious inflammatory disease, resembling Kawasaki syndrome, has emerged in children, primarily in the United States' coronavirus epicenter, New York. The illness, now known as pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome, shares common symptoms with Kawasaki syndrome, such as prolonged fever, a rash, conjunctivitis, swelling of the palms or soles of the feet, sometimes peeling of the skin in those areas, and lymph node enlargement.

During a Senate hearing on Tuesday, Dr. Anthony Fauci, a member of the White House coronavirus task force, warned against rushing to reopen schools in the fall, citing the potential risks of this new illness. He stated that some children with COVID-19 have developed this strange inflammatory syndrome.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo reported that the state is investigating about 100 possible cases of the new disease, which has resulted in at least three deaths. The illness has also been detected in Los Angeles, the San Francisco Bay Area, Chicago, Britain, and Spain.

Dr. Charles Schleien, chair of pediatrics at Northwell Health in New York, reported that his hospital has seen about 40 cases since mid-April, with the majority showing antibodies similar to the coronavirus, indicating they had been infected but had no symptoms of COVID-19. Several others tested positive for the virus and did not exhibit symptoms either.

Though a causal connection between the virus and the new illness has yet to be proven, Schleien stated, "The relationship seems pretty strong." He added, "We never see these many kids with Kawasaki. Usually, we'll see a few kids a year. We won't see three dozen over a period of a few weeks. So, given the numbers and given the fact it's not acting exactly like Kawasaki, it looks like it's probably a post-COVID-19 infection inflammatory disease."

One difference from Kawasaki, which typically affects children under 5 years old, is the age range for this disease, which extends into adolescence. Schleien reported seeing cases in minors as old as 14.

The good news is that, like Kawasaki disease, almost all the kids are treatable, usually with intravenous immunoglobulin and sometimes steroids, followed by aspirin. Hospital stays for patients may last two to four days. Parents are advised to check with a physician or take their children to an emergency room if their fever persists for more than two to three days, especially if some of the other symptoms appear, including a rapid heartbeat.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is studying the rare disease and does not have statistics about its incidence. The CDC plans to send out an alert in the next couple of days, asking doctors to be on the lookout for the syndrome.

Researchers from the U.K., where a few dozen cases of the syndrome have been reported, participated in a webinar discussing the case. They noted that children who had COVID-19 symptoms did not show signs of the new disease. However, children who remained asymptomatic despite being in a family with several infected and sick members developed the inflammatory response a week or two later.

Dr. Yvonne Maldonado, a professor of pediatric infectious diseases at Stanford University, hosted a webinar addressing the case on Friday as scientists try to find out whether the virus precipitates the syndrome. Maldonado stated, "The question is, will this be something to look out for in children over time? It may be that it's another inflammatory reaction, like we're seeing in adults who have inflammation of their lungs. It seems like this virus triggers in some people a really intense inflammatory response."

Maldonado emphasized the rarity of the syndrome and the importance of practicing social distancing and encouraging it on children. She also reminded parents that the syndrome is real and not a made-up disease.

Title: Senate Silences Elizabeth Warren During Debate on Jeff Sessions' Nomination

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, the United States Senate, primarily Republicans, silenced Senator Elizabeth Warren during a debate on the nomination of Jeff Sessions as Attorney General. The incident occurred when Warren read a letter written by Coretta Scott King, the widow of Martin Luther King Jr., opposing Sessions' nomination for a federal judgeship in 1986.

The incident took place during a debate on Sessions' nomination, which is expected to be confirmed in a vote on Wednesday. Warren, a vocal critic of President Donald Trump, read from King's letter to the Senate Judiciary Committee, stating, "Mr. Sessions has used the awesome power of his office to chill the free exercise of the vote by black citizens in the district he now seeks to serve as a federal judge."

Republicans accused Warren of violating Senate rules against impugning another senator. A vote along party lines upheld the decision, turning what could have been an ordinary partisan floor speech into a national story. Warren later told CNN's Don Lemon, "They can shut me up, but they can't change the truth."

The incident immediately galvanized the Democratic base, providing a new rallying point following the women's marches around the country. The silencing of Warren, who was attempting to read a letter from a civil rights icon, was seen as a hypocritical move by some, as her male colleagues were able to read from the letter uninterrupted. Senators Tom Udall of New Mexico and Jeff Merkley were allowed to read from King's letter, though they couched their remarks as only reading portions of the letter and with the context to be in line with Senate rules.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell defended invoking Rule 19, a rarely used chamber regulation that prohibits senators from impugning each other. Warren is now forbidden from participating in the floor debate over Sessions' nomination.

The incident comes at a crucial time for Warren, who is up for re-election in 2018. On Tuesday, she announced she hired an aide who is an expert on national security, a move that could help burnish her expertise in that area, as well as the publication of a new book, which will become available in April.

Liberals had been frustrated with Warren's vote in committee in favor of Ben Carson, Trump's nominee for secretary of Housing and Urban Development. By Tuesday night, the hashtag #LetLizSpeak was trending on Twitter, and millions of people had watched on Facebook as Warren read the letter outside the Senate chamber. MoveOn members contributed $250,000 to Warren's re-election campaign in about 12 hours.

Warren took to social media to express her frustration, writing, "I will not be silent about a nominee for AG who has made derogatory & racist comments that have no place in our justice system." In a follow-up tweet, she said, "I will not be silent while the Republicans rubber stamp an AG who will never stand up to the @POTUS when he breaks the law."

The incident has become a rallying cry for fellow Democrats, with Senators Kamala Harris, Patrick Leahy, and Chuck Schumer speaking out against the decision to silence Warren. The Senate has descended into a series of complaints about declining decorum on both sides.

Title: Henry Kissinger Expresses Optimism for Trump's Foreign Policy Opportunities

Article:

Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, who served under Presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford, has expressed optimism about President-elect Donald Trump's potential influence on the international community. In an interview on "Face the Nation," Kissinger stated that Trump's presidency could present an "extraordinary opportunity" for the nation and its foreign relations.

Kissinger acknowledged that Trump's unconventional rhetoric and lack of political experience raised concerns during his campaign. However, he commended Trump for his ability to navigate the political landscape and secure the presidency despite opposition from his own party.

"In the first appearances, I thought it was a transitory phenomenon," Kissinger said. "But I give him huge credit for having analyzed an aspect of the American situation, developed a strategy, carried it out against the leadership of his own party, and prevailed."

Kissinger believes that Trump could apply the same skills he used to win the presidency to shape a foreign policy plan. He noted that Trump's unexpected victory and the subsequent transition period have created a "partial vacuum" and "new questions" that could lead to "something remarkable and new" in international relations.

However, Kissinger also expressed hope that Trump would modify his tone, particularly when addressing complex issues like the relationship between the U.S. and China, which he believes has the potential to be mutually beneficial if managed properly.

"I think he operates by a kind of instinct that is a different form of analysis as my more academic one," Kissinger said. "But he's raised a number of issues that I think are important, very important. And if they're addressed properly, could lead to good — great results."

The international community is now grappling with the reality of Trump as the world leader, as many nations reassess their relationships in light of his unconventional approach and policies. Kissinger's comments suggest that the Trump administration's foreign policy could deviate significantly from previous administrations, potentially leading to new and unprecedented developments in international relations.

Title: RNC Chairman Threatens Non-Supportive Republicans with Potential Party Consequences

Article:

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus has threatened Republican politicians who refuse to support the party's presidential nominee, Donald Trump, suggesting that the party may take steps to impede their future electoral prospects. In an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation," Mr. Priebus stated that every Republican who ran in the 2016 election needs to back Mr. Trump.

Those who have not, including Ohio Governor John Kasich, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, and Texas Senator Ted Cruz, could face diminished support from the party moving forward, according to Mr. Priebus.

"People who agreed to support the nominee, that took part in our process, they used tools from the RNC. They agreed to support the nominee. They took part in our process. We’re a private party, we’re not a public entity. Those people need to get on board," Mr. Priebus said.

"And if they’re thinking they’re going to run again someday, I think we’re going to evaluate our process, the nomination process, and I don’t think it’s going to be that easy for them," he added.

Governor Kasich has stated it is "very unlikely" he will vote for Mr. Trump, while former Governor Bush and Senator Cruz have expressed similar sentiments. Mr. Cruz notably withheld an endorsement of Mr. Trump during the Republican National Convention and instead urged Republicans to "vote their conscience" in November.

Mr. Priebus denied that he was threatening Mr. Kasich, Mr. Cruz, or anyone else, yet he clearly suggested the party would put roadblocks in front of the electoral hopes of anyone who hasn't offered a full-throated endorsement of Mr. Trump.

"People in our party are talking about what we’re going to do about this... It’s not a threat. It’s just a question," the RNC chairman said. "What should a private party do about that if those same people come around in four or eight years?"

Governor Kasich, a former 2016 GOP presidential candidate himself, emphasized the importance of getting out the vote for Republicans like Senator Rob Portman, who is running for re-election in Ohio.

"We want to get people out to vote. We want to re-elect Senator Portman, and we want to re-elect people down ticket," Mr. Kasich said. "I’m not voting for Hillary [Clinton]."

"I’ll let everybody know... but I think my actions have spoken very loudly. Louder than even my words," he added.

Governor Kasich was in Cleveland during the Republican National Convention in July but did not attend the convention itself. When asked about Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson, Mr. Kasich said, "I haven’t even gone there yet. It’s a long way [until] Election Day."

Title: Trump Claims "Total and Complete Vindication" Following Comey's Testimony, Accuses Former FBI Director of Lying and Leaking

Article:

President Donald Trump broke his silence on Friday regarding former FBI Director James Comey's testimony before Congress, claiming "total and complete vindication" while appearing to accuse Comey of lying and labeling him a "leaker."

"Despite so many false statements and lies, total and complete vindication... and WOW, Comey is a leaker!" Trump wrote on Twitter just after 6 a.m. on Friday.

The accusation, essentially alleging that Comey committed perjury in his congressional testimony, is just the latest broadside Trump has launched against his former FBI director. However, it is not expected to be the last.

The tweet also raised eyebrows in the White House, with at least two senior White House aides expressing surprise Friday morning at the president's missive slamming Comey.

The president's tweet is just one part of the counteroffensive against Comey. A person close to Trump's outside legal team confirmed on Friday that it will aim to file a complaint next week with the Department of Justice inspector general about the so-called leak, in which Comey handed off memos describing his conversations with Trump to a friend who in turn passed them onto The New York Times.

Trump's lawyer, Marc Kasowitz, was immediately criticized for the move, which followed a bellicose statement on Thursday in which Kasowitz, too, accused Comey of lying under oath and inappropriately disclosing the contents of his conversations with Trump.

"This is an abuse of process & we will be filing a defense of Comey. @marckasowitz beware: there r serious consequences for abuse of process," former Obama ethics adviser Norm Eisen wrote on Twitter Friday.

Trump, however, has a long history of threatening legal action but failing to follow through.

The president on Thursday managed to stay quiet on Twitter throughout Comey's testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee, in which the former director himself accused the president of lying and told lawmakers that it was "the nature of the person" he was dealing with that compelled him to take copious, contemporaneous notes to protect against the possibility that Trump might later "lie about the nature of our meeting."

And while Comey did verify Trump's past statement that he assured the president he was not personally under investigation, what Comey provided Trump was far from "complete vindication."

Comey, while declining to directly say whether he thought Trump tried to obstruct justice, nevertheless testified that he believed Trump directed him to shut down a probe into former national security adviser Michael Flynn and fired him with the intent of changing the course of the larger Russia investigation.

Trump's team has been quick to push back, and a main thrust of their strategy is to discredit Comey, painting him as disgruntled and untrustworthy. The process began with an RNC-coordinated counter-messaging effort, and was followed by Kasowitz's prepared statement at the National Press Club, near the White House.

The president upped the ante on Friday morning with his tweet. However, the defense of Trump has been inconsistent. While Trump and Kasowitz have directly refuted the substance of Comey's accounts, many of Trump's fellow Republicans sought to frame it as a misinterpretation by Comey rather than a total fabrication.

"The president's new at this. He's new at government," House Speaker Paul Ryan said on Thursday. "He's not steeped in the long-running protocols that establish the relationships between DOJ, FBI and White Houses."

New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, a staunch Trump ally, defended Trump by saying the Flynn discussion was "normal New York City conversation."

Trump's allies are also eager to shift the conversation to Comey's conduct. While White House officials were largely absent from the morning TV news circuit, former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski made the president's case in three separate appearances on ABC, NBC, and Fox News. Lewandowski worked to thread a difficult needle, emphasizing Comey's statement that Trump had never been under investigation while at the same time calling into question the FBI director's credibility to dispute other portions of his testimony.

Lewandowski criticized Comey for relaying his notes from meetings with the president to the media through an intermediary, suggesting that the former director should be prosecuted if such a move was part of a regular pattern of behavior. Lewandowski also mocked Comey, telling NBC's "Today" show that the former director had used a go-between to share his memos "because he was not man enough to give the notes directly to the media when he wanted them out to the media."

And while Trump has suggested that he might be in possession of recordings of his meetings with Comey—recordings that the former director said Thursday he would like the president to release if they exist—Lewandowski said he did not know if such tapes exist because he does not work in the White House. Regardless, he said on NBC, "I think Jim Comey's credibility is at about zero right now."

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, appearing on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," said the president's behavior with Comey was "certainly inappropriate" and "an abuse of power" but she stopped short of discussing impeachment, a topic she said she has urged her Democratic colleagues to approach carefully and only if they have the facts behind them.

"In terms of obstruction of justice, I think there's reason to believe and Mueller should look into this," she said. "It's certainly, in the court of public opinion, very incriminating."

Trump is also expected to address the controversy further when he holds a joint news conference with the president of Romania on Friday afternoon in the Rose Garden.

Title: ISIS Takes Control of Ramadi, Highlighting Weakness of Iraqi Military and Dependence on Allies

Article:

In a significant development, ISIS forces have taken control of the Iraqi city of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar province, marking the biggest victory for the militant group in Iraq in nearly a year. The fall of Ramadi underscores the fundamental weakness of the Iraqi military and its deep reliance on radical Shia militias.

The city's loss to ISIS is noteworthy beyond just Ramadi. The militant group has been unusually successful in Anbar province, a predominantly Sunni region, where it has blocked Iraqi army attacks and at times advanced despite setbacks in other parts of the country. The balance in Anbar has been shifting in favor of ISIS, as the fall of Ramadi demonstrates.

The Iraqi military contingent in Ramadi has been under-resourced for over a year. As reported by Liz Sly, the Washington Post's Beirut bureau chief, Iraqi troops had held out in Ramadi for 16 months with little help before succumbing. The Iraqi army's core problem lies in its profound weakness due to corruption and mass defections during last June's ISIS offensive. It lacks enough effective, battle-hardened units to take on ISIS independently.

Even an Iraqi elite special forces unit, the Golden Division, was defeated in Ramadi because it is "a small force stretched over a dozen battlefields, fighting nonstop for a year," according to Michael Knights, the Lafer fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.

This fundamental weakness forces the Iraqi army to rely on allies, such as the Kurdish peshmerga in the north and violent sectarian Shia militias in the rest of the country. Together, their combined forces are stronger than ISIS, with both the Kurds and the militias proving effective against ISIS on the battlefield. However, the factions are also at odds with one another.

ISIS's victory in Ramadi did not change the fundamentals of the conflict. ISIS remains outnumbered, surrounded by enemies, vulnerable to American airstrikes, and facing increasingly competent enemies. The anti-ISIS campaign will likely have more setbacks, and the fighting will continue to devastate Iraq and potentially deepen the Sunni-Shia divides that gave rise to ISIS in the first place. Even with ISIS's fundamental weakness, Iraq remains in a very bad place.

Title: Private Prison Companies See Profit in Trump's Immigration Policies

Article:

The Trump administration has announced plans to expand the capacity of immigrant detention centers in the United States, potentially leading to a need for additional facilities if the administration intends to carry out its proposed mass deportation of millions of undocumented residents. This development has sparked nationwide outrage among many, but one group seemingly welcoming the expansion is private prison companies.

As of November, approximately 65% of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detainees are housed in facilities operated by private prison companies. These corporations typically earn a fee per detainee per night, and their business model relies on minimizing costs to maximize profits for their shareholders. Since President Trump's election, private prison stocks have surged, and two new for-profit detention centers are set to open in Georgia and Texas.

Moreover, a private prison company, Management & Training Corp., is reportedly seeking a contract with ICE to reopen the Willacy County Correctional Institution, a troubled detention camp that housed up to 2,000 ICE detainees in Kevlar tents between 2006 and 2011. According to George Takei, a well-known activist, "Historically, ICE has relied heavily on the private prison industry every time the detention system has expanded. There's little doubt in my mind that they will continue to rely on the private prison industry in what's going to be the biggest expansion of the agency in history."

The expansion of private detention facilities under the Trump administration could potentially lead to increased profits, with the more aggressive the administration's immigration policies, the larger the detention centers may become. It is important to note that running a private prison company is not focused on providing humane conditions. While those being rounded up may be guilty of overstaying their visas or similar offenses, they may find themselves in private detention facilities that have been terminated by other federal agencies due to patterns of abuse and neglect in the past.

Title: Scalia Criticizes Obama's Immigration Policies, Questions Framers' Response

Article:

Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia suggested on Monday that the Framers of the U.S. Constitution would have reacted negatively to President Barack Obama's recent decision not to enforce certain immigration laws. In a dissenting opinion on the court's ruling on Arizona's SB 1070 immigration law, Scalia criticized the Obama administration's new policy of ending deportations for many young adults who entered the country illegally.

Scalia questioned whether states would have joined the union if the Constitution included a clause enacting immigration laws but allowed the president to choose whether to enforce them. He suggested that the Framers would have left Independence Hall if presented with such a clause.

Scalia argued that Arizona, by passing a state immigration law, was protecting its sovereignty, not contradicting federal law but complying with it. However, he expressed concern that the court's decision to strike down most of the key provisions of Arizona's SB 1070 immigration law could limit Arizona's ability to enforce immigration laws.

The court upheld a key piece of the Arizona law, requiring police to check the immigration status of those they arrest or stop for questioning, but struck down other pieces of the law, arguing that the state had stepped into the bounds of federal law. Scalia criticized the court's decision, stating that it was illogical for Arizona to be accused of contradicting federal law by enforcing immigration laws that the president declines to enforce.

Scalia also criticized the Obama administration's policies, stating that the problem Arizona faces is not the allocation of resources for enforcing immigration laws elsewhere, but the administration's policies. He expressed concern that the new Department of Homeland Security directives would require as many as 1.4 million background checks and biennial rulings on requests for dispensation, which would consume scarce enforcement resources.

Title: GOP Faces Bitter Choices as September Deadlines Loom

Article:

Republican lawmakers are facing a challenging month as they may be required to vote on two contentious issues by the end of September: a continuing resolution to keep the government open and funded at current spending levels, and a bill to raise the debt ceiling. The debt ceiling increase, another measure that is unpopular among congressional conservatives, is likely to be tied to the continuing resolution.

The government faces a September 30 deadline to prevent a shutdown, while Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has set a September 29 deadline for raising the nation's borrowing limit. Mnuchin has stated that the hike should be "clean," meaning it should not be tied to spending cuts or reforms demanded by conservatives.

To get the bill through the Senate, Republicans will need support from Democrats, giving the minority leverage. Republicans typically oppose funding the government with a continuing resolution because it blocks or postpones their priorities, including funds for President Trump's border wall, significant increases in military spending, and cuts to nondefense discretionary spending.

Republicans could avoid the continuing resolution by reaching a deal on a broader spending bill, but that would also require Democratic support in the Senate, and time is running out. So far, the House has only managed to approve four spending bills, while the Senate has not approved any, and most have not even made it out of committee. This means the continuing resolution is a more likely outcome and one that would buy time for a longer budget deal at the end of the year.

Several prominent conservative leaders have expressed resignation to a continuing resolution as House members began their recess last week. "September is going to be a very difficult month," said Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), the chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus. "I think that there is no way to work quick enough to do a normal appropriations process, so a CR will be the result, because of inactivity in the Senate."

Congress will still be under pressure this fall to secure a spending deal even with a continuing resolution. New budget caps under a previous long-term budget deal are set to kick in in January, which would reduce spending below existing levels unless Congress passes a new law.

Raising the borrowing limit is a difficult vote for most members of Congress, but particularly for Republicans. A Harvard–Harris Poll in June found that an astonishing 69 percent of voters were opposed to Congress raising the debt ceiling, even though the failure to do so could lead the United States to default on its debt. Under former President Barack Obama, conservatives tried to use the must-pass legislation to get spending reforms or other Republican priorities made into law. With Trump in the White House and Republicans controlling both the House and Senate, however, the dynamics have shifted. Democrats may try to turn the tables and extract concessions from Republicans, who will need Democratic support to pass the debt ceiling.

Title: PG&E Initiates Largest Power Outage in California History to Prevent Wildfires

Article:

Hundreds of thousands of residents in California faced a power outage on Wednesday as Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) initiated a series of power cuts to prevent wildfires. The utility company reported that over 500,000 customers in Northern California were affected, with plans to cut power to nearly 800,000 customers in total. A second group of approximately 234,000 customers will lose power starting at noon.

PG&E plans to shut off power in parts of 34 northern, central, and coastal California counties to reduce the risk of trees falling onto power lines during hot, windy weather. Gusts of 56 to 72kph (35-45 mph) are forecast to sweep across the state, affecting areas from the San Francisco Bay area to the agricultural Central Valley and the Sierra Nevada foothills, where a November wildfire in 2018, blamed on PG&E transmission lines, resulted in 85 fatalities and the near-total destruction of the town of Paradise.

The California Department of Forestry and Fire Prevention has increased staffing in preparation for extreme fire weather. The winds are expected to be the strongest and most widespread the region has seen in two years. Given the scope of the danger, PG&E stated that this was a necessary precaution, with Sumeet Singh, head of the utility's Community Wildfire Safety Program, describing it as a "last resort."

However, Governor Gavin Newsom expressed dissatisfaction, stating, "No one is satisfied with this, no one is happy with this." He emphasized the need for PG&E to upgrade and fix its equipment to prevent widespread outages in the future. PG&E estimates that it could take up to five days to restore power after the danger has passed, as every inch of power line must be checked to ensure it is not damaged or in danger of sparking a blaze.

The outages were not limited to fire-prone areas, as the utilities must turn off entire distribution and transmission lines to wider areas to minimize the risk of wildfires. Classes were cancelled for thousands of schoolchildren and at universities such as the University of California, Berkeley, Sonoma State University, and Mills College. The California Department of Transportation is installing generators to avoid closing the Caldecott Tunnel linking the East Bay to San Francisco and the Tom Lantos Tunnel on State Route 1 in Pacifica.

Residents in affected areas are advised to have supplies of water for several days, to keep sensitive medicines such as insulin in cool places, to drive carefully because traffic lights could be out, to have a full gas tank for emergencies, and to check the food in freezers and refrigerators for spoilage after power is restored. PG&E has set up about 30 community centers offering air conditioning, restrooms, bottled water, and electronic charging stations during daylight hours.

East Bay Municipal Utility District, serving Alameda and Contra Costa counties, recently spent $409,000 to rent 29 backup generators for use beginning at noon on Wednesday. The backup generators are stationed at the pumping plants, which pump water to the fire hydrants. Counties have activated their emergency centers, and authorities urge people to be prepared.

Title: Obama's Re-election and the Future of American Politics

Article:

The re-election of President Barack Obama for a second term in the United States has sparked discussions about the nation's political landscape and the role of government in American society. The election results reflect a divided nation, with half of the country supporting Obama's policies and the other half expressing dissent.

Obama's re-election, according to some analysts, is a testament to the historical observation made by Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton that the public may elect leaders who promote dependency over self-reliance when the public treasury is perceived as a public trough. This trend, they argue, has been a feature of American politics since the presidencies of Woodrow Wilson, Theodore Roosevelt, FDR, and LBJ, and is now a common characteristic of both modern-day Democrats and contemporary Republicans.

Mitt Romney, a Republican, is one of those who promised to maintain existing federal entitlements, which currently cost taxpayers approximately $1.7 trillion per year. Under Obama's administration, the costs have increased, as have the number of recipients.

President Obama's second term is expected to bring significant changes, with the implementation of ObamaCare and an increase in the national debt. The federal government's debt is projected to reach $20 trillion, leading to an estimated $1 trillion in annual interest payments if the Republican-controlled House of Representatives continues to support Obama's policies, as it did during his first term. Additionally, the expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts on New Year's Day will result in increased taxes for many Americans.

The election results and the policies that follow have sparked concerns about the future of American politics, with some expressing apprehension about the potential for increased government intervention in private lives and the economy. Critics argue that Obama's policies reflect an expansive view of the federal government, which may lead to the creation of a European-style welfare state and the subordination of the individual to the state at every turn.

In conclusion, the re-election of President Obama for a second term marks a significant shift in the American political landscape, with many anticipating increased government intervention in the economy and personal lives. The election results and the policies that follow have sparked debates about the role of government in American society and the potential for a European-style welfare state.

Title: Wisconsin's Political Dichotomy: A Study of its Schizophrenic Political Personality

Article:

Madison, Wis. — Wisconsin, a state known for its idyllic landscapes between two lakes, has long been a subject of fascination and perplexity for its politically diverse history. The state has been the home of Robert "Fighting Bob" La Follette, a populist senator and Progressive Party presidential candidate in 1924, and Joseph McCarthy, the hard-line conservative senator behind the Communist witch-hunts of the 1950s.

This political disparity is not limited to the past. In 1973, civil rights and anti-Vietnam War activist Paul Soglin, a self-proclaimed "radical" at the time, was elected mayor of Madison. He succeeded William Dyke, an ultra-conservative who was Lester Maddox's running-mate on the American Independent Party's presidential ticket in 1976. Soglin, incidentally, is mayor again today.

The current U.S. senators, Ron Johnson (Republican) and Tammy Baldwin (Democrat), represent the widest ideological gulf of any state's senators, according to a 2013 National Journal ranking of voting records. Baldwin, the Senate's first openly gay member, was listed as the 5th most liberal; Johnson the 9th most conservative.

Rutgers University political science professor Ross Baker observes, "Wisconsin defies political trends. It doesn't swing, it pivots." This political dichotomy is instructive as another native son, Gov. Scott Walker, makes a run for the Republican presidential nomination next year, casting himself as Ronald Reagan's natural heir.

Part of Walker's compelling storyline is his ability to win two elections as governor and survive a recall election in a swing state with such a strong liberal tradition. Wisconsin's electorate has a history of electing liberal politicians, such as William Proxmire, a liberal and early anti-Vietnam war opponent who replaced McCarthy following the Red-baiting senator's death, and Democrat Russ Feingold, the champion of campaign finance changes until he got knocked off by Johnson in 2010.

Michael Wagner, a political science and journalism professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, agrees that the state's politics "look pretty schizophrenic to people on the outside — and the inside, too." Wagner attributes this political polarization to long-standing divisions among voters, with a very small swing vote deciding whether a conservative Republican or liberal Democrat wins.

Like most states, midterm elections favor Republicans because their loyal voters, namely whites, turn out in higher proportions than Democratic voters, mainly minorities who are more likely to show up in presidential years. Wagner notes that Walker and Johnson won their races in midterm election cycles, while Baldwin won in 2012, when President Obama topped the ticket.

Wisconsin is one of the least diverse states in the nation, with whites accounting for 88% of the population. Yet, with such a narrowly divided electorate, that small minority vote—or its absence—can swing an election.

Political scientist Wagner notes that both sides have gotten very good at winning elections. The loser: consensus politics that serve the greater good. "Compromise is not possible with such polarization," he says.

Such a bitter divide means politicians elected to statewide office wind up representing the interests of those that got 'em there, the greater good of the state be damned. This is the chilling takeaway for Washington, and it explains why so little has been accomplished in recent years in the nation's capital. Compromise is a dirty word. It's all about winning, now.

Title: The Lack of Political Guardrails: A Look at the Current Political Landscape

Article:

In a recent article, Kimberley Strassel of The Wall Street Journal highlighted the apparent lack of political guardrails in today's political climate, using the metaphor of physical guardrails on treacherous roads to illustrate the need for constraints on political power.

Strassel's piece points to the actions of prominent politicians, such as former President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, who have bypassed legislative processes to implement their desired policies. Obama, for instance, unilaterally altered the Affordable Care Act, and Clinton has promised to impose gun control laws and new taxes if Congress does not support her proposals.

The public's response to such actions, according to Strassel, is a preference for a strong, decisive leader who will take control and make things better, regardless of constitutional restraints. This trend is also evident in the rise of Donald Trump, whose controversial statements and promises have garnered him support.

However, the article argues that the Constitution was written to limit political authority, with the intention of leaving individual Americans to their own devices and creating a free and prosperous nation. The author expresses concern that both major parties are off the rails, with some Republicans demanding an IRS audit of the Clinton Foundation and Congress quietly reauthorizing the Export-Import Bank, a subsidy for corporations that undermines free-market principles.

The article concludes by lamenting the lack of humble, constitutional candidates and the overshadowing of important government reform by sensational, unconstitutional actions. The author calls for a return to the principles of the Constitution and a focus on constitutional guardrails in politics.

Title: U.S. 2013 Elections: Voters Cite Washington Gridlock as Top Problem

Article:

The 2013 U.S. elections are approaching on Tuesday, with a national survey conducted by the George Washington University Battleground Poll indicating that Washington gridlock is the nation's most pressing problem. The survey, a joint effort by Republican pollster Ed Goeas and Democratic pollster Celinda Lake, was discussed by both strategists at a Monitor-hosted breakfast for reporters on Monday.

Ed Goeas, of the Tarrance Group, a Republican campaign consulting firm, stated that the Battleground survey found that 73 percent of voters believe the country is on the wrong track. Celinda Lake of Lake Research Partners noted that, according to those surveyed, "the No. 1 problem in the country is the dysfunction in Washington." This problem is rated higher now than jobs and the economy combined.

When voters were asked to rate the job Congress is doing, 87 percent said they disapprove versus just 9 percent who approve. Voters also blame their own Congressperson for the gridlock, with 50 percent disapproving of how their own member of Congress is doing versus 39 percent who approved and 11 percent who were unsure.

Republicans in Congress had worse ratings than Democrats, according to the survey. Sixty-five percent of those polled had an unfavorable view of Republicans in Congress, while Democrats were viewed unfavorably by 53 percent. The government shutdown last month played a role in these numbers, both strategists said.

In the poll taken almost a month after a government shutdown largely driven by the demands of tea party activists, only 54 percent of those polled said they had an unfavorable impression of the tea party – 11 points lower than the disapproval level for Republicans and a statistical dead heat with Democrats.

While Republicans in Congress have reason to be concerned about their standing, this latest poll also contains bad news for President Obama. His approval rating now stands at 44 percent, with 52 percent disapproving. Obama's personal ratings are also down, with 47 percent of those surveyed saying they had a favorable view of him and 50 percent holding unfavorable views.

This is the first time in the Battleground survey that Obama has had both a majority unfavorable image and majority disapproval of his job performance, Goeas says. "The key question... is has Barack Obama lost the ability to lead in this country," Goeas stated. Goeas also noted that, in a second term of the White House, once a president's numbers decline, they never come back up, and once a president loses the trust of the American people in the second term, they never gain it back. He suggested that the ongoing health care issues could lead to Obama losing the trust of the American people.

Title: White House and Congress Debate Corporate Tax Rate in Proposed U.S. Tax Overhaul

Article:

Washington, D.C. - President Donald Trump's recent remarks about a potential 22% corporate tax rate in the upcoming tax legislation have sparked debate within the U.S. Congress. The proposed tax bills, passed separately by the Senate and the House of Representatives, aim to reduce the U.S. corporate tax rate to 20%, but differ in other areas that Republicans are trying to merge into final legislation.

On Saturday, after the Senate approved its tax bill, Trump stated that the corporate tax rate in the final legislation "could be 22%...it could also be 20%." This remark has piqued the interest of some Republicans who see a slight increase in the proposed corporate tax rate as a potential source of federal revenue to address other issues within the legislation.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, who is expected to head a bicameral House-Senate negotiating committee, stated, "The 20 percent rate ought to be our goal." However, Brady also noted that no decision has been made on whether a higher corporate tax rate is needed.

White House legislative affairs director Marc Short stated on Thursday that Trump was not expressing support for a higher corporate tax rate. Instead, Short suggested that Trump may have been reflecting conversations he had with Republican senators.

"I think he was just reflecting what conversations he had heard from them, but that... wasn't intended to signal: this is an endorsement of raising the corporate rate," Short said.

The White House and Republicans have a significant stake in the outcome of the tax overhaul, as it has not been achieved since 1986. A successful tax overhaul would provide Republicans with their first major legislative victory of 2017, following their failure to overturn former President Barack Obama's healthcare law. Without a win, Republicans fear they could lose their control of the House and Senate in the 2018 congressional elections.

However, it may be too late to avoid confusion over priorities as the tax debate moves forward in Congress. Lobbyists stated that many perceive that Trump and his advisers would accept a corporate rate higher than 20%.

White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett stated on Thursday that a 22% corporate rate would not undermine the economic boost that Republicans claim tax cuts will create. Analysts suggest that the corporate income tax rate could be a ready source of revenue for lawmakers, as they move toward a final bill that can lose no more than $1.5 trillion in revenue over the next decade under Senate rules.

Republicans are considering a more costly deduction for state and local taxes than the $10,000 property tax deduction contained in the House and Senate bills. One version would allow taxpayers to choose a $10,000 deduction for either property or income taxes.

House lawmakers also want to adopt the House bill's repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax, which would cost about $40 billion in revenue over a decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. The Senate retained the tax.

A House limit on the amount of debt interest payments that businesses can deduct from their income would also cost about $136 billion more than the Senate version, the JCT said. Analysts suggest that a one percentage point change in the corporate rate equals about $100 billion in revenues over a decade.

Title: President Trump Announces Immediate Negotiations on Border Security Measures Following Government Shutdown

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that negotiations with congressional Democrats over border security measures will commence immediately following the end of the longest government shutdown in U.S. history.
