The shutdown, which lasted 35 days, ended on Friday when Trump signed a bill to fund the government until February 15.

In a series of tweets on Saturday, Trump stated, "Negotiations with Democrats will start immediately. Will not be easy to make a deal, both parties very dug in. The case for National Security has been greatly enhanced by what has been happening at the Border & through dialogue. We will build the Wall!"

The president signaled that he plans to use a new caravan of Central American migrants approaching the U.S.-Mexico border as justification for his proposed wall. Trump tweeted, "If we had a powerful Wall, they wouldn’t even try to make the long and dangerous journey. Build the Wall and Crime will Fall!"

Trump had tweeted seven times before 10 a.m. ET, including five times on border security, once on Roger Stone being indicted for lying to Congress, and another on the RNC pledging support for the president in 2020.

Later on Saturday, Trump tweeted, "Only fools, or people with a political agenda, don’t want a Wall or Steel Barrier to protect our Country from Crime, Drugs and Human Trafficking. It will happen - it always does!"

In a tweet late on Friday, the president stated, "I wish people would read or listen to my words on the Border Wall. This was in no way a concession. It was taking care of millions of people who were getting badly hurt by the Shutdown with the understanding that in 21 days, if no deal is done, it’s off to the races!"

Title: Jared Kushner Takes Central Role in White House Coronavirus Response Efforts, Draws Criticism for Lack of Public Health Expertise

Article:

Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, criticized governors on Thursday, stating they lack control over their own supplies of masks and ventilators needed to combat the coronavirus outbreak. In a rare appearance in the White House briefing room, Kushner urged governors and some senators to be more resourceful in their own states instead of relying on the federal government for help.

Kushner, a real estate executive with no public health expertise, generally works behind the scenes at the White House. His role in the administration's efforts to confront the coronavirus pandemic has drawn scrutiny, especially when he referred to the national stockpile of medical supplies as "our stockpile."

Kushner has emerged with a central role working with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to oversee the distribution of vital medical supplies to hospital and health care providers. On Thursday, he explained that Trump and Vice President Mike Pence came to him looking for new ideas and "outside-the-box" thinking.

However, Kushner's lack of experience has drawn scrutiny, especially when he referred to the national stockpile of medical supplies as "our stockpile."

"The notion of the federal stockpile was it's supposed to be our stockpile," he said. "It's not supposed to be states' stockpiles that they then use."

Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, told NPR's Here & Now that she disagreed with Kushner's statement. "That is absolutely not the way it is supposed to work," she said. "The national stockpile was supposed to be a backup for states—and that the Trump administration should have done more to fill it."

A day after Kushner made his remarks, language on a government website about the national stockpile was changed to more closely reflect his description. However, a spokesperson for the Department of Health and Human Services said the department had been using the new language for weeks. The assistant secretary for preparedness and response "first began working to update the website text a week ago to more clearly explain to state and local agencies and members of the public the role of the 'Strategic National Stockpile,'" the spokesperson said.

When asked Friday about his son-in-law's remarks, Trump said Kushner was "talking about our country."

"We need it for the government and the federal government," he said, complaining that state governments should have had their own stockpiles. "The federal government needs it, too, not just the states," he said.

Part of Kushner's strength is his proximity to the president. He has been his father-in-law's point man on issues as diverse as the Middle East peace process, immigration, and now the response to the coronavirus. The real estate developer and scion of the Kushner family, which operates the Kushner Companies, is well-connected—and he's using those connections, working with FEMA and the U.S. military, to get things where they need to be with the response to the outbreak.

As he recounted Thursday, the president had called him earlier that morning about reports he was hearing about critical shortages in the New York public hospital system. Kushner called Dr. Mitchell Katz, who runs the system, asked him which supply was the most critical, and arranged for the necessary supplies to be sent.

However, some experts question Kushner's lack of experience overseeing the response to emergencies of this scale. Craig Fugate, who ran FEMA during the Obama administration, said the federal government can't base decisions on requests. The coronavirus is moving so fast that states can't keep up.

"My experience in disasters is the burn rate is always greater than what anybody anticipates," he said. "And if we had waited for states to identify their needs, we were always behind and not there fast enough."

There are also concerns raised by ethics groups who contend that Kushner's role in the response is akin to overseeing a shadow task force with no oversight. Noah Bookbinder, executive director of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, said in a statement, "If there was ever a time we need records and transparency, this is it. The public needs to understand who in the White House is making policy decisions, who from private industry is influencing those decisions, and how decisions to address this pandemic are being made."

However, Andy Slavitt, the Obama-era administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, calls the current crisis an all-hands-on-deck effort. He appreciates Kushner or anyone else in government sharing their expertise. But he does say roles need to be clear and execution much more coordinated.

"The issue should be, we don't need five generals," he said. "We need somebody in charge." He said the military is best poised to lead that effort.

Title: Obama Meets Orlando Nightclub Shooting Survivors, Urges Gun Control Measures

Article:

President Barack Obama met with survivors of the Orlando nightclub shooting and relatives of the 49 victims on Thursday, expressing his condolences and urging Congress to take action on gun control and countering homegrown terrorism.

During the meeting, Obama laid flowers at a memorial for the victims of the attack on the Pulse nightclub. The shooting, carried out by a U.S.-born gunman, Omar Mateen, on Sunday, is the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history.

Mateen, a U.S. citizen born in New York to Afghan immigrants, was killed by police after a three-hour standoff inside the nightclub. Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, but U.S. officials have stated that Mateen was not assisted from abroad.

According to reports, Mateen exchanged text messages with his wife during the attack, as well as posting on Facebook and placing a phone call to a television station. Mateen's wife, Noor Salman, is currently under investigation to determine whether she had prior knowledge of Mateen's plans.

Obama expressed his frustration over the failure of Congress to pass any gun control measures in over two decades. The massacre has put pressure on Congress to act, and after a series of speeches by Democrats, a Democratic senator stated that Republicans had agreed to hold votes on measures to expand background checks and prevent people on U.S. terrorism watch lists from buying guns.

The attack has sparked a new debate over how the United States responds to Islamist militant violence at home and abroad. Republican Senator John McCain stated that Obama is "directly responsible" for the Orlando attack due to his failure to prevent the rise of Islamic State. McCain later clarified that he was referring to Obama's national security decisions, not the President himself.

Mateen carried out the attack using an assault weapon and handgun that were legally purchased, despite having been investigated by the FBI for possible connections with militant Islamist groups. The attack has reignited the ongoing debate over gun control in the United States.

Wakes were held for at least four victims on Thursday, and more somber events are expected to take place over the following two weeks. Over 300 people, including Florida Governor Rick Scott, attended the viewing for Eric Ortiz-Rivera, one of the victims. Ortiz-Rivera was 36 when he was killed during a night of dancing to celebrate a friend's new house.

Information about Mateen's past, including his school record, is not available in the provided source text. The attack has also led to renewed calls for increased vigilance and security in the United States, particularly in areas with large LGBTQ+ communities.

Title: 113th Congress Shows Signs of Increased Productivity Despite Ongoing Partisan Divide

Article:

The 113th Congress, which began following the 2010 Tea Party wave and ended with President Obama's reelection in 2012, was the least productive session in over 60 years. However, the 113th Congress is showing signs of achieving more legislative accomplishments over the next two years, despite the ongoing partisan rancor.

The year started with a bipartisan group of senior senators preventing a potential "nuclear" showdown over the filibuster, a controversial Senate rule. In March, the long-delayed Violence Against Women Act moved from moribund to becoming law. More recently, House and Senate lawmakers have worked diligently to keep the government funded through the end of the fiscal year, without the protests that have characterized such measures in recent years.

On nearly every major legislative initiative, at least some bipartisan activity is underway, even if it is not yielding everything its sponsors would like. From strengthening firearm controls to immigration reform to renewed discussions of a "grand bargain" on taxes and entitlement programs, Congress is currently active with the possibility of compromise. In other words, the dealmakers are resurfacing.

Many of the obstacles to congressional deal-making have been building for years and are not unique to Washington's current dysfunction. The sharp divide among lawmakers reflects the polarization on a wide range of policy and cultural issues that exists among the voters who sent them there.

The positions are hardened by deep-pocketed advocacy groups with intense ideological focuses and narrow agendas. Such groups make departing from the party line more dangerous than ever. The increasing amount of money needed to run for Congress also means lawmakers spend more time fundraising and less time studying issues or forging relationships with colleagues, the foundation on which deal-making is built.

Complicating the impulse to compromise today is the frequency of "wave" elections. Several electoral drubbings – Democratic triumphs in 2006 and 2008, the Republican resurgence in 2010 – have created cliques of lawmakers with seemingly narrow mandates to an extent rarely seen in US history.

Members elected in such waves "are really not going to make deals that go against what the people who put them there want [ them ] to do," says former Rep. Steven LaTourette (R-OH), a centrist. "On 'Obamacare,' you do not hear a lot of the 2010 class say, 'Well, let's save the good parts and jettison the rest.' It's'repeal, repeal, repeal,' because that was the war drum on the campaign trail."

Given the tough constraints, today's congressional dealmakers are not coming from either party's moderate wing, as many of them have in the past. Those lawmakers have either been defeated or have left office on their own, out of frustration with the toxic atmosphere on the Hill or fear of a primary challenge. Instead, it's up to lawmakers respected on both the left and right, like Republicans Sen. Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin or Democrats like Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) and Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD), to get things done.

"If you're waiting for the moderates to compromise," you're going to be waiting quite a while," says former Sen. Joe Lieberman (I-CT). "There are not enough left."

Getting those on either end of the spectrum to sit down together can be aided by what might be called political entrepreneurs, like Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC), legislators willing to tackle sensitive issues such as immigration and Social Security before their parties are willing to do the same. However, bringing disparate politicians together on new ideas is another matter. That is now often done through old-fashioned bargaining in the backroom, where lawmakers can make the kind of concessions key to compromise.

"Part of the value [ of such groups ] is they are working on the outlines of what a bargain on any issue would be before it hits the media," says Julian Zelizer, a congressional historian at Princeton University. Bipartisan gangs "give some kind of signal to other party members that it's OK" to depart from orthodoxy.

The public's general disdain for gridlock and voters' outspokenness on individual issues are other factors that may force more compromise. "Sometimes dealmakers gain strength when there is some kind of social pressure to do something," says Mr. Zelizer.

Title: Four Republicans and an Independent Break Away from Party to Condemn President's Language in House Vote

Article:

In a significant turn of events, four Republicans and one independent broke ranks and voted with the Democrats in a House vote on Tuesday, condemning the president's language. This action serves as a stark reminder of the evolution of the Republican Party, which, in the past, prided itself on being a big tent, welcoming to Latino and African-American voters.

Instead of aligning with the four dissenting members, several party leaders have been advocating messages of patriotism. Some have attempted to sidestep the racial implications, while others seem less concerned about potential backlash.

Kellyanne Conway, counselor to the president, expressed her views in an interview with Fox News on Tuesday. She described the four as representing a "dark underbelly of people in this country," adding, "We are sick and tired of people denigrating that American flag, the American military, veterans, and America."

Other party members have been attempting to reframe and soften the message. Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, the third-ranking House Republican, offered a tutorial to Mr. Trump on how to go on the offensive without inviting a backlash. She stated, "Our opposition to our socialist colleagues has absolutely nothing to do with their gender, with their religion or with their race. It has to do with the content of their policies."

The 2020 election is still over 15 months away, and the Democrats will eventually have a standard-bearer to define the party in opposition to Mr. Trump. However, some Democrats are concerned that criticism of the four congresswomen may resonate with a segment of their voters and independents, who may share similar unease with the policies they support and some of their rhetoric, as they do with Mr. Trump's own bombast.

The Democrats who performed well in the midterms were those who played down Mr. Trump while highlighting issues like protecting the health insurance of people with pre-existing conditions. Many strategists rallying behind former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. believe the party cannot count on increasing turnout among young people and minorities and needs to lure back voters it lost to Mr. Trump.

Title: GOP Faces Challenges in Passing American Healthcare Act as Vote Approaches

Article:

The American Healthcare Act (AHCA), the Republican Party's attempt to replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), has faced difficulties in garnering enough support for a vote, leading to a planned reattempt on Friday. President Trump, according to Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney, has urged House Republicans to pass the bill now, stating that the time for negotiations is over. If the bill fails this time, they will be stuck with the ACA.

The AHCA has faced opposition from both Democrats and within the GOP, with some moderates and conservatives rejecting the bill due to its deviation from a clean repeal of the ACA. The bill has been criticized as "Obamacare 2.0" and "Obamacare Lite" by its detractors. Moderates have expressed concerns about the bill's timeline for rolling back the ACA's Medicaid expansion, fearing it would leave too many uninsured. Opponents also criticize the bill for not doing enough to control rising premium costs.

Over the past week, GOP leaders and the president have offered changes to the bill, including a manager's amendment that tinkered with Medicaid and the IRS code. On Thursday, Republicans discussed removing Obamacare "essential benefits" such as maternity and prenatal care, preventative care, and other mandatory insurance provisions since the passage of the ACA.

The stakes are high, with President Trump expressing his "100 percent" support for the bill and making a hard sell in recent weeks. He has warned Republican lawmakers that their seats and the Republican majority are in danger in 2018 if they do not pass the bill.

However, reluctant House Republicans may also be considering the Senate's stance, as they weigh their votes. At least three senators - Rand Paul, Mike Lee, and Tom Cotton - currently oppose the bill, while Ted Cruz has stated he cannot support the bill as it stands. Four other senators have objected to the treatment of the Medicaid expansion in the bill. If three Republican senators vote against the bill, the AHCA will fail in the Senate, which has a slim 52-48 Republican majority.

Republicans need 215 votes to win passage in the House, due to the absence of Rep. Bobby Rush, a Democrat from Illinois. They can lose no more than 22 votes. The list of House Republicans who have expressed opposition to the bill in its current form is subject to change, with negotiations and potential shifts in support leading up to the vote. Updates on the list will be provided as decisions are made or positions change.

Title: House Republicans Abandon Health Care Replacement Bill, Affordable Care Act Remains in Effect

Article:

House Republicans have abandoned their health care replacement plan, effectively leaving the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, as the law of the land. House Speaker Paul Ryan admitted the defeat of the bill shortly after it was pulled from a vote on Friday.

"We're going to be living with Obamacare for the foreseeable future," Ryan said. "I do not know how long it's going to take us to replace this law."

President Trump, who had previously expressed optimism about the bill's passage, described the setback as a "learning experience." He also suggested the possibility of a future bipartisan bill, stating, "Both parties can get together...and have a better bill."

However, Trump and Ryan both indicated that health care would be put on hold for the time being, with the focus shifting to tax reform. The failure of the health care bill is a significant setback for Trump's leadership and Ryan's ability to control his conference, as it was a key campaign promise for the Republican Party.

The inability of Republicans to reach consensus on a bill, given their control of the House, Senate, and White House, has been met with criticism and raises questions about the party's ability to govern. The risks were high for Trump on the bill, as he has been portrayed as a deal-maker, and the failure to pass the bill raises questions about his legislative and policy experience.

The way forward for Republicans on exactly how to replace Obamacare remains unclear, and it is not certain whether they will try again. The GOP has vowed repeatedly over the past eight years to repeal and replace Obamacare, but the legislative stalemate casts a cloud over the legislative path forward after an election waged largely as the antithesis to a progressive agenda enacted by former President Barack Obama.

Democrats, meanwhile, have taken a victory lap in the GOP's defeat. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, whose caucus was decimated in 2010 after the health care bill was passed, appeared flanked by Democratic leadership to gloat just a day after the seventh anniversary of the signing of the Affordable Care Act.

Title: President Trump Embraces "Border Warrior" Role Amid Government Shutdown

Article:

President Donald Trump is now the "proud" owner of a government shutdown — his third — and he does not seem to mind. The threat of an extended shutdown is less of a concern to the president than not fulfilling his central campaign pledge to build a border wall and appearing as a fraud, according to White House aides and Trump allies.

Trump spent the weekend digging in on his position, meeting with hard-line conservatives and signaling through his top aides that he could stomach a shutdown that could drag on well into the new year. Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, set the bar on Sunday, stating, "I don't think things are going to move very quickly here for the next couple of days."

The holiday shutdown comes amid a series of turbulent events, including a stock market rout, Cabinet shakeups, and turbulence from the Republican congressional ranks over the president's decision to pull troops from Syria and scale back the U.S. presence in Afghanistan.

Amid the disarray, Trump is resuming a partisan mantle he views as a unifier for the right: border warrior. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) argued that Democrats and their leaders were the reason the country was in for a protracted confrontation. "We're not going to abandon the wall," Graham said. "We're going to build a wall, and to all those Americans who want us to abandon the wall and open up the border, that's what this fight's about."

Trump's aides have half-heartedly tried to pin the blame on Democrats, despite the president's earlier statements suggesting that the American people were with him on the issue. Trump, who casts the southern border wall in political terms as a "total winner," even as polls show that majorities of Americans don't support the structure, is marching out senior administration officials to assert that he's been "very clear" about his expectations for funding various "physical barriers."

Republicans are not uniformly falling in line. Sen. Bob Corker of Tennessee blasted Trump for failing to avoid the partial shutdown, dismissing his hardening negotiating posture on immigration as "a made-up fight so that the president could look like he's fighting."

Trump's reelection campaign has leapt quickly at the chance to capitalize on the stalemate and paint him as an authentic promise-keeper. One Trump campaign appeal to supporters tarred Democrats as insensitive to the safety of Americans. "FIGHT BACK," it implored. "Donate to become an Official Build the Wall Member." And other Trump-backed groups are running ads and circulating petitions to Republicans.

For the president, the border wall is about far more than a structure, allies concede. The White House has long seen his "Build the wall" promise as an indicator for how far his early pledges alone could take him with voters he'll need to secure reelection. "The wall is important, but it's more the underlying anti-immigrant message that's the key," a former White House official said.

In addition to saying Mexico would pay for the wall — a goal the administration maintains is still viable, albeit most likely retroactively — other of Trump's big early claims remain unfulfilled and look increasingly doubtful. During his 2016 campaign, Trump estimated he would complete the entire border wall within two years from the time he started. "We'll start quickly," he added. "And it'll be a real wall."

While the wall has yet to come to fruition, the president has been filling the void with more words. Trump repeatedly boasts about how much of the wall has already been built, even though little if any building has happened, let alone during his presidency. To keep up appearances during the midterm elections, aides handed out signs that read "Finish the Wall."

Well before the recent conservative backlash reared, one threat the president's team identified on the subject was supporters beginning to doubt his ability to deliver. Though Trump could continue to point a finger at Congress, which has given him only a fraction of what he wants for border security, another person close to the president noted that the government-funding exercise was one area where he had the ultimate say.

For now, it's a function of leverage, which the ally acknowledged Democrats have.

Title: House of Representatives Gains Momentum for DACA, Net Neutrality, and Sexual Harassment Bills Despite Leadership Opposition

Article:

In a series of events this week, the House of Representatives has shown signs of increasing independence from leadership, with members pushing for votes on several legislative fixes for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, net neutrality, and sexual harassment.

Rep. Jeff Denham (R-CA) is leading a move to gather a majority of House members to sign a discharge petition that would force floor votes on immigration, despite Speaker Paul Ryan's opposition. As of Thursday, Denham reportedly has enough support for the discharge petition to force a vote, but he continues to negotiate behind closed doors to find a compromise immigration bill that leadership can bring up.

The Republican leadership is not pleased with this development. Speaker Ryan stated on Thursday that discharge petitions "lose control" on the House floor, meaning he loses control over when and how to vote on immigration—if at all. Politico reported that Ryan and his team are "quietly promising the figures behind the discharge petition and those who might sign that they will put a bunch of immigration bills on the floor" in June, a clear effort to regain power over the situation.

In a separate development, a bipartisan group of senators defied Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and voted to overturn the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) controversial ruling to dismantle net neutrality. The vote to reinstate the Obama-era net neutrality rules won the support of 49 Democrats as well as three Republican senators: Susan Collins of Maine, John Kennedy of Louisiana, and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska. This group was enough to pass the 51-vote benchmark needed to repeal recently introduced federal rules, such as the FCC's internet guidance.

In another sign of frustration, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand invoked an obscure Senate rule to try to put a House-passed sexual harassment and discrimination bill on the Senate calendar without McConnell's support, in another sign of frustration. The bill would overhaul how harassment complaints are made in Congress and make lawmakers personally accountable for paying settlements. The legislation, a version of which the House has passed 100 days ago, has been stalled in the Senate while negotiators iron out some details in the language.

These developments highlight the growing frustration among rank-and-file lawmakers with deferring to leadership. James Wallner, a political scientist and former executive director of the Senate Steering Committee, stated, "When [members] look behind the curtain and the emperor has no clothes, then it becomes contagious. And that's what leaders don't like. So far they have been successful in convincing members that it's not good for the majority."

It remains to be seen where these efforts will go, but it is clear that rank-and-file members are increasingly taking matters into their own hands, despite leadership's opposition.

Title: Lori Lightfoot Wins Chicago Mayoral Race, Becoming First Black Woman and Openly Gay Person to Lead Third-Largest U.S. City

Article:

Former federal prosecutor Lori Lightfoot has been declared the winner of the Chicago mayoral race, making history as the first black woman and openly gay individual to lead the third-largest city in the United States. Lightfoot defeated Toni Preckwinkle, a longtime political insider and Cook County Board president, in Tuesday's election.

Lightfoot, who has never been elected to public office, delivered a commanding victory over Preckwinkle, who served in the City Council for 19 years. Lightfoot's campaign focused on ridding City Hall of corruption and addressing the needs of low-income and working-class residents, a message that resonated with voters weary of political scandal and insider deals.

In her victory speech, Lightfoot pledged to break the city's cycle of corruption and ensure that a resident's zip code does not determine their destiny. She also emphasized her commitment to making Chicago a place where race and sexual orientation do not matter.

Chicago will become the largest U.S. city to elect a black woman as mayor when Lightfoot is sworn in May 20. She will join seven other black women currently serving as mayors in major U.S. cities, including Atlanta and New Orleans.

The vote to succeed outgoing Mayor Rahm Emanuel came just days after Chicago state prosecutors dropped charges against actor Jussie Smollett, who was accused of faking a hate-crime attack that implicated supporters of President Trump. The decision to drop charges has sparked controversy and criticism.

Lightfoot seized on outrage over the deadly shooting of black teenager Laquan McDonald to launch her campaign. The shooting, at the hands of white officer Jason Van Dyke, became a major issue in the election.

Throughout the campaign, the two candidates exchanged barbs, with Preckwinkle focusing on Lightfoot's work as a partner at Mayer Brown, a large law firm, and labeling her a "wealthy corporate lawyer." Preckwinkle also tried to cast Lightfoot as an insider for working in police oversight posts under Emanuel and former Mayor Richard M. Daley.

In one ad, Preckwinkle criticized Lightfoot's oversight of emergency communications in 2004 when a fire killed four children. A judge ordered Lightfoot to preserve 911 tapes after questions were raised about how the emergency call was handled. The ad noted some of the tapes were destroyed, prompting the judge to rebuke Lightfoot.

Despite the contentious campaign, both candidates expressed similar ideas to boost the city's finances, including support for a casino in Chicago and a graduated income tax system. Preckwinkle also promoted additional investments in neighborhood schools, affordable housing, and criminal justice reform.

Lightfoot said that as mayor, she would focus on investing in neighborhoods on the West and South Sides and bringing transparency and accountability to City Hall. She added she also wanted to end City Hall corruption and restore people's faith in government.

"The machine's been in decline for a while, but it still has a grip on certain things," Lightfoot said. "This is our opportunity to send it to its grave, once and for all."

Title: Kentucky Senator Rand Paul Stages 12-Hour Filibuster on Drone Strikes

Article:

Kentucky Senator Rand Paul staged a 12-hour filibuster in the Senate on Wednesday, expressing concerns over the potential danger of drone strikes to U.S. citizens on American soil. The filibuster, which was the longest in recent Senate memory, successfully delayed a potential vote to confirm President Barack Obama's nominee to run the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

Senator Paul began speaking at 11:47 a.m. on Wednesday and continued until about 12:39 a.m. on Thursday. He yielded the floor after more than 12 hours of continuous speaking, having remained inside the Senate chamber during this time.

"I would try to go another 12 hours and try to break Strom Thurmond's record, but there are some limits to filibustering and I am going to have to go take care of one of those here," Paul said.

Immediately after Paul finished, Majority Whip Dick Durbin of Illinois introduced a motion to end debate on the nomination of John Brennan to run the CIA.

In an interview with reporters after the filibuster, Paul stated that his team had not planned for the extended debate, which turned into a rare marathon talkfest. However, he did employ some strategy, such as frequent visits to the candy drawer and minimizing water consumption to manage his energy levels.

Senator Paul's filibuster initially surprised many members of the Senate, who had been prepared to vote to confirm Brennan to lead the spy agency earlier on Wednesday. As the day progressed, several of Paul's colleagues, as well as one Democrat, joined him to criticize the Obama administration for its refusal to rule out the use of drones against Americans on U.S. soil or to disclose more information about drone policy.

By nightfall, Paul's effort had gained the support of more of his colleagues, including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who joined him on the floor. They used their time to quote figures such as Ronald Reagan, Shakespeare, and Florida Senator Marco Rubio referenced "The Godfather" and rapper Jay-Z.

Shortly before the 12-hour mark, Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus called via Twitter for "all Republican US senators" to join the filibuster. Senators Ron Johnson of Wisconsin and Tim Scott of South Carolina spoke about the Senate's dysfunction and the dangers of the national debt, while Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona expressed support for Paul's questions about drone policy.

Title: Trump Requests $8.6 Billion for Border Wall in 2020 Budget Proposal

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced his intention to request $8.6 billion for the construction of a border wall with Mexico in his 2020 congressional budget proposal, set to be submitted on Monday. This move is expected to reignite a funding standoff with Congress, as the proposed funding amount is likely to face stiff opposition from the Democrat-held House.

According to a senior administration official, the $8.6 billion would be used to build or replace approximately 700 miles of barriers along the U.S.-Mexico border. Reuters reported that the funding for the wall would be drawn from the Department of Homeland Security budget ($5 billion) and the military construction budget at the Pentagon ($3.6 billion).

The budget proposal also includes $3.6 million in military construction funding to help fund projects affected by the wall. In addition to wall funding, Trump's proposal calls for the hiring of an additional 2,800 law enforcement and other personnel to reinforce the border and 100 immigration judge teams.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) have indicated that the president's $8.6 billion ask is a non-starter. In a statement, they criticized Trump for causing widespread chaos by shutting down the government to secure wall funding in the past.

Congress must approve funding for fiscal 2020 by Oct. 1, or funding could lapse, and the government could shut down. Trump's requests for border funding have shifted during his time in office as he seeks to fulfill a signature campaign promise.

In the past, the administration's proposal for fiscal year 2019 sought $18 billion for the wall, including $1.6 billion to construct 65 miles in south Texas. The president triggered a partial government shutdown in December when he demanded $5.7 billion in wall funding. Trump agreed to reopen the government without wall funding but continued to press lawmakers for $5.7 billion for the structure. Congress ultimately approved $1.375 billion for border barriers, and the president issued a national emergency to bypass Congress and spend roughly $8 billion to construct his long-desired border wall.

In making the emergency declaration, the president said he planned to redirect $3.6 billion in military construction funding toward the border project. He also said he would take separate executive action to repurpose about $2.5 billion from the Defense Department's drug-interdiction program and $600 million from the Treasury Department's asset-forfeiture fund.

The national emergency has drawn pushback from Congress, with the House voting to approve a resolution that would terminate the emergency. The Senate is expected to do the same this week. The Senate vote would set Trump up for the first veto of his presidency, with neither chamber likely to override it.

Trump has made the construction of a wall along the southern border a key agenda item since he launched his campaign in 2015. His inability to complete the task has prompted criticism from immigration hard-liners, though Trump has insisted the wall is being built, and he has transitioned his mantra from "Build the wall" to "Finish the wall."

Larry Kudlow, Trump's top economic adviser, acknowledged on "Fox News Sunday" that the request for wall funding is likely to spur yet another fight with Congress, but he depicted it as a necessary one. "We have to be much tougher and have more constructive immigration policy," Kudlow said. "We have to be much together and have more constructive immigration policy, which we will be developing." Kudlow added, "The whole issue of the wall and border security is of paramount importance."

Title: Democratic National Convention Kicks Off in Charlotte: A Clear Plan for a Stronger America

Article:

The Democratic National Convention commenced in Charlotte, North Carolina, on Tuesday, with Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, the convention's chair, outlining the party's aim to present a clear plan for the nation's economic recovery. Villaraigosa stated that by the convention's conclusion on Thursday, the Democratic platform would be defined, and the election would be about a significant choice.

Villaraigosa compared the Democratic candidate's economic approach to that of the Republican nominee, stating, "We are talking about a candidate who wants to build an economy from the middle out and a candidate who wants to build an economy from the top down."

The opening press conference mirrored themes expressed by President Obama in recent interviews, such as his assertion to Time magazine that a clear explanation of his policies and the contrasting approach of the Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, would sway American voters in his favor.

Alice Germond, the National Committee Secretary, reiterated the Democrats' pride in President Obama and his accomplishments during the media briefing. In response to perceived GOP secrecy regarding their platform, Germond stated that by the time President Obama delivers his acceptance speech on Thursday evening, everyone will have a copy of the platform.

Villaraigosa indicated that the following days would serve to remind the country of Obama's first term in office, highlighting his role in "stopping an economic catastrophe," "saving the auto industry," and passing the landmark healthcare law.

In response to a recently released Gallup poll indicating tepid reception to Romney's acceptance speech, Obama campaign National Press Secretary Ben LaBolt stated, "Most Americans are looking for an answer on how we're going to secure the middle class." He added that the convention would be used to address these concerns and engage in an honest conversation about the country's state in 2008.

LaBolt emphasized that the Democrats had made progress and that the president would use his Thursday speech to outline his plans to continue on this path.

Title: Obama's Last-Minute Actions: Commutation of Chelsea Manning's Sentence and UN Resolution on Israel

Article:

In the final days of his presidency, Barack Obama took two controversial actions that were met with criticism and surprise. The commutation of Chelsea Manning's sentence and the passing of a United Nations Security Council resolution critical of Israel were the president's last acts before leaving office.

On January 17, 2017, Obama commuted the sentence of Chelsea Manning, a former Army intelligence analyst who was convicted of espionage and theft of government documents. Manning had been sentenced to 35 years in prison for leaking nearly half a million military reports and another quarter-million State Department documents to WikiLeaks. The documents, according to intelligence sources, jeopardized the lives of American soldiers and local allies in Iraq and Afghanistan.

The commutation of Manning's sentence was criticized as a "finger-in-the-eye willfulness" by some, as the documents released by Manning were considered a threat to national security. The documents exposed military secrets that could have caused harm to American troops, allies, and interests.

The other last-minute Obama bombshell occurred four weeks earlier when, for the first time in nearly a half-century, the United States abandoned Israel on a crucial Security Council resolution, allowing the passage of a condemnation that will plague both Israel and its citizens for years to come. The U.S. has no power to reverse the Security Council resolution.

The actions were seen as a departure from Obama's previous stance on WikiLeaks and Israel. During the 2016 election campaign, Obama had demanded a report on the release of stolen materials and e-mails by WikiLeaks and had imposed sanctions on Russia. He had also been vocal about the sanctity of the American political process.

The actions were met with criticism from both sides of the political spectrum, with some arguing that the actions were a calculated move to curry favor with the international left or to establish bona fides for a potential future role on the international stage. However, others suggest that the actions were authentic, reflecting Obama's true beliefs and values.

The article does not provide a clear explanation for Obama's actions, and it is unavailable whether the president had any specific motives for his last-minute actions. The article also does not provide any further details about the commutation of Oscar Lopez Rivera's sentence, a Puerto Rican terrorist who was also released by Obama in the final days of his presidency.

Title: US Secretary of State Kerry Seeks Coalition Partners to Combat Islamic State

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry is currently in Saudi Arabia, aiming to assemble a "broad coalition of partners" to join the U.S. in the fight against the Islamic State. This initiative is a key component of a strategy unveiled by President Obama in his national address the previous day.

During the talks, which involve a diverse group of Middle Eastern nations, a senior U.S. State Department official stated that the U.S. requires regional support for establishing military bases and overflight for airstrikes, as well as improved coordination to prevent individuals from funding extremist groups.

The U.S. seeks to halt Islamic State oil smuggling through the Jordanian and Turkish borders, with authorities pledging to take action, but the U.S. will work more closely with them over the next few weeks on intelligence sharing and border control, according to the official.

The talks today include leaders from Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Jordan, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman, and Qatar. President Obama stated last night that the U.S. "will be joined by a broad coalition of partners," and Secretary Kerry will travel across the Middle East and Europe in the coming days to enlist more partners in this fight, particularly Arab nations who can help mobilize Sunni communities in Iraq and Syria to drive the terrorists from their lands.

Saudi Arabia's agreement to host training camps for "moderate Syrian rebels" is seen as a sign of support, according to U.S. officials. Saudi Arabia is considered crucial to a successful coalition due to its religious significance with Sunnis, as Islamic State fighters are Sunni.

However, challenges remain. Many countries essential to the coalition are skeptical of the U.S. commitment to follow through on its promises to eliminate the Islamic State, after it refrained from airstrikes last year against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

The Monitor reports that these countries have favored, in various ways, the same anti-Assad rebels that the U.S. would like to see prevail, but they also support Islamist groups that spawned the Islamic State and other jihadi groups that are now beyond their control. This complicates any U.S.-led coalition against radicalism.

Dan Murphy, writing for the Monitor's Backchannels column, cautions that arming "Syrian moderates" is fraught with uncertainty. The Obama administration's previous attempts to arm "moderate" Syrian rebels were unsuccessful, with a U.S. weapons depot being quickly overrun and seized by IS militants, effectively ending that effort.

After his Middle East tour, Secretary of State Kerry will travel to Europe, where he should receive a warmer response from governments concerned about the fact that hundreds of Europeans have left to fight in Syria. At the NATO Summit last week in Wales, the U.S. had support from Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Australia, Turkey, Italy, Poland, and Denmark.

France has played the most public supporting role so far, pledging to act in an international coalition if international law is followed. French President François Hollande and Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius will travel to Baghdad tomorrow, before France hosts a conference in Paris on Monday to coordinate efforts to tackle the Islamic State.

"An international mobilization is necessary to respond to this trans-national danger that can reach our territory," Mr. Fabius said, according to Reuters. "In Iraq, the government and minorities have called for help (and) we answered with deliveries of military equipment and humanitarian aid."

This week, the UK said it would send a limited amount of arms to Kurds in Iraq to fight the Islamic State. Germany also agreed to do the same. In a Guardian opinion piece, Hayder al-Khoei, an associate fellow on the Middle East and North Africa program at Chatham House, said that "the UK should be an important player in the international coalition that Obama is trying to set up to confront the most dangerous terrorist organization of the 21st century."

Title: George Papadopoulos Labeled as "Proactive Cooperator" in Mueller Investigation

Article:

The former Trump campaign adviser, George Papadopoulos, has been identified as a "proactive cooperator" in court documents unveiled on Monday. This term, referring to Papadopoulos, has sparked speculation that the 30-year-old energy consultant may have worn a wire to aid investigators in the Office of Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian interference in the presidential campaign.

According to a court filing submitted by prosecutors, the reference to Papadopoulos' status is aimed at sealing court filings in the case, stating that "premature disclosure" of his arrest would significantly undermine his ability to serve as a proactive cooperator.

The term "proactive cooperation" is generally understood to mean that the defendant will engage in some type of undercover work on behalf of the Government, such as wearing a wire and/or meeting face to face with persons suspected of involvement in criminal activity, as explained in a 2001 federal court case.

At a plea hearing held on Oct. 5, Aaron Zelinsky, a prosecutor in the Office of the Special Counsel, shed light on Papadopoulos' cooperation. Zelinsky stated that at Papadopoulos' sentencing, prosecutors would make note of his "efforts to cooperate with the Government" as long as he continued "to meet with and provide information to the Government on request."

Papadopoulos was arrested on July 27 on charges that he lied to FBI agents during a Jan. 27 interview. Agents met with Papadopoulos as part of the bureau's investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian government.

As part of his plea deal, Papadopoulos acknowledged that he lied to agents during that meeting about his interactions with three Russian nationals. Papadopoulos initially claimed that he knew the Russians prior to joining the Trump campaign on March 6, 2016. However, investigators obtained Papadopoulos' emails and social media exchanges, which showed that he was lying.

Papadopoulos discussed arranging meetings between Russian government officials and the Trump campaign. One of Papadopoulos' contacts, a London-based professor, also told him in April that the Russian government had obtained "thousands" of Hillary Clinton's emails.

The White House on Monday downplayed the revelations, stating that Papadopoulos played a small part on the campaign and that the Trump team did not collude with the Russian government.

Papadopoulos' Oct. 5 plea deal and his earlier arrest remained a closely held secret until Monday, just hours after Mueller's office unsealed an indictment against former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his business associate, Rick Gates.

Manafort and Gates are charged with money laundering and conspiracy. The indictment provides no evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian government.

The revelation that Papadopoulos was serving as a "proactive cooperator" has sparked widespread speculation about the extent of his cooperation with the Mueller team.

Ron Hosko, a former assistant director of the FBI's criminal division, suggests that it is possible that Papadopoulos wore a wire as part of his cooperation agreement. "I think it's a fair assessment that it means Mueller and Co. might have been working with [Papadopoulos] to engage other subjects in conversation along the lines suggested in the article," said Hosko, referring to the possibility of Papadopoulos wearing a wire.

Recordings of Papadopoulos' conversations could have then been used to approach additional subjects. On CNN, legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin stated that the government's disclosure strongly suggests that Papadopoulos was wearing a wire or recording conversations with Trump associates.

"What this says to me is that Papadopoulos between July and October was wearing a wire. He was recording conversations secretly with people who are subjects and targets of this investigation," he said, adding that "that's the only reasonable explanation of what's in those court papers."

"If he was wearing a wire, this summer and fall, think about that, just weeks ago, that is a whole new chapter of possibilities in this investigation and potentially a very, very big deal," Toobin concluded.

Title: Senate Democrats to Grill William Barr on Mueller's Russia Investigation at Attorney General Confirmation Hearing

Article:

As the Senate Judiciary Committee prepares for hearings on William Barr's nomination for attorney general, special counsel Robert Mueller will be a significant presence in the room. Several Senate Democrats on the committee plan to question Barr at his confirmation hearing next week about his views on Mueller's Russia investigation, focusing on a controversial memo Barr wrote last year to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

In the memo, Barr criticized Mueller's investigation into possible obstruction of justice as "fatally misconceived." Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer on Wednesday stated that Barr should be disqualified from leading the DOJ in part because of the memo.

Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) said he will ask Barr if he will stop political interference in the special counsel's probe and whether he will recuse himself from overseeing the investigation if he cannot provide an "ironclad" commitment to protecting Mueller and disavowing statements made in the memo.

Barr's nomination battle comes at a critical moment in Donald Trump's presidency, with the Justice Department in transition and Mueller's probe entering its 20th month. The investigation has resulted in seven guilty pleas and a conviction of the president's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort.

Trump has repeatedly denounced the Mueller investigation, labeling it a "witch hunt," and has taken to Twitter dozens of times to criticize the investigation and the investigators involved. A bipartisan group of senators is also reintroducing a bill to protect Mueller, though Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has said such a bill isn't needed and has refused to bring it up for a floor vote.

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), another Judiciary committee member, also agreed that the Mueller investigation will be a central issue and called it "troublesome" that Barr volunteered his opinion on Mueller's authority. "I'm sure he'll deny any culpability and assure me that he's going to be a straight arrow, but I come to it with a degree of skepticism," he said.

Democrats say that the departure of Rosenstein, who is reportedly leaving the Justice Department after a new attorney general is confirmed, also raises the stakes for choosing the next attorney general. While Democrats can't block Barr's nomination by themselves, they may succeed in getting him to commit to protecting the Mueller investigation under oath.

"I would have liked [Rosenstein]... to be the attorney general," said Sen. Mazie Hirono (D-Hawaii) adding that she wants to hear from Barr "that the Attorney General's office is an independent entity."

Trump nominated Barr for attorney general in December. If confirmed, he would replace former Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who Trump resented after he recused himself from the Russia investigation. Barr also served as attorney general under President George H.W. Bush.

Despite the focus on the Mueller investigation, Democrats on the Judiciary Committee don't appear to have a completely uniform strategy for how to approach the nomination hearing. When asked about the Democratic strategy, Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said he had "no idea" and would focus his attention on meeting with Barr and asking his own questions. Blumenthal seemed to agree.

"I have my questions and my strategy for asking those questions. I don't think there's a Democratic strategy," he said.

Senate Republicans are bracing for Barr's hearing to become confrontational, particularly given the contentious nature of the committee's high-profile hearing of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) has no doubt that Democrats will try to block Barr's confirmation in no small part because Democratic senators with 2020 aspirations may use the hearing to stand out.

"Senate Democrats especially on the Judiciary Committee have demonstrated that they will treat almost anything like a political circus, and you've got right now it seems like half of the Judiciary Committee on the Democratic side running for president so I fully expect more 'Spartacus' moments in the next two years," said Cruz, referencing Sen. Cory Booker's performance during the Kavanaugh hearings.

Despite potential Democratic attacks, Senate Republicans don't appear concerned about Barr's memo to Rosenstein and remain confident that he will be confirmed, particularly given that they expanded their majority during the midterm election. Only 50 votes are needed to confirm a nominee, and so Republicans don't need any Democratic votes.

Barr met Wednesday with Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and former Committee Chair Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa). Graham said that during their meeting, Barr reassured him of his respect for Mueller.

"He said 'I've known Bob Mueller for decades,' their wives are like best friends," Graham said, adding that Barr believes Mueller is "professional, will be fair to the president, fair to the country and... is going to make sure that Bob Mueller can finish his job."

Graham also expressed support for bringing up the Mueller protection bill in his committee if the probe is still going on next month.

Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.), who is also on the Judiciary Committee, doesn't see Barr's memo to Rosenstein on the Mueller investigation as disqualifying and noted in an interview that Barr wrote the memo as a private citizen.

Not all Republicans are on board yet with Barr's nomination. Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) reiterated his concern Wednesday with Barr's view of civil liberties. "I believe there are some statements of his saying the Patriot Act didn't go far enough and should have gone farther," Paul said.

Title: Health Insurance Renewal Process for 2015: Changes, Confusion, and Improvements

Article:

Individuals renewing their health insurance policies for 2015 may face changes in pricing and federal tax credits, potentially leading to higher costs for the same plan. The renewal period begins on November 15, with a deadline of December 15 for those renewing to secure a new plan by the start of the year.

The specifics of the renewal process have yet to be determined, as stated by Paula Steiner, chief strategy officer for Health Care Service Corporation, which offers Blue Cross plans in five states. "We're still waiting on the details of the process," she said, adding, "We haven't gone through any testing yet of any changes to the system for 2015."

Andrew Slavitt, principal deputy administrator for Medicare, which oversees the insurance marketplaces, expressed optimism about the renewal process, stating, "We're putting in place the simplest path for consumers this year to renew their coverage." Those who prefer to maintain their current plan can do so automatically, as is common with employer coverage, with the option to renew by taking no action.

The federal online marketplace is being continuously improved, according to Mr. Slavitt, who noted that the government was updating the website to allow renewals. "We're in a very different position than we were last year," he said.

Compared to the 2014 marketplaces, 30 carriers have requested entrance into the marketplaces for 2015, and 1.6 times more plans are being offered, according to McKinsey & Company's Center for US Health System Reform. Prices for 2015 are expected to remain varied, with some plans experiencing a 30% increase while others see a similar decrease, depending on the market and policy. "We are definitely seeing a lot of volatility in pricing," said Erica Hutchins Coe, a McKinsey expert.

Title: Ferguson October: A Wake-Up Call for America

Article:

Over the weekend, protestors and activists, including students, clergy, and concerned citizens, descended on Ferguson, Missouri, for a series of marches, protests, sit-ins, and civil disobedience, collectively known as Ferguson October. Among the activists arrested was Patrisse Cullors-Brignac, an organizer with Black Lives Matter, who tweeted from a St. Louis County jail cell about taking over a Wal-Mart.

The arrests have sparked debate on social media, with some questioning the appropriateness of disturbing the peace in a private business. However, the activists argue that the time for business as usual has passed. The shooting of John Crawford in a Beaver Creek, Ohio Wal-Mart, who could not reasonably expect to come out alive, is seen as a sign that the status quo is no longer acceptable.

The activists draw parallels to the racial segregation of the past, which occurred in "private" businesses like Woolworth's and Hecht's. They argue that Black people are the hands on the nation's social progress clock, and the current state of racial inequality is a reflection of that.

The activists are also drawing inspiration from young people, who are creative, political, and joyful in their struggle for justice. They are registering new voters, disrupting public events, and taking over public spaces with impromptu games and performances. The movement has collected over 3000 new voter registrations (Update: This number has since been revised downward to 128), but the activists remain skeptical of the voting system.

The movement is also a symbolic rejection of the current political leadership, with activists criticizing President Barack Obama for his silence on the issue and his inability to effect change. Some have compared the movement to the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s, with activists arguing that they are fighting for a new future and a new version of themselves.

The movement is a call to action, with activists urging people to "stay woke" and to put their bodies on the line for justice. The movement is undignified, improper, unabashed, and unapologetic, but the activists argue that this is necessary to effect change. The movement is a call for a new America, one that is willing to fight for justice and to reject the status quo of racial inequality.

Title: Mayorkas Denies Allegations of Improper Visa Aid at Homeland Security Confirmation Hearing

Article:

President Obama's nominee for the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, Alejandro Mayorkas, unequivocally denied allegations that he improperly helped a company run by Hillary Clinton's brother obtain a visa during his confirmation hearing on Thursday. The hearing proceeded despite calls by Republicans for a postponement due to an ongoing investigation by the department's inspector general.

Mayorkas, the current director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, testified before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee. He stated that he "made no orders" in these cases and only offers guidance based on the "facts" and "the law."

"I have never, ever in my career exercised undue influence to influence the outcome of a case," he said. Mayorkas also stated that he had "no idea" he was under investigation and "quite frankly, I still don't understand it."

Republicans boycotted the hearing, after having tried unsuccessfully to get it postponed. In a statement, Sen. Tom Coburn, R-Okla., said, "I cannot participate in a hearing I believe to be unfair and improper to all parties involved."

In a letter to committee Chairman Sen. Tom Carper, D-Del., on Wednesday, four Republican senators claimed the news of the investigation took them by surprise. They said neither the White House nor Mayorkas had disclosed the existence of the probe to them before. The investigation was first reported on Tuesday.

"We believe it is neither appropriate nor fair to consider the nomination of an individual under investigation," the lawmakers wrote. The letter was signed by Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz.; Rob Portman, R-Ohio; Ron Johnson, R-Wis.; and Coburn.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, also wrote committee leaders asking for a postponement "until the facts are more fully developed."

The White House is supporting Mayorkas' nomination, stating that he underwent a "thorough" FBI background check before the nomination, and they have no concerns about his suitability for the position. However, the inspector general's office has not closed the book on the case.

The office has confirmed that it is investigating Mayorkas' role in helping secure a foreign investor visa for Tony Rodham's Gulf Coast Funds Management even after the application was denied and an appeal rejected. The international investor visa program run by USCIS, known as EB-5, allows foreigners to get visas if they invest $500,000 to $1 million in projects or businesses that create jobs for U.S. citizens.

In an email to lawmakers on Monday, the IG's office said "at this point in our investigation, we do not have any findings of criminal misconduct." Congressional officials briefed on the investigation said the visa was for a Chinese executive. Homeland Security and Citizenship and Immigration Services have not commented on the investigation.

Rodham's company said Tuesday it was not aware of the investigation or of any investor visa application being denied. In a prepared opening statement, Sen. Tom Carper acknowledged questions surrounding "Director Mayorkas' qualifications."

"At this point in time, we do not have all the facts," Carper said. He also stated that it's "my understanding" that Mayorkas has not yet been interviewed by the IG's office. He added that despite objections from Republicans, "This hearing will allow us to continue the process of vetting this nominee."

Aside from the controversy surrounding Mayorkas, Carper expressed confidence in his nomination. "I have also taken the opportunity to review Mr. Mayorkas' FBI file, not once, but twice," Carper said. He added, "Nothing in my conversations with Mr. Mayorkas or in my review of his FBI file has convinced me that we should not be holding this hearing today."

According to the IG's office email to lawmakers, the FBI's Washington Field Office was told about the Mayorkas investigation in June after it inquired about Mayorkas as part of the White House background investigation for his nomination. The investigation does not appear to have any direct ties to Clinton's tenure as secretary of state.

Title: Congressional Research Service Suggests Congressional Power to Halt Presidential Executive Action on Immigration

Article:

In a letter to Senator Jeff Sessions, the Congressional Research Service (CRS) has concluded that Congress has the power to halt President Obama's executive action on immigration, despite the president's use of a fee-based agency to carry out the key work. As Congress prepares to conclude its session, the annual spending bills, the response to Mr. Obama's immigration moves, and the annual defense policy bill are among the chief issues lawmakers must address.

Representative Tom Cotton, an Arkansas Republican, stated that Congress needs to protect its prerogatives. In a recent appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press," Mr. Cotton argued that the employment situation alone should motivate Congress to block the president's executive action. He suggested that the president's first post-election action, easing the employment of illegal immigrants, was not beneficial for working families, while jobs for American workers were still scarce.

Congress is scheduled to conclude its session by December 11, leaving less than two weeks for lawmakers to finish their business. Republican leaders are grappling with decisions on which issues to address now, while Democrats control the Senate, and which issues to defer until the next Congress, when Republicans will have at least 53 seats and control of the Senate and a larger House majority.

The CRS, in its letter to Mr. Sessions, stated that Congress has power over fee-based agencies, even though such agencies have independent sources of funding. The Supreme Court has established that Congress can dictate how an agency spends because all government revenue, even when collected by a fee-based agency, technically goes to the overall fund and is reappropriated to the agency. The CRS noted that the funds available to the agency through fee collections would be subject to the same potential restrictions imposed by Congress on the use of its appropriations as any other type of appropriated fund.

The House Appropriations Committee, which controls the spending process, had previously stated that the annual spending process would not be able to curb the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), the federal agency that will handle most of the president's amnesty. USCIS is almost entirely fee-based, which means it has sources of funding independent of taxpayers. The House Appropriations Committee stated that this meant it had less leverage. However, the CRS analysts argued that Congress does have power, even over fee-based agencies.

Other issues Congress may confront in the coming weeks include December tax and spending deadlines, the expansion of the war in Iraq to combat Islamic State terrorists, and the thorny issue of detainees at Guantanamo Bay when Congress tackles the annual defense policy bill. Additionally, the House and Senate may face the contentious issue of detainees at Guantanamo Bay when Congress addresses the annual defense policy bill. The House and Senate may also confront the thorny issue of detainees at Guantanamo Bay when Congress tackles the annual defense policy bill, which is considered must-pass legislation.

Title: Analysis of the 2012 Presidential Race: Economic Narratives and Upcoming Debates

Article:

In the ongoing 2012 Presidential race, the Democratic narrative, as outlined by former President Bill Clinton and Vice President Joe Biden, suggests that President Barack Obama has been burdened with impossibly high expectations regarding jobs and economic growth. The argument is that Obama inherited a dire economic situation, prevented it from worsening, and is now overseeing an improvement, a situation that no one else could have navigated as effectively.

Former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate, is perceived as not doing an adequate job of countering this narrative. Romney's strategy, according to some, is to focus on the economy, as the incumbent president traditionally bears the responsibility for the state of the economy.

One interpretation of the ongoing discourse is that the public is becoming increasingly aware that President Obama inherited an eight-year catastrophic economic situation. Critics argue that, a year ago, the public was beginning to accept the idea that Obama had worsened the situation, not improved it, through his actions.

Another point of contention is the unemployment rate. Critics argue that the high unemployment numbers should be adjusted to account for those who have given up looking for work. They also suggest that the Obama administration has lost sight of the message of economic resurgence, focusing instead on the negative aspects of the economy.

The upcoming presidential debates, scheduled for three times between now and Election Day, are seen as Romney's best opportunity to change the narrative and close the gap in the race. The debates are expected to be closely watched by undecided voters, who are still making up their minds, and by those who enjoy the competitive nature of the debates.

The debates are also seen as an opportunity for Romney to present a more likable and relatable image, in contrast to the president, who has been on stage with a rival for three and a half years. The debates are expected to be a significant factor in the final weeks of the campaign.

Title: Senate Republicans and Democrats Negotiate Stimulus Package Details

Article:

Senate Republicans unveiled a $1-trillion economic stimulus plan last Thursday, proposing direct payments of $1,200 for individuals and $2,400 for joint returns. However, Senate Democrats blocked the bill on Sunday, expressing concerns over its support for big corporations and insufficient aid for working families.

As negotiations continue, Senate Democrats have outlined several requirements to pass the bill, including:

1. President Donald Trump invoking the Defense Production Act to compel private companies to manufacture necessary medical equipment such as respirators and masks.
2. Allocating nearly $40 billion to help states maintain school funding and support colleges during the crisis.
3. Providing states with billions in grant funding to facilitate elections, including expanding early, absentee, and mail voting.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer stated on Monday, "We're very close to reaching a deal. Very close. Our goal is to reach a deal today. And we’re hopeful, even confident, that we will meet that goal." However, Schumer added, "We have the obligation to get the details right."

The current proposal includes one-time lump-sum payments of up to $1,200 for individuals, $2,400 for joint returns, and an additional $500 for each qualifying child. The income limit starts at $75,000 for individuals and $150,000 for joint returns. The amount individuals receive would be reduced by 5% for each dollar of income exceeding these thresholds.

The federal government is expected to use tax filings to determine eligibility for stimulus checks. Individuals who have set up direct deposit with the IRS can expect the payment quicker than those who receive checks by mail.

The last time the federal government sent checks to Americans was in 2008, under President George W. Bush, with the Economic Stimulus Act providing individual tax relief in the form of tax rebates. The payments did not start until late April.

The current stimulus checks, if approved, would be part of the $1-trillion "phase three" package, following the "phase two" bill signed by Trump on Wednesday. The aid package also includes paid sick and family leave, free coronavirus testing, bolstered unemployment insurance, student loan interest payment hold, and a suspension of foreclosures and evictions on FHA-insured mortgages by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

Further details on the financial assistance efforts and the timeline for the stimulus checks are subject to change during the appropriations process in Congress.

Title: California Assembly Bill 5 Threatens to Reshape Gig Economy, Heads to Governor's Desk

Article:

California lawmakers have passed Assembly Bill 5 (AB5), a legislation that could significantly alter the business models of companies like Uber and Lyft. The bill, which was passed in the state Assembly in a 61-16 vote, now heads to Democratic California Governor Gavin Newsom's desk.

AB5 aims to reclassify gig economy workers as employees instead of contractors. If signed into law, this bill would require companies like Uber and Lyft to provide benefits such as minimum wage, insurance, and sick days to their workers.

Uber and Lyft have stated that AB5 will not immediately change the status of their independent contractors to employees. Tony West, Uber's chief legal officer, said on a call with reporters that the bill builds on legal tests already established in California regarding worker classification. West suggested that drivers may not necessarily fall under the new rules outlined in AB5.

Under the three-part test, a company must prove that contractors are doing work "outside the usual course" of its business. West stated that several previous rulings have found that drivers' work is outside the usual course of Uber's business, which is serving as a technology platform for various digital marketplaces.

Uber and Lyft have informed their drivers that they may need to implement shifts if workers are classified as employees. This would limit when ride-hailing drivers can start and stop accepting rides. In a notice to drivers, Lyft also stated that drivers might only be allowed to work for one ride-hailing service at a time.

Governor Newsom has been engaged in talks with Uber, Lyft, and other gig economy companies about possible negotiations around the bill. Newsom is expected to sign the bill, after voicing support for it earlier this month.

AB5 has received broad support from Democratic presidential candidates, including Senators Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, and Kamala Harris, as well as South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg. The bill has the potential to affect more than 1 million low-wage workers in California, not just gig workers at companies like Uber, Lyft, DoorDash, Postmates, and Instacart.

In response to the bill, Uber and Lyft have proposed establishing a $21-an-hour minimum wage for drivers in California. The ride-hailing companies, as well as DoorDash, have also pledged $90 million on a ballot initiative for the 2020 election that would exempt them from AB5. Uber and Lyft are open to investing more on the initiative and are working to include other businesses that face similar issues with AB5.

Title: Prosecutors Leave Open Possibility of New Charges Against Manafort for Lying

Article:

The special counsel's team, led by Robert Mueller, has left open the possibility of filing new charges against Paul Manafort for lying during his interviews with the special counsel's office. Manafort's lawyers have stated that he believes he was honest during these interviews.

The filing was signed by Andrew Weissmann, a prosecutor known for his aggressive approach, who has been a target of President Trump's criticism. On Friday, President Trump tweeted, "He wrongly destroyed people's lives," referring to Weissmann.

This filing concludes a busy week for Mueller's team. On Friday, they also filed a sentencing recommendation for Michael D. Cohen, President Trump's former lawyer. The prosecutors accused Cohen of using his power and influence "for deceptive ends" and sought about four years in prison for him when he is sentenced next week. Cohen is facing charges for lying to Congress about the extent of President Trump's business dealings in Moscow, as well as for campaign finance violations and other charges.

Manafort, who was convicted by a Northern Virginia jury in August of eight counts of financial fraud, agreed to a plea deal on the verge of a second trial. However, the special counsel's office declared that he had violated the plea agreement.

The prosecutors have previously accused Konstantin V. Kilimnik, a Russian they claim Manafort was in touch with, of ties to Russian intelligence. Kilimnik, a Russian Army-trained linguist, served as Manafort's right-hand man in Ukraine for over a decade, working on behalf of the country's Russia-aligned former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, his party, and the oligarchs behind it.

In Friday's filing, prosecutors blacked out much of the information related to Kilimnik, but revealed that some of it had been uncovered in emails and testimony. They claimed that Manafort lied about various interactions and meetings with him, as well as his involvement with witnesses who might testify against Manafort.

Title: DNC Assists Iowa Democratic Party in Caucus Results Verification Following App Malfunction

Article:

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) is taking an active role in verifying the results of Monday's botched Iowa caucus count, as state party officials remain unable to provide a timeline for releasing the remaining tally, according to a report by ABC News.

DNC staffers have been contacting leaders of each precinct to verify the results, with Polk County Democratic chairman Sean Bagniewski and Des Moines precinct chairman Carl Voss confirming these calls. An anonymous Democratic official also reported similar experiences. They all stated that this level of DNC involvement in caucus results has not occurred in previous elections.

In a series of tweets Tuesday evening, DNC chairman Tom Perez expressed that DNC staffers were "assisting" the Iowa Democratic Party (IDP) to ensure the results are released as soon and as accurately as possible. Perez emphasized the importance of counting all votes and maintaining accuracy.

The IDP has been in turmoil since Monday night, when an app commissioned by the IDP and created by Shadow Inc. to streamline the process of reporting caucus results malfunctioned, causing problems for precinct chairs across the state when downloading or logging into the app. As of Wednesday afternoon, only 71 percent of results had been released by the IDP, and IDP chairman Troy Price has refused to provide a timeline for when the remaining 29 percent of results will be verified and made public.

"We're going to take the time we need to get these results done," Price said Tuesday. A spokesperson for the DNC could not be reached for comment by The Post.
