Title: White Men in Ohio Favor Bernie Sanders in Economic Discontent

Article:

In the ongoing Democratic primary race, Bernie Sanders' victory in Michigan last week has shifted the narrative, with white men playing a significant role in his success. If Sanders manages to win in Ohio, this demographic is likely to remain crucial.

Jim, a self-proclaimed "angry white man" who requested anonymity due to his union, AFSCME, endorsing Hillary Clinton, expressed his support for Sanders. "We're pissed off," Jim said. "We haven't gotten raises. Our pensions have been cut. Our healthcare's increased." He added, "Bernie, he speaks from the trenches."

In Michigan, Sanders won the support of 62 percent of white men, who comprised one-third of voters, according to exit polls. In the 2008 Democratic primary in Ohio, white men turned out in similar proportions.

Black voters could make up a smaller proportion of the electorate and may not be enough to secure a win for Clinton. In Michigan, Clinton won more than two-thirds of black voters, who were 21 percent of the electorate. In 2008, Barack Obama won nearly 90 percent of black voters in Ohio, who were 18 percent of the electorate, with Clinton winning the state with the support of white voters, including white men.

Ryan, a member of a building trades union in Cleveland who also requested anonymity due to his union's endorsement of Clinton, shares Jim's sentiments. "She's [Clinton] seen as the centrist candidate," Ryan said. "And she's a big-money candidate. And big money and centrism hasn't been working for middle-class America for the past 30 years."

When Ryan first saw Sanders speak a few months ago, something resonated. He felt as if a politician was finally saying what he had been thinking about the state of the country. Ryan was so swayed he even sent a small donation to Sanders' campaign and later bought a T-shirt.

At a union hall in Cleveland, both Jim and Ryan discussed rising healthcare costs and trade deals they believe have hurt more than helped. Sanders overwhelmingly won voters in Michigan who thought trade deals cost American jobs—58 percent of voters said so, and Sanders won them 2-to-1.

Jim stated he's only received one raise, really more like a cost-of-living adjustment, in eight years. "You look at the stock market," he said, "it's gone up I don't know how many, a couple of hundred percent. You know, my wages have gone up 2-and-a-half percent. And who's speaking to that? Bernie is."

Sanders' attacks on Clinton's trade record, her superPAC, and her big money speeches to Wall Street banks are resonating. The money issue is a concern for Dave Passalacqua. He appreciates that Sanders gets his campaign cash from regular people.

Passalacqua is the executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America Local 4340 in Cleveland. His union has endorsed Sanders, but he's still undecided.

Passalacqua agreed to meet at a Cleveland diner with Jim Goggin, a fixture in the city's labor community. Goggin, an organizer for the Delaware Valley Health Care Coalition, expressed doubts about Sanders' promises. "It's pie in the sky," Goggin said. "I mean, everything Bernie says, I think would be fantastic. But the fact of the matter is, that I am also a realist, and I know that you can't do that."

For Goggin, the priority is defeating the Republicans in November. "And I wish to God that I thought he could win," Goggin said. "But I don't unfortunately think he can win. Consequently, I'm with Hillary, because at least she's not going to throw us under the bus, the working people."

Passalacqua added, "And one good thing that Bernie's been doing, though, even with Hillary, is Bernie has moved Hillary's positions on things."

Despite their doubts, all four men interviewed stated they would support the Democratic nominee in November. Passalacqua expressed a classic voter's struggle between his head and his heart, unsure if Sanders can deliver on his promises. "Whoever I think is going best for me and my family is the bottom line," Passalacqua said. "Whoever is going to make—not to steal Donald's line—but America great again, that's who I'll end up having to vote for."

Title: A Considered Approach to Coronavirus Reopening Strategy: Controlled Avalanche and Protecting the Vulnerable

Article:

As the United States grapples with the question of how to reopen society amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, the debate seems to be dividing into three main groups. The first group believes the virus is not particularly serious and wants a swift reopening, a small minority of Americans according to polling data. The second group views the virus as extraordinarily serious and advocates for prolonged closures, a significant minority of Americans. The third group, comprising the vast majority, acknowledges the severity of the virus, the economic damage caused by the pandemic, and advocates for a measured, considered reopening strategy.

The question of a considered coronavirus reopening strategy hinges on the assumptions underlying policy recommendations. The primary objective is to minimize deaths, but the assumptions regarding vaccine development timelines, herd immunity, and therapeutic measures are crucial. The economic impact is also a significant factor, with assumptions about the resilience of businesses and the government's ability to shoulder additional debt.

If the worst-case scenario is assumed—no significant therapeutic advancements, no vaccines for 18 months or more, and an economy functioning at a quarter or half of its normal capacity—a strategy known as controlled avalanche may be the best option. This strategy, proposed by Israeli scientists, involves tranching populations and exposing the least vulnerable to COVID-19 to develop antibodies, similar to the controlled avalanches created by ski resorts to prevent major avalanches.

Data suggests that a significant portion of COVID-19 deaths in the European Union and in California have occurred in nursing homes. If authorities had adequately protected nursing homes, the infection fatality rate across the industrialized world could be half of the current rate. The infection fatality rate for COVID-19 also varies widely by age, with a low number of deaths among those under 45 and under 25, and most deaths occurring in individuals with underlying conditions.

Israeli scientists propose protecting the elderly and vulnerable and allowing herd immunity to develop among the least vulnerable, which could significantly reduce overall mortality, reduce the number of people requiring intensive care units (ICUs), and shorten the time needed to allow low-risk populations freedom by months.

While this strategy is not foolproof, it may offer a better approach than simply hoping for the best while the world economy collapses, even as the hope for a deus ex machina may remain unfulfilled. The key to a considered reopening strategy lies in understanding and addressing the underlying assumptions that guide policy recommendations.

Title: Trump Administration Abandons Defense of ACA, Potentially Affecting Pre-Existing Condition Protections

Article:

The Trump administration's decision to withdraw its defense of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in an ongoing court challenge could potentially impact the law's popular provisions regarding pre-existing conditions. This move intensifies the ongoing health care debate during an election year.

In February, 20 states sued the federal government, claiming the individual mandate is unconstitutional after Congress zeroed out the tax penalty for not having health insurance in its 2017 tax cut law. The lawsuit, led by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, argues that without an individual mandate, the entire ACA is unconstitutional.

If this argument prevails in the courts, it would render unconstitutional Obamacare provisions that ban insurance companies from denying coverage to people with pre-existing conditions. According to the Department of Health and Human Services, as many as 130 million adults under age 65 in the U.S. have pre-existing conditions that could potentially prevent them from obtaining insurance coverage in the private market.

Before the ACA became law, insurance companies routinely declined health insurance coverage to people with ongoing medical conditions or recent illnesses. Even when insurers offered policies to those with health problems, they often excluded those illnesses. Insurance companies could also cancel coverage for people who became ill once the policy year ended.

The ACA made all those practices illegal. By withdrawing from defending the law in court, the Trump administration is effectively stating that it no longer supports these consumer protections, which are popular with voters. This move could disrupt insurance markets for next year and change the dynamic of this fall's elections.

Larry Levitt, senior vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, states, "This suit comes as insurers are proposing individual market premiums for 2019. The lawsuit injects more uncertainty into what is already an uncertain environment for insurers. Insurers hate uncertainty, and they respond to it by hedging their bets and increasing premiums."

Nicholas Bagley, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School who was a Justice Department lawyer, finds the move troubling. "The Justice Department has a long-standing, durable, bipartisan commitment to defend acts of Congress. It's a cornerstone of what they do. For the Trump administration to crumple that up and throw it out the window is galling," he says.

Just hours before the Justice Department officially withdrew from the case, three of the staff attorneys who had been working on it withdrew. Bagley notes, "These are civil servants. They're not political. They are good soldiers. Their job is to defend federal programs." He adds, "They believed they could not in good conscience, consistent with their professional obligations, sign the brief. These are people who defend programs they disagree with all the time."

The Justice Department has opted not to defend existing law in the courts in other matters. For instance, in 2012, the Obama Justice Department said it would not defend the Defense of Marriage Act, which legally defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman for federal purposes.

America's Health Insurance Plans, the trade association for health insurance companies, supports the pre-existing condition protections under the ACA. "Removing those provisions will result in renewed uncertainty in the individual market, create a patchwork of requirements in the states, cause rates to go even higher for older Americans and sicker patients, and make it challenging to introduce products and rates for 2019," AHIP said in a statement.

AHIP plans to file an amicus brief in support of the law that "provides more detail about the harm that would come to millions of Americans if the request to invalidate the ACA is granted in whole or in part."

On Capitol Hill, congressional Republicans' reaction to the Trump administration's decision was muted, with many lawmakers voicing skepticism that the courts would ultimately rule against a law already upheld by the Supreme Court.

"We need to let that go forward and see if it goes anywhere," said Rep. Tom MacArthur, R-N.J. "I do not know if that legal logic will fly or not." MacArthur worked on legislation to continue pre-existing condition protections during the GOP's unsuccessful effort to repeal Obamacare last year.

Health care is already a dominant issue in this year's elections, with voters regularly citing it as a leading determinant for how they will vote. "There is no doubt that Republicans are responsible for the rising cost of healthcare premiums and the high likelihood that many will no longer be able to afford basic care at all, and they will face serious blowback in the midterms," the House Democrats' campaign operation said in a statement.

Title: CNN's Brian Stelter Criticizes Republican Candidates for Using Media Bias Claims to Deflect Questions and Increase Polarization

Article:

In a piece during Thursday's AC360, CNN's senior media correspondent, Brian Stelter, discussed the tactic of Republican presidential candidates using claims of media bias to deflect tough questions and increase polarization among the electorate.

Stelter began by stating that it is a common strategy for Republican politicians to make claims of media bias, which he referred to as a "shield and a sword." He suggested that this tactic is not because the liberal media is inherently biased, but rather to deflect unwelcome questions and to project strength by putting the press on the defensive.

During the CNBC debate on Wednesday night, Stelter noted that several candidates effectively employed media bashing, and raising the issue made for easy applause lines in front of conservative audiences.

Stelter acknowledged that most journalists strive to remove any and all bias from their stories, but he added that many conservatives are skeptical of this claim. He then criticized conservatives for contributing to political polarization in America by not aligning with the media.

According to Stelter, the result of this lack of alignment is more political polarization, as per a Pew Research Center study that indicates the more conservative one is, the fewer mainstream media sources one trusts. Fox News and some candidates have benefited from this trend, Stelter argued.

Stelter questioned if the questions posed by CNBC were any tougher than those posed by Fox News or CNN, and he quoted University of Virginia's Larry Sabato, who defended the CNBC moderators for trying to uncover the truth. Sabato stated, "Some of the criticism is for show. What those moderators at CNBC were trying to do was to get candidates to tell more of the truth."

The relevant transcript from CNN's Anderson Cooper 360 on October 29 can be found below.

Title: North Korea Conducts Sixth Nuclear Test, Boosting Weapon Capabilities and Escalating Tensions

Article:

North Korea has conducted its sixth nuclear test, reportedly detonating a hydrogen bomb with a yield of approximately 100 kilotons, making it seven times stronger than the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. The test, which took place on September 3 at the Punggye-ri testing site, was followed by a series of strong reactions from regional allies and the international community.

The United States Geological Survey registered a 6.3-magnitude earthquake at the testing site, indicating the detonation of a hydrogen bomb. Experts, including Jeffrey Lewis, an expert on North Korea's missile program at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, estimate that the device is around seven times stronger than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima. This test marks North Korea's first nuclear test during the Trump administration.

Hours before the test, the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), North Korea's state-run media organization, released images of the country's leader, Kim Jong Un, overseeing the loading of a hydrogen bomb onto an intercontinental ballistic missile. After the test, KCNA stated that the test was conducted to "examine and confirm the accuracy and credibility" of the weapon.

Jeffrey Lewis stated, "North Korea wants the ability to target the United States. A thermonuclear weapon does more damage." Vipin Narang, a nuclear expert at MIT, added that even with relatively inaccurate intercontinental ballistic missile technology, North Korea can destroy the better part of a city with this yield.

Following the test, President Donald Trump tweeted his displeasure, stating, "North Korea has conducted a major Nuclear Test. Their words and actions continue to be very hostile and dangerous to the United States." Trump also claimed that China has had "little success" in stopping North Korea's nuclear program and that South Korea's "talk of appeasement with North Korea will not work."

Secretary of Defense James Mattis offered a stern warning to North Korea after a meeting of national security leaders with the president. "Any threat to the United States or its territories, including Guam, or our allies, will be met with a massive military response—a response both effective and overwhelming," he said.

Regional allies South Korea and Japan also reacted strongly. South Korean President Moon Jae-in convened a meeting of his national security team, and his national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, stated that Seoul wants the "most powerful sanctions" placed on North Korea at the United Nations.

Japan sent out a statement of disapproval, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stating, "It is absolutely unacceptable if North Korea did force another nuclear test, and we must protest strongly." On August 29, North Korea launched a missile into Japanese airspace that eventually landed about 733 miles east of the country.

It remains unclear if the Japanese government finds North Korea's latest nuclear test more threatening than the missile launch. Trump could respond with a military strike, but that is still unlikely. The Trump administration still prefers a diplomatic approach toward Pyongyang in hopes that it would give up its nuclear weapons. However, it is unclear what incentive North Korea has to stop its nuclear program, especially now that it has tested a powerful hydrogen bomb. This will make it much harder for Trump to strike a deal with the North.

Title: Illinois State Workers Receive Automatic Pay Raise Amidst Unemployment Crisis; Federal Aid to States Debated

Article:

On July 1, Illinois state workers received an automatic pay raise, costing taxpayers $261 million. This move comes as nearly 1.4 million Illinois residents have filed for unemployment since the COVID-19 pandemic forced widespread economic shutdowns in March.

While some state governments have implemented cost-cutting measures in response to significant revenue shortfalls, Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker signed a budget that increases spending by $2.4 billion over the previous year and relies on $5 billion from a nonexistent federal bailout to partially address a $6 billion deficit.

In contrast, governors in Washington, Pennsylvania, New York, and Virginia have implemented measures such as canceled pay raises, furloughs, and 15% agency spending cuts for fiscal year 2021. The ongoing debate in Congress regarding additional aid to state and local governments, with a potential new coronavirus relief package expected this month, highlights the polarized views on the issue.

Some on the right are philosophically opposed to offering aid to struggling states, while the left advocates for up to $1 trillion in additional aid without regard for the actual amount needed or safeguards for the funds. The recession and pandemic have created legitimate challenges for government finances, but a compromise solution could avoid rewarding irresponsible behavior in states with a history of financial mismanagement.

Congress can offer more aid, but only if it is conditioned on sound financial management to protect taxpayers from tax increases or service failures. Attaching "strings" to financial rescues is a common practice, as seen in relief packages following the 2010 Greek debt crisis, the 2007-2009 U.S. bank bailouts, and the corporate financial assistance under the recently passed CARES Act.

To ensure good money isn't wasted, conditions should be placed on federal aid to states such as Illinois, New Jersey, and Connecticut, which have accumulated significant debt burdens due to decades of poor financial decisions unrelated to the COVID-19 pandemic. Funding should be conditioned on three hallmarks of healthy state finances: sound pensions, truly balanced budgets, and sufficient rainy-day savings.

First, states must be on a path to fully eliminating unfunded pension liabilities over no more than 25 years, in line with generally accepted actuarial principles. If a state cannot achieve this, pension liabilities should be reduced to the level the state can afford without increasing employer contributions, i.e., taxpayer costs. States with unsound pension systems should be required to close those systems to new employees in exchange for more sustainable models such as a defined contribution plan or Wisconsin-style risk-sharing systems.

Second, any state receiving funds should be asked to maintain a truly balanced budget, meaning the fiscal year ends in the black and no deficits are carried over. Illinois is one of just 11 states that does not require end-of-year balance by state law or constitution. Balance should also mean only money actually coming in gets counted as revenue, rather than allowing for Illinois-style gimmicks such as sweeping money from other state funds or relying on short-term borrowing to paper over deficits.

Lastly, states should have restrictions on rainy-day fund withdrawals to ensure they are only used in emergencies and have rules for automatic deposits when the economy returns to growth. The federal government should not be expected to bail out states in every future recession, and that means states must have sufficient emergency savings of their own.

Without these reforms and proof of effort by state governments, fiscally irresponsible states would use aid money in an inefficient and ineffective manner – just as they've done with their own mismanaged funds for decades. Federal lawmakers have a significant opportunity in front of them: they can provide aid to ensure the people have access to essential government services while encouraging mismanaged states to fix their tumbledown fiscal houses.

Title: Minneapolis Sports Bar Owner's Business Destroyed During Protests

Article:

A Minneapolis sports bar owner, Korboi Balla, saw his life's work reduced to ruins after looters destroyed his establishment during the widespread rioting and looting that followed the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died in Minneapolis police custody on Monday. Balla, a black firefighter, had been preparing to open his bar after Minnesota allowed restaurants to reopen on June 1, following a delay due to the coronavirus crisis.

On Thursday morning, while CBS News was interviewing Balla, looters attempted to break into his bar to steal the safe. Balla's wife, Twyana Balla, shared this incident in a Facebook post, stating, "As we were standing in front of the restaurant, people were in the back trying to steal the safe!" She also mentioned that they do not have insurance for their business.

By Friday morning, Balla's bar was little more than a pile of bricks. Twyana Balla shared a video on Facebook, stating, "There must have been an explosion because the whole front part of the building is gone."

In response to the destruction, Balla launched a GoFundMe campaign to raise funds for rebuilding his bar. The crowdfunding campaign has raised over $173,000 in its first 24 hours.

According to the Twin Cities Pioneer Press, more than 170 businesses in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area have been damaged or looted since Floyd's death on Monday.

Title: FBI Email Review Resurfaces Clinton Email Scandal, Altering Presidential Race Landscape

Article:

The 2016 presidential campaign, described as the most unpredictable, surprising, and contentious in modern times, is entering its final full week. The race has taken a dramatic turn as Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, who previously seemed to be on a path to historical victory, now faces renewed scrutiny over her use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State.

The FBI's review of new emails from longtime Clinton aide Huma Abedin found on the computer of her estranged husband, Anthony Weiner, ensures that an issue that has dogged Clinton since the beginning of her campaign will remain at the forefront until the election.

Democrats are expressing frustration with FBI Director James Comey for reopening the investigation, while Republican nominee Donald Trump is seizing the opportunity to unite a Republican base that has been divided by his controversial candidacy.

Some surveys suggest a tightening race, though CNN's Poll of Polls currently has Clinton ahead by five points. The question now is whether this late-in-the-game twist will bring a final, shocking turn—a November surprise—before the campaign concludes.

Clinton, who was previously cleared of any criminal charges in July regarding her use of a private email server, now faces renewed criticism and questions about her honesty, secrecy, and involvement in scandals. Clinton's campaign is responding by shifting its focus to attacking Trump, in line with their campaign-long effort to portray him as unfit for the presidency due to his moral and intellectual shortcomings.

Clinton will travel to Florida, Ohio, and North Carolina in the coming days, where she is in a tight race with Trump, and North Carolina where she is leading. By winning any one of these states, Clinton can block Trump's path to the presidency. She will also make a foray into Arizona, a traditionally red state that appears competitive a week out.

Clinton will also leverage her advantage over Trump by dispatching former President Bill Clinton, President Barack Obama, and First Lady Michelle Obama to battleground states. However, Clinton's campaign faces nervous days ahead, with the potential for further damaging twists in the email saga, more WikiLeaks releases of John Podesta's emails, and the scheduled release of more Clinton emails from the State Department on Friday.

Many Democrats believe the character issue is already baked into polls that show Clinton as the favorite to win the election. However, her plans for a smooth run to Election Day have been disrupted, and her campaign has been forced into a tactical shift, unleashing its full fury on the FBI chief.

``This is something that has been tossed into the middle of the campaign,'' Clinton's campaign chairman John Podesta said on "State of the Union." ``We would have preferred that that not happen, but now that it has happened, Mr. Comey really needs to come forward and explain why he took this unprecedented step.''

However, spending time attacking the FBI director is time that could be used to make a closing argument for Clinton or to attack Trump. For the moment, Clinton is using the move as a rallying cry to drive up Democratic turnout.

``There have been ups and downs in all that we have gone through over the years and even in this campaign, but I want you to know I am focused on one thing: you,'' Clinton told supporters in Florida on Sunday. ``There's a lot of noise and distraction, but really comes down to what kind of future we want.''

In the hours after Comey's Friday bombshell, Trump and his aides could barely contain their glee. A campaign that had seemed headed for certain defeat grabbed gratefully onto the late October gift, immediately using the revelations to bolster Trump's theme that Clinton is a crook, broke the law with her email server, and is symptomatic of a corrupt political status quo.

However, it remains to be seen whether Trump can effectively use this new information to his advantage in the final days of the campaign. Trump's presidential bid has been plagued by his failure to turn a trove of material detrimental to Clinton into sustained attacks. He has been repeatedly undermined by his own indiscipline and tendency to detonate controversies that harm him more than his opponent.

``The problem with the Trump campaign all along is that they've had lots of potential material, a lot of grist for the mill that he has failed to prosecute,'' said Mark McKinnon, former strategist for President George W. Bush and Sen. John McCain on "State of the Union." ``Trump needs to just for once maintain a clear and constant focus for the next 10 days on the issues that can move the dial.''

To mount a stunning comeback on November 8, Trump must also improve his position on the political map. He must forge ahead in Florida and Ohio, cut his deficit to Clinton in North Carolina, capitalize on an advantage in Iowa, then find a way to put states like New Hampshire and Nevada, that went for Obama, in play. He could carve out a decisive edge by making a big blue state like Pennsylvania or Michigan competitive—though polls suggest that is a long shot.

But Trump's team must also be wondering, even as they salivate over Clinton's woes, if there is one last big shock awaiting Trump, following October Surprise controversies over claims he sexually assaulted women and an "Access Hollywood" tape exposing his lewd language that left him so far behind his rival that he starts the campaign's last week possibly too far behind to catch up.

Title: Terrorism and Cultural Tensions: A Comparative Analysis of the U.S. and France

Article:

The recent terrorist attacks in Orlando, Florida, and the previous incidents in San Bernardino and Paris have raised concerns about the global threat of Islamic extremism. The source of these attacks, whether they are lone wolf attacks or coordinated by terrorist organizations like ISIS, remains uncertain.

The United States and France are both grappling with the aftermath of these attacks, with the U.S. experiencing a sense of being under siege due to the recent Islamic extremist terrorism incidents. However, it is important to note that the U.S. is also suffering from an epidemic of domestic violence, such as the mass shootings in Dallas, Roseburg, Charleston, Newtown, and Aurora.

France, on the other hand, appears to be the epicenter for ISIS-coordinated terrorism, as opposed to lone wolf or locally inspired splinter groups. This is attributed to France's long colonial history in the Middle East, its experience in Algeria, and its traditional cultural intolerance. The country has the largest Muslim population in Europe, and its insistence on strict adaptation to French mores has created a combustible mixture in a dangerous time.

The U.S., despite its horrific history, has generally been one of the best at assimilating culturally diverse populations. Muslims were easily accepted into American society for many decades, but post-9/11, this acceptance has waned. There are now reports of profiling and investigations of Muslims, as well as protests against the building of mosques.

France, however, is in the midst of a serious homegrown Islamic terrorism crisis. The country's people are grappling with the extent of their tolerance, and there are concerns about draconian solutions. In the U.S., despite a different scale of violence, there is a political figure, Donald Trump, who is advocating for drastic measures such as banning Muslims and building a wall to keep out immigrants from Mexico and Central America.

Despite these challenges, both countries' underlying commitment to diversity remains, and American Muslims still believe in it. The hope is that these radical extremists are sowing the seeds of their own demise by bringing the world together in solidarity rather than inciting people to turn on one another. The empathy felt by the vast majority of the human population in the face of these attacks is a testament to our common humanity.

Title: Democratic Party Faces Potential Internal Strife as Republican Party Struggles

Article:

In a recent appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press," New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman suggested that the Republican Party might need to "crash and burn" to give way to a more "sane" version of the party. This perspective, shared by some Democratic establishment figures and media personalities, envisions a one-party political landscape in the United States.

While it is not inaccurate to predict or advocate for such a scenario, it is important to recognize that such daydreams overlook a significant factor: both parties may face internal strife and potential civil wars.

The Republican Party's internal divide, exacerbated by the Donald Trump presidency, is undeniable. However, the Democratic Party may also face significant challenges, particularly if a Democrat resides in the White House, especially an unpopular figure like Hillary Clinton.

One source of potential conflict within the Democratic Party stems from the 2016 primary election. Senator Bernie Sanders and his supporters believe that the Democratic National Committee (DNC) rigged the primary process against him. The resignation of Debbie Wasserman Schultz, following the first WikiLeaks revelation, and the expected departure of interim Chairwoman Donna Brazile, following the second such revelation, underscore this belief.

Sanders has also announced his intention to oppose government action, including laws or policies not sufficiently leftist, which could put him at odds with Hillary Clinton, particularly on economic and regulatory issues. Additionally, Senator Elizabeth Warren, who endorsed Clinton in June, holds views on economic policy and business regulation that mirror Sanders' to a significant extent.

Another potential source of conflict within the Democratic Party concerns Supreme Court nominations. Hillary Clinton might face pressure to select a nominee who aligns with the views of Sanders and Warren, risking a Republican filibuster. Alternatively, she might choose a more moderate nominee to secure Republican support, which could lead to internal discord within the Democratic Party.

A vocal minority of the Democratic base, including some who supported Green Party candidate Jill Stein, opposes much of Clinton's agenda. This faction, much like Trump supporters, is ideological and unwilling to compromise, potentially leading to contentious debates within the party.

Unlike Trump supporters, however, these progressive Democrats' debates may take place in the public eye, given their opposition to Clinton. This could make Clinton's presidency a tumultuous four years, with the Democratic infighting serving as a notable contrast to what is expected to be a relatively uneventful term in office.

Title: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo Addresses Human Life Value and Abortion in Press Conference

Article:

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, during a recent press conference discussing the gradual reopening of the state, addressed the value of human life and the inconsistencies in policies related to abortion.

In his speech, Cuomo rhetorically asked, "How much is a human life worth?" He continued, stating, "That is the real discussion that no one is admitting, openly or freely. That we should. To me, I say the cost of a human life—a human life is priceless. Period."

The governor's comments come amidst concerns about nursing home policies and the continued operation of abortion clinics during the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2019, Cuomo expanded legal abortion in New York, an action that was celebrated with the lighting of the Freedom Tower and the bridge named after his father. Last year, he also expressed support for legalizing assisted suicide in the state.

During the quarantine, New York State has also become a surrogacy state, a move that has been met with opposition from a coalition of pro-lifers and liberal feminists, who argue that it can lead to the exploitation of women.

The Sisters of Life, a Catholic religious community based in New York, have been approached by women, including those inside abortion clinics, who feel they have no choice but to undergo abortions due to the pressure in their lives. The Sisters of Life advocate for the pricelessness of every human life, emphasizing that each person is chosen by a Creator who loves them and created them in His image and likeness.

Governor Cuomo's comments have sparked discussions about the inconsistencies in policies related to human life, and calls for open and honest discussions about the value of life and the need for consistency in policies.

Title: Dreamers Express Disappointment as Democratic Leaders Delay Dream Act Push to Early 2018

Article:

Illegal immigrant Dreamers, who had set a year-end deadline for the passage of the Dream Act, expressed disappointment this week as Democratic leaders signaled they would revisit the immigration issue in early 2018. Hundreds of Dreamers, some risking arrest, protested in Congress, demanding the passage of the Dream Act, a bill that would grant temporary legal status to over 2 million illegal immigrants and allow 1.7 million of them to earn green cards.

Final negotiations were ongoing late Wednesday over the shape of a year-end spending bill, which includes an extension of the government's chief foreign intelligence communications surveillance program, disaster relief for states and U.S. territories affected by this year's hurricanes, and a renewal of the Children's Health Insurance Program. The biggest moving part, however, is a year-end spending bill needed to avoid a government shutdown when current funding expires on Friday.

House Republicans have proposed full-year funding for the Defense Department coupled with a four-week extension of current funding for domestic needs, known as a "continuing resolution." Democrats have said they won't accept this and insist on parity between defense and domestic programs to allocate money for veterans' health, a pension bailout, opioid-fighting programs, and medical research.

As of late Wednesday, House Republican leaders were still trying to figure out a path forward. Democrats said they were waiting for Republicans. "Unless we see a respect for our values and priorities, we continue to urge a strong NO on the continuing resolution," House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, wrote in a letter to her troops.

Rank-and-file Republicans complained that Democrats were pushing Congress toward a government shutdown by threatening an all-or-nothing Senate filibuster. "The American people sent us the Republican majorities in the House, the Senate, and the White House. And we have to get eight votes on the Democrat side, and we should compromise, right? But it should be proportional to Democratic Senate votes," said Rep. Dave Brat, Virginia Republican.

Usually, it's Republicans facing calls for a shutdown showdown from their right flank. But the Dreamers flipped the script, forcing Democrats into a tight spot by demanding a permanent fix after President Trump announced a phaseout of the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals deportation amnesty. Trump's phaseout kicks in on March 5, but Dreamers set an artificial end-of-year deadline, and Democratic leaders initially agreed, though some have since backed off their red line.

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat who has been a leading voice for Dreamers, said he believed his party's leaders in the House were holding firm in their DACA demand and that some Senate Democrats were also adamant. However, he was less sure about Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, New York Democrat. "I believe that at this particular moment, the onus is on Sen. Schumer," Mr. Gutierrez said. Dreamers were more pointed, saying Mr. Schumer was betraying them.

Dreamers and their defenders did not blame only Democratic leaders; several dozen Republicans said they wanted a DACA solution this year. Sen. Jeff Flake, an Arizona Republican who has been pushing for the Dream Act, said Wednesday that he has assurances the DACA issue will be taken up in January. He said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, "has committed to bring the bipartisan DACA bill we are currently negotiating to the Senate floor" next month.

Mr. Gutierrez said Dreamers can't bank on another promise. "It's very easy for Sen. Flake to send out a tweet this morning and say, 'Dreamers in January.' His kids aren't getting deported. He's going home to his wife. He's celebrating Christmas," he said.

Title: Obama Administration Announces New Gun Control Measures, Including Restrictions on Military Surplus Weapons Imports

Article:

The Obama administration announced two new gun control measures on Thursday, including one that would curb the import of military surplus weapons. The new rules, announced while Washington was otherwise focused on the crisis in Syria, took the form of executive actions, which President Obama added to the list of 23 steps the White House already determined the president could take on his own.

The steps come after Congress declined to pass any gun control legislation earlier this year despite an aggressive White House push for action in the wake of the Newton, Conn., shooting massacre. With the political world focused on Mideast tensions and looming fiscal battles, the move signaled Obama's intent to show he has not lost sight of the issue.

One new policy will end a government practice that lets military weapons, sold or donated by the U.S. to allies, be reimported into the U.S. by private entities. The White House said the U.S. has approved 250,000 of those guns to be reimported since 2005; under the new policy, only museums and a few other entities like the government will be eligible to reimport military-grade firearms.

The Obama administration is also proposing a federal rule to stop those who would be ineligible to pass a background check from skirting the law by registering a gun to a corporation or trust. The new rule would require people associated with those entities, like beneficiaries and trustees, to undergo the same type of fingerprint-based background checks as individuals if they want to register guns.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) said that neither measure would reduce crime, since neither the re-importation of firearms nor the corporate gun registration is known to be a source of weapons for criminals.

The types of surplus weapons that have been re-imported under this provision are all more than 50 years old, and fall under the definition of "curio" or "relic" firearms. They include M1 Garand rifles and several other models. As such, it is safe to assume that few are used in crimes.

The event in the Roosevelt Room where Vice President Biden spoke also marked the ceremonial swearing-in for Todd Jones, whose confirmation to head the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives after six years of political wrangling to fill that position was another of Obama's post-Newtown priorities. A Senate deal to approve the president's pending nominations after Democrats threatened to change Senate rules cleared the way for Jones' confirmation last month.

Still out of reach for Obama were the steps that gun control advocates and the administration's own review say could most effectively combat gun violence in the U.S., like an assault weapons ban and fewer exceptions for background checks for individual sales. Only Congress can act on those fronts.

Although Obama and Biden have said the fight is not over, there is scant evidence that there is more support for gun control legislation than there was in April, when efforts died in the Senate amid staunch opposition from the National Rifle Association and most Republican senators.

"Sooner or later, we are going to get this right," Obama said that day in the White House Rose Garden, with the families of Newtown victims and former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords -- herself a victim of a gunman -- at his side. "The memories of these children demand it, and so do the American people," the president said at the time.

In the months following the Senate vote, Biden has claimed that a handful of lawmakers who opposed expanded background checks have told him privately they've changed their minds and want another chance. But Biden and White House officials have not named any of those lawmakers.

These days, Obama mentions gun control with far less regularity than when it appeared the Senate was poised to take action, although Obama did meet Tuesday with 18 city mayors to discuss ways to contain youth violence. And with immigration and pressing fiscal issues dominating Congress' agenda, the prospects for reviving gun legislation appear negligible. With Jones' confirmation at ATF, the White House has completed or made significant progress on all but one of the 23 executive actions Obama had previously ordered in January, the White House said. Still lingering is an effort to finalize regulations to require insurers to cover mental health at parity with medical benefits, although the White House said that it is committed to making that happen by the end of 2013.

The new rules for guns registered to corporations will follow the traditional regulatory process, with a 90-day comment period before ATF reviews suggestions and finalizes the rule. Last year, ATF received 39,000 requests to register guns to corporations and trusts.

Title: China Steps into Void Left by U.S. Withdrawal from Paris Climate Agreement

Article:

President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement has caused global anger and anxiety, with one notable exception: China. With the U.S. stepping away from its role as a leader in the global fight against climate change, Beijing is moving to fill the void, providing it with opportunities for both diplomatic and economic gains.

This is not the first time President Trump, who campaigned on demonizing China, has inadvertently given Beijing a significant opportunity to expand its global standing. After the U.S. withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, China inserted itself into trade talks among other nations disappointed by America's reversal. As Canada and Mexico have felt spurned by Trump during the runup to renegotiating NAFTA, China has emerged as a more reliable trading partner.

At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Chinese President Xi Jinping criticized the West for its flirtation with protectionism and painted a picture of China as a champion of free trade and an attractive destination for foreign investment. As the U.S. withdraws from the global community's effort to curb carbon emissions, China's profile as a forward-thinking world leader will only grow. It is set to become closer to the U.S.'s allies that feel abandoned by Trump's recent actions, as well as take a more aggressive lead in building a green economy.

Alex Wang, an environmental law professor at the University of California Los Angeles, stated, "While the U.S. is breaking these ties, China — which has traditionally been more reserved in international affairs — is building them at breakneck pace. As the U.S. loses goodwill, China is building it."

The reshuffling of the world order in the wake of Trump's announcement could be seen almost immediately, with top Chinese and European leaders criticizing the U.S.'s withdrawal side by side on Thursday. Standing next to German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said that "fighting climate change is a global consensus" and pledged that China would remain committed to the Paris agreement. Merkel said, "The cooperation of the European Union with China in this area will play a crucial role, especially in regards to new technologies."

In a statement to the press, Miguel Arias Cañete, the European Union commissioner on climate action and energy, made the point even more forcefully: "No one should be left behind, but the EU and China have decided to move forward. Our successful cooperation on issues like emissions trading and clean technologies are bearing fruit. Now is the time to further strengthen these ties to keep the wheels turning for ambitious global climate action."

It won't be the last time that Beijing and Brussels find themselves seeing eye to eye, or that the two sides look past the U.S. and look to work on joint initiatives that don't involve Washington. And Europe and China's enhanced cooperation is quite likely to go beyond coordinating on climate change.

"These agreements... build ties and align interests in ways that reduce the likelihood of conflict and bolster the opportunities for greater growth and development," Wang says.

If Europe and China are actually able to grow closer through their coordination on climate change, it could potentially build a better relationship for navigating conflicts over trade. In the meantime, the U.S. and Europe are going through the roughest patch they've had since they split over the Iraq War in 2003. Even before Trump pulled out of the Paris agreement on Thursday, he had already alienated Europe during his trip abroad last week, when he, among other things, refused to reaffirm America's commitment to NATO and accused Germany of being a trade cheat.

Trump's America First agenda has been a huge gift to China. The impact of Trump's withdrawal from the world stage is bigger than China's relationship with Europe. Consider how, on his first full working day as president, he withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, an agreement that would have boosted trade ties between the U.S. and 11 countries along the Pacific Rim and generated the largest trade bloc the world had ever seen. The accord would have strengthened ties between the U.S. and a number of China's neighbors and would have served as a counterweight to Beijing's increasing influence in the region (China was not part of the deal). Now, Trump's move means that Beijing has a major opportunity to step into that vacuum and negotiate a regional trade deal that basically serves as a China-centric version of the TPP. It's already making efforts to do exactly that.

China has generally been eager to capitalize on Trump's protectionist tendencies. In his World Economic Forum speech, Chinese President Xi warned against rising nationalism in the West and defended free trade. This is China lecturing the U.S. and Europe about free trade. China's economy has liberalized significantly in recent decades, but it's a country that flagrantly disregards all kinds of global trade rules, from denying market access to foreign companies to subsidizing many of its key industries. But when you have the most powerful politician in the world calling for 45 percent tariffs against other countries, Xi doesn't look so preposterous.

If there's one realm where China is set to best the U.S. in the wake of Paris, it's in developing a sustainable economy. It's already investing more than the U.S. in clean energy—in 2016, it invested more than $88 billion to the U.S.'s $59 billion—but the gap between the U.S. and China will grow as the U.S. decides that renewable energy investment isn't a priority. And it will grow fast. America First is turning out to be anything but.

Title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Portions of Affordable Care Act, Leaving Future of Healthcare Program Uncertain

Article:

A federal judge in Texas has ruled that certain aspects of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, are unconstitutional. The ruling, which is expected to be appealed, could potentially have significant implications for the healthcare coverage of millions of Americans.

In a 55-page ruling, U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor, a George W. Bush appointee, agreed with a coalition of Republican-led states that the individual mandate, which requires individuals to either purchase health insurance or pay a penalty, is unconstitutional. The judge's decision was based on the elimination of the penalty for not having health insurance, a provision of the $1.5 trillion tax overhaul passed by Congress last December.

The ruling is likely to be appealed by California and other states to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which is dominated by Republican-appointed judges. The expected lengthy court fight between Republican and Democratic state officials over the ruling could potentially end up at the Supreme Court, which has twice previously voted to uphold other challenges to the ACA.

While President Donald Trump hailed the ruling as "great news for America," the White House acknowledged that the law remains in place while the lawsuit is appealed. Trump, who has long criticized the ACA, called on Congress to pass a "STRONG law that provides GREAT healthcare." In a statement, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who is expected to become House Speaker in January, expressed no interest in compromise and vowed to intervene in the appeals process when Democrats take control of the House next month.

The ruling has no immediate effect, and consumers who buy insurance through federal or state marketplaces can still purchase 2019 coverage through Saturday. If the ruling is upheld after the appeal process, however, subsidies that people collect to buy health coverage would no longer be available, and Medicaid, which has extended insurance coverage to millions of low-income and working-class Americans, could also be in jeopardy.

Many GOP candidates took care to champion the pre-existing conditions aspect of the law during the midterm elections. In a signal of the shifting public opinion in favor of the 2010 law, Trump stressed in his latest tweet that any new program should include a ban on health insurers denying coverage to people based on pre-existing conditions. The Kaiser Family Foundation estimates that 52 million adults from 18 to 64, or 27 percent of that age group, would be denied coverage under the practices that were in effect in most states before the ACA was passed.

Title: The Shift in American Voter Engagement and the Importance of Participatory Democracy

Article:

The presidential election cycle in the United States appears to be progressing earlier each round, mirroring the holiday shopping season. As the election cycle unfolds, American voters prepare to exercise their civic duty by dusting off their voting identification cards.

While active participation in the democratic political process is essential, the majority of political engagement occurs through social media discussions and printed press editorials. Participatory democracy has transformed into an online argument, often marked by name-calling and political polarization.

The American voter's political engagement is primarily focused on the presidential race, with the excitement, vitriol, and participation being a recurring feature of every four-year or two-year contested race. The average voter turnout for presidential elections is approximately 55%, while midterm elections see an average of 45% turnout.

The article suggests that political solutions and a functioning democracy rely on the active participation of the voter. The current political process has been likened to reality television, with the media coverage of the 2016 presidential election serving as a potential means to engage the American voter. Instead of relying on presidential candidates to solve the nation's problems, the electorate should be more active in local, congressional, midterm, and gubernatorial elections.

The article emphasizes the importance of participatory democracy, which extends beyond casting a vote. It involves encouraging thoughtful discussions on important issues, donating time and money to organizations that support a healthy democratic process, and engaging in dialogue with neighbors to foster a bipartisan society and political process.

The author, Barrio, is a native New Mexican and recent New Mexico State University graduate who has been covering Southwest music culture through various online music publications. He has a passion for political activism and public discourse. The article concludes by highlighting the need for American citizens to move beyond selective news consumption and engage in meaningful dialogue to address pressing issues such as economic prosperity, national security, the environment, and societal division.

Title: House Energy and Commerce Committee Rejects Climate Change Acknowledgement Amendment

Article:

The House Energy and Commerce Committee spent a significant portion of Tuesday discussing and voting on The Electricity Security and Affordability Act, a bill that aims to suspend the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed climate rules for power plants. The committee also rejected an amendment that would have acknowledged the reality of climate change.

Representative Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.) introduced the amendment, stating that greenhouse gas pollution "threatens the American public's health and welfare" by contributing to climatic changes. ClimateProgress reported that the amendment was rejected, with 24 Energy & Commerce Committee members, all Republicans, voting against it.

In 2011, House Republicans also voted down amendments that called on Congress to accept that climate change is real, man-made, and a human health threat. The rejection of climate change acknowledgement amendments is not unique to this bill or this committee.

ClimateProgress further reported that the Republicans who voted against the amendment have collectively accepted approximately $9.3 million in career contributions from the oil, gas, and coal industries.

It is unclear why the Republicans on the energy committee continue to reject the acknowledgement of climate change, but the financial ties to the fossil fuel industry may provide one explanation.

Title: "Americans United for Life Advocates for Comprehensive Regulation of Abortion Clinics"

Article:

The grand jury report on Kermit Gosnell, a Philadelphia abortionist currently on trial for murder, details allegations of substandard care, dangerous drug overdoses, and unsanitary conditions at his clinic. This incident is not an isolated case, as at least 15 states have launched investigations into abortion clinics and providers over the past three years for substandard care.

Americans United for Life (AUFL) has been at the forefront of efforts to combat substandard care in abortion clinics. Over the past three years, eight states have enacted new comprehensive abortion clinic regulations or improved existing ones, in response to AUFL's call for protection of women from such clinics.

One of AUFL's key initiatives is the "Abortion Patients' Enhanced Safety Act," model legislation that mandates abortion clinics meet the same health and safety standards as facilities performing other outpatient surgeries. Alabama recently enacted legislation inspired by this model, and Virginia has approved final regulations for abortion clinics, which are now considered a subset of "hospitals" and are required to meet rigorous and protective standards for patient care.

The debate over Virginia's abortion clinic standards illustrates the ongoing battle to ensure women's health and safety overrides profit margins and unregulated abortion practices. Virginia officials and pro-life advocates argue for licensing, regular inspections, operable emergency equipment, and sanitary facilities. Pro-abortion advocates countered that these standards would force clinics to close due to the cost of compliance.

Despite evidence of substandard conditions in Virginia abortion clinics, pro-abortion advocates refused to acknowledge or contradict this evidence. In response to recurring health and safety violations and the failure of some clinics to fulfill "plans of correction" for previously documented violations, a representative from NARAL Virginia wrongly insisted that there was no demonstrated public health need supporting the regulations.

However, documentation obtained by the Family Foundation of Virginia from the Virginia Board of Health confirms the widespread continuation of health and safety violations in Virginia's abortion clinics. Victoria Cobb, president of the Family Foundation of Virginia, stated, "These inspection reports are indisputable evidence that nothing could be further from the truth."

The "right" to abortion, as defined by the U.S. Supreme Court, does not grant abortion providers a "right" to practice without meaningful oversight and regulation, or to maim and kill women in unlicensed, substandard, and dangerous clinics. Denise M. Burke, vice president of legal affairs at Americans United for Life, emphasizes this point.

Title: Democratic Presidential Aspirants' Healthcare and Busing Policies Under Scrutiny

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, several Democratic candidates vying to replace President Donald Trump are facing scrutiny for their healthcare and busing policies, with some drawing comparisons to Trump's own political style.

California Senator Kamala Harris, one of the presidential hopefuls, has been under fire for her inconsistent stance on private health insurance. If elected and re-elected, Harris might have to address the question of whether Americans should be prohibited from having private health insurance, a system currently serving 18 percent of the U.S. economy.

Seven days after announcing her candidacy in January, Harris endorsed "Medicare for All" and, when asked about private insurance, she stated that everyone would have access to medical care without the need to go through an insurance company. However, her subsequent statements have been described as "waffling" regarding private insurance, and she has been criticized for her inconsistency on the issue.

At the second Democratic presidential debate in Miami, Harris raised her hand when asked if she would abolish private insurance in favor of a government-run plan. This contradicted her later statement on MSNBC, where she claimed she does not support ending private health insurance.

Another contentious issue for Harris is her stance on school busing, a policy that ended 20 years ago. During a debate with former Vice President Joe Biden, she used busing as a cudgel, but her approach was met with criticism for reviving an unpopular policy that sparked controversy in the 1970s. In a 1973 Gallup poll, only 4 percent of whites and 9 percent of blacks chose busing as a means of achieving integration.

Biden, too, has faced criticism for his evolving stance on political issues. He has been accused of contorting his convictions, such as his recent support for federal funding of abortions, a shift from his previous 40-year support for the Hyde amendment.

The debate over healthcare and busing policies among Democratic candidates highlights the challenges they face in presenting coherent, consistent, and popular platforms while differentiating themselves from President Trump. The candidates' evolving stances on these issues have led some to accuse them of imitating Trump's political style, with his campaign strategy of labeling America a "hellhole" and his inaugural address's depiction of "American carnage" being mirrored in their speeches.

Title: Trump Promotes Plastics Production Amidst Corporate America's Environmental Shift

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed his support for plastic production, distinguishing himself from Democrats who have environmental concerns. This stance comes as corporate America, including companies like Google and Coca-Cola, attempt to align with environmentalists, reducing plastic usage and promoting recycling.

In a recent event, Trump took credit for a new plastic manufacturing plant being built by Royal Dutch Shell in Pennsylvania. However, the plant's planning dates back to 2012, and it was built with over $1 billion in tax credits from state taxpayers.

Trump used the occasion to encourage Pennsylvanians to support his reelection, stating, "Virtually every leading Democrat has vowed to eliminate fossil fuels." The plant will use a byproduct of fracking to produce pellets for various plastic products, including those used in cars and wind turbines.

When asked about the excessive use of plastic before his speech at the new plant, Trump attributed the issue to other countries, particularly China. He stated, "We have tremendous plastics coming over from Asia, from China, and various others. It's not our plastic. It's plastic that's floating over in the ocean and the various oceans from other places."

Trump has made strides in addressing plastic waste, signing the bipartisan Save Our Seas Act to combat ocean garbage and plastic. However, he did not mention the word "plastic" at the signing event.

Meanwhile, Trump's reelection campaign is selling 10-packs of plastic Trump straws on its official website, raising over $450,000. The campaign's website states, "Liberal paper straws do not work. STAND WITH PRESIDENT TRUMP and buy your pack of recyclable straws today."

Corporate America, including Coca-Cola and Pepsi, is making efforts to reduce plastic waste and improve their environmental images. Coca-Cola produced over 3 million tons of plastic packaging in 2017 and aims to recycle or collect the equivalent of everything it produces by 2030. Both companies have announced plans to sell their water in aluminum cans in addition to plastic bottles.

Recent city laws limiting plastic straws have led to a backlash, prompting the Trump campaign's straw sale. However, some companies are moving away from plastic straws regardless of the laws. Starbucks, for example, has developed a recyclable lid for its iced drinks and is one of several companies phasing out plastic straws. The UK is banning plastic straws by 2020, and companies there are adjusting accordingly. McDonald's moved away from plastic straws in its UK and Ireland stores but found the new paper straws were not recyclable.

Google has announced plans to include recycled plastic in its products by 2022, and Amazon, responsible for significant packaging, has moved toward paper-padded packaging that it claims is recyclable. Amazon also has a portion of its website dedicated to its sustainability and environment efforts.

Support for plastic bag bans, such as New York's ban on single-use plastic bags in grocery stores, has bipartisan backing. However, these bans can only do so much, as demonstrated by China's significant contribution to plastic waste in oceans despite having laws limiting single-use plastic bags.

Title: Stephen Colbert Challenges Elizabeth Warren on Single-Payer Healthcare and Middle Class Taxes

Article:

In a recent appearance on Stephen Colbert's CBS late night show, the host questioned Elizabeth Warren on the issue of single-payer healthcare, a policy she supports. Colbert pressed Warren on the potential increase in middle-class taxes to fund the program she and Bernie Sanders have proposed. Warren, seemingly taken aback, evaded the question multiple times.

Colbert, in a comedic tone, asked Warren, "You keep being asked in the debates, how are you going to pay for it? Are you going to raise the middle class taxes?" After a pause, he repeated, "How are you going to pay for it? Are you going to raise the middle class taxes?"

Warren responded by discussing increased costs for the wealthiest Americans and big corporations. However, Colbert interjected, "Taxes, which is what you mean by 'costs'?" Warren continued, stating that hardworking middle-class families would see their costs decrease.

Colbert then offered Warren advice on how to argue in favor of middle-class tax hikes for the greater good of single-payer healthcare. His critique stemmed from a place of support and agreement, aiming to help Warren present her argument more effectively.

However, political experts have noted that openly admitting the need for significant tax increases is a politically risky move. A poll by Robert Blendon, a professor at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, found that support for government-run single-payer systems plummeted when voters were presented with the possibility of delays in care or higher taxes, dropping to 26% and 37%, respectively.

Another challenge for Warren is that her plan would replace private healthcare plans for nearly 180 million Americans, making such coverage illegal. At the last Democratic debate, Warren attempted to downplay this issue by claiming that few Americans love their insurance companies. However, polling suggests that many Americans value their coverage and providers, making such uprooting a significant political liability for single-payer advocates.

According to Gallup polling from late last year, 82% of Democrats reported receiving good or excellent healthcare, and 71% believed their health care coverage was good or excellent. Even when it comes to health care costs, 61% of Democrats were satisfied with what they paid. The same poll also noted that the vast majority of all Americans are satisfied with the quality of their health care and their level of coverage.

Furthermore, a recent Kaiser poll found that 86% of Americans with private coverage were satisfied with it. Healthcare disruption is deeply unpopular, as both parties have learned in recent years. Warren may try to navigate around these facts, but she cannot deflect from the issues of higher taxes, illegal private coverage, and potential long wait times for care.

Title: San Francisco Shooting: A Call for Smarter Immigration Enforcement, Not More

Article:

The shooting of Kate Steinle in San Francisco on July 1st has sparked a national conversation about immigration and crime. The suspect, Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez, a Mexican immigrant, was arrested in connection with the fatal shooting of Steinle, a 31-year-old woman, while she was walking with her father on a busy pier. Lopez-Sanchez is reported to have been in the country without documentation and has a criminal history, including seven felony convictions.

However, it is crucial to note that Lopez-Sanchez does not represent the majority of immigrants in the United States, legal or otherwise. The Washington Post recently analyzed Donald Trump's comments about Mexican immigrants being drug dealers and "rapists" and found them to be incorrect. Being in the country without authorization is not a crime; it is a civil infraction.

Most undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work and provide a better life for themselves and their families. It is a myth that increased illegal immigration leads to more crime. Research from the Immigration Policy Center shows that crime rates fell in the United States as the size of our immigrant population, including undocumented immigrants, grew from 1990 to 2010.

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) recently announced it is rethinking its deportation priorities to focus on recent arrivals and serious criminals. This move is a step in the right direction, as it is time to start seriously targeting those immigrants who are a real threat to public safety. The government will be focusing its enforcement efforts on three categories of people: convicted criminals, recent border crossers, and terrorism threats.

It is important to remember that Lopez-Sanchez should not have been in the country, or he should at least have been behind bars. However, immigration authorities erred in not seeking a warrant or court order for his arrest, and he was released in accordance with city law in March. President Barack Obama's proposed executive action on immigration, currently tied up in a legal battle, might also have made a difference because it would have freed up resources to go after people like Lopez-Sanchez.

The executive action would have given deportation relief to parents of DREAMers, while allowing DHS to zero in on criminals. Instead, despite the fact that our country spends more on immigration enforcement than all other law enforcement agencies combined, our system failed Kate Steinle. Although Steinle's death was a tragedy, it was the alleged action of one man. All undocumented immigrants do not deserve to be vilified by false association.

Title: New Hampshire Senate Debate Moderator Apologizes to Scott Brown for Geography Error

Article:

In a recent New Hampshire Senate debate, moderator James Pindell of WMUR apologized to Republican candidate Scott Brown for incorrectly disputing him on state geography. During the debate, Mr. Brown, a former Massachusetts senator, was asked about the economic conditions in Sullivan County, a county located on the western border of New Hampshire.

Mr. Brown responded by discussing the economic challenges faced by areas north of Concord, the state capital. He highlighted the presence of jobs, opportunities, and tourism, particularly in relation to ski areas and snowmobile trails.

However, Mr. Pindell interrupted Mr. Brown, reminding him that the question was about Sullivan County, not the North Country. Mr. Brown clarified that he was referring to any area past Concord, and the challenges faced by the state as a whole.

Despite Mr. Pindell's interruptions, Mr. Brown continued to discuss the economic challenges faced by northern counties. Later, Mr. Pindell admitted that Mr. Brown's geography was correct in a tweet, noting that Mr. Brown was referring to Mt. Sunapee, a ski resort in Sullivan County, which is north of Concord.

"I said that Sullivan County was west of Concord, not north of Concord. The truth is, it's both. So on this point, Scott Brown was right, I was wrong, and I apologize to Scott Brown and to both campaigns," Mr. Pindell said in his tweet.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Indicted in Three Corruption Cases

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been indicted in three corruption cases, marking the first time a sitting head of state in Israel will face criminal charges. The indictment, announced Thursday, includes charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust.

The indictment follows a four-day hearing last month with Netanyahu's defense team. The charges stem from three distinct cases:

1. Case 4000: This case alleges that Netanyahu, during his tenure as communication minister, engaged in a quid pro quo deal with businessman and media mogul Shaul Elovich. The deal, as reported by Haaretz, involved Netanyahu spearheading regulations that helped Elovich gain roughly $500 million. In return, Netanyahu and his wife allegedly requested alterations to Walla News, which Elovich ran, to serve their political interests and undercut their opponents.

2. Case 2000: This case accuses Netanyahu and Arnon Mozes, the publisher of the Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper, of trying to limit the circulation of a rival paper in return for favorable media coverage.

3. Case 1000: This case accuses Netanyahu of fraud and breach of trust for allegedly using his public role to receive gifts from Hollywood mogul Arnon Milchan and billionaire James Packer.

If convicted, Netanyahu could face up to 10 years in prison for bribery and a maximum of three years for fraud and breach of trust. Netanyahu, Israel's longest-serving prime minister, is not required to step down as a result of the charges. He can ask the parliament for immunity, though the establishment of a special committee to consider this request is currently delayed due to ongoing gridlock.

The indictment casts further uncertainty over Netanyahu's political future. Israel appears to be headed toward an unprecedented third election in less than a year after Netanyahu's chief rival announced Wednesday he would miss a deadline to form a ruling coalition.

During the 21-day period following the announcement, the parliament can try to nominate any one of its 120 lawmakers to establish a coalition. Should that effort fail, an election would be triggered within 90 days.

If Netanyahu were to win a new election, Israeli President Reuven Rivlin would be forced to decide if he can give Netanyahu the mandate to form the next government given the criminal charges against him.

Title: Republicans Push for Reduced Unemployment Benefits as Economy Shows Mixed Signs

Article:

The June jobs report, released this week, has sparked a renewed debate among political parties, with Republicans claiming victory following a reported growth of 4.8 million jobs and a decrease in the official unemployment rate to 11.1 percent. President Trump took to Twitter, proclaiming the numbers as "HISTORIC JOBS NUMBERS!"

However, a closer look at the report reveals a more complex picture. Economist Jed Kolko, in his analysis, calculates a "core" unemployment rate, which includes permanent layoffs or quits, and the "marginally attached" people who express a desire to work but have not searched for a job in the past four weeks. This kind of unemployment has increased steadily since February and accelerated in June, rising from 5.0 percent to 5.9 percent.

The increase in jobs over the last month is primarily due to the reversal of temporary layoffs. While this is a positive development, the economy is still nearly 15 million jobs short of pre-pandemic levels, and there is a growing problem of permanent unemployment as recessionary effects take hold and businesses shrink or close.

Moreover, the June numbers are already outdated, as they are based on surveys conducted during the first two weeks of the month. The last two weeks have seen a surge in coronavirus cases across the country, and private economic activity indexes have shown a stalling out of spending. In states with high coronavirus case numbers, such as Texas and Florida, economic activity is going into reverse. Weekly unemployment claims have also plateaued over the last month or so, at levels many times higher than during the Great Recession.

The expiration of the $600 weekly unemployment supplement and the small business loan program, at least for the moment, has left millions of Americans without a crucial source of income. Economists and policymakers warn that without further government aid, the economic situation will worsen, and we may see a resurgence in unemployment and even bread riots.

The article argues that the U.S. government can borrow without limit as long as the economy has not recovered. Once the pandemic has passed, the focus can shift to restoring employment and production. The author suggests that universal checks could be increased to compensate for lower-income people taking jobs, addressing conservative complaints about labor incentives.

The article concludes by stating that Republicans' focus on shoving people into the labor market, regardless of the economic conditions, may harm President Trump's re-election prospects. The author argues that the U.S. government's primary duty should be to ensure the well-being of its citizens, and that this can be achieved through targeted economic aid during the pandemic.

Title: California Senator Dianne Feinstein Introduces Comprehensive Gun Control Legislation

Article:

California Senator Dianne Feinstein is set to introduce new gun control legislation today, aiming to reinstate the "assault weapons" ban of the Clinton era. However, the proposed legislation extends beyond the ban of firearms with a "scary look" to encompass a wide range of handguns, rifles, and shotguns.

The bill, to be introduced today, covers:
1. Semiautomatic rifles, handguns, and shotguns that can accept a detachable magazine and have one or more military characteristics.
2. Semiautomatic rifles and handguns with a fixed magazine that can accept more than 10 rounds.

The legislation aims to strengthen the 1994 Assault Weapons Ban and various state bans by:
1. Eliminating easy-to-remove bayonet mounts and flash suppressors from the characteristics test.
2. Banning firearms with “thumbhole stocks” and “bullet buttons” to address attempts to “work around” prior bans.

The bill also bans large-capacity ammunition feeding devices capable of accepting more than 10 rounds. To protect legitimate hunters and the rights of existing gun owners, the legislation exempts over 900 specifically-named weapons used for hunting or sporting purposes.

Grandfathered weapons must be registered under the National Firearms Act. This registration process includes certification from local law enforcement of the individual's identity and that possession would not violate State or local law. Fingerprinting for firearms that have been lawfully purchased is part of the proposed legislation.
