The bill covers a wide range of firearms, with nearly every semi-automatic handgun in the United States having a detachable magazine. The term "assault weapon" is a political term not specific to any weapon, and it is typically used in reference to semi-automatic rifles. However, any weapon can be used to assault someone.

The legislation's provision for protecting legitimate hunters and existing gun owners has raised questions about who qualifies as a legitimate hunter, particularly considering many people may not hunt annually but only occasionally. The hunting argument is often used by pro-gun control advocates as a compromise on the issue, but the Second Amendment has no connection to hunting.

The success of Feinstein's legislation is uncertain, as it reflects extreme stances on the Second Amendment that many Democrats have already criticized as out of touch, wrong-headed, and an ineffective method of preventing school shootings.

In a related development, according to CNN, Feinstein has received permission from DC police to be flanked with semi-automatic rifles during a press conference today at 11 a.m. when the legislation will be officially introduced.

Title: Clinton and Sanders Accused of Debate Date Dispute Ahead of Wisconsin Primary

Article:

The campaigns of Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have been engaged in a dispute over debate dates ahead of the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday. Clinton, who is the current Democratic front-runner, and Sanders, who has won five of the last six primaries or caucuses, have been readying their final appeals to Wisconsin voters.

Clinton, in an interview with NBC's "Meet the Press," expressed her readiness for a debate with Sanders in New York, her adopted home state, ahead of its April 19 primary. Sanders, a Brooklynite, has challenged Clinton to a debate in delegate-rich New York.

The Clinton campaign has offered a few dates, including a weekday morning and at the same time as Monday night's NCAA men's basketball championship, which the Sanders campaign and others view as less than optimal for viewership. Clinton, however, expressed confidence about the debate happening.

On Sunday, the Sanders campaign countered by stating that the candidate is available to debate on April 10, 11, 12, or 13. Sanders campaign spokesman Michael Briggs also accused the Clinton campaign of being disingenuous, stating they announced a debate date when they knew Sanders already had park permits for a major rally in New York City.

Briggs said in a statement late Sunday that Sanders accepted an invitation for a prime-time debate on April 10 on NBC News. "Let's stop the silly political games," Briggs said. "Let's get on with debating the candidates' stands on serious issues affecting New York and the United States."

Clinton had no public events Sunday in Wisconsin, where some polls show Sanders with a slight lead. Clinton, however, made clear that Sanders remains a political threat. "I certainly have not moved on," she told NBC. "I know that I still have work to do to win the nomination."

Meanwhile, the top two Republican presidential candidates, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, were campaigning in Wisconsin. Trump, the Republican front-runner, doubled-down on his comments about the US should "do a better deal" with Japan, South Korea, and other allies, suggesting they should pay more for America's protection while taking a greater role in their defense, including building their own nuclear weapons.

Trump also discussed his plans to change the nation's tax code by "simplifying" it. "The very rich are probably going to end up paying more," he said, "but there's an incentive for them to invest and create jobs in the country."

Ohio Governor John Kasich, the other Republican candidate, told ABC's "This Week" that the Republican convention, which could happen in July without a clear nominee based on delegate wins, could be a civics lesson for the country. "Kids will spend less time focusing on Bieber and Kardashian and more time focusing on how we elect presidents," said Kasich, who has won only Ohio. "It will be so cool."

Trump called for Kasich to drop out of the race, arguing he should not be allowed to continue accumulating delegates if he has no chance of being the nominee. Trump has 736 pledged delegates, followed by Cruz with 463, then Kasich with 143—with 1,237 needed to secure the nomination. Trump, however, after a difficult week, now trails Cruz in Wisconsin, after some polls showed him leading by double-digits several weeks ago. Trump said Sunday that Kasich could be considered as a nominee at the GOP convention in July even without competing in the remaining nominating contests.

Title: Military Deployment to Puerto Rico: Pace of Relief Efforts Accelerates Amidst Criticism

Article:

The deployment of military personnel to Puerto Rico, following the aftermath of Hurricane Maria, has been criticized for its slow pace, with approximately 5,000 National Guard forces and active military members currently assisting a population of 3.5 million. This number is significantly lower compared to the 22,000 troops deployed to Haiti after the 2010 earthquake.

In the first six days after the hurricane made landfall, the Navy had deployed only two ships due to concerns about the damage to Puerto Rico's ports. However, harrowing reports of U.S. citizens struggling without electricity, food, and water have prompted the Pentagon to escalate the relief effort, despite not receiving specific requests from territorial officials.

The issue of port congestion has been raised as a reason for the slow response and the reluctance to waive the Jones Act. However, it appears that a lack of preparedness may also be a factor. For instance, the hospital ship USNS Comfort, which was announced to be on its way to Puerto Rico, is still not en route, despite being ready to deploy as soon as the call comes.

The Comfort, a mammoth ship, was docked Tuesday in its home port of Norfolk, Virginia, with a minimal crew, requiring up to five days to stock up and prepare. When reached by phone Tuesday afternoon, the commanding officer of the ship's hospital, Capt. Kevin D. Buckley, said, "The Comfort is ready to go, if the call comes."

The order to move the Comfort finally came a week after the storm, but the ship is still not en route, a delay that could have been avoided if preparations had been made a week before Maria hit Puerto Rico, as soon as the power and course of the storm became clear. In comparison, during the Haiti disaster, the Comfort was ordered on its way immediately following the earthquake.

While the White House has allowed foreign-built or flagged ships to deliver supplies during the emergency, it has restricted members of Congress from making official visits as part of official delegations to the hurricane-battered U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Congressional sources from both parties said Wednesday that the Trump administration is restricting these visits. The office of Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), who had been organizing a visit to Puerto Rico by several representatives and senators from both parties, is now trying to find alternatives to assess the federal response thus far.

The San Juan Airport is open, though the speed of flights going in and out is severely restricted by the damaged infrastructure. The restriction on Congressional flights has some validity, though it has the notable side effect of preventing any Congressional oversight or evaluation of conditions on the ground.

Title: Hillary Clinton Discusses High Expectations for Women in Public Eye

Article:

In an interview that aired on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" on Friday, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton expressed that high-achieving women in the public eye are often expected to perform at a higher level.

During the interview, Clinton stated, "I think Mika and I understand this, and maybe it's because still today, when you are a high-achieving woman—particularly one in the public eye—you really are just expected to perform at a higher level all the time."

Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential front-runner, was referring to her co-host, Mika Brzezinski, who was doing more preparation for the interview. Host Joe Scarborough had previously commented on Brzezinski's extensive preparation.

Clinton continued, "And there are not enough experiences with different styles or different approaches that women make. Men, my goodness—you know, there's a million different ways you could be successful, you could communicate and all the rest of it. And look, I'm not telling you anything you don't know."

When asked by Scarborough if she ever looked at how her husband, former President Bill Clinton, did things and thought "it's not fair," Clinton responded, "I am not a natural politician like Bill Clinton or Barack Obama." She explained, "So for me, it really came through the root of service; it really came from my deep conviction that we had to make sure that this country we all love kept producing opportunities for everybody, and I see that narrowing, and I see people being left out, and it upsets me."

Clinton further elaborated, "And so I invest a lot of energy and a lot of my own emotion into what I do and I think sometimes, instead of that being as easy to understand as I would like it to be, it sometimes is a little nerve-wracking."

Title: America's Progress and Comparative Analysis of Racism and Bigotry

Article:

In a speech at the GLAAD Media Awards, pop icon Britney Spears expressed her thoughts on societal norms and individuality. The speech, while sincere and heartfelt, sparked a reflection on the perception of America's societal issues, particularly racism and bigotry.

The article discusses the observation made by political scientist Seymour Martin Lipset that those who only know one country cannot truly understand its norms and exceptionalities. This perspective is applied to the United States, where discussions about deep-seated racism and bigotry are prevalent.

While it is acknowledged that discrimination exists in the United States, the article argues that it is a mischaracterization to claim that America is the most racist or bigoted country in the world. The author cites statistics from a 2014 study that ranked the United States 47th in opposition to having a racially different neighbor, with only 6% of the population expressing opposition.

The article also highlights the increasing trend of interracial marriages in the United States, with the rate rising from 3% in 1967 to 17% in 2015. This trend suggests a significant shift in societal attitudes towards race, the author argues.

The article also touches upon the progress made in terms of attitudes towards homosexuality, citing the similar trend in attitudes as race and the election of racial minorities as heads of state in the United States.

The author concludes by questioning the assertion that America is uniquely hostile to "being different," suggesting that such a claim may have had some basis in fact in the past, but may be less accurate in the present day. The article emphasizes that while the United States is not without its problems, it is essential to recognize and acknowledge the progress that has been made.

Title: Senate to Hold Briefing on Election Security Amidst Ongoing Opposition to Legislation

Article:

The United States Senate will hold a private briefing on election security on Wednesday, a move that Democrats have advocated for over several months. The briefing, which is expected to include officials from the Department of Homeland Security, the FBI, and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, is taking place amidst Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's ongoing opposition to the consideration of election security legislation.

While both parties have expressed concerns about potential foreign interference in the 2020 elections, Republican lawmakers have generally been more reluctant to take up concrete measures. This reluctance is partly due to McConnell's strong opposition, as he views these laws as potentially giving the federal government too much control over state and local elections, and as a means to benefit the Democrats.

Despite repeated warnings from high-level government officials, the Republican-controlled Senate has allowed several bills addressing election security to fall by the wayside. Bills such as the Protecting American Votes and Elections Act, the Defending the Integrity of Voting Systems Act, and the Foreign Influence Reporting in Elections Act have not been passed. As a result, the US Senate, which allocated $380 million in election security funds last year, is now effectively promoting a do-nothing approach to a subject that special counsel Robert Mueller and numerous national security officials have raised as a serious threat requiring additional action.

It remains to be seen whether the information shared during the briefing will be enough to spur further action. The actions of the Republican-controlled Senate up until this point suggest they might not. McConnell's unwillingness to tackle election security is not just sending a political message, it could have major consequences. Democrats are hoping an in-depth briefing about the risks the US faces might push Republicans to change course.

Title: Trump Sets Conditions for U.S. Participation in Iran Nuclear Agreement, Gives Congress 60 Days to Address Flaws

Article:

President Donald Trump has criticized the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement and called for stricter conditions regarding Iranian behavior in order to maintain U.S. participation in the pact. In a speech on Friday, Trump stated that the agreement is under review and could be terminated if a solution cannot be reached with Congress and allies.

The president's speech outlined the growing threat from Iran, including its sponsorship of terrorism, missile program, and efforts to destabilize the Middle East. Trump's ultimatum was the most significant part of his speech, as he announced that he will terminate the agreement unless its flaws are addressed.

Congress now has 60 days to decide whether to reimpose severe economic sanctions on Iran that were lifted by the nuclear agreement. Congress will also consider legislation addressing the agreement's shortcomings and "triggers" imposing sanctions in response to Iranian behavior.

The nuclear agreement's three major flaws, as identified by the president, include allowing Iran to enrich uranium, operate a plutonium-producing heavy-water reactor, and the deal's weak inspection provisions. Other issues, such as Iran's missile program, support of terrorism, and meddling in regional conflicts, should also be addressed.

While there has been some discussion of extending the deal's "sunset" clause, such a fix would be meaningless without addressing the above changes concerning Iran's nuclear program. However, it is unlikely that these vital changes will be approved by Congress in legislation or agreed to by other nations who signed the Iran deal.

Congress is unlikely to pass legislation with any substantial fixes to the agreement due to the need for 60 votes in the Senate, making it difficult to garner enough support from moderate Republican senators and Democratic votes. European states also plan to resist any efforts by U.S. officials to fix the nuclear deal, according to a senior European Union official.

President Trump can reimpose most sanctions on Iran himself if Congress fails to act, and he could take such action as part of a withdrawal decision. The president's decision to give Congress and European leaders a final chance to fix the agreement before terminating it is a departure from President Obama's approach, which did not submit the pact to the Senate for ratification as a treaty.

Title: HHS Reverses Obama-Era Policy, Defines "Sex" as Biological for Obamacare Nondiscrimination Policy

Article:

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has announced a new rule that defines "sex" as biological for the purposes of the Affordable Care Act's (Obamacare) nondiscrimination policy. This rule reverses a regulation implemented during the Obama administration that redefined "sex" to include "gender identity" and "termination of pregnancy."

Section 1557 of Obamacare prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, age, or disability in health-related programs or activities. In late 2016, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas enjoined Section 1557's prohibitions against discrimination on the basis of gender identity and termination of pregnancy. Last fall, the same federal judge vacated the regulation, stating that it violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the federal Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

As a result of these rulings, HHS could no longer enforce the Obama-era provision, and today's new rule brings federal policy into compliance with court rulings. Roger Severino, director of the HHS Office for Civil Rights, stated, "What this regulatory reform does is update the books to reflect the reality that 'gender identity' and 'termination of pregnancy' have been deemed unlawful interpretations of civil-rights law. This final rule is merely conforming to that legal reality."

The new HHS rule also maintains the Obama administration's decision not to include "sexual orientation" as a protected category under the definition of sex discrimination. Some progressive advocates had urged the Obama-era HHS to add "sexual orientation" to its regulation, but it failed to do so.

Opponents of the Obama administration's regulation had both health-care and religious-freedom concerns about its implications. Because the policy applied to any health programs or activities funded or administered by HHS, as well as any plans offered in Obamacare's health-insurance marketplaces, it affected a large number of health-care providers in the U.S.

By redefining "sex," the policy required medical professionals to treat biological males who identify as women, and biological women who identify as men, according to their gender identity rather than their biological sex—a practice that can lead to improper health-care decisions. There was, for instance, a documented case in which a biological female who identified as a male visited a hospital complaining of abdominal pain. Because the doctors were required to treat this person according to gender identity, this biological woman, who was unknowingly pregnant, ended up delivering a stillborn child.

"We agree with the court's rationale that the plain original meaning of'sex' under our sex-discrimination laws referred to the biological realities of sex, and this is particularly important for programs administered or funded by HHS, because we so often deal with the scientific reality of sex in our health and research programs," Severino explained.

The Obama policy also had negative implications for religious-liberty and conscience rights, particularly for health-care workers. "There were religious-freedom concerns at play, as well as to the ability of doctors to be able to act according to their best medical judgment, as well as their conscience and religious beliefs," Severino said.

The decision to reverse the Obama-administration regulation will likely be met with fury by progressive activists and their allies in the media. When it first became public that the Trump administration was considering undoing the Section 1557 rule, the New York Times falsely asserted that "Transgender" Could Be Defined Out of Existence Under Trump Administration. Nevertheless, the move fulfills a key promise that President Trump made both on the campaign trail and throughout his time in office, voicing support for undoing Obama-era policies that redefined "sex" to include "sexual orientation" and "gender identity." This move, though it comes near the end of his first term, is another step in showing his supporters, especially social conservatives, that he is willing to follow through.

Title: Clinton's National Lead Over Trump Expands Amidst Email Scandal; James Carville Discusses 2016 Election Outlook

Article:

In the aftermath of the Democratic National Convention, Hillary Clinton has maintained an average lead of over 5 percent against Donald Trump in national polls. This lead is even more substantial in traditional battleground states, where Clinton currently holds a double-digit advantage over her Republican rival. However, the latest chapter in Clinton's email scandal, involving the discovery of 15,000 previously undisclosed emails and documents, has prompted renewed criticism.

The new wave of scrutiny has led to fresh accusations that Clinton may have given preferential treatment to major Clinton Foundation donors and fostered a "pay to play" culture during her tenure as Secretary of State.

Prior to the latest scandal, James Carville, a longtime Clinton confidant and political strategist who guided Bill Clinton's 1992 presidential campaign, spoke to * ███'s Hive about Clinton's chances in the 2016 presidential election and the state of the Republican Party.

When asked about the election's outcome, Carville expressed a belief that the Democrats were likely to secure a significant victory. He attributed this to the substantial and rapidly changing demographics in the country, which are unfavorable to the Republican Party, and the party's continued focus on non-college whites, a demographic that has not been successful in presidential years.

Beyond the changing demographics, Carville pointed to the legacy of the last Republican presidency and the disastrous war and recession that marked that period. He suggested that these factors, combined with the Republican Party's primary appeal to non-college whites, were contributing to the party's struggles in the 2016 election cycle.

Regarding Trump's hard-core supporters, Carville noted that they are not the same people who voted for candidates like Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, or Jeb Bush. He attributed Trump's success to his alignment with a version of an ethnocentric, nationalistic party that differs significantly from traditional Republican views. Carville also suggested that as Republicans perceive their party shrinking, they have hardened in their views, which is damaging to their immediate-term prospects.

Carville further commented on the concerns within the Republican Party, stating, "Republicans are not so much worried about losing the election as they are about losing an entire generation." He suggested that many Republicans feel their influence is shrinking, and Trump's campaign appeals to those who feel their lives have not turned out as they expected or hoped. Trump's message resonates with those who feel the country is not the same as it was when they were growing up.

Title: President Obama Highlights American Resilience, Calls for Vote on Tuesday

Article:

In the aftermath of recent natural disasters, former President Barack Obama emphasized the American spirit of unity and resilience, stating that Americans come together during trying times. He highlighted the country's progress in overcoming economic recession and war, and expressed optimism about the current economic recovery.

Obama pointed out that the middle class thrives when everyone receives a fair opportunity, contributes their fair share, and adheres to the same rules. He declared his intention to be an advocate for the aspirations of all Americans and encouraged citizens to vote on Tuesday.

The former president underscored the significant progress made during his administration, including the end of the Iraq war, the death of Osama bin Laden, the creation of nearly 5.5 million jobs in the last two and a half years, and the resurgence of the American auto industry. He acknowledged that the country still has work to do but emphasized the real progress that has been made.

Obama contrasted the two presidential candidates' visions for the country, stating that the path offered by his opponent, Mitt Romney, is a return to the policies that led to the economic crisis. He criticized Romney's proposed tax cuts for the wealthy, encouragement of job outsourcing, and deregulation of big banks and insurance companies.

The former president emphasized the need for education, job training, and investment in technology to create good jobs and stimulate economic growth. He highlighted his administration's efforts to make college more affordable, recruit math and science teachers, and train community college students for in-demand jobs.

Obama also emphasized the need for domestic investment in manufacturing, innovation, and infrastructure, as well as a shift in energy policy to prioritize clean energy and reduce oil imports. He also called for a reduction in military spending, using the savings to pay down the national debt and rebuild America's infrastructure.

The former president also addressed the need to reduce the deficit through spending cuts and tax reform, but opposed cuts to social welfare programs and the privatization of Medicare. He emphasized the need to support the American people, particularly those who are struggling, and to create opportunities for all, regardless of their background or circumstances.

Obama concluded by emphasizing the need to finish the work that has been started, to educate and train the workforce, create jobs, and provide opportunities for all Americans. He expressed optimism for the future and called on Americans to vote on Tuesday.

Title: Florida High School Shooting Survivors Lobby for Assault-Style Rifle Ban in Tallahassee

Article:

Dozens of students and parents from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, the site of a shooting rampage that left 17 dead last week, traveled to Tallahassee on Tuesday to advocate for a ban on assault-style rifles. The massacre, the second-deadliest shooting at a public school in U.S. history, has sparked a national debate about gun rights and stricter firearms controls.

Students from the South Florida high school were emotional as they stepped off buses in Tallahassee, greeted with waves, cheers, and somber applause from fellow teens. Diego Pfeiffer, a senior at Stoneman Douglas High, told the crowd, "We're here to make sure this never happens again."

On Tuesday, less than a week after the shooting, the Republican-controlled Florida House of Representatives rejected a bill to block sales of assault-style rifles in the state. Tyra Hemans, a 19-year-old senior who traveled to the state capital, said, "I am not going back to school until lawmakers, and the president, change this law."

Student and parent activists from the high school in Parkland, Florida, near Fort Lauderdale, were expected to stage a rally on Wednesday at the statehouse. Fourteen students and three educators were killed, and 15 other people were wounded in the Feb. 14 attack. Nikolas Cruz, 19, a former student expelled from Stoneman Douglas High for disciplinary problems, was arrested and charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder.

Authorities say Cruz was armed with a semiautomatic AR-15 assault-style rifle that he legally purchased from a licensed gun dealer last year, when he was 18. Former classmates have described Cruz as a social outcast and trouble-maker with a fascination for guns, and police have acknowledged responding to numerous calls related to Cruz during the past few years.

On Tuesday, a member of the accused gunman's legal team from the Broward County public defender's office said Cruz saw his life unravel last year, when he was expelled and his mother died. In 2017, Florida's Department of Children and Families had opened an inquiry into Cruz after he was reported to have been cutting himself, but the case was closed in November of that year with the finding that he was receiving sufficient support, the agency said.

The youth-led protest movement that erupted within hours of the shooting attracted prominent celebrity supporters on Tuesday when film star George Clooney and his wife Amal, a human rights lawyer, said they would donate $500,000 to help fund a planned March 24 gun control march in Washington. Hollywood director Steven Spielberg and media mogul Oprah Winfrey later joined in contributing $500,000 each toward the march.

A Washington Post-ABC News opinion poll released on Tuesday showed 77 percent of Americans believe the Republican-dominated U.S. Congress is doing too little to prevent mass shootings, with 62 percent saying President Donald Trump, also a Republican, has not done enough on that front. Trump said on Tuesday he had signed a memorandum directing the attorney general to draw up regulations banning devices that turn firearms into machine guns, like the bump stock used in October's mass shooting in Las Vegas.

Students and parents elsewhere in Florida and in other states, including Tennessee and Minnesota, staged sympathy protests on Tuesday, according to local media reports. Gun violence on public school and college campuses has become so commonplace in the United States during the past several years that education officials regularly stage drills to train students and staff about what they should do in the event of a mass shooting on school grounds.

Gun ownership is protected by the Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution and remains one of the nation's more divisive issues. A federal ban on assault weapons, in force for 10 years, expired in 2004. Funerals continued for the young victims of Wednesday's attack. The U.S. Military Academy at West Point on Tuesday said it made a rare posthumous letter of acceptance to Peter Wang, a student of the school killed in the shooting. A Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps cadet, Wang had aspired to attend the elite academy.

Title: Five Tax Breaks Under Threat in Upcoming Tax Reform

Article:

In the final 15 days before the Senate's deadline to reevaluate the entire Tax Code, two key senators, Max Baucus (D-Mont.) and Orrin Hatch (R-Utah), are employing a "blank slate" approach. This strategy involves eliminating most special tax provisions, shifting the burden to colleagues to justify their inclusion. By July 26, senators must explain why each provision should remain.

One of the most significant tax breaks under scrutiny is the mortgage interest deduction, which allows homeowners to deduct up to $1 million in mortgage interest annually, including for vacation homes. This deduction, often considered the "motherhood and apple pie" of tax breaks, is projected to cost over $1 trillion over 10 years, making it one of the biggest tax expenditures.

While it is unlikely that the deduction will be completely abolished, it may undergo significant changes if tax reform progresses. Critics argue that the government should not subsidize the wealthy who can afford to spend $1 million on a home. Options to reduce the value of the deduction while maintaining it for middle-class homeowners include capping all deductions at 28%, as proposed by President Barack Obama, or focusing the write-off more on lower-income individuals by capping it at $500,000 and replacing the deduction with a credit. This change could save $213 billion, according to the Tax Policy Center.

Lobbyists, such as the National Association of Realtors, are expected to remind lawmakers of the ongoing housing market recovery and argue that curbing the break could negatively impact housing prices, particularly in vacation communities.

Another tax break under threat is the carried interest tax rate, which applies to hedge fund managers, private equity executives, and others working on Wall Street. Instead of paying ordinary income taxes, which top out at nearly 40%, carried interest is taxed as a capital gain, generally at a rate of 20%. Top earners started paying an additional 3.8% tax on their investment income this year. This break costs about $17 billion over 10 years.

Democrats have long argued that the break is unfair, as Wall Street executives' pay is taxed as capital gains rather than ordinary income. If lawmakers decide it is not worth spending time on the issue during tax reform, they may finally address this complaint. Lobbyists, such as the Private Equity Growth Capital Council, are expected to argue that higher taxes on carried interest would negatively impact the economy.

Title: FBI Fails to Act on Tip Regarding Florida School Shooter Nikolas Cruz

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) admitted on Friday that it had received a tip more than a month before the Parkland, Florida, high school shooting on Wednesday, in which 17 people were killed. The tip, made on January 5, 2018, described Nikolas Cruz's gun ownership, his desire to kill people, erratic behavior, disturbing social media posts, and potential school shooting plans.

According to the FBI, the tip should have been forwarded to the Miami field office for investigation, but that did not occur. The Miami field office did not receive the tip, and no further investigation was conducted at the time. The FBI stated, "Protocols were not followed."

The FBI's failure to act on this tip is likely to generate scrutiny on how law enforcement handles its investigations in such cases. FBI Director Christopher Wray stated, "We are still investigating the facts. I am committed to getting to the bottom of what happened in this particular matter, as well as reviewing the processes for responding to information that we receive from the public."

Florida Governor Rick Scott called for Wray's resignation, stating, "We constantly promote'see something, say something,' and a courageous person did just that to the FBI. And the FBI failed to act." Scott emphasized, "See something, say something' is an incredibly important tool, and people must have confidence in the follow-through from law enforcement."

In addition to the call to the FBI tip line, Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel stated at a press conference on Friday that his department had received about 20 calls regarding Cruz in the past few years. He did not provide details about the calls but stated he would investigate each one to ensure it was handled appropriately.

President Donald Trump, in a tweet on February 15, 2018, appeared to blame "neighbors and classmates" for not reporting Cruz to authorities. The FBI's statement is the latest piece of evidence that many people not only saw red flags in Cruz's behavior but tried to report them, and those warnings were not thoroughly pursued or fell on deaf ears.

This failure of the FBI to act on the tip comes after questions over a YouTube comment posted last fall by someone named "nikolas cruz" that read, "Im going to be a professional school shooter." A man in Mississippi saw the comment on his YouTube channel and flagged it to both YouTube, which removed it, and the authorities. The FBI has stated that they were unable to identify the commenter despite conducting database reviews and checks.

Title: Uninsured Rate Among Low- and Middle-Income LGBT Americans Decreases by a Quarter Since Affordable Care Act Implementation

Article:

According to a report from the Center for American Progress, the uninsured rate among low- and middle-income LGBT Americans has decreased by a quarter since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The report, which relies on surveys of LGBT Americans earning less than 400 percent of the poverty line, shows that the uninsured rate fell from 34 percent in 2013 to 26 percent in 2014.

The decline in the uninsured rate among LGBT individuals has been slightly faster than the drop among the general population, where the uninsured rate fell by about a quarter. The gains were particularly large among lower-income groups, which were eligible for bigger insurance subsidies or the Medicaid expansion. The uninsured rate for LGBT individuals earning between 139 and 200 percent of the poverty line fell by 18 percentage points.

The report indicates that 26 percent of LGBT Americans under 400 percent of the poverty line are uninsured, while the number is 20 percent among the general population. LGBT people can face unique obstacles in gaining coverage, as there is no federal law requiring all companies to offer health benefits to their employees' same-sex partners. The report also suggests that some individuals could miss out on coverage due to anti-LGBT bias in hiring, which may push many LGBT people into unemployment or low-wage jobs that do not offer benefits such as health insurance coverage.

Only 38 percent of LGBT people under 400 percent of the poverty line have an offer of insurance through either their own or their spouse's employer, while the number stands at 58 percent among the general population. The report also highlights disparities in coverage rates within the LGBT community, with gay and bisexual individuals having higher insured rates than lesbian women, and the uninsured rate among transgender populations being especially high. The report suggests that the uninsured rate among transgender populations has come down significantly under the Affordable Care Act, although the 2013 survey only included a smaller number of transgender individuals.

A correction has been made to an initial version of this story, which misstated the size of the decline of the uninsured rate for LGBT people. It is 24 percent, not 25 percent.

Title: Historic Flooding in Texas Expected to Worsen as Hurricane Harvey Brings Record Rainfall

Article:

Catastrophic flooding in the U.S. state of Texas is expected to worsen in the coming days as waters continue to rise following Hurricane Harvey, a storm of historic proportions. The city of Houston has already received a record 30 inches (75cm) of rain, turning roads into rivers. Forecasters predict the total rainfall could nearly double later this week.

U.S. President Donald Trump has promised swift action to help those affected and is due to visit Texas on Tuesday. He stated, "Recovery will be a long and difficult road, and the federal government stands ready, willing, and able to support that effort." He added that he was dealing with Congress on funding, warning, "It's going to be a very expensive situation."

Harvey made landfall as a category-four hurricane late on Friday, bringing unprecedented flooding. It was later downgraded to a tropical storm. More than 3,000 people have been rescued in and around Houston, where about 6.6 million people live in the metropolitan area. Helicopters have plucked victims from rooftops.

At least nine people are reported to have died in incidents related to the storm, according to Texan officials. Six members of the same family died trying to flee rising floodwaters, relatives told U.S. media, but the incident has not been confirmed.

Governor Greg Abbott has activated the entire Texas National Guard - some 12,000 "civilian soldiers" - to assist national forces in search and rescue operations. The area is expected to have received a year's rainfall within a week.

Officials expect half a million disaster victims to seek assistance in Texas and 30,000 people to be housed in emergency shelters. The National Hurricane Center expects "catastrophic and life-threatening flooding" to continue across south-eastern Texas, with additional rainfall accumulations of 15 to 25 inches expected.

Army engineers have begun releasing water from two dams controlling water flowing along a major river into the heart of Houston. Officials said they were opening the Addicks and Barker dams to stop water spilling into neighboring communities, but that this could cause further damage down the Buffalo Bayou.

Many schools are closed, as are Houston's two main airports, with runways completely flooded. The Texas Gulf Coast is a key center of the U.S. oil and gas industry, and some of the largest refineries in the country have halted operations.

In the suburbs to the west of Houston, hundreds of families waded cautiously along a road they usually take to the shops, to school, and to work. It was an exhausting journey of well over a mile in waist-high flooding. All night, as water lapped into their homes, people had been calling for help, they said, but no-one came. Eventually, a lone police officer arrived, but by then, people had taken matters into their own hands, forming a makeshift armada of little boats, jet skis, blow-up mattresses, and even rubber rings.

Similar levels of 15-25 inches of rain are predicted for south-western and central Louisiana. The state suffered huge destruction following Hurricane Katrina in 2005. Observers have drawn comparisons with the disastrous evacuation of homes in New Orleans ahead of Katrina, which left thousands of people stranded in squalid conditions at that city's stadium.

Tens of thousands of people have been ordered to leave parts of Fort Bend County, about 35 miles south-west of Houston, where a river is set to crest this week. Dallas, 240 miles north of Houston, will set up a "mega shelter" at its convention center to house 5,000 evacuees, city officials said. However, Houston authorities have not issued a mass evacuation order.

Mayor Sylvester Turner on Sunday defended the decision by citing the "crazy" logistics of planning an evacuation of 2.3 million people. Meanwhile, Police Chief Art Acevedo said officers were focused on protecting the city from looters, with four people arrested on Monday.

For further information or to speak to a BBC journalist, please contact the provided contact number or use the given methods.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Rules Out 2020 Presidential Run, Addresses Native American Heritage Controversy

Article:

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren, a prominent figure in the Democratic Party's progressive wing, has ruled out a 2020 presidential run and has addressed the long-standing controversy surrounding her Native American heritage. In an interview on "Fox News Sunday," Warren stated, "I'm not running for president."

When asked about calls for genetic testing to resolve the heritage controversy, Warren shared a family history as told by her parents and grandparents. She said, "It's a part of who I am, and no one's ever going to take that away."

Senator Warren, who is seeking a second Senate term this year, has been accused of claiming Native American heritage to secure jobs, including a position as a Harvard law professor. She has acknowledged identifying as a minority but denies using such status to advance her career.

President Trump has repeatedly referred to Warren, a Wall Street critic and potential White House rival, as "Pocahontas," a notable American Indian woman in colonial history, to highlight the controversy.

In the interview, Warren shared details about her family, stating, "My mom and dad were born and raised out in Oklahoma, and my daddy was in his teens when he fell in love with my mother. She was a beautiful girl who played the piano. And he was head over heels in love with her and wanted to marry her. And his family was bitterly opposed to that because she was part Native American."

Warren went on to describe the hardships her parents faced during the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl, and how they raised three boys, all of whom went off to the military. She concluded by saying, "They raised me. They knocked around, and it was tough, but they hung together. They hung together for 63 years."

Title: Supreme Court Justices Align on Prisoner's Supervised Release Case

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Supreme Court Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Clarence Thomas, John Roberts, Samuel Alito, and Brett Kavanaugh formed a majority on Monday, ruling that a criminal defendant can be sentenced for violating their supervised release, even if the release expires while they are incarcerated awaiting new charges. Ginsburg's vote was swapped with conservative Justice Neil Gorsuch, who joined liberal Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Stephen Breyer, and Elena Kagan in their dissent.

The case in question involves Jason Mont, who was indicted by a grand jury for multiple drug and firearm offenses. Mont was released from federal prison on March 6, 2012, but was found guilty of two counts of cocaine trafficking while on supervised release, and tested positive on several drug tests. His supervised release date was set for June 28, 2017.

The District Court issued a warrant on March 30, 2017, and ultimately set a supervised-release hearing for June 28, 2017. Two days before that hearing, Mont challenged the jurisdiction of the District Court, based on the fact that his supervised release had initially been set to expire on March 6, 2017. The court concluded that it had authority to supervise Mont, revoked his supervised release, and ordered him to serve an additional 42 months' imprisonment to run consecutive to his state sentence.

In his opinion, Justice Ginsburg wrote, "Under our view, in contrast, time in pretrial detention constitutes supervised release only if the charges against the defendant are dismissed or the defendant is acquitted. This ensures that the defendant is not faulted for conduct he might not have committed, while otherwise giving full effect to the lawful judgment previously imposed on the defendant."

This unexpected alliance between Ginsburg and Thomas comes a week after a tense argument between the two justices over the case Box v. Planned Parenthood of Indiana and Kentucky Inc. The Court decided against taking up the question of the Sex Selective and Disability Abortion Ban, which, as Justice Thomas described it, bans abortions in which "the mother is seeking the abortion solely because of the child's race, sex, diagnosis of Down syndrome, disability, or related characteristics."

In a 20-page opinion, Thomas wrote about how the abortion rights movement was starting to look a lot like eugenics. "This case highlights the fact that abortion is an act rife with the potential for eugenic manipulation," he wrote. "Planned Parenthood founder Margaret Sanger was particularly open about the fact that birth control could be used for eugenic purposes."

A frustrated Ginsburg said that Thomas's diatribe "displays more heat than light." She reasoned that, "A woman who exercises her constitutionally protected right to terminate a pregnancy is not a'mother.'"

Today, the justices managed to find an issue on which they have common ground.

Title: Bipartisan Immigration Bill Includes Industry-Specific Provisions for Meat, Ski, and Cruise Industries

Article:

In the 844-page bipartisan immigration bill, various senators have included provisions that cater to specific industries in their respective states. South Carolina Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham has advocated for more visas for the meat industry, a significant employer in his state. New York Democrat Sen. Charles Schumer has pushed for special treatment for Irish workers, given the large Irish population in his state. Florida Republican Sen. Marco Rubio has sought assistance for the cruise-ship industry, a major business in his home state. Colorado Democratic Sen. Michael Bennet has included a boost for ski areas.

The new work-visa program, allowing up to 200,000 low-skill workers, was not part of the initial deal. However, additional visas for meat, poultry, and fish cutters were added due to the efforts of Sen. Graham, according to people familiar with the negotiations. The final bill sets aside up to 20,000 additional visas for meat cutters and trimmers.

In South Carolina, broilers (chickens raised for meat) are the primary commodity, generating nearly 27% of all agricultural cash in the state in 2011, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union is not in favor of the visas for foreign workers, stating there is no labor shortage in the industry.

Sen. Bennet, working with an association representing most of Colorado's ski resorts, crafted a provision to make it easier for them to hire foreign ski instructors. Instead of using a visa program for temporary, low-skilled workers, ski instructors would be eligible to come to the U.S. under the same program that professional athletes use.

For Sen. Schumer, the immigration bill provided an opportunity to include an extra 10,500 visas for Irish people with at least a high-school degree. An aide to Sen. Schumer stated the provision aims to rectify a 1965 change to immigration law that allegedly made it difficult for Irish immigrants to obtain visas, despite their strong cultural ties to the U.S.

Sen. Rubio, from hurricane-prone Florida, inserted an opportunity for foreigners to work on relief operations after state or federal disasters for 90 days. He also included a provision allowing certain foreigners to repair cruise ships made abroad, as well as other transportation equipment. Florida drew $6.7 billion in direct spending from the cruise industry in 2011, according to the Cruise Lines International Association.

The construction industry has been critical of immigration-bill provisions, but it fared better than expected. Sen. Rubio and Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) were not able to get a cap lifted that limits construction visas to 15,000, but they did include a provision allowing foreigners to work in higher-skilled jobs such as electricians, plumbers, and welders.

Despite the victory, various construction groups stated in interviews they would fight the overall cap on construction jobs. "Obviously, this is just the first step of a long road," said Marco Giamberardino, executive director of government affairs at the National Electrical Contractors Association.

Title: Martin Family Calls for President Obama to Investigate Trayvon Martin's Death

Article:

In a television interview on Thursday, Sybrina Fulton, the mother of Trayvon Martin, and his father, Tracy Martin, called on President Barack Obama to thoroughly investigate the circumstances surrounding the shooting death of their son. The request was made during an appearance on CBS This Morning.

When asked what they wanted the president to do, Sybrina Fulton responded, "That's pretty tough. To say the least, at least investigate what happened. At least go through it with a fine-tooth comb and just make sure all the T's were crossed and all the I's were dotted, because this is sending a terrible message."

Fulton expressed concern about the impact the verdict might have on American teenagers, stating, "It's sending out a terrible message to young teenagers. Trayvon was walking too slow, so should they be walking too fast? You know, so I don't think teenagers in whole know exactly what to do now."

This was the first time Martin's parents had given television interviews since the verdict was announced. Following the verdict, a Florida jury found George Zimmerman not guilty of murdering Trayvon Martin. President Obama released a statement urging calm but has not spoken publicly about the verdict.

The Department of Justice is considering whether to bring a civil rights case against Zimmerman, but the White House has stated that Obama will not be involved in the decision-making process. Martin's family attorney, Benjamin Crump, stated that they were examining legal options for a potential civil suit and were seeking the Justice Department's input.

Tracy Martin spoke on NBC's Today show on Thursday, stating, "Obviously, any time you have a person that makes an assumption that a person is up to no good, there's some type of profiling there. Was he racially profiled? I think that if Trayvon had been white, this wouldn't have ever happened. So obviously race played some type of role."

The family also urged protesters to remain peaceful and not to damage property or get arrested. Sybrina Fulton stated on NBC, "We have always maintained to do things decent and in order, and we think the protests should be peaceful protests. We're not saying for them not to protest, because they have a right to protest, they have a right to be heard. But we just want to make sure that it is peaceful, that nobody gets hurt, that nobody gets arrested, that you don't damage your own property."

Martin's parents also discussed the emotional impact the case has had on them. Tracy Martin stated, "I was in a bit of shock. I thought surely that he would be found guilty of second-degree murder, manslaughter at the least, but I just knew that they would see that this was a teenager just trying to get home."

Sybrina Fulton responded to one of the jurors who spoke anonymously with CNN and placed some of the blame for Trayvon's death on him. Fulton stated, "I don't think she knows Trayvon. Trayvon is not a confrontational person. So instead of placing the blame on the teenager, we need to place the blame on the responsible adult. There were two people involved. We had an adult that was chasing a kid, and we had the kid, who I feel was afraid."

Title: Former Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama Share Stage in Portrait Unveiling Ceremony

Article:

In a rare public appearance, former President George W. Bush shared the stage with his successor, President Barack Obama, during the unveiling of Bush's official portrait at the White House. The event, attended by Bush's family, including his daughters Jenna and Barbara, as well as former President George H.W. Bush and former first lady Barbara Bush, was marked by humor and camaraderie.

During his speech, Bush jokingly compared his portrait to that of George Washington, stating, "I am pleased that my portrait brings an interesting symmetry to the White House collection: It now starts and ends with George W." He also playfully advised Obama to "gaze at his portrait" whenever he had a significant decision to make and ask himself, "What would George do?"

The audience, which included Bush administration officials and friends, erupted in laughter. The Obamas, in the midst of their re-election campaign, were seen focusing on the shared experiences of living in the White House and the pressures of the job.

President Obama thanked the Bush family for their assistance during the transition in late 2008 and for the advice given to his daughters Malia and Sasha. He noted that the advice, which included enjoying the White House and its experiences, had been taken to heart by his daughters.

Despite the political differences between the two administrations, the event was marked by a spirit of mutual respect and appreciation. White House spokesman Jay Carney stated, "There were differences, I'm sure, in the past when incumbent presidents have presided over these ceremonies. But there is so much in common for the men thus far who have occupied this office and for their families who have lived in the White House, that I think there is a great deal of respect and appreciation held by everyone who is participating."

The event, while not addressing the political differences between the two administrations, provided a moment of unity and camaraderie in the White House.

Title: Tech Privacy Concerns and Voluntary Information Sharing

Article:

In recent events, actress Scarlett Johansson's nude photos were leaked after a hacker obtained them from her computer, and a Pennsylvania high school remotely activated the cameras on laptops issued to students while they were away from school. These incidents highlight the growing concern over privacy in the digital age.

Individuals' personal data, including browsing habits and credit card information, is often collected by websites and companies. This information is used for targeted advertising and other purposes. In response, some individuals opt to use anti-virus software and change passwords, but the risk of data breaches remains.

The distinction between voluntary and involuntary information sharing is a key factor in privacy concerns. While individuals may willingly provide personal information to companies like Amazon or Facebook, they do not have the same level of control over government agencies accessing their data.

The National Security Agency's data mining, for example, gathers patterns of phone numbers, but does not listen to calls or know individuals' names, according to their claims. However, the important difference is whether the information sharing is voluntary.

Individuals can decide whether to use Facebook or allow private sites to install cookies to track their information. Scarlett Johansson did not give the hacker permission to steal her photos, and individuals do not give government agencies permission to access their information.

While some argue that sharing information with companies is as involuntary, the truth is that individuals often do not check privacy policies thoroughly. The lack of concern over company data breaches is often due to the limited consequences compared to government data breaches, such as the potential for SWAT teams or imprisonment.

Individuals have adapted their behavior online, being cautious about what they email and aware that their activities may be monitored. However, the freedom to choose when to share information is a crucial aspect of privacy.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's proposal for mandatory black box recorders in all cars raises privacy concerns, as the bureaucrats aim to track travel patterns for infrastructure planning and accident investigation. While the data collected is intended to improve road safety, the potential for misuse remains a concern.

In conclusion, the value placed on privacy varies, and individuals are often willing to give up some privacy for convenience or benefits. However, the freedom to choose when and with whom to share personal information is a key aspect of privacy that should be preserved.

Title: Police in the United States Use Various Non-Lethal Weapons During Protests

Article:

Police forces across the United States have been employing a range of non-lethal weapons during ongoing protests against the police killing of George Floyd. These weapons include tear gas, pepper spray, and rubber bullets, which have at times resulted in serious injuries to protesters.

Tear gas, also known as CS or CN gas, is a chemical compound powder that is sprayed from canisters, causing a burning sensation in the eyes and mouth that incapacitates. Images from Minneapolis, Minnesota, on May 30, 2020, depict police officers discharging tear gas amidst protesters.

In addition to tear gas, police have used pepper spray, both from handheld devices and projectiles. Pepper spray, chemically distinct from tear gas, produces similar effects: a burning and watering of the eyes and skin.

Police have also deployed pepper balls, small projectiles containing chemical irritants. These projectiles can contain PAVA spray, an irritant similar to pepper spray, as well as CS gas. They can be shot from launchers or modified paintball guns.

Flashbang grenades, which explode with bright light and sound to stun and disorient demonstrators, have also been used by police.

Protesters have reported being hit by a variety of rubber, plastic, and "sponger" bullets. In some instances, journalists in Minneapolis were shot by police with 40mm hard plastic projectiles during a protest on Saturday.

In Los Angeles, police have used rubber projectiles, and Mayor Eric Garcetti has stated that the police department will minimize their use going forward.

A 2017 survey published by the British Medical Journal found that injuries from such "kinetic impact projectiles" resulted in death in 2.7% of cases. Protesters have also reported police using sting ball grenades, which upon explosion spray the surrounding area with rubber pellets. In addition to the rubber balls, the grenades can contain chemical agents.

Protesters in Columbus, Ohio, have reported being shot with wooden bullets by police forces. Images online showed wooden dowel-shaped rods sliced into small, bullet-sized projectiles. The Columbus Police Department did not respond to requests for comment.

Title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Concealed Illness, Tore Up Medical Leave Note Before Plane Crash

Article:

German prosecutors have stated that Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot responsible for deliberately crashing a German airliner into the Alps, concealed an illness from his employers and tore up a doctor's note calling for him to go on medical leave on the day of the tragic incident.

Police found the medical certificate and other documents during a search on Thursday at Lubitz's apartment in Dusseldorf. Germanwings, the budget airline for which Lubitz worked, stated that it had received no such sick leave note for the day of the ill-fated flight. Lufthansa, the parent company of Germanwings, previously declared that Lubitz was "100% fit to fly."

The statement from the Dusseldorf prosecutor's office revealed no suicide note or claim of responsibility from Lubitz, who investigators believe deliberately crashed the plane on Tuesday, resulting in the deaths of all 150 people on board. The officials also stated that no evidence of a political or religious background linked to the tragedy was found.

The statement said police found medical documents "indicating an existing illness and corresponding medical treatment." A torn-up current sick note, also valid for the day of the incident, was among the documents, the prosecutor said, adding that this "would -- according to preliminary evaluation -- support the assumption that the deceased had concealed his illness towards his employer and his occupational environment."

The nature of Lubitz's illness remains undisclosed, although German media outlets reported he may have suffered from depression. Dusseldorf University Clinic stated that Lubitz visited the facility in February and March, most recently on March 10, for diagnosis but denied he was treated there for depression, according to Sky News reports.

Germany's Federal Aviation Office has requested that Lufthansa provide access to Lubitz's medical records, DPA reports. The information would then be sent to French investigators, the news agency said.

The cockpit voice recorder revealed that Lubitz deliberately locked the pilot out of the cockpit and then initiated a descent that led to the deaths of all aboard the plane bound from Barcelona to Dusseldorf, French prosecutor Brice Robin said Thursday. He provided no motive.

Investigators searched Lubitz's apartment in Dusseldorf and the home of his parents in Montabaur, about 40 miles from Bonn. They were seen removing boxes and large blue bags from both residences.

Unconfirmed reports circulating in the German media suggest that Lubitz, by all official accounts a skilled pilot with a distinguished training record who was not being monitored by security services, may have been suffering from depression.

Bild reported that on several occasions, Lubitz's training at Lufthansa's flight school in Phoenix, Ariz., was interrupted for mental health reasons after he had a "serious depressive episode." The German tabloid reported that Lubitz may have undergone treatment after being what it called "demoted" several times during his training in the United States.

The newspaper referred to him as a mass murderer. It said the "episode" was noted on his medical records held by the aviation authorities. Der Spiegel also separately reported the findings that have not been confirmed.

Germany's Federal Aviation Office would not confirm the report. Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr said Thursday that Lubitz's training was "interrupted" six years ago, but declined to elaborate.

Thomas Winkelmann, the low-cost carrier's chief executive, released a statement Friday saying that the airline has begun setting up a family assistance center in Marseille, France, and that briefings with family members will start there on Saturday.

"The suffering and pain this catastrophe has caused is immeasurable," he said in the statement. "No words can express it and no amount of consolation is sufficient but we want to be there for visiting family members and friends if our support is desired."

Title: NBC News Poll: Christie Trails Clinton in Hypothetical 2016 Match-Up, Faces Divided GOP

Article:

An NBC News poll released on Tuesday morning indicates that New Jersey Governor Chris Christie trails former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in a hypothetical 2016 presidential match-up. The poll also suggests a divided Republican Party.

The poll, which is one of many early surveys conducted at the start of the election cycle, has Christie trailing Clinton by 53% to 40%. However, it is important to note that neither Clinton nor Christie have officially declared their candidacy for the 2016 presidential election.

The first contest, if no changes occur, will be the Iowa caucuses, likely in January 2016. The general election is more than 1,000 days away.

The accuracy of polls taken at such an early stage is a matter of debate. For instance, President Rudy Giuliani had high poll numbers in 2007 due to his time as the take-charge mayor of New York on 9/11, but his poll numbers faded quickly once the GOP primaries got underway. Similarly, other potential candidates such as President Colin Powell, President Mario Cuomo, President Gary Hart, President Edmund Muskie, and others have seen their poll numbers fluctuate or decline after initially high numbers.

While the polls will become more meaningful as the election cycle progresses, it is still early in the process. The author of the article, who covers politics full-time, expresses a desire to take a breather and focus on other issues before the election season heats up. The article concludes by noting that there are other important issues to discuss and examine in the meantime.

Title: U.S. President Donald Trump to Meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Hamburg

Article:

On Friday, U.S. President Donald Trump will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Hamburg, Germany. The meeting, which will be attended by Tillerson, the U.S. Secretary of State, and Lavrov, the Russian Foreign Minister, among others, has raised concerns due to the potential for an unpredictable outcome.

According to reports, the meeting will involve six individuals: the presidents, Tillerson, Lavrov, and two translators. This small grouping has been criticized as a potentially dangerous approach to an already tense encounter. Lavrov, who has served as Foreign Minister since 2004, is known for his diplomatic skills and execution of Putin's foreign policy. Tillerson and the U.S. diplomatic corps have reportedly been sidelined by Trump, who appears to trust only military personnel.

In a hypothetical scenario, a well-informed and diplomatically astute U.S. president might use this meeting to address the issue of Russian meddling in the 2016 election. This president would acknowledge the meddling, support investigations into the matter, and pledge to take action against future interference. The president might also threaten to expose the financial dealings of senior Kremlin officials as a means of undermining Russia's status as a great power.

However, it is expected that this meeting will not follow such a course. Trump's national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, has indicated that the president will approach the meeting informally. The outcome of the meeting remains uncertain, and the potential for unforeseen consequences is a cause for concern.

In a press briefing, the U.S. president might expand on his comments to Putin, emphasizing the seriousness with which the U.S. views Russian interference in elections, including those of NATO allies. In the event of Russian hacking into foreign elections, the U.S. might invoke Article 5 of the NATO agreement, which stipulates collective defense, and work with allies to respond swiftly and proportionately.

The exact nature of the meeting and its aftermath remains to be seen. The U.S. president's approach to the meeting, and his subsequent comments, will likely be closely scrutinized.

Title: Indiana Primary Polling: Uncertainty Surrounds Trump and Cruz as Indiana Voting Approaches

Article:

As Indiana prepares to vote on Tuesday, the state's primary contests have received less attention due to a limited number of public telephone surveys. Only seven public telephone surveys have been conducted in Indiana over the past month, compared to nine in Wisconsin and 17 in New York before their respective primaries.

The relative scarcity of public polling, along with varying results, has added a layer of uncertainty to Tuesday's high-stakes primary. The two leading candidates, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, could potentially strengthen their chances to win a majority of delegates on the first ballot at the convention with a decisive victory in Indiana or Cruz could gain a significant boost.

Ted Cruz's campaign has been eager to dismiss the new Indiana surveys showing the Texas senator trailing Trump. Cruz stated on Mike Gallagher's syndicated conservative-talk-radio show that "Indiana is neck and neck." Of the seven public polls conducted over the past three weeks, Trump leads six, with Cruz's only advantage coming from an Indiana University-Purdue University Fort Wayne survey that showed Cruz with a massive 16-point lead.

Andy Downs, IPFW pollster, expressed surprise when the results came back with Cruz way on top, even questioning if the results for Cruz and Trump were incorrectly reversed. The IPFW poll differs from the other surveys in two ways: a longer, 15-day field period and not weighting results according to demographic targets.

The other public polls show Trump ahead, but by varying margins. Trump's slimmest lead came in a one-day survey conducted last Wednesday by Clout Research, with a 2-point advantage over Cruz (37% to 35%). Trump's largest lead, 17 points, was in a poll conducted last Thursday and Friday by Gravis Marketing, a prolific but less-respected firm.

The most recent reliable poll, an NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist survey conducted last Wednesday-Friday and released on Sunday, showed Trump with a commanding 15-point lead over Cruz (49% to 34%). The Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, which conducted the poll, cited two newsmaking maneuvers the Cruz campaign has attempted, such as the deal with Ohio Gov. John Kasich and naming Carly Fiorina as Cruz's running mate, as potential reasons for the results.

Lee Miringoff, the director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, acknowledged that the poll may have been off in the past but emphasized their overall good track record in the primaries. IPFW's Downs acknowledged that his poll is out on a limb showing Cruz ahead but stressed that he doesn't yet know why his numbers differ from other pollsters.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar Calls for Impeachment of Supreme Court Justice Kavanaugh Amid New Allegations

Article:

Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) has called for the impeachment of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh following a report in The New York Times on Saturday. The report alleged that an eyewitness saw friends of Kavanaugh push "his penis into the hand of" a female student at a college party.

However, on Sunday evening, The Times added to its piece that the female student did not recall the incident, according to friends, and declined to comment. An earlier version of the article, adapted from a forthcoming book, did not include this element of the book's account. The book reports that the female student declined to be interviewed and friends say that she does not recall the incident.

Before The Times added what amounted to a walk-back of the new allegation, Democrats, including Omar, began calling for Kavanaugh's impeachment. On Sunday, Omar tweeted, "Nothing terrifies this corrupt president more than the idea of Congress upholding the rule of law. We must open impeachment inquiries against Trump * and * Kavanaugh immediately. It's our constitutional duty."

Omar has not commented or taken back her tweet as of Monday. The Times piece was adapted from a forthcoming book by two Times journalists, Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly, titled The Education of Brett Kavanaugh: An Investigation.

The walk-back of the allegation was prompted by backlash from conservative media commentators and journalists, led by The Federalist's Mollie Hemingway, who had received an early copy of the book and noted that the book itself said that the alleged victim did not recall the incident.

After The Times acquiesced in an "Editors' note," the paper was criticized by the right and the left for omitting the important detail that the alleged female victim did not recall the incident. MSNBC's Morning Joe host Joe Scarborough questioned why The Times originally left out that the alleged victim could not recall the episode.

"Everybody makes mistakes," he said Monday, according to the Washington Examiner. "We were on the phone yesterday asking each other, wait a second, there's a woman who [Max] Stier claims was abused by Kavanaugh. Has she denied this? Has she claimed this happened? Why is there this glaring omission in the New York Times story?"

"I could not believe the New York Times would write this piece without that information contained in it," he added. The Times piece also failed to mention that the person making the new allegation, Max Stier, had served on former President Bill Clinton's defense team during impeachment proceedings. Kavanaugh had served on independent counsel Kenneth Starr's team.

Title: The Increasing Polarization in American Politics: A Look at the Factors Influencing the Divide

Article:

The United States, over the past decade and a half, has experienced a significant increase in political polarization, a concept that has become a common topic of discussion. Some argue that the nation is as divided as it was during the Civil War. This article explores the factors contributing to the polarized attitudes among Americans.

One factor identified is the influence of geographical location on political views. The BBC's video, "The Tribes of America," investigates how the neighborhood in which a person resides can impact their political beliefs. Additionally, hyper-partisan news and social media contribute to Americans living in ideological isolation, allowing them to remain in an echo chamber if they choose. This isolation, fueled by anger or disenchantment towards the opposing side, discourages open dialogue and understanding of opposing viewpoints.

In the past, American politics did not exhibit such a stark divide. For instance, in 1994, moderates comprised a majority of voters, and the ideological gap between Democrats and Republicans was not as wide. However, over the past two decades, the number of moderates has significantly decreased, and Democrats and Republicans have moved further apart in terms of finding common ground.

The question remains: Can America find common ground again? While it is hoped for the future, the current state of affairs does not indicate a quick resolution. Each American strives for what they believe is best for the country, but understanding complex issues and determining effective solutions is a challenging task.

In the future, it is hoped that Americans and American media will strive for integrity in the sharing of information, allowing voters to comprehend that they are in this together, whether they recognize it or not. By promoting factual and unbiased information, Americans can work towards bridging the ideological divide and finding common ground.

Title: Presidential Candidate Amy Klobuchar Vows to Counter Abortion Laws, Supports Late-Term Abortions in Certain Cases

Article:

Presidential hopeful Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) has expressed her opposition to new abortion laws in Republican-led states, promising to take action if she wins in 2020. Several states, including Georgia and Alabama, have passed "heartbeat bills," which prohibit abortion once a fetal heartbeat is detected, typically after six weeks - a time when many women may not yet be aware they are pregnant. Last week, Alabama enacted a law that bans nearly all abortions at any point in time, even in cases of rape or incest.

Klobuchar, during an appearance on "Fox News Sunday," described these new laws as "dangerous" and "a place that we have never seen." She noted that these laws would effectively make it impossible for women to obtain abortions, while also mentioning that some states are attempting to cut funding for Planned Parenthood, which could limit access to contraception.

Lawmakers, such as the sponsor of the Alabama law, have made it clear that the purpose of passing such sweeping restrictions on abortion is to provoke a legal challenge. Their aim is to have a case reach the Supreme Court, where a conservative majority might overturn Roe v. Wade, a landmark 1973 decision that established a woman's right to an abortion under the Constitution. If Roe v. Wade is overturned, individual states would be able to decide whether or not to keep abortion legal.

To counter this, Klobuchar promised that if Roe v. Wade is overturned, "I would make sure that we are codifying Roe v. Wade into law."

On the other side of the political spectrum, Republicans have expressed concern over bills that were proposed in states including Virginia and New York, which make broad allowances for abortion, permitting it at any time during a pregnancy under certain circumstances. The Virginia bill, which sparked outrage when Delegate Kathy Tran stated it would allow abortion up until birth, failed in the state legislature. In January, New York passed the Reproductive Health Act, which removed certain restrictions on third-trimester abortions and allowed the procedure at any point in a woman's pregnancy in certain situations.

Klobuchar was asked about laws like this and whether she supports legislation that permits late-term abortions. She stated that she does, in cases where the mother's life or health are in jeopardy. "That is exactly what the Supreme Court ruling says and I am OK with that," she said.

Title: Bernie Sanders' Lead in New Hampshire Challenges Hillary Clinton's 'Inevitability'

Article:

Bernie Sanders is currently leading in the New Hampshire primary, according to recent polls. This development has been met with approval from some, despite the fact that Sanders is not considered a strong contender in the general election. The reason for this support lies in the belief that Sanders' presence in the race serves to challenge the perceived inevitability of Hillary Clinton's nomination.

Clinton continues to lead in national polls by a significant margin, with few formidable opponents challenging her for the Democratic nomination. This lack of competition has been criticized as irresponsible, given the baggage Clinton and her husband carry. The Democratic party is in need of more serious and viable candidates, or those poised to enter the race at a moment's notice.

The primary concern surrounding Clinton's campaign is the ongoing email scandal, which has been a source of controversy since it was first reported in March. The handling of the scandal, the swirl of half-truths, denials, reversals, and revelations, as well as the potential for new explosive information to come to light, has caused unease among many.

For the past five months, the email scandal has been a source of déjà vu-inspired dread, reminiscent of the scandals that plagued the Clinton family during the 1990s. The handling of the scandal, the counter-attacks from the Clinton machine, and the backtracking and self-doubts from journalists have led to a sense of uncertainty about the true nature of the story.
