In addition to the email scandal, there are other concerns surrounding Clinton's campaign, including the potential for further revelations about the Clinton Foundation, Bill Clinton's sexual behavior, and his association with Jeffrey Epstein, a billionaire investor with a history of associating with underage prostitutes.

The timing of any potential scandals remains uncertain, but many believe it is only a matter of time before another scandal emerges, potentially impacting Clinton's campaign. The email scandal, in particular, has been a source of concern for some, with the potential for it to explode before or after the primaries, before or after the convention, or before or after the debates. The impact of such a scandal on Clinton's campaign remains to be seen.

Title: Michael Cohen's Guilty Plea and the Obsessive Focus on Political Scandals

Article:

Michael Cohen, former lawyer to President Donald Trump, pleaded guilty to multiple crimes on Tuesday, including making false statements to Congress and orchestrating payments to two women to prevent them from disclosing allegations about Trump. The revelations have sparked a renewed wave of criticism towards the president, with many interpreting the developments as vindication.

However, the impact of Cohen's court appearance on public opinion regarding Trump remains questionable. The author expresses doubts about whether the latest developments will significantly alter anyone's view of the president. The author further reflects on the potential consequences of the nation's fixation on political scandals, citing several pressing issues that require the government's attention.

For instance, it was revealed on Tuesday that the Russian military attempted to hack the websites of conservative think tanks. The United States continues to engage in low-intensity wars in Afghanistan, Syria, and Yemen without a clear strategic goal or measure of victory. Additionally, an assertive and self-confident China is constructing islands in the South China Sea for potential military bases, posing a threat to crucial trade routes.

The author argues that the nation's preoccupation with the "gory details of illicit but consensual sex between adults" and West Wing intrigue detracts from addressing these critical issues. The author expresses exhaustion and boredom with the psychodramas that consume an unnatural amount of public attention.

The author asserts that this focus on petty personal corruption serves as a harmful distraction, regardless of political affiliation. The author suggests that if individuals disagree with the president's policies, they should voice their opinions, but the fixation on personal scandals is unproductive. The author compares the current focus on Trump's alleged indiscretions to the media frenzy surrounding Bill Clinton's "bimbo eruptions" during his presidency.

Title: Trump Accuses China and EU of Currency Manipulation, Threatens Tariffs on All Chinese Imports

Article:

President Donald Trump has criticized China and the European Union for manipulating their currencies and interest rates, stating that a stronger U.S. dollar and rising interest rates are undermining America's "competitive edge." In a series of tweets on Friday, Trump indicated his readiness to impose U.S. tariffs on all Chinese imports, amounting to approximately $500 billion, the value of all U.S. imports from China last year.

Trump's comments come during a week when he is facing growing pressure over his relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The president's lukewarm support during a news conference with Putin for the finding by U.S. intelligence agencies that Russia meddled in the 2016 election has drawn criticism.

This marks the latest twist in an escalating trade war with countries the president accuses of trading unfairly. Until now, Trump has mostly focused on using tariffs as leverage to try to convince China and other nations to open up their markets.

Trump's comments on currency and monetary policy break with decades of tradition that presidents avoid commenting directly on these matters. The Federal Reserve, which sets U.S. monetary policy, and the U.S. Treasury secretary, who is typically the chief spokesman on the dollar, are usually the primary sources of information regarding these issues. For years, the U.S. has hewed to the idea that a strong dollar is good for the U.S. economy.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is expected to face questions about the U.S.'s dollar policy and the Fed's independence during two days of talks with G-20 counterparts in Buenos Aires this week. Mnuchin has faced criticism from international counterparts about the U.S. talking about currencies before.

Trump's comments contradict a Treasury Department semi-annual report released in April that refrained from naming any country a currency manipulator based on specific criteria. The president also criticized the Fed's series of rate increases on Thursday, breaking with more than two decades of White House tradition of avoiding comments on monetary policy out of respect for the independence of the U.S. central bank.

The U.S. economy has so far proven resilient to Trump's threat of taking a trade conflict to the next level. The president has already angered allies by slapping tariffs on steel and aluminum, and he is considering a widely-criticized move to levy duties on auto-imports. Trump earlier this month imposed 25 percent tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods, with another $16 billion to follow soon. The administration has also released a list of 10 percent tariffs on an additional $200 billion of Chinese goods, which could take effect as early as next month. China retaliated on the first wave of tariffs by slapping duties on the same dollar amount of U.S. imports, and Beijing has said it will fight against any further U.S. actions.

Title: California Senator Diane Feinstein to Propose Legislation Banning Semi-Automatic Firearms and Large-Capacity Magazines

Article:

California Senator Diane Feinstein has announced plans to introduce legislation in January that would ban the import, export, manufacturing, sale, and transfer of semi-automatic firearms, often referred to as "assault weapons." The term "assault" is a political one, and the proper name for the guns Feinstein is trying to ban is "semi-automatic," which can include both handguns and rifles.

In an interview with NBC's David Gregory on "Meet the Press," Feinstein stated that ammunition clips holding more than 10 bullets would be banned should her bill become law. "It [the bill] will ban the sale, the transfer, the transportation, and the possession," Feinstein said. "Not retroactively, but prospectively. And it will ban the same for big clips, drums, or strips of more than 10 bullets."

Feinstein's proposal is aimed at removing "weapons of war off the streets of our cities." Meanwhile, New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who is protected by armed security, has been advocating for more gun control since last Friday. Bloomberg stated that gun control should be President Obama's top priority and that most gun owners support an assault weapons ban.

However, support for the reinstatement of an assault weapons ban is at an all-time low, according to Gallup. For the first time, Gallup finds greater opposition to than support for a ban on semi-automatic guns or assault rifles, with 53% opposed and 43% in favor. In 1996, the numbers were nearly reversed, with 57% in favor and 42% opposed.

Despite Mayor Bloomberg's assertions, mass shootings are not exclusive to the United States. There have been numerous instances of mass shootings in other countries, such as the predawn attack in Afghanistan on March 11, 2012, that resulted in the deaths of 16 villagers, including nine children. Similarly, there was the twin attack in Norway on July 22, 2011, in which self-styled anti-Muslim militant Anders Behring Breivik killed 77 people.

President Obama implied last night at a memorial service in Connecticut for the victims of last week's rampage that he will use his executive power to push through new gun control measures before the new Congress starts. The details of these measures have not been disclosed.

Title: New York Introduces Alcohol-Filled Traps to Combat Rat Infestation

Article:

New York City officials have introduced a new method to combat its rat infestation problem. The solution involves a machine, a trap door, and a pool filled with an alcohol-based liquid. The rodents are lured by the machine and sent through a trap door into the pool, where they are knocked unconscious and eventually "drown."

According to Anthony Giaquinto, the president of Rat Trap, the importer of the device, the rodents die in the tank, which can hold up to 80 rat carcasses. During a trial in Brooklyn, a total of 107 rodents were lured and killed.

Rat sightings have reportedly increased by almost 38% to 17,353 last year, according to OpenTheBooks, a non-profit watchdog group. This new solution has been described as "humane and environmentally friendly" by Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams, who stated it would be rolled out in some of Brooklyn's most rat-infested districts.

However, animal rights group PETA has criticized the new method, describing it as "cruel and frightening." Elisa Allen, PETA's director, argues that the method will not effectively control overall rodent populations in the long run, as the animals remain fertile. She states that drowning, like poisoning, will be ineffective in the long run.

The city previously announced a $32 million (£26 million) program in July 2017 to cull thousands of rodents by installing rat-resistant bins and trialing a liquid bait that could make rats infertile.

Title: Republican Senators Criticize Trump for Requesting China to Investigate Biden

Article:

WASHINGTON – Senator Susan Collins (R-Maine) has joined two other Republican senators in criticizing President Donald Trump for asking China to investigate Joe and Hunter Biden.

Collins stated on Saturday, according to the Bangor Daily News, "I thought the president made a big mistake by asking China to get involved in investigating a political opponent." She added, "It's completely inappropriate."

Collins joins Senators Mitt Romney (R-Utah) and Ben Sasse (R-Nebraska) in speaking out against the president's actions. House Democrats have launched an impeachment inquiry against Trump over his pressuring the Ukrainian president to probe the former vice president and his son over business dealings in the country.

Trump's request for China to investigate the Bidens comes as Hunter Biden had business dealings in China as well. Senator Ron Johnson (R-Wisconsin) had a contentious exchange with NBC's Chuck Todd after the "Meet the Press" host asked him about comments he made to the Wall Street Journal.

Johnson had said he "winced" at the suggestion that Trump was holding back military aid from Ukraine if the country didn't probe 2016 election meddling. Asked about the comments on Sunday, Johnson attacked the CIA, FBI, and the news media.

"Can we please answer the question I asked you instead of trying to make Donald Trump feel better here that you are not criticizing him?" Todd said. "I'm just trying to ask a simple question of what made you wince."

Johnson eventually explained that he didn't want aid tied to an investigation. "When I asked the president about that, he completely denied it. He adamantly denied it. He vehemently, angrily denied it. He said, 'I'd never do that,'" Johnson said, defending Trump.

Senator Marco Rubio (R-Florida) suggested that Trump was kidding when he said Thursday morning that "China should start an investigation into the Bidens." Rubio stated, "He's pretty good at getting everybody fired up. I don't think it's a real request."

Representative Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), a top Trump ally in the House of Representatives, made similar comments on ABC's "This Week." Jordan said, "I don't think he really meant go investigate. Do you think China's going to investigate him? We know they're not. I just don't think that's what the president was really saying."

Meanwhile, on Twitter, Trump was defending his requests to Ukraine and China to investigate Hunter Biden's business dealings in the two countries. Trump wrote, "There is NO WAY these can be legitimate transactions? As lawyers & others have stated, as President, I have an OBLIGATION to look into possible, or probable, CORRUPTION!"

Title: Ethan Couch's Extradition Raises Questions on Equal Justice

Article:

Ethan Couch, a Texas teenager who was sentenced to probation and a California rehabilitation center in 2013 for manslaughter after a drunk-driving crash that resulted in four deaths, is likely to face a tougher sentence as he is extradited from Mexico following his arrest for parole violation. The case has once again sparked discussions about equal justice under the law, with some observers noting the juxtaposition of Couch's case with the recent grand jury decision not to bring charges against the police officers involved in the shooting of 12-year-old Tamir Rice in 2014.

In 2013, Couch was sentenced by a Texas judge to probation and rehabilitation after pleading guilty to four counts of manslaughter. The case gained national attention when a psychologist, during the trial, coined the term "affluenza" to describe Couch's condition, suggesting that his wealthy upbringing had led to a lack of accountability for his actions. The term sparked controversy and was later regretted by the psychologist.

The timing of Couch's capture in Mexico coincides with the grand jury decision not to bring charges against the police officers who killed Tamir Rice, a black 12-year-old who was playing with a pellet gun in a park when he was fatally shot. The case has raised questions about the application of neutral rules based on cultural factors, according to Daniel Filler, a law professor at Drexel University in Philadelphia.

The Couch case has been compared to the death of Trayvon Martin, a black teenager who was shot and killed in 2012. The verdict in the Couch case was seen by many as evidence of separate justice systems in the United States, with Ethan Couch becoming a symbol of wealth and privilege.

The terms of Couch's parole suggest he could now face up to 10 years in prison, which would represent half the amount requested by prosecutors after the crash. The sentence came after Ethan pleaded guilty to four counts of manslaughter.

The Couch case has raised questions about the U.S. justice system and its treatment of different demographics. A growing list of disparities has affected how Americans think about how punishment is meted out in the United States. According to a report by the Pew Research Center, only 32 percent of Americans think the country has made enough changes to its justice system, down from 49 percent in 2014. Likewise, the percentage of Americans who say that more change is needed has risen from 46 to 59 percent in the same span.

Professor Filler suggests that events like the capture of Couch in Mexico raise public awareness about glitches in the promise of equal protection, which in turn can act as a check on the law. "Every time you add a layer of risk that someone will detect misconduct, I think you increase the chances that misconduct [in the justice system] will be reduced," Filler says.

Title: Tea Party Groups Focus on Immigration Bill, Threatening President Obama's Speedy Approval

Article:

As the Senate has approved its version of the immigration bill, the focus of Tea Party groups has shifted from the IRS targeting scandal to the immigration bill, potentially posing a challenge to President Obama's hopes for swift approval. The bill now rests with the House, where Republicans plan to take up their own version.

During his Africa trip, President Obama called on the House to "get this done" before the August recess. However, House lawmakers are already facing conservative calls to slow down the process. If the debate extends into August, when Congress takes a nearly month-long recess, the prospects could become more uncertain.

In the 2009 August recess, the Tea Party famously helped stall ObamaCare by organizing town hall meetings and other events. Tea Party groups may be preparing to mount demonstrations during the summer break. Even if the House passes a bill this month, it's unlikely the two chambers would agree on a unified piece of legislation by August, leaving the work unfinished going into recess.

This week, dozens of conservative groups, including the Cincinnati Tea Party, sent a letter to House Speaker John Boehner urging him to declare the Senate package "dead on arrival." They expressed concerns that the Senate bill, by offering up to 11 million illegal immigrants a path to legal status, would make life harder for U.S. workers struggling to reach the bottom rung of the economic ladder.

The effectiveness of the Tea Party's grassroots efforts on the immigration bill remains uncertain, as the Republican Party and base are split on the issue. On health care, the movement benefited from a largely anti-Obamacare stance. On immigration, the party is divided, with 14 Republican senators voting for the bill that passed the Senate last week.

Several influential conservative economists argue that immigration legislation would be beneficial for the economy, with newly legalized workers and an enhanced legal immigration system providing the economy with the boost it needs. Tea Party supporters, however, question the claim that the so-called "amnesty" would coincide with enhanced border security. They warn that mass legalization will override any security improvements.

Political strategists view immigration as an important issue that the Republican Party should not ignore. However, Tea Partiers have a powerful tool at their disposal - the ability to threaten wavering lawmakers with a primary challenge. In South Carolina, Tea Party activists staged protests at Sen. Lindsey Graham's office, a key Republican who helped draft the bill. Ron Hughes, with the South Carolina Tea Party Coalition, stated that activists would "love" to see Graham face a primary challenge.

House Republicans have stated they will proceed at their own pace, working on their own bills when it comes to immigration. Last Sunday, they dismissed a prediction by Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) that the House would simply pass the Senate bill. "The House will not simply take up and pass the Senate bill," a Boehner spokesman said. "Our legislation will reflect our principles, particularly on border security."

Title: Fox News Reduces Coverage of President Trump's Rallies Ahead of Midterms

Article:

President Donald Trump's rallies, a staple of his political strategy, are no longer receiving the prime-time coverage they once did on Fox News. During three rallies last week, Fox News aired clips and highlights from Trump's speeches but largely stuck with its regular weekday prime-time programming. On some occasions, the network did not air live rallies, with C-SPAN opting for other programming instead.

Since Trump took office, CNN and MSNBC have mostly declined to air his campaign rallies, though they will typically carry any presidential speeches or comments to reporters. The loss of national coverage is concerning for both the White House and the candidates Trump is traveling to support.

A Senate Republican campaign staffer stated, "It exposes us to a national audience that we normally don't get to. We tend to see lots of new sign-ups and small-dollar donations. There's obviously folks streaming [rallies] online, but being able to be onstage with the president in front of a prime-time audience is huge for a campaign trying to reach conservatives across the country who will open up their wallets."

A source close to Trump described the declining coverage as a "huge loss on the state and local level for Republicans because they're certainly not going to get any of that on other cable networks."

Fox News and the White House did not respond to requests for comment. The decrease in coverage is attributed to a variety of factors, including the sheer number of rallies, the repetitive nature of Trump's speeches, and the impact on advertising revenue during long speeches.

In 2017, Trump's events at times drew over 4 million viewers on Fox News, a number he hasn't come close to in 2018. This year, numbers have typically ranged from 2.5 to 3.5 million, according to a ███ assessment of Nielsen ratings.

Trump has increased his campaign travel considerably in the final weeks before the midterm elections, leaving Fox News to decide between wall-to-wall coverage of his rallies or more selective airtime for the president. One GOP campaign operative stated, "If every night Trump does a rally, a station carries it, you just become the president's station."

The president has not faulted the network for recent changes to its programming. At his Tuesday-night rally in Iowa, which wasn't aired, he heaped praise on his "great friends" at Fox News.

Title: American Service Members Thwart Train Attack in Europe

Article:

On August 21, two American service members, U.S. Airman Spencer Stone and Alek Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon Army National Guard, prevented a potential tragedy on a train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris. Two people were injured in the attack, one of whom was a person with dual French/American citizenship, who was shot, and Airman Stone, who was cut by the attacker.

According to Skarlatos, the incident lasted less than two minutes. Skarlatos, who was returning from Afghanistan, said he and Stone, a friend, noticed the attacker carrying an AK-47 and a handgun. Skarlatos stated, "I looked over at Spencer and said, 'Let's go.' Spencer got the guy first, grabbed the guy by the neck, I grabbed the handgun."

The suspect was identified by French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve on Saturday as a 26-year-old Moroccan man known to Spanish authorities as belonging to "the radical Islamist movement." However, Cazeneuve cautioned that the French police had not yet fully confirmed his identity. French officials had identified the man as a security risk, but he was not under surveillance and had apparently spent little time in France.

After being arrested in Arras on Friday night, the suspect was taken early Saturday to the headquarters of the antiterrorism police outside Paris, Mr. Cazeneuve said, and was being interrogated. French news reports said that he had denied having terrorist aims and that he had said he merely intended to rob the passengers.

However, the arsenal described by the minister suggested otherwise: a Kalashnikov assault rifle, a Luger automatic pistol, nine cartridges, and a sharp blade—a "cutter," the interior minister said, which he used to wound Airman Stone.

The violent encounter was over in barely two minutes. If not for the quick action by the two American servicemen and the suspect's malfunctioning automatic rifle, many lives could have been lost. Chris Norman, a British businessman who helped restrain the suspect after he had been subdued, stated, "The guy actually came up, he pulled out a cutter, started cutting Spencer. He cut Spencer behind the neck, he nearly cut his thumb off. We eventually got him under control."

Title: Trump Proposes Compromise on DACA, TPS, and Asylum in Bid to Break Immigration Stalemate

Article:

President Donald Trump's latest immigration proposal represents a shift in policy on three contentious areas, marking an attempt to break the long-standing impasse on the contentious issue. The areas in question are the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, Temporary Protected Status (TPS), and a new path for asylum for children in Central America.

In a reversal of his previous stance, President Trump has proposed restoring and legalizing these programs, offering to enshrine them in law, providing them with a level of permanence that was not achievable during the Obama administration. In return, he is seeking $5.7 billion for his border wall project and changes to facilitate the deportation of illegal immigrant families and address abuses in the asylum system.

The proposal also includes items that both sides generally agree on, such as more technology to scan for drugs in vehicles at legal border crossings and an increase in the number of immigration judges to address the backlog of cases.

Vice President Mike Pence described the proposal as a "compromise offer" during a press briefing following President Trump's announcement. The embrace of the DACA program is a significant change, as President Trump had previously stated he would not act until the Supreme Court had ruled on his 2017 attempt to phase out the program, which protects approximately 700,000 "Dreamers."

In the case of TPS, the Homeland Security Department has signaled an end to protection for as many as 300,000 individuals, some of whom have been protected for two decades. The Trump administration, in immigration negotiations last year, resisted adding protected status holders into any deal, but this resistance has reportedly dissipated.

Regarding the Central American Minor program, which was canceled in 2017, President Trump is proposing to restart the program, offering full legal protections this time.

Democrats have expressed preference for a full pathway to citizenship for the 1.5 million people who could qualify for DACA and the hundreds of thousands under TPS. They also criticize the proposal as disingenuous, stating that President Trump has put Dreamers and TPS recipients at risk by rescinding their protections.

The Senate, led by Republicans, is scheduled to vote on President Trump's plans next week. However, House Democrats are unlikely to support the proposal. Speaker Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, has rejected the president's proposal and stated that her chamber will vote instead on areas of overall agreement, such as immigration judges and scanning technology.

Title: Donald Trump Jr.'s Speech: No Evidence of Plagiarism, According to Speechwriter

Article:

The allegations of plagiarism against Donald Trump Jr. following his speech at the Republican National Convention have been refuted by his speechwriter, Frank Buckley. Buckley, who also wrote the essay that Donald Jr.'s speech in Cleveland was based on, stated that the repetition was not a case of plagiarism, but rather a repurposing of a previous insight with permission.

Critics persisted, arguing that self-plagiarism is unethical in an academic setting. However, the context of the political arena was emphasized, and the defense mounted by the Obama campaign during the 2008 cycle was brought up. In that instance, Barack Obama was accused of using unoriginal passages without attribution, a claim that was dismissed with the argument that the granting of permission made it acceptable.

Jon Favreau, one of Obama's former speechwriters, echoed this point on Twitter, stating that if the lines in Donald Trump Jr.'s speech were not plagiarism because the author gave permission, neither was the Obama riff from Deval, who also did not receive permission for his lines.

In conclusion, the issue of plagiarism in the political arena is a complex one, with the granting of permission being a key factor in determining its acceptability. It is important to note that the sitting Vice President has also been accused and admitted to plagiarism in the past.

Title: Ex-Congresswoman Halvorson Leads in Race to Fill Jackson's Seat Despite Previous Defeat

Article:

Debbie Halvorson, a former Democratic congresswoman with an "A" rating from the National Rifle Association (NRA), is the front-runner in the race to replace Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr. in a majority-black district that encompasses Chicago and its surrounding areas. The district, which has inner-city neighborhoods affected by gun violence, is historically represented by African-American lawmakers.

Despite Halvorson's defeat in a primary against Jackson last year and the district's predominantly African-American demographic, Halvorson's support base in suburban and rural areas of the district could potentially secure her the Democratic nomination. With a crowded field of 16 candidates, a candidate could win the Democratic nomination with as little as 20% of the vote, given the district's liberal leanings.

Black leaders, concerned about Halvorson's lead in the polls, are planning to make gun control a central issue in the contest. The goal is to portray Halvorson as an NRA ally who is too conservative for the seat and insensitive to Chicago's rising tide of gun violence.

Halvorson, who has described herself as a conservative Democrat, voted with her party more than 90% of the time in Congress. She supported cap-and-trade bills, President Barack Obama's health care and economic stimulus measures, and positions herself as an experienced hand who can quickly adapt to Washington after Jackson's resignation in November.

However, it is her stance on guns that is drawing the most attention. Despite her primary rivals not directly attacking Halvorson, the campaign's focus on guns is seen as a way to differentiate herself from the front-runner.

Title: Young Conservatives Advocate for Shift in GOP's Stance on Same-Sex Marriage

Article:

A group of young conservative activists is advocating for a change in the Republican Party's approach to social issues, particularly regarding same-sex marriage. They argue that the GOP's current stance on the issue is driving away younger voters who would otherwise support the party.

Ryan Rauner, a leader of NextGen GOP, organized an event last week in Arlington, Virginia, to discuss this issue. Rauner stated, "We need more compassion, empathy, and tolerance, and, unfortunately, sometimes tolerance means tolerance of intolerance. What we can never tolerate is the power of government being used by one group against another because they disagree with their beliefs or their lifestyle. That's not freedom; that's not equality."

According to Gallup polling released Wednesday, a record 60 percent of Americans now support same-sex marriage, a 5-percentage-point increase from last year and a 20-point jump since 2009. Among younger Americans, the issue is even more settled, according to conservative activists.

Jerri Ann Henry, the campaign manager for Young Conservatives for the Freedom to Marry, stated, "There are a lot of LGBT people out there who are brilliant small business owners, who hold to the principles of limited government, strong families, fiscal conservatism, and strong national security—things that we as Republicans love—but they don't have a place in the Republican Party right now."

While support for traditional marriage helps Republicans more than it hurts, only 26 percent of voters said it is a make-or-break issue, and a candidate must share their opinion on the issue to win their vote. Among those who oppose gay marriage, 37 percent said a candidate must agree with them, compared to only 27 percent who support recognition of same-sex marriage.

Republican analysts doubted that the 2016 elections will see any major policy shifts for Republicans on the issue, stating that even for most young voters, it's not a threshold issue. Mary Anna Mancuso, a former campaign director for former Florida Republican Rep. Connie Mack's Senate race and founder of Political Hype, said, "I think that it's an issue that polls well, but I'm not sure it's an issue that's going to vote well."

In reaching young voters, harnessing a digital campaign will likely be critical, and Sen. Rand Paul and Sen. Marco Rubio, two already-announced candidates, have done well on that score, according to Alex Patton, owner of Ozean Consulting. However, on a national level, it would be in a candidate's best interest to stress issues that rank higher on the scale of importance for millennials like job security and growing the economy rather than same-sex marriage, Mr. Patton said.

The issue could matter in certain swing states with large youth populations, such as Florida, according to Mr. Patton. "All of these little small things will add up. None of them will be decisive on a national scale, but it could matter in a state as important as Florida, where the line is razor-thin," Mr. Patton said. "A tenth of a point here can be the difference between winning and losing."

The conservatives at the rally said they don't expect same-sex marriage to be the tipping point in the 2016 election, but they want to see more Republicans embrace it. Sara Coleman, a realtor who attended the rally, stated, "Overwhelmingly, Republicans across the country are still going to be viewed as anti-that, anti-equality, and [anti-] marriage, and it's a shame. But all you can do is develop these little core groups, let them rise up, and eventually they will become the norm. So in this election, no, I don't think that marriage equality will be the deciding factor or big issue, but as the nation develops through the course of the years, eventually we will be on the right side of history."

Title: Trump Submits Written Answers to Mueller's Probe, Avoids Post-Election Questions

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has provided written answers to questions from Special Counsel Robert Mueller in his investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 election and potential collusion with the Trump campaign. This was announced by Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, on Tuesday.

"We answered every question they asked that was legitimately pre-election and focused on Russia," Giuliani said in an interview. "Nothing post-election. And we've told them we're not going to do that."

Giuliani stated that Trump did not plan to answer any questions from Mueller regarding whether he attempted to obstruct the investigation after taking office, such as by firing former FBI Director James Comey.

"It is time to bring this inquiry to a conclusion," the lawyer said in a statement earlier on Tuesday, announcing that Trump's answers had been submitted in the probe, which Trump has repeatedly referred to as a "witch hunt."

Trump signed the submission on Tuesday before departing Washington to spend the Thanksgiving holiday in Florida, according to a person familiar with the matter. A spokesman for Mueller declined to comment.

Mueller was appointed special counsel in May 2017 to probe "any matters that arose or may arise directly from the investigation" into possible collusion between Trump's campaign and Russia during the 2016 election. U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election to try to tip it toward Trump by undermining Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton.

Among the topics Trump answered questions about on Tuesday was a June 2016 meeting between the president's son Donald Trump Jr., other members of Trump's campaign team, and a group of Russians. Trump has denied knowing about the Trump Tower meeting with the Russians, who had promised damaging information about Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

Other questions may have touched on WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange and Roger Stone, a longtime Trump ally with ties to WikiLeaks, who is also under investigation.

"There were no real big surprises in the questions. They were detailed, complex, they were multipart," Giuliani said. He would not say how many questions there were.

Mueller has already brought charges against some former Trump aides, including his former campaign chairman and his former national security adviser, as well as a number of Russian individuals and entities. U.S. prosecutors are also preparing to pursue a criminal case against Assange, having obtained a sealed indictment that was revealed in an unrelated criminal case filing last week.

WikiLeaks is known for publishing documents that were previously not public. During the campaign, the group published Democratic emails that U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded were hacked by Russia. Trump praised WikiLeaks during the campaign.

Giuliani said in the statement on Tuesday the president had provided "unprecedented cooperation" with the probe over the past year and a half, noting that more than 30 White House-related witnesses had been questioned and 1.4 million pages of material turned over before Trump responded to the pre-election questions in writing.

He added that "much of what has been asked raised serious constitutional issues and was beyond the scope of a legitimate inquiry."

Giuliani later told CNN there was "very little hope" Trump would sit for an interview with the special counsel. Trump's lawyers have been negotiating with Mueller's prosecutors since last year over whether the president would sit for an interview. Trump himself has offered mixed responses.

In an interview that aired on Sunday, he told "Fox News Sunday" that he was unlikely to do so, explaining that "we've wasted enough time on this witch hunt, and the answer is, probably, we're finished."

It is unclear whether Mueller would subpoena him to testify, likely setting off a legal and political battle. Earlier this month, Trump fired Attorney General Jeff Sessions and appointed Matthew Whitaker as his replacement on an acting basis, renewing calls for legislation to protect Mueller's work. As a private citizen, Whitaker criticized the Mueller probe. Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has opposed such legislation.

Lisa Kern Griffin, a former federal prosecutor and a law professor at Duke University, said she was skeptical much of what had been asked was outside the scope of legitimate authority, as Giuliani maintained.

"The special counsel has a broad mandate to determine what took place during the campaign and to determine whether there has been an effort to obstruct that investigation," Griffin said. "As other presidents have found out, they are not above the law."

Title: Presidential Debate Expected to Break Viewership Records as Clinton and Trump Prepare for High-Stakes Showdown

Article:

The upcoming presidential debate between Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump is anticipated to be one of the most-watched political events in American history, with viewership potentially reaching 80 million, akin to the audience for the 1980 debate between Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter. One-third of voters consider the debates crucial in deciding their presidential preference, making it a significant opportunity for both candidates to present their case for the presidency.

The first presidential debate, along with the subsequent debates on October 9 and October 19, is expected to be characterized by political and personal attacks, departures from the truth, particularly from Mr. Trump, who has a history of disregarding factual constraints.

In an effort to appeal to undecided or third-party-leaning voters, approximately 20% of likely November voters, Mrs. Clinton must either attract these voters to her camp or prevent them from supporting Mr. Trump. Historically, the Democratic candidate has won more votes than the Republican candidate in five out of the last six presidential elections, suggesting that if Mrs. Clinton can mobilize regular Democratic voters, she will be in a strong position on Election Day.

To achieve this, Mrs. Clinton is expected to address the concerns of today's Democratic coalition, a multiracial, multicultural, and multilingual group with diverse interests. She is likely to emphasize her commitment to social justice issues and a reform of the U.S. immigration system, and remind black and Hispanic voters of Mr. Trump's past comments questioning President Barack Obama's birthplace.

Mrs. Clinton is the second least popular major-party presidential nominee in the history of modern polling, with Mr. Trump holding the top spot. While it is important to offer voters someone to support, Mrs. Clinton must be careful not to allow Mr. Trump to redefine himself as a candidate who could be a viable president for suburban women and college-educated white voters, who are swing demographics that Mr. Trump lags behind in what a Republican needs to win a national election.

To counter Mr. Trump's attacks, Mrs. Clinton will need to challenge him in real-time on inaccurate statements he makes during the debate. Mr. Trump's unpredictability, a trait that has seen him make provocative statements, such as boasting about the size of his genitalia during a primary debate, is his biggest advantage. However, his unpredictability also presents a risk, as there is no guarantee of what he will do on the biggest stage of the campaign.

Already, Mr. Trump has demonstrated this unpredictability, as evidenced by his Twitter invitation to Gennifer Flowers, with whom Bill Clinton reportedly had an affair, to attend the debate as his guest. This move was later clarified by Trump's running mate Mike Pence and campaign manager Kellyanne Conway, stating that she had not been invited.

To win over voters and appear presidential, Mr. Trump will need to demonstrate a command of policy sufficient to run the federal government. Refreshing his long-cemented image will be a challenging task, but if he is to achieve it, he will need to display discipline and preparedness during the debate that he has not demonstrated to date.

Mr. Trump's biggest opening lies in Mrs. Clinton's unpopularity. He would be wise to weave issues such as her use of a personal email server and questions about the Clinton Foundation's fundraising practices into his responses. However, Mr. Trump must exercise caution in presenting his case against Mrs. Clinton, avoiding exaggerations and falsehoods that could distract from his message.

Ryan Praises Trump's Outreach to Black Voters: 'Half of It Is Just Showing Up' - This statement is a separate news item and not directly related to the upcoming presidential debate.

Title: GOP Divided Over Bill Allowing Undocumented Immigrants to Serve in U.S. Military

Article:

A split within the Republican Party has emerged over a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants, often referred to as Dreamers, to serve in the U.S. military. Cesar Vargas, a Dreamer and co-director of the Dream Action Coalition, has advocated for legislation to provide a path to citizenship for immigrants like him, with the goal of becoming a military lawyer.

Vargas, who was brought to the United States from Mexico illegally when he was 5 years old, expressed his desire to serve the country he calls home. "This is the reality for us," Vargas said. "This is the country we call home... What it really comes down to is the commitment to serve the country you call home, the country you want to wear a uniform for."

Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) has been a proponent of a bill that would grant legal status to young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military. An amendment, sponsored by Rep. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.), to a must-pass defense-policy bill encourages the Pentagon to consider allowing immigrants brought to the country as children to serve in the military.

However, this amendment has faced opposition from conservatives, led by Alabama Rep. Mo Brooks, who argue that it threatens the passage of the $612 billion defense-policy bill, which typically passes with broad bipartisan support. In a letter to the House Rules Committee, more than two dozen House Republicans threatened to oppose the defense bill if the immigration provision was not removed.

Brooks claimed that the amendment could lead to the Pentagon exempting Dreamers from citizenship and lawful immigrant requirements to serve in the military. "That is not the sense of Congress," Brooks said, "and it's certainly not the sense of the American people to put already struggling American families in the position of not only having to compete in the private sector with illegal aliens, but also trying to compete for military service positions."

Gallego's amendment passed with the support of House Armed Services Committee Democrats and six Republicans, including Rep. Mike Coffman (R-Colo.), who served in both Iraq wars. Coffman, who supports immigration reform, expressed his disappointment with his Republican colleagues for opposing the amendment. "I'm disappointed in my colleagues for fighting this," Coffman said. "I'm not sure why they're so opposed to this. I've been in the Congress side by side with people who are opposed to this, but yet they themselves did not want to serve. These young people ought to have the opportunity to serve."

The bill is expected to be taken up by the full House this week and then must go to the Senate, where Arizona Sen. John McCain leads the Armed Services Committee. McCain has stated that there will not be a similar provision included in his committee's version of the bill.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Freeze on Vehicle Fuel Economy Requirements, Challenging California's Emissions Authority

Article:

The Trump administration has proposed to freeze vehicle fuel economy requirements at the 2020 level and revoke California's authority to set more stringent tailpipe emissions standards. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) jointly proposed on Thursday to cap fleetwide fuel economy at 37 miles per gallon starting in 2020, a move that would reverse the gradual increase to roughly 47 mpg by 2025 under the Obama administration's plan.

The proposal also aims to revoke California's authority under the Clean Air Act, which has allowed the state to set rules more stringent than federal ones limiting tailpipe greenhouse gas emissions and an electric-vehicle sales mandate. The move is seen as an aggressive step to dismantle one of the most significant efforts to combat climate change.

The proposal begins a 60-day period of public comment, during which California's leaders and environmentalists are expected to respond vigorously. Automakers, who have expressed misgivings about accommodating a patchwork of federal and state standards, are also likely to comment on the proposal.

Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao stated, "There are compelling reasons for a new rulemaking on fuel economy standards for 2021-2026. More realistic standards will promote a healthy economy by bringing newer, safer, cleaner, and more fuel-efficient vehicles to U.S. roads, and we look forward to receiving input from the public."

In March 2017, President Donald Trump announced his administration would reopen a review of the Obama automobile rules, citing their unfairness. The Trump administration's rule-making proposal also presents several other options for modifying the Obama targets, while recommending the proposed freeze starting in 2020, the most severe of the scenarios.

In a separate move, the proposal also asserts that a 1975 law prohibits states from setting their own greenhouse gas limits, a view two federal district judges have already rejected. A 60-day comment period will begin once the proposal is published in the Federal Register, and a final rule could be finalized by the end of 2018 or early next year.

The Trump administration argues that its proposed freeze will have a "negligible" impact on air quality and boost the Earth's temperature by 3/1000th of one degree Celsius by 2100. The administration also claims that its preferred plan for fuel economy will reduce society-wide spending by $502 billion for vehicles built between 1975 and 2029.

Critics question the administration's cost estimates, with Nic Lutsey, an engineer at the International Council on Clean Transportation, stating, "This would be utterly unprecedented. Nobody in any regulatory agency has ever done a cost-benefit analysis anything like this. There's no evidence that efficiency regulations have depressed sales and added fatalities as a result -- in any market in the world."

The efficacy of the administration's cost estimates will shape the plan's public acceptance and its ability to withstand court challenges. California, 16 states, and the District of Columbia have already filed a lawsuit challenging the plan's scientific underpinnings.

Title: Trump Warns Iranian Government Amid Ongoing Protests Over Downed Plane Incident

Article:

In the midst of escalating protests and public outrage in Iran, President Donald Trump issued a direct warning to the Iranian government on Sunday via a Twitter post. "To the leaders of Iran - DO NOT KILL YOUR PROTESTERS," Mr. Trump stated. "Thousands have already been killed or imprisoned by you, and the World is watching. More importantly, the USA is watching. Turn your internet back on and let reporters roam free! Stop the killing of your great Iranian people!"

The protests in Iran intensified on Sunday following the Iranian government's admission that it accidentally shot down a Ukrainian passenger plane last week, resulting in the deaths of all 176 passengers and crew members and sparking international condemnation. The incident occurred shortly after Iran launched ballistic missiles at U.S. military bases in Iraq, bringing Washington and Tehran to the brink of all-out war.

The demonstrations across Iran reveal a growing internal anger towards the Iranian government itself. Initially, Iranian leaders denied responsibility for the downing of the plane, only to later reverse their stance as the truth became apparent.

"They are lying that our enemy is America, our enemy is right here," a group of Iranian protesters reportedly shouted during a demonstration in Tehran, according to Reuters. Protesters also reportedly chanted "Death to the dictator," referring to Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

Iranian leaders have since apologized for the incident and pledged to prosecute those responsible.

Trump administration officials on Sunday reaffirmed their willingness to engage in negotiations with the Iranian government for a permanent end to Iran's nuclear weapons program. Simultaneously, U.S. officials sought to exploit the growing protests and create a rift between the government in Tehran and Iranian citizens.

"They want the same things that most people around the world want. They want prosperity," Defense Secretary Mark Esper told CBS' "Face the Nation" program on Sunday. "They want the ability to live their lives, to raise their children. And we do support those same aspirations for people wherever they are. I just think you see a very corrupt regime that the Iranian people are finally standing up and trying to hold them accountable."

Title: Trump Administration Announces New Healthcare Price Transparency Rules

Article:

The Trump administration has announced new rules that will require hospitals and insurance companies to disclose the actual prices for common medical tests and procedures. The aim is to promote competition and reduce costs. However, these sweeping changes face opposition from the healthcare industry and could potentially be challenged in court.

The final rule will apply to hospitals, while a proposed regulation will apply to insurance plans. The disclosure requirements for hospitals will not take effect until 2021, and the timing for insurers is unclear. The rules do not directly affect doctors.

The new rules are intended to illuminate the complex maze of healthcare prices, enabling informed patients to find quality services at the lowest cost. For instance, the cost of an MRI scan can vary by hundreds of dollars depending on the location.

Insurers will be required to provide individualized estimates of what patients would owe out-of-pocket due to deductibles and copayments.

The healthcare industry and insurance companies argue that the push for disclosure goes too far. They contend that the government would force them to publicly disclose rates negotiated as part of private contracts, which are typically beyond the purview of authorities.

Insurers also express concern that the plan could lead to providers raising their prices if others are getting more. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar dismissed this concern, calling it a "canard," stating that transparency does not lead to higher prices in any other area of the economy.

If the industry decides to take legal action, it could be a prolonged process before consumers see any significant changes.

The new rules will require the publication of negotiated rates for the 300 most common services that can be scheduled in advance, such as a knee replacement, a Cesarean-section delivery, or an MRI scan. Hospitals will also have to disclose what they would accept if a patient pays cash. The information will be updated annually.

In addition, hospitals will be required to publish all their charges in a format that can be read on the internet by other computer systems. This will allow web developers and consumer groups to create tools that patients and their families can use.

The administration is also working on creating an online tool that policyholders can use to get a real-time personalized estimate of their out-of-pocket costs for all covered healthcare services and items, from hospitalization to doctor visits, lab tests, and medicines.

The disclosure requirements will implement an executive order signed by President Donald Trump this summer.

Title: Grand Jury Decision in Eric Garner Case Sparks Outcry and Calls for Federal Investigation

Article:

Following the announcement of a grand jury decision on Wednesday not to indict a New York police officer in the death of Eric Garner, politicians and community leaders have weighed in, expressing their views on the incident and its implications for police-community relations.

U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder stated that the Department of Justice will investigate the cases of Eric Garner and Michael Brown. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand expressed her condolences to Garner's family and called for accountability, stating, "Nobody unarmed should die on a New York City street corner for suspected low-level offenses."

New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo acknowledged the tragedy of Garner's death and the need for respect for the legal process and rule of law. He also suggested that the federal government may conduct additional investigations and reviews in this case, and that improvements could be made to better the system.

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, D-Brooklyn/Queens, questioned the grand jury's decision, stating that it was difficult to understand how the officer's actions did not result in charges of second-degree manslaughter or criminally negligent homicide.

The Rev. Al Sharpton has called for a national march in Washington, D.C. on December 13 to halt police brutality and ask for the Department of Justice to prosecute NYPD officer Daniel Pantaleo, the officer in the Garner case. Sharpton's National Action Network will meet with the National Urban League, the National Coalition on Black Civic Participation, and the Black Women's Roundtable on Thursday in New York City to discuss further action.

Garner's mother, Gwen Carr, questioned the justice system's ability to protect minority communities, stating, "How could we put our trust in the justice system when they fail us like this?"

Staten Island Borough President James Oddo called for calm and asserted that disagreeing with the grand jury's decision and peacefully protesting is a right. Police commissioner Bill Bratton assigned extra police for Staten Island in anticipation of potential protests.

Patrick Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, issued a statement expressing remorse for Garner's death but not accepting responsibility for his actions during the incident. Garner's attorney, Stu London, stated that the officer was relieved and emotional upon learning of the grand jury's decision.

Garner's mother, Gwen Carr, and his wife, Emerald Garner, have consistently carried themselves with grace during the past four months, expressing their heartache and demanding accountability for their husband and father's death.

Title: Death Toll Rises to 50 in Las Vegas Shooting: Witness Accounts and Latest Updates

Article:

In the aftermath of a deadly shooting incident at a country music festival in Las Vegas on Sunday night, survivors and witnesses recounted their harrowing experiences as the death toll rose to 50 and over 400 people were reported injured.

The attack occurred during a concert by Jason Aldean at the Route 91 Harvest Festival, with the gunman opening fire from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel. The two gold towers of the Mandalay Bay overlook the concert site.

Witnesses described the initial confusion as the gunfire began, with some mistaking the sound for issues with the speakers. Jason Aldean continued playing through three rounds of gunfire before the concertgoers took the incident more seriously.

Survivors spoke of running for their lives, jumping walls, and climbing cars to escape the hail of bullets. Some huddled together for protection, while others were trampled in the chaos.

"It was hysteria," said Jackie Hoffing, still in a state of trauma. "There were people trampled. We jumped walls, climbed cars, ran for our lives. I've never run that hard or been that scared in my whole life."

The gunshots were described as sounding as though they were coming from different directions and getting closer each time the shooter reloaded. Many took cover under tables, behind buildings, and behind police cars.

"I didn't want to get up because I didn't want to get mistaken for a bad guy and get shot," said Kevin Kropf, who took cover under a table and waited for tactical police units to arrive.

The streets between the concert grounds and the nearest medical center were a non-stop convoy of ambulances and police. Survivors emerged from apartment buildings, motels, parking garages, and other emergency shelters, with nowhere to go as the Strip remained on lockdown.

Reports of gunmen and shootings at other hotels circulated on social media, adding to the chaos and panic. The authorities have not confirmed these reports.

As of the time of this report, the identity of the shooter has not been officially confirmed by the authorities, and the motive behind the attack remains unknown. The investigation is ongoing.

Title: Yang Proposes Licensing Reform to Boost Mobility and Economic Dynamism

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang has introduced a plan to reform licensing requirements in an effort to stimulate mobility and economic dynamism in the United States. The proposal aims to help lower-income individuals move to areas with better job prospects by increasing state-by-state recognition of occupational licenses.

According to data from the Tax Foundation, mobility in the U.S. has significantly decreased over the years. In 1948, 22.2% of Americans moved, but this figure dropped to an all-time low of 11.2% in 2015-2016.

Yang's plan includes increasing state-by-state recognition of occupational licenses, a practice currently adopted by only three states: Arizona, Montana, and Pennsylvania. Licensing requirements often restrict workers from moving to different states and continuing their profession due to the lack of out-of-state recognition of their licenses. This results in additional costs and burdensome licensing processes when workers relocate.

A 2017 paper by labor economists Janna Johnson and Morris Kleiner found that more than 33% of U.S. professions now require a state-issued license. The researchers discovered that workers in licensed professions were, on average, 36% less likely to move across state lines than workers in non-licensed professions.

In addition to licensing reform, Yang's plan includes a tax credit of up to $1,000 for moving expenses. The tax code previously provided for an above-the-line deduction for similar claims, but this provision was eliminated by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017.

Garrett Watson, Special Projects Manager at the Tax Foundation, suggests that Yang's proposed tax credit for moving expenses could stimulate the economy. However, Watson cautions that it would need to be part of a larger set of reforms, including reducing licensing burdens and zoning laws that drive up housing costs, to make a significant impact.

Title: Trump's Town Hall Performance in Wisconsin: A Focus on Salesmanship Over Substance

Article:

In a town hall setting moderated by Greta Van Susteren on Fox News in Madison, Wisconsin, Donald Trump delivered an hour-long performance that left the impression of a skilled salesman rather than a political candidate. The event took place amidst what is believed to be a challenging week for Trump's campaign.

During the town hall, Trump did not clarify or retract any of his controversial statements on various topics, including his stance on abortion, NATO, and trade deals. He reiterated his plans to repeal Obamacare, lower taxes, renegotiate trade deals, and bring jobs back to the United States, but provided few details on how these plans would be executed.

Trump emphasized his intention to address the drug epidemic in New Hampshire, offering specifics on this issue. He also mentioned his plan to speak with Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto to address the issue of drug trafficking.

The Republican nomination battle remains ongoing, with Trump continuing to campaign. Ted Cruz, on the other hand, reportedly gained at least 18 delegates in North Dakota during the same evening, a significant development in the long-running race.

Trump's approach to the town hall meeting has been compared to Muhammad Ali's "Rope a Dope" strategy, where the boxer would evade punches to wear out his opponents. Trump's strategy appears to involve talking extensively without providing specifics, a tactic that has been a hallmark of his campaign.

Despite the lack of detailed policy discussions, Trump maintained a positive outlook, promising a "greatest," "cheapest," and "best-looking" presidency. However, the specifics of his plans remain unclear.

Title: Trump's Unorthodox Foreign Policy Approach: Achievements and Concerns

Article:

President Donald Trump, who was primarily elected on domestic issues, has made a significant impact on foreign affairs in his first 16 months in office. The president's international actions, such as withdrawing from the Iran nuclear deal and moving the U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, are the latest in a series of substantial foreign policy moves.

In contrast, Trump's major domestic achievements have been limited to the passage of a large tax cut in December and the confirmation of Neil Gorsuch as a Supreme Court justice over a year ago. However, in the international arena, the list of substantive actions is far longer.

Trump has initiated efforts to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula with a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, a historic event. He has also pulled out of the Paris climate agreement and the Trans-Pacific Partnership, made gains against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS), and increased troop levels in Afghanistan.

Republican strategist Alex Conant, who worked for Trump rival Sen. Marco Rubio during the 2016 primaries, acknowledged that when it comes to foreign policy, "He has exceeded the expectations of his critics. He is very unorthodox, but that isn’t to say he hasn’t seen some early successes."

Trump's approach seems to be driven less by any putative Trump doctrine and more by instinct. Few experts are sure of Trump's exact position on the ideological spectrum when it comes to foreign policy, given his zigzags on issues including North Korea and Syria.

Trump loyalists see this trait as an asset, showing a useful flexibility. Detractors, however, insist that the president's approach breeds new instabilities. Joel Rubin, who served as a deputy assistant secretary of State during the Obama administration, said that Trump "really lacks a clear, coherent approach around which adversaries, allies, and the agencies—the three As—can orient themselves."

Rubin cited the example of the recent visit to Washington by French President Emmanuel Macron. Macron's primary hope as he crossed the Atlantic was that the Iran nuclear deal could somehow be saved. But he ultimately failed to sway Trump or even get significant concessions, despite having taken significant political risks in making the trip.

Trump, however, clearly thinks that foreign policy figures in both parties are not so wise as they believe themselves to be. Exhibit A in defense of the president's unorthodox approach is North Korea. When Trump blasted Kim and threatened to "totally destroy" North Korea during a speech at the United Nations in September, numerous experts predicted a downward spiral in relations—and feared that war was a real possibility.

Instead, Trump executed an abrupt change of tack in March, agreeing to a meeting with Kim in response to an offer conveyed through South Korea. Skeptics note there is no guarantee that anything of substance will emerge from the Trump-Kim summit, set for June 12 in Singapore. But the mere fact that it is happening—the first-ever meeting between a North Korean leader and a sitting U.S. president—is a considerable boost for Trump's approach.

Supporters argue that it is part of a broader picture in which Trump is persistently underestimated. "He doesn’t articulate and conceptualize things in the way a traditional bureaucrat does," said James Jay Carafano of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank. "There is the showman Trump and the serious Trump. We just see the showman—the tweets and everything else. But you can’t understand the foreign policy just by looking at the surface."

Carafano argued that the idea of Trump as a chaotic figure was exaggerated. "This is not a scattershot president. This is not a presidency lurching from fire to fire," he said. "This is a president going out very deliberately and pursuing policy. [The administration] clearly have a policy direction. They have made all the big policy decisions and now they are just in execution mode."

Trump has found that executing foreign policy is in some respects easier than domestic policy. The president's frequent campaign trail promises to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, foundered during his first year in office. Another huge campaign slogan—building a wall on the southern border—is still a long way from realization, with Congress balking at providing funding.

Amid those frustrations, Trump and Republicans see his foreign policy record as something to tout. It may be difficult for Trump to reap many electoral benefits from his moves, however. "Voters primarily care about what impacts them and their families," said Conant. "Faraway threats that don’t directly involve American lives can be hard to get voters to prioritize."

There may be political gains to be harvested by incorporating foreign policy achievement into a broader narrative, however. As the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem opened on Monday, Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, in rare public remarks, stated: "While presidents before him have backed down from their pledge to move the American Embassy once in office, this president delivered. Because when President Trump makes a promise, he keeps it."

The idea that Trump keeps his promises is repeated often by his allies, even as it is fiercely contested by critics. "The world looks to the United States for predictability and stability. When you look at the world today, few people say it needs more instability. That’s the concern many people have when it comes to foreign policy."

Title: Al Franken's Impact on Political Polarization in Washington

Article:

The search for a culprit responsible for the polarization, gridlock, and negative feelings in Washington D.C. can be traced back to Senator Al Franken. This is not a personal attack on Franken, but rather an examination of the potential consequences of his narrow victory in the 2008 Minnesota Senate race.

In a hypothetical scenario, if Franken had lost the Senate race by several hundred votes instead of winning by a razor-thin margin that prompted months of recounts, the Democratic Party would have had only 59 votes in December 2009. This would have required them to corral at least one Republican vote to pass ObamaCare.

President Obama faced little real resistance in Congress to start his presidency, and this lack of opposition set the stage for the polarization to come. Without a Democratic supermajority, Obama would have been forced to negotiate with Republicans (or, at least, former Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine) and settle for incremental health care legislation that his then-Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel recommended. The GOP would still have been opposed to any Democratic health care reforms, but the antipathy would have been muted because a few Republicans would have supported the legislation.

Instead of provoking a pitched partisan showdown that culminated with then-House Minority Leader John Boehner exclaiming that the Congress had "shattered the bonds of trust" with the American people, Obama could have tempered the wrath of the Republican opposition.

"In a democracy, you can only ignore the will of the people for so long and get away with it," Boehner presciently argued before the House's fateful ObamaCare vote. "If we defy the will of our fellow citizens and pass this bill, we are going to be held to account by those who have placed us in their trust."

Imagine, for a moment, the state of the 2010 midterms without ObamaCare in the equation. Republicans would have run against the stagnant economy with some success. But without the galvanizing opposition to Obama's health care law—Republicans netted a whopping 63 House seats that year—Democrats would likely have narrowly kept control of Congress, and continued to press forward with Obama's agenda. There would be tea-party-aligned Republicans elected, but absent the wave, not enough to form the concerted opposition that emerged. Veteran Blue Dog Democrats like Reps. Ike Skelton, Gene Taylor, and Chet Edwards (among others) would likely have been reelected, and become bridge-builders between parties.

The notion of moderate pragmatism prevailing might sound like fantasy to readers who have watched the political cage-fighting over the last seven years. But even in our polarized times, politics is still primarily about self-interest.

Obama acted against his political self-interest in pushing ObamaCare through Congress, but given the divided government that ensued, it then made some sense for him to play to his base in his reelection campaign and stick to his liberal principles after winning. At the same time, Republicans would have been committing political malpractice if they ignored the tea-party tsunami that enveloped the country in 2010. With intensifying energy on the Right, the biggest political threat to members emerged from within their own party, and they adapted accordingly.

The question then becomes: Who started the fire? Obama certainly deserves some of the blame, and he has admitted recently that one of his biggest regrets as president was the polarization that he's leaving behind. The problem is that he hasn't connected his early actions with what transpired.

The notion that Obama was fated to face an intransigent Republican opposition has always been off-base. He won a historically-high 53 percent of the vote in 2008, bringing Democratic congressional seats that they hadn't won in decades, including ones in rural Alabama and Louisiana. He even won 40 percent of non-college-educated whites—a remarkable tally given how despised he is among this constituency today. Democrats had all the political tools they needed to press Obama's widespread personal popularity into an agenda that could pick off enough moderate Republicans to succeed. (Just consider an alternate reality in which legislation addressing income inequality, job-skills training, and the costs and quality of college education were the centerpieces of an Obama agenda after the recession.)

But it's also understandable that Obama, eager to be seen as a historically-consequential president, would want to spend all of his political capital early on the Democratic dream of expanding public access to health care—political backlash be damned.

That's where Al Franken comes in. If it weren't for 312 voters in Minnesota, Obama's ambitions would at least have been curtailed by legislative realities, and the trajectory of his presidency would have looked much different. Franken, the first insult comic to get elected to the Senate, circuitously paved the way for the rise of a much different type of entertainer—Donald J. Trump.

Title: Donald Sterling's First Amendment Rights Intact Despite NBA Scandal, Says Legal Expert

Article:

In the recent uproar surrounding Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling's racist remarks about black people, many have questioned whether his First Amendment rights were violated. However, according to legal expert Marc J. Randazza, while Sterling's privacy rights may have been violated, his First Amendment rights remain intact.

The First Amendment protects individuals from governmental punishment due to their speech. The National Basketball Association (NBA), as a private club, has the right to discipline Sterling as it sees fit. The criticism leveled against Sterling is not a violation of his First Amendment rights, but rather an example of the marketplace of ideas in action.

Randazza points out that the recording of Sterling's conversation may have been illegal, and the leaking of the recording was morally wrong. The recording, featuring Sterling and V. Stiviano, may have been the result of a crime, as California law requires the knowledge or consent of both parties to record a conversation.

Randazza argues that we all have private conversations that we might not share publicly, and we should have the freedom to make the choice of whether to make those ideas public. The Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy, who made his own controversial and bigoted statements, is an example of someone who chose to make his statements public and faces the consequences.

Randazza warns that the public character execution of Sterling could lead to a world where individuals fear expressing unpopular views, even in private conversations. He compares this to George Orwell's novel "1984," where the Telescreen, a device that beamed information into the home but also spied on people constantly, represents a world where there is no privacy.

Randazza concludes that the Sterling story is not just about finding a bigot and condemning him, but about the breakdown of privacy and trust in society. He questions whether we now live in a world where we can trust nobody and where there is no privacy. Randazza suggests that we should condemn the complete breakdown of privacy and trust at least as loudly as we condemn Sterling's racist remarks.

Title: New Congress Takes Office, Prioritizing Healthcare Reform, Regulatory Rollbacks, and Cabinet Confirmations

Article:

A new Congress took office in the nation's capital on Tuesday, with the swearing-in ceremony led by re-elected Speaker of the House Paul Ryan. The 115th Congress, which opens with Republicans in full control of both chambers and the White House for the first time in almost a decade, is eager to get to work.

Top on the agenda is the potential scrapping of President Barack Obama's signature piece of legislation, the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Republican lawmaker Cory Gardner of Colorado stated, "We'll work to repair the damage of Obamacare." He added, "A law that was sold on broken promises to the American people. A law that has led to soaring premiums, failing insurance markets, and dwindling choices."

House lawmakers are also planning bills to roll back thousands of federal regulations imposed by the Obama administration on various sectors, including the environment, drilling, and businesses.

The confirmation of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet nominees is another priority. Democrats are reportedly planning to target at least eight of Trump's 15 cabinet picks, according to The Washington Post. However, the confirmation process may present challenges, as Democrats have vowed not to make it easy.

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich expressed concern that the incoming administration might "lose their nerve" in taking on the Democrats. He stated, "I worry that when they realize how big the problem is, that they decide that they're just going to do the best they can and give in."

Congressional Republicans have already backed down from a controversial last-minute plan to revise congressional oversight, following heavy criticism from both sides. The plan involved reining in the independent Congressional Ethics Office and putting it under the oversight of the House Ethics Committee.

President-elect Trump has also expressed concern about this decision, tweeting, "With all that Congress has to work on, do they really have to make the weakening of the Independent Ethics Watchdog, as unfair as it may be, their number one act and priority?"

In foreign policy, President Trump will face a series of challenges, including dealing with Russia, the ongoing battle to defeat ISIS, the ongoing chaos in Syria, and North Korea's recent announcement of its plans to test launch an intercontinental ballistic missile. On Monday, Trump tweeted about North Korea's missile ambitions, saying, "It won't happen" on his watch.

Title: Justice Department Declares Case Against Andrew McCabe Closed Following Allegations of Lying to Investigators

Article:

The Justice Department announced on Friday that former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe will not face charges following an investigation by the department's inspector general that he lied to investigators about a leak to the media. In a letter to McCabe's attorneys, the department stated, "based on the totality of the circumstances and all of the information known to the government at this time, we consider the matter closed."

The decision is unlikely to be welcomed by President Trump, who has repeatedly criticized McCabe online and in public remarks. McCabe has long been a target of Republican leaders who allege political bias within the FBI. McCabe's wife ran for the state legislature in Virginia as a Democrat, prompting early attacks that he might be going easy on Hillary Clinton. Later, McCabe was fired after investigators concluded he lacked candor about an episode involving the release of information to a reporter. He was relieved of duty in March, hours before he was set to retire.

McCabe has maintained his innocence and has called himself the victim of political vengeance. In a statement on Friday, McCabe's lawyers said, "At long last, justice has been done in this matter." They added, "We said at the outset of the criminal investigation, almost two years ago, that if the facts and the law determined the result, no charges would be brought." The lawyers continued, "We are pleased that Andrew McCabe and his family can go on with their lives without this cloud hanging over them."

The allegations against McCabe stemmed from a Justice Department Office of Inspector General's report, which found that McCabe "lacked candor" when he told investigators that he did not know who authorized an aide to talk to the Wall Street Journal about the FBI investigation into the Clinton Foundation.

The Justice Department's decision not to pursue charges against McCabe comes a day after Attorney General William Barr publicly criticized Trump, saying his tweets "make it impossible for me to do my job."
