McCabe has sued the Justice Department, alleging that his March 2018 firing by then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions was a politically motivated act of retribution by Trump and "unlawful."

Title: Virginia Democrats Face Political Quandary as Three Top Officials Accused of Misconduct

Article:

In the midst of the 2020 Democratic presidential primary, a political quandary has arisen in Virginia as three top officials, including Governor Ralph Northam, Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax, and Attorney General Mark Herring, face allegations of misconduct. The situation is particularly challenging for the Democratic party due to the historical presence of black and female candidates in the race.

State Senator J. Chapman Petersen, a white Democrat, commented on the potential optics of the situation, stating, "To show a firm grasp of the obvious, the optics would be difficult and the substance would be difficult."

The Democrats' recent political successes, such as their 40-seat win in the House midterm elections in November and their 2017 triumph in the top Virginia races, have been significantly influenced by women and African-American voters. With Republicans barely holding onto their legislative majority in the Virginia Capitol, these two blocs are crucial for the Democrats' victory in the upcoming election of all 140 delegates and state senators.

Given the current situation, some Democrats are turning to their most loyal constituency: black women.

Shortly after Vanessa T. Carroll, a Duke University alumna, accused Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax of sexual assault in 2000, several senior Virginia Democrats began advocating for State Senator Jennifer McClellan to replace Fairfax if he resigns or is impeached. However, it is unclear whether Governor Northam could appoint any successor to Fairfax due to conflicting provisions and interpretations of the Virginia Constitution and state law.

Senator McClellan, who is black, is a longtime Richmond legislator with statewide ambitions and a close relationship with Senator Tim Kaine. When asked about McClellan, C. Richard Cranwell, a former state Democratic chairman and legislator, stated, "Jennifer would make an exceptionally good lieutenant governor."

Title: House of Representatives Votes to Protect State Medical Marijuana Laws

Article:

In a move that aligns with recent public opinion surveys, the Republican-led House of Representatives voted early Friday to prohibit the federal government from interfering with medical marijuana laws passed by 32 states and the District of Columbia. The vote saw 218 yes votes, with 49 of these coming from actual Republicans.

California Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, a former employee of Ronald Reagan, the president who made the "War on Drugs" a national priority, was among the leading advocates for the measure. Rohrabacher argued that the strict federal policies, particularly in the case of medical marijuana, were causing more harm than good.

"Some people are suffering, and if a doctor feels that he needs to prescribe something to alleviate that suffering, it is immoral for this government to get in the way," Rohrabacher said. "The state governments have recognized that a doctor has a right to treat his patient any way he sees fit, and so did our Founding Fathers."

However, not all Republicans supported this view. Virginia's Frank Wolf, who chairs the House committee that wrote the $50 billion appropriations bill on which the marijuana language was tacked, questioned the legitimacy of medical marijuana. Wolf pointed out that several medical organizations, including the American Medical Association, American Cancer Society, American Glaucoma Society, and Glaucoma Research Foundation, among others, opposed medicinal marijuana.

Two doctors who are also members of Congress, Louisiana Republican Rep. John Fleming and Maryland GOP Rep. Andy Harris, expressed concerns about the impact of marijuana on brain development and the imprecision of marijuana prescriptions, respectively.

In response, Georgia Republican Rep. Paul Broun countered with his own medical expert, stating that the components in marijuana are useful for some conditions. "It's actually less dangerous than some narcotics that doctors prescribe all over this country," Broun said.

The vote result surprised even those who had been lobbying for it over the past decade. Mason Tvert, a spokesman for the Marijuana Policy Project, noted that the proposal had received the most votes previously in the House (165 in 2007).

"We expected that we'd get close to passing it, and then pass it next year," Tvert said. "But clearly things are moving forward very quickly at the federal level just as they are at the state level. People are fed up with the current state of marijuana laws."

However, the proposal has only cleared the House, and Rohrabacher and his Democratic co-sponsors acknowledged that they did not have Senate supporters lined up yet to move the language in that chamber. Democratic Rep. Jared Polis, whose state of Colorado allows non-medicinal marijuana, stated that focusing on what happens next in the congressional process misses the larger point.

"The will of the House is important on this issue," Polis said. "Congress is far from leading the country in this regard. Rather, we're catching up with where the country already is."

Title: Democrats Offer Criticism of Biden, Discussions on Buttigieg's Speech Emerge

Article:

The political landscape is shifting, with the Democratic party expressing encouragement following recent polling results, while maintaining criticism towards President Joe Biden and offering thoughts on the speeches delivered by candidate Pete Buttigieg.

The polling data indicates a challenging outlook for President Donald Trump, with his approval rating significantly lower than in the 2016 election in Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa - states he won during that election. However, it is important to note that much can change between now and the November 2021 election, and it is true that state-level polls underestimated Trump's support in 2016.

The head-to-head polling does not provide a clear picture of events 18 months in the future, but it does suggest that there is no counterintuitive process whereby Trump secures the votes of people who disapprove of his presidency. The public, for the most part, expresses a desire to vote for any Democratic candidate, with better-known Democrats performing better than less-known ones.

Democrats are advised to take a modest amount of reassurance from Trump's poor polling numbers and focus on other issues. The ongoing debate within the party centers around Biden's assertion that if Trump is no longer in office, Republicans in Congress will negotiate with a Democratic president in good faith. However, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has stated that he will continue to obstruct any legislation from a Democratic president, while promising to further pack the Supreme Court if a vacancy arises during an election year.

Biden and other Democratic candidates are encouraged to run against McConnell and the Trump Republicans in Washington. Some argue that Biden may be attempting to woo Obama-to-Trump voters and upscale white suburbanites who are reportedly dismayed by Trump's behavior. However, there is evidence to suggest that Biden believes he brings unique skills at bipartisanship to the table, having made deals with the Republicans in the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s.

Regarding Buttigieg's speech, opinions are divided. Some view Buttigieg as an heir to Obama's cautious and intellectual worldview, while others see him as a liberal internationalist who aims to bridge the gap between the Obama and Clinton wings of the party. The debate revolves around Buttigieg's ability to articulate his vision and policies effectively, as he seeks to set a generous narrative of national identity against Trump's narrow and uncompromising vision.

In conclusion, the political landscape is evolving, with the Democratic party offering criticism towards President Biden and discussing the speeches delivered by candidate Pete Buttigieg. The polling data suggests a challenging outlook for President Trump, while the debate within the Democratic party centers around bipartisanship, national identity, and the role of the wealthy in politics.

Title: "Caution Advised in Interpreting 2020 Presidential Polls Due to Persisting Challenges from 2016"

Article:

Several Republican officials and pollsters have expressed concerns about the reliability of 2020 presidential election polls, citing the inaccurate polling results from the 2016 election. In a recent report, more than 50 Republican officials interviewed from across the country have expressed optimism for President Donald Trump's re-election prospects, attributing the optimism to unreliable polls, a rebounding economy, and a fading pandemic.

Neil Newhouse, a veteran GOP pollster, stated that there is a "shy Trump supporter," or voters unwilling to disclose their support for President Trump during phone surveys. He believes that this group could account for at least 2 to 3 percentage points in the vote count. The "shy Trump supporter" phenomenon was a factor in the flawed polling of the 2016 election, with national polls showing Hillary Clinton winning the popular vote by 3 percentage points, but she ultimately won by only 2 points. Election-eve polls in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, and Michigan also failed to predict Trump's victories in those states, which ultimately decided the Electoral College.

The Trump campaign has seized on the "shy voter" theme, leading to headlines such as "Trump has a point about the polls." The polling community, particularly in battleground states, is still grappling with the same issues they faced in 2016, including shy voters and possibly inadequate consideration of non-college-educated white voters.

Courtney Kennedy, director of research at the Pew Research Center and the lead author of a report on 2016 polling flaws, warned that the fundamental, structural challenges that came to a head in 2016 are still in place in 2020. This warning is significant for both campaigns and voters, as it suggests that if pollsters do not address these issues, both parties must behave as if the polling might be off. In other words, when it comes to polls, caveat emptor - buyer beware.

Title: Romney Shifts Strategy, Emphasizes Policy Prescriptions and Foreign Policy in Campaign

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, is altering his campaign strategy, focusing on a broader range of issues beyond the economy in response to recent polls showing President Barack Obama leading in crucial swing states. Chief strategist Stuart Stevens revealed this shift in strategy to ███.

The new strategy, which includes a more comprehensive focus on policy prescriptions, marks a departure from Romney's long-held strategy of emphasizing the struggling economy almost exclusively. However, Stevens emphasized that the economy will remain the dominant focus of the campaign.

The change in strategy comes as polls indicate Obama gaining ground in states like Ohio, a critical battleground state. Romney advisers concluded that a course correction was necessary to counter this trend.

The new strategy will see Romney's ads and speeches addressing a wider array of issues, including foreign policy, the threat from China, debt, and the tone in Washington. Stevens stated that the central question of the campaign will be: "Can we do better on every front?"

On Monday, Romney unveiled a new ad, "The Romney Plan," which counters Obama's emphasis on growing the economy for the middle class and outlines Romney's plans. In the ad, Romney says, "My plan is to help the middle class. Trade has to work for America. That means cracking down on cheaters like China. It means opening up new markets."

A second ad, "Failing American Families," released on Monday, is more critical, with a male narrator stating, "Barack Obama: More spending. More debt. Failing American families."

The new ads represent a concession to internal critics of Romney's previous ad series, the 16 "A Better Future" ads, which were customized for nine swing states. Each ad begins with a clip of Romney at the convention, followed by a quick statistic arguing that Obama has failed that particular state, and ending with Romney's plan to help the state (defense in Colorado, home values in Florida, manufacturing in North Carolina).

Romney also plans to emphasize policy solutions when he speaks Monday to the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce in Los Angeles. In prepared remarks, Romney criticizes Obama for not discussing the unemployed and not unveiling a jobs plan at the Democratic National Convention.

Romney, who is losing the Hispanic vote to Obama, also includes a pitch to improve "legal immigration." He states, "I will work with Republicans and Democrats to permanently fix our immigration system. I believe we can all agree that what we need are fair and enforceable immigration laws that will stem the flow of illegal immigration, while strengthening legal immigration."

Stevens argued that Romney is performing better than many pundits recognize, and the Middle East unrest and continuing economic unease will help Romney regain momentum and alleviate concerns among GOP insiders.

Title: Kupperman Lawsuit Halts Testimony in Trump Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

Charles Kupperman, former White House official and top aide to John Bolton, failed to appear for a scheduled deposition with House investigators on Monday as part of the impeachment inquiry into President Trump. Kupperman filed a lawsuit on Friday, seeking a court ruling on whether he should comply with the House subpoena to testify or comply with a White House order to stay away.

House investigators had expected Kupperman to corroborate key elements of a top U.S. diplomat's account that Trump built a shadow foreign policy team around his personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, to pressure the Ukrainian president to investigate a political rival, and that Trump held up U.S. military aid for Ukraine as leverage.

Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, rejected Kupperman's move as a ploy to delay his appearance. However, Schiff also stated that House Democrats do not intend to wait for the court ruling and are prepared to move ahead with their impeachment inquiry.

Kupperman's lawyer, Charles Cooper, stated in a Friday statement that his client seeks only to carry out whichever constitutional obligation the Judicial Branch determines to be lawful and binding on him. House investigators called the lawsuit a stall tactic and accused Kupperman of working with the White House to stonewall Congress.

Nicholas Rostow, who served as legal adviser to the National Security Council in George W. Bush's White House, expects the congressional subpoena to take precedence over the White House claim, but cautioned that the court may take a different view. Rostow, who has long worked with Bolton and knows Kupperman, said the court may have to wrestle with the question of whether the House has officially voted on the impeachment inquiry, potentially allowing executive privilege to still apply.

People who know Kupperman describe him as honest, straightforward, and not swayed by politics or ideology. Former Trump administration officials note that Kupperman is known for following procedures and served various roles in President Reagan's administration, including in the White House and on an advisory committee on arms control. Kupperman worked as an executive at defense contractors Boeing and Lockheed Martin before joining the Trump administration in January. He left the White House on Sept. 20, 10 days after Bolton and Trump parted ways.

Kupperman has expressed some controversial hard-line views in his past work with Frank Gaffney, the founder of the Center for Security Policy, who has advocated curtailing immigration and has repeatedly denounced Muslims. However, a former Bush administration official noted that Kupperman was also known to be "quietly instrumental" in helping to strengthen and build National Security Council staff during his time in Trump's White House.

Kupperman started at the National Security Council two months after Bolton's first deputy, Mira Ricardel, was pushed out of her post following an argument with first lady Melania Trump's office. Despite their political differences, Ross said he never knew Kupperman to be anything but straightforward. "It'll be the real facts," Ross said. "It won't be something else. It won't be alternative facts."

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Senator Ted Cruz Engage in Debate over Government Shutdown and Obamacare Funding

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Senator Ted Cruz have engaged in a heated debate over the potential government shutdown due to the funding of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. In an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press" on Sunday, Senator Cruz, who has been leading the charge to defund Obamacare, accused Senator Reid of being unwilling to negotiate or compromise on the issue.

Cruz stated that Senator Reid's position is that "100 percent of Obamacare must be funded in all instances, and other than that he's going to shut the government down." Cruz also mentioned that early Sunday morning, the House passed a compromise bill, which would delay the implementation of Obamacare for a year, rather than defund it entirely.

Senator Cruz argued that although he believes Obamacare should be repealed, he is currently fighting only to defund it. He stated, "That's the essence of a compromise." In response to criticism from some of his fellow Republicans that his efforts may harm the party if the government is shut down, Cruz compared his stance to that of former Senator Phil Gramm, R-Texas, who in 1993 opposed the Clinton healthcare initiative. Gramm's arguments persuaded other Republicans to oppose what Cruz called "Hillarycare Lite."

Senator Cruz also addressed the argument that the public is not protesting in the streets against the Affordable Care Act. He responded, "The only people who are not listening to the argument are the career politicians in Washington." The article concludes with a call-to-action for readers to visit NBCNews.com for more information.

Title: Democrats Show Flexibility on Revenue Targets in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

In the ongoing negotiations regarding the fiscal cliff, incoming House Democratic Caucus chair Xavier Becerra has indicated a willingness to negotiate on the revenue target, signaling a shift from the party's hardline stance on tax rate increases for top-wage earners and resistance to major entitlement changes.

While Democrats continue to advocate for tax rate increases on the wealthy and avoid significant revisions to Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security, they are not necessarily tied to the multitrillion-dollar revenue target proposed by President Barack Obama, which Republicans deem unrealistic.

California Rep. Xavier Becerra, the incoming Democratic Caucus chairman, stated, "So long as you come out with a balanced approach, you could come up with almost any number."

The year-end tax debate has primarily focused on the extent to which Republicans are willing to accept tax increases. House Democrats, who have been largely excluded from talks between House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and Obama, could play a significant role if a year-end budget package is negotiated.

Democrats in the House, who lost the majority in 2010, will likely be called upon to move the package across the finish line to offset potential GOP defections. While most Democrats are unlikely to oppose the White House, the administration is already adjusting its revenue goals.

After initially requesting $1.6 trillion in revenue, the administration presented Republicans with a proposal this week that reduced the request to $1.4 trillion. Most Democrats aim for a deal that closely aligns with Obama's opening bid and reject the $800 billion in revenue offered by Republicans as insufficient.

If lawmakers were to pursue a middle ground between the Republican and Democratic offers, they would find themselves in the vicinity of $1.2 trillion. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-Texas) stated that this revenue goal is acceptable.

"Without me committing Democrats, what I would say is we are open to an idea that is in that range," she said.

Rep. Bill Pascrell (D-NJ), a member of the tax-writing Ways and Means panel, also suggested a deal could be reached at $1.2 trillion, but not lower.

"The president could come down to $1.2 trillion," he said. "I don't think he'll go any lower if he did."

Other Democrats argue there is room for negotiation. In the Senate, Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus (D-MT) has discussed a deal that raises $1 trillion in revenue.

"There is a lot of middle ground between $1.6 trillion and $800 billion," said Rep. Linda Sanchez (D-CA), who will join the Ways and Means Committee next year.

Another incoming Ways and Means Democrat, Pennsylvania's Allyson Schwartz, stated, "Nothing is set in stone."

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Distance Themselves from Obama's Policies Amidst High Approval Ratings

Article:

In the ongoing 2020 Democratic presidential race, several candidates are distancing themselves from former President Barack Obama's policies, despite high approval ratings among Democratic voters. While many voters are searching for a candidate reminiscent of Obama, the candidates argue that Obama's administration failed on immigration, healthcare, and trade.

Former Vice President Joe Biden, who once referred to Obama as his "brother from another mother," criticized Obamacare, the trade deal negotiated during the Obama administration, and the high number of deportations during Obama's tenure. When asked if he would continue Obama administration deportation policies, Biden said, "Absolutely not."

Senators Kamala Harris of California and Cory Booker of New Jersey also criticized Obama's immigration and healthcare policies, respectively. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio criticized the Obama Justice Department's handling of the 2014 killing of Eric Garner, a black man who died in a chokehold by city police during his arrest for selling cigarettes on the street.

In response, Biden defended the Obama immigration record, citing the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) deportation amnesty granted to illegal immigrant "Dreamers." He argued that the number of deportations was not a fair measure of the administration's accomplishments.

Democratic strategist Zach Friend, who worked on Obama's 2008 campaign, stated that it was a mistake to criticize Obama's legacy, as his popularity among Democrats has been as high as 97% in recent polls. Friend argued that the focus should be on President Trump's current policies rather than criticizing Obama's legacy.

The Rev. Wendell Anthony, president of the Detroit NAACP, agreed, stating that the focus should be on Trump "because his record is destroying the nation and who we are."

Despite the criticism, Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez made it clear that Obama's legacy remains popular, stating, "Am I the only one who misses Barack Obama in this room?" during the debate.

Criticizing Obama's time in the White House is a risky move for any of the 2020 hopefuls, as they risk alienating the party's voters who romanticize Obama's not-so-long-ago days. It is particularly treacherous for Biden, who is running as Obama's political heir with the promise of restoring the normalcy of the Obama era.

Obama voters were irked by the attacks on the former president's policies at the debates. Francois Demonique, a professional chauffeur in Detroit, stated, "I felt bad seeing Obama's legacy dragged through the mud." Demonique, who moved to the U.S. from Liberia more than 30 years ago and got his U.S. citizenship to vote for Obama, was especially distraught that Senators Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts want to replace Obamacare with "Medicare for All" government-run health care.

Iowa-based Democratic strategist Jeff Link stated that it is smart for Biden to keep Obama close, as the good in the eyes of primary voters far outweighs the bad. Link stated, "I wouldn't put a lot of distance between [Biden] and President Obama on anything." Link also noted that Biden's words against Obama may have been "in the heat of the moment" of the debate and that Biden tried to repair any damage afterward.

However, the Democratic Party has moved dramatically to the left since Obama was in office. Some of the strongest challengers to Biden, who remains the front-runner, are far-left champions Senators Sanders and Warren. Another powerful contender, Senator Harris, is more moderate but also is embracing parts of the far-left agenda, including a variation of Medicare for All.

According to Darrell West, vice president and director of governance studies at the Brookings Institution, it is an effective strategy for Biden to tap into Obama's popularity with the party's voters. West stated, "That may well be Biden's best claim to the nomination. However, in the current political environment, it will be hard to defend Obama's record on deportation and trade, as the party has moved well to the left on those issues, and no one is going to accept those policies as the right ones at the current time."

Title: Colin Kaepernick's Controversial Protest and Its Impact on American Sports

Article:

Colin Kaepernick, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback, has been making headlines for his controversial decision to not stand during the national anthem, a move that has sparked both criticism and support. Kaepernick, who is currently not playing due to his limited career success, has been using this controversy to keep his name in the spotlight.

Kaepernick's actions have been compared to the marketing strategies of athletes like Dizzy Dean and Muhammad Ali, who were known for their boastful and charismatic personalities. However, unlike Ali, who backed up his claims with exceptional athletic performance, Kaepernick's career has been moderately successful at best.

Kaepernick's protest is a response to what he perceives as the oppression of black people and people of color in America. He stated, "I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and people of color. To me, this is bigger than football, and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way." He has vowed to continue his protest until there is "significant change" and he feels the flag represents the country as it should.

The country, as a whole, may not meet Kaepernick's exacting standard, and it is unclear if it ever will. Kaepernick, who is 28, may not recognize himself in 10 years. He was raised by white foster parents, and his relationship with them is not widely known.

The anthem, originally an English drinking song called "To Anacreon in Heaven," has been the national anthem since 1931, beating out "America, the Beautiful." Angry football fans have resorted to burning Kaepernick's jersey, a move that, ironically, still generates revenue for the athlete due to jersey sales.

The internet has been ablaze with reactions to Kaepernick's actions, with some taking pride in the unique American right of free speech he is exercising, while others have expressed disdain for his actions. The greater glory of America, as some have pointed out, is the right to peacefully protest, a right that has been protected and preserved by many who have given their lives in service to the country.

Title: First Lady Michelle Obama Urges Fundraising Support for Democrats Ahead of Midterm Elections

Article:

First Lady Michelle Obama called upon supporters in Chicago on Thursday to contribute the maximum allowable amount to Democratic campaign committees in an effort to bolster the party's chances in the upcoming midterm elections. The fundraising push comes as President Barack Obama, who has been actively fundraising in recent weeks, concluded a three-day West Coast tour that raised millions of dollars for the committees.

In her address to donors, Michelle Obama stated, "We need you to write the biggest, fattest check that you can possibly write." She emphasized, "Writing those checks is the single-most impactful thing that you can do right now."

The midterm elections in November present a challenging landscape for Democrats, with their chances of taking control of the House appearing slim, and Republicans aiming to secure the six Senate seats necessary to take over the chamber.

President Obama's approval ratings remain at record lows, which has left many incumbent Democrats hesitant to campaign alongside him. However, the President remains a draw at high-dollar fundraisers, having attended events in New York, Texas, Colorado, Washington state, and California over the past month.

During his recent West Coast trip, Obama made stops in Seattle, San Francisco, and Los Angeles, including a star-studded event at the home of "Scandal" and "Grey's Anatomy" creator Shonda Rhimes.

In addition to official Democratic committees, Obama has also appeared at several events for two Democratic super PACs, despite his past opposition to outside groups with unlimited fundraising potential. These events, while not officially labeled as fundraisers, do not have official price tags, and organizers claim they are not fundraisers.

Although Obama does not explicitly ask for funds during these super PAC events, attendees are generally understood to be high-dollar donors who write substantial checks before departing. There is no limit to the size of contributions to super PACs. Neither the White House nor the organizations themselves have disclosed the attendees at the four events Obama has attended for the groups.

In her fundraising pitch on Thursday, Michelle Obama acknowledged "there's too much money in politics," but argued that Democrats could not afford to trail behind Republicans in that area. "We can't just stake out the moral high ground and feel good about ourselves—we need to act," she said.

During her remarks, Obama expressed continued faith in her husband's ability to bring about positive change, a campaign slogan from 2008 that Vice President Joe Biden seemed to suggest had not yet materialized last week. "When folks ask me whether I still believe everything we said about hope and change back in 2008, I tell them that I believe it more strongly than ever before," she said. "While we still have plenty of work to do, we have truly made so much of that change we've been talking about."

Title: Bipartisan Opposition to NSA Phone Data Collection Program

Article:

A bipartisan group of lawmakers, led by Representative Justin Amash (R-Michigan), has introduced a measure to end the National Security Agency's (NSA) bulk collection of phone records. The push for the measure has found an unexpected ally in Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. (R-Wisconsin), one of the principal authors of the USA PATRIOT Act.

Sensenbrenner, in a statement, expressed his opposition to the program, stating, "The time has come to stop it." The program, he argued, was not in line with his original intent when authoring the PATRIOT Act.

Opposing this measure are not only President Barack Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio, but also leaders of the nation's defense and intelligence establishment. On Tuesday, the director of the NSA, General Keith Alexander, provided classified briefings to lawmakers regarding the program, and the White House issued a statement urging lawmakers not to approve the measure.

On Wednesday, James L. Jones, the retired Marine Corps general who was President Obama's national security adviser from 2009-10, added his name to an open letter in support of preserving the NSA programs. The letter, signed by more than half a dozen top national-security officials from the Bush administration, stated, "Denying the NSA such access to data will leave the nation at risk."

Representative Mike Rogers (R-Michigan), a supporter of the NSA program, took a personal swipe at Representative Amash, stating, "This is not a game, this is real. It will have real consequences."

Despite these overtures, many rank-and-file Republicans and Democrats appear impervious to such arguments. Representative Jared Polis (D-Colorado) and a supporter of the amendment, stated that if the Obama administration felt strongly about defending the program, President Obama would have spoken out personally. Instead, the White House released a statement under the name of the press secretary, Jay Carney.

"The press secretary says hundreds of things every day," Mr. Polis said.

The divisions in Congress seem to reflect the ambivalence in the nation. In a CBS News poll released Wednesday, 67 percent of Americans said the government's collection of phone records was a violation of privacy. At the same time, 52 percent called it a necessary tool to help find terrorists.

Title: Clinton's Personal Fundraising for Super PAC Sparks Controversy Among Progressive Critics

Article:

Hillary Clinton's decision to personally raise funds for a super PAC supporting her presidential campaign has sparked criticism from progressive Democrats, who view the move as a contradiction to her populist rhetoric. The former Secretary of State's involvement with Priorities USA, a super PAC, has highlighted the contrast between her and her only declared rival, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, as well as other potential Democratic candidates.

Clinton's campaign has explained the decision as a matter of political necessity, citing the need for resources to compete against Republican candidates and their reported reliance on super PACs. However, the move has been met with criticism from progressive activists who find the prominent role of super PACs in elections distasteful.

Sen. Bernie Sanders, an independent from Vermont seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, has aggressively opposed super PAC donations. As a long-shot candidate without a national fundraising operation, Sanders has no chance of matching Clinton's fundraising haul and has little to lose by going after millionaire and billionaire donors.

The development has also exposed a core tension for Democrats, who have increasingly embraced super PACs at the same time that they decry the explosion of soft money in national politics. Critics argue that Clinton's personal involvement with Priorities USA underscores a perceived disconnect between Clinton and middle-class voters.

Phil Noble, a South Carolina Democratic activist and supporter of former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, a potential Democratic candidate for president, said the development underscores what progressives view as a "fundamental disconnect" between Clinton and middle-class voters.

Activists who are pushing Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren to challenge Clinton see campaign finance reform as a major issue. "Being a true champion for working families like Elizabeth Warren is about clearly and unequivocally supporting such critical priorities as a constitutional amendment overturning Citizens United," said Erica Sagrans, campaign manager for Ready for Warren, a movement dedicated to drafting Sen. Elizabeth Warren into the 2016 race.

The 2016 money race is well underway on the other side of the political aisle. Declared GOP candidates including Sens. Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida, as well as expected candidates like former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, are on a fundraising tear. They have shown no signs of distancing themselves from super PAC money.

Some progressive leaders argue that the stiff competition against Republican money is a reality that cannot be ignored. Former Vermont governor and Democratic National Committee Chairman Howard Dean said it would be unwise for Clinton to reject super PAC money. "Unfortunately, if you don't play by the same rules everybody else does, you end up losing elections," said Dean, founder of Democracy for America, one of the groups behind the draft Warren movement. "The key is to change the rules, and I think we have a much better chance of doing that with her as president than we do with one of the Republicans."

Title: Mueller's Office Disputes BuzzFeed News Report on Trump and Cohen

Article:

In a rare public statement, special counsel Robert Mueller's office on Friday disputed a report from BuzzFeed News that alleged President Donald Trump directed his former attorney, Michael Cohen, to lie in his testimony before Congress. The BuzzFeed report, which received worldwide coverage and intense interest, claimed that Trump instructed Cohen to lie about the Trump Organization's pursuit of a deal to build a luxury residential high-rise in Moscow, hoping to conceal these actions during his presidential bid.

Mueller's office, which has remained mostly quiet on reports regarding the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, took the rare step of calling BuzzFeed's story "not accurate." Peter Carr, a spokesman for Mueller's office, stated, "BuzzFeed’s description of specific statements to the Special Counsel’s Office, and characterization of documents and testimony obtained by this office, regarding Michael Cohen’s Congressional testimony are not accurate."

The BuzzFeed report also asserted that Mueller's office knew of the president's alleged actions after obtaining information through internal emails, text messages, and multiple interviews. The report revived discussions about the possibility of impeaching Trump and emboldened House Democrats who vowed to investigate the allegations.

While Mueller's office disputed how BuzzFeed characterized statements, documents, and testimony in its story, the statement did not include specifics or a sweeping denial of the story's overall theme: that the president directed Cohen to lie to Congress. BuzzFeed responded Friday, saying the news organization remained "confident in the accuracy of our report."

The news organization's Editor-In-Chief, Ben Smith, asked that Mueller's office be more clear as to what was inaccurate in the story. "In response to the statement tonight from the Special Counsel's spokesman: We stand by our reporting and the sources who informed it, and we urge the Special Counsel to make clear what he's disputing," Smith said on Twitter.

The president, who frequently calls the media "fake news," lashed out about the report and Cohen's credibility. "Lying to reduce his jail time!" the president wrote on Twitter. Michael Cohen, 52, is expected to begin a three-year prison sentence in March after pleading guilty to federal financial crimes, campaign finance violations, and lying to Congress, which was at the heart of the BuzzFeed story.

Cohen admitted he was not truthful when he told the Senate and House Intelligence Committees that all discussions about a Moscow development had ceased in January 2016, knowing that such efforts had continued through at least June – in the heat of the campaign and as Trump repeatedly denied any links to Russia. Prosecutors have asserted in court documents filed late last year that the tower project "likely required the assistance of the Russian government." The court documents did not address whether Cohen's false statements about the Moscow tower discussions were prompted by any other consideration than an attempt to personally shield the campaign from public association with Russia.

Title: US Opposition Calls for Trump's Interpreter to Testify over Putin Summit

Article:

U.S. opposition politicians, led by Robert Menendez, the lead Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, have called for Marina Gross, Donald Trump's interpreter during his summit with Vladimir Putin, to testify before Congress. The request comes amid controversy surrounding the summit, with questions arising over the details of the private conversation between the two leaders.

At their first bilateral summit, held in Helsinki on Monday, the two presidents met privately for two hours with only their interpreters present. Despite ongoing investigations into alleged Russian state interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, Mr. Trump proceeded with the meeting.

Confusion over Mr. Trump's position took another turn when he appeared to reject suggestions that Russia might try again to influence American elections, prompting a hasty denial by the White House. Democrats argue that, as the only other American official present in the room, Ms. Gross can and should provide details of what the two presidents said to each other.

Senator Menendez stated, "We want the interpreter to come before the committee. We want to see the notes. We're going to have a massive effort to try to get to what happened." Democratic Representative Bill Pascrell added, "Congress and the American public deserve to know the details of their private conversation."

If Ms. Gross declined to appear before the committee, she should be subpoenaed, he wrote. "We need public testimony by the only American present at this meeting to ensure Trump did not further undermine our intelligence or law enforcement communities," he said.

Interpreters are typically meant to be all but invisible at summits, and Ms. Gross is a U.S. State Department employee with years of experience translating at the highest level, according to CNN. However, Bob Corker, the Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, expressed reservations about the idea.

"They're not policy people," he told reporters. "They are in some cases contract folks. In the future, would any notes even be allowed to be taken if you started doing this kind of thing?" He also pointed out that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who was in Helsinki with Mr. Trump, would be questioned by the committee next week.

In Russia, Konstantin Kosachev, head of the foreign affairs committee in the upper house of parliament, said the idea of questioning an interpreter set a dangerous precedent that threatened the "whole idea of diplomacy." The Associated Press reports this view.

Gamal Helal, an Arabic interpreter and senior adviser to four U.S. presidents and seven secretaries of state, told CNN he could not remember such a situation. "It would be a horrible precedent if a president was not free to talk one-on-one with a head of state... If he [Mr. Trump] spoke in English, there would be no other way for Congress to know what he said, except to ask the president himself. Or Putin."

While the summit was held behind closed doors, the two leaders gave a news conference afterwards at which Mr. Trump shocked many by defending Russia over the allegations of election interference. Contradicting his own intelligence agencies, he said there had been no reason for Russia to meddle in the vote. A day later, Mr. Trump came out to say he had "misspoken" and did actually accept U.S. intelligence agencies' findings that Russia had interfered.

However, a new row developed when the U.S. leader appeared to disagree with U.S. intelligence over whether Russia was still targeting American elections. Investigations into the alleged interference, denied by Russia, continue, and last week, the U.S. justice department charged 12 Russian intelligence officers with hacking Democratic officials in 2016.

Title: Democratic Representatives Boycott State of the Union Address Over President Trump's Remarks

Article:

Florida Representative Frederica Wilson has announced her decision to boycott President Trump's State of the Union address, joining a growing list of Democratic lawmakers who have expressed discontent with the President. Wilson's decision stems from President Trump's "recent racist and incendiary remarks about Haiti and African nations."

In a statement released late Sunday, Wilson stated, "For the first time since I began serving in the U.S. House of Representatives, I will not be attending the president's State of the Union address." She further expressed her belief that the address would be filled with "innuendo, empty promises, and lies."

Representatives Maxine Waters (D-Calif.), John Lewis (D-Ga.), and Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) have also announced their intention to boycott the event.

Representative Waters, in an interview with MSNBC over the weekend, stated, "Why would I take my time to go and sit and listen to a liar?" She added, "Someone who lies in the face of facts, someone who can change their tune day in and day out. What does he have to say that I would be interested in?"

Representative Lewis made his announcement on Friday, citing reports that Trump had referred to some African countries as "s--tholes" in a conversation with lawmakers about immigration. Lewis stated, "I can not in all good conscience be in a room with what he has said about so many Americans."

Representative Blumenauer had announced his intention to skip the event before Trump's remarks became public, stating that it would be a waste of time and that he would be working at home instead.

In response to the accusations of racism, President Trump stated, "I'm not a racist," adding, "I am the least racist person you have ever interviewed."

In addition to the State of the Union boycott, other protests planned by Democrats include Representative Jackie Speier (D-Calif.) wearing black in solidarity with victims of sexual harassment, and inviting victims of sexual assault to attend the President's first State of the Union address.

Other ideas, such as holding mock trials with women who have accused Trump of sexual misconduct, have been proposed but not yet implemented.

In 2016, Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) skipped former President Barack Obama's last State of the Union address, and three conservative Supreme Court justices - Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, and Antonin Scalia - were also a no-show. Scalia, who died in 2016, had missed the State of the Union address more than a dozen times and called the event "a childish spectacle."

Title: Florida Senate Rejects Assault Weapons Ban, Advances Bill to Arm Some Teachers

Article:

In a party-line vote, the Florida Senate rejected a proposal to ban assault weapons and advanced a measure to arm some teachers, following the deadliest high school shooting in U.S. history that occurred on February 14 at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. The assault weapon ban amendment, attached to a wider bill, was voted down on Saturday, with the final tally being 20-17 against the ban. Two Republicans joined all 15 Senate Democrats in support of the proposal, according to the Miami Herald.

The full bill, known as the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School Public Safety Act, is expected to pass the state Senate on Monday and then move to the Florida House. Following the Senate's rejection of the assault weapon ban, Stoneman Douglas student Jaclyn Corin tweeted, "This breaks my heart, but we will NOT let this ruin our movement. This is for the kids." Fellow classmate David Hogg, who has become one of the school's leading activists on gun safety, tweeted, "Elections are going to be fun!"

An amendment to remove a provision to train and arm some teachers also failed. The bill raises the minimum age to buy a rifle or a shotgun to 21 from 18 and bans the use, sale, or possession of bump stocks, which were used in the October 1 shooting deaths of 58 people in Las Vegas. The device effectively turns semi-automatic weapons into automatics.

The bill includes $400 million in funding for schools to address mental health issues, the Herald reported. Nikolas Cruz, the accused 19-year-old shooter who was expelled from Stoneman Douglas, had a history of run-ins with the law and school officials. The Broward County school system and sheriff's department have been criticized for not acting on red flags regarding Cruz's mental health problems and potentially violent behavior.

Title: The Role of Politics and Government in Society: A Reflection on the 2016 Election

Article:

The conclusion of the 2016 election serves as a reminder of the significant role politics plays in modern society, and the potential consequences of elevating politics to a central position in our lives. The article suggests that a less politically-centric approach might lead to a more content and self-sufficient society.

The piece argues that politics, when given undue prominence, attracts individuals with questionable intentions who promise to solve all problems in exchange for votes. These promises, if kept, would eliminate the need for further political engagement, but they are rarely fulfilled. The author uses examples such as the Affordable Care Act, the removal of Confederate battle flags, and Title IX regulations to illustrate this point.

The article also touches on the tendency of both major political parties to impose their agendas, with Democrats being compared to strict schoolmarms and Republicans to overzealous enforcers of centrally conceived projects. The current obsession with Title IX rules governing sex on college campuses is cited as an example of political types benefiting from drawing up rules and regulations.

The article emphasizes the importance of character and personal conduct, suggesting that these aspects were once the foundation of moral law and discourse in civilized societies. The author questions the role of bureaucracy in shaping individual character and calls for a reevaluation of the purpose of politics and government in a democratic society.

The piece concludes by asserting that the role of a democratic society is to protect the inborn right to a life of freedom, virtue, and contentment, a right that is less familiar to Americans today compared to the past. The author suggests that this right is being undermined by excessive political involvement and calls for a return to a more self-reliant, self-sufficient society.

Title: Kentucky's Affordable Care Act Enrollment: A Double-Edged Sword for Sen. Mitch McConnell

Article:

In the closely watched Senate race between Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell and his Democratic opponent, the Affordable Care Act (ACA), often referred to as "Obamacare," has become a significant campaign issue. However, the effectiveness of this strategy may be questionable, as the ACA has been implemented smoothly in Kentucky, and more than 1 in 10 residents are now covered by "kynect," the state-run exchange under the ACA.

According to Stephen Voss, an associate professor of political science at the University of Kentucky in Lexington, the ACA may be a "wash" as a political issue in Kentucky. Voters in the state recognize the ACA's flaws, but they also appreciate the assistance it provides, particularly through kynect.

In 2014, more than 413,400 people were enrolled in kynect by mid-April. Surveys of enrollees show that 75 percent had no health insurance prior to kynect. Moreover, more than half of those signed up are under the age of 35, a significant demographic for this crucial age bracket.

Kentucky's popular Democratic governor, Steven Beshear, embraced the ACA's provision to expand Medicaid, health care for the poor. Statewide, about 80 percent of kynect customers are covered by the Medicaid expansion, and the other 20 percent have chosen the exchange's private plans.

In areas devastated by the recent collapse of the coal industry, such as Hazard, the coverage for the poor is particularly welcome. In the past year, more than 10,000 jobs have been lost in eastern Kentucky, where unemployment now stands at 14.5 percent.

Stephen Kelly, a young man with a wife and two sons and a master's degree in Christian ministry, recently moved to Hazard on the promise of a job that then fizzled. After signing up in person for Medicaid under kynect, which he found to be a "convenient, simple" process, he underwent a physical and lab tests, which he had not had "in quite some time." This is the first time he has had health insurance.

While the ACA is helping him and his family, Mr. Kelly has mixed feelings about the law. While it is helping those who need it, he notes that it is causing insurance costs to skyrocket for those who already had insurance, such as his parents.

The ambivalence of Kentuckians toward the ACA is reflected in an April poll by The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation. People don't like the health-care law, but they don't want to scrap it either. A majority – 55 percent – disapprove of the health-care law. However, a majority also say their representative in Congress should work to improve the law, not repeal it and replace it with something else.

This ambivalence is also seen in other states with hotly contested Senate seats, such as Louisiana and North Carolina. In Arkansas, another state with a close Senate race, a plurality – 48 percent – want Congress to fix, rather than repeal, the ACA.

Sen. McConnell's Democratic opponent, Kentucky Secretary of State Alison Lundergan Grimes, who favors the keep-and-fix approach, has avoided discussing the health-care law. Her supporters call kynect "Beshearcare," after the governor.

State Sen. Robert Stivers (R) predicts that people will experience "sticker shock" when health insurance enrollment notices go out for the new year, just before the election. If this occurs, Sen. McConnell may benefit from his anti-ACA message. However, until then, the new law "loses its power as an issue" due to the ambivalence about it, according to Professor Voss.

Title: Former Vice President Biden's Marijuana Policy Stance and Its Impact on 2020 Presidential Race

Article:

In a recent public appearance, a potential 2020 Democratic candidate, speaking as a parent of a middle school student, expressed concerns about the growing market for marijuana sales in middle schools. He stated that in the black market, sellers do not verify the age of buyers, disregarding the need for identification.

The Democratic candidate who may face the most scrutiny on marijuana policy is former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who, during the 1980s and 90s, was a prominent figure in the "war on drugs." He advocated for laws imposing strict mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses, including marijuana possession, leading to an era of mass incarceration with significant economic and social consequences for minorities.

John Hudak, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution specializing in state and federal marijuana policy, stated that Biden's history on criminal justice issues is his most significant liability in the 2020 primary. Hudak noted that Biden's stance in 1994, while mainstream at the time, is now "almost offensive" in the context of current Democratic politics.

In 1994, Biden supported a law that mandated harsher penalties for crack cocaine compared to powder cocaine, a distinction that disproportionately affected African-Americans and whites. Biden has since acknowledged this law as a "big mistake."

Spokespeople for Biden, who has reportedly told aides he is 95 percent committed to entering the presidential race, did not respond to requests for comment.

Two Democratic senators who oppose federal marijuana legalization, Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, represent Midwestern battleground states with politics less progressive than the coastal states that have led the way in legalizing cannabis for adult use.

Title: ASEAN Foreign Ministers Express Concern Over South China Sea Tensions, Seek Meeting with China

Article:

Foreign ministers from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) have expressed serious concern over recent developments in the disputed South China Sea region and have agreed to seek a meeting with China to discuss the issue. The concern was voiced at the end of their annual retreat, which took place in the Laotian capital of Vientiane this year.

The strategically important South China Sea is at the heart of a territorial dispute involving China on one side and several ASEAN countries, including Vietnam, the Philippines, and Malaysia. Tensions have escalated since China began a massive land reclamation program in 2013. Recent satellite imagery suggests that China has installed surface-to-air missiles in a disputed area in the Paracels chain, leading to accusations that Beijing is militarizing the area.

In a joint statement, the ASEAN foreign ministers expressed their concern over "recent and ongoing developments" and took note of the concerns expressed by some members regarding land reclamations and the escalation of activities in the South China Sea. The activities, they said, have "eroded trust and confidence, increased tensions, and may undermine peace, security, and stability in the region."

Vietnam's foreign minister, Pham Binh Minh, stated as he left the meeting that he was "seriously concerned about the situation" and called for the "non-militarization" of the South China Sea. Cambodia's foreign minister, Hor Namhong, said ASEAN would seek a meeting with China over the matter, though no date or venue has been set.

In addition to the South China Sea issue, other matters were on the agenda. The ministers reiterated their perennial call for the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. They also addressed Islamic extremism, in the wake of an attack in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta in January that left eight people dead.

Malaysia's foreign minister, Anifah Aman, said, "The threat is real. It's no longer fictitious or mere imagination."

Other topics included ways to bring about ever closer economic cooperation since the advent of the ASEAN Economic Community at the end of last year.

Title: Rowan County Clerk's Absence Leads to Issuance of First Same-Sex Marriage License

Article:

In a significant turn of events at the Rowan County Courthouse in Kentucky, a gay couple, James Yates and William Smith, were issued a marriage license after five previous unsuccessful attempts. The event took place on a morning that saw an emotional and contentious scene, with protesters both condemning and cheering the couple as they entered the clerk's office.

The couple arrived at the courthouse as the sun began to rise, passing by protesters on their way to the clerk's office. The county clerk, Kim Davis, who had previously denied them marriage licenses on five occasions, was in jail due to being held in contempt by a federal judge on Thursday for defying the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling on same-sex marriage. In her absence, Deputy Clerk Brian Mason handled the couple's application.

Yates and Smith became the first same-sex couple to receive a marriage license from Rowan County. After a brief process, Mason congratulated the couple and handed them an envelope.

Outside the courthouse, the couple was greeted with chants of "Love has won." Yates expressed his feelings about Kim Davis' incarceration, stating, "I don't want her in jail. No one wanted her in jail. We just wanted the licenses given out." He further added, "This is not a blessing. It's an official license."

Yates' sentiments were that civil rights should not be subject to personal beliefs. "This means, at least for this area, civil rights are civil rights and they're not subject to beliefs," he said.

Kim Davis' husband, Joe Davis, was also present outside the courthouse with a group of protesters who considered this a moral fight. Joe Davis stated, "We don't hate these people. That's the furthest thing from our hearts. We do not hate nobody. We just want to have the same rights that they have." He further added, "They're saying, 'Hey we're going to make you accept us.' But they don't want to accept our beliefs. But they want us to accept theirs."

There is some question regarding the legality of the marriage licenses issued today, as they do not bear Kim Davis' signature.

Title: Attorney General Jeff Sessions Responds to President Trump's Criticism

Article:

In a rare move, Attorney General Jeff Sessions responded to repeated criticism from President Donald Trump by defending his tenure at the Department of Justice (DOJ). Sessions' statement comes after Trump's interview with Fox and Friends host Ainsley Earhardt, in which the President criticized Sessions for not taking control of the DOJ.

Sessions' statement emphasized the department's success in enforcing the President's agenda, reducing violent crime, and promoting economic growth, among other achievements. He also reiterated his commitment to upholding the rule of law and maintaining the highest standards within the DOJ.

The President's criticism of Sessions in the Fox interview was not limited to his perceived lack of control over the DOJ. Trump also suggested that Sessions should have informed him of his intention to recuse himself from the FBI investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election, and that he only appointed Sessions due to his loyalty. In a personal attack, Trump questioned Sessions' masculinity and ethics.

This is not the first time Trump has publicly criticized Sessions, but it is the first time Sessions has directly responded to such attacks. In February, Sessions responded to Trump's tweets about the Inspector General's investigation into potentially massive FISA abuse, stating that he had initiated the appropriate process to address complaints against the DOJ.

Sessions' latest statement seems to be a response to Trump's recent frustration over the conviction of former campaign chairman Paul Manafort and the plea deal of former lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen, both of which are outcomes of the special counsel Robert Mueller's probe. Trump has expressed his belief that the investigation is illegal and that Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the Russian interference investigation is the root of his political problems.

However, most legal experts view Sessions' recusal as the right decision, given his role as a prominent surrogate for Trump during the 2016 campaign and his failure to disclose several interactions with Russians during his confirmation hearings. Despite Trump's criticism, he has not fired Sessions, with Trump's lawyer Rudy Giuliani stating in late May that Trump has no intention of doing so before the Mueller investigation concludes.

With Sessions' statement, it appears he is challenging Trump to fire him, seemingly unwilling to be bullied into resigning or being forced out of his post.

Title: President Obama Promotes Infrastructure Investment Plan in Miami

Article:

In a speech at the port of Miami on Friday, President Barack Obama advocated for his "Rebuild America Partnership" plan, which aims to encourage private sector investment in infrastructure to stimulate job creation and economic growth in the United States.

"There are few more important things we can do to create jobs right now and strengthen our economy over the long haul than rebuilding the infrastructure that powers our businesses and our economy - our roads, our bridges, our schools, and our ports like this one," President Obama said.

The "Rebuild America Partnership" consists of three components: the creation of a $10 billion national infrastructure bank, the establishment of new "America Fast Forward Bonds" for infrastructure investment, and the expansion of funding for the TIGER and TIFFIA infrastructure programs.

"Let's rebuild this country we love. Let's make sure we're staying on the cutting edge. Let's make sure we've always got the best ports. Let's make sure we've got the best airports. Let's make sure we've got the best rail lines. Let's make sure we've got the best roads. Let's make sure we've got the best schools," he said. "We're going to push on this issue each and every day and make sure we get the middle class going again."

Before delivering his speech, the president toured a tunnel project at the port of Miami, which is undergoing a $2 billion renovation funded by government and private money.

"Breaking ground on more projects like this tunnel that I just saw means more good construction jobs that can't be outsourced," Obama said. "They have to be done right here in America, and they end up getting people good pay and good opportunities to raise their family."

Alan Krueger, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, stated that the program will total $21 billion but vowed that it would not increase the deficit. Details of the costs of the program will be outlined in the president's budget, which will be presented on April 10.

"They will not increase the deficit by a dime because they are paid for in our budget," Krueger told reporters aboard Air Force One Friday. The president stood in front of a crane manufactured by a Chinese company called ZPMC during his speech.

Title: Charlotte Police Allege 70% of Arrested Protesters Were Out-of-State Residents

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent unrest in Charlotte, North Carolina, Todd Walther, spokesman for the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Fraternal Order of Police, stated to CNN's Erin Burnett that 70% of the arrested protesters had out-of-state identification cards. Walther claimed that the unrest was not caused by local protestors but by outside entities instigating the violence.

According to a tweet by OutFrontCNN on September 22, 2016, Walther stated, "We've got the instigators that are coming in from the outside. They were coming in on buses from out of state. If you go back and look at some of the arrests that were made last night, I can about say probably 70% of those had out-of-state IDs. They're not coming from Charlotte."

This statement comes as a surprise to many, but it may not be entirely unexpected given the events that transpired in Ferguson, Missouri, 18 months prior. In August 2014, the riots in Fergusion gained national attention, and liberal billionaire George Soros was accused of funding social justice organizations to turn local protests into a national flashpoint.

In an interview with The Washington Times, key players and financial records revealed that Soros had been funding and mobilizing groups across the U.S. for years, contributing $33 million to social justice organizations. However, in 2015, Ken Zimmerman, the director of U.S. programs at Soros' Open Society Foundations (OSF), denied that Soros had funded Black Lives Matter (BLM), stating it was just a rumor.

This changed when hackers with DCLeaks.com published OSF documents showing that the Soros group had already given at least $650,000 directly to BLM. The documents revealed that the reason for OSF's bankrolling of BLM was to "dismantle" America and recast it according to the vision of Soros and his leftist cohorts. The communist-on-its-face nature of the demands of the organizations under the BLM umbrella are a clear indicator of the real intent of BLM.

With Hillary Clinton's poll numbers declining rapidly and a debate looming, some question whether the sudden appearance of "out-of-state" protesters in Charlotte could be an attempt to shift the focus from Clinton's email scandal, pay-to-play allegations, foreign policy missteps, and health concerns. George Soros, a significant political donor, has been mercurial in his political contributions. In 2004, he contributed $23.5 million to organizations opposing George W. Bush's reelection effort. In 2008, he donated $2,300 to both Clinton and Barack Obama, and that was it. Soros' Open Society Policy Center, the advocacy arm of his philanthropic network, spent $8.2 million on lobbying Washington in 2015. Since 2003, Soros has contributed $54 million to federal candidates and committees.

Title: Campaigns Focus on Foreign Policy Amid Middle East Attacks

Article:

In a shift from their previous focus on the economy, the presidential campaigns of Mitt Romney and Barack Obama have engaged in a second day of forceful foreign policy debate following attacks on U.S. diplomatic posts in Cairo and Benghazi, Libya.

At a rally in a northern Virginia suburb of Washington, Romney expressed condolences for the families of American diplomatic workers who died in the Benghazi attack, including Chris Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya. However, he quickly turned to a critical assessment of President Obama's foreign policy strategy.

"As we watch the world today, sometimes it seems that we're at the mercy of events instead of shaping events, and a strong America is essential to shape events," Romney said.

Obama, also campaigning Thursday, did not mention Romney's criticisms but issued a warning to the perpetrators of Tuesday's killings.

"I want all of you to know that we are going to bring those who killed our fellow Americans to justice," Obama said to applause at a campaign stop in Colorado. "I want people around the world to hear me, to all those who would do us harm, no act of terror will go unpunished."

The aggressive stance from Obama was a contrast to the image Romney began painting of the president late Tuesday, when his campaign issued a statement calling the Obama administration's response to an assault on the U.S. embassy in Cairo "disgraceful." That statement came before news broke that America's ambassador to Libya had died in an attack on a consulate in Benghazi.

On Wednesday, Romney continued his approach, saying Obama had "demonstrated a lack of clarity as to a foreign policy."

"I think it is a terrible course for America to stand in apology for our values," Romney also said. "That instead when our grounds are being attacked and being breached that the first response of the United States must be outrage at the breach of the sovereignty of our nation. And apology for America's values is never the right course."

In his remarks, Romney again accused the Obama administration of sympathizing with the instigators of the violence in Cairo, citing a statement released by the American embassy there stating it "condemns the continuing efforts by misguided individuals to hurt the religious feelings of Muslims."

A timeline of events Tuesday suggests Romney was mistaken in that allegation, since the violence came after the first statement was published. A later tweet from the embassy, which was subsequently deleted, indicated the embassy was standing by their original statement and also condemning the protests.

Reaction to Romney's sharply negative tack has been mixed. Obama, along with other Democrats, pushed back, saying Romney was injecting politics during a time of still-developing international crisis. Like Romney, Obama did not mince words about his political opponent.

"Gov. Romney seems to have a tendency to shoot first and aim later," Obama said during an interview with CBS. "As president, one of the things I've learned is you can't do that. It's important for you to make sure that the statements that you make are backed up by the facts and that you've thought through the ramifications before you make them."

Former Ambassador Nick Burns, who served in the administrations of former Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, said he was "dismayed" by Romney's choice to inject politics into what he said was a "very difficult situation" for the United States.

"I think it's time for Americans to stand together and I hope Gov. Romney would stand with the administration," Burns said, also on CNN.

Republicans have largely refrained from criticizing their party's nominee, at least publicly. Sen. John McCain of Arizona, the 2008 GOP presidential nominee and the ranking Republican member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, would not support or chastise Romney's stance on CNN Thursday morning, saying only that he agreed Obama's policy toward the Middle East was weak.

"Now the tick tock back and forth is something, frankly, I didn't pay attention to," McCain said on "Starting Point."

"I do know this. Americans are outraged when our embassy is attacked and the Egyptian government does not take the proper measures to protect it," McCain continued. "How much that affects our relationship with Egypt, I think, is something we have to carefully calibrate, recognizing how important a role Egypt is in the entire Middle East."

Other conservative voices, including the editorial page of the Wall Street Journal, also attempted to shield Romney from critics.

"As Tuesday's events showed, pandering to Islamists who would use the video to inflame anti-American sentiment is not going to stop the protests," read the editorial, which was published under the headline "Romney Offends the Pundits."

"His political faux pas (sic) was to offend a pundit class that wants to cede the foreign policy debate to Mr. Obama without thinking seriously about the trouble for America that is building in the world," it continued.

This week's deviation to foreign policy comes after more than a year of a near-singular campaign focus on jobs and the economy. The topic re-entered the political discussion following the Republican National Convention at the end of August, when Democrats piled on Romney for not mentioning Afghanistan in his speech accepting the GOP presidential nomination.

Later, during their own convention, Democrats highlighted support for American troops currently in war zones and the president's successful foreign policy actions, including the mission that killed Osama bin Laden. This particular thread was viewed by many as successfully positioning Obama ahead of Romney on an issue that Democrats have traditionally not seen as a strength.

Voters consistently say in polls Obama would better handle America's relationships with other countries if re-elected. In the latest CNN/ORC International survey released earlier this week, Obama had a 54% - 42% advantage over Romney on foreign policy.

Title: Hillary Clinton's History of Controversial Statements and Allegations of Dishonesty Resurface Amid Health Scare

Article:

Hillary Clinton's recent health scare, captured on video, has reignited discussions about her honesty and trustworthiness, a concern that has been a recurring theme in her political career. The Democratic presidential nominee has faced numerous allegations of deceit and dishonesty throughout her political career, dating back to the early 1990s.

One of Clinton's earliest controversies involved her defense of her husband, then-presidential candidate Bill Clinton, during a 1992 interview on "60 Minutes." In the interview, Clinton famously defended herself against accusations of her husband's extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers, stating, "I'm not sitting here some little woman standing by my man like Tammy Wynette... I'm sitting here because I love him and I respect him."

Clinton's credibility was further questioned during the White House Travel Office scandal in 1993, when she was accused of orchestrating the firings of employees to make room for friends of the Clintons. The independent counsel investigating the scandal, known as Travelgate, found that Clinton's statements denying her involvement were "factually inaccurate."

In 2015, FBI Director James B. Comey outlined numerous lies Clinton told the public about her private email server as secretary of state, including misrepresenting the number of devices she used, the classification of emails, and the number of emails she turned over to the State Department.

Clinton has also been accused of misrepresenting her foreign policy credentials, such as her claim of "landing under sniper fire" in Bosnia in 1996, which was disproven by video footage. Clinton has also been criticized for changing her positions on various political issues, such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, the Keystone XL pipeline, same-sex marriage, the Cuba embargo, charter schools, and driver's licenses for illegal immigrants.

Some of Clinton's alleged misstatements have been minor, such as claiming that "all my grandparents" were immigrants, when only one of her grandparents was an immigrant. Clinton also claimed that she was named after Sir Edmund Hillary, one of the first men to climb Mount Everest, but Sir Hillary did not accomplish this feat until after Clinton was six years old.

Clinton has also been criticized for her role in the 2012 Benghazi attack, where she has been accused of misrepresenting the cause of the attack to the families of the victims. Clinton has repeatedly denied discussing the cause of the attack with the families, but relatives of three of the victims have claimed otherwise.

In response to the health scare, Republican strategist Ed Rollins traced Clinton's problem with veracity back to her 1992 "60 Minutes" interview. "It was just a combination of Whitewater, the impeachment, the whole bit. You kind of forgot all that and then basically Benghazi, the emails, that kind of raised it all again," Rollins said on Fox News. "You've got a candidate who has got a 60 [percent] or 70 percent disapproval rating, and people don't think she's honest. And then there's something like this [health episode]—it has an impact."

Title: Rising Car Loan Delinquencies Pose Challenge for America's Working Poor

Article:

More than 7 million Americans are currently 90 or more days behind on their car loans, according to the New York Federal Reserve. This issue disproportionately affects borrowers with the lowest credit scores, whose delinquency rates have seen the fastest acceleration.

The roots of this problem can be traced back to the 2008 financial crisis, when automakers significantly reduced production in the midst of the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression. A decade later, this has made used 10-year-old vehicles, typically more affordable for low-wage earners, a relative rarity.

According to data provided to [███] by industry consultant and car shopping website Edmunds, the average price of that vintage of vehicle is $8,657, still nearly 75% higher than in 2010 despite some softening in prices over the last year. In contrast, the average new car has seen a price rise of 25% in that same time period.

"This is pinching people at the worst point possible," said Ivan Drury, Edmunds' senior manager of industry analysis. "If you need basic A to B transportation, you have to get an older car that needs more repairs and has more wear-and-tear issues."

Monthly auto payments for Americans making under $40,000 have remained flat since 2017, while those in higher wage brackets have seen their payments rise, according to a Cox Automotive Inc analysis for [███].

This might seem like good news, but to Cox chief economist Jonathan Smoke, it indicates poorer Americans are stretched so thin they can not afford to pay more.

"They just don't have any flexibility to increase their payment," Smoke said.

Weak lending standards in recent years are partly to blame for the rising delinquency rates, which Warren Kornfeld, a senior vice president on Moody's financial institutions team, said are approaching record highs despite a solid economy. Auto lenders are belatedly tightening lending standards, but it may already be too late, he said.

"The economy is masking the true performance of auto loans," Kornfeld said. "If we hit a downturn today, the performance of auto loans would not look very good."

Research from the New York Fed earlier this year showed that while delinquency rates among borrowers with high credit scores have remained steady and low, for subprime borrowers they have been rising, pushing up the overall delinquency rate. Around 8% of loans originated by lower-score buyers with a credit score below 620 were categorized as seriously late, "a development that is surprising during a strong economy and labor market," Fed researchers wrote.
