For many Americans, a car means job access. Hollis Heyward, a 30-year-old father of two making $10 an hour working at a warehouse in Freeport, Illinois, is one such individual. In the midst of a divorce, all he could afford was a gray 2005 Pontiac Grand Prix with close to 200,000 miles on it, which he bought for $1,300 cash - a fraction of the average new car price.

Suddenly also stuck paying off the loan on his future ex-wife's car, Heyward had to rework the loan with local used-car dealer Gordy Tormohlen of Good People Automotive. Under his "workout" deal, Heyward is paying the loan's principal only, and Tormohlen has waived the interest payments. Heyward's monthly payment is now around $120 per month, down from around $350 before the workout.

"Right now, it's hard to make ends meet," said Heyward. "But I am not the kind of guy to walk away from my commitments."

Tormohlen, 59, a second-generation dealer, said his business is up 10% this year as auto finance companies tighten lending standards. He said the market feels like it did before the financial crisis hit in 2008, when consumers were over-extended with debt.

"Americans have grown too comfortable with debt, and the time has come to pay the piper," he said.

Tormohlen is a "Buy Here, Pay Here" dealer, offering subprime loans that he finances himself at 19%, which is higher than a bank but lower than many finance companies. He said he can work directly with struggling customers like Heyward, whom he has known for a decade, but worries that large finance companies with tens or hundreds of thousands of borrowers will be in deep trouble when a downturn hits.

Indeed, according to the New York Fed, more than 1 million more Americans are behind on their car loans now than at the peak of delinquencies in 2010 after the financial crisis.

"The big lenders who do not know their customers are going to have a problem when the economy turns," Tormohlen says.

Expensive older used cars are exacerbating the problem, and it may take years for them to return to more affordable levels. George Augustaitis, director of automotive industry analytics at CarGurus Inc (CARG.O), an online marketplace for new and used cars, said late this spring his team started to notice an "accelerating decline" in the number of available vehicles under $10,000, which typically would include vehicles between eight and 12 years old.

In an analysis for [███], CarGuru's data shows a falling share of inventory of Great Recession-era cars, while the number of online "leads" from consumers seeking those vehicles has remained steady. In fact, the average American car is the oldest on record, and CarGurus' Augustaitis said the available inventory of vehicles costing under $10,000 will not return to more normal levels until 2022, reflecting rising car production after the Great Recession.

Ken Shilson, president of the National Alliance of Buy Here, Pay Here Dealers (NABD), said American consumers have become too comfortable with debt, and subprime customers have been "poisoned" by easy access to capital for much of the long economic expansion. But he added that those customers will be forced by tighter underwriting to seek even older vehicles.

"The American way is to always live beyond your means, and Americans aren't good at making life adjustments," Shilson said. "But there's a reality check coming, and many subprime buyers will be forced to find more affordable transportation."

Title: Unemployment Rate Drops to 7.8 Percent; 114,000 Jobs Added to Payrolls

Article:

The United States unemployment rate decreased to 7.8 percent in September from 8.1 percent in August, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). Despite a relatively weak job growth of 114,000 jobs added to private and public payrolls, the decline in the jobless rate is partly attributed to an increase in the number of Americans who found part-time jobs.

This report marks the first time since President Obama took office in January 2009 that the unemployment rate is officially below 8 percent. With jobs and the economy being top concerns for voters, the report is expected to be a significant topic during the ongoing political campaign.

At a campaign event in Fairfax, Virginia, President Obama stated, "Today's report is a reminder that this country has come too far to turn back now." He acknowledged that "there are still too many of our friends and neighbors" looking for work, but emphasized, "we are moving forward again."

Businesses have reportedly added 5.2 million new jobs over the past 2 1/2 years, according to President Obama. The Labor Department will provide further details and reactions to the report shortly.

In response to the report, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney stated, "This is not what a real recovery looks like." Romney's campaign also noted that the U.S. has lost over 600,000 manufacturing jobs since President Obama took office.

The BLS report is based on two surveys: a household survey and a survey of employers. The sampling error on the business establishment survey is plus or minus 100,000 jobs, while the sampling error on the household survey is plus or minus 280,000 jobs. The unemployment rate is based on the household survey, while the figure on job growth comes from the survey of employers.

The BLS report also indicates that 86,000 more jobs were created in July and August than initially estimated, bringing the average job growth to 146,000 per month from July through September. Additionally, there were 456,000 fewer people counted as being among the unemployed last month.

Title: Bush's Presidential Campaign: Fundraising and Establishment Support

Article:

Jeb Bush, a potential Republican presidential candidate, is taking a cautious approach, according to Scott Reed, the top political adviser to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Reed stated, "The smart money is taking it slower and waiting to see who runs and how these candidates develop a platform."

With the first primary votes still approximately 10 months away, Bush's team has ample time to adjust their strategy. The Republican party shows no signs of coalescing behind another candidate, indicating a potentially competitive primary season.

Bush's advisers maintain that he never expected to clear the field, and his refusal to cater to the demands of those whose views he does not share demonstrates a unique approach to the race. Kristy Campbell, a spokeswoman for Bush, stated in an email, "As Governor Bush considers the possibility of a run, he’s working hard to earn the support of people throughout the party and deliver a positive message about how conservative reforms can restore opportunity and prosperity for more Americans."

In January, Bush's allies began using the phrase "shock and awe" to describe his plan to secure a significant portion of the party's major donors and policy experts. The objective was to establish Bush as the sole credible contender for the Republican establishment's endorsement. Bush successfully deterred Mitt Romney, the 2012 nominee, from mounting another campaign. However, his organization will not disclose its finances until July.

Despite Bush's efforts to position himself as the Republicans' strongest general election candidate, recent polls show him performing no better against Hillary Rodham Clinton than Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin or Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky. Bush also trails behind Mr. Walker in Iowa, a state known for rejecting candidates perceived as the party's inevitable nominees.

Criticism of Bush comes from both the political establishment and the Tea Party grassroots. Colleen Platt, a City Council member in University Park, Iowa, questioned Bush's motivation for running, stating, "If he’s going to run for the presidency because his father and his brother were president, is that why we should support him?"

Lingering suspicion of Bush among the Tea Party grassroots stems from his focus on business and philanthropic interests during his career.

Title: Biden Denies Inappropriate Conduct, Promises to Listen to Accusations

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, a prospective 2020 presidential candidate, has issued a statement denying allegations of inappropriate sexual conduct made by Nevada Lieutenant Governor candidate Lucy Flores. Flores accused Biden of planting a kiss on the back of her head during a 2014 campaign event.

In his statement, Biden stated, "In my many years on the campaign trail and in public life, I have offered countless handshakes, hugs, expressions of affection, support, and comfort. And not once -- never -- did I believe I acted inappropriately."

Biden added, "I may not recall these moments the same way, and I may be surprised at what I hear. But we have arrived at an important time when women feel they can and should relate their experiences, and men should pay attention. And I will."

Flores, in response to Biden's statement, expressed that she is glad he is willing to listen but believes he should acknowledge his actions as wrong. "I want him to change his behavior and I want him to acknowledge that it was wrong," she said.

The allegations have led to a flood of pictures showing Biden with various women at campaign events and other administration functions surfacing on social media. Vox.com published an article on Friday titled, "Lucy Flores isn’t alone. Joe Biden’s got a long history of touching women inappropriately," which catalogued several alleged episodes of misconduct by the former vice president.

White House adviser Kellyanne Conway, speaking on Fox News Sunday, defended Biden, stating, "Joe Biden has a big problem here, because he calls it affection and handshakes -- his party calls it completely inappropriate."

Meanwhile, several other Democratic 2020 presidential hopefuls, including Bernie Sanders, Kamala Harris, and Kirsten Gillibrand, are also defending their self-professed commitment to the ideals of the #MeToo movement against a series of accusations they recently mismanaged sexual-misconduct claims against their subordinates. As the three prominent senators each have sought to draw a sharp contrast with President Trump, who has faced his own misconduct allegations, the claims highlighted vulnerabilities that could become major liabilities not only in a heated Democrat Party primary, but also in the general election.

Title: The Importance of Understanding the U.S. Constitution: A Call to Familiarize Ourselves with the Foundational Document

Article:

The 4th of July, Independence Day, is a time of celebration and patriotism for Americans, marked by fireworks, parades, and tributes to the Declaration of Independence. In contrast, September 17, Constitution Day, often passes without notice. However, the authors argue that the U.S. Constitution, which outlines the structure of the republic, is crucial to understanding the nation's history and the decisions made by government agencies and the judiciary.

The longevity of the U.S. Constitution is remarkable, with an average lifespan of written constitutions since 1789 being only 17 years, according to Thomas Ginsburg, Zachary Elkins, and James Melton, authors of "The Lifespan of Written Constitutions." The Constitution's endurance, spanning over two centuries, is a testament to its significance and resilience.

The U.S. Constitution, at approximately 4,500 words, is not as daunting as some may assume. It can be read in about half an hour. To truly understand it, additional resources, such as the Heritage Foundation's "The Heritage Guide to the Constitution," may be helpful. This guide provides expert analysis of every clause, relevant court cases, interpretations throughout constitutional history, and an overview of the Constitution's creation.

The guide is used by law schools nationwide and is beneficial for any citizen seeking to understand the law of the land. Whether writing a complex thesis or a simple letter to the editor, the Heritage guide can provide valuable insights.

Edwin Meese III, former U.S. Attorney General, writes in the guide, "It is our fundamental law because it represents the settled and deliberate will of the people, against which the actions of government officials must be squared." The authors emphasize the importance of understanding and adhering to the Constitution for the continued success and viability of the democratic republic.

In conclusion, the next time September 17 rolls around, it may be worth revisiting the U.S. Constitution, a foundational document that shapes the workings of the American government and the decisions made by its officials. A better understanding of the Constitution can help citizens make informed opinions and ensure the continued success of the democratic republic.

Title: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney Hints at Possible Delay of Obamacare Individual Mandate

Article:

White House press secretary Jay Carney has suggested that the individual mandate of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, could potentially be delayed due to issues with the healthcare law's enrollment website. During a press briefing on Monday, Carney did not explicitly state that the individual mandate would be delayed, but he did indicate that individuals who are unable to enroll in Obamacare due to website issues would not be penalized.

Under the Affordable Care Act, uninsured Americans are required to sign up for health insurance. If they do not, they could face a fine. When asked if individuals would have to pay a fine if they were unable to enroll in Obamacare due to the glitchy website, Carney did not provide a clear answer.

This is the first official indication that the president may be considering a delay of the individual mandate. The administration has faced criticism for its handling of the healthcare law's implementation, with many Republicans pushing for a delay for months. The White House has consistently rejected these efforts, insisting that the program would be ready to launch on October 1.

The administration's own legal positions during the Obamacare Supreme Court case could potentially complicate matters if lawsuits begin to arise. It is unclear at this time whether the president will ask Congress for the delay or impose it unilaterally.

During the press briefing, Carney also struggled to provide details about the "tech surge" that the administration has announced to repair the website issues. It is unclear who is participating in this "surge."

The White House's efforts to showcase success stories of individuals enrolling in Obamacare have also faced criticism. During a photo-op on Monday, the White House presented 13 individuals who had supposedly enrolled in the healthcare exchanges. However, it was later revealed that only three of these individuals were actually enrolled in the exchanges.

The White House has been criticized for its handling of the healthcare law's implementation, with many questioning the accuracy of the success stories presented by the administration. It is unclear at this time whether anyone will be held accountable for the mounting issues with the healthcare law's implementation.

Title: Montana House Candidate Greg Gianforte Charged with Misdemeanor Assault

Article:

Montana law enforcement officials have charged GOP House candidate Greg Gianforte with misdemeanor assault following an alleged physical altercation with a reporter Wednesday evening, just hours before voters head to the polls. The incident occurred at the candidate's campaign headquarters in Bozeman.

Gianforte allegedly assaulted Ben Jacobs, a reporter for The Guardian, as he posed questions about the Republicans' ObamaCare repeal plan. In a statement Wednesday night, Gallatin County Sheriff Brian Gootkin stated that Gianforte had been cited for misdemeanor assault.

The Guardian released an audio recording of the incident, in which Gianforte initially brushes aside Jacobs' question about the new Congressional Budget Office score of the House GOP's American Health Care Act, which passed the House earlier in the month. The nature of the injuries did not meet the statutory elements of felony assault, according to the sheriff's office.

Jacobs was asking about the new Congressional Budget Office score when Gianforte allegedly grabbed him, slammed him to the ground, and broke his glasses. Gianforte's office offered a different account, stating that Jacobs encroached on "a separate interview in a private office" and "aggressively shoved a recorder in Greg's face."

Eyewitness accounts from several Fox News reporters contradict Gianforte's story. Fox reporter Alicia Acuna stated that Gianforte grabbed Jacobs by the neck with both hands and slammed him into the ground. Acuna and others "watched in disbelief as Gianforte then began punching the man, as he moved on top the reporter and began yelling something to the effect of 'I'm sick and tired of this!'"

Democrats have called on Gianforte to quit the race and for Republicans to condemn his conduct. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee stated, "Greg Gianforte must immediately withdraw his candidacy after his alleged violent assault of an innocent journalist." The committee also launched an 11th-hour Facebook ad campaign highlighting the episode in hopes of swaying voters heading to the polls Thursday.

Thursday's special election pits Gianforte against Democrat Rob Quist in a contest to replace former GOP Rep. Ryan Zinke, who is now heading President Trump's Interior Department. Gianforte is seen as a slight favorite in the race.

Gianforte is expected to appear in court before June 7. He faces a maximum sentence of six months in jail, a $500 fine, or both. Sheriff Gootkin, a Gianforte supporter, contributed $250 to the Republican candidate in March, but he quickly added that "this contribution has nothing to do with our investigation which is now complete."

Title: Trump Disputes Wall Street Journal's Account of Interview on Relationship with Kim Jong Un

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has disputed a report by the Wall Street Journal that he said he had a "very good relationship" with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un during an interview last week. In a series of tweets on Sunday, Trump claimed the newspaper misquoted him, stating that he used a conditional tense, saying "I'd probably" have a good relationship with Kim, rather than stating that he did.

The White House released a portion of the audio from the interview, which it said showed Trump saying "I'd." The Wall Street Journal also released its own audio, claiming it backed up its version of the events.

The Trump comment is significant as any hint of direct contact between the two leaders, who have exchanged threats and insults, would suggest a major shift in the U.S.-led pressure campaign against Pyongyang over its nuclear and missile programs.

Trump has referred to Kim as a "maniac" and "little rocket man," while Kim has called Trump a "mentally deranged U.S. dotard." Fears of war have eased somewhat after the first round of intra-Korean talks in more than two years last week, which Trump has welcomed, ahead of February's Winter Olympics hosted by South Korea. North Korea has said it will participate in the Games.

When asked what he would do to resolve the North Korea standoff, Trump told reporters in Florida on Sunday, "We'll see what happens." He cited upcoming meetings, possibly a reference to further talks planned between North and South Korea. "Hopefully it's all gonna work out," Trump added. "We have great talks going on, the Olympics you know about, a lot of things can happen."

In the Wall Street Journal interview, Trump was asked whether he had spoken with the North Korean leader. "I don't want to comment on it. I'm not saying I have or haven't. I just don't want to comment," he had said.

Trump, who is spending a long weekend at his oceanfront Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Florida, tweeted on Sunday, "Obviously I didn't say that. I said 'I'd have a good relationship with Kim Jong Un,' a big difference. Fortunately, we now record conversations with reporters... and they knew exactly what I said and meant. They just wanted a story. FAKE NEWS!"

A White House official stated that the delay in publicly disputing the Journal's account was the result of a failed attempt to get the paper to correct the record. "The reason there was a delay is because we had several calls and emails with WSJ, starting Friday morning, asking them to issue a correction. They refused and so we pushed out our own clarification," the official said.

Title: Republican and Democratic Candidates Differ in TV Ad Strategies Ahead of Midterm Elections

Article:

In the run-up to the midterm elections, House Republican candidates are airing a significant number of TV ads emphasizing a hardline stance on immigration, according to an analysis by Kantar Media. This shift in focus is a stark contrast to the midterm elections in 2014.

Republicans have aired over 14,000 ads this year promoting a Trump-style immigration platform. This trend underscores the concerns of House GOP leaders about the potential risks for Republican candidates if a legislative fix for DREAMers, undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children, is passed.

Democrats, on the other hand, are focusing on ads that promise to protect Obamacare, shore up Social Security, and expand Medicare. One such ad by California Democrat Paul Kerr recounts his family's financial struggles due to medical bills after his mother was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig's disease.

The competing messages highlight the significant ideological divide between the two parties. They are not just discussing issues differently; they are prioritizing different issues to mobilize activists and win hotly contested primaries.

Kyle Kondik, a political analyst with the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, noted that the parties are appealing to different demographics, particularly in primaries. Republicans tend to appeal to a whiter, older, more rural electorate, while Democrats court a more diverse, younger, urban constituency.

The GOP's focus on immigration is particularly notable, given that it was not among the top 10 issues Republicans spent their ad dollars on at this point in the 2014 midterms. In that cycle, GOP contenders attacked President Obama, bashing the Affordable Care Act and promising to rein in government spending.

Now, immigration ranks second only to pro-Trump spots in GOP campaigns across the country. Brian Murray, a GOP consultant based in Arizona, attributes this shift to the national spotlight immigration received during Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.

In Washington, House GOP leaders are divided over the immigration issue, with moderates pushing for legal status for DREAMers and conservatives advocating for stricter immigration policies and border wall construction. This internal conflict is causing tension within the GOP conference and potentially jeopardizing House Speaker Paul Ryan's grip on power.

Some strategists warn that the GOP's full-throated embrace of Trump's anti-immigration positions in primaries could harm them in the general election, as the majority of Americans support granting permanent legal status to DREAMers and oppose expanding the wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

Meanwhile, Democratic candidates are focusing heavily on health issues in their advertising, running over 26,000 ads on the subject. Of these, more than 8,500 Democratic spots promise to protect or expand Medicare.

In the primary races, Democratic candidates in some states are taking extreme positions that strategists warn could hurt them in the general election. For example, in Montana's only House seat, Grant Kier, a Democrat, promises to fight Trump on climate change, oppose his health care plan, and protect women's health care choices. These positions, according to the Congressional Leadership Fund, a super PAC affiliated with House Republicans, are "woefully out of touch with Montana values."

In summary, the competing primary ads from both parties demonstrate the significant ideological divide between the two parties, with each focusing on different issues to mobilize their respective bases. The immigration issue is a particularly contentious point of contention, with the majority of Americans supporting legal status for DREAMers and opposing expanded border wall construction.

Title: Trump Legal Team Files Lawsuit to Block Congressional Subpoena of Financial Information from Mazars USA

Article:

Attorneys for President Donald J. Trump and the Trump Organization have filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia to block a subpoena issued by the House Oversight Committee, which seeks financial information from Mazars USA, a longtime accounting firm for the company. The lawsuit, which names House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings, is the latest move from Trump's legal team to push back against what one of his attorneys called "presidential harassment" from the newly empowered Democratic majority in the House.

The lawsuit, filed Monday, argues that the subpoena lacks a "legitimate legislative purpose" and that it threatens to expose "confidential information." The lawsuit also claims that Democrats are using their newfound majority on congressional committees in the House to investigate "every aspect" of Trump's personal finances, businesses, and his family, and that House Democrats are "singularly obsessed" with finding politically damaging information on the president.

The subpoena demands financial statements and supporting documents from Mazars for Trump, the Trump Organization, and other entities, covering documents from 2011 to 2018. In a memo to committee members announcing his intention to issue the subpoena, Mr. Cummings said financial statements provided by Michael Cohen, Trump's longtime former lawyer and fixer, raise "serious questions" about Trump's representations of his financial condition.

Cohen, who testified to the committee in February about his work for Trump, has pleaded guilty to lying to Congress, among other crimes. In a separate battle between Trump and congressional Democrats, Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal has given the IRS a new April 23 deadline to turn over six years' worth of Trump's personal tax returns, as well as returns for some associated organizations, like one of his golf courses.

Title: Impact of China Tariffs Expected to be Larger and More Concentrated Than Steel and Aluminum Measures

Article:

The potential impact of the proposed tariffs on Chinese goods is expected to be larger and more concentrated than the tariffs on steel and aluminum, according to experts. The steel and aluminum tariffs are estimated to affect imports of approximately $33 billion, excluding Canada and Mexico, which are expected to be exempt from the measures, said Joseph Parilla of the Brookings Institution. The proposed tariffs on Chinese goods would affect at least $50 billion in annual imports, according to officials.

Chinese companies have been investing heavily in American companies, with new acquisition deals totaling tens of billions of dollars annually, according to Rhodium Group, which tracks Chinese investments abroad. However, last year, these investments fell sharply to $8.7 billion as China tightened controls on money leaving its borders.

Chinese companies have acquired various assets in the United States, including non-strategic assets like movie theaters and the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York. They have also sought out deals in cutting-edge areas like semiconductors and start-ups related to autonomous driving, as China aims to upgrade its technological capabilities. China views the American stranglehold on fundamental technologies as a long-term economic and security threat to its rise as a superpower.

Unlike the metal tariffs, which caused divisions within the Trump administration and were opposed by many Republican lawmakers and businesspeople, the technology moves against China are likely to be politically popular on Capitol Hill and throughout some industries.

"Their theft costs us over $350 billion per year, so the bigger the better," said Daniel DiMicco, a steel executive and trade adviser to the Trump campaign, referring to the forced transfer of intellectual property and other unfair practices alleged by the administration.

The business community, which long defended trade with China despite accusations of theft of intellectual property, has grown more dissatisfied with adverse treatment in the Chinese economy. With the Chinese government and state-owned enterprises playing an ever-larger role in the market, the environment for American companies has steadily deteriorated.

However, American business groups expressed concern over the possibility that the United States tariffs would spur others around the world to raise their own trade barriers.

Title: Obama's Austin Visit: A Continuation of Economic Agenda Amidst Partisan Divide

Article:

In a move that has been met with criticism from Republican officials, President Barack Obama visited Austin, Texas, this week, with the visit being described as a campaign-style stunt by the Republican National Committee. The news release from the committee labeled the visit as "Obama's Jobs Strategy: Pivot Back to the Economy Every So Often."

In his State of the Union address this year, President Obama outlined an economic agenda that included a new emphasis on manufacturing, increased funding for early childhood education, an increase in the minimum wage, and greater investment in infrastructure. While some Republicans have expressed support for parts of this agenda, there is little indication that the bulk of it is headed toward passage anytime soon in a Congress that is increasingly frozen when it comes to fiscal issues.

Aides to the president believe that events like the ones in Austin, though likely in service to a lost cause, are necessary to keep pressure on Republicans and to show Americans that President Obama is still pushing for his agenda. The risk for President Obama is that the events can come across as little more than costly excursions that do little to actually improve the economy. However, aides are quick to point out that the president would most likely be criticized if he announced an agenda in the State of the Union address and did not push for it.

During his first two years in office, President Obama rarely traveled around the country, staying in Washington to shepherd his health care legislation through Congress. His approval ratings and his mood sank, leading aides to believe that it is important that he travel the country frequently.

In Austin, President Obama was scheduled to meet with some local residents and technology entrepreneurs, officials said. He was also to tour a facility of Applied Materials, a company based in Silicon Valley that manufactures the complex equipment needed to make silicon chips for computers, phones, and other high-tech machines.

Title: Deadly Riot in Altamira Prison Leaves 57 Inmates Dead, 16 Decapitated

RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) — At least 57 prisoners were killed by other inmates during clashes between organized crime groups in the Altamira prison in northern Brazil Monday, with 16 of the victims being decapitated, according to prison officials.

The fight erupted around 7 a.m. between the Rio de Janeiro-based Comando Vermelho and a local criminal group known as Comando Classe A, according to Para state prison authorities. A fire set by the Comando Classe A spread rapidly in the prison, which houses inmates in old container units, preventing police forces from entering the building for several hours.

Two prison staff members were held hostage but were eventually released. State prisons chief Jarbas Vasconcelos said the incident was a targeted attack, not a protest or rebellion against the prison system.

Authorities have not found any firearms following the riot, only makeshift knives. Prison authorities said 46 inmates will be transferred to other prisons, with 10 of them going to stricter federal facilities.

President Jair Bolsonaro, who was elected on the promise of curbing widespread violence in Brazil, including in the country's often overcrowded, out-of-control prisons, has not yet commented on the incident.

The Altamira prison had 343 detainees as of July 2019, according to a report from the National Justice Council, which exceeds the maximum capacity of 163. However, state prisons chief Jarbas Vasconcelos said the situation did not meet the official requirements to be considered overcrowded.

The judge who filed the report described the overall state of the prison in the city of Altamira as "terrible." In many of Brazil's prisons, badly outnumbered guards struggle to retain power over an ever-growing population of inmates who are able to run criminal activities from behind bars.

The killings echoed those of 55 inmates who died in a series of riots in May in several prisons in the neighboring state of Amazonas. In early 2017, more than 120 inmates died in prisons across several northern states when rival gangs clashed over control of drug-trafficking routes in the region.

Para state authorities spent the afternoon in Altamira, drafting a security plan to avoid possible retaliations in the region. Police forces from the nearby municipality of Santerem were sent as reinforcement in the coming weeks. Prison authorities said they had not received any prior intelligence reports of an upcoming attack. The prison is run directly by the state, not a third-party private operator as in the Manaus prisons where the riots took place in May. Last year, inmates had already set fire to another wing inside the same prison unit, according to the state prosecutors' office.

Title: Al Gore Expresses Optimism on Climate Change Debate, Citing Shift in Republican Stance

Article:

Former Vice President Al Gore, in an interview with The Washington Post, expressed optimism about the future of the climate change debate, stating that activists are "winning the conversation" similar to past movements such as civil rights, the nuclear arms race, and the abolition of slavery.

Gore compared the current climate change debate to historical movements, stating, "The same thing happened on apartheid. The same thing happened on the nuclear arms race with the freeze movement. The same thing happened in an earlier era with abolition." He further added, "A few months ago, I saw an article about two gay men standing in line for pizza and some homophobe made an ugly comment about them holding hands and everyone else in line told them to shut up. We're winning that conversation."

Gore also referenced the debate over smoking, citing the late-Sen. Frank Lautenburg of New Jersey being labeled "crazy" for pushing legislation that would ban smoking in airplanes. He stated, "But he was rewarded politically and then politicians began falling all over themselves to do the same. That's the optimistic scenario. And it's not just a scenario! It's happening now."

Gore attributed this shift in the climate change debate to a process of "winning the conversation," but noted that this process has been stalled in prior years due to a "shrinking group of denialists who fly into a rage when it's mentioned." He likened this group to an alcoholic father who becomes enraged when certain topics are discussed, leading others to avoid the issue to maintain peace.

However, Gore argued that the ability of these "raging deniers" to halt progress is diminishing daily. Organizing for Action, a political group formed from President Barack Obama's re-election campaign, recently delivered unicorn statues to Republican climate change deniers in Congress as part of a larger push to "hold members of Congress accountable for their positions on climate change."

Gore commended President Obama for his aggressive new climate change strategy, which includes limiting pollution from existing coal-fired power plants and issuing directives requiring the EPA to establish carbon pollution standards for plants that are already active. Gore expressed being "very encouraged" by these policy moves.

Title: US Urges Iranian Aid Ship to Divert to Djibouti for UN Oversight

Article:

U.S. officials have called on an Iranian ship, reportedly carrying humanitarian aid to Yemen, to change course and head to Djibouti, where the United Nations is overseeing humanitarian deliveries. The U.S. military is tracking the ship, the Iran Shahed, after Tehran announced plans to send warships to escort the vessel to Yemen.

According to the marinetraffic.com site, the ship has moved through the Strait of Hormuz and is currently in the Gulf of Oman. However, the vessel is not under any naval escort at the moment, according to Pentagon spokesman Colonel Steven Warren.

"We are monitoring the Iranian ship," Warren said. "We are aware of the Iranians' statement that they plan to escort this ship with warships." The state Iranian IRNA news agency earlier quoted a naval commander, Rear Admiral Hossein Azad, saying naval forces would be "safeguarding" the vessel.

Iran's Red Crescent had announced last week that it would send a ship carrying 2,500 tons of humanitarian aid to Yemen, where Tehran-backed Huthi rebels are fighting pro-government forces supported by a Saudi-led coalition.

"The Iranians have stated that this is humanitarian aid," Warren said. "If that is the case, then we certainly encourage the Iranians to deliver that humanitarian aid to the United Nations humanitarian aid distribution hub, which has been established in Djibouti."

"This will allow the aid to be rapidly and efficiently distributed to those in Yemen who require it," he added. When asked if the U.S. military would try to search the ship or prevent it from docking in Yemen, Warren declined to comment.

The warnings from Washington raised the possibility of a potential confrontation at sea after tensions flared in recent days in the Strait of Hormuz. The U.S. Navy bolstered its presence in the Gulf after Iran seized a Marshall Islands-flagged vessel in the vital waterway. Iranian authorities later released the ship, citing a commercial dispute with Denmark's Maersk group, which chartered the vessel.

"If the Iranians are planning some sort of stunt in the region, they know as well as we do that it would be unhelpful and in fact could potentially threaten the ceasefire (in Yemen) that has been so painstakingly brought about," Warren said. "We call on the Iranians to do the right thing here and deliver their humanitarian aid in accordance with UN protocols which is through the distribution hub that's been established in Djibouti."

Title: Elizabeth Warren Calls for Law Allowing Indictment of Sitting Presidents for Obstruction of Justice

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has called for Congress to pass a law that makes it clear the Justice Department can criminally indict a sitting president for obstructing justice. In a statement released by her campaign, Warren stated, "No president is above the law."

Warren's call comes in response to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's 448-page report on his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and Mueller's statement this week that Justice Department policy prevented him from bringing charges against a sitting president.

Mueller's report concluded that Russia repeatedly interfered in the 2016 election and that Trump's election campaign had multiple contacts with Russian officials, but did not establish a criminal conspiracy with Moscow to win the White House. The report declined to make a judgment on whether Trump obstructed justice, although it outlined 10 instances in which Trump tried to have Mueller fired or otherwise impede the investigation.

"When the federal government tried to investigate, Donald Trump did everything he could to delay, distract, and otherwise obstruct that investigation," Warren's statement said. "That's a crime. If Donald Trump were anyone other than the president of the United States, he would be in handcuffs and indicted."

Warren urged Congress to pass a law making it clear that presidents can be indicted for criminal activity, including obstruction of justice. She also suggested amending statutes relating to such obstruction to allow for indictment when a president abuses the powers of office.

Warren criticized Trump's Attorney General, William Barr, stating he had "acted like Trump's personal defense attorney." She promised that if elected, she would ensure her appointees reverse a Justice Department opinion that argues a sitting president cannot be indicted.

"Donald Trump is not a king. No president is. And our democracy only works if everyone can be held accountable," Warren concluded.

Title: Court Ruling Reveals NSA Metadata Querying Violations, Criticizes Oversight

Article:

In a recent ruling, Judge Bates recounted that the National Security Agency (NSA) had been routinely running queries of metadata using terms that did not meet the standard for querying. This violation was significant enough to render the requirement for such queries ineffective, according to the 2009 ruling.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), a group advocating for free speech and privacy rights, sued to obtain the ruling. The impetus for the lawsuit was Senator Ron Wyden's push last summer to declassify the basic fact that the surveillance court had ruled that the NSA had violated the Fourth Amendment.

Senator Wyden, an outspoken critic of NSA surveillance, described the declassification of the ruling as "long overdue." He argued that while the NSA had increased privacy protections for purely domestic and unrelated communications that were incidentally collected during the surveillance, the collection itself constituted a serious violation of the Fourth Amendment.

Mark Rumold of the EFF praised the administration for releasing the document with relatively few redactions, although he criticized the time and difficulty in obtaining it. However, he also noted that the ruling demonstrated the surveillance court's inability to provide adequate oversight of the NSA.

"This opinion illustrates that the way the court is structured now, it cannot serve as an effective check on the NSA because it's wholly dependent on the representations that the NSA makes to it," Mr. Rumold said. "It has no ability to investigate. And it's clear that the NSA's representations have not been entirely candid to the court."

A senior intelligence official, speaking to reporters in a conference call, portrayed the ruling as evidence of robust and serious NSA oversight. He stated that approximately 300 NSA employees were assigned to seek out even inadvertent violations of the rules, and the court conducted "vigorous" oversight.

The ruling focused on a program under which the NSA has been searching domestic Internet links for communications—where at least one side is overseas—in which there are "strong selectors" indicating insider knowledge of someone who has been targeted for foreign-intelligence collection. An example would be mentioning a person's private email address in the body of an email.

Title: House Republican Leaders Unlikely to Pursue Immigration Bill This Year, Citing Trust Issues with President Obama

Article:

Conservative Republicans have expressed doubts about their chamber's intention to address an immigration bill this year, stating that while they welcome the House GOP leaders' principles as a starting point for discussion, it is premature to attempt to pass a bill at this time.

During a speech at a Heritage Foundation event, Republican House members expressed reservations about President Obama's commitment to enforcing the stringent security measures that would be included in any potential bill. They emphasized that these security measures must be implemented before any immigration reform could be considered.

Rep. Raul Labrador, an Idaho Republican who was part of a group working on a comprehensive immigration bill last year but dropped out, stated that Mr. Obama should spend this year demonstrating his commitment to these security measures before Republicans would consider action in 2015 if they regain control of the Senate.

"We need to have the trust with this administration, and that trust is not there," Mr. Labrador said. "Until we have that trust, there will be no immigration reform, and it would be a mistake for leadership to push that."

House Speaker John A. Boehner released principles last week that called for increased security but also for illegal immigrants to be granted legal status, with a specific pathway to citizenship for young adult illegal immigrants, often referred to as the "Dreamers." However, Mr. Boehner himself stated on Tuesday that Republicans have not yet decided whether to move forward with a bill this year.

Rep. Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, noted that while it is not the appropriate time to advance a broad bill, the principles themselves are beneficial for "beginning a dialogue with the Hispanic community on conservative principles."

The Senate passed a comprehensive bill in June that grants citizenship rights to most illegal immigrants, passing the measure on a bipartisan 68-32 vote. However, even this legislation has faced challenges.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who voted against the Senate bill, stated on Tuesday that he does not see a way to align the Senate bill with the House's current discussions.

"I don't see how you get to an outcome this year with the two bodies in such a different place," he said.

Democrats had hoped the release of the principles would facilitate an agreement this year, but the two sides remain far apart on key issues. House Republicans have insisted on addressing the issue through a series of bills, while the Senate passed a single, comprehensive measure. House Republicans also have insisted on prioritizing border security, while the Senate bill grants quick legal status to most illegal immigrants while simultaneously working to increase manpower and technology at the border.

The most significant point of contention, however, is the question of citizenship. The Senate bill proposes a new specific pathway that would allow most illegal immigrants to become citizens in about 13 years. House Republicans' principles call for illegal immigrants to receive some form of legal status, but only specify a path to citizenship for young illegal immigrants, often referred to as the "Dreamers," who are considered the most sympathetic cases.

Title: Trump's Debut: A Shift in the Republican Presidential Race's Tide

Article:

The first Republican presidential debate on Thursday night in Cleveland may have left Donald Trump questioning his participation, as he transitioned from the central figure of the campaign to a contender among many.

Entering the debate as the frontrunner, Trump was not only included in the official GOP field but was the focal point, leading in multiple polls of Republicans and Republican-leaners. However, as the two-hour debate progressed, Trump found himself waiting his turn to speak, with several rivals choosing not to engage him to avoid sharing the spotlight.

The debate began with a challenge to Trump from Fox News' Bret Baier, who asked if anyone onstage was unwilling to commit to supporting the eventual Republican nominee in 2016. Trump immediately raised his right hand, causing a mix of boos and cheers from the live crowd. Trump stated that he could not pledge to support the nominee "if it's not me," adding that he would be proud to run as a Republican if the party was good enough to nominate him.

Throughout the debate, Trump tussled with Rand Paul about single-payer health care and wrangled with Jeb Bush about the tone of Trump's own rhetoric. Yet, even at his most outlandish, he could not eclipse the other personalities onstage in the same way he has done all summer.

The sharpest exchange of the night did not involve Trump. It stemmed from Sen. Rand Paul's speech about his opposition to phone records being gathered by the National Security Agency. The exchange between Paul and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, who questioned Paul's ability to differentiate between terrorist and citizen phone numbers, became a platform for both candidates to showcase their political stances.

Other candidates, such as Ohio Gov. John Kasich, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, Sen. Ted Cruz, Sen. Marco Rubio, and neurosurgeon Ben Carson, also had their moments to shine. Businesswoman Carly Fiorina, who did not make the cut for the evening debate, was a standout in a separate debate earlier in the day, delivering a controlled, crisp, and gimlet-eyed performance.

Fiorina's question for Trump, asking about the principles by which he will govern, was perhaps the best of the night. As the race continues, with nine more debates and countless media interviews ahead, it remains to be seen if Trump can continue to make up the rules as he goes along.

Title: Senator Rand Paul Declares Victory as Attorney General Holder Clarifies Drone Use on U.S. Soil

Article:

Senator Rand Paul (R-KY) declared victory on Thursday after Attorney General Eric Holder confirmed in a letter that the president does not have the authority to use a drone to kill a noncombatant American on U.S. soil. The assurance came in response to a 13-hour filibuster by Paul, which delayed a vote on the confirmation of CIA director nominee John Brennan.

During the filibuster, Paul had demanded the administration clarify the government's authority to kill on U.S. soil. The filibuster ended early Thursday morning, and the Senate voted 63-34 to confirm Brennan later in the day.

In the letter, Holder stated, "It has come to my attention that you have now asked an additional question: 'Does the President have the authority to use a weaponized drone to kill an American not engaged in combat on American soil?' The answer to that question is no."

In response, Paul said, "We're proud to announce that the president is not going to kill unarmed Americans on American soil." He later took to the floor to promote the attorney general's response as the Senate moved to confirm Brennan.

While Paul's 13-hour stand drew praise from various political perspectives, the senator also faced criticism from some within his own party. Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) argued that Paul's concerns about drone missile attacks on Americans were "ridiculous." Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) displayed a sign showing the number of Americans killed in the U.S. by Al Qaeda (2,958) versus the number killed in the U.S. by drones (0).

Paul, however, argued that he was raising concerns about how future presidents might use their drone authority. He told Fox News that some senators "think the whole world is a battlefield, including America." Paul added, "I do not think the laws of war apply to America. I think the Bill of Rights do."

The Obama administration increasingly employs armed drones as a counterterrorism tool overseas, while domestic law enforcement agencies are also moving to broaden the use of surveillance mini-drones over the next several years. The Federal Aviation Administration projects as many as 10,000 licensed systems by 2017.

The lethal drones used in Pakistan are a far cry from the unarmed eyes in the sky used in America. However, Paul and a host of other lawmakers see constitutional pitfalls across the board, focusing on how armed and unarmed drones might someday be used against American citizens.

Lawmakers have already started pushing legislation to rein in the drone program, and Paul's dramatic performance Wednesday may give a second look to such legislation. Rep. Zoe Lofgren (D-CA) and Ted Poe (R-TX) last month introduced a bill to regulate domestic drones much like the government regulates wiretaps. The bill would require officials to obtain a warrant in order to perform many kinds of surveillance with those drones and would prohibit law enforcement drones from being equipped with firearms or explosives in U.S. airspace.

"As we enter this uncharted world of drone technology, Congress must be proactive and establish boundaries for drone use that safeguard the constitutional rights of Americans," Poe said in a statement last month. The use of armed drones in U.S. airspace fueled Paul's lengthy filibuster Wednesday.

Title: Polling Discrepancies in U.S. Presidential Election: Debate on Bias and Methodology

Article:

As President Obama and congressional Democrats have shown a surge in polls, Republicans are increasingly arguing that the surveys are skewed, with some accusing pollsters of purposely trying to demoralize GOP voters. Pollsters deny any attempt at bias, stating that they are simply sampling people who answer their phones.

Polling firms acknowledge the difficulty of their job, which is bound to receive criticism due to the judgments that have to be made regarding how to handle the data. John Zogby, senior analyst for JZ Analytics, which conducts polling for clients including The ███, said, "We’re all taking pulses right now. If you look at them, we’re all pretty close together."

Polls over the past week have shown Mr. Obama leading Republican challenger Mitt Romney by 1 percentage point to 8 percentage points in the popular vote. The random samplings of these polls are designed to yield an accurate representation of voter demographics by party, gender, ethnicity, and other categories, but this is easier said than done, especially when surveys usually sample fewer than 1,500 people.

The question for pollsters then becomes whether to tweak the data to give added weight to responses from groups that often go underrepresented in polls, such as Republicans, young voters, and minorities, to come up with a sampling that better represents the electorate.

Charles Franklin, who runs the Marquette University Law School poll, which is tracking the presidential and U.S. Senate races in Wisconsin, said he adjusts weights for gender, age, and ethnic balance but not for political party. He argued that an increase in participation by a certain party can be an indicator that it is more energized than the other side.

Democrats historically hold a turnout edge in presidential elections, but their advantage often fluctuates. In 2008, 39 percent of presidential voters were Democrats compared with 32 percent who were Republicans, according to exit polling. The parties each represented 37 percent of the electorate in 2004, which was the Republicans’ largest share in decades.

"Forcing there to be a certain percentage of your electorate denies that change," Mr. Franklin said. "There’s a legitimate debate as to which way to go, and I don’t think it is by any means a settled statistical question."

Scott Rasmussen, founder of Rasmussen Reports, which has Mr. Obama with a 1-point lead over Mr. Romney, said, "We absolutely know that party affiliation is the best single indicator of how someone is going to vote."

In addition to cries of party bias, pollsters are also dealing with issues brought on by technology and changing demographics. Many polls continue to collect their data from calls to landlines rather than cellphones, which could increase responses from older voters who rely on their home phones and minimize participation among younger voters.

Mr. Rasmussen predicts that polling might move entirely online in five to 10 years. The different methods and varieties of approaches among the various pollsters mean poll watchers need to take individual surveys with a grain of salt.

"Look across all of the polling," Mr. Franklin said. "Don’t just try to believe that one poll is always right or that one is always the best. If you see all of the polls pointing in the same direction, that’s certainly more reliable."

Title: Global Climate Strike Draws Record Participation in 139 Countries

Article:

The global climate strike on Friday, September 20, 2019, saw an unprecedented turnout with 4,638 events scheduled in 139 countries. The strike, organized by the "Fridays for Future" movement, led by 16-year-old Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg, aimed to raise awareness about climate change.

Thunberg, who testified at a Capitol Hill hearing on Wednesday, urged U.S. lawmakers to take immediate action, stating, "I want you to take real action." The Fridays for Future website states, "With the worsening climate destruction, this goal of going to school begins to be pointless. Why study for a future, which may not be there?"

Youth participants in the climate strike demonstrations displayed a mix of humor and urgency in their protest signs. One sign read, "We are skipping our lessons to teach you one." Another, referencing a popular song, stated, "It's getting hot in here, so take off all your coal."

Social media platforms, including Twitter and Facebook, were flooded with images of climate strike crowds from around the world. Primary school pupils in Abuja, Nigeria, called for climate action, while others demanded climate justice.

The strike also saw a creative take on the Amazon rainforest fires, with signs reading, "The wrong Amazon is burning." The movement gained widespread support, with many sharing their favorite signs on Twitter.

This global climate strike is part of a growing movement led by young people, who are urging world leaders to take immediate action to combat climate change.

Title: Virginia Governor Ralph Northam Declares Juneteenth a State Holiday

Article:

Virginia Governor Ralph Northam announced on Tuesday, June 16, 2020, that he will make Juneteenth, a day commemorating the end of slavery in the United States, an official holiday in Virginia. The state was once home to the capital of the Confederacy.

Juneteenth, also known as Emancipation Day and Freedom Day, is celebrated annually on June 19. Texas first made it a state holiday in 1980. The holiday will be a paid day off for all state employees. Northam stated that Virginia would be only the second state to do so.

"It's time we elevate this," Northam said of the June 19 commemoration. "Not just a celebration by and for some Virginians but one acknowledged and celebrated by all of us."

The Democratic governor is granting every executive branch employee this Friday off as a paid holiday and will work with the legislature later this year to pass a law codifying Juneteenth as a permanent state holiday. The legislation is likely to pass the Democratic-controlled legislature with little trouble.

Juneteenth commemorates June 19, 1865, when news reached African Americans in Texas that President Abraham Lincoln had issued the Emancipation Proclamation freeing slaves living in Confederate states two years earlier. When Union soldiers arrived in Galveston to bring the news that slavery had been abolished, former slaves celebrated.

The announcement came less than two weeks after Northam announced he was ordering the removal of a statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee along Richmond's prominent Monument Avenue. It is one of the country's most iconic monuments to the Confederacy. Earlier this year, Northam signed legislation scrapping Lee-Jackson Day, a state holiday named after two Confederate generals.

Nearly forced from office last year after a racist yearbook photo surfaced, Northam has won widespread praise among black lawmakers for his actions in Virginia following the death of George Floyd, a black man who died after a Minneapolis officer pressed his knee into Floyd's neck as he pleaded for air.

President Donald Trump announced last week that he has rescheduled a campaign rally that was planned in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on Juneteenth. The announcement of the rally had sparked an outcry because Tulsa was the site of one of the worst instances of racial violence in U.S. history in 1921, when hundreds of African Americans were massacred by a white mob that burned black-owned businesses and homes.

Northam was joined Tuesday at his news conference by musician Pharrell Williams, who is from Virginia. Williams said Juneteenth deserves the same level of recognition and celebration as Independence Day.

"Here's our day, and if you love us, it'll be your day too," Williams said.

In a statement, state House Republican Leader Todd Gilbert echoed the same sentiments.

"July 4th is the birthday of our nation, but Juneteenth is the day where it truly began to fulfill its promise of freedom for all," Gilbert said. "For the first time since enslaved Africans landed at Jamestown in 1619, the chains of bondage were finally cast off."

Joseph Rogers, a 29-year-old activist who has been a regular protester in Richmond during more than two weeks of demonstrations over Floyd's killing, hailed Northam's announcement.

Title: Boehner Unveils Plan B to Avert Fiscal Cliff, Senate Majority Leader Declares Bill Dead on Arrival

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) has unveiled a new strategy to avoid the fiscal cliff, proposing a bill that would increase tax rates for income exceeding $1 million while extending rates for the rest of Americans. The legislation, dubbed "Plan B," has been met with skepticism from Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) and the White House, who argue it still favors the wealthy.

The bill, which is expected to be voted on this week, is intended to provide cover for House Republicans in case the nation goes over the fiscal cliff and income tax rates increase for all. If President Barack Obama continues to accuse Republicans of prioritizing the wealthy, the backup plan allows them to counter that it is not true.

Despite progress in talks between Obama and Boehner over the past few days, there is still a long way to go before an agreement is reached. The fact that Boehner is putting his own bill forward suggests that negotiations between the White House and the House Republicans have reached a temporary impasse.

Boehner informed Obama about his Plan B during a phone call on Monday night, prompting Obama to inform Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that talks between the White House and Boehner had stalled. White House aides Rob Nabors and Gene Sperling addressed both the Senate and House Democratic caucuses on Tuesday.

In 13 days, taxes will increase for everyone. Shortly after, tens of billions of dollars in spending cuts for the Pentagon and other federal agencies will take effect. The fact that Boehner is putting his own bill forward indicates that the fiscal cliff negotiations have reached a temporary impasse.

As of Monday evening, the two sides seemed to be inching toward an agreement. Boehner has moved off his insistence that tax rates not rise for the wealthy and offered the president $1 trillion in fresh revenue, a significant concession that was unthinkable a year ago. However, the fate of the fiscal cliff negotiations remains uncertain.

Title: Debt and Deficit Issues Take a Back Seat in Democratic Presidential Debates

Article:

In the four-hour debate among Democratic contenders for the U.S. presidency, the terms "deficit" and "debt" were scarcely mentioned, with the government's debt being mentioned only once. This reluctance to discuss one of America's most pressing issues - the ballooning annual budget deficits and overall debt under President Donald Trump - is a reflection of the Democrats' apprehension in making it a campaign issue due to the significant budget challenges posed by their popular policies, such as expanding Medicare health coverage and offering government assistance to reduce college costs and student debt.

While Democrats claim they have viable plans to cover the costs of these proposals, Republicans argue that their tax-the-rich solutions are unrealistic. On the other side of the political divide, Republicans are equally reticent on the subject, having supported Trump's massive tax cuts and increased military spending - two key drivers of the deficit increase - after championing fiscal conservatism for years. By backing Trump, many Republican lawmakers have essentially abandoned their already waning commitment to balanced budgets and reducing the national debt.

Senator Rob Portman, a former White House budget director and a self-proclaimed hawk on government spending, lamented the lack of interest in addressing the issue. Portman, who was also a strong defender of the 2017 tax-cut law that will drive up the national debt by at least $1 trillion over 10 years, is seen as a fiscal conservative.

Economists worry that rising debt will lead to higher interest costs, increasing the pressure on future governments to make deep spending cuts or even causing the United States to default on its debt payments, which could have catastrophic global consequences. Bill Hoagland, a senior vice president at the Bipartisan Policy Center, a Washington think tank focused on fiscal policy, likened the situation to termites undermining a porch: "You step on the porch and everything's fine... Then one day, you fall through."

When running for president, Trump claimed he would pay off the national debt in about eight years. Instead, it has increased by $2.45 trillion since he took office in January 2017. The total debt outstanding, accumulated over many years of deficits, is now $22.4 trillion, its highest level ever, equating to about $68,000 of debt for every American. The deficit has jumped from $666 billion in fiscal 2017, the final year President Barack Obama's administration had an impact on budgets, to an expected $900 billion this year, and is projected to exceed $1 trillion a year by 2022.

The prospect of such high and rising debt poses substantial risks for the nation, according to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office. With the U.S. economy expanding, inflation and unemployment low, and the stock market near record levels, the government could be expected to take advantage of the strong fundamentals to reduce deficits. However, the opposite is happening.

Asked about rising deficits last month, White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow downplayed concerns, stating, "It doesn't bother me right now." On a campaign stop in Marshalltown, Iowa, former Vice President Joe Biden accused Republicans of running up the nation's debt as a pretext for seeking cuts to federal retirement and healthcare benefits later.

"Folks, this is a sham," said Biden, who has led most polls in the early days of the Democratic primary race. Marlene Rush, a Marshalltown community organizer, said Biden was "the first Democrat I've heard actually mention the deficits." "I appreciate that. Deficits matter. For Republicans, it seems, they only care about the deficit when Democrats are in the White House," she said.

The first set of Democratic primary debates on June 26-27 in Miami passed without any of the 20 candidates offering up ideas to control debt or deficits. When asked about paying for the expansion of public benefits if they win the White House, Senator Kamala Harris responded, "I hear that question, but where was that question when the Republicans and Donald Trump passed a tax bill that benefits the top 1 percent and the biggest corporations in this country?" Harris' response was met with silence from the other candidates on the stage.

Although Republicans portray Democrats as the party of big spending, the last time the budget was balanced was under Democratic President Bill Clinton in 1998 and for the next three years. This run ended under Republican George W. Bush, who slashed taxes and fought wars abroad while presiding over large domestic spending increases. Obama, another Democrat, ran deficits high at the start of his presidency to address a deep recession, then trimmed them in his final years in office as the economy picked up.

Now, neither party shows any interest in offering detailed policies to tackle the debt in the 2020 campaign, preferring to focus on healthcare, immigration, and climate change. Maya MacGuineas, head of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a nonpartisan group focused on budget reform, described this era as one of "hyper-partisanship with both parties engaging in free lunchism to try to appeal to voters." Last year, the House of Representatives and Senate formed a special bipartisan panel to examine ways to improve how budgets are written. It failed to make any recommendations, but its operating expenses added about $500,000 to the national debt.

Title: Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber Resigns Amidst Scandal, Leaving Legacy in Question

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber has resigned from office this week, following a scandal that has been likened to a "Greek tragedy" by a Democratic Oregon legislator. The events surrounding Kitzhaber's resignation have been marked by confusion and a hint of hubris, a trait that appears to have contributed to the governor's downfall.

The scandal revolves around Kitzhaber's fiancée, Cylvia Hayes, who has been linked to the governor since his 2002 campaign. Hayes, 20 years his junior, has served as an adviser to Kitzhaber, initially drawing scrutiny for her private consulting work during his 2010 campaign. The latest developments involve Hayes advising Kitzhaber and state employees on energy policy while being paid by a group advocating for specific policies. Additionally, she did not disclose some of her income from the state, and the governor reportedly tried to erase his personal emails from public records, raising further questions about the situation.

These developments have led to a criminal investigation by the state Attorney General and an FBI investigation as well. Kitzhaber had long defended Hayes' work for both the state and private consulting firms, arguing his fiancée should be able to maintain a career she had built independently of their relationship.

Despite the scandal, Kitzhaber managed to win reelection last year, but the situation reached a tipping point when it threatened to undermine the Oregon legislature's agenda. Few lawmakers were willing to work with Kitzhaber going forward, and Democrats do not want to "tarnish an agenda" that had wide support in the legislature by keeping it pinned to a scandal-marred governor.

Kitzhaber's successor, Secretary of State Kate Brown, is seen as more of a Democratic loyalist than Kitzhaber. She will make history as the nation's first openly bisexual governor. Chad Griffin, the president of the Human Rights Campaign, stated, "While she'll make history as the nation's first sitting LGBT governor, the more important truth is that she's supremely capable of leading the state to better days ahead."

The resignation of Governor Kitzhaber leaves his legacy in question, with some, like state Sen. Elizabeth Steiner Hayward, expressing concern that it will overshadow the good he has done for the state. Hayward stated, "This is flat-out Greek tragedy. Kitzhaber has done so many good things for the state."

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and Carly Fiorina Exit 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and former HP executive Carly Fiorina have suspended their Republican presidential bids on Wednesday, following a disappointing performance in the New Hampshire primary. Christie and Fiorina finished sixth and seventh, respectively, in the primary contest.

In a statement on Facebook, Christie expressed his political beliefs, stating, "I ran for president to say that the government needs to once again work for the people, not the people work for the government." He added, "I leave the race without an ounce of regret."

Fiorina, in a written statement, said, "I will continue to travel this country and fight for those Americans who refuse to settle for the way things are and a status quo that no longer works for them."

Christie was banking on a strong performance in the New Hampshire contest, seen as more friendly territory for the Northeast governor who did poorly in Iowa. However, his rivals, including current and former governors, outperformed him in the primary.

Despite receiving attention for his aggressive criticism of Florida Sen. Marco Rubio at Saturday's debate, the spat seemed to hurt Rubio more than it helped Christie. Rubio finished fifth, while Christie ended up well behind the freshman senator, pulling just 7 percent in the state.

Christie's political career has seen a drastic turnaround. In 2012, he delivered the keynote address at the Republican National Convention, after gaining national political fame for taking on the state's public employee unions and his no-nonsense approach to governing. However, the George Washington Bridge scandal and the controversy surrounding it have politically damaged him.

Fiorina, the only female GOP candidate in the 2016 race, entered the primary in April. She promoted herself as an outsider with business experience and argued that as the lone woman in the GOP field, she was best positioned to oppose likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. After a standout performance in the first undercard debate, Fiorina rose to the mainstage and soared in the polls in the fall. However, her momentum quickly stalled, and by the end of the year, she had dropped back down.

Fiorina's first major foray into politics was in 2010, when she ran for Senate in California and lost to incumbent Sen. Barbara Boxer by 10 points. Throughout her presidential bid, Fiorina emphasized her meteoric rise in the business world. A Stanford University graduate, she started her career as a secretary, earned an MBA, and worked her way up at AT&T to become a senior executive at the telecom giant. However, she was also dogged by questions about her record at Hewlett-Packard, where she was hired as CEO in 1999. She was fired six years later, after leading a major merger with Compaq and laying off 30,000 workers.

The exits of Christie and Fiorina immediately kick off the race in the still-crowded GOP field to scoop up their support. The 2016 road for these two candidates who showed political promise earlier in the race has now come to an end.

Title: Sen. Lindsey Graham Criticizes Democratic Push for Expanded Background Checks, Argues for System Improvement

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham (R-SC) criticized Democratic efforts to pass new gun-control bills during a recent appearance on CNN's State of the Union, particularly legislation that expands background checks. Graham argued that the current system is broken and needs improvement before any expansion is considered.

Graham cited statistics showing that in 2020, approximately 76,000 individuals who failed a background check were not prosecuted, and in 2010, around 9,000 felons who failed a background check were also not prosecuted. He argued that resources should be directed at fixing the current system before expanding it to include private transfers.

Graham also stated that the legislation being discussed would not have prevented the Sandy Hook massacre, as the shooter did not fail a background check. He further stated that he would not join the five Senate Republicans who pledged to filibuster any legislation that infringes on the Second Amendment, but only if Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) did not allow alternative amendments.

Senate Democrats have shifted their focus to background checks since bans on semi-automatic weapons are no longer a priority. New York Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer told NBC's "Meet the Press" that he considers background checks the "sweet spot" because it would do a lot of good and have a good chance of passing. Schumer stated that he is working with both Democrats and Republicans to come up with a background check that will be acceptable to 60 senators and be strong enough to effectively address the issue. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is expected to bring legislation to the floor next month.

Title: U.S. International Trade Commission Forecasts Modest Economic Growth from Trans-Pacific Partnership

Article:

The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) has released a report stating that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would result in modest economic growth for the United States, with an estimated increase in real GDP of nearly $43 billion annually by 2032. The report also predicts the creation of an additional 128,000 full-time jobs.

The ITC concluded that TPP would have positive effects, albeit small as a percentage of the overall size of the U.S. economy. The biggest winner on a percentage basis would be agriculture and food, which would see a $10 billion boost, up 0.5 percent, by year 15 of the deal.

However, the report also indicates that manufacturing, natural resources, and energy would be down by a collective $10 billion, or 0.1 percent, after 15 years. The ITC was asked by Congress to assess the economic impact of the proposed trade deal involving the United States and 11 other countries.

President Obama strongly supports the pact and signed it in February. However, the deal is on hold without congressional approval, and no action is currently planned on Capitol Hill. Next week, Obama will be visiting Vietnam and Japan, where he will highlight his support for an economic partnership with those two countries, along with Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Mexico, Chile, and Peru.

The TPP is intended to open markets for U.S. exporters and farmers and help protect intellectual property. It is also meant to strengthen the U.S. political position in Asia. According to Obama, TPP allows America to write the rules of the road in the 21st century, which is especially important in a region as dynamic as the Asia-Pacific.

While most economists say TPP would help more than harm the U.S. economy, some critics argue that the new report shows the pact could have disastrous effects. Lori Wallach of Public Citizen states, "This report spotlights how damaging the TPP would be for most Americans' jobs and wages given it concludes 16 out of 25 U.S. economic sectors would suffer losses while the 'upside' projection is minuscule gains in economic growth despite these findings being based on the same widely criticized methodology and unrealistic assumptions that have resulted in past USITC reports systematically overstating the benefits from trade deals that ended up causing serious damage."

In the past, trade deals have been criticized for failing to meet their corporate and political backers' glowing promises of job creation. For instance, Public Citizen stated last year that trade deals "have failed to meet their corporate and political backers' glowing promises of job creation."

The ITC report on NAFTA issued in January 1993 predicted only modest gains. It said the "estimated long-term gains in U.S. and Canadian real GDP are 0.5 percent or less." In the post-World War II era, the U.S. economy has averaged a 3.21 percent annual GDP growth rate.

For the 20th anniversary of NAFTA's implementation, the Congressional Research Service found that "In reality, NAFTA did not cause the huge job losses feared by the critics or the large economic gains predicted by supporters. The net overall effect of NAFTA on the U.S. economy appears to have been relatively modest."

Whether this new TPP forecast will turn out to be accurate remains to be seen, as the proposed trade deal "will come into effect anywhere from five to maybe 30 years from now," according to Brandeis Professor Peter Petri. "It's basically a long-term gradual transition in which very small changes will be made along the way, up as long as 30 years in the future."
