Trade has become a central issue in this year's election cycle. For example, Republican Donald Trump has called TPP "a horrible deal," while Bernie Sanders, running for the Democratic nomination, regularly refers to trade deals as disasters.

Title: Hillary Clinton Hints at 2016 Presidential Run in Iowa Speech

Article:

Hillary Clinton, a frontrunner in many early presidential polls, returned to Iowa on Sunday, a state she has not visited since her 2008 Iowa caucus loss to Barack Obama. The former Secretary of State, who has not yet announced her intentions for a 2016 presidential run, appeared alongside her husband, former President Bill Clinton, at the annual steak fry hosted by U.S. Sen. Tom Harkin, a significant event for state Democratic activists.

Clinton's speech at the event revealed little about her presidential plans, but did not dampen the widespread belief that she will indeed run. The event, which marked Harkin's last steak fry as he prepares to leave office in January after five terms, was filled with anticipation for Clinton.

Cindy Pollard, 57, who was a precinct captain for Clinton during her 2008 presidential campaign, expressed her readiness for Clinton's potential return. "I was a precinct captain for Hillary. I've been decided," Pollard said.

The event took place on a large open field in Indianola, featuring a giant American flag, bales of straw, and rolling hills and cornfields in the background. After speeches by Iowa Democrats running for U.S. Senate and House seats and for governor, Sen. Harkin spoke and introduced Clinton.

Harkin mentioned Clinton's new memoir, stating, "There are 25 chapters in the book. I'm here to tell you that there are many more chapters to be written in the amazing life of Hillary Clinton." As the crowd chanted her name, Clinton stepped up to the microphone, saying, "Hello, Iowa. I'm baaack."

Clinton teased the crowd about her visit, stating, "When Tom Harkin called and asked me to come, I have to admit I was not sure what to say. I've got a few things on my mind these days." She mentioned her grandchild-watch duties, as her daughter Chelsea is expecting this month, before addressing the elephant in the room.

"And then, of course, there's that other thing," she said playfully as the crowd cheered. "It is true I am thinking about it," Clinton added, "but for today, that is not why I'm here." The crowd groaned.

Nobody expected Clinton to announce anything at the event, but nobody in the crowd seemed to doubt she's running. Some attendees, like Linda Dedecker, an accountant from Ames, were still considering their options. "I'm considering her," Dedecker said, "but I don't know who else is going to run."

Dedecker emphasized the importance of Clinton campaigning in Iowa, meeting people face to face, and expressed concern that Clinton and her advisers may not have fully appreciated the state's caucus system in 2008, leading to her third-place finish in the caucuses.

Karen Hill of Marshalltown, a potential Clinton supporter, offered advice for 2016: "Don't take anything for granted—come and hang out with us for a while."

At the steak fry, a table was also set up on behalf of the push to get Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren into the race as a progressive alternative to Clinton. One Warren supporter emphasized the importance of not anointing Clinton so early—before anyone has officially declared that they are running.

Title: Trump Calls for Border Legislation, Cites Immigration and DACA

Article:

President Donald Trump reiterated his criticism of the Democratic Party over the country's immigration policies and the lack of a deal on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in a series of tweets on Monday.

In his tweets, Trump emphasized that Mexico has the power to prevent large groups of migrants, commonly referred to as "Caravans," from entering their country at the northern border. He also stated that the United States lacks effective border laws, which he believes allows people to pass through into the country.

The President called for immediate passage of Border Legislation, suggesting the use of the "Nuclear Option" if necessary, to address the influx of drugs and people. He praised Border Patrol Agents and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) but expressed concern that current Democratic laws impede their ability to perform their duties effectively.

Trump also declared DACA "dead" due to the Democrats' lack of action, and stated that the program is no longer viable. He emphasized the need to build a wall and secure the borders with proper border legislation. The President also suggested that Democrats desire open borders, leading to increased drug trafficking and crime.

Trump's comments follow his Sunday tweets threatening that there would be "NO MORE DACA DEAL." The messages come after a report emerged showing photos of over 1,000 migrants from Central America moving through the streets of Mexico, with Mexican immigration officials reportedly taking no action to halt the flow.

Title: Rival Candidates Call for Each Other's Exit Ahead of Super Tuesday

Article:

In a last-ditch effort before Super Tuesday, Donald Trump's Republican rivals are attempting to undermine each other in an attempt to boost their own chances and mount a viable challenge against the billionaire front-runner. Each candidate has called on the others to exit the race.

Ahead of a crucial debate on Thursday night, Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and John Kasich have all claimed to be the only candidate capable of derailing Trump, whose momentum has been growing with three consecutive wins in the previous four contests. Ben Carson is the only candidate who has refrained from the fray, instead interpreting his distant finishes as evidence that "things are starting to happen."

Ohio Governor John Kasich's campaign, despite performing poorly in the South Carolina and Nevada contests, issued a defiant call on Thursday for Rubio to drop out. Kasich spokesman Chris Schrimpf tweeted, ". @ JohnKasich is the ONLY candidate who can beat @ realDonaldTrump on 3/15. @ marcorubio needs to do the right thing & suspend campaign."

Rubio, who has yet to win a primary contest but has been steadily accumulating endorsements from fellow lawmakers and big-name Republicans, has been positioning himself as the best candidate to win a general election in November and the best choice to take on Trump. Rubio acknowledged during a forum with host Megyn Kelly on Wednesday that Trump is "the frontrunner and I'm the underdog, but I've been an underdog my entire life."

The candidates will square off on Thursday night in Houston for a CNN-Telemundo debate. For some, it could represent their last debate opportunity to define themselves as the anti-Trump candidate, as the field moves on to more than a dozen states holding contests on Super Tuesday. A close sweep by Trump on Tuesday would be devastating for the remaining candidates. Texas, Georgia, and other delegate-heavy states are at stake that day.

At the forum on Wednesday, Texas Senator Ted Cruz argued that he, not anyone else, is the best alternative candidate since he is the only other one who has won a primary contest, the Iowa caucuses. He said his campaign was "the only campaign that can beat Donald [and] has beat Donald."

Trump, however, has consistently argued against the conventional wisdom that if other candidates drop out, their support will gravitate to the other non-Trump candidates. Trump argues that he would also pick up some of that support. Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia Center for Politics, agreed with Trump in this regard.

"Trump will get a share. He might not get a majority, but he'll get a share," Sabato told the media outlet.

The pressure is strongest on candidates Kasich and especially Carson, whose campaign has steadily fallen in the polls and has performed poorly in the first four contests. Carson, however, has appeared immune to the political pressure or the poor showings in South Carolina and Nevada. After placing fourth in Nevada, Carson nevertheless declared to supporters that "things are starting to happen."

Carson seemed to level a bit more with supporters in a fundraising email on Wednesday, saying without a strong showing on Super Tuesday, "it's going to be very tough for my campaign. That's the honest truth."

Kasich, however, told the media outlet that "the people calling for me to get out are the people who are inside the Beltway... I'm certainly not listening to a bunch of lobbyist insiders."

Title: Rep. Denny Heck Announces Retirement from Congress, Leaving Democratic-Leaning Seat Open

Article:

Representative Denny Heck (D-WA) has announced his retirement from Congress, citing his discouragement following the investigation of Russian election interference and the impeachment inquiry. In a statement, Heck expressed his dismay at the actions of some of his colleagues who he believes ignored or denied the President's attacks on the free press, character assassinations, and demonstrable disregard for truth.

Heck, who served a decade in the Washington state House, began his political career with his election in 1976. He also served as chief of staff to then-Washington Governor Booth Gardner during Gardner's second term in Olympia. He first ran for Congress in 2010, losing to Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler (R-WA), but won a different seat in 2012 due to post-2010 redistricting.

In Congress, Heck led recruitment efforts for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) for the past two cycles, personally drafting many of the newly elected Democratic freshman members, including Reps. Stephanie Murphy (D-FL) and Susie Lee (D-NV). He ran unsuccessfully last year to serve as chairman of the committee, losing a four-way race to Rep. Cheri Bustos (D-IL).

Washington's 10th District is considered Democratic-leaning territory. Heck won reelection last year with 62% of the vote, and Hillary Clinton carried the district by an 11-point margin in 2016. Heck's retirement is expected to result in a crowded field of candidates vying to succeed him. Under Washington's top-two primary system, all candidates will run together on the same ballot, regardless of party, in the Aug. 4 primary, with the top two finishers advancing to a head-to-head general election.

Possible Democratic candidates for the seat include Olympia Mayor Cheryl Selby, Phil Gardner, Heck's district director, state Reps. Beth Doglio, Christine Kilduff, and Mari Leavitt. Heck already had a Democratic challenger next year: truck driver Joshua Collins.

Title: Pope Francis' U.S. Visit: A Week of Controversy and Expectation

Article:

Pope Francis' visit to the United States this week is marked by a variety of expectations and controversies, as the pontiff navigates through Washington D.C., Philadelphia, and New York City. The visit has sparked debate on a range of issues, from capitalism to social justice, and homosexuality to religious liberty.

In Cuba, the pope received a warm welcome from the Castro brothers, who praised his long-standing commitment to left-wing politics. Raul Castro, in a speech commending Cuba's repressive government, criticized America's economic system and called for the suspension of the trade embargo on Cuba, which he described as "cruel, immoral, and illegal."

President Obama is expected to use the pontiff as a tool in his campaign against perceived social injustice, while some believe the pope may soften his stance on homosexuality, given his promise not to judge. Meanwhile, the pope's visit to the United Nations may be met with Marxist bloviation, as the president of Cuba has previously delivered long-winded and bitter speeches in similar forums.

In Washington D.C., some Catholic members of Congress have discussed boycotting the pope's speech to a joint session, while the White House has reportedly snubbed representatives of the anti-abortion movement. Some bishops are urging the pope to address threats to religious liberty, particularly the requirement in Obamacare for religious institutions to pay for abortions, a practice that violates strongly held faith beliefs.

The pope's visit to Philadelphia on Saturday will provide an opportunity for him to deliver a final speech at the Independence National Historical Park. The visit is expected to be a significant moment in the tale of three cities, as the pope navigates through the chaos of crosstown traffic and the diverse array of opinions and beliefs that characterize modern America.

Title: Congressional Opposition to Iran Nuclear Deal: Prospects of a "Better Deal"

Article:

As the Iran nuclear deal, a complex international agreement limiting Iran's nuclear program, is under debate in Congress, the possibility of rejecting the current deal in favor of a "better deal" is gaining traction. On Wednesday, Rep. Grace Meng (D-NY) announced her opposition to the deal, stating that "the world could and should have a better deal." However, the likelihood of renegotiating and strengthening the deal if Congress rejects it and overcomes a presidential veto is a contentious issue.

The debate hinges on perceptions of Iran, with critics arguing that Iran should not be entangled in such a complex deal and should not be allowed to possess any uranium enrichment program. Mark Dubowitz, an international sanctions expert and executive director of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies (FDD) in Washington, suggests that Congress should require the administration to renegotiate certain terms of the proposed deal and resubmit the amended agreement to Congress.

However, senior administration officials involved in the Iran negotiations argue that the deal cannot be renegotiated, and warn that rejection of the deal would likely result in a more aggressive uranium enrichment program by Iran, shortening the "breakout" time for Iran to rush to produce a nuclear weapon if it chose to do so. Secretary of State John Kerry has described the prospect of a "better deal" as a "fantasy."

Some nonproliferation experts share this view, stating that the Iranian nuclear program is too advanced to be significantly reduced. Jeffrey Lewis, director of nonproliferation studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey, Calif., states, "The most important thing now is to prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon in the next 10 to 15 years, and this deal does that."

Others believe a renegotiated deal could block Iran's paths to a nuclear weapon. FDD's Mr. Dubowitz outlines three potential scenarios if Congress rejects the current deal and holds out for a renegotiated deal: Iran could implement its commitments under the deal, abandon its commitments and escalate its nuclear program, or attempt to comply with certain commitments while abandoning others. In any of these scenarios, Dubowitz suggests that the US could work to persuade European allies to join in demanding a renegotiation of key parts of the deal.

However, regional experts question the prospects of wooing European allies to join the US in pressing for a tougher deal. Jon Alterman, a Middle East expert at Washington's Center for Strategic and International Studies, stated this week that European allies would likely feel frustrated and misled in the wake of a US rejection of the deal, and would likely invest in Iran's energy sector.

Suspicions among deal supporters that those calling for a "better deal" are not sincere in their pursuit of a stronger deal are also prevalent. Jeffrey Lewis states, "We had a 'better deal' in Iraq after 1991 [following the Gulf War], there were no restrictions, inspectors could go where they wanted when they wanted, and that deal wasn't good enough. So really I don't believe them when they say they just want a 'better deal' this time."

Critics of the "better deal" campaign also point out that the sponsor of the TV ad campaign is a group called Citizens for a Nuclear Free Iran, which is backed by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israel organization lobbying Congress hard for the deal's defeat. "There really is no 'better deal' for [such critics] in the sense of an agreement that leaves any nuclear program in the hands of the current Iranian government," Lewis says. "Any deal is bad because it means living with the Islamic Republic."

Title: Study Finds Higher Lead Levels in Blood of Children Relying on Private Wells for Drinking Water

Article:

A new study published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences has found that American children whose homes rely on private wells for drinking water are 25 percent more likely to have high lead levels in their blood than those with access to regulated community water services. The research, which is the first to specifically analyze lead exposure in children who rely on private wells, was conducted by researchers examining the water sources and health records from almost 60,000 children in North Carolina.

The study found that children relying on private wells had blood lead concentrations that were 20 percent higher, on average, than children with community water service. The study also found that children living in older, lower-value houses suffered higher lead levels and had higher risks of elevated blood lead, as did those in majority-Black neighborhoods.

Lead, a heavy metal which has no smell and is invisible to the naked eye, is a suspected carcinogen and highly toxic to the brain and nervous system, as well as most other organs. The water scandal in Flint, Michigan, in 2014 exposed concerns about lead in regulated city drinking water supplies, but little attention has been paid to dangerous contaminants in unregulated private wells which provide drinking water to 42.5 million Americans, the equivalent of 13 percent of the population.

"Risks are especially high for children in low-income households and in African American neighborhoods that remain excluded from access to nearby municipal water service—a legacy of discriminatory zoning practices," said Jackie MacDonald Gibson, author of the study and chair of the department of environmental and occupational health at the Indiana University school of public health. "This unfortunate legacy contributes to persistent intergenerational poverty through its impacts on children’s cognitive development."

There is no safe lead level, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and childhood exposure has been linked to reduced IQ, ADHD, school failure, and criminality. The increased exposure is probably due to corrosion of indoor plumbing and well components.

Private wells are excluded from the Safe Drinking Water Act, which since 1991 has required all community water utilities to monitor lead levels as part of the Lead and Copper Rule provision. This means households with private wells must monitor their own water quality, and, when necessary, replace parts and install and manage their own corrosion-control systems. However, according to Gibson, lead control requires awareness of the risks, knowledge about testing, and money, which is seldom done.

"This study highlights the need for an overhaul of the Safe Drinking Water Act to provide support for households relying on private wells," Gibson said. "That includes financial support, and education and support on proper testing. No level of lead exposure is safe. This is an issue that must continue to be addressed."

Title: George Papadopoulos Claims Sessions Was Enthusiastic About Trump-Putin Summit in 2016

Article:

George Papadopoulos, a former advisor to the Trump campaign, has stated that then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions was "quite enthusiastic" during the 2016 campaign about the prospect of a summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Papadopoulos recounted a roundtable meeting in 2016 where he mentioned his connection that could establish a summit between the two leaders.

According to Papadopoulos, President Trump, then a candidate, seemed noncommittal, but Sessions appeared "quite enthusiastic" about the idea. However, Sessions has testified that he pushed back on the idea.

Papadopoulos was sentenced to two weeks in prison on Friday for lying to investigators probing Russian interference in the 2016 election. He pleaded guilty in October 2017 to lying to federal investigators about his contacts with Joseph Mifsud, a London-based professor who supposedly told him in 2016 that Russia had damaging information on Hillary Clinton, Trump's Democratic opponent.

During the interview, Papadopoulos also addressed an email about the possible dirt he was alleged to have sent to John Mashburn, a Trump campaign and White House official. He stated, "If I did send an email, and especially if others were copied on it, I’m sure that evidence would have [been] introduced by now." He added, "If that email was sent, even if I deleted it, if that’s what people believe I did, there would be a copy somewhere else."

Papadopoulos also expressed uncertainty about whether special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation would reveal actual collusion between Russian officials and the Trump campaign. "All I can say is that my testimony might have helped move something towards that," he said, "but I have no idea."

President Trump has repeatedly stated there was "no collusion."

Title: Biden, Sanders Cancel Campaign Events Amid Coronavirus Outbreak; Trump Campaign Shifts to Virtual Engagement

Article:

In response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, Democratic presidential candidates Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders have canceled campaign events and shifted their operations to virtual engagements. The Trump campaign, too, has adjusted its strategies, moving towards online events and remote work for its staff.

Joe Biden delivered a sober speech on Thursday, with only his wife, Jill, in the camera shot. Bernie Sanders, known for his large rallies, has also suspended large events. The Trump campaign had been eager to hold a fundraiser with casino magnate Sheldon Adelson, which was canceled, as well as the first lady's scheduled Los Angeles fundraiser, now under a state of emergency.

Both the Biden and Sanders campaigns have opted for remote work. The Biden campaign has instructed employees at its Philadelphia headquarters to work from home starting this weekend, while staffers in other locations can choose to work from home or short-term housing rentals. The Sanders campaign has similarly asked all staff to work from home.

Field organizing, traditionally conducted in-person, has become more complex due to the outbreak. The Republican National Committee (RNC) had planned a National Week of Training, a nationwide effort to recruit and activate supporters, which is now set to be held online and over the phone.

The Trump campaign, with its extensive digital infrastructure and database, is relying on its online presence to engage voters. The reelection effort recently launched ArmyforTrump.com, a website designed to serve as an online hub for volunteers.

Tim Murtaugh, a Trump campaign spokesman, stated, "The Trump campaign is built on data and uses technology to its highest advantages, so is better positioned to virtually engage voters than any other campaign."

The Biden campaign, in its Thursday memo, announced the closure of all field offices to the public and plans to organize voters through phone banking, text messaging, virtual events, and other distributed organizing models. The Sanders campaign, in response to the outbreak, has halted door-to-door canvasses and will move to digital formats and outreach wherever possible.

While Trump advisers express concerns about the president's response to the coronavirus and its impact on his reelection hopes, they remain relatively optimistic. However, they acknowledge the political risks associated with the ongoing crisis, as schools and offices close, and people lose their lives.

Ron Klain, a top Biden campaign adviser, emphasized the importance of a swift and effective response to the coronavirus, implying that the current administration has not followed this approach. "The No. 1 question right now," said Klain, "is what's your response to this coronavirus?"

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Shift: A New Approach to Iran and North Korea

Article:

President Donald Trump, in his first year in office, often deferred to the advice of cautious national security advisors, adding troops to the war in Afghanistan, delaying plans to move the U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, and preserving a nuclear-containment deal with Iran. However, in his second year, Trump has adopted a more assertive foreign policy, trusting his own efforts to negotiate, coerce, and intimidate global rivals.

On Tuesday, Trump took his latest step in this direction by withdrawing from the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement, a move that has sparked criticism and concerns about potential risks. The U.S. shift towards a more confrontational approach to Iran led to Syrian officials reporting Israeli airstrikes on Iranian targets near Damascus, raising fears of increased conflict in the Middle East.

Trump's approach has been described as high-risk, with the potential for significant successes or failures. Mark Dubowitz, chief executive of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, who advocated for changes to the Iran deal, not its scrapping, said, "It's the Art of the Deal: Refuse to be bound by existing agreements that are not in America's interest. Exit, or threaten to exit, these agreements and use maximum pressure in order to get a better deal."

Critics argue that Trump's decision to withdraw from the Iran deal makes it less likely that North Korea will agree to a deal with the U.S. However, Trump's national security adviser, John Bolton, contends that the move strengthens the U.S.'s hand in negotiations.

Trump's approach to North Korea, characterized by threats and pressure, has raised fears of a nuclear war. Yet, Trump's supporters argue that the threats have rattled North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Un. The U.S. is now relying more on Israel and Saudi Arabia, Iran's two biggest rivals in the Middle East, to counter Iran's regional influence.

Trump's foreign policy strategy has been compared to President Ronald Reagan's approach to the Soviet Union in the 1980s. Reagan's style, like Trump's, stoked fears of nuclear war, but he eventually negotiated a historic reduction in nuclear weapons with the Soviet Union. However, there were differences, with Reagan relying on the recommendations of his seasoned national security team, while Trump has often clashed with his own advisors.

Trump's allies argue that his approach to foreign policy is a template for Iran: use threats to intimidate adversaries, pressure allies into taking tough steps to isolate the troubling rival, and force people to the negotiating table. The administration faces challenges in persuading European allies to work with the U.S. after dismissing their attempts to save the Iran deal. European leaders have distanced themselves from the U.S. decision and vowed to work with Iran to salvage the agreement.

Title: Republican Tax Policy Makers to Propose Corporate Tax Rate Reduction, Avoid Individual Tax Rate Cuts

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. President Donald Trump and top Republicans in Congress are set to reveal a plan on Wednesday targeting tax cuts for businesses, with few details about how to replace the reduced federal revenues, according to lobbyists and congressional sources. The "Big Six" team of Republican tax policy makers, which includes top Trump aides and congressional Republican leaders, is expected to propose a corporate income tax target rate within a range of 18-23 percent, down from the current rate of 35 percent.

However, the Big Six is expected to refrain from cutting the top individual tax rate of 39.6 percent, a move that many Republicans in the House of Representatives could find difficult to accept. Stephen Moore, a fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation think tank who helped write Trump's campaign tax plan, predicted that they will not cut the highest income tax rate.

Overhauling the tax code was a key pledge for Trump in his 2016 presidential campaign. After eight months in office, he has made only limited progress, with Washington achieving no major tax overhaul since 1986.

Trump portrays lower corporate taxes as a boon to workers, stating that they would lead to more jobs and higher salaries. A rate cut on corporate profits could also benefit shareholders and offer more executive bonuses, however.

The Big Six, which also includes Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, Trump economic adviser Gary Cohn, Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan, and two tax committee chairmen, have been working on their plan for months. They are still undecided on key issues, including whether to let businesses write off new investments immediately, how to lower tax rates for small businesses, and whether to cut middle-class taxes simply by doubling the standard deduction for individuals and families, according to lobbyists.

Resolving such issues will help determine how aggressively Republicans can cut corporate taxes. Lobbyists said they do not expect the Big Six to offer many details about the tax loopholes and deductions that could be eliminated to help pay for tax cuts.

The Big Six is also expected to address the estimated $2.6 trillion in U.S. corporate profits held overseas by requiring companies to bring the money home at rates of 3.5 percent for reinvested profits and 8.75 percent for on cash and equivalents, lobbyists said. To offset lost revenue, the Trump administration plans to forecast a flood of new tax revenue in coming years, based on aggressive assumptions of tax-fueled economic expansion.

However, Senate Republicans have shown signs of moving away from such "dynamic" scoring of any tax legislation impact. Two senators, including a prominent fiscal hawk, agreed this week to a "static" score that could allow tax reform to lose up to $1.5 trillion over the next decade. Senate Republicans are also likely to avoid budget baseline changes to generate savings for tax reform on paper, which could well mean the Big Six plan would balloon the federal budget deficit.

"Without those, the price goes up. There's no other way to look at it," said John Gimigliano, a former House Ways and Means Committee tax counsel who leads federal legislative and regulatory services at KPMG LLP.

Title: Trump's Appointment of Retired Generals for Cabinet Positions: A Historical Perspective

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump's decision to appoint retired generals to cabinet-level positions, such as Michael Flynn as national security adviser, James Mattis as defense secretary, and John Kelly as secretary of homeland security, has been met with criticism for supposedly "militarizing" the government. However, this practice is not unprecedented in American politics.

Historically, retired generals and admirals have held cabinet positions and other high offices in the United States. For instance, during Barack Obama's administration, Petraeus served as CIA director, and Flynn was director of the Defense Intelligence Agency. Other retired generals, such as Eric Shinseki, James Jones, Dennis Blair, and James Clapper, held high-ranking positions in Obama's administration.

Ronald Reagan also appointed a number of retired and acting generals to cabinet positions or other high offices, including Al Haig as secretary of state, Colin Powell (while on active duty) as national security adviser, and Vernon Walters as ambassador to the United Nations.

In the 20th century, many of the stars of the American effort in World War II later served in the executive branch. President Harry Truman appointed General George Marshall, of Marshall Plan fame, as secretary of state and later secretary of defense. General Omar Bradley was head of the Veterans Administration while still on active duty.

The chief complaint about Trump's appointments is that too many generals will mean too great a likelihood of war. However, historical evidence points to the opposite conclusion. Generals were not the proverbial "best and brightest" who argued for military intervention in Vietnam, the invasion of Iraq in 2003, or the bombing of Libya in 2011.

Traditionally, retired generals and flag officers have no desire to see their own troops killed in what they see as optional wars abroad. Their occasional harangues about building up military power are predicated on notions of peace-through-strength deterrence: The more powerful the military is perceived abroad, the less likely it will be needed to be used.

Far more worrisome is the tired presidential custom of relying on ex-senators and politicians with law degrees to fill important executive positions despite their lack of outside-the-Beltway administrative experience. In 2008, Obama's résumé consisted mainly of having been a Harvard Law School grad and, briefly, a U.S. senator. No wonder he looked to people with similar backgrounds for some key appointments—former senator and lawyer Joe Biden as vice president, former senator and lawyer Hillary Clinton as secretary of state, and later, former senator and lawyer John Kerry as secretary of state.

Lawyers, Ivy League graduates, and former politicians usually dominate presidential appointments. How have these stereotypical profiles worked out? We are currently nearing $20 trillion in national debt, stagnating under nonexistent economic growth and near-zero interest rates, and suffering from record labor nonparticipation rates. We are seeing a failed health-care system, a discredited IRS and VA, and the worst racial relations in half a century. Generals did not compile that record. Lawyers and lifetime Washington politicians did.

Title: Democratic Political Group Launches Ad Campaign Questioning Bernie Sanders' Electability and Health in Nevada

Article:

A Democratic political action committee (PAC), the Democratic Majority for Israel (DMFI), has initiated a new ad campaign in Nevada, targeting presidential candidate Bernie Sanders. The group has purchased tens of thousands of dollars in cable and network ad time this week ahead of the February 22nd presidential nominating caucuses, according to Federal Communications Commission (FCC) filings.

The exact size of DMFI's Nevada purchase is not immediately clear, as the group has not yet filed an independent expenditure report with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) as of Friday morning. However, FCC filings indicate the total size of the buy is over $175,000.

DMFI ran similar anti-Sanders ads in the lead-up to the Iowa caucuses earlier this month. The thirty-second video spot questions Sanders' ability to win a general election and raises concerns about the Vermont senator's health. A woman featured in the ad states, "I do have some concerns about Bernie Sanders' health, considering he did have a heart attack."

Mark Mellman, a Democratic consultant who runs DMFI PAC, stated that the group's ad in Nevada would be different from the one that ran in Iowa, but did not provide further details.

DMFI has received the majority of its funding from a few high-dollar donors. Stacy Schusterman, a Tulsa oil and gas heiress, donated nearly $1 million to DMFI PAC in December, according to FEC records. The group also received $495,000 from venture capitalist Mark Gary Lauder.

DMFI's new offensive against Sanders comes as he attempts to gain ground in the race for Democratic delegates in the third presidential nominating contest. He currently trails former South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg by a pair of delegates despite strong showings in both Iowa and New Hampshire.

The group's plans for a Nevada attack on Sanders were first reported by Mediaite. FCC filings posted on the agency's website on Wednesday and Thursday show DMFI has purchased ad time on broadcast stations in Las Vegas and Reno, as well as a host of statewide cable programs.

Title: U.S. Court of Appeals Orders Judge to Respond to Petition for Dismissal of Michael Flynn's Case

Article:

WASHINGTON - The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has instructed Judge Emmet Sullivan to respond to an emergency petition filed by Michael Flynn's lawyers, seeking to compel Sullivan to grant a Justice Department request to dismiss the criminal case against the former national security adviser.

Flynn, a retired Army lieutenant general who also advised Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, pleaded guilty in 2017 to lying to the FBI about his conversations with Russia's U.S. ambassador, Sergey Kislyak, in the weeks before Trump took office. The charges were part of former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation that documented Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election to boost Trump's candidacy.

In May, the Department of Justice, in a major reversal, asked Sullivan to drop the charges, drawing accusations from Democrats and retired career prosecutors that Attorney General William Barr was politicizing the U.S. criminal justice system to go light on Trump's friends and associates.

Flynn later sought to withdraw his plea and accused the FBI of tricking him. The Department's decision to ask Sullivan to drop the charges followed public pressure from Trump and the Republican president's political allies.

Last week, Sullivan signaled reluctance to drop the charges, appointing a retired judge to advise whether Flynn should face an additional criminal contempt charge for perjury. Sullivan has scheduled an in-person court hearing in the case for July 16.

Flynn served as national security adviser in the first weeks of Trump's presidency before being fired for misleading Vice President Mike Pence about his dealings with Kislyak.

Title: U.S. Policy in Syria: A Look at the Unintended Consequences

Article:

The recent string of tragedies in cities such as Orlando, Istanbul, Dhaka, Baghdad, Medina, and Nice have been linked to the ongoing Syrian conflict. A common argument suggests that if the United States had taken a more active role in Syria's civil war, the Islamic State (ISIL) might not have gained traction, and the scale of the war might have been significantly smaller. However, a new analysis challenges this conventional wisdom, arguing that a different policy approach could have prevented the chaos currently engulfing the region.

According to this perspective, the U.S. and its allies should have allowed Syrian President Bashar Assad to win the war. This alternative policy would have prevented the rise of ISIL and the ensuing chaos. Instead, an anti-ISIL coalition recently met in Washington to discuss next steps against the caliphate and its affiliates.

Several key points are worth considering when examining the origins of the Syrian civil war. First, the moderate opposition was weak, with limited resources and inexperienced fighters. Providing lethal aid early would have resulted in weapons falling into the wrong hands, exacerbating the conflict rather than mitigating it.

Second, the opposition was disorganized and lacked coherent leadership. While names like Assad, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi (leader of ISIL), and Abu Mohammad al-Julani (head of the Nusra Front) are well-known, few can name leaders within the moderate Syrian opposition, such as the Free Syrian Army or the Syrian National Coalition.

Third, Assad and his allies had a clear objective: maintain power. Syria's allies were unburdened by the regime's atrocities, as they had a vested interest in Assad's survival. In contrast, the U.S. found itself in a catch-22, as attacking Assad would aid extremist rebels, while attacking extremist rebels would aid Assad. Unwilling to back either party and lacking a clear alternative, the U.S. had no clear goal or strategy, leading to a lack of intervention and a rising body count.

In this context, the U.S. pursued a third way. When President Obama called on Assad to step down in August 2011, the U.S. invested in Assad's defeat without implementing policies to facilitate that outcome. The possibility of Assad winning the war outright was no longer an option, and U.S. acquiescence to a political solution in which Assad remained became increasingly difficult.

To address the situation, the U.S. imposed additional sanctions on the Syrian government, froze Syrian assets under U.S. control, prohibited commercial ties with Damascus, and blocked the import of Syrian oil. The U.S. also established supply routes, funneled money, intelligence, and non-lethal aid to handpicked rebels, many of whom later switched sides. Physical supplies included communications equipment, night vision goggles, bulletproof vests, pickup trucks, food, medicine, and more.

However, these actions were insufficient to prevent Assad's victory and prolonged the war. Furthermore, the U.S. and its partners did little to prevent states like Qatar and Saudi Arabia from sending vast sums of materiel and money to Assad's opposition, including its most extreme elements. Turkey faced little pressure to control its border, even as thousands of militants flooded into Syria to join the war.

In essence, the main problem with U.S. policy toward Syria is not that the administration did too little early in the conflict. It is that the administration did too much. If the U.S. and its partners had not intervened, Assad would have likely quelled the civil war before it began. A brutal dictator would have retained control of his country, but the death toll would be lower, Syria would be more stable, the refugee crisis might not have occurred, and ISIL might never have taken its current form.

When examining the unintended consequences of intervention in Iraq and Libya, it is crucial to consider the same in Syria. As Seth Cantey, an assistant professor of politics at Washington & Lee University, notes, "We should see that when we look at Syria, too."

Title: North Dakota Senators Heitkamp and Cramer Agree on Civility, Differ on Key Issues in Final Debate

Article:

In a display of political civility, North Dakota Senators Heidi Heitkamp and Kevin Cramer, engaged in their final debate ahead of the November midterm elections, agreeing on the need for more civility in American politics following the arrest of a pro-Trump bomber earlier in the day.

The debate, held Thursday, took place amidst the backdrop of the arrest of Florida resident Cesar Sayoc, who is accused of sending dangerous packages to CNN and Democratic leaders who have criticized President Trump. Both senators, in their opening statements, distanced themselves from any blame, stating that Sayoc was solely responsible for his actions.

The harmony between the two candidates comes after critics have accused President Trump of using divisive rhetoric, with some suggesting it may have sparked one of his supporters to terrorize the nation this week. In response, Heitkamp recalled Republican Rep. Steve Scalise, who was shot and wounded by a left-wing partisan last year, speaking in the aftermath of the attack.

"He never once mentioned Democratic politics," said Heitkamp. "Looking at that as an example, the message couldn't be clearer—we all need to quit blaming. There is only one person responsible here," she said.

Both senators acknowledged the need for accountability in their words, with Cramer, a Trump-ally, emphasizing the importance of debates, like the one they held Thursday, as an opportunity to celebrate political civility.

The two have been in a fierce race, with Heitkamp trying to hold onto her seat in the U.S. Senate this November in a state where Trump won by 36 points. However, Heitkamp's poll numbers have sunk after voting against Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh. In a poll released this week, she is behind Cramer by 16 points, a significant increase from the four-point deficit she faced prior to her vote against the president's high court pick.

Despite the setback, Heitkamp's campaign has received more than $12 million in donations during the first two weeks of October, according to a recent filing with the Federal Elections Commission. Former Vice President Joe Biden, one of the bomber's targets earlier this week, is set to campaign for Heitkamp, kicking off her statewide tour in Fargo next week.

Both lawmakers agreed on the need for a border wall and increased security to deter illegal immigrants from entering the country, as thousands of migrants from Central America are heading to the border through a caravan.

"We can not leave our borders unprotected. The rule of law has to be imposed—if there is 4,000 today, there will be a million tomorrow," said Heitkamp, distancing herself from many of her Democratic colleagues who have balked at a wall along the southern border.

"We ought to have something to say about who comes in our country," said Cramer.

Both lawmakers also disagreed on the Paris Climate Accord, with Heitkamp and Cramer opposing Trump's decision to pull out of the agreement. However, they sparred over the Affordable Care Act and whether to fix the law as it exists, or to repeal and replace it entirely.

Cramer argued that money should go to the states, where they can provide better health care options for constituents, while Heitkamp said not to throw the baby out with the bathwater—and instead, fix areas of the healthcare law which aren't working. The debate concluded with both lawmakers yielding time to one another, demonstrating a level of respect and civility that was evident throughout the hour-long showdown.

Title: AFL-CIO President Warns Hillary Clinton of Political Consequences Over Pacific Trade Pact

Article:

Richard Trumka, president of the AFL-CIO, the nation's most powerful labor union, has warned Hillary Clinton of potential political repercussions if she fails to oppose President Obama's key trade legislation, the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), also known as "fast-track." In an interview with Capital Download, Trumka predicted that no more than 20 House Democrats would vote for the TPA, which would require Congress to approve or reject the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade deal among the United States and 12 other Pacific Rim nations, without amendments.

The AFL-CIO and the Obama administration have found themselves on opposing sides in a contentious political battle over the TPA. Many labor unions have halted campaign donations as they lobby against the legislation. The TPP would lower trade barriers, but organized labor argues that it will cost jobs and lower wages in the U.S.

Trumka expressed uncertainty about Clinton's stance on the issue, stating, "She's going to have to answer that." He suggested that her position on the TPP and TPA will significantly impact her presidential campaign. If Clinton supports the trade pact and the fast-track authority, it could negatively affect her ability to mobilize working people for her campaign, according to Trumka.

When asked about the impact of Obama's presidency on working Americans, Trumka expressed mixed feelings. He acknowledged the president's challenges in delivering results due to opposition from the Republican Party, but also criticized Obama for not fighting harder for policies that would benefit working Americans.

In the Senate vote, Trumka was surprised to see Democratic senators Benjamin Cardin of Maryland, Chris Coons of Delaware, and Patty Murray of Washington state vote in favor of the TPA. When asked about the difficulty of defeating a president, Trumka replied, "We'll see." The AFL-CIO president also hinted that the union might not endorse a presidential candidate if both candidates were not interested in raising wages and creating jobs.

Title: Trump Announces Temporary Immigration Suspension, Sparking Debate on Economic Impact

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Monday via Twitter that he would be signing an executive order to temporarily suspend immigration to the United States in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The order, which is more limited than the initial announcement suggested, will halt the issuance of permanent residency visas, or green cards, for 60 days. The order does not affect temporary workers and reportedly includes exceptions for workers in "essential" professions and family members of U.S. citizens.

The move is intended to "protect the jobs" of American workers amid an unprecedented spike in unemployment caused by lockdown measures aimed at limiting the spread of the virus. Immigration has already been significantly curtailed during the outbreak due to travel restrictions and a pause in most visa processing procedures.

The economic impact of the order is a subject of debate. Limiting restrictions to green card applicants, who represent a fraction of the immigrant workforce, may have little to no impact on jobs, many economists say.

Trump's conservative allies argue that the order is a sincere, if limited, attempt to ensure that jobs are reserved for the more than 20 million Americans who have become unemployed since the start of the crisis.

Others view the order as a political tactic. Critics argue that cutting immigration was a key element of Trump's 2016 election platform and that doubling down on that strategy could serve to invigorate his base supporters and distract from the administration's response to the virus, which has received significant criticism.

Some of the president's liberal critics say he is using the crisis as an opportunity to impose an anti-immigrant agenda that has been high on the Republican to-do list since long before the pandemic began.

The initial 60-day freeze on new green cards could be extended indefinitely depending on economic conditions, Trump said. He also said the administration was considering a "secondary order" that could further limit immigration down the road.

The pandemic provides an opportunity to enact Trump's wish list of immigration policies, according to some analysts. White House adviser Stephen Miller has long advocated for shutting down most immigration, legal and illegal. In the coronavirus, they may have found their opening.

Trump is also being accused of looking for anyone else to blame for the crisis. Some argue that he is using immigrants, public health officials, governors, and the news media as scapegoats to avoid accountability for his response to the pandemic.

The extent to which the order will impact the economy remains to be seen. The order is set to take effect on Wednesday.

Title: Israel's Election Results Remain Unclear as Netanyahu and Gantz Tied in Initial Vote Count

Article:

Initial vote counting in Israel's historic election shows no clear winner as of Wednesday morning, with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party and Benny Gantz's rival Blue and White party reportedly tied with 32 seats each, according to Israel's Kan public broadcaster and an exit poll on Channel 12. Official results are not expected to be announced until Wednesday afternoon local time.

"We're still waiting for the results," Netanyahu told supporters early Wednesday morning at the Likud election headquarters in Tel Aviv. "But one thing is clear, the State of Israel is at a historic turning point. We are facing immense opportunities and immense challenges... including the existential threat from Iran," he added.

Netanyahu also stated that Israel will never have a government "that leans on Arab, anti-Zionist parties."

Gantz, on the other hand, said, "We were busy with the campaign for too long. And with your permission, we will be waiting for another day or two, and we wish the people of Israel a good and desirable unity government."

Tuesday's election is said to be a referendum on Netanyahu, who has served as Israel's longest-running prime minister. This is an unprecedented election as it is the first time Israel has held elections twice in the same year. Netanyahu's Likud party won the election in April, but the prime minister's inability to form a government coalition weeks after the election sent millions of Israelis back to the polls on Tuesday.

After casting his ballot in Jerusalem, Netanyahu said the vote would be "very close."

"It's not in the bag. But if you go [vote], we will win," Netanyahu told Israelis in Jerusalem.

Gantz voted in his hometown of Rosh Haayin and asked fellow Israelis to end Netanyahu's long reign as prime minister.

"We will bring hope, we will bring change, without corruption, without extremism," he said.

There was plenty of drama as Israelis made their way to the polls. Police reported at least 29 arrests and 69 investigations were launched against individuals suspected of voting fraud and other violations. Voting slips were vandalized, several people illegally filmed inside the voting booths, and one man cut the power at a polling site and stole several voting slips. One suspect even threw a firework outside a polling station outside Jerusalem.

Israeli media also reported that the Blue and White website was shut down due to a cyberattack hours before polls closed. The party said the "significant cyberattack" was carried out in a wide-scale operation.

"Over 500 attempted breaches were detected from various servers abroad," the party said.

Both Likud and Blue and White are cautious not to celebrate any perceived victory too early. Party leaders are waiting for the final vote to be counted. Official results will only come out in the next week, and forming a government can take another month or more after that. If no government is formed, Israelis will go to a third round of elections. For now, Israelis are waiting to see if a government is formed and what it will look like.

Title: Beijing Wins 2022 Winter Olympics in Low-Key Manner

Article:

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has awarded the 2022 Winter Games to Beijing, China, in a joint bid with the nearby city of Zhangjiakou. The decision was made in a 44-40 vote, with the remote Central Asian city of Almaty, Kazakhstan, being the sole rival. This makes Beijing the first city to host both the winter and summer competitions, following the 2008 Olympics.

The announcement was met with a brief celebration, contrasting the exuberant response 14 years ago when Beijing won the right to host the 2008 Summer Olympics. This time, people paused during the evening rush hour to watch the IOC announcement on television and mobile phones, but the crowd dispersed quickly.

Financial analyst Zhang Shuo, a 30-year-old with Huatai Insurance Group, expressed indifference towards the winter sports activities, citing their expense and lack of personal interest. In contrast, 14 years ago, Beijing erupted in triumph, with cars honking their horns, people waving flags, and strangers hugging.

The low-key response to the 2022 Winter Olympics win is attributed to several factors, including winter sports being less popular in China, a less aggressive publicity campaign by Beijing, and the significance of hosting a second Olympics being less freighted due to the triumphant return to the world stage that the 2008 Olympics represented.

Here is a summary of the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics:
- Beijing will be the first city to host both a Summer and Winter Games.
- The total budget is $3.9 billion, with $1.98 billion for operations and $1.92 billion for infrastructure.
- The budget does not include a new 108-mile high-speed train line linking Beijing with mountain venues.
- There are 12 venues, half of which are recycled from the 2008 Summer Games.
- The average snow depth at the alpine skiing venue in February is 5.3 inches.

China is expected to spend far beyond the official event budget, as it did for the 2008 Olympics, which brought an additional $36 billion in redevelopment, subway lines, and building bedroom communities. The games are projected to bring 350 billion yuan (approximately $56.4 billion) in investment, primarily for Zhangjiakou and the surrounding rural areas.

The 2022 Winter Olympics seem to be more focused on addressing the needs of a prosperous population eager for leisure activities, as opposed to the national ambitions that characterized the 2008 Olympics. The emerging middle class in Beijing has doubled its disposable income since 2008, and the ski resorts outside Zhangjiakou are now packed with Beijingers.

Not everyone is a fan of the winter sports, however. Amid the performers organized by the Beijing government to watch the IOC ceremony was 21-year-old subway worker Xiao Shuai, who expressed indifference towards winter sports due to their expense and accessibility.

Title: Unprecedented Political Victory for Donald Trump: A Shift in U.S. Politics and Society

Article:

In a historic turn of events, billionaire developer Donald Trump has been elected as the 45th President of the United States, marking a significant political rebellion among rural white America. This unexpected victory has overthrown the perceived dominance of the Democratic Party and challenged the predictions of political pundits.

The election results, which also secured Republican control of the House and Senate, were largely attributed to a Republican surge that went unnoticed in most polling. According to Columbia University political science professor Donald P. Green, the polls underestimated two key factors: voter discontent and the Republicans' loyalty to their party's nominee, despite the ambivalence expressed by GOP leaders.

The Trump presidency promises at least four years of a unified Washington, potentially leading to significant shifts in the nation's direction on core issues such as foreign policy, trade, immigration, health care, and the environment.

Trump's victory marks a reversal of the narrative of the past few years, as many conservative white voters have expressed despair over what they perceive as America's economic, military, and cultural decline. With Trump's election, they have emphatically turned the tables on Democratic voters.

After conceding the election, Hillary Clinton called Trump to congratulate him on a "very, very hard-fought campaign." Trump, in turn, called for national unity, pledging to be a president for all Americans and reaching out to those who did not support him for guidance and help in unifying the nation.

Trump's core supporters, primarily whites without college degrees, turned out in large numbers and supported him to an unprecedented degree. This mixed up the nation's long-standing order of electoral swing states, with Trump taking Florida, Ohio, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania.

Exurban and rural areas were the heartland of Trump's support. In areas such as Newton County, Georgia, Trump won by significant margins. Exit polls showed Trump winning 80 percent or more of voters who rated "change" as their top priority.

Al Fortune, a trucking company manager, expressed expectations for job creation, conservative healthcare reform, and energy independence from the Middle East if Trump were elected. This seems to reflect the voter who prioritizes change.

Now, it will be up to Trump to deliver on his voters' expectations. They are expecting decisive action from the new president.

In New Hampshire, lifelong resident Tyler Brouillard registered as a Republican and voted for Trump, expecting high-speed change in U.S. policies. Brouillard attributed this expectation to Trump's personality and demeanor.

Hillary Clinton's loss is likely to spark bitter recriminations among Democrats, with the liberal faction, personified by Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, pushing for radical change in the party agenda.

Trump's victory represents a major change in GOP identity, focusing unabashedly on white Americans, contrary to the desires of party leadership, and rejecting mainstream Republican principles such as free trade. While this strategy won Trump the White House in 2016, the changing demographics of the U.S., with a fast-growing Hispanic population and a declining percentage of whites, may challenge the approach in coming years.

"It's not a good strategy in the long-term," noted Matthew Wilson, an associate professor of political science at Southern Methodist University, as Trump's victory hung in the balance.

Title: Georgia and Virginia Loosen Gun Laws, See Decrease in Violent Crime, While Chicago Experiences Increase

Article:

In a stark contrast to Chicago's recent surge in gun violence, states like Georgia and Virginia have been relaxing their gun control laws, with Georgia signing a bill this week to allow law-abiding residents to carry guns into taverns, churches, schools, and government buildings under certain circumstances. This move follows Virginia's decision four years ago to abolish its ban on guns in bars, which has reportedly led to a 5% decrease in violent crime at drinking establishments.

Chicago, known for some of the nation's toughest gun laws, has seen a spike in gun violence over the Easter weekend, with 40 persons shot, nine of whom fatally. Despite Chicago Police Superintendent Garry McCarthy's claim that the city's declining homicide tally is "still ahead of where we were last year," with 415 homicides in 2013, down 18% from the year before, critics argue that the city's strict gun laws are ineffective.

In 2010, the U.S. Supreme Court declared Chicago's 28-year-old handgun ban unconstitutional. A ban on gun sales was overturned in February, making Illinois the 50th state to enable residents to carry concealed weapons. However, the City Council and the Illinois legislature continue to discourage law-abiding citizens from defending themselves.

Georgia Governor Nathan Deal, a Republican, defends the new law, stating, "This bill respects the rights of private-property owners, who still set the rules for their land and their buildings." Opponents of the expansion of gun rights predict that the Georgia law will lead to increased violence, but evidence from Virginia suggests otherwise.

In Virginia, when the Richmond Times-Dispatch investigated crimes committed by concealed-carry permit holders, it could only find one instance of a randy man with such a permit who had propositioned a waitress. Despite strict gun control measures, Washington D.C. counted 103 homicides in 2019, while Fairfax County, Alexandria, and Arlington County in Virginia reported eight, five, and zero homicides, respectively.

Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who has been criticized for his handling of gun violence in the city, may want to consider adopting Georgia and Virginia's approach to gun laws, as their relaxation seems to have led to a decrease in violent crime.

Title: Government Shutdown Likely as Bipartisan Agreement Remains Elusive

Article:

The United States federal government is on the brink of a shutdown, with no clear solution in sight. The House-passed bill, which failed to secure the necessary support, has left the government with less than twelve hours before a potential shutdown. As of Friday, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and his Democratic counterpart, Chuck Schumer, have yet to discuss a plan B.

The most probable outcome at this point is a government shutdown, marking the first such occurrence since 2013. The impasse stems from a disagreement over the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which shields undocumented children of immigrants from deportation. Democrats have demanded that any legislation addressing government funding also address DACA, while Republicans, led by President Donald Trump, have refused to link the two issues.

Given the current dynamics, a short-term continuing resolution, providing only a temporary reprieve from a shutdown, seems unlikely to resolve the issue. The time crunch and the need to pass the bill through both the House and the Senate before midnight make this option challenging.

Democrats, who view DACA as their primary leverage, are reluctant to compromise. They believe they will bear the political advantage in the event of a shutdown, as the average American may question why the GOP, controlling the House, Senate, and White House, cannot maintain government operations. Additionally, Democratic lawmakers, particularly those eyeing the 2020 presidential race, must cater to their liberal base, which demands opposition to President Trump at all times.

Republicans, led by McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan, are in a more compromising position due to the historical precedent of shutdowns not favoring their side if a deal is not reached by the deadline. The unpredictability of President Trump, as demonstrated by his Twitter activity, further complicates the process of negotiating and finalizing a deal.

As the deadline approaches, both parties are shifting their focus from finding a solution to avert a shutdown to preparing for the political fallout that may ensue. The White House's decision to hold a press briefing, featuring Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney, suggests a pivot toward positioning for a likely shutdown. Momentum, a crucial factor in last-minute crises, currently favors a shutdown, with no obvious solution or interest in finding one on either side of the aisle.

Title: Lawmakers, Aides Discuss Early Retirement Due to Obamacare Premium Hikes

Article:

Dozens of lawmakers and their aides are considering early retirement or resignation due to fears that their health insurance premiums will significantly increase next year as a result of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The concern stems from a provision in the health care law that will transition lawmakers and their staff onto the government health care exchanges, which could make their benefits excessively expensive due to the potential disappearance of government-subsidized premiums at the end of the year.

Democratic and Republican leaders are taking the issue seriously, but they are awaiting more specific guidance from the Office of Personnel Management on how the new rule should be implemented. Sources expect a decision by fall at the latest. The administration has remained silent on the matter in anticipation of a ruling.

If the issue remains unresolved, and a large number of lawmakers and aides choose to leave, there is a concern that this could lead to a "brain drain" as Congress tackles critical issues such as tax code reform and immigration reform. The problem is particularly acute in the House, where lawmakers and aides are generally younger and less wealthy. Several aides have already given notice that they will be leaving due to concerns about Obamacare.

Rep. John Larson (D-CT), a Connecticut Democrat in leadership when the law was passed, believes the problem will be resolved. "If not, I think we should begin an immediate amicus brief to say, 'Listen, this is simply not fair to these employees,'" Larson told ███. "They are federal employees."

Republicans, who have been critical of the Democratic health care reform, are more vocal about the potential negative effects of the provision. Rep. Pete Sessions (R-TX) stated, "It's a reality. This is the law.... It's going to hinder our ability with retention of members, it's going to hinder our ability for members to take care of their families." Sessions added that lawmakers are having "quiet conversations" about the threat.

Alabama Rep. Jo Bonner noted that the threat is already real, especially for veteran lawmakers and staff. If they leave this year, they believe they can continue to be covered under the current health care plan. "I've lost one staffer who told me in confidence that he had been here for a number of years and the thought of losing the opportunity to keep his health insurance on Dec. 31 [forced him to leave]," said Bonner, who had already planned his resignation from Congress. "And then I've got another staff member that I think it will be a factor as she's contemplating her future."

The Affordable Care Act, signed into law in 2010, contains a provision known as the Grassley Amendment. This provision states that the government can only offer members of Congress and their staff plans that are "created" in the bill or "offered through an exchange" unless the bill is amended. Currently, aides and lawmakers receive their health care under the Federal Employee Health Benefits Program, which is subsidized by the government up to 75 percent of the premiums for the health insurance plans. In 2014, most Capitol Hill aides and lawmakers are expected to be put onto the exchanges, and there has been no guidance on whether the government will subsidize those premiums, which is expected to cause a steep increase in health insurance costs.

Title: Conservative Group Criticizes McConnell for Fiscal Cliff Deal Negotiations

Article:

A conservative advocacy group, ForAmerica, is targeting Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell with a series of online ads in his home state, criticizing him for his role in negotiating the fiscal cliff deal. Brent Bozell, president of ForAmerica, stated, "It's a statement we're making, and I suspect there will be more statements that are going to be coming out. It is a statement to make it emphatically clear that what the minority leader did was 100 percent unacceptable. Conservatives are going to hold him responsible for this."

The ads, with the headline "Mitch McConnell: Whose side are you on?", feature an image of a morose McConnell sandwiched between pictures of a smiling Vice President Joe Biden and a smirking President Barack Obama. The ad buy is reportedly a "five-figure" amount and will be distributed through Google display ads and Facebook in Kentucky, as well as run on The Daily Caller and Drudge Report in Washington.

McConnell is up for reelection in 2014 and is aiming to fend off a potential conservative primary challenge. After fiscal cliff negotiations between House Speaker John Boehner and Obama broke down, McConnell and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) took over negotiations. McConnell called in Vice President Biden at the final minute when negotiations reached an impasse, and the McConnell-Biden framework became the basis for the deal.

Bozell, who vocally opposed the fiscal cliff deal that involved tax increases, made clear that his criticism is directed at McConnell for signing off on the deal. "When Republicans agree to do what they did agree to do, then they are just as much tax-and-spend Democrats as Democrats are," Bozell said. "Do I have any confidence that Republicans will stand by [McConnell's] statements a couple of days ago that the talk about tax increases are over? None," Bozell said. "It is a fluid situation. There are some serious battles coming up. I'm not writing off anything. If Republicans find their mojo and rediscovered their soul and try to do the right thing, we'll support them, but they just can't count on us anymore."

Title: Pennsylvania Voters Declare Hillary Clinton the Winner in Presidential Debate, Remain Pessimistic About Choices

Article:

In a focus group of undecided voters in the battleground state of Pennsylvania, Hillary Clinton was declared the clear winner of the first presidential debate, but the participants expressed deep pessimism about their choices in November. The group, selected and paid to participate in a focus group conducted by Republican pollster Frank Luntz in Philadelphia on Monday, described Clinton as "liar," "corrupt," "secretive," and "self-centered." Trump was labeled "scary," "fake," an "egomaniac," and a "shape-shifter."

The debate was watched from a room inside the National Constitution Center while Luntz's team tracked the voters' snap reactions throughout the 90-minute debate. At the end of the debate, 16 of the 27 participants agreed that Clinton had won, while just six believed Trump had won. In near uniformity, the voters said the outcome of the debate was the result of Trump's failure rather than Clinton's success.

When asked to react to their performances, the voters offered that Trump's was "strong start, weak finish," "bombastic," "sloppy," and "verbose." When asked to respond to Clinton's performance, the answers were markedly positive: "firm," "powerful," "strong," and "informed."

Trump struggled to defend himself against attacks by Clinton over his denigration of women, insensitivity on race relations, and an assertion that he avoided paying federal taxes for years. The freewheeling Republican nominee repeatedly interrupted Clinton and drew sardonic laughs from both the audience in New York and the voters in Pennsylvania, when he claimed to have a "winning temperament."

Clinton wove the so-called birtherism issue into a larger narrative, accusing Trump of having "a long record of engaging in racist behavior." As she spoke, many of the voters in the room agreed with her, especially among those already leaning towards her. After the debate, the voters lamented that too much time was spent discussing birtherism. Overall, the voters rated Clinton's response on issues of race higher than Trump's, and after the debate, several people flatly labeled the Republican nominee a racist.

The group included women and men who were reluctant to support either candidate, including a lifelong conservative voter who would rather sit out than vote for Trump, a millennial who supported Bernie Sanders in the primary but has been persuaded by Clinton, and a middle school teacher who says Trump "lost" her when he began denigrating Muslims.

Some left the first debate impossibly conflicted and even more pessimistic than when they arrived. "Hillary Clinton is not a good candidate and Donald Trump is just a despicable person," Nicole Gerson, an attorney in Philadelphia, reflected after the debate. She said Trump's criticism of Clinton steered her away from the Democrat but not in his direction. "I'm actually thinking of voting for Gary Johnson," she said, naming the Libertarian candidate. "Maybe the third party will finally become more viable so we're not left with such extreme candidates. It's a vote for the future."

Title: Study Finds Facebook's Fact-Checking Efforts May Have Worsened Misinformation Problem

Article:

A new study from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) suggests that Facebook's efforts to combat fake news may have inadvertently worsened the problem. The study, which involved over 6,000 participants, found that the platform's use of fact-checking tags to flag inaccurate content may have led people to assume that unmarked content is accurate.

David Rand, one of the authors of the report and a professor at the MIT Sloan School of Management, explained, "Putting a warning on some content is going to make you think, to some extent, that all of the other content without the warning might have been checked and verified."

The study, dubbed the "implied truth effect," suggests that the sheer scale of Facebook's platform, which has 1.25 billion daily users, and the amount of content posted on it, makes it impossible for fact-checkers to keep up.

The MIT team conducted studies with participants who were shown a variety of real and fake news headlines as they would appear on Facebook. One half of the group was shown stories without fact-checking tags of any sort, while the other half was shown a typical Facebook feed comprising a mixture of marked and unmarked posts. Participants were then asked if they believed the headlines were accurate.

The results found that the use of "false" tags that are used to flag inaccurate content did significantly reduce participants' willingness to share fake stories from 29.2% to 16.1%. However, the study also found that unmarked false stories were believed to be true and shared 36.2% of the time.

Over one-fifth of the study's participants said they believed that the unmarked posts had already been fact-checked.

Rand, an unpaid advisor to Facebook's efforts to combat fake news, suggests one obvious fix is to employ more fact-checkers so that all news content posted to Facebook is checked. He also suggests that ordinary Facebook users could be recruited to do this work.

While many people assume that allowing Facebook users to do this work would make the situation much worse, given the partisan nature of content already on the site, Rand's research has found the opposite. In fact, this is something Facebook is already considering. In December, it announced it would be hiring some part-time "community reviewers" who will help corroborate or debunk content flagged by the company's automated systems. Facebook did not respond to questions about the study's findings.

Rand suggests a potential solution is to put verification panels on content that fact-checkers find to be true, eliminating any ambiguity. "If you see a story without a label, you know it simply hasn't been checked," he said.

Title: Trump Announces Three Potential Vice Presidential Picks Ahead of Republican National Convention

Article:

In a series of events on Monday, former President Donald Trump named three Republican politicians as potential vice-presidential picks for the party's national convention later this month in Cleveland. The named individuals are first-term Iowa Senator Joni Ernst, first-term Arkansas Senator Tom Cotton, and Governor of Indiana, Mike Pence.

Trump spent time with Pence and his family on Sunday and was due to meet Ernst in New Jersey on Monday. Ernst, endorsed by the Tea Party, won her Senate seat in 2014 with an ad featuring her background of growing up "castrating hogs on an Iowa farm" and her promise to "know how to cut pork" in Washington. In 2015, she delivered the Republican response to Barack Obama's State of the Union address.

Cotton, 39, has not been as often named among potential Trump's vice-presidential picks as Pence and Ernst. In his tweet, Trump praised Cotton for his performance on "Meet the Press" on Sunday, stating that despite a one-sided interview by Chuck Todd, the end result was "solid."

Cotton gave little away in his NBC interview, saying Trump could "make the case for himself" as to why he should be president. He was more forthright in attacking Hillary Clinton, who he said had been "responsible for many of the worst decisions of the Obama administration."

Trump's note of complaint about Todd's questioning echoed another tweet sent on Monday, in which he blamed the "dishonest media" for a furor over a tweet he sent and then deleted on Saturday, which showed Clinton next to a six-pointed star against a background of dollar bills, prompting accusations of antisemitism. The image was later found by reporters on a white supremacist message board, in a post predating Trump's tweet.

Newt Gingrich, who has repeatedly said he is open to being Trump's vice-presidential pick, may yet be considered too forthright. Last week, in words that echoed strongly on Monday in the controversy over Trump's Clinton tweet, he told an audience at the Aspen Ideas Festival: "Trump's job is, frankly, to quit screwing up and get the election down to three or four big issues."

The New Jersey governor, Chris Christie, and Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama have also been reported to be under consideration. Trump has said the pick will likely be announced at the convention in Cleveland, which starts on 18 July, but some sources suggest he may announce sooner to help drum up excitement.

As evidence of his management of a process which generates relatively positive publicity, Trump also tweeted on Monday: "The only people who are not interested in being the VP pick are the people who have not been asked!"
