Many of the Republican party's biggest names are not willing to appear at the convention. The former presidents George HW Bush and George W Bush; the 2012 presidential nominee, Mitt Romney; and the Ohio governor, John Kasich, all plan to avoid the four-day event.

Possible speakers include the former Indiana basketball coach Bobby Knight, the New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, and the boxing promoter Don King. "I'm going to be involved, definitely," King, who lives in Cleveland, told the Associated Press. "He's my man. I love him. He's going to be the next president."

Some celebrities backing Trump have, however, passed on the convention. The Super Bowl-winning Chicago Bears coach Mike Ditka told the Chicago Tribune last week: "I spoke with Mr. Trump this afternoon, and he invited me. But I don't think I'm going to go."

Trump's campaign has also been in touch with aides to the man who challenged him most strongly in the primary, the Texas senator Ted Cruz, who has reportedly been trying to win a speaking slot. Others under consideration include the former United Nations ambassador and sometime presidential hopeful John Bolton, the West Virginia senator Shelley Moore Capito, and the Washington representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers.

Gingrich, a likely convention speaker who also spoke to the AP, said Trump "understands that if he can appeal to consumer America, he drowns political America." He also recalled a recent conversation with a Trump family member who confidently told him: "We know how to do conventions."

Title: White House Tensions Rise as 'Saturday Night Live' Spicer Skit Draws Criticism

Article:

The portrayal of White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer in a recent 'Saturday Night Live' sketch has reportedly caused discomfort within the White House, with President Donald Trump and his team finding the gum-chomping, super soaker-wielding caricature of Spicer by actress Melissa McCarthy particularly problematic.

Sources close to the president have stated that Spicer's portrayal by a woman was most troubling for Trump, as it was seen as an unflattering send-up by a female comedian that could negatively impact Spicer's longevity in the high-profile role. The White House's discomfort was reportedly evident in Trump's uncharacteristic silence on Twitter over the weekend regarding the sketch.

Sean Spicer, for his part, attempted to downplay the impact of the sketch during an interview with Extra, joking about McCarthy's gum-chewing and suggesting that the attention from the sketch had helped him achieve a new level of fame.

However, Spicer's allies are reportedly trying to put a positive spin on the incident, with one person close to Spicer stating, "He takes the job seriously but does not take himself that seriously." This person also noted that the instant-viral skit had helped Spicer gain recognition.

On Tuesday, Spicer will face the press once again in the briefing room, where the 'SNL' skit is expected to be a significant topic of discussion. White House sources have suggested that Spicer will attempt to diffuse the tension with humor, as he has reportedly been on a charm offensive in recent days, reaching out to reporters to wish them happy birthdays and making self-effacing jokes during public appearances.

Spicer has been struggling to repair his troubling first impression behind the lectern, as he is still operating under a cloud created by his initial false statements about the crowd size at Trump's inauguration. Internally, people close to Trump are eager to point out that Spicer was not Trump's first choice for the high-profile position of press secretary, but that Chief of Staff Reince Priebus pushed for Spicer to get the job.

Spicer has taken the role seriously, participating in mock briefing sessions during the transition to prepare for his on-camera performances. Since January 20, Spicer has had the added difficulty of doing two jobs at once: acting as communications director in addition to his role as press secretary, while the administration seeks to fill the former position. Senior White House officials Kellyanne Conway and Hope Hicks still attend the daily briefings and sit on the side to watch Spicer, a move some interpreted as a sign that Spicer still needs supervision.

The 'SNL' clip was seen by some in Trump's orbit as devastating because it was considered an accurate portrayal of Spicer. One Trump ally stated, "I thought they had Sean down pretty good." This individual also believed that Spicer had been set up in an impossible position.

In a phone interview on Monday afternoon, Spicer attempted to distance himself from the skit, stating, "I would much rather have the focus be on the president's agenda and the success he's having." When pressed about his own reaction to the skit, Spicer demurred, stating, "It doesn't really matter what I think."

Title: House Speaker John Boehner's Struggle with Hard-Line Faction in Government Shutdown

Article:

The ongoing government shutdown and its causes can be traced back to the influence of a group of approximately 30 hard-line House Republican members and their relationship with Speaker John Boehner.

In mid-September, Boehner stated, "We have a diverse caucus," referring to the 233 members of the House Republican caucus, each with their individual plans. "It's tough to get them on the same track. We got there." Boehner's original plan for a temporary government funding bill was abandoned due to the hard-liners' insistence on a more aggressive approach to defunding the Affordable Care Act.

The following day, Boehner held a rally in the Capitol, celebrating a government funding bill's passage that also defunded the health care law. Iowa Republican Rep. Steve King, who was present at the rally, commented, "I think the speaker is stronger today than he was yesterday. And he was stronger yesterday than he was the day before. If we continue in that direction, we're going to be in pretty good shape."

Despite their constituents' conservative leanings, the hard-liners, who predominantly occupy safe seats in deep-red districts, face minimal pressure from their constituents. Florida Republican Rep. Ted Yoho, a freshman, stated, "I come from a very conservative area, and my constituents are saying, 'Don't blink, don't cave in, don't back up.'"

The question on everyone's mind in Washington is whether Boehner will ultimately bring up a "clean CR" – a short-term spending bill that the Senate passed with Obamacare funding intact. It is believed that this bill would pass easily on the House floor with a combination of Democratic and Republican votes. However, Indiana Republican Rep. Marlin Stutzman, another hard-liner, argues that passing a clean CR at this time would be detrimental to the Republican conference and weaken Boehner's negotiating ability in the future.

Boston College political scientist David Hopkins suggests that the hard-liners' actions could potentially threaten Boehner's speakership, as they do not view him as one of their own and may attempt to depose him as speaker. The hard-liners' influence is amplified due to the relatively slim Republican majority in the House, and Hopkins estimates that there are at least 50 other Republicans who do not want any daylight between themselves and the hard-liners, fearing reprisal from outside activist groups or primary challenges.

Hopkins also notes that the remaining Republicans have not discouraged the hard-liners, and the hard-liners are often portrayed as the villains in the government shutdown story, with the rest of the Republican caucus being implicated in their strategy by going along with it. As long as the rest of the caucus continues to support the hard-liners, there is no reason to expect Boehner to deviate from their stance.

Title: Freedom Caucus Threatens to Release Own Tax Reform Plan if White House Delays Action

Article:

House Freedom Caucus leaders, including Chairman Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) and Vice Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), have warned White House officials that the conservative group may release its own tax reform plan if the White House does not present a plan soon. In a meeting with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, and White House legislative liaison Marc Short on Thursday, Meadows and Jordan expressed their concern about the lack of action on a tax reform plan.

Meadows and Jordan delivered the message to Mnuchin, Cohn, and Short that Republicans need to release a tax plan soon, or the Freedom Caucus may put out its own legislation. The White House officials are reportedly concerned that the Freedom Caucus releasing its own plan would prevent Republicans from uniting behind one plan.

Meadows downplayed the possibility that the group would release its own legislation, stating that the White House has assured him that action is imminent. However, if the White House does not take action soon, the Freedom Caucus may release its own plan. Meadows added that every day that goes by, there is less of a chance of getting a tax reform bill passed before the end of the year.

The White House officials would prefer to avoid dealing with dissent from the Freedom Caucus. However, they are also concerned about keeping conservatives in the fold after President Trump cut a budget deal this week with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), startling his own party.

The tax reform debate is ongoing between the House and the Senate, with debates still ongoing on specifics, including whether to allow immediate business expensing and deciding how much the corporate tax rate can be lowered. Trump has repeatedly pushed for a 15 percent rate, but some of his top advisers say it is not mathematically possible.

The possibility of the Freedom Caucus going rogue on tax reform petrifies administration and Capitol Hill Republicans working on the issue. GOP leaders believe that a single, unified tax bill backed by Trump, the House, and the Senate is critical to success. The White House has been meeting weekly with House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), along with the GOP chairmen of the House and Senate tax panels, known as the Big Six.

Conservatives also want a seat at the table and are eager to see a plan and influence the text. There is a palpable fear that the Big Six will release a plan and try to jam conservatives, just as they did with health care. Meadows stated that the White House and the speaker's conversations are about making decisions and starting debates on the merits of rates and expensing models, rather than allowing the Big Six to negotiate something and then giving everyone a binary choice.

Conservatives are desperate for a win to show to constituents back home. Meadows ticked off six major tax reform questions that have not been answered, including the exact corporate tax rate and how business expensing will be handled. Meadows stated that if they cannot answer these questions, then they do not have any idea what they are doing on tax reform.

Meadows stated that there are several Freedom Caucus members crafting tax legislation. Axios reported earlier this week that one such plan would lower the corporate tax rate to 16 percent, a much more aggressive cut than the Big Six believes Congress can achieve. However, the meeting appears to have persuaded conservatives to hold off—at least for now.

Meadows stated that the only way a plan from the Freedom Caucus would be introduced is if there is inaction on behalf of the Big Six, and they are still talking about principles weeks from now. Meadows argued that there is no need for his group to drop a plan at the moment, as long as the Big Six puts out a bill and negotiates in good faith over the next few weeks. Meadows added that he is not saying that he will never put out a bill, but as long as they put out a bill and negotiate in good faith, there will be no need for a Freedom Caucus bill.

Title: California and New Jersey Primaries Yield Mixed Results for Democrats, Republicans Advance in Key Races

Article:

In the primary elections held in eight U.S. states on Tuesday, California and New Jersey emerged as key battlegrounds, with Democrats aiming to flip Republican-held seats in the upcoming midterm elections. The unique electoral system in California, where the top two vote-getters advance to the election regardless of party, raised concerns for Democrats in conservative suburbs south of Los Angeles.

In some areas, the large number of Democratic candidates risked splitting the party's vote, though the same quirk also threatened to eliminate Republican John Cox from the race for Governor. In the end, Democratic candidates managed to advance, as did Cox.

Democrats, buoyed by President Donald Trump's poor approval ratings and a string of victories in special elections, hope to gain a majority in the 435-seat U.S. House of Representatives by flipping 23 seats this fall. The party has targeted more than a dozen Republican-held seats in California and New Jersey alone.

Control of the House would likely stall much of Republican President Donald Trump's policy agenda, while ushering in a new era of committee oversight and investigation into the administration. A power shift would also lend strength to any potential effort to impeach Trump if Democrats decide grounds exist, either by virtue of the ongoing probe into Russian election interference by special counsel Robert Mueller or other reasons.

California is seen as key to the eventual outcome in November. Democrats have taken aim at 10 of the 14 House seats held by Republicans. However, strong turnouts by Republican voters in all of the districts underscore the challenges that Democrats will face in trying to win in the conservative areas that they have targeted in suburban areas near Los Angeles and Sacramento, and in the agricultural San Joaquin Valley.

The battle for a place on the final ballot was particularly dramatic in the 48th Congressional District, where voters chose Democrat Hillary Clinton over Trump in the 2016 presidential election but re-elected longtime Republican Representative Dana Rohrabacher. So many Democrats were vying to challenge Rohrabacher that they divided their party's vote. With 414 of 415 precincts reporting early Wednesday, Rohrabacher easily won a spot on the November ballot. Two Democrats, Harley Rouda and Hans Keirstead, were next, separated by fewer than 100 votes, leaving the race too close to call. About 1,000 votes behind the two Democrats was Republican Scott Baugh. If the final tally puts him ahead of them, it could set up a general election fight between Rohrabacher and his fellow Republican, ending Democrats' chances to take that seat.

In the race for Governor, Democrat Gavin Newsom's first-place finish over a field of 27 candidates was expected. However, Republican John Cox's presence as the second candidate to advance to the November ballot could color the race. Republicans hope he will spur supporters to come out and vote in greater numbers, possibly improving the party's chances in Congressional races.

In New Jersey, establishment-backed Democrats muscled past liberal challengers in key New Jersey congressional races on Tuesday, setting up contests in November that will test the question of whether more moderate candidates will fare better against Republicans in swing districts.

In southern New Jersey, where the retirement of a longtime Republican incumbent gave Democrats an opening, state Sen. Jeff Van Drew, a conservative Democrat, appeared set to prevail over left-leaning candidates frustrated by his past votes against same-sex marriage and minimum wage increases. He will face Republican Seth Grossman, a former city and county official, who emerged from a four-way contest.

In a suburban New Jersey district, former Obama official Tom Malinowski was well ahead of two Democrats backed by independent liberal groups and will take on the moderate Republican Leonard Lance in what is expected to be a competitive race. Democrats also hope to capture two other Republican-held seats in the state.

Republicans control both chambers of Congress. While Democrats need only a net total of two seats to take command of the Senate, Democratic senators must defend a bevy of seats in rural states such as Indiana, Montana, North Dakota, and West Virginia that supported Trump two years ago.

Voters on Tuesday also went to the polls to choose candidates in primaries in Iowa, Mississippi, Alabama, Montana, South Dakota, and New Mexico. A number of women won Democratic contests, continuing a trend that began earlier this year. Women will represent the party in key House races in Iowa, New Jersey, and New Mexico, based on Tuesday's results.

Title: Hagel Acknowledges Possible Ground Force Recommendation in Iraq, Obama Maintains No Change in Stance on U.S. Combat Troops

Article:

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has indicated that he may consider recommendations to deploy ground forces in Iraq to assist local forces in locating targets, contingent upon a recommendation from the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Martin Dempsey. However, Hagel emphasized that these forces would not be fighting forces, and there will be no American combat troops in Iraq or Syria.

President Obama reiterated during the G20 summit in Australia that he has not changed his mind about U.S. ground forces in Iraq. He does not plan to deploy them, and Dempsey has not advised him to send U.S. troops to fight. However, the President did not rule out the possibility of deploying ground troops in the most dire of circumstances, such as if ISIL obtained a nuclear weapon.

In an interview with CNN, Hagel declined to comment on whether any top members of the Khorasan Group have been killed by U.S. airstrikes in Syria, but stated that the group still poses a significant threat.

The seminar on national security strategy at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California, was attended by Hagel, Republican Sen. John McCain, former defense secretaries Leon Panetta and Robert Gates, and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson. The issue of a strategy to combat ISIS dominated several panel discussions.

In a blistering critique of President Barack Obama and the Pentagon, Sen. McCain stated, "No one outside the Joint Chiefs of Staff believes we have a strategy" to defeat and degrade ISIS, as set forth by the administration. Former defense secretaries Panetta and Gates have recently published books that criticize Obama. In his remarks, Gates likened Obama to President Lyndon B. Johnson in what he called "micromanagement" of military policy and targeting during the Vietnam War. Jeh Johnson stated that the potential for a lone wolf attack inspired by ISIS was a primary concern.

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Announces Impeachment Resolution for President Trump, Contrary to House Leadership's Position

Article:

Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) has announced her plans to file a resolution to impeach President Donald Trump, a move that breaks ranks with House leadership. On Wednesday, Tlaib, a freshman progressive, made the "emergency" announcement surrounded by a group of supporters who wore shirts and held signs with statements such as "He's a Racist" and "#TimeToImpeach."

Tlaib stated, "We want to be able to work on these economic justice issues, racial justice issues, and everything. But guess what? There is a wall there, and a constitutional crisis that is not going to be able to have us be able to do our jobs as American Congress members to push a lot of these agendas forward." She argued that the last election was a calling, and the American people wanted to elect the jury that would begin the impeachment proceedings against Trump.

In an attempt to maintain party unity, Tlaib argued that her party agrees the president needs to be impeached. "This is not to say that we disagree. I think that every single colleague of mine agrees there are impeachable offenses. That's one thing we all agree on," Tlaib continued. "We may disagree on the pace. We may disagree that we have to wait on certain hearings, but at the same time, I think they all know the dangers of allowing President Trump to continue to violate our United States Constitution."

Demonstrators went to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office to push for her support. Tlaib's decision to file the motion is contrary to the desire of Pelosi and other senior Democrat leaders. The Washington Examiner reports that Democrat Caucus Chair, Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY), called the announcement "premature."

Speaker Pelosi has continually pushed back on the notion that the Democrats' priority is impeachment. Party leaders maintain they're waiting to hear from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 election before making their final decision.

"When the facts are known, then we can make a judgment," Pelosi said last week according to Fox News. In a February interview with Rolling Stone Magazine, Pelosi shared her concerns about impeachment, finding the process to be "disruptive" to the nation.

Tlaib's move comes at a divisive time in the Democrat Party, as House Democrats attempt to establish a measure addressing recent anti-Semitic remarks from freshman Democrats Rep. Ilhan Omar and Rep. Tlaib. Senior leaders want to maintain Jewish support; however, the newer House members want the measure to include protections from Islamophobia.

Rep. Tlaib faces her own turmoil as she stands accused of breaking campaign rules. Fox News reports Tlaib is under questioning for campaign records that reveal she paid herself $17,500 after the midterm elections. The FEC rules no one can receive salary payments "beyond the date he or she is no longer a candidate."

After making the public impeachment announcement from Capitol Hill, Rep. Tlaib took to Twitter to announce the resolution would be introduced later this month. "Today, I announced that later this month, I will be introducing a resolution to have the Judiciary Committee move on investigating grounds for impeachment," Tlaib wrote. "Our democracy must be protected."

Title: Immigration Reform Returns to Forefront as GOP Responds to Record Hispanic Voter Turnout

Article:

Top Republicans have signaled a renewed interest in immigration reform, a shift that has not been seen in five years. This sudden focus on immigration, which has been on the legislative back burner for years, highlights the concern among Republicans about the potential loss of Latino voters.

The possibility of enacting a comprehensive overhaul remains uncertain due to deep-rooted opposition within the GOP to creating a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. However, the renewed focus on the issue suggests a significant change in the Republican party's approach, a shift that was not anticipated even a few months ago.

Kansas Sen. Jerry Moran, who is running for the National Republican Senatorial Committee chairmanship, stated, "It's clear to me, if Republicans are going to have the opportunity to be in the majority, we clearly have to determine how we deal with minority and Latino voters. In some fashion, the way we have dealt with immigration gives us a black eye. And we need to figure out how to talk about issues and pursue policies that matter to Latino, Hispanic voters."

Republicans are not the only ones under pressure. Latino leaders expect President Barack Obama to deliver on a promise he failed to fulfill in his first term. Eliseo Medina, secretary-treasurer of the Service Employees International Union and a leader of Latino mobilization in battleground states, said, "The Latino giant is wide awake, cranky and taking names."

President Obama is expected to pursue a broad immigration reform proposal early next year, according to Democratic officials. Obama had promised to introduce a comprehensive immigration reform bill during his first year in office but did not follow through due to a lack of Republican support. Facing pressure from the Latino community to show progress on the issue, Obama took executive action last summer to allow certain young immigrants to stay in the country.

Vice President Joe Biden expressed optimism about immigration reform, stating, "I feel very optimistic about, in my view, immigration reform."

Title: White House Withholds Email Regarding Susan Rice's Benghazi Talking Points, Citing Non-Relation to Attack

Article:

The White House admitted on Wednesday that it withheld an email from Congress and the media regarding Susan Rice's "talking points" about the terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, because the memo did not deal directly with the attack.

White House press secretary Jay Carney stated, "This document was explicitly not about Benghazi, but about the general dynamic in the Muslim world at the time."

A government watchdog group obtained an email this week that reveals direct White House involvement in shaping the administration's message about the September 11, 2012, attacks in Benghazi, which resulted in the death of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

The internal email, sent on September 14, 2012, was from Ben Rhodes, President Obama's assistant and deputy national security adviser, to White House press officials. In the email, Mr. Rhodes listed as a "goal" the White House's desire "To underscore that these protests are rooted in an Internet video, and not a broader failure or policy."

The email, titled "RE: PREP CALL with Susan, Saturday at 4:00 pm ET," covered White House involvement in preparing Rice, then-U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, for her upcoming appearance on Sunday television talk shows.

The email and others provide the clearest evidence to date that top presidential aides sought to use anti-American protests sweeping across the Middle East in 2012—as well as the aftermath of the Benghazi terrorist attack—to project an image of President Obama's foreign policy as "steady and statesmanlike," just weeks before his re-election.

Mr. Carney stated that the White House withheld the Rhodes memo from congressional and media inquiries because "it was explicitly not about Benghazi."

"The overall issue of unrest in the Muslim world and the danger posed by these protests... was very much a topic in the news," Mr. Carney said. At the time, protests in Egypt and elsewhere were directed at the U.S. over an anti-Muslim video produced in America.

Under the heading "Goals" for Rice's appearance on five Sunday talk shows, Mr. Rhodes wrote to other White House communications officials that a main objective of Rice's interviews should be to "reinforce the president and the administration's strength and steadiness in dealing with difficult challenges."

A second goal was to link the Benghazi attack—and those on other diplomatic sites across the Middle East—to an obscure anti-Muslim video and to insist that the protests were not "rooted" in a "broader failure of [administration] policy."

Title: Unemployment Claims Reach 17 Million in Three Weeks; Senate Republicans Push for Small Business Aid

Article:

In a span of three weeks, nearly 17 million Americans have filed for unemployment benefits. In California this week, a long line of individuals waited in the rain for food, a scene repeated in other states. Many states are struggling to keep up with the influx of unemployment requests.

"How long it takes will vary by states," said Secretary of Labor Eugene Scalia. In Washington on Thursday, Senate Republicans pushed for an additional $250 billion to help small businesses in dire need.

"We need more funding, and we need it fast," said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R) during a speech on the floor. However, Democrats blocked the aid, demanding a $500 billion bill to offer more to health care providers and state and local governments.

"This was in fact, designed to fail, designed as a political stunt," argued Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) from the Senate floor.

There is now fear the unemployment rate could hit 15% soon, and White House officials, eager to stave off a severe recession, say companies in certain parts of the country that are free from outbreaks could reopen in May. However, the decision to restart the economy is largely out of the federal government's hands as many governors have issued stay-at-home orders through the end of May or later.

"We're at the top of the hill. Pretty sure we're at the top of the hill, and now we're going downward. In some cases, we've already started that process," said President Trump Thursday during his daily coronavirus briefing from the White House briefing room.

Health officials say social isolation methods are working. Dr. Anthony Fauci now predicts the American death toll will be 60,000, which is down from the earlier, more dire, predictions of 100,000 to 240,000.

"We have to be prepared that when the infections start to rear their heads again that we have in place a very aggressive and effective way to identify, isolate, contact, trace," Dr. Fauci told CBS News.

Meanwhile, a bipartisan group of senators is calling on China to immediately close all wet markets where fresh meat and produce is sold in unsanitary conditions. This comes after the director of the Chinese CDC admitted, "The origin of the new coronavirus is the wildlife sold illegally in a Wuhan seafood market."

Title: Obama Vows to Take Executive Action on Immigration Despite Congressional Opposition

Article:

President Barack Obama, during a diplomatic trip to Asia, reaffirmed his commitment to taking executive action on immigration reform, despite opposition from Congress. At a joint news conference with Myanmar dissident leader Aung San Suu Kyi, Obama stated that Congress has the ability to address the issue, but not the power to expect the system to remain broken indefinitely.

Obama emphasized that the immigration issue has been stalled for over a decade and that he intends to act before the end of the year on proposals that may include extending amnesty and work permits to potentially millions of illegal immigrants. The president noted that he had given the House over a year to at least give a vote on the Senate bill, but they failed to do so.

Republicans have threatened that Obama's decision to act will lead to an adversarial relationship with Congress. House Speaker John Boehner stated that if the president continues down this path, Republicans will fight him tooth and nail. The Washington Post reported that Boehner warned, "This is the wrong way to govern. This is exactly what the American people said on Election Day they did not want."

In response, Obama warned Republicans against an approach to governance where disagreement on a single issue becomes a deal-breaker on every issue. He stated, "Democracy cannot work that way. There will always be some differences."

The president also reiterated a previous promise that if congressional Republicans put forward a reform proposal, he will revoke any executive actions he has put into effect.

As Republicans grapple with a strategy to derail the president's plans, a rift is developing within the party about the best way forward. At least 50 conservative lawmakers are pushing to leverage the upcoming spending bill to force Obama to stand down. Their plan is to stipulate in the legislation that the president cannot act unilaterally, an approach that would likely trigger a government shutdown when the president refuses to capitulate.

The leadership has not yet developed a clear alternative other than ruling out the possibility of a shutdown. One option they are considering is to allow the executive action to take effect but work to undermine its provisions incrementally over the coming months. A lawsuit over the president's misuse of his authority is also an idea that has been floated.

According to reports, the president has not yet decided the timing for his announcement, but The New York Times reported Thursday that Obama may announce his planned action as soon as next week. Final decisions about the details of the plan have not been made, but by some accounts, a proposal may grant amnesty to as many as 5 million illegal immigrants. Officials said it could also authorize amnesty for parents of children who are U.S. citizens or legal residents and give them the right to obtain work documents.

Meanwhile, Democrats and immigration rights supporters are pushing for Obama to extend amnesty to as many migrants as possible. In recent days, they have been rallying behind the president's decision to take action, saying it is not out of step with other presidents who have acted unilaterally on major issues. The Washington Post reported.

Title: Fiscal Cliff Negotiations and the U.S. Budget Crisis

Article:

The ongoing negotiations to avert the Fiscal Cliff are generating significant political drama, but they may not resolve Washington's budget woes and could potentially lead the nation into another recession or worse. The Budget Act of 2011 mandates a nine-year $1.2 trillion deficit reduction program, or equal cuts in annual defense and non-entitlement outlays totaling $54.7 billion, set to take effect on January 1. Simultaneously, the Bush Tax cuts, the 2 percentage point payroll tax holiday, and other programs expire.

The combined annual spending reductions and additional taxes could trigger severe economic consequences, including unemployment surpassing 15 percent, state government financial collapse, homeowner mortgage defaults, and the failure of hundreds of banks. To prevent catastrophe, President Obama and House Republicans are expected to agree on raising taxes on high-income Americans by $100 to $150 billion and reducing spending by an equal amount. However, these efforts may still not be sufficient, and the economy could still slip into recession, depriving the federal government of tax revenues and further increasing the budget gap.

The federal deficit currently exceeds $1 trillion, up from $161 billion in 2007, the last year before the financial collapse. Spending has increased by approximately $1 trillion, as outlays for Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and other entitlements have increased by an amount equivalent to the entire 2013 defense budget. By the end of the decade, runaway entitlement spending will require significant cuts to the military or crippling many other domestic spending programs to prevent ballooning deficits.

The only reasonable solution to address the growing entitlement spending is to raise the Social Security retirement age to 70 and pattern U.S. healthcare reforms after other national systems that better control costs. The Germans and Dutch spend one-third less on healthcare than the United States, as their governments more aggressively regulate prices, better ration care, and spend less on lawsuits.

Democrats, constrained by unions, are reluctant to require Americans to work longer, and are too beholden to tort lawyers and the medical establishment for campaign support, resulting in ObamaCare's additional funding to a broken system rather than addressing the root causes of rising healthcare costs. Republicans refuse to acknowledge more competition as a solution, arguing that there is already sufficient competition among providers, drug and device manufacturers, and insurance companies, and that it will not adequately slow the rise in healthcare costs.

Over the next decade, without a significantly higher retirement age, effective price controls in healthcare, and tort reform, federal spending and the national debt will skyrocket. Mounting interest payments, investor reluctance to buy U.S. Treasurys, and consequent draconian cuts in spending will thrust the United States into the crisis now gripping Greece and Spain.

More immediately, even modest tax increases and spending cuts threaten a second recession, as President Obama and Congress have failed to address the dysfunctions that created the bubble and bust of the 2000s and made the economy overly dependent on deficit spending. From 2001 to 2005, the trade deficit doubled to over $700 billion, due to subsidized imports from China, restrictions on U.S. sales into the Middle Kingdom, and rising oil prices. This resulting loss of demand for U.S.-made goods and services should have instigated a recession; however, Chinese and Middle East oil exporters stepped up purchases of U.S. securities, helping finance questionable mortgages, car loans, and credit card debt. Americans spent more than they earned, and the boom continued into 2007. When homeowners and other borrowers could no longer service their debts, defaults and bankruptcies resulted, and the economy crashed.

A huge trade deficit with China and on oil continues, but now the federal government is doing the extra spending and borrowing for us. If budget negotiations reduce the deficit by $200 to $300 billion, as is likely, GDP will contract $350 to 500 billion, and unemployment will rise above 10 percent. President Obama and House Republicans indicate no interest in confronting Beijing to force a more equitable trading relationship with the Middle Kingdom. Slashing oil imports requires the President to permit more drilling in the Gulf, off the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, and in Alaska, and for Republicans to embrace alternative energy sources and more aggressive conservation measures.

In summary, absent major changes in trade and energy policies to boost domestic demand and growth, budget deficit reduction is not possible without another long, hard recession. And absent genuine deficit reduction, the country is headed for economic chaos by the end of the decade.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Abortion Access in Louisiana, but Roberts' Ruling May Signal Future Erosion of Roe v. Wade

Article:

In a 5-4 ruling announced on Monday, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a Louisiana law that required abortion providers to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, preserving the court's precedents and protecting abortion access. However, the outcome is not an unalloyed endorsement of a constitutional right to choose, as Chief Justice John Roberts' reasoning in the case, June Medical Services v. Russo, may signal a future erosion, if not outright reversal, of Roe v. Wade.

Legal writer Mark Joseph Stern, in an article for Slate, argues that the Supreme Court's ruling in June Medical Services is not as favorable to abortion rights as it may initially appear. The outcome is, indisputably, a triumph for Louisiana's three remaining clinics, which can now remain open thanks to the Supreme Court. However, Roberts' opinion itself is far from an unalloyed endorsement of a constitutional right to choose. In fact, the chief justice cut back protections for women seeking abortions and laid the groundwork for a future erosion, if not outright reversal, of Roe v. Wade.

The Supreme Court's ruling in June Medical Services is similar to its 2016 ruling in the case Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, which struck down a similar law in Texas. In Whole Woman's Health, the Court ruled that Texas' admitting privileges law imposed an 'undue burden' on the constitutional right to abortion. Since Louisiana's law is indistinguishable from Texas's, it should have been plainly unconstitutional under Whole Woman's Health. However, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals effectively defied precedent by upholding the Louisiana regulation.

Some major changes on the U.S. Supreme Court have occurred since 2016. Former Justice Anthony Kennedy, a right-wing libertarian, is no longer on the Court, which now includes two nominees of President Donald Trump: Justice Brett Kavanaugh and Justice Neil Gorsuch. The big question in June Medical was whether Roberts, who dissented in Whole Woman's Health, would nonetheless invalidate Louisiana's law on the grounds of stare decisis, or respect for precedent. And that's exactly what Roberts did—with a catch. The Court actually splintered 4-1-4: Justice Stephen Breyer wrote for the four liberals, the chief justice wrote an opinion concurring in the judgment, and the four other conservatives dissented.

Although Roberts supported Breyer's bottom-line holding, he declined to join Breyer's opinion. Because the chief justice's opinion is narrower than Breyer's, it is 'controlling'—that is, it's the law of the land. Advocates on both sides of the abortion debate will thus be scrutinizing Roberts' concurrence for years to come. And it gives both sides reason for encouragement.

According to Stern, Roberts' decision in June Medical does not necessarily mean that Roe v. Wade will not be overturned at some point. In short, Roberts—alone among the conservatives—agreed with the liberals that Louisiana cannot pretend its law creates no real burden for abortion patients in the face of ample evidence that it would shutter clinics. However, the chief justice then whittled down the holding of Whole Woman's Health, replacing its balancing test with a stingier rule that may give states broader leeway to restrict abortion. Roberts expressly disavowed Breyer's test, which weighed a law's benefits to patients against its burdens.

Title: New Pass-Through Tax Loophole in GOP Tax Bill Favors Wealthy, Costs Government Billions

Article:

The new pass-through tax loophole in the recently passed Republican tax bill has come under scrutiny for its potential impact on the government's revenue and the distribution of benefits. The loophole, which allows for a 20% deduction on pass-through business income, is estimated to cost the government $414.5 billion in lost revenue over a decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation.

This figure is significant, as it is approximately 29 times the annual federal funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which covers nearly nine million children from low-income families. The program's authorization lapsed at the end of September.

The pass-through tax provision has been a point of contention, with some arguing that it was not intended to win over the vote of Senator Bob Corker, who has a real estate partnership in Tennessee. Corker, whose party can only afford to lose two votes, has become more influential in the tax bill's passage due to Senator John McCain's absence due to the aftereffects of his cancer treatment.

Republican leaders and Mr. Corker himself have stated that the provision was not inserted during conference committee negotiations as a "airdropped" measure, as Mr. Corker described it. They argue that the main purpose of the provision is to ensure that pass-through businesses are not unfairly treated compared to corporations, which will receive a significant tax cut from 35% to 21%.

President Trump has stated that the tax bill would "cost me a fortune" and that his accountants are "going crazy now." However, this claim has been labeled as "fake news" by fact-checkers. With the new loophole, the argument for this claim becoming more nonsensical.

The tax bill's generosity towards real estate titans stands in stark contrast to its stinginess towards the average wage earner. Average wage earners who would initially receive modest tax cuts would see these benefits disappear after 2025. Additionally, homeowners and others in high-cost states like California, New Jersey, and New York would see their once-substantial deductions for state and local taxes shrink to a maximum of $10,000 a year, which could potentially reduce home values.

Furthermore, the tax bill would permanently change how tax brackets are adjusted for inflation, causing more people to be pushed into higher tax brackets over time even if they received only modest raises in salary.

Title: Alternative Media Scenario: Trump's Post-Election Evolution and Media Coverage

Article:

In an alternate universe, the media's coverage of Donald Trump after his election mirrors the sympathetic treatment given to Barack Obama. President-elect Trump has shown a surprising inclusiveness in reaching out to former critics, such as Mitt Romney, Nikki Haley, and Rick Perry.

Trump has temporarily ceased his rhetorical war on the media, even engaging with The New York Times, describing the newspaper as a "jewel." The President-elect has demonstrated flexibility in reconsidering some campaign promises, abandoning his support for waterboarding, expressing an open mind on climate change, and maintaining key parts of Obamacare.

The media's portrayal of Trump's evolution has been met with mixed reactions. Some view it as a positive development, while others see it as a series of flip-flops. A Politico headline reads, "15 Trump Flip-Flops in 15 Days." The media's initial shock at Trump's victory has led to a lack of benefit of the doubt, with few expecting him to win.

One area of focus has been the disappointment on the right after the "Lock Her Up" rallies. Breitbart ran a "Broken Promise" headline, while cable news segments debate whether Hillary Clinton should be prosecuted or not. Similarly, Trump's evolving views on various issues have been either downplayed or praised, with CNN's Fareed Zakaria writing, "One might wonder why he didn't have that conversation during the campaign or why he pounded home the opposite views on all these topics for a year and a half. But at this point, it doesn't matter. Trump is president-elect. We should all hope that he flip-flops some more."

From the right, Trump critic Kathleen Parker criticizes Trump's campaign promises, labeling them as lies. However, she admits to being happier with his new positions. Trump's efforts to bring establishment Republicans into his administration have received some media credit, with the media focusing on the potential derailment of Mitt Romney's nomination as secretary of State and the controversy surrounding Nikki Haley's appointment as U.N. ambassador.

The media has also addressed questions surrounding Trump's potential conflicts of interest due to his real estate empire and the role of his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, in his administration. The New York Times ran a lengthy story on the former, while the latter's lack of government or diplomatic experience is a topic of discussion.

The media has also covered the debate over a recount in Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania, with Trump dismissing it as a "scam" and criticizing the Clinton campaign for cooperating. However, the recount will not change the inauguration's presiding party.

In conclusion, the media's coverage of Donald Trump's post-election evolution has been a subject of debate, with some viewing it as a positive development and others seeing it as a series of flip-flops. The relationship between the media and the President-elect should always be adversarial, but the media's coverage of Trump is not as sympathetic as it was for President-elect Obama.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Same-sex Marriage: Implications for Religious and LGBT Rights

Article:

In a landmark decision on Friday, the Supreme Court ruled that states cannot ban same-sex marriage, establishing a new civil right and marking a significant victory for gay and lesbian advocates. The ruling, however, has sparked concerns among religious groups, who argue that their religious freedoms may be at risk.

President Barack Obama, speaking after the ruling, acknowledged the deep-seated beliefs of those who oppose same-sex marriage. He emphasized the importance of religious freedom, stating that those beliefs should remain protected as part of the country's commitment to religious freedom.

The decision, written by Justice Anthony Kennedy, briefly acknowledged the right of faith groups to object to same-sex marriage. However, more conservative justices and several religious groups criticized the decision for not addressing the First Amendment's "free exercise" clause, which they argue encompasses not just preaching and teaching, but also the "free exercise" of faith in various activities, including religious ceremonies, charitable works, and business operations.

Justice Clarence Thomas, in his dissent, argued that the majority's nod towards religious liberty was a "weak gesture," and that the ruling could have "ruinous consequences." He suggested that conflicts between competing definitions of marriage, particularly in terms of religious ceremonies, would arise.

Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Antonin Scalia also expressed concerns about the potential impact of the ruling on religious institutions. They raised questions about the future of religious colleges, faith-based adoption agencies, and the potential loss of tax exemptions for organizations that conflict with the new right to same-sex marriage.

Archbishop William Lori of Baltimore, representing the U.S. Catholic bishops, stated that the ruling would affect "thousands" of state and local statutes across the country and could lead to "a lot of legal controversies in terms of the way we organize and run our ministries."

Evangelical groups, who make up about 25% of the country's population, have also pledged to fight the legal implications of the ruling. They expressed concerns about the potential coercion or infringement upon the rights of institutions to live by their sacred beliefs about marriage and sexuality.

The skirmish over religious and LGBT rights is expected to continue, with both sides anticipating legal battles in the coming years. The outcome remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the battle lines have been drawn, and the fight for religious and LGBT rights will likely continue to shape American society in the years to come.

Title: Grand Jury Decision in Ferguson Shooting Delayed Until Monday at the Earliest

Article:

Residents in Ferguson, Missouri, remain on edge as they await a decision from a grand jury regarding the shooting death of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old resident. The expected grand jury decision, initially anticipated as early as this weekend, has been delayed until Monday at the earliest, according to a federal law enforcement official who spoke to a media outlet on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to comment publicly on the matter.

Protesters took to the streets again Saturday evening, chanting slogans such as "No justice, no peace" and "Mike Brown means, we've got to fight back." They gathered at the Ferguson police station before moving back into the street when police in riot gear appeared. Two people were arrested for unlawful assembly, according to St. Louis County Police spokesman Brian Schellman.

Authorities have set up barricades around the building where the grand jury has been meeting, as well as in a shopping center parking lot where police established a makeshift command center following Brown's death.

Police and protesters are planning ahead. Police leaders have met five times with some protest group leaders, resulting in them agreeing to 11 rules of engagement, such as avoiding the use of excessive force and communicating to de-escalate tense situations.

President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder have called for people to temper their reactions. The president spoke during an ABC News interview, saying people who were upset should not use the grand jury's decision as "an excuse for violence." Holder urged law enforcement officials to minimize the potential for confrontations during demonstrations.

Michael Brown's father has also joined in the call for calm. In a video statement released Thursday, he said, "We are hurting... But hurting others and destroying property is not the answer."

If violence or unrest does erupt, Missouri Governor Jay Nixon will call in the National Guard. He declared a state of emergency earlier this week.

Some schools in the area are preparing for what comes next. The Jennings school district decided to close its schools on Monday and Tuesday, lengthening the Thanksgiving break for its students and avoiding having them in school during potential demonstrations.

Regardless of what happens, Darren Wilson, the officer involved in the shooting, reportedly is resigning from Ferguson's police force.

Yamiche Alcindor, a reporter for ███, is on the ground in Missouri. Follow her on Twitter for live updates.

Title: Socialist Economic Model: Allocating Capital and Addressing Social Issues

Article:

The discussion revolves around the concept of a socialist economic model, focusing on the allocation of capital and its role in addressing social issues. The objective is to create a system that strengthens equality rather than undermining it.

One proposed solution is the establishment of sectoral councils. In this model, instead of firms competing within a sector, workers from the firms elect representatives to a sectoral council. These councils would be responsible for planning the sector as a whole, with the aim of raising productivity and quality in every firm. Capital would be distributed within the sector to meet the overall plans, promoting equality and productivity.

Centralized research and development is another aspect of this model, ensuring that all sectors have access to the same resources for innovation. This approach introduces an additional layer of planning, separate from the central planning board, allowing for planning at the sectoral, regional, and firm levels.

Economist Friedrich Hayek argues that capitalism is the only system capable of revealing latent information and capacities through markets. However, the counterargument is that capitalism, under its current system, systematically hides information due to the benefits of private property and competition. Socialism, in this context, is seen as a means to share information more openly.

Hayek's argument about the capacities of capitalism is acknowledged, but it is argued that he overlooks the potential of ordinary people. The proponents of socialism argue that it is concerned not just with the capacities of entrepreneurs, but with the capacity of learners, enabling workers to develop and utilize their skills effectively.

The productivity growth in capitalism is typically around 1-2 percent, with the argument being that capitalism incentivizes higher productivity. However, it is suggested that workers, given the opportunity, could come up with ideas to improve productivity that could match or even surpass this rate. The benefits of such an approach would extend beyond productivity, proponents argue.

Title: Kobe Bryant's Helicopter Granted Special Flight Clearance Despite Bad Weather Conditions, Officials Say

Article:

The helicopter carrying Kobe Bryant, his daughter, and seven others that crashed in California on Sunday was reportedly given a special flight clearance to fly through dense fog, despite the poor weather conditions. The New York Times reported Monday, citing audio records between the pilot and Burbank Airport's air traffic control, that the helicopter was cleared to fly through fog from Orange County toward the Los Angeles area, allowing it to enter Burbank airspace.

However, a Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) official told The Times that the special clearance would have only allowed the pilot to fly around Burbank and Van Nuys but not from there onto Calabasas. The FAA official stated that a pilot is responsible for determining whether it is safe to fly in current and expected conditions, and for determining flight visibility. It would have been up to the pilot to determine that the weather was good enough to fly.

Los Angeles police Sgt. Yvette Tuning, LAPD's Air Support Division Watch commander when the crash occurred, told The Times that police helicopters don't tend to fly under such conditions. She said while the weather has been good most of the winter, she knew that police helicopters were not going to operate in the fog that overtook the Los Angeles basin.

Officials in Los Angeles said late Sunday that dense fog likely played a role in the crash. Several experts pointed to the poor flying conditions in the area and said fog will likely play a key part in the investigation, the Los Angeles Times reported.

The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner's Office announced three bodies were recovered from the scene but have not identified the remains. The Sikorsky S-76 helicopter went down in Calabasas, about 30 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles.

The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Office said in a Sunday afternoon press conference there were nine people listed on the helicopter's manifest and all were believed to be dead. Federal transportation safety investigators were on their way to the scene. Among other things, they will look at the pilot's history, the chopper's maintenance records, and the records of its owner and operator, said NTSB board member Jennifer Homendy at a news conference.

The helicopter left Santa Ana in Orange County, south of Los Angeles, shortly after 9 a.m. and circled for a time just east of Interstate 5, near Glendale. Air traffic controllers noted poor visibility around Burbank, just to the north, and Van Nuys, to the northwest. After holding up the helicopter for other aircraft, they cleared the Sikorsky S-76 to proceed north along Interstate 5 through Burbank before turning west to follow U.S Route 101, the Ventura Highway.

Shortly after 9:40 a.m., the helicopter turned again, toward the southeast, and climbed to more than 2,000 feet. It then descended and crashed into the hillside at about 1,400 feet, according to data from Flightradar24. When it struck the ground, the helicopter was flying at about 184 mph and descending at a rate of more than 4,000 feet per minute, the data showed.

Title: Maryland Representative Elijah Cummings Dies at 68

Article:

Maryland Representative Elijah E. Cummings, a powerful figure in U.S. politics, passed away on Thursday at Johns Hopkins Hospital due to complications from longstanding health challenges. He was 68 years old.

Born on January 18, 1951, Cummings, a sharecropper's son, served as the chairman of the U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Reform, where he led multiple investigations into President Donald Trump's governmental dealings. His district, which encompasses a large portion of Baltimore and well-to-do suburbs, is a black-majority constituency.

As chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, Cummings led investigations into the president's family members serving in the White House in 2019. President Trump criticized the Democrat's district as a "rodent-infested mess" where "no human being would want to live." The comments came weeks after Trump drew bipartisan condemnation for his calls for Democratic congresswomen of color to leave the U.S. "right now," and return to their "broken and crime-infested countries."

Cummings responded by stating that government officials must stop making "hateful, incendiary comments" that only serve to divide and distract the nation from its real problems, including mass shootings and white supremacy.

Cummings' political career spanned decades in Maryland politics. He rose through the ranks of the Maryland House of Delegates before winning his congressional seat in a special election in 1996 to replace former Rep. Kweisi Mfume, who left the seat to lead the NAACP.

Throughout his career, Cummings used his fiery voice to highlight the struggles and needs of inner-city residents. He was a firm believer in some much-debated approaches to help the poor and addicted, such as needle exchange programs as a way to reduce the spread of AIDS.

Cummings was an early supporter of Barack Obama's presidential bid in 2008. He chaired the Congressional Black Caucus from 2003 to 2004, employing a hard-charging, explore-every-option style to put the group in the national spotlight.

Cummings was born on January 18, 1951. In grade school, a counselor told Cummings he was too slow to learn and spoke poorly, and he would never fulfill his dream of becoming a lawyer. Despite this, Cummings proved the counselor wrong, becoming not only a lawyer but one of the most powerful orators in the Maryland House of Delegates, where he entered office in 1983. He rose to become House speaker pro tem, the first black delegate to hold the position. He would begin his comments slowly, developing his theme and raising the emotional heat until it became like a sermon from the pulpit.

Cummings noted the differences between Congress and the Maryland General Assembly, which has long been controlled by Democrats. "After coming from the state where, basically, you had a lot of people working together, it's clear that the lines are drawn here," Cummings said about a month after entering office in Washington in 1996.

Cummings chaired the Congressional Black Caucus from 2003 to 2004, employing a hard-charging, explore-every-option style to put the group in the national spotlight. He cruised to big victories in the overwhelmingly Democratic district, which had given Maryland its first black congressman in 1970 when Parren Mitchell was elected.

Title: Movement for Broad-Based Ownership Gains Momentum in U.S. Communities

Article:

A movement to address wealth inequality in the United States by promoting broad-based ownership is gaining momentum at the community level. Coalitions of civic, advocacy, city, and state leaders are embracing policies and practices that create broad-owned assets, aiming to return wealth to communities.

One model for broad-based ownership is employee ownership, where employees hold shares in a retirement trust. Employee-owned businesses pay 5 to 12 percent more in wages, have more than double the retirement accounts, and are one-fourth as likely to lay off workers compared to traditionally owned companies. Over a ten-year period, ESOP companies showed 2.5 percent higher job growth than other firms.

One successful example of employee ownership is Recology, a waste collection and recycling company in San Francisco with $800 million in revenues, entirely owned by its 3,000 employees. Nationally, there are over 7,000 companies with ESOPs, covering more than 10 million employees and collectively holding assets of nearly $1 trillion.

Other models of broad-based ownership include social enterprises, municipally owned enterprises, and B Corporations, which are profit-making firms with a professed aim of social benefit. The nation's largest banks can be key allies in promoting these job-creating models, as they are already committed to investing in low- and moderate-income communities under the 1977 Community Reinvestment Act.

The coming wave of company sales from aging baby boomer entrepreneurs presents an opportunity to shift wealth from the few to the many. At least 7 million owners of privately held businesses will reach retirement age between now and 2030. A new initiative, 50 by 50, aims to have 50 million employee owners by 2050.

Cities like New York have already allocated funds to develop worker cooperatives, such as the nation's largest worker cooperative, Cooperative Home Health Care Associates, with revenues of $60 million and over 2,300 employees. Another tool for advancing broad-based ownership is the nation's nearly 1,000 Community Development Finance Institutions (CDFIs), chartered to aid disadvantaged communities.

H.R. 2096, the Promotion and Expansion of Employee Ownership Act, would aid in spreading the development of ESOPs by providing further tax incentives for conversion and technical assistance for making the transition. Sixty-eight percent of Americans support employee ownership, and it offers greater protection against layoffs, keeps companies rooted locally over the long term, and works to spread wealth to many.

Broad-based ownership models, proven to be stable and sustainable, provide an important new strategy for reversing income inequality. As more and more cities and states develop cooperative economic models, financing of broad-based ownership is no longer on the fringe of economic debate; it's just good business. Marjorie Kelly, a Senior Fellow and Executive Vice-President of the Democracy Collaborative, is a proponent of this movement.

Title: U.S. Faces Challenges in Responding to Egypt's Political Crisis Following President Morsi's Ouster

Article:

The removal of Egypt's President Mohammed Morsi by the Egyptian military has released the United States from a delicate position it found itself in before Wednesday's events: caught between a democratically elected leader and the democratic forces seeking his removal. The US will face hard questions over how to respond to a military coup in a country that is a key Middle East partner and a major recipient of US military aid.

The days ahead are likely to remain agitated and tense in Egypt, and the US will almost certainly face criticism from Mr. Morsi's supporters, who will say the US acquiesced to the illegal removal of an elected leader who had just marked the first year of a four-year term.

The Egyptian military acted to deflect accusations that the manner in which it removed Morsi amounted to a coup. While the military suspended the Morsi-era constitution, the commander-in-chief of the Egyptian armed forces, Gen. Abdel Fatah al-Sissi, told Egyptians in a televised address Wednesday night that the chief justice of Egypt's constitutional court – and not a military leader – would fill the presidency until new presidential elections can be held. The new interim president is to be sworn in Thursday.

The military said it acted in the "public service" not just to end the country's chaotic political crisis but to implement a "roadmap to democracy" that would have the support of Egypt's political factions and foster the "reconciliation" that Morsi failed to promote, General Sissi said. Although he did not mention Morsi by name, Sissi said the president had "responded with negativity" up to the last minute to the military's demands for a resolution of the political crisis.

The Egyptian military also sought to assure the United States, in a phone call to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, that it has no interest in holding onto power. As Egypt's turmoil reached a crescendo in recent days, the US attempted to appear neutral among the dueling parties, with both the White House and the State Department emphasizing that "we don't take sides" and calling on all factions to "engage with each other" and find a nonviolent political solution to their differences.

But by Wednesday afternoon, with events in Cairo moving fast and Morsi's ouster looking likely, US officials began shifting their stance. At the State Department, spokeswoman Jen Psaki reminded reporters that democracy is about more than elections. And she spoke critically of Morsi over what she said was his failure to "take steps" to address Egyptians' concerns – even as she held her fire toward the military.

Morsi's televised speech Tuesday, in which he defiantly refused to meet protesters' demands and vowed never to step down, was a particular disappointment to the US, Ms. Psaki said. "He had the opportunity [in the speech] to lay out certain steps" to address the crisis, she said, "and he did not take the opportunity to do that."

Thousands of Egyptians celebrated publicly Wednesday night, but it was unclear what path Morsi's many supporters planned to take. Meanwhile, the US military was preparing for the worst in Egypt, dispatching part of a Marine crisis response team stationed in Spain to Sigonella, Italy, to shorten the team's distance from Egypt in case its intervention was needed. The United States also ordered the evacuation of its embassy in Cairo, news reports said.

In May, the US quietly approved the annual $1.3 billion in US military aid to Egypt, despite qualms over progress in the country's democratization process, and it seems unlikely to suspend that aid even after a coup. The Egyptian military has close ties to the Pentagon, and the emphasis Wednesday on civilian leaders and a "roadmap" to democracy appears likely to blunt any criticism in Washington.

Now that Morsi is out, the US is likely to insist that it continues to take no sides and only supports "the Egyptian people," some regional analysts say. "They'll continue trying to maintain this idea of a neutral position because they want to avoid looking like they are intervening in Egypt's politics," says James Phillips, a Middle East expert at the Heritage Foundation in Washington.

However, the US was already suffering from a perception among Egyptians opposed to Morsi and the increasingly repressive actions of his Muslim Brotherhood party that it had "tilted" in Morsi's favor, Mr. Phillips says. And he says it will take more forceful pronouncements from Washington in favor of a democratic transition – at least – to sway a public dubious of US support.

"After having given the impression that we were shoring up the Muslim Brotherhood," Phillips says, "I would welcome even an even-handed statement that indicates we are distancing ourselves from the political forces that aren't really interested in building a democracy in Egypt."

Title: Obama Administration Announces Deportation Reprieve for Young Illegal Immigrants

Article:

The Obama administration has announced a policy change that will halt the deportation of young illegal immigrants who meet certain conditions and begin granting work permits to them. The policy, which could affect as many as 800,000 individuals, is aimed at those who were brought to the United States before they turned 16, are 30 or younger, have lived in the country for at least five years, have no criminal record, and have either attended or graduated from a U.S. high school or served in the military.

The policy change is similar to the DREAM Act, a legislative proposal that has been blocked by Congress. The administration's move is seen as an attempt to address the concerns of Latino voters, who have been ambivalent about President Obama's re-election due to his failure to deliver on his promises regarding immigration reform during his first term.

However, the policy change has been met with criticism and confusion. Some argue that the administration is attempting to "checkmate" a nearly identical proposal by Republican Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, which also offers work permits to DREAMers but does not provide a pathway to citizenship. The left has been critical of the omission of a pathway to citizenship in the Rubio plan, but is supportive of the Obama administration's policy despite the lack of a pathway to citizenship as well.

Additionally, there is controversy surrounding the administration's previous statements regarding the deportation of DREAMers. In the past, the administration has claimed that it is not deporting DREAMers, instead focusing on criminal enforcement. However, this has been called into question as DREAMers and other undocumented immigrants continue to be deported.

It is unclear how the administration will implement the policy change and how many DREAMers will ultimately benefit from it. Some may be able to take advantage of the new initiative, but many may not due to the unpopularity of the DREAM Act among a wide portion of the electorate. The administration has not provided details on how it will prioritize cases or how it will handle those who do not meet all of the criteria.

In the words of former President Ronald Reagan, "Trust, but verify." The administration's record on immigration reform has been a subject of controversy and criticism, and it remains to be seen how this latest policy change will be implemented and how it will impact the lives of DREAMers.

Title: Trump Administration Weighs Paris Climate Agreement Options, Including Senate Ratification

Article:

As President Donald Trump's advisers prepare to finalize a policy on the Paris climate agreement, a new option has emerged: declaring the agreement a treaty and sending it to the Senate for potential rejection. This option could serve as a middle ground in the escalating debate between those who advocate for adhering to President Barack Obama's global warming deal and the Paris agreement's detractors, who argue that Trump would break a key campaign promise by not withdrawing from the pact.

The treaty proposal was put forth by Christopher C. Horner and Marlo Lewis Jr., senior fellows at the Competitive Enterprise Institute. Under their vision, Trump could reclassify the Paris accord as a treaty, send it to the Senate for ratification, and require a two-thirds vote for approval. Given the Republican majority in the Senate, opponents of the agreement suggest that senators would either shelve the deal or outright reject it, thereby derailing the agreement.

A briefing paper circulated among Republican senators this week stated that the deal should have been sent to Capitol Hill by Obama, but he "knew that Congress would never approve such a flawed deal, so he refused to seek the Senate's advice and consent."

Supporters of the Paris accord have their own memo drafted by lawyers in the State Department. That memo argues that sending the agreement to the Senate would result in the president giving up important powers and leaving Trump and his successors open to congressional meddling.

The Paris agreement is the primary international vehicle for addressing climate change. Obama committed the U.S. to the deal in 2015 but never submitted it for ratification, stating that it was an extension of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, which the Senate ratified in 1992.

The State Department memo asserts that there are few risks to remaining part of the Paris deal, stating that the "legal obligations are relatively few and are generally process-oriented [and] discretionary in their application or repeat existing obligations already contained in the Framework Convention."

As a decision nears, the positions among Trump's top advisers have become clear. Energy Secretary Rick Perry appears to join the "remainers," though he advocates for renegotiating the agreement. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, daughter Ivanka Trump, and the White House general counsel's office also lean toward remaining in the agreement, according to sources familiar with the negotiations.

Environmental Protection Agency chief Scott Pruitt is pushing for withdrawal, and he is joined by U.N. Ambassador Nikki R. Haley, analysts said. Top presidential strategist Stephen K. Bannon is also an advocate for withdrawal.

Exxon Mobil Corp. has written a letter urging the administration to maintain the Paris agreement, and the National Mining Association said this week, after its leaders met with Pruitt, that it will push for withdrawal, according to Politico.

The next test for the Paris accord will be in the middle of May, when finance ministers of the Group of Seven major economies meet in Italy. The heads of state meet at the end of the month. The leaders are hoping for a communique reaffirming the Paris agreement, while opponents within the U.S. are hoping to prevent that, stating it would tie Trump's hands going forward.

Title: Trump Supporter's Perspectives on Presidential Behavior and Approval Ratings

Article:

Gregory Kline, a 46-year-old lawyer from Severna Park, Maryland, and a Republican, expressed understanding for President Donald Trump's support base, despite not voting for him. Kline believes that part of Trump's appeal comes from the anger directed towards the left, particularly the media. He noted that when Muslim terrorist attacks occur, the media often seeks pundits who claim most Muslims are peaceful, but when white supremacist incidents arise, all conservatives are associated with such actions.

Kline acknowledged that people are aware of Trump's erratic behavior but choose to overlook it due to his perceived fight against perceived attacks. He stated, "It's not that people are deaf and dumb and don't see it. It's that they don't care. I've heard rational people I really respect make the craziest apologies for this president because they are sick of getting beat on and they are happy he's fighting back."

A recent Monmouth University poll indicates that 41% of Americans approve of Trump's job performance, with 61% of these approvers stating they cannot imagine Trump doing anything that would make them disapprove of him. Conversely, a similar percentage of the opposing side believes there is nothing Trump could do, other than resigning, to win their approval.

Support for Trump, however, is not absolute for many individuals. Michael Dye, a 52-year-old engineer and the treasurer for the Republican Party in Annapolis, Maryland, expressed disappointment in Trump's response to the neo-Nazi march through the University of Virginia, his alma mater. Dye, who voted for Trump reluctantly, stated, "At best it is naïve to think that the people showing up for the original protest were there simply because they were upset that this statue was being taken down."

Dye also expressed disapproval of the chant "Jews will not replace us" during the march, stating, "You can argue that it was 10% of the crowd. But there are those types in there and I've got a problem with that and I wish he'd specified that."

Title: Presidential Candidates Mobilize for Election Day as Campaigns Prepare for Voter Turnout Operations

Article:

In the final days leading up to the U.S. presidential election, both the Republican and Democratic parties are gearing up for Election Day, with each side expressing concerns about voter fraud and voting rights.

Robert Bauer, the chief counsel for President Barack Obama's campaign, stated, "The larger issue is the scale of the effort that is required to have Election Day run smoothly." He added, "Any number of things can go wrong, not by anybody's fault or intention, but we are fully prepared, and so, we believe, are election officials around the country."

On the campaign trail, both candidates presented themselves as agents of change while painting the other as an obstacle in a tight race that may hinge on the success of the campaigns' elaborate turnout operations.

At a rally in Des Moines, Iowa, President Obama scoffed at Mitt Romney's bid to claim the mantle of change, deriding him as a political quick-change artist who is repackaging the failed policies of previous Republican administrations. Speaking to 23,000 people on a high school football field in Hollywood, Florida, Mr. Obama said, "When you make this choice, part of what you're choosing is who do you trust."

Racing against the sun and the clock, both campaigns expressed confidence about their chances on Tuesday, though polls showed Mr. Obama holding a slender lead in several of the battleground states he needs to win the Electoral College.

While each covered familiar ground from New Hampshire to Ohio, Mitt Romney sought to open a new front with a rally in Pennsylvania. Tightening polls have given him hope that he can take the state from Mr. Obama, who won there by a double-digit margin in 2008. However, Mr. Obama's advisers dismissed the foray as a desperate move by a challenger running out of other paths to victory.

At a rally in Morrisville, Pennsylvania, Mr. Romney made a point of mentioning a high-profile supporter, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, whose lavish praise of Mr. Obama's leadership after Hurricane Sandy has raised Republican eyebrows. In Hollywood, Florida, Mr. Obama was endorsed by Pitbull, a Cuban-American hip-hop artist, while the Marshall Tucker Band warmed up the audience for Mr. Romney in Pennsylvania, and Stevie Wonder played "Signed, Sealed, Delivered" for Mr. Obama at a rally in Cincinnati.
