Hours earlier in New Hampshire, Mr. Obama spoke to 14,000 people beneath the gold dome of the State House in Concord on a bright, chilly day that recalled any number of days that he and other hopefuls had walked the streets in their quest for a victory in the nation's first presidential primaries. Nearby was a reminder of how the state almost dashed Mr. Obama's dreams in 2008. On a line of paving stones in front of the New Hampshire State Library are chiseled the names of winners in the state's primary, including Hillary Rodham Clinton, whose victory there halted, for a time, Mr. Obama's surge after he won the Iowa caucus.

On this Sunday, however, Mr. Obama had the fortifying presence of former President Bill Clinton, who noted approvingly in his introductory speech that Mr. Obama wanted to accomplish many of the same things that Mr. Clinton had during his two terms in office. "The test should be: What did the president do? What are the results? And compared to what?" Mr. Clinton said. "Compared to what could have happened, Barack Obama has done a good job."

Savoring the moment, his voice not yet raw from too many speeches, Mr. Clinton gleefully accused Mr. Romney of shifting his position on the bailout of the automakers so many times that he could find work as "chief contortionist in Cirque du Soleil."

Moments earlier, in Des Moines, Mr. Romney told his supporters that the clock had nearly run out on the president's time in office, and he promised to usher in a new era of economic hope for families who are struggling across the country. "Instead of building bridges, he's made the divide wider," Mr. Romney said. "Let me tell you why it is he's fallen so short of what he promised: it's because he cared more about a liberal agenda than he did about repairing the economy."

Mr. Romney led the crowd in a call and response: "I mean, do you think Obamacare created jobs? Did his war on coal, oil, and gas create jobs? Did Dodd-Frank regulations help banks make more loans? Does raising taxes put people to work?"

"No," the crowd cried out in response to each question.

Iowa was also the scene of skirmishing over voting, as Republicans on Sunday night accused Democratic operatives of encouraging older voters to illegally fill out absentee ballots for their family members. A letter to the state's top election official from the chief counsel of the Republican National Committee said that a news report of "the alleged conduct of Democratic and Obama operatives, if true, is highly disconcerting."

With the election being waged most intensely in fewer than a dozen states, the candidates seemed to be shadowboxing each other, with one arriving in a state just hours after the other left. After Iowa, Mr. Romney held rallies in Ohio and Virginia. He planned events in Florida, Virginia, Ohio, and New Hampshire on Monday.

Title: Ceasefire Between Israel and Hamas Holds, but Tensions Remain High on Gaza Border

Article:

A fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hamas, which began two days ago, remains intact despite clashes on the Gaza-Israel border on Friday. The truce, which calls for an end to Gaza rocket fire on Israel and Israeli airstrikes on Gaza, was initiated after eight days of cross-border fighting, the bloodiest between Israel and Hamas in four years.

Hundreds of Palestinians approached the border fence in several locations in southern Gaza, testing expectations that Israel would no longer enforce a 300-meter-wide no-go zone on the Palestinian side of the fence. In one incident, several dozen Palestinians, most of them young men, approached the fence, coming close to a group of Israeli soldiers standing on the other side.

In one incident captured by Associated Press video, some Palestinians briefly talked to the soldiers, while others appeared to be taunting them with chants of "God is Great" and "Morsi, Morsi," in praise of Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi, whose mediation led to the truce. At one point, a soldier shouted in Hebrew, "Go there, before I shoot you," and pointed away from the fence, toward Gaza. The soldier then dropped to one knee, assuming a firing position. Eventually, a burst of automatic fire was heard, but it was not clear whether any of the casualties were from this incident.

Gaza health official Ashraf al-Kidra said a 20-year-old man was killed and 19 people were wounded by Israeli fire near the border. Palestinian U.N. observer Riyad Mansour said Israeli forces fatally shot Anwar Abdulhadi Qudaih in the head and injured at least 19 other Palestinian civilians in a border area east of Khan Younis.

During the incidents, Hamas security tried to defuse the situation and keep the crowds away from the fence. Moussa Abu Marzouk, a top Hamas official at the ongoing negotiations in Cairo, told The Associated Press that the violence would have no effect on the ceasefire.

The crowds were mainly made up of young men but also included farmers hoping to once again farm lands in the buffer zone. Speaking by phone from the buffer zone, 19-year-old Ali Abu Taimah said he and his father were checking three acres of family land that have been fallow for several years. "When we go to our land, we are telling the occupation (Israel) that we are not afraid at all," he said.

Israel's military said roughly 300 Palestinians approached the security fence at different points, tried to damage it, and cross into Israel. Soldiers fired warning shots in the air, but after the Palestinians refused to move back, troops fired at their legs, the military said. A Palestinian infiltrated into Israel during the unrest, but was returned to Gaza, it said.

The truce allowed both Hamas and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to step back from the brink of a full-fledged war. Over eight days, Israel's aircraft carried out some 1,500 strikes on Hamas-linked targets, while Gaza fighters fired roughly the same number of rockets at Israel. The fighting killed 166 Palestinians, including scores of civilians, and six Israelis. Mansour, the Palestinian U.N. envoy, said more than 1,230 Palestinians were injured, predominantly women and children.

In Cairo, Egypt is hosting separate talks with Israeli and Hamas envoys on the next phase of the ceasefire - a new border deal for blockaded Gaza. Hamas demands an end to border restrictions, while Israel insists Hamas halt weapons smuggling to Gaza.

Mansour also accused Israel of intensifying its use of "excessive and lethal force" against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank and East Jerusalem in recent days and of arresting at least 230 Palestinian civilians since the Gaza fighting began, including several members of the Palestinian Legislative Council who were detained at dawn Friday.

The Palestinian U.N. observer called on the Security Council and the international community "to remain vigilant in their demands for a complete cessation of hostilities and for compliance by Israel." A poll Friday showed about half of Israelis think their government should have continued its Gaza offensive. The same survey showed Netanyahu's Likud Party and electoral partner Israel Beiteinu losing some support, but his hard-line bloc was still favored to form the next government after Jan. 22 elections.

Title: Debt Ceiling Fight Likely to Resume Following Budget Agreement

Article:

The recent bipartisan budget agreement, passed by the House last week and expected to be approved by the Senate this week, has alleviated the threat of a costly government shutdown. However, the looming debt ceiling fight, with its attendant risks of a U.S. government default, appears imminent.

House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R-WI) hinted at another debt ceiling standoff over the weekend, stating on Fox News Sunday, "We don't want nothing out of this debt limit. We're going to decide what it is we can accomplish out of this debt limit fight."

Ryan's stance is consistent with his previous statements, as he has long advocated for the debt ceiling as a battleground for spending cuts. During the government shutdown, Ryan argued in a Wall Street Journal op-ed and with fellow Republican House members that the debt ceiling was the appropriate venue for fiscal debates.

The White House, on the other hand, has maintained that there will be no negotiations over the debt ceiling. Press Secretary Jay Carney reiterated this position on Monday, stating, "We have not and will not change our position, nor do we expect Republicans to travel down that road again."

Given Ryan's credibility as a fiscal conservative and his ambitions for higher office, it is unlikely he will back down from this position. This places him on a collision course with the White House.

The potential for another debt ceiling standoff comes at a time when the 2014 primary season is set to begin, increasing pressure on many Republicans to vote against a clean debt ceiling bill. If the two-year budget agreement marks a brief respite from the partisan tensions in Washington, it may only signal a temporary reprieve.

Title: Protests on Immigration and Policing Disrupt Second Night of Democratic Debate

Article:

The second night of the Democratic presidential primary debate in Detroit was disrupted twice by protesters, who aimed to draw attention to immigration and policing issues.

The first interruption occurred during New Jersey Senator Cory Booker's opening statement, with a few audience members chanting, "Fire Pantaleo." The chant was a reference to Staten Island, New York, police officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was involved in the 2014 death of Eric Garner. Garner, who was African American, died after being placed in a chokehold by Pantaleo, who is white. Police had approached Garner, suspecting he was illegally selling cigarettes.

The protest seemed to be directed at New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has been criticized for not pushing for Pantaleo's dismissal, particularly after the Justice Department declined to bring criminal charges against Pantaleo on July 16. De Blasio does not legally have the power to fire Pantaleo, according to The New York Times. However, his handling of the issue has contributed to his low approval ratings from his constituents. Other city leaders say de Blasio, who often talks about race issues through the lens of having a biracial son and who touted halting "stop and frisk" during his own opening statement, needs to speak up.

New York City public advocate Jumaane Williams told The Times that the mayor needs to "do something or do not mention Eric Garner's name ever again... You cannot be president, you cannot be the Democratic nominee if Daniel Pantaleo is still on the force."

The chants grew loudest not when de Blasio spoke but during Booker's time. The former Newark, New Jersey, mayor has pressed de Blasio on the issue, and his staff tweeted during the debate that they welcomed the interruption to draw attention to the controversy, writing, "Good for you. That's how change is made."

De Blasio did later acknowledge the issue on Twitter, writing, "While I believe that respecting the process is the best way to get justice for Eric Garner's family, I recognize and identify with the pain people across this country are feeling."

Former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro weighed in from the debate stage, saying Pantaleo should be immediately removed from the NYPD. "Officer Pantaleo used a chokehold that was prohibited by NYPD," Castro said. "He knew what he was doing, that he was killing Eric Garner, and yet he has not been brought to justice."

A separate group of protesters later briefly disrupted the debate to protest former Vice President Joe Biden and the Obama administration's record on immigration. A group who identified themselves as the Cosecha Movement began chanting "3 million deportations" and unfurled a banner that read "Stop all deportations on day one."

The group says it wants a halt to all immigrant detention and deportations on the first day of a new Democratic president's term in office. It's also pushing for reunification of families separated by deportation under the Trump administration and the immediate legalization of all estimated 11 million people who live in the country illegally.

Earlier in the day, the Cosecha Movement had held a protest outside the Detroit theater and blocked traffic at the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel, which is an international border crossing between the U.S. and Canada.

Title: Millennial Candidate Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Defeats 10-Term Incumbent Joe Crowley in Democratic Primary

Article:

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a 28-year-old former Bernie Sanders volunteer, has defeated 10-term Democrat Joe Crowley in the Democratic primary for New York's 14th congressional district. Ocasio-Cortez won with 57.5% of the vote, while Crowley, who had not faced a primary challenger in 14 years, received the remaining 42.5%.

Ocasio-Cortez, a political novice and self-proclaimed socialist Democrat, ran a progressive campaign, supporting universal healthcare, tuition-free college, and criminal justice reform. She led a grassroots movement, raising more small-dollar donations than any other New York City congressional candidate.

Crowley, who was seen as a potential future Speaker of the House, conceded defeat on Tuesday night. In his concession speech, he paid tribute to Ocasio-Cortez with a rendition of Bruce Springsteen's "Born to Run."

The political left has been energized during the Trump presidency, and this upset within the Democratic Party establishment is seen as a warning shot. The liberal base's anger, stoked by heart-rending accounts of children separated from their parents at the US-Mexico border, has led to new bursts of activism, confrontation, and an anti-establishment fervor that could endanger seemingly safe Democratic politicians.

Ocasio-Cortez will now face Republican candidate Anthony Pappas in the November mid-terms. If she wins, she will become the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. The political newcomer is one of 130 women who have won primary elections for US House seats, 80% of whom are Democrats.

Ocasio-Cortez is a Bronx-born Latina, a community organizer, and educator from a working-class background. She made a viral campaign video in which she said, "Women like me are not supposed to run for office." She has a degree in economics and international relations from Boston University, but after graduation, she worked as a waitress and bartender to supplement her mother's income as a house cleaner and bus driver.

During her campaign, Ocasio-Cortez criticized Crowley for his ties to Wall Street and accused him of being out of touch with his increasingly diverse constituents. They thanked each other after the result, with Crowley saying he would support Ocasio-Cortez in the mid-terms.

Political analysts see Ocasio-Cortez's 15-percentage-point victory as the biggest political upset within a party since Republican House Majority Leader Eric Cantor lost in 2014 to a little-known right-wing professor, Dave Brat. The political left's shift towards universal healthcare and free college education will shape the coming mid-term congressional primaries, and prospective 2020 Democratic presidential candidates will certainly take note.

What are the issues that matter to you? And if you live outside the US, what would you like to know about the US mid-term elections?

Title: House of Representatives Passes Continuing Resolution to Fund Government, Excluding Obamacare

Article:

In the final days leading up to the expiration date for America's "temporary budget," the House of Representatives has passed a continuing resolution that will fund all parts of the government at sequestration levels through Dec. 15. The resolution, however, does not include funding for the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare.

The Republicans' stance on the matter is clear. If the health care law is not ready for full implementation, the American people should not be paying for it. No Republican is calling for a government shutdown, as that does not defund Obamacare. Instead, they are demanding an Obamacare shutdown.

The House has found a way to fund the government without funding Obamacare, following thousands of calls from constituents nationwide and a tumultuous August town hall recess. The Senate, however, has yet to take action on the resolution.

Critics of Obamacare argue that the law has been plagued with procedural failures and unintended consequences. To date, there have been more than 20 delays, exemptions, and revisions to Obamacare, including a delay of the employer mandate for businesses.

Public discontent for the law continues to grow. A recent FreedomWorks national poll found that an overwhelming 82 percent of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor a continuing resolution that "does not include funding for Obamacare." Only 17 percent of all voters think Obamacare will have a positive personal impact, a new low point since the law was passed in March 2010.

The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, and the Senate Democrats have been criticized for their staunch defense of the law. Obamacare disproportionately burdens the most vulnerable among us, with young Americans paying higher costs to subsidize the older and wealthier.

The House Republicans' move to defund Obamacare has garnered support from various organizations, including the Teamsters, Young Americans for Liberty, and the AFL-CIO. Even AFL-CIO President Richard L. Trumka admitted this year that "we made some mistakes" in writing Obamacare.

The debate over the continuing resolution and Obamacare funding is ongoing, with the Senate yet to take action on the House-passed resolution. The standoff between the two houses of Congress could potentially lead to a government shutdown if a resolution is not reached by the deadline.

Title: GOP Health Care Bill: A Tight Margin for Success as Republicans Seek to Replace ObamaCare

Article:

Congressional Republicans are facing a tight margin for success as they seek to replace the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare) with their own health care package. The passage of the Republican health care bill comes down to the numbers, with the GOP only able to lose 21 votes before the measure fails on a party-line vote.

The Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative Republicans, has the power to incinerate the health care measure on the floor due to a bylaw that compels its members to vote as a bloc if 80% of its 40-plus members feel the same on a given issue. This is reminiscent of the Democratic Blue Dog coalition, which was key to approving ObamaCare in 2010.

In 2010, then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., lacked the votes to pass the final version of the Affordable Care Act (ACA). She authorized the House Rules Committee to allow but two amendments before the decisive ObamaCare debate. One amendment was for a Republican health care plan, and the other was a proposal written by then-Rep. Bart Stupak, D-Mich. The "Stupak Amendment" ultimately courted the support of just enough conservative, pro-life Democrats, allowing the House to approve the first iteration of Obamacare 220-215.

The question now is how lawmakers will contour the GOP health care plan to their liking, and what amendments might the GOP brass permit. Some top GOP aides and even lawmakers spent the past few days trolling conservatives who weren't on board, privately bad-mouthing them.

House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., may not emulate Pelosi when it comes to whipping a vote, but he exuded confidence Tuesday, predicting, "We will have 218 votes. I can guarantee you." Ryan only needs 216 to approve the American Health Care Act (ACHA).

Ryan and other ACHA supporters must court members of the Freedom Caucus for their votes. Some top GOP aides and even lawmakers spent the past few days trolling conservatives who weren't on board, privately bad-mouthing them. House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Greg Walden, R-Ore., co-wrote the ObamaCare replacement bill alongside House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, R-Texas.

The margin to pass this bill could be tight. As the King sings, "It's now or never" – if Republicans are to repeal and replace ObamaCare. "Tomorrow will be too late."

Title: Republican Candidates' Stances on Iran Nuclear Agreement and Oil Fields in Iraq

Article:

In the ongoing 2016 presidential race, the Iran nuclear agreement and the potential seizure of oil fields in Iraq have become key points of debate among the Republican candidates. Donald J. Trump, a candidate with minimal foreign policy experience, recently advocated for seizing oil fields that fund extremist groups, drawing a sharp rebuke from retiring Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Ray Odierno.

Gen. Odierno, who led American troops during the worst days of the Iraq war, cautioned against the candidates' eagerness to advocate force, reminding them of the need for "sustainable outcomes" after American troops leave. A similar debate about short-term versus long-term results, and American strength or weakness, is playing out in the debate over the nuclear agreement with Iran, signed a month ago in Vienna.

All Republican candidates oppose the Iran nuclear agreement. Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has pledged to "tear up" the accord on his first day in office, a statement that often draws applause, as it does for at least five other candidates. However, scrapping the accord would, of course, free the Iranians to do the same. Some candidates are more cautious, such as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who stated he would not "abrogate the agreement on Day 1."

Almost none of the candidates have outlined what they would replace the agreement with, or how they would prevent Iran, once the deal was abandoned, from resuming a nuclear program that, by the Obama administration's own public estimates, has brought it within two or three months of "breakout," the production of one weapon's worth of highly enriched uranium.

Marco Rubio, the Florida senator, has suggested reimposing the sanctions waived by President Obama and working with Congress to impose new crushing sanctions. However, even he has skirted the question of what good reimposing those sanctions would do if America's negotiating partners—China, Russia, and three European powers—refuse to go along.

Title: Study Shows Decline of Local Newspapers Leads to Political Polarization

Article:

A new study by political scientists and communications scholars reveals a correlation between the decline of local newspapers and political polarization in the United States. The research, which examines split-ticket voting as a measure of polarization, suggests that the loss of local news contributes to voters' increased partisanship and may impact election outcomes.

The study, published in the journal Political Communication, found that voters were 1.9 percent more likely to vote for the same party for president and senator after a newspaper closed in their community, compared to voters in statistically similar areas where a newspaper did not close. This shift in voting patterns is significant, as it is often enough to decide close elections, such as the U.S. House races in Minnesota's 1st district, Utah's 4th district, and Illinois's 13th district in 2018.

The study's authors examined the most extreme examples of declining local news, including 110 newspaper closures between 2009 and 2012. These closures affected both small weeklies, such as the Clarke Courier of Virginia and the alt-weekly Boston Phoenix, as well as major metropolitan dailies like Denver's Rocky Mountain News.

The researchers considered two explanations for their findings: either people switched to national news once their local newspaper closed or they felt less informed about local politics. To test these options, they looked at "ballot roll-off," when voters leave their ballots blank for lower-level offices. If roll-off increased, that would show that people did not feel like they had enough information to vote in state elections. However, the study did not find higher roll-off after newspapers closed.

The partisan voting the study found is likely due to switching to national news rather than feeling less informed about local politics. The authors argue that local newspapers provide a valuable service to democracy by keeping readers' focus on their communities. When they lose local newspapers, readers turn to their political partisanship to inform their political choices.

The study's findings suggest that supporting local news with dollars and attention could help counteract the partisan polarization that has taken over American politics. The authors call for Americans to prioritize local news and recognize its importance in maintaining an informed and engaged citizenry.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee Report Confirms Al Qaeda Involvement in Benghazi Attack

Article:

The Senate Intelligence Committee has released a report stating that individuals linked to Al Qaeda groups were involved in the 2012 Benghazi attack, contradicting recent claims that the terror network was not a factor. The report, released on Monday, comes nearly a year after then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's controversial statement, "What difference, at this point, does it make?" during congressional questioning about the nature of the attack.

The report does not implicate Al Qaeda's "core" leadership, but it does blame some of the most influential Al Qaeda branches, including Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). The report states, "Individuals affiliated with terrorist groups, including AQIM, Ansar al-Sharia, AQAP, and the Mohammad Jamal Network, participated in the September 11, 2012, attacks."

The Senate committee report emphasizes that the intelligence suggests the attack was not "highly coordinated," but rather "opportunistic" – possibly put in place in "short order" after protests over an anti-Islam film elsewhere in the region. However, it remains unclear if any group or person exercised overall command and control of the attacks. The report also reiterates that there was no protest in Benghazi before the attack.

The report delves into the security failures leading up to the attack at the U.S. mission in Benghazi. The committee determined the attack was "preventable" and the administration failed to respond to "ample" warnings that security was deteriorating before Sept. 11, 2012. The report faults the State and Defense departments and criticizes the Obama administration for failing to "bring the attackers to justice."

The report provides details about a possible failed ambush, where attackers attempted to lure the CIA into the hospital where Ambassador Chris Stevens' body was being held.

Senate Intelligence Committee Chairwoman Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) stated, "The committee worked on a bipartisan basis to investigate the various allegations that have come out since the terrorist attacks in Benghazi in September 2012 and to get to the truth about what happened leading up to, during, and after the attacks." She hopes the report puts "conspiracy theories" to rest.

Sen. Saxby Chambliss (R-Ga.), the top Republican on the panel, also said the report provides "needed and deserved answers." He added, "In spite of the deteriorating security situation in Benghazi and ample strategic warnings, the United States Government simply did not do enough to prevent these attacks and ensure the safety of those serving in Benghazi."

Title: Iowa Democratic Caucuses: Buttigieg and Sanders in Virtual Tie, Biden and Warren Trail

Article:

In the latest results released overnight from the Iowa Democratic caucuses, former South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT) are in a virtual tie. With 97% of precincts reporting, Buttigieg has 26.2% of state delegate equivalents, while Sanders has 26.1%, a difference of just 3 out of 1,097 votes.

Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) trails with 18.2%, former Vice President Joe Biden has 15.8%, and Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) has 12.2%. No other Democratic presidential candidates broke the double-digit level in state delegate equivalents in the caucuses, which were marred by technical problems.

In the popular vote, Sanders leads with 26.5% compared to Buttigieg's 25%, translating into a difference of about 2,500 votes. Warren is also in third place in the popular vote in Iowa, getting more than 18,000 votes.

Earlier tallies of state delegate equivalents showed Buttigieg with a narrow lead over Sanders. The chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, Troy Price, said in a call with state party officials Wednesday night that full results should be released by Thursday morning, according to CNN. A person on the call also told the network that Price promised an independent review.

This report was contributed by Marty Johnson and was last updated at 7:48 a.m.

Title: New Poll Shows Biden Leading Trump in Potential 2020 Election Matchup, but Gap Narrows

Article:

According to a recent CNN/SSRS poll, former Vice President Joe Biden leads President Donald Trump by 5 percentage points in a potential general election matchup, with Biden receiving 49% of the vote and Trump receiving 44%. In matchups between Trump and other leading Democratic contenders, including South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, the gap is closer.

Compared to polling conducted in October, the Democratic margin in all head-to-heads has narrowed by at least 5 points. The polling data suggests that Trump is gaining ground as the 2020 election approaches.

Throughout Trump's presidency, his approval rating has remained relatively stable, typically hovering in the high 30s to low 40s. He has consistently trailed Biden by high single to low double digits in the polls. However, the latest poll shows a significant shift in Trump's favor, with his lead over Biden dropping from 12 points to 7 points, and Trump picking up at least 4 points against other leading Democrats since October.

In the 15 closest states of the 2016 election, where the presidential contest was decided by 8 or fewer points, Trump is in a stronger position. None of the Democrats led in CNN's December poll in these states. This follows other swing state polling suggesting that, similar to 2016, Trump could win the electoral college while losing the popular vote.

The shift in Trump's favor nationally coincides with an upward movement in his personal popularity. His net favorable rating (favorable - unfavorable) stood at -6 points among voters in CNN's latest poll. This is a significant improvement from the -12 points he had in the two prior CNN polls that asked the question.

The average poll also shows Trump at the high end in his popularity. According to the FiveThirtyEight aggregate, this week Trump hit his highest approval rating among voters (45%) since March 2017.

Trump's upward trajectory may be, at least in part, due to the economy. While most people generally think the economy is good, a booming 76% said it was good in the CNN poll out this week. That was the highest percentage since 2001.

The impeachment of Trump does not seem to be making much of an impact on the polls. This could be because fewer voters say it's an extremely or very important issue to their vote than any other issue tested by CNN in November. Additionally, it could be because opposition to impeaching and removing Trump is higher than Trump's popularity ratings. This means that more talk of impeachment may actually move Trump's approval rating up.

Another factor helping Trump is that presidential elections are not referendums. He will have a named Democratic opponent. None of the leading Democrats had a positive net favorability rating among voters in CNN's December poll. The drop in the Democrats' popularity could be because they are involved in a competitive primary, which is hurting their intra-party favorability ratings. None of the Democrats are anywhere near as popular among their own party's voters as Trump is with his. This could change once the primary ends, though.

Indeed, it's not like Trump is in a great position. The two most likely Democratic nominees, Biden and Sanders, are ahead of him by 7 points and 4 points, respectively, in the average poll. Most incumbent presidents have been leading their potential opposition at this point before the election.

Title: Trump's Approval Rating Remains Stable Amidst Criticism Following Putin Meeting

Article:

President Donald Trump's approval rating has shown little change in the first polls following his controversial joint press conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin, according to recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal and Economist/YouGov polls. Trump's approval rating rose to 45 percent in the NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, marking his highest level in that poll since taking office. The Economist/YouGov survey showed no significant deviation from Trump's numbers the previous week.

The polls, which included responses both before and after the July 16 news conference in Helsinki, suggest a more pronounced negative impact may not be immediately apparent. However, it is possible that a more significant negative effect could emerge in the next wave of polls.

Democrats have offered several explanations for Trump's resilience, including the strength of the economy, his base's tendency to disregard negative press coverage, and the emotional connection he maintains with his supporters due to his willingness to address cultural hot-button issues such as race and immigration.

However, Democrats argue that Trump's base may not be large enough to ensure sustained electoral success, either in the 2018 midterm elections or in the 2020 presidential race. Robert Shrum, a Democratic strategist who has worked on several presidential campaigns, stated, "If another president had these numbers, his political people would be very worried about it. He only cares about his base, and, if you look at polls in general, they are in deep trouble for the 2018 election."

The NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll revealed that while 29 percent of Americans strongly approve of Trump, 44 percent strongly disapprove. This imbalance suggests that Democrats can expect greater intensity among their base, a factor that could be crucial since Democratic-leaning voting blocs tend to turn out less reliably in midterm elections than in presidential contests.

On the other hand, the same poll showed that the Democrats' lead in the so-called generic ballot—where voters nationwide are asked which party they would prefer to control Congress—had shrunk to 6 percentage points. This represents a notable slippage from the 10-point advantage the party enjoyed just a month prior.

This shrinkage in the Democrats' lead calls into question the idea of a "blue wave" that might sweep Democrats into power in the House or Senate after November, even if few independent voices back the president's claim, made on Twitter last month, that there might be a "Red Wave" for Republicans instead.

Among Democrats, there is continued faith that things will go their way in November. Tad Devine, who served as a senior adviser to Sen. Bernie Sanders' 2016 presidential campaign, stated, "The intensity is there. Democratic voters are paying a lot more attention, they are a lot more interested in participating." He added that the party did not need to adopt a one-size-fits-all approach to framing the election.

Many Democrats also emphasize the significant swath of the voting public that appears alienated—perhaps permanently—from Trump. His polarizing approach, they say, makes him more enemies than friends. The effect could be to the detriment of his party.

Referring to Trump's conduct during the news conference with Putin and in the days afterward, Democratic strategist Joe Trippi stated, "The 55 or 56 percent who say they disapprove of him? I think this really locks that in...This last nine, 10 days or so makes it much tougher for a Republican candidate for Congress to pull them back."

Opinions diverge as to why Trump himself commands such strong loyalty from his base of support. Shrum argued that economic factors were less relevant than other, gut-level responses. "I just think there is a deep emotional investment in him by a shrinking Republican Party," Shrum said. "He speaks to the politics of resentment, he speaks to the anxieties—though I think his remedies are absurd—of people who think they have been left behind, and so they don't want to give up on him."

Devine argued that the strong economy played its part as "protective armor" for Trump—but he asserted that an anti-media reflex is also part of the picture. "Usually the battles are between the Democrats and the Republicans, but in Trump's case it is himself and the press," he said. "That's the battle, and he is delivering these messages to people in his base, and they are responding to it."

Devine also asserted that support for Trump was more complicated than the headline figures from a poll suggest. "They don't really like the way Trump has handled himself, but they also think he is being attacked unfairly and all this other stuff," he said.

For the moment, however, the idea of a Trump collapse looks increasingly unrealistic, at least in the short term. That's giving his opponents, as well as his supporters, plenty of food for thought.

Title: IRS Ex-Commissioner's Wife Tied to Liberal Campaign Finance Reform Group

Article:

Douglas Shulman, the former Internal Revenue Service (IRS) commissioner who oversaw the agency during the period it targeted conservative groups, has come under renewed scrutiny due to his wife's association with a prominent left-leaning political organization. Susan L. Anderson, Shulman's wife, is a senior program adviser for the Washington-based group Public Campaign.

Public Campaign, which bills itself as nonpartisan, states it works with a broad range of organizations to reform campaign-finance rules. However, the group receives significant funding from liberal organizations such as the Ford Foundation, Barbra Streisand's The Streisand Foundation, and Health Care for America NOW, a coalition of labor unions supporting ObamaCare that includes the AFL-CIO and the Service Employees International Union, according to the Public Campaign website.

In 2011, Public Campaign produced a video that appeared to suggest that the wealthiest Americans, specifically the top 1 percent, were trying to buy or influence elections by secretly donating to political groups. The video's message was critical of conservative figures like the Koch brothers, who have nonprofit groups supporting Tea Party-tied heavyweights like FreedomWorks and Americans for Prosperity.

When the IRS scandal over the targeting of conservative groups broke, Public Campaign appeared to defend the tax agency. Nick Nyhart, the group's chief executive, suggested to ABC News that the misdeeds of a "few bad apples" within the agency would "make it harder for those questions to be asked without claims of bias."

Anderson, who has also been a supporter and apparent participant in the Occupy Wall Street movement, met Shulman as students at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. Shulman was appointed commissioner by former President George W. Bush and reportedly logged more than 100 visits to the White House under Obama, a claim he did not deny during congressional testimony last month on the IRS scandal. That number refers to the number of times Shulman was cleared to visit.

Title: U.S. to Issue Guidance on Reducing Unnecessary COVID-19 Testing

Article:

The United States is set to release guidance aimed at reducing unnecessary COVID-19 testing, as part of efforts to decrease turnaround times for tests. Brett Giroir, assistant secretary for health at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, made the announcement on Thursday.

The specifics of the guidance are still under development, but it will reportedly discourage individuals who have completed home quarantine from getting retested before returning to work or school. Giroir stated that such unnecessary tests are contributing to system congestion.

Giroir explained that individuals who are critically ill or have immune system issues may require retesting due to the possibility of prolonged virus shedding. However, for most individuals, a seven to eight-day isolation period should suffice.

Turnaround times for COVID-19 tests remain an issue, with Giroir expressing a desire to see the average time decrease to three days. Currently, only 26 states are managing to produce test results within this timeframe, with one state taking more than five days.

Giroir emphasized that the new testing guidance is not a response to shortages, but rather a measure to address the unnecessary use of tests. The U.S. government is working towards a transition from lab-based tests, which can take longer to process, to point-of-care tests. These tests can provide results in minutes and can be conducted in a wider variety of locations.

The U.S. government anticipates having 20 million point-of-care tests per month available by September. Becton Dickinson announced on Wednesday that the U.S. government has agreed to purchase 750,000 of its point-of-care tests.

Title: Biden Expresses Regret to Anita Hill Over 1991 Supreme Court Hearings, but Hill Says She Is Not Satisfied

Article:

Joe Biden, who launched his third presidential campaign on Thursday, contacted Anita Hill to express his regret for the way he handled her testimony against Clarence Thomas during the 1991 Supreme Court hearings. However, Hill, in an interview with the New York Times, stated that she was not satisfied with the conversation and declined to characterize his comments as an apology.

Biden, who was chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and oversaw the confirmation hearing during which Hill accused Thomas of sexual harassment, contacted Hill earlier this month to express his "regret for what she endured" during the hearing. But Hill told the newspaper that she could not support Biden until he takes responsibility for his behavior.

Hill, now a law professor, told the New York Times that she was not satisfied with Biden's outreach and declined to characterize his comments as an apology. "I can not be satisfied by simply saying I'm sorry for what happened to you," she said. "I will be satisfied when I know there is real change and real accountability and real purpose."

Biden has previously apologized for allowing an all-male and all-white panel of lawmakers to aggressively question Hill during the hearing. His role in the hearing has come under fresh scrutiny in light of the #MeToo movement and the 2018 Supreme Court hearing of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, who denied accusations of sexually assaulting a woman when he was a teenager.

Hill told the newspaper that she could not support Biden until he takes responsibility for his behavior. "The focus on apology to me is one thing," she said. "But he needs to give an apology to the other women and to the American public because we know now how deeply disappointed Americans around the country were about what they saw. And not just women. There are women and men now who have just really lost confidence in our government to respond to the problem of gender violence."

A spokesperson for Biden's 2020 campaign confirmed his outreach to Hill. "They had a private discussion where he shared with her directly his regret for what she endured and his admiration for everything she has done to change the culture around sexual harassment in this country," the spokesperson said.

Biden publicly addressed his treatment of Hill last month at an event in New York City honoring students who helped fight sexual violence on college campuses. "She faced a committee that didn't fully understand what the hell this was all about," he said at the event. "To this day, I regret I couldn't give her the kind of hearing she deserved."

Hill's comments come as Biden defends himself against allegations from several women who have accused him of unwanted, inappropriate behavior. "Social norms are changing," Biden said in a video. "I understand that, and I've heard what these women are saying. Politics to me has always been about making connections, but I will be more mindful of personal space in the future. That's my responsibility, and I will meet it."

Title: Facebook Study Shows Partisan Tendencies in News Feed, Raising Concerns for Future Influence

Article:

Facebook, with over 1.3 billion users, functions as the world's most widely read daily newspaper, according to Pew Research Center. Approximately 30 percent of American adults obtain their news from Facebook. The editorial decisions on the platform, however, are made with limited transparency through the News Feed algorithm.

In a recent study published in Science, Facebook researchers have found that the News Feed algorithm does not significantly contribute to the polarization of national discourse, potentially providing a defense for the social network against criticisms. The study's results were reviewed before publication, with an anonymous panel of scholars unaffiliated with Facebook overseeing the process.

It is important to note that this study differs from a previous controversy involving Facebook, where the company's scientists manipulated the number of positive and negative posts that some users saw to examine the effects on mood. In contrast, this study did not involve any experiment that altered users' experience of Facebook; instead, researchers analyzed how people use Facebook as it stands today.

For the study, researchers first identified the political leanings of news articles by examining which political group shared them most frequently. They found predictable partisan attitudes toward certain news sources, with Fox News stories being shared primarily by conservatives and Huffington Post articles being shared by liberals.

Next, they measured how often the feeds of users, whose identifying details had been removed, displayed stories that contradicted their professed ideologies, and how often they clicked on those stories.

Some academics have expressed concerns that Facebook could easily manipulate the News Feed to create a more isolated echo chamber. David Lazer, a political scientist at Northeastern University who studies social networks, wrote in a commentary on the Facebook study also published in Science, "A small effect today might become a large effect tomorrow. The deliberative sky is not yet falling, but the skies are not completely clear either."

Title: House Representative Matt Gaetz Introduces Resolution Calling for Robert Mueller's Recusal from Special Counsel Role

Article:

Representative Matt Gaetz (R-FL) has introduced a resolution calling for the resignation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller from his role in the ongoing investigation into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. Gaetz, along with Reps. Louie Gohmert of Texas and Andy Biggs of Arizona, cite Mueller's involvement in the "Uranium One" controversy, during which he served as FBI Director.

The Uranium One scandal refers to a deal approved by the Obama administration that allowed a Russian company to purchase a controlling interest in Uranium One, a Canadian mining company. The deal is frequently used by Republicans to shift the focus away from Mueller's investigation towards the story President Trump has called "one of the biggest stories in a decade."

Individuals like Gaetz and Gohmert argue that Hillary Clinton, who was serving as Secretary of State, approved the Uranium One sale in exchange for $145 million in donations from company investors to the Clinton Foundation. However, Clinton did not have the ability to approve or veto the sale, and her involvement was as one of nine cabinet members of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). Only the president can decide to block a sale for national security reasons. None of the other eight members or President Obama voted against or blocked the sale, and this is likely because the sale posed no national security risk.

A lot of discussion surrounding the scandal focuses on an argument that Russia obtained 20 percent of the American uranium supply—in reality, it's closer to zero. This is because the U.S. mines owned by Uranium One do not contain quality uranium and are barely used. The Russians were only interested in Uranium One to create productive Uranium mines in Kazakhstan.

While a recent report found that roughly 20 Republican Senators have expressed support for Mueller and his investigation, there is still a faction on the right that believes Mueller should resign. A headline on FoxNews.com from Monday, when former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort and his close associate Rick Gates were asked to turn themselves in to the FBI, read "Mueller facing new Republican pressure to resign in Russia probe."

A spokeswoman for Gaetz told the Washington Post they expect to pick up more support from the House Freedom Caucus, many members of which signed on to another bill by Gaetz that called for Attorney General Jeff Sessions to appoint a special counsel to look into former FBI Director James Comey's actions.

While the White House has stated Trump has "no intention" on firing Mueller, Trump himself has certainly left the possibility open. His personal lawyer Jay Sekulow went on ABC News this week and said, "You could only terminate a special counsel for cause, and we just don't see any basis for cause." Sekulow admits that there is no cause for Trump firing Mueller at the moment, but Trump himself has hinted at one issue he has with the Muller investigation that could give him cause.

During a New York Times interview in July, Trump responded to a question by reporter Michael Schmidt asking if Mueller's focus on the Trump family finances would be taking the investigation too far. "I would say yeah," Trump responded.

What this resolution shows is if Trump were to fire Mueller, he would have the support of some members in Congress.

Title: Decline in Community Organizations and Its Impact on American Society

Article:

French historian Alexis de Tocqueville, in his observations of the United States in the 1830s, noted the prevalence of non-political community organizations among Americans. These groups, clubs, and associations played a unique role in American society, as they filled needs and worked for change more efficiently than any government program ever could.

Examples of such organizations include Kiwanis, supper clubs, Shriners, churches, bowling leagues, the PTA, the Elks, ladies' associations, and countless others. These groups raised thousands of dollars for local charities and volunteered countless hours.

However, since the height of social clubs and civic organizations in the 1960s, membership has more than halved. The Elks, for instance, boasted 1.6 million members in 1976, but by 2012, there were around 800,000 Elks nationwide. Similarly, the PTA's membership plummeted from 12 million in 1964 to fewer than 4 million by 2016.

Political scientist Robert Putnam first raised the alarm about this trend in his 2000 book "Bowling Alone." Putnam's research on Americans' socializing habits revealed a concerning trend of isolation, with a significant drop in participation in club meetings, family dinners, and social gatherings.

The decline in community organizations has led to a fracturing of communities, which has contributed to increasing political polarization. In the past, neighbors with competing political views could come together in community organizations, such as the Elks Lodge, the PTA, or church.

Today, most Americans have few or even no friends with worldviews that differ from their own. Distrust and even loathing of people with opposing political views is rapidly growing, and people are reading and watching their own side's news almost exclusively.

Sharing freedom and changing hearts and minds, which depend on forming real relationships with people who disagree with us, is almost impossible in a climate like this. As 2018 approaches, let's make a recommitment to our communities, find that social club, civic organization, or bridge game, and make an effort to step outside our comfort zone and build relationships with the people who live down the street. After all, being together is so much better than bowling alone, and it just might help you build a stronger community and save the country.

Slade O' Brien, the vice president of Grassroots Leadership Academy, an organization dedicated to equipping people to fight for freedom in their communities, emphasizes the importance of community engagement. Learn more about GLA here.

Title: Republican Leadership Vows to Avoid Gridlock and Infighting After Midterm Elections

 Article:

 In the aftermath of their recent midterm election victories, the Republican congressional leadership has signaled a shift towards avoiding gridlock and infighting. According to Politico, incoming Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has indicated he will not support conservative calls to use the debt ceiling as a bargaining chip for spending cuts, a move that triggered the government shutdown last year.

 Politico reported that Republican leaders are determined to avoid repeating the fiscal fights of the past, which eroded public confidence in Washington and became synonymous with the GOP-controlled House. McConnell has already pledged that there will be no government shutdown during his tenure, and in his victory speech, he extended an olive branch to President Barack Obama, stating that the GOP has a "duty" to work with the White House on issues they agree on.

 House Speaker John Boehner is also reportedly planning to act as a "responsible leader," and the party needs to be unified to capitalize on its political dominance, according to Politico. The leadership may feel more justified in demanding loyalty from the conservative wing of the party, given that the election victories were largely due to the party's early backing of establishment candidates, some of whom represent moderate districts.

 Ohio GOP Rep. Steve Stivers, a close ally of Boehner, told Politico, "What this election did is give us a working majority where we have at least 218 votes to pass a Republican agenda, and what I think will be a responsible Republican agenda." He added, "We're not veering hard right, we're playing it straight down the fairway, to use a Boehner-ism."

 McConnell and Boehner have already outlined their legislative agenda, stating in a joint editorial that their top priority is to help the struggling middle class. They plan to pass many of the bills the House has already approved as a first step, which they believe will signal that the Washington logjam has been broken and establish a foundation of certainty and stability.

 The leadership will also be aware that unity could be crucial to maintaining the Senate majority in 2016, when a number of senators from blue and purple states are up for re-election, according to Politico.

Title: Republican Party Shifts Stance on Marijuana Laws Ahead of 2016 Elections

Article:

Republican presidential hopefuls are advocating for a softening of federal marijuana laws, marking a significant shift from the party's previous stance. Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky and Texas Gov. Rick Perry have been the most vocal in this regard, advocating for states' rights in marijuana-related issues.

Sen. Paul argues that the federal government should not interfere with marijuana laws, while Gov. Perry supports state-level decriminalization, citing drug courts in Texas that he believes have contributed to the state's movement towards decriminalization.

New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie has expressed a desire to end the "failed war on drugs," a policy initiated by President Nixon, a Republican, in 1971. Erik Altieri, a spokesman for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, noted that this shift in Republican stance is particularly noticeable in the past few months.

In contrast, during the 2012 presidential election, Republican nominee Mitt Romney vowed to fight marijuana legalization, even for medical use, and the 2008 nominee, Sen. John McCain, labeled marijuana as a "gateway drug." However, Mr. McCain recently signaled a change in attitude by suggesting that marijuana should be legalized.

The shift in marijuana policy is not limited to the Republican Party. In a recent interview, President Obama, who has acknowledged using marijuana in his youth, stated that marijuana may be less dangerous than alcohol.

Public opinion is also shifting, with voters in Colorado and Washington approving referendums allowing recreational use of marijuana for adults over 21. More than 12 states have decriminalized possession of small amounts of marijuana, and 20 states, including California since 1996, have enacted legislation allowing medical marijuana.

Under federal law, marijuana is classified as a Schedule I substance, making it illegal to manufacture or distribute the drug. However, the Obama administration has stated it will allow states leeway as long as they do not see evidence of criminal gangs trafficking the drug or children gaining access.

The issue of marijuana legalization is significant in states crucial to the 2016 elections, such as New Hampshire, which hosts the first-in-the-nation presidential primaries. In New Hampshire, Republicans in the state legislature have helped pass a bill legalizing marijuana for recreational use.

Rep. Steve Vaillancourt, the Republican sponsor of the bill, expressed hope that Republicans will not oppose marijuana legalization as they did with same-sex marriage. He believes that, in a few years, Republicans will overwhelmingly support marijuana legalization.

Sen. Paul has stated that smoking marijuana is not a good idea and could lower a person's IQ. However, he believes states should be able to legalize marijuana if they wish, and it does not make sense to imprison nonviolent marijuana users.

Gov. Perry opposes legalization but supports policies that can lead to decriminalization, such as drug courts. Gov. Christie, in his inaugural address, criticized the "war on drugs" as based on the misguided notion that incarceration is the solution to every ill caused by drug abuse.

Title: South and North Korean Leaders Meet to Discuss US-North Korea Summit

Article:

The leaders of South Korea and North Korea have met in the demilitarized zone (DMZ) between the two countries. The meeting, which is the second between South Korea's Moon Jae-in and North Korea's Kim Jong-un, comes as the two sides continue efforts to put a historic US-North Korea summit back on track.

The latest talks were held on the northern side of the Panmunjom truce village between 15:00 and 17:00 local time (06:00 and 08:00 GMT), according to Mr. Moon's office. Both leaders exchanged opinions for the successful holding of the North Korea-US summit, with Mr. Moon announcing the outcome of the talks on Sunday morning.

In Washington, Trump administration spokeswoman Sarah Sanders confirmed that an advance team of White House and Department of State officials would leave for Singapore this weekend, as originally scheduled, to prepare for a possible summit there. The talks between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim, if they were to go ahead, would be focused on ways of denuclearizing the Korean peninsula and reducing tensions.

After cancelling the scheduled summit last Thursday, blaming North Korea's "tremendous anger and open hostility," Mr. Trump tweeted on Friday that "very productive talks" had taken place with the North on reinstating the summit with Mr. Kim.

While the goal of both sides is said to be denuclearization, what this actually means to Pyongyang and Washington appears to differ. US officials have said they would like to see the complete and irreversible dismantling of the North's nuclear program and weapons, allowing international inspectors to check every step of that process, before any talk of sanctions being lifted. For North Korea, denuclearization means a much more reciprocal agreement. If Pyongyang were to give up its nuclear assets, it would like to see a comparable gesture from Washington.

The US has a large military presence in South Korea and in Japan - both of which North Korea would expect to be scaled down. It also wants assurances that its survival as a state would never be in question. Doubt was cast over the scheduled summit when North became angered by comments from senior US officials, who made comparisons with Libya. There, former leader Colonel Gaddafi gave up his nascent nuclear program only for him to be killed by Western-backed rebels a few years later.

In April, the leaders of both Koreas held a historic meeting at the border, promising to end hostilities and work towards the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. The rare dialogue - the first time the Korean leaders met to hold talks since 2007 - came after months of improving relations between the two countries. At the carefully choreographed meeting, Mr. Kim said that he wanted to "write a new chapter" for the region's troubled history. "New history starts from now, at the historic starting point of an era of peace," he said.

Future economic cooperation between the Koreas was also discussed, and Mr. Kim admitted to Mr. Moon that the North's critical infrastructure was in need of improvement. Such projects are likely to have suffered under international and US sanctions, imposed on the North as a reaction against its nuclear program and missile tests.

Title: New Jersey Senator Cory Booker's Testimony Against Sessions and the Debate on Civility in Politics

Article:

New Jersey Senator Cory Booker testified against Senator Jeff Sessions' nomination to be attorney general in 2017, an event that has sparked a renewed discussion on civility in politics. In a recent article, conservative commentator David French criticizes Booker's behavior during the hearing, citing instances where he interrupted California Senator Kamala Harris in two separate hearings and displaying what French describes as "temper tantrum" behavior.

French, a senior writer for a certain publication and senior fellow at the ███ Institute, argues that if a conservative male senator had behaved similarly towards a progressive female cabinet secretary, there would be widespread outrage from the liberal side. He introduces the term "manterrupting" to describe this behavior, which he claims is not uncommon when a female pundit, politician, or activist leans slightly to the right of moderate.

French criticizes the hypocrisy he perceives in the Democratic Party, citing their condemnation of President Trump's comments and actions towards women, while seemingly tolerating similar behavior from their own members. He also references the Iran-Iraq War phase of conflicts over civility, suggesting that the only remaining norm is hypocrisy.

French concludes by advocating for a return to respectful discourse, even in times of anger, quoting a retired federal judge who advised speaking with regret, not outrage, to counteract a culture of outrage. French criticizes Booker's behavior during the Sessions hearing and suggests that the Democratic Party should offer the country something other than Trumpism dressed in blue if they aim to argue they can do better.

Title: U.S. President Trump Imposes Tariffs on Remaining Chinese Imports, Escalating Trade War

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has ordered the imposition of tariffs on all remaining imports from China, marking an escalation in the ongoing trade war between the two nations. The new tariffs, which are expected to affect approximately $300 billion worth of Chinese imports, will be in addition to the existing 25% tariff rate on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports, as announced by U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer in a statement.

Lighthizer stated that a final decision on the new duties has not been made, but the increased tariffs would come into effect following the current 10% rate. The talks between the U.S. and Chinese negotiators have not resulted in significant progress, as China proposed extensive revisions to a draft trade agreement last week.

In a series of tweets, Trump defended the tariff hike and stated that he is in "absolutely no rush" to finalize a deal, adding that the U.S. economy would gain more from the levies than any agreement. Despite the escalation in tariffs, both Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He have agreed to continue negotiations, avoiding a complete breakdown in talks between the world's two largest economies.

China responded to the U.S. tariff hike with countermeasures, but did not elaborate on the nature of these countermeasures. In response to the increased tariffs, U.S. stock indexes reversed course to close higher, and yields on U.S. government debt also drifted higher after the end of the talks.

The new 25% U.S. duty is being imposed on more than 5,700 categories of products, including internet modems, routers, circuit boards, furniture, and lighting products. Seaborne cargoes shipped from China before midnight were not subject to the new tax as long as they arrive in the United States prior to June 1. Those cargoes will be charged the original 10% rate.

Economists and industry consultants predict that it may take three or four months for American shoppers to feel the impact of the increased tariffs. The higher tariffs could reduce U.S. gross domestic product by 0.3% and China's by 0.8% in 2020, according to consultancy Oxford Economics.

While Trump has maintained that his trade policies will boost U.S. manufacturing, some in the sector are concerned that the policies could backfire if the dispute with China is not resolved soon. Michael Haberman, president of Gradall Industries Inc in New Philadelphia, Ohio, which sells about 5% of its machinery to China, expressed concern, stating, "For us, the longer this continues, the more dangerous it becomes."

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue stated that Trump had asked him to create a plan to support American farmers, as the U.S. government has already rolled out up to $12 billion to help offset their China-related losses.

Title: Mitt Romney's Vice Presidential Pick: Michael Bloomberg as a Potential Compassionate, Fiscal Conservative

Article:

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, is reportedly considering a vice presidential running mate with a strong conservative background and a track record of success, particularly in a swing state. This potential choice, according to political analyst LZ Granderson, could be former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

Bloomberg, known for his union-fighting and gay-friendly policies, has been elected three times in a diverse region while being a wealthy, older white man. His election history, combined with his moderate social views, could attract voters on the fence, a demographic that Romney is targeting.

In 2008, Sen. John McCain selected Sarah Palin, a game-changer who, while popular, was criticized for her lack of experience. Bloomberg, like Palin, would be a curveball, but unlike Palin, he would engage voters in thoughtful discussions rather than just generating buzz.

Bloomberg is perceived as a compassionate leader with traditional Republican views, focusing on deficit reduction through increased revenue and tough spending cuts. He is also known for his pragmatic approach to politics, a quality that could appeal to independent voters.

One of Bloomberg's notable statements is his opposition to the idea of promising a "free lunch," a reference to the common criticism that Republicans often promise tax cuts without addressing the resulting deficits. This stance, Granderson notes, resonates with voters who are looking for honest assessments and solutions, rather than partisan cheerleading.

In the past, Bloomberg has expressed support for Romney's presidential bid but has not endorsed him due to differences in social policy. However, Granderson suggests that Romney's social conservatism has not been well-received by the religious right, and choosing a safe, religious conservative running mate may not improve his standing with this group.

Granderson argues that Romney needs a vice president who can address economic issues effectively, as opposed to focusing on social policy. He suggests that the country cannot afford another platform bait-and-switch, referring to the 2010 government shutdown over the Republican obsession with Planned Parenthood during budget talks.

In conclusion, Granderson posits that a vice presidential pick like Bloomberg, who is a real, old-school Republican, could help Romney appeal to independent voters and address economic issues effectively, potentially leading to a more successful presidential campaign. The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of LZ Granderson.

Title: Migrant Mother Selected for U.S. Asylum Processing in Tijuana

Article:

Gabriela Hernandez, a 27-year-old pregnant mother of two, was chosen by her fellow migrants to begin the process of seeking asylum in the United States on Monday. Hernandez, who had fled a threat of violence in Honduras with her sons, ages 6 and 2, was among eight people selected to present themselves to U.S. border officials.

Hernandez and her sons were part of a group of migrants who had traveled hundreds of miles to reach the U.S. border crossing at Tijuana, Mexico. However, they were initially turned away due to capacity constraints at the port of entry.

Dozens of migrants vowed to camp outside the center, waiting for "every last one" to be admitted into the United States. When U.S. customs officials resumed processing cases of "undocumented arrivals" on Monday, the migrants chose Hernandez and another woman, Tesla Rich, to step forward.

Hernandez and Rich, along with their children and another mother and child, and a teenager traveling alone, were processed by border protection officers. The outcome of their asylum claims is unknown.

Hernandez's plan had always been to claim asylum, given the danger to her life and her children in Honduras. "I don't know what I'm going to do," she had said earlier. "I can't go back to my country."

Title: State Attorneys General Launch Antitrust Investigations of Google and Facebook, Adding Pressure on Federal Regulators

Article:

A bipartisan group of attorneys general from 48 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico announced on Monday that they would pool resources to probe Google's advertising business. This announcement follows that of a smaller, overlapping group of attorneys general led by New York's Letitia James, who is investigating Facebook's business practices.

The group investigating Google, which includes all states except California and Alabama, stressed their independence from federal regulators, who are already asking their own questions of the company. Google previously disclosed that it is under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC).

D.C. Attorney General Karl Racine, a Democrat, said, "The state attorneys general, they are an independent bunch. And they can be quite tenacious. So I'm very confident that this bipartisan group is going to be led by the facts and not be swayed by any conclusion that may fall short, if you will, if it's inconsistent with our facts, on the federal side."

The state attorneys general's actions could indicate a level of dissatisfaction among top state legal officials when it comes to federal action against Big Tech. Recently, federal regulatory action against Facebook and Google has had little impact on their core businesses or stock prices.

In the past, states have played a noteworthy role in antitrust cases, gaining significant concessions from tobacco companies and pressing Microsoft in a landmark antitrust case. In that case, attorneys general from 20 states and the District of Columbia joined the Justice Department in alleging Microsoft suppressed competition in the software market. However, the Justice Department decided to settle with the company, and several states vocally dissented against what they saw as a weak agreement.

Half a dozen antitrust experts interviewed for this article said state investigations can certainly add heat to the federal probes, but ultimately, their resources pale in comparison to those of the FTC and the Department of Justice (DOJ). "The big picture here is that states can serve as a backstop if the federal government decides not to go after these companies," Rutgers Law professor Michael Carrier said. "You're putting 30 generally small offices together and then they have to coordinate," said Harry First, a professor at the New York University School of Law. "It's good, but it's not quite the same as the extent of the staffs on the federal level."

Considering both Google and Facebook are large global companies, "it's a heavy lift," First said. The state attorneys general's investigations may, however, serve as a welcome development for those waiting to see if the U.S. government will deal a more significant blow to Big Tech.

Title: Facebook to Adjust Salaries for Remote Workers Based on Location, Zuckerberg Says

Article:

Facebook Inc.'s Chief Executive Officer, Mark Zuckerberg, has outlined the company's future remote-working plans during a videoconference with employees on Thursday. Zuckerberg expects about half of Facebook's employees to work from home five to ten years from now, with a caveat for those planning to live in low-cost areas while maintaining high salaries.

Zuckerberg stated that Facebook will "aggressively" ramp up the hiring of remote workers, though not all employees would be allowed to permanently work from home at the start. For those who choose to work in areas with lower costs of living, salaries will be adjusted accordingly.

"That means if you live in a location where the cost of living is dramatically lower, or the cost of labor is lower, then salaries do tend to be somewhat lower in those places," Zuckerberg said.

Facebook already pays based on location, but employees working remotely must notify Facebook if they move to a new area before January 1, 2021. "We'll adjust salary to your location at that point," he said, noting that taxes will need to be taken into account. "There'll be severe ramifications for people who are not honest about this."

This may impact the plans of some workers hoping to stretch their salaries further in cheaper areas. A recent survey of San Francisco Bay Area tech workers found that two-thirds would consider moving away from the pricey area if they could work remotely.

As of 2018, the median employee compensation at Facebook was over $240,000 a year. The median home price in Menlo Park, California, where Facebook has its headquarters, is $2.4 million, according to Zillow, while the median home price in the wider Bay Area was $928,000 last year.

Zuckerberg shared that, in a company survey, of the people who said they would want to work remotely full-time, about 45% were "pretty confident" that they would move to another place if they had that opportunity, with an additional 30% saying they "might" move. About 60% of that total said they'd prefer to move to a smaller city or town.

Ultimately, Zuckerberg said the changes will help Facebook become more diverse in its workforce. "When you limit hiring to people who either live in a small number of big cities or are willing to move there, that cuts out a lot of people who live in different communities, different backgrounds or may have different perspectives," he said. "Certainly being able to recruit more broadly, especially across the U.S. and Canada to start, is going to open up a lot of new talent that previously wouldn't have considered moving to a big city."

Currently, about 95% of Facebook's employees are working from home due to coronavirus stay-at-home orders. The company has previously said workers will be able to work from home at least through the end of the year.

Title: A Neutral Perspective on the 2016 U.S. Election, Data Leaks, and the Alleged Russian Interference

Article:

Last week, President Obama announced sanctions against Russia in response to alleged data theft and disclosure activities that were intended to interfere with the U.S. election process. Hillary Clinton, in her unsuccessful presidential campaign, described these activities as an "attack against our country" and "our electoral system" that undermined "the integrity of our democracy."

However, these overheated descriptions may misleadingly equate information that guides voters' choices with nullification of those choices. A calmer, less partisan perspective suggests that what Clinton and Obama view as interference with the election process might more accurately be described as voter education, which strengthens democracy by helping its participants make better-informed choices.

News reports often describe the leaking of emails stolen from the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and John Podesta, Clinton's campaign chairman, as "election hacking." John McCain, the GOP's 2008 presidential nominee, seems to agree with that characterization. In a CNN interview last month, the Arizona senator, a harsh critic of Donald Trump who denounced him, endorsed him, and then withdrew his endorsement, complained that by leaking information helpful to the Republican nominee, "the Russians…have been able to interfere with our electoral process." He warned that "if they are able to harm the electoral process, then they destroy democracy, which is based on free and fair elections."

However, that take seems pretty hysterical in light of what actually happened. True election hacking, aimed at perpetrating voting fraud, obviously would be a threat to the democratic process. But there is no evidence of such interference, and it's not even clear that the DNC and Podesta emails had an impact on the election results—or why it would be so terrible if they did.

The New York Times reports that hackers gained access to the emails through standard phishing techniques, tricking Podesta and at least one DNC employee into revealing their passwords by pretending to be from Google. The Times notes that "every major publication, including The Times, published multiple stories citing the D.N.C. and Podesta emails posted by WikiLeaks, becoming a de facto instrument of Russian intelligence."

Those news organizations did that because much of the information in the emails—including DNC officials' disdain for Clinton rival Bernie Sanders, excerpts from her secret Wall Street speeches, and observations about her weaknesses as a candidate—concerned matters of legitimate public interest. It was information that voters might rationally want to consider before deciding which candidate to support.

Valuable journalism is often based on information that was obtained or divulged illegally by people with axes to grind. It is hard to see how this case is different in principle. Is it the nationality of the informants that matters? If the emails that embarrassed Clinton had been swiped by Americans, would she still be talking about a democracy-threatening attack on our electoral process?

Last fall, the Times "obtained" parts of Donald Trump's 1995 tax return and shared them with the public. If that information had come from a foreign source, would publishing it have undermined democracy?
