Suppose German hackers had managed to obtain complete copies of Trump's recent tax returns—a subject of intense journalistic interest—and shared them with news outlets, either directly or through an intermediary like Wikileaks. Would Clinton have perceived the resulting exposés as undermining the electoral process or assisting it?

Cybersecurity is a serious concern, especially when it comes to systems that control important functions such as vote counting, banking, and the distribution of electricity. Helping politicians conceal facts that might alienate voters probably does not belong in the same category. Judging from the account in the Times, both the FBI and the DNC were remarkably lax in their initial responses to the intrusions that produced a bounty of newsworthy emails. Politicians with things to hide might want to be more careful about the security of the systems they use to discuss sensitive matters. But we should not confuse their challenge with a threat to democracy.

Title: China Expresses Confidence in U.S. Trade Deal, Despite Trump's Tariff Threat

Article:

China has expressed confidence that it can reach a trade deal with the United States, despite fresh warnings from President Donald Trump that he may revert to imposing more tariffs if the two sides fail to resolve their differences. The Chinese Commerce Ministry made these remarks on Wednesday, following a period of relative quiet from Beijing after Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping reached a temporary truce in their trade war at a meeting over dinner in Argentina on Saturday.

In a brief statement on its website, the ministry said China would work quickly to implement issues already agreed upon, as both sides "actively promote the work of negotiations within 90 days in accordance with a clear timetable and roadmap." The ministry called the latest bilateral talks "very successful."

Trump, via Twitter, held out the possibility of an extension of the ceasefire but warned tariffs would be reinstated if the talks failed to bear fruit. "The negotiations with China have already started. Unless extended, they will end 90 days from the date of our wonderful and very warm dinner with President Xi in Argentina," Trump tweeted. He said he would impose "major tariffs" on Chinese goods imported into the United States if his administration is unable to reach an effective trade deal with Beijing.

China's Foreign Ministry referred specific questions to the Commerce Ministry, which is due to hold its weekly news briefing on Thursday in Beijing. "We hope the two working teams from both sides can, based on the consensus reached between the two countries' leaders, strengthen consultations, and reach a mutually beneficial agreement soon," Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang told reporters.

The threat of further escalation in the trade war between the world's two largest economies has loomed large over financial markets and the global economy for much of the year, and investors initially greeted the ceasefire with relief. However, the mood has quickly soured on skepticism that the two sides will be able to reach a substantive deal on a host of highly divisive issues within the short negotiating period agreed.

Failure would raise the specter of a major escalation in the trade battle, with fresh U.S. tariff action and Chinese retaliation possibly as early as March. The White House says China had committed to start buying more American products and lifting tariff and non-tariff barriers immediately, while beginning talks on structural changes with respect to forced technology transfers and intellectual property protection.

Sources told Reuters that Chinese oil trader Unipec plans to resume buying U.S. crude by March after the Xi-Trump deal reduced the risk of tariffs on those imports. China's crude oil imports from the U.S. had ground to a halt.

Global financial markets tumbled on Tuesday as doubts over what could realistically be accomplished in the tight negotiating window added to concerns about fading global growth. The benchmark Shanghai stock index closed down 0.6 percent on Wednesday.

"Despite a temporary de-escalation of hostilities following the G-20 summit, the relationship between the U.S. and China will remain contentious," Moody's Investors Service said in a report. "Narrow agreements and modest concessions in the ongoing trade dispute will not bridge the wide gulf in their respective economic, political, and strategic interests."

Officials from the U.S. and a number of other major economies have often criticized China for its slow approach to negotiations and not following through on commitments. China has said comparatively little about the Trump-Xi agreement after senior Chinese officials briefed the media following the meeting, and there have been some differences between U.S. and Chinese accounts of what the deal entails.

"Officials now face the difficult task of fleshing out a deal that is acceptable to the Chinese but also involves significant enough concessions not to be torpedoed by the China hawks in the Trump administration," Capital Economics said in a note this week. "We would not be surprised if no agreement can be reached within 90 days, with the higher tariff rate coming into force only a few months later than originally planned."

A Chinese official told Reuters officials were "waiting for the leaders to return" before publicizing details. President Xi and his most senior officials are due back in China on Thursday having visited Panama and Portugal since leaving Argentina.

On Wednesday, the Global Times tabloid, which is run by the Chinese Communist Party's main newspaper, said myriad statements from the Trump administration about the deal - including the agreement that China would buy $1.2 trillion in additional U.S. goods - were designed to highlight or even exaggerate facets of the deal that benefited the United States.

"Reaching an agreement within three months is a spur to not only China, but also the U.S. If the two sides fail to reach a deal, all the White House promises will be invalid," it said. "It will be a win-win situation if a deal is realized. But if not, more fights and talks will continue alternately for a longer while. Chinese society should maintain a calm attitude."

Title: Harvard Honors Colin Kaepernick, Dave Chappelle, and Other African Americans with W.E.B. Du Bois Medal

Article:

Harvard University's Hutchins Center for African & African American Studies has announced the recipients of this year's W.E.B. Du Bois Medal, the institution's highest honor in the field of African and African American Studies. The medal honors individuals who have made significant contributions to African American culture and the life of the mind.

The eight recipients of the 2021 W.E.B. Du Bois Medal are Colin Kaepernick, Dave Chappelle, Kevin Hart, Bryan Stevenson, Kenneth Chenault, Shirley Ann Jackson, Pamela Joyner, and Florence Ladd. The medal is named after William Edward Burghardt "W.E.B." Du Bois, a scholar, pan-Africanist, NAACP founder, and the first African American to earn a doctorate from Harvard.

Colin Kaepernick, the former NFL quarterback, is being recognized for his protests against racial injustice and inequality. Dave Chappelle, a celebrated comedian, is being honored for his ability to combine racial insight, reason, and comedy. Kevin Hart was considered but was not selected due to a lack of booster seats in the auditorium.

Bryan Stevenson, the founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative, is being recognized for his work in the field of criminal justice reform. Kenneth Chenault, the former CEO of American Express and a member of Facebook's Board of Directors, is being honored for his efforts to promote diversity in corporate boardrooms.

Shirley Ann Jackson, the first black woman to earn a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is being recognized for her contributions to physics and education. Pamela Joyner, a San Francisco philanthropist, is being honored for her significant collection and promotion of black art. Florence Ladd, a legendary novelist and poet, is being recognized for her contributions to education and her work in building national education platforms in South Africa and Zimbabwe.

Kehinde Wiley, the artist who painted the portrait of Barack Obama that hangs in the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery, is also a recipient of the W.E.B. Du Bois Medal. The ceremony honoring the recipients will be held at Harvard's Memorial Hall on October 11. Tickets are free, and the event is expected to attract a large crowd, including the author of this article.

Title: The Misinterpretation of Social Mobility in America: A Closer Look at the Distinction Between Opportunity and Achievement

Article:

A growing number of studies suggest that America's upward mobility for individuals born in lower socioeconomic levels is limited. However, it is crucial to distinguish between upward "mobility," defined as the opportunity to rise, and mobility defined as actual upward movement. This distinction is often overlooked in many studies.

The focus on the lack of upward mobility is frequently interpreted as a sign of societal unfairness, particularly when examining the disparity in career choices between the sons of high school dropouts and those of Ph.D. holders. If equal probabilities of achieving a specific goal is the definition of fairness, then it could be argued that life has never been fair, anywhere or any time in recorded history.

Individual aspirations and cultural differences play a significant role in the representation of various demographic groups in different fields. For instance, growing up in Harlem, the thought of becoming a ballet dancer never crossed the author's mind, and it is likely that the same was true for many growing up in New York's lower east side. This does not necessarily imply the existence of external barriers preventing individuals from pursuing certain careers.

Barriers are external obstacles, as opposed to internal values and aspirations. The under-representation of women in computer engineering, for example, may not be the result of societal barriers but rather a reflection of women's own agendas and interests. Women, like other groups, may not be dedicated to fulfilling the prevailing ideology among the intelligentsia that every demographic group should be equally represented in all areas.

One recent celebrated statistical study of social mobility omits Asian Americans, a group whose achievements challenge the notion that upward mobility is limited in America. Immigrants from Asia, along with American-born Mormons, are among the groups whose achievements undermine the idea that upward mobility can seldom be realized in America.

Those who preach this counterproductive message may never consider that the envy, resentment, and hopelessness they promote, as well as the welfare state they advocate for, are among the factors keeping people down. It is essential to approach the discussion of social mobility with a clear understanding of the distinction between opportunity and achievement, and to recognize the role of individual aspirations and cultural differences in shaping societal outcomes.

Title: Conservative Commentator Ann Coulter Criticizes Sen. Marco Rubio's Immigration Reform Proposals

Article:

Conservative commentator Ann Coulter has joined a few other Republicans in criticizing Sen. Marco Rubio's immigration reform proposals, stating that the primary result of his amnesty plan would be to create more Democratic voters. In a column for Human Events, Coulter argued that some Republicans are attempting to create more Democratic voters through their immigration policies.

Coulter's criticism follows similar sentiments from Louisiana Sen. David Vitter, who labeled Rubio's efforts to forge a bipartisan overhaul bill that grants citizenship to illegal immigrants as "naive." Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, without naming Rubio directly, also wrote this week that some in Congress are seeking "quick fixes" to the problem.

In her column, Coulter noted that Rubio's supporters claim his proposals are not amnesty, but rather enforcement-first measures. However, Coulter contends that Rubio's bill is, in fact, amnesty, stating, "Despite all the blather about how Rubio demands 'Enforcement First,' the very first thing his proposal does is make illegal aliens legal."

On Wednesday, Rubio defended his efforts in a conversation with Rush Limbaugh, emphasizing the bipartisan nature of the group working on a comprehensive overhaul plan. Rubio stated that his efforts aim to avoid the problems that plagued the 1986 immigration bill, which granted amnesty to three million illegal immigrants but failed to provide more border security and tougher enforcement mechanisms.

Coulter, however, asserts that "Step One of Marco Rubio's plan is: Grant illegal aliens the right to live and work in America legally." She did not provide further details on the specifics of Rubio's plan.

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Speech: A Closer Look at Potential Contradictions

Article:

In his first major foreign policy address, former President Donald Trump presented a plan titled "America First," which, according to some, contains contradictions and inconsistencies. The speech has sparked a political debate, with supporters praising Trump's critique of the Democratic establishment's approach, while critics, such as former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, have pointed out "simplistic slogans, contradictions, and misstatements" in the speech.

Here are ten passages that suggest Trump may be "having his cake and eating it":

1. Trump stated that some groups "will never be anything but our enemies," while later claiming, "The world must know we do not go abroad in search of enemies."
2. Trump criticized Obama for not paying for NATO membership, but also promised, "America is going to be a reliable friend and ally again."
3. Trump was ambiguous about America's role in promoting democracy, stating, "We are getting out of the nation-building business," but also adding, "I will work with our allies to reinvigorate western values and institutions."
4. Trump called for Middle East nations to do more to fight Islamic extremism, but has recently offended much of the Muslim world by threatening to ban their citizens from entering the US.
5. Criticisms of Obama's "humiliations" at the hands of foreign governments do not stand up to scrutiny, such as Trump's claim that Obama was snubbed during state visits due to a lack of a senior leader's greeting.
6. Trump criticized Obama for failing to secure the 2016 Summer Games for Chicago, but it is unclear why he would have flown to the IOC meeting if the games were already secured.
7. Trump claimed there are "scores of recent migrants inside our borders charged with terrorism," an assertion already open to dispute, and went on to say, "for every case known to the public there are dozens and dozens more."
8. Trump's slogan, "America First," could be seen as an extension of his campaign promise to make America great again, but it also harks back to the America First Committee of the 1940s, a group set up to prevent the US from joining World War II.
9. The speech contains a tension between its isolationism and interventionism, with Trump urging a pragmatic and realist approach, but also blasting Obama for having "no vision, no purpose, no direction, no strategy."
10. Trump's statement, "We will no longer surrender this country or its people to the false song of globalism," contradicts his previous statement, "Do I look like a president? How handsome am I?" made at a rally in Pennsylvania.

It is important to note that the speech was written by a number of people, and it may not be entirely reflective of Trump's personal views. The speech's textual analysis reveals potential contradictions and inconsistencies, but further investigation is needed to determine the accuracy of the statements made.

Title: Hillary Clinton Advocates for Path to Citizenship and Expanded Executive Action on Immigration

Article:

In a speech on immigration in Las Vegas on Tuesday, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton took a position to the left of President Barack Obama, proposing a more aggressive approach to the issue. As a presidential candidate, Clinton aims to revitalize the stalled debate and offer hope to the estimated 11 million immigrants living in the United States without legal status.

Clinton advocated for a path to citizenship for the undocumented, and pledged as president to take executive action more broadly than Obama has, to defer the deportations of those with strong community ties through family and work. She also promised to improve conditions for immigrant detainees, describing them as more humane.

Clinton's stance on immigration sets her apart from most Republican candidates in the 2016 presidential race. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a former advocate of sensible reform, now appears to support a provisional status for the undocumented, a long and difficult path to a temporary work permit. Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, has been moderate in the past but is unclear on citizenship, with his position on the issue fluctuating and difficult to pin down.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin have more conservative views on immigration. Paul speaks compassionately of immigrants at times, but his agenda seems limited to sealing the border and ending the 14th Amendment guarantee of citizenship by birth. Walker has stated that every unauthorized immigrant should leave the country and also wants to limit legal immigration.

It is early in the campaign, and positions may shift. Clinton's public commitment to expansive immigration action is only a few hours old, and it remains to be seen whether she will prove to be a staunch defender of immigrants' rights. Last fall, Clinton was evasive when questioned by young immigrant advocates, known as Dreamers, with a non-answer: "Elect more Democrats."

Title: Trump Files Lawsuit to Prevent Banks from Handing Over Financial Records to Congress

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has initiated a lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and Capital One in an attempt to prevent them from complying with subpoenas issued by Democrat-led committees for information regarding his financial affairs. The lawsuit, filed on Monday in New York, aims to block the banks from adhering to subpoenas issued by the Democrat-controlled Congress, which is investigating the Trump family's financial dealings.

The lawsuit argues that there are no legitimate grounds for investigating the president's business affairs. Trump's three eldest children and the Trump Organization have also joined the lawsuit. The filing asserts that the subpoenas "have no legitimate or lawful purpose" and were issued to "harass President Donald J. Trump, to rummage through every aspect of his personal finances, his businesses, and the private information of the president and his family."

Deutsche Bank, one of the Trump Organization's major lenders, and a number of other financial institutions received subpoenas earlier this month from the House Intelligence and Financial Services Committees. The committees are reportedly seeking documents and materials relating to the bank's longstanding relationship with Trump and his family.

Representative Adam Schiff, the Democratic chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, stated that the subpoenas were part of an investigation "into allegations of potential foreign influence on the US political process." Schiff and fellow Democrat Maxine Waters, the chairwoman of the Financial Services Committee, described the lawsuit as "meritless."

In a joint statement, they said, "This lawsuit shows the depths to which President Trump will go to obstruct Congress's constitutional oversight authority. He will find that Congress will not be deterred from carrying out its constitutional responsibilities."

In 2017, Deutsche Bank rejected requests by Democrats in the House of Representatives to provide details of the president's finances, citing privacy laws. That year it was also reported that special counsel Robert Mueller, who led the investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia, had ordered Deutsche Bank to provide records of Trump's accounts.

Title: US Summer Meal Program Provides Free Lunches for Over 3 Million Children Across the Country

Article:

Every summer, more than 3 million children across the United States receive free meals at over 30,000 sites, including schools, recreation centers, and migrant worker camps. This program, funded by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, offers a valuable resource for families struggling financially, but it has also sparked controversy due to its open-door policy.

At the "Summer Fun Cafe" in northern California, and similar locations, meals are provided to at least half the children in the area who qualify for free lunches during the school year. During the summer, any child 18 and under can partake in these free meals, as stated by Monique Stovall, the nutrition director for the San Juan Unified School District outside Sacramento.

Signs around the district headquarters advertise the fact that there is no eligibility requirement, inviting all children in the community to take advantage. This open invitation has led to concerns among some taxpayer watchdog groups, who question whether the program could be feeding children who may not be in need.

Jon Coupal, with the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association, wonders if the program could be unintentionally providing meals to children from families with high incomes, who may not be checking their eligibility. He questions, "If someone is coming from a family that makes a quarter-of-a-million dollars a year, and they're not checking eligibility when they're coming in the door, I think most people would wonder, 'Am I paying for this?'"

For low-income families, a free lunch means more money can be allocated towards other meals or necessities. For those who can afford to feed their children, it offers a convenient option.

Julie Marks, a mother who brought her two young boys, stated, "Normally we wouldn't qualify for a free lunch, but we're close and it's convenient, and my kids like it—that's important."

In many cases, charity and nonprofit groups help sponsor free meal sites in their community. Program supporters argue that the summer lunch program is easier to administer when the location qualifies, as opposed to the user.

Monique Stovall explained, "We don't have to ask your income, because the overall purpose of the program is to provide a healthy meal to children."

Organizers contend that after a summer of nourishing meals, these children will do better when school resumes in the fall. Monitors are on hand to ensure that the lunch is eaten on site, and that adults do not take advantage of the program.

Title: Senate Proposal Aims to Replace Columbus Day with Juneteenth as Federal Holiday

Article:

In the aftermath of the death of George Floyd, Republican senators Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) and James Lankford (R-Okla.) have introduced an amendment to replace Columbus Day with Juneteenth as a federal holiday. The proposal, which follows a bipartisan Senate bill introduced by Senator John Cornyn (R-Texas), aims to offset the cost associated with Cornyn's plan for establishing Juneteenth as a federal holiday.

The amendment, introduced on June 10, 2020, is part of a growing movement to recognize Juneteenth, commemorating the day in 1865 when slavery definitively ended in the U.S., as a federal holiday. Currently, Juneteenth is celebrated as a holiday in 47 states.

Senator Lankford stated, "Throughout our history, we have strived to become a more perfect union and Juneteenth was a huge step in attaining that goal." He added, "We should celebrate these strides on the federal level while remaining cognizant of the impact the existing 10 federal holidays have on federal services and local businesses."

Senator Johnson also expressed support for the idea, stating, "We support celebrating emancipation with a federal holiday, but believe we should eliminate a current holiday in exchange." He chose Columbus Day as a holiday that is lightly celebrated and least disruptive to Americans' schedules.

Juneteenth has gained increased attention amid the nationwide protests that followed George Floyd's death in police custody. Protestors have torn down and vandalized statues of Christopher Columbus, an Italian Renaissance-era explorer often credited with being the first European to discover the Americas. A growing number of critics have called for Columbus Day to be eliminated or renamed Indigenous Peoples' Day, upset at the celebration of what they see as Columbus's subjugation and mistreatment of the New World's native population.

Senator Cornyn told The Hill that eliminating Columbus Day in favor of Juneteenth is "problematic" and "dilutes the message we're trying to send, which is one of being respectful and honoring and remembering our history." The cost associated with each new federal holiday for government employees is estimated to be $600 million in paid time off, according to a Fox News report.

Title: House Passes Coronavirus Relief Bill After Intense Negotiations Between Democrats and Republicans

Article:

In a series of events that unfolded over the weekend, the House of Representatives passed the Families First Coronavirus Response Act, a bill aimed at providing relief in response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The bill's passage followed a day of intense and chaotic negotiations between Democrats and Republicans, with uncertainty surrounding President Trump's support for the proposal.

Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, in a letter to fellow Democrats after 10 p.m. on Friday, acknowledged the intense negotiations required to secure the bill's passage by the weekend. She thanked her colleagues for their patience amid the frenetic back-and-forth with the administration.

Initially, Pelosi had announced to her members shortly after 6 p.m. that she had reached a deal. However, House Republicans, including the No. 2 House Democrat, Steny Hoyer, had stated that talks were still ongoing, and a deal had not yet been reached.

Key Republicans expressed concerns about the tax credit for paid family sick leave, with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy advocating for more flexibility for small business owners who would be forced to offer paid leave to affected workers.

The confusion was further compounded by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's announcement on Fox Business that he had reached an agreement with Pelosi. Mnuchin's statement came after a meeting with Trump, which delayed his appearance on the network for so long that he ran out of time to speak before the program ended.

President Trump eventually tweeted his support for the bill hours later, providing long-awaited relief to hundreds of members and aides who had spent 48 hours in limbo awaiting updates about the status of the funding package. Trump's tweet read, "I fully support H.R. 6201: Families First Coronavirus Response Act, which will be voted on in the House this evening. I have directed the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Labor to issue regulations that will provide flexibility so that in no way will Small Businesses be hurt. I encourage all Republicans and Democrats to come together and VOTE YES!"

One of the other major obstacles involved in the negotiations was President Trump's personal demand for a payroll tax cut in this package. This idea has little support on Capitol Hill, and Democrats have already stated that it would be debated as part of future coronavirus crisis-related legislation at a later date.

McCarthy, who met with Trump and Mnuchin multiple times in the last 24 hours, confirmed that Trump had sought the last-minute addition. He also stated that Republicans would push for it in Congress's next tranche of economic relief, which could come later this month or in April.

"I believe this will not be the only one," McCarthy said, alluding to future aid packages related to the outbreak. "This is something that the president wants, we would have liked to have that as well. I think that would have taken a little more time."

Title: GOP Faces Division on Healthcare Reform as ObamaCare Replacement Effort Stalls

Article:

The Republican party is currently grappling with competing ideas on how to proceed with healthcare reform following the collapse of the current ObamaCare replacement effort. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) acknowledged on Monday that the Senate's current approach would fail after two more senators announced opposition to the current healthcare draft.

Without the necessary votes, McConnell stated that the Senate will take up a repeal-only bill that Congress passed in 2015. "Regretfully, it is now apparent that the effort to repeal and immediately replace the failure of Obamacare will not be successful," McConnell said in a statement.

The repeal-only approach is supported by conservatives, who argue that Congress should simply pass again what it already approved in 2015. President Trump joined the conservatives, tweeting Monday night, "Republicans should just REPEAL failing ObamaCare now & work on a new Healthcare Plan that will start from a clean slate. Dems will join in!"

However, the repeal-only bill does not appear to have the votes to pass, and other GOP lawmakers called Monday for working with Democrats or passing an alternative GOP bill. A separate repeal was the initial GOP strategy at the beginning of this year and ended up being rejected due to a lack of votes to pass.

Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.) wrote in The Washington Post last week, "There must be a replace with repeal." In a report that could unsettle moderates, the Congressional Budget Office previously found that the 2015 repeal-only bill would lead to 32 million more uninsured people over a decade, with premiums nearly doubling.

Conservatives, including Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) and Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), called for a clean repeal vote on Monday night. "Clean repeal now!" tweeted Sen. Paul. "Time for full repeal of # Obamacare — let's put the same thing on President Trump's desk that we put on President Obama's desk," added Rep. Meadows, chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus.

In contrast, other Republicans, such as Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), called for working with Democrats on a new plan. McCain is currently recovering from surgery, which prompted a delay in consideration of the bill this week. Some Republicans have raised the idea of a bipartisan bill to stabilize ObamaCare markets, which could include funding for key payments to insurers known as cost-sharing reductions and possibly funding to bring down premiums for high-cost enrollees, known as "reinsurance."

However, conservative members, including Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas), have objected to the idea of a stabilization bill as simply throwing more money at the healthcare law. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) put forward a third approach on Monday night, touting a bill he recently proposed with Sen. Cassidy to give states a chunk of money and let them decide whether to keep much of ObamaCare or try something new. That approach has been attacked from both the left and right.

Title: President Trump Surprises Troops in Afghanistan, Holds Secret Thanksgiving Visit

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, President Donald Trump made a surprise visit to Afghanistan on Thanksgiving morning to express gratitude to troops for their service and to share a turkey dinner. The visit required stringent security measures to maintain secrecy and prevent leaks.

Upon arrival, President Trump addressed the troops, stating, "There's nowhere I'd rather spend Thanksgiving than with the toughest, fiercest warriors." He continued, "I'm here to say Happy Thanksgiving and thank you very much. As president of the United States, I have no higher honor than serving as commander in chief."

The journey began on Wednesday, with the president departing from Mar-a-Lago undercover. Details of the departure are scarce, but it is known that Trump flew out of an undisclosed airport in Florida on a small, undisclosed plane in the evening.

The flight to Joint Base Andrews, in Maryland, had only one Fox News journalist, who served as the pool reporter. The plane was sparsely furnished, with four blue leather chairs and a portable toilet brought for the occasion. To maintain security, phones were confiscated from all onboard, including senior White House officials.

Upon landing at Joint Base Andrews, Trump switched to Air Force One, which was hidden in a hangar. The plane took off from JBA with all interior lights off and the windows drawn. The plane landed in Afghanistan on a pitch-black runway, and the pool was only allowed to take pictures of Trump's arrival from a nearby van.

Accompanying Trump were White House Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham, Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien, Deputy Press Secretary Judd Deere, and Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.). Grisham revealed that only a tight circle of White House officials knew about the trip, and the White House even scheduled tweets to be sent out during the Internet blackout that the president faced.

"It's a dangerous area, and he (the President) wants to support the troops," Grisham said. "He and Mrs. Trump recognize that there are a lot of people who are away from their families during the holidays, and we thought it would be a nice surprise."

The visit took many by surprise, including some news outlets. Newsweek had to rewrite an article that initially reported the president would spend the day tweeting and playing golf.

After serving and dining with the troops, President Trump met with Afghan President Ashraf Ghani. Due to security concerns, Ghani was notified only a few hours before the meeting. Trump then addressed a few hundred cheering troops in the hangar on the airfield, bringing Ghani on stage to also express appreciation to the American troops. Trump told them that everyone was working hard to bring them back home.

"We will continue to work tirelessly for the day when all of you can go home to your families... and that day is coming very soon," he said.

Title: Witness Accounts and Details of Terror Incident in London

Article:

Kirsten Hurrell, a 70-year-old newsstand owner opposite Big Ben, reported seeing a car swerve across a bicycle lane and crash into a fence surrounding Parliament. She found a body on the ground and called emergency services. "At first, I thought it was an accident," she said, "but I was told the car had already mowed down quite a number of people on Westminster Bridge."

Robert Vaudry, a 52-year-old fund manager from Stratford-upon-Avon, emerged from the Westminster subway station around 2:40 p.m. for a meeting with a lawmaker when he realized something was amiss. "I came out of the Tube and there were two armed policemen," he said in an interview. "One grabbed my arm, pushed me to the left, and said, 'Get out of here.'" He added, "They were shouting at everyone to get away." As he spoke, police officers were cordoning off the area. One officer shouted, "We need everyone to move back past Downing Street."

Radoslaw Sikorski, a former foreign minister of Poland who was in the area, was in a taxi on Westminster Bridge when pedestrians were hit by the car. "I didn't see the impact, I heard it—it sounded like a car hitting a sheet of metal," he said. "I saw these people lying on the tarmac, on the pavement. I saw five people down, one unconscious and one bleeding heavily from his head. He was not moving."

Andrew Bone, the executive director of the Responsible Jewellery Council, an industry standards group, was on a bus heading toward Victoria Station when it was stopped at the edge of Parliament Square. Seeing the commotion, he initially thought an action movie was being shot, but quickly discerned the gravity of the situation as the bus was evacuated and he saw the vehicle that had crashed into a railing.

"We had a front-row seat as the first responders arrived," Mr. Bone said. "I am of the generation who remembers I.R.A. bombs in London during the Troubles," he said, referring to the sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland. "We are not indifferent, but police have reacted with calm. I saw no panic."

Britain has not suffered a large-scale terrorist attack since July 7, 2005, when bomb attacks on subway trains and on a bus killed more than 50 people. Political violence is relatively rare in Britain, where gun ownership is stringently restricted.

Jo Cox, a Labour member of Parliament, was assassinated in her constituency in northern England on June 16, a week before the contentious referendum on whether Britain should leave the European Union.

In 1979, a lawmaker was assassinated near the Parliament building. Airey Neave, a Conservative Party member, was killed when his car was blown up.

Jeremy Shapiro, a former State Department official now at the European Council on Foreign Relations, said that the London attack was consistent with the recent pattern of attacks in which a vehicle was used to kill people, citing assaults in France, Germany, and Israel.

"We've seen a gradual movement away from terrorist attacks on the West to attacks on softer and softer targets with more improvised weapons," he said. "In a way, it's a sign of desperation and a demonstration of the effectiveness of counterterrorism in the West. It's spectacularly easy to kill a bunch of people with a car or a truck if you don't care who they are."

Title: Trump Drops John Ratcliffe as U.S. Spy Chief Nominee, Considering Alternatives

Article:

President Donald Trump on Friday withdrew his choice of John Ratcliffe to be the U.S. Director of National Intelligence (DNI) after questions arose about the congressman's lack of experience and possible exaggerations in his resume. This marks the latest upheaval over a top national security post.

Trump announced the move five days after he surprised many in Washington by making the conservative Republican lawmaker from Texas his selection to replace Daniel Coats as DNI. The vacancy comes as the U.S. intelligence community grapples with an array of challenges, including the threat of foreign interference in next year's U.S. elections, the impact of a rising China, escalating tensions with Iran, North Korea's nuclear program, and the desire to end years of conflict in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria.

According to a source familiar with the situation, Trump is considering Republican Representatives Michael McCaul and Devin Nunes for the job. McCaul is a former chairman of the House of Representatives Homeland Security Committee, and Nunes is a former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. Trump told reporters at the White House he has "a list of three people" he will consider for the job this weekend.

Ratcliffe, a Trump loyalist and the most junior member of the House Intelligence Committee, had been tapped but not formally nominated to replace Coats. "Rather than going through months of slander and libel, I explained to John how miserable it would be for him and his family to deal with these people," Trump said on Twitter. Ratcliffe, 53, faced a potentially difficult Senate confirmation process.

The change in leadership at the top of the U.S. intelligence community comes after a half-year of turmoil atop the Pentagon. The Senate on July 23 confirmed Army Secretary Mark Esper as defense secretary, ending the longest period that the Pentagon had been without a permanent top official, a stint that began after James Mattis resigned in December over policy differences with Trump. Trump's previous pick for defense secretary, Patrick Shanahan, withdrew in June after reports of domestic violence in his family.

The post of DNI was created after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States. Ratcliffe, confirming he had withdrawn from consideration, said he thought the confirmation process would become a partisan battle between Republicans and Democrats.

Ratcliffe gained attention by defending Trump and criticizing former Special Counsel Robert Mueller during a July hearing on Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election. Although Ratcliffe had touted his counter-terrorism experience as a federal prosecutor in Texas, media outlets including ███ reported on concerns that he may have exaggerated his achievements in the post.

Democratic lawmakers and some former senior U.S. intelligence officers had said Ratcliffe lacked the expertise and experience to replace Coats. Some voiced concern that he would warp U.S. intelligence to support Trump's views. Ratcliffe served for six months on the intelligence panel.

Trump said he might name the No. 2 intelligence official, Sue Gordon, as acting DNI. That is required when there is a vacancy in the top job. Such a move would likely be reassuring to many U.S. intelligence experts because of her deep experience. However, some Trump allies, according to the source familiar with the matter, were floating the possibility of instead naming CIA Director Gina Haspel as acting director until a permanent director is confirmed by the Senate.

Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr said while he was "heartened" that the office of the DNI has an experienced team in place during the transition, "there is no substitute for having a Senate-confirmed director in place" leading it. Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, a critic of Ratcliffe for the job, said in a statement, "The next Director of National Intelligence must be someone who is nonpartisan, sees the world objectively, and speaks truth to power."

U.S. President Donald Trump talks to reporters as he departs for travel to Bedminster, New Jersey from the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, U.S., August 2, 2019. ███/Leah Millis

Ratcliffe joined a growing list of Trump's choices for senior jobs who have had to withdraw, leading to questions about the rigorousness of White House background checks. Asked whether Ratcliffe's history was inadequately reviewed before he was picked, Trump defended the White House process. While Trump regularly attacks the media, he told reporters, "You're part of the vetting process... We save a lot of money that way."

Title: Major US Retailers Implement New Gun Sales Restrictions Following Florida School Shooting

Article:

Two major U.S. retailers, Dick's Sporting Goods and Walmart, have announced new restrictions on gun sales following the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, where 17 people were killed.

Dick's Sporting Goods, with over 600 stores, has decided to stop selling assault-style rifles and high-capacity magazines, and will not sell any firearms to anyone under the age of 21. The company had previously stopped selling such weapons at its main shops after the 2012 Sandy Hook shooting but 35 shops run by a subsidiary called Field & Stream had continued to do so.

Walmart, the largest seller of guns in the U.S., has raised the minimum age for anyone buying guns or ammunition to 21 years and will remove items from its website that resemble assault-style rifles. The retailer stopped selling high-powered rifles in its shops in 2015, citing low demand.

In a statement, Walmart said, "We take seriously our obligation to be a responsible seller of firearms."

In Washington, President Donald Trump urged a group of lawmakers with diverse views to come up with a comprehensive bipartisan solution in a televised meeting. Republican leaders in Congress have rejected raising the minimum legal age to buy rifles from 18 to 21, but Mr. Trump said he "would give pretty serious thought to it."

Dick's Sporting Goods, in announcing its policy change, said, "We have tremendous respect and admiration for the students organizing and making their voices heard regarding gun violence in schools and elsewhere in our country." The company added, "We have heard you. The nation has heard you."

In the aftermath of the shooting, pressure has mounted on U.S. politicians to act on gun control and for corporations to cut ties with the National Rifle Association (NRA). Firms including Hertz car rental, United Airlines, and Delta Airlines have ended discounts to NRA members.

On Wednesday, a teacher in the state of Georgia was arrested after barricading himself in a classroom and firing a handgun. No one was injured.

At Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, a line of police officers, school staff, and community members bearing flowers greeted some 3,000 students who returned to classes on Wednesday morning. There were also many reporters, shouting questions to the teenagers about how they felt.

Lyliah Skinner, a 16-year-old student, told the BBC before she left home, "We're not going to really be learning much today - it's all about healing." She also said she was feeling nervous "because I'm scared it's going to happen again." Lyliah listed people she knew who would not be returning, including Joaquin Oliver, who sat just in front of her in a class they shared.

David Hogg, a senior student and now leading activist, was also feeling trepidation. It was "really hard to think about" what occurred two weeks ago, he said. "Imagine getting in a plane crash and having to get back on the same plane again and again and being expected to learn and act like nothing's wrong," he told NBC News.

The handling of the shooting by authorities sparked criticism after it emerged that the FBI and local police had failed to follow up on multiple tips about the shooter, and that an armed deputy at the school had stayed outside the school building while the attack took place.

The school's Building 12, the site of the shootings, will remain closed and cordoned off indefinitely. Members of Florida's State House and Senate will soon begin reviewing proposed bills related to firearms, which need their approval and also that of Governor Rick Scott.

Among other restrictions, they would raise the legal age to buy rifles from 18 to 21 and give police more control to seize weapons from mentally ill people. A controversial $67m voluntary program to arm school staff, including teachers, would ensure they were trained by law enforcement and allowed to carry concealed weapons on campus, according to the New York Times.

Title: Power Cuts Plague Middle Eastern Countries, Affecting Daily Life and Infrastructure

Article:

A power cut in the midst of a hysterectomy operation in an Egyptian hospital last month left doctors scrambling for alternatives, with a handful of cellphones providing the necessary light. This incident is not an isolated example of the power outages that plague the Middle East, where conflict and severe economic strife have led to regular power cuts.

In Egypt, President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi acknowledged the issue in a half-hour, nationally televised speech, attributing the outages to crumbling infrastructure that requires billions of dollars and time to fix. The outages have caused frustration and anger among the public, with the power cuts lasting for several hours in some cases.

In neighboring Libya, power outages have been common since the 2011 revolution against dictator Moammar Gadhafi. Rival militias in the capital Tripoli have fought for control of the city's international airport since mid-July, affecting many aspects of life, including power supply.

The Gaza Strip has also struggled with power outages, with power sources meeting no more than 70% of the population's needs before its recent war with Israel. The Gaza Strip's only power plant was hit by Israeli shelling, which also damaged transformers and electrical wires, hindering flows of power coming from Israel.

In Iraq, power outages have been a problem since the rule of Saddam Hussein, with electrical flows growing more chaotic over time. In Lebanon, power cuts are so routine that apps for Apple and Android devices were created to let users track them. An ongoing strike by electrical company workers threatens to make matters worse in Lebanon, as limited state funds and increased demand from an influx of more than 1 million Syrian refugees have led to a rise in power rationing.

In Syria, power cuts have hit Damascus, while some parts of Aleppo had no power at all at the end of June. Other districts had less than one hour a day, according to the United Nations. The problem contributes to worsening health conditions.

The power outages have affected daily life, infrastructure, and the economy in these countries, with many people resorting to generators to keep their homes and businesses running. However, the poor cannot afford them, and the lack of a reliable power supply has led to the spoilage of refrigerated medicines and vaccinations, sewage flowing into the Mediterranean Sea, and agricultural irrigation suffering.

In the Gaza Strip, life without electricity can hardly be managed, according to Khalil Abu Shammala, director of the Al Dameer Association for Human Rights. In Baghdad, where stifling summer temperatures routinely hang above 110 degrees, many people have generators, but the poor cannot afford them.

The power outages have been a long-standing issue in the Middle East, with some areas experiencing power cuts since the rule of Saddam Hussein in Iraq. However, the situation has grown more chaotic over time, with the power cuts lasting for several hours in some cases. The leaders of these countries have acknowledged the issue and have pledged to invest in infrastructure to address the problem, but the process will take time and significant investment.

Title: New Zealand Implements Immediate Ban on Assault Rifles Following Christchurch Mosque Shootings

Article:

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced on Thursday the immediate ban on all assault rifles, high-capacity magazines, and military-style semi-automatic rifles in response to the nation's deadliest massacre in history, which occurred on March 15 in Christchurch. The ban, which will be followed by legislation next month, requires New Zealand citizens to make arrangements to turn in weapons banned under the new laws.

Ardern stated that the alleged shooter in the attacks at two Christchurch mosques killed most of the 50 victims with two legally purchased semi-automatic rifles modified with 30-plus round magazines, effectively turning them into military-style semi-automatic weapons. An amnesty will be put in place for weapons to be handed in by citizens, and the New Zealand cabinet will implement a buyback plan for banned weapons. Tightly regulated exemptions will be made for some owners, such as hunters and farmers.

Ardern emphasized that the vast majority of legitimate gun owners in New Zealand will understand that these measures are in the national interest and will take these changes in their stride. She also noted that gun ownership is "a privilege and not a right" in New Zealand.

Since the attacks, Ardern has led a nation trying to grieve and work through the news of the killings, which, in total, rival the annual number of murders in New Zealand. On Tuesday, Ardern told New Zealand's Parliament that tough gun laws were coming and that she would deny the man responsible for the nation's worst terror attack in modern history the one thing he likely craved: fame.

Ardern opened her speech to lawmakers in New Zealand by using the Arabic greeting "As-salamu alaykum," which translates as "Peace be upon you." In her speech, she condemned the suspect in the attacks, stating, "You may have chosen us, but we utterly reject and condemn you."

New Zealand has fewer restrictions on rifles or shotguns than many countries. Handguns are more tightly controlled. About 1.5 million firearms are owned – legally and illegally – by civilians in New Zealand, according to police data tracked by GunPolicy.org, a website run in conjunction with the University of Sydney. This equates to about 30 firearms per 100 people. In the United States, the rate is approximately 120 firearms per 100 people, according to the site.

All gun owners in New Zealand must have a license, which they can get from age 16 (age 18 for semi-automatic weapons), but the weapon itself does not need to be registered with authorities, according to the Council of Licensed Firearms Owners, a New Zealand lobby group. Ardern said the suspect in Friday's attacks had a license and owned five guns. The majority of firearm owners in New Zealand are farmers or hunters.

According to GunPolicy.org, New Zealand is among a handful of countries where police officers are routinely unarmed when they are on patrol. Officers in Britain, Ireland, Norway, and Iceland also carry firearms only in special circumstances.

Australia and Britain both changed their gun laws in response to mass shootings. The Australian government overhauled its gun laws in 1996 after 35 people were murdered during a shooting spree in Tasmania. Australia banned all semi-automatic weapons and restricted certain handguns. It offered to buy back prohibited firearms.

A 2016 study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that Australia had not had a fatal mass shooting – one in which five or more people are killed – since the 1996 shooting. In the 18 years prior to the new laws, there were 13.

The turning point for Britain came in 1996, when a man used a legally owned handgun to kill 16 young children and a teacher at a school in Dunblane, Scotland. In the aftermath, all private ownership of handguns was banned. Since then, there has been one mass shooting, in 2010, in Britain.

The death toll in the attack at the Al Noor and Linwood mosques rose to 50 people Saturday; victims range in age from 2 to over 60. Services for the victims were held at churches across the country Sunday, and people laid flowers at memorial sites. A group of bikers performed the haka – a traditional ceremonial dance of New Zealand's Maori people – at the memorial in Christchurch. Thirty-nine people remain in the hospital, and 11 were in intensive care in critical condition.

Title: Call for Proscription of Order of Nine Angles as Terrorist Organization

Article:

Anti-racism campaign group Hope Not Hate has called for the British government to outlaw the neo-Nazi Satanist group Order of Nine Angles (ONA) as a terrorist organization. In their annual State of Hate report, Hope Not Hate argues that the ONA should be added to the list of proscribed terrorist groups, which is currently under review by the Home Office.

Last week, two British extreme right-wing organizations were added to the list, one of which, Sonnenkrieg Division, is influenced by the ONA's Nazi-Satanist ideology. In the past year, four teenagers linked to the ideology have been jailed in the UK for terror offenses, with one convicted of preparing for a terror attack by following instructions set out in ONA texts.

In court, prosecutors described the ONA as "self-consciously, explicitly malevolent" and the "most prominent and recognizable link between Satanism and the extreme right." The anti-racist campaign group, which investigates violent extremism, argues that the group's "sick ideas have drawn in young extremists in the UK and elsewhere, and have helped nourish a dangerous culture of unprecedented depravity amongst the extreme right, which has none of the moral constraints that previous generations of far-right activists had."

Yvette Cooper MP, chair of the home affairs select committee, has urged the home secretary to immediately refer the ONA to the government's proscription review group. "The combination of Nazi-Satanism, extreme violence, and sexual abuse makes it particularly troubling, and action needs to be taken to prevent them from grooming and radicalizing other people," she said.

A Home Office spokesperson stated that action is being taken to "root out and dismantle the groups that promote extreme right-wing views and we are giving police the tools and resources they need to tackle this threat." The spokesperson added that the list of proscribed organizations is kept under review. Counter-terrorism police have previously spoken about the increasing amount of work relating to "niche ideologies" such as violent Satanism.

Title: Biden's Moderate Label Reflects Shift in Democratic Party

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden addressed union workers at the Teamsters Local 249 hall in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, on April 29, 2019.

The labeling of Biden as a moderate is indicative of the significant shift towards the left within the Democratic Party. At the time of writing, Biden, the most recent candidate to file for the Democratic presidential nomination, is considered a moderate. This characterization underscores both the rapid movement of the party to the left and the liberal lean of the national press.

A Democratic politician is now considered a moderate if they believe in preserving private health insurance and opposing the implementation of a government system, restricting third-trimester abortions, and maintaining deportation as a key aspect of the immigration regime. These positions were once considered compatible with liberal Democratic ideology, as recently as three years ago when Biden was vice president. However, they are now being criticized by left-wing activists who hold significant influence in the party's primaries.

In the progressive media, Biden is facing criticism for not expanding his indictment of President Donald Trump to include an indictment of America for electing him.

As the primary race progresses, there is a possibility that Biden may shift his positions further left to appeal to the party's base. He has already denounced the legal system as "white man's law," which may be a reference to its respect for the presumption of innocence. Clarity on this matter is sought from Biden regarding his comments.

Throughout his career, Biden has been a strong, albeit not wholly consistent, supporter of left-wing causes, including higher taxes, hate-crimes laws, and liberal judicial activism. Conservatives should not be deceived into thinking Biden is a moderate, and neither should actual moderates.

Title: Parents of ISIS Victims Call for U.S. Assistance in Repatriating Hostages

Article:

The parents of victims of the late ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi have appealed to President Trump to collaborate with them in bringing more U.S. hostages and detainees home from around the world. The Trump administration has prioritized the return of American hostages during his presidency. During the announcement of al-Baghdadi's death last weekend, President Trump named some of the innocent Americans who were killed by ISIS, including James Foley and Kayla Mueller.

Dianne Foley, the mother of American journalist James Foley, who was beheaded by ISIS in 2014, expressed gratitude for the president's actions but emphasized the need for further assistance. Kayla Mueller's parents, who conducted a private investigation outside of the government after their daughter was kidnapped in 2013 while serving as an aid worker, praised Trump's actions but called for more focus on finding and rescuing American hostages.

Carl and Marsha Mueller, Kayla Mueller's parents, have found intelligence that they believe the U.S. government has not, but have yet to find their daughter's body. Marsha Mueller stated she was "just numb" when she heard the president's announcement. She expressed the need for the U.S. government's help in locating and rescuing American hostages.

The Muellers have been advocating for their daughter's return since her kidnapping in 2013. They are asking President Trump to work with the individuals they are currently working with to bring the hostages home.

Title: Pennsylvania Congressman Tim Murphy Faces Allegations of Hypocrisy in Abortion Case

Article:

Representative Tim Murphy, a vocal anti-abortion congressman from Pennsylvania, is facing allegations of hypocrisy after it was reported that he asked his girlfriend to terminate a pregnancy this year. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette published the story on Tuesday, citing documents they obtained.

According to the report, Shannon Edwards, a Pittsburgh woman half Murphy's age with whom he admitted to having an extramarital affair, texted Murphy in January about a possible pregnancy that turned out to be a false alarm. Edwards reportedly texted, "You have zero issue posting your pro-life stance all over the place when you had no issue asking me to abort our unborn child just last week when we thought that was one of the options."

Murphy, in response, reportedly admitted to the post-abortion stance but distanced himself from the anti-abortion messages on his professional Facebook account, stating, "I've never written them. Staff does them. I read them and winced. I told staff don't write any more. I will."

The revelation has sparked controversy, as Murphy is a pro-life congressman who has advocated for the U.S. government to define life as beginning at conception, a stance that would outlaw some forms of birth control and force every woman to birth any conceived fetus against her will. The congressman is a current sponsor of the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, a bill that would ban abortion care provided after 20 weeks' gestation, defying the protections enshrined by Roe v. Wade. The House is set to vote on the bill on Tuesday.

Murphy is not the first anti-abortion legislator to face allegations of hypocrisy. Anti-abortion Representative Scott DesJarlais of Tennessee, who is still in office, supported his wife's two abortions and was recorded telling a 24-year-old woman with whom he was having an affair that she had to have an abortion "to get this solved and get it over with so we can get on with our lives." DesJarlais, like Murphy, is also a sponsor of the 20-week abortion ban.

Title: Ted Cruz Apologizes to New Yorkers in Stump Speech in South Carolina

Article:

In TIGERVILLE, South Carolina, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas delivered a speech on Friday, addressing the controversial statement he made about New York values during a previous campaign event. Cruz, who had been criticized by New York residents and officials for his initial comment, appeared eager to spread his message.

During his speech at North Greenville University, Cruz asked the audience, "Do the people of South Carolina know what New York values are?" He followed up his initial question with a series of statements that seemed to criticize New York's political climate, including references to liberal politics, job losses due to fracking bans, and high taxes and regulations affecting small businesses.

Cruz issued apologies in various forms, including remarks to reporters, on Sean Hannity's radio show, a news release, and a tweet. He also addressed specific issues such as the clashes between New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and the police department, as well as the city's charter schools.

In his speech, Cruz stated, "I apologize to the millions of New Yorkers who’ve been abandoned for years by liberal politicians." He also expressed sympathy for New Yorkers who are pro-life, pro-marriage, and pro-Second Amendment, and for small businesses leaving New York City due to high taxes and regulations.

Jim Clinton, a 55-year-old resident of Greer, South Carolina, commented on Cruz's speech, saying, "He basically apologized to the rest of New York."

Title: Trump Administration to Provide $12 Billion in Emergency Aid to Farmers Amid Ongoing Trade Disputes

Article:

President Donald Trump reiterated his support for tariffs on Tuesday via Twitter, stating that the tariffs are "the greatest" and that the United States will either negotiate fair trade deals or impose tariffs. The administration is reportedly planning to provide $12 billion in emergency aid to farmers to cope with the financial turmoil caused by the tariffs, according to Politico.

Farmers have been among the hardest hit by Trump's protectionist trade policies, as foreign countries have retaliated with tens of billions of dollars in tariffs on American agricultural products. China, Mexico, and Canada have imposed tariffs on soybeans, dairy, pork, apples, and potatoes, among other US products, in response to the Trump administration's taxes on imported steel, aluminum, and electronics.

The impact of tariffs on US agriculture has been significant. Prices for agricultural products like soybeans have dropped to a 10-year low since Trump imposed sweeping tariffs on trade and aluminum earlier this year. Farmers across various markets have grown increasingly concerned about the future of their businesses due to the ongoing trade war.

The administration's plan, which has yet to be formally released, is reported to consist of three programs: direct financial assistance for farmers, a purchase and distribution program where the government buys up surplus agricultural products and redistributes them for low-income food assistance, and a trade promotion program.

The Washington Post reported that this stabilization package will utilize a Depression-era program that allows the government to borrow up to $30 billion from the Treasury without congressional approval.

Rep. Mike Conaway (R-TX), who chairs the House Agricultural Committee, expressed confidence last week that the administration would take action to help farmers "persevere" during this period.

"The president has great agriculture advisers around him, and his public comments indicate that he understands this is troubling to the folks in the production of agriculture in Middle America," Conaway said. " [ Agriculture Secretary ] Sonny Perdue has some tools that he's working on to mitigate in some small way the impact the tariffs are having."

Meanwhile, Trump appears to remain steadfast in his tariff agenda, having already threatened to tax foreign car imports ahead of trade talks with the European Union this week and tweeting a positive outlook on the tariffs' impact on the American economy.

"I am fighting for a level playing field for our farmers, and will win!" Trump tweeted earlier this month.

Trump's tariffs have disproportionately affected farmers, and it remains unclear when the trade disputes will end. Agriculture has low barriers to trade, making the industry an easy target for retaliatory tariffs. Already, Mexico, China, and Canada have retaliated to the United States' newly placed steel and aluminum tariffs with tariffs of their own.

"It's one of the few areas that the US has a surplus; it makes sense they would target that," Chad Hart, a crops market specialist with Iowa State University, told ███, adding that there's a political strategy element as well. "It makes sense politically because you are looking at Republican leadership, and farmers do tend to vote more Republican."

The US has approximately $140 billion in agricultural exports per year. Canada and Mexico are major trade partners, together importing about $39 billion. China, Japan, and South Korea import around $39 billion, and Europe makes up around a $12 billion share of agricultural imports. However, tensions are high across the board.

While many farmers are Republicans and Trump supporters—and generally can get behind Trump's call to equalize the playing field—one Wisconsin dairy farmer, Roger Mehre, told ███ earlier in July that farmers in his circles are growing increasingly nervous.

"I almost get the feeling that [Trump] is trying to be a bully and he is making these countries bow to him, and that's just not going to happen," Mehre said, pointing out that it's not just dairy that's affected; it's pork, soybeans, corn, poultry—the list goes on. "We need them, and they need us. Both sides are going to lose."

Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue has attempted to assure farmers they'll be protected from any trade wars, and this emergency aid package is certainly a step to mitigate financial disaster. However, farmers don't have a clear idea of what the president's endgame is, and Trump hasn't tread lightly with his rhetoric. It's something Republican lawmakers from agriculture-heavy states, like Sens. Ben Sasse (R-NE) and Chuck Grassley (R-IA), have warned the administration about.

"This is dumb," Sasse said in a statement in May. "Europe, Canada, and Mexico are not China, and you don't treat allies the same way you treat opponents. We've been down this road before—blanket protectionism is a big part of why America had a Great Depression."

Trump does seem aware of the potential political fallout. But for now, he's trying to convince farmers to stick with him—and his administration is attempting to stanch the bleeding with billions in emergency aid.

Title: Russian Warplane Downed by Turkey: One Crew Member Rescued, International Tensions Escalate

Article:

One of the two crew members of the Russian warplane shot down by Turkey on Tuesday has been rescued, according to Russian officials. The rescue operation ended early Wednesday, as reported by NPR's Corey Flintoff for our Newscast unit. The other crew member was reportedly found dead on Tuesday by a Syrian rebel group.

The incident has escalated international tensions, with both countries exchanging angry rhetoric while calling for military restraint. The Russian Su-24 fighter jet was reportedly flying over Syria when it was shot down by Turkish F-16s, according to Russian officials. Turkey claims the jet was in Turkish airspace and was warned 10 times before being targeted.

Russia maintains the jet was flying over Syria at the time. Both crew members appeared to eject from the jet and parachute to the ground, but one was reportedly found dead Tuesday by a Syrian rebel group. Russia now says the other crew member has been rescued in a 12-hour operation. Rebel fighters in the area claim they shot one of the Russian helicopters involved in the search yesterday and then used a missile to destroy it on the ground after it was forced to land. Russia says one of the helicopter crewmen was killed, but the rest were evacuated safely.

Russia and Turkey continue to exchange heated statements. Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said Wednesday that Russia could not justify its attacks on ethnic Turks in Syria under the pretext of fighting the Islamic State, and reiterated statements by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan that Turkey will continue to defend its airspace. However, Davutoglu said targeting Russia is "out of the question."

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov called the shooting of the plane a "planned provocation" that is prompting Moscow to "reconsider relations with Ankara." On Tuesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin called the shooting a "stab in the back." However, Lavrov says Moscow has "no intention to go to war with Turkey."

Russia is reportedly deploying an advanced anti-aircraft system to its base in Syria. The missiles appear to be guarding against Turkish planes or planes from other coalition members, such as the U.S. or France. As far as we know, ISIS and other jihadi groups in Syria have no aircraft that could threaten the Russian base.

Moscow may be considering nonmilitary forms of retaliation against Turkey. Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev said Wednesday that "important joint projects could be canceled and Turkish firms could lose Russian market share." The two countries' economies are closely linked by energy purchases, tourism, and other business activity.

Title: Bipartisan Senators Close to Deal on Debt Ceiling and Government Shutdown, Reid Rejects Plan

Article:

A bipartisan group of senators, led by Sen. Joe Manchin (D-West Virginia) and Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine), is reportedly 70% to 80% close to a deal that would end the ongoing government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling. The senators have been working on a plan that would provide a longer extension of the debt limit and government funding, as well as a two-year delay on the 2.3% tax on medical devices.

On Monday, Manchin told CNN's Chris Cuomo that they are making progress and have a "good template" for the plan. Collins also told reporters on Capitol Hill Monday morning that the conversations have been "very constructive" and that they are not releasing any details until they have an agreement.

However, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nevada) rejected the plan on Saturday, stating that it "is not going to go anyplace at this stage." Reid expressed that while the plan opens the government and extends the debt ceiling, there is little agreement with the Democrats on other aspects of the plan.

The Senate voted on a separate procedural measure to extend the debt limit with no strings attached on Saturday, but the measure fell short of the 60 votes needed to proceed. The Senate will reconvene Monday at 2 p.m. ET, while the House meets at noon.

A key sticking point for Democrats is sequestration, as the Collins' plan gives "flexibility" on the spending cuts, but Democrats and the White House do not want to agree to anything that allows another round of the spending limits to kick in as they are supposed to in mid-January.

Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tennessee), who has been working closely with Manchin and Collins on the deal, said he has reason to believe the Senate will come to an agreement Monday.

Before leaving Capitol Hill on Sunday, Reid struck a positive note as he spoke on the Senate floor, stating, "I've had a productive conversation with the Republican leader this afternoon. Our discussions were substantive, and we'll continue those discussions. I'm optimistic about the prospects for a positive conclusion."

Title: Clinton Interviewed by FBI in Email Investigation; Trump Calls for Charges

Article:

Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump called for charges to be filed against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton on Saturday following her meeting with the FBI regarding the agency's investigation into her use of a private email server for official correspondence.

"It is impossible for the FBI not to recommend criminal charges against Hillary Clinton," Trump tweeted Saturday afternoon. "What she did was wrong! What Bill did was stupid!"

The Clinton campaign stated that the voluntary meeting, which took place at FBI headquarters in Washington, lasted about three-and-a-half hours. Clinton's campaign spokesman Nick Merrill said in a statement that Clinton, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, would have no further comment about the interview.

The Clinton campaign issued the statement Saturday shortly before 12:30 p.m. ET, minutes after Clinton returned to her Washington home and then departed again about 30 minutes later.

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus stated, "Hillary Clinton has just taken the unprecedented step of becoming the first major party presidential candidate to be interviewed by the FBI as part of a criminal investigation surrounding her reckless conduct." He continued, "We must ask ourselves if this is the kind of leadership we want in the White House."

There was no immediate comment from the FBI or Justice Department Saturday.

Clinton's use of a private server and email address, and whether classified information was mishandled as a result of that setup, has cast a shadow over her campaign from the start. The FBI investigation is purportedly coming to a close, and the Clinton interview is considered among the final steps in the case.

Trump has seized on the email issue and repeatedly said the probe undermines Clinton's fitness for office. Trump has called his opponent "Crooked Hillary" and said she cannot be trusted in the White House.

Clinton has argued that she is more trustworthy than Trump on handling the issues that matter to most Americans: foreign policy, national security, and running the economy. However, the email investigation has lingered throughout her campaign, and Trump has asserted that Clinton will receive leniency from a Democratic administration.

Earlier this week, the entire, ongoing email scandal grew when Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, initiated an impromptu meeting with Attorney General Loretta Lynch on her airplane in Phoenix.

"The American people need to have confidence that the Obama Justice Department is conducting a fair and impartial investigation," Priebus also said. "When the attorney general meets secretly with Bill Clinton just days before Hillary's interrogation is conducted discreetly over a holiday weekend, it raises serious concerns about special treatment."

There was already speculation about whether an agency under the Obama administration could conduct an unbiased probe, which only intensified after Clinton met with Lynch, a President Obama appointee who decides whether to bring charges in the case. Lynch says she will accept whatever recommendations she receives from the agency's career prosecutors and lawyers.

Clinton has said relying on a private server was a mistake but that other secretaries of state had also used a personal email address. The matter was referred for investigation last July by the inspectors general for the State Department and intelligence community following the discovery of emails that they said contained classified information.

The State Department's inspector general, the agency's internal watchdog, said in a blistering audit in May that Clinton and her team ignored clear warnings from State Department officials that her email setup violated federal standards and could leave sensitive material vulnerable to hackers. Clinton declined to talk to the inspector general, but the audit reported that Clinton feared "the personal being accessible" if she used a government email account.

Agents have already interviewed top Clinton aides including her former State Department chief of staff Cheryl Mills and Huma Abedin, a longtime aide who is currently the vice chairwoman of Clinton's campaign. The staffer who set up the server, Bryan Pagliano, was granted limited immunity from prosecution by the Justice Department last fall in exchange for his cooperation. The FBI, as a matter of course, seeks to interview individuals central to an investigation before concluding its work.

The emails were routed through a server located in the basement of Clinton's New York home during her tenure as the nation's top diplomat from 2009 to 2013. Dozens of the emails sent or received by Clinton through her private server were later determined to contain classified material. Clinton has repeatedly said that none of the emails were marked classified at the time they were sent or received. As part of the probe, she has turned over the hard drive from her email server to the FBI.

Title: Satellite Images Confirm Destruction of Oldest Christian Monastery in Iraq by Islamic State

Article:

Satellite images obtained by the Associated Press have confirmed the destruction of St Elijah's Monastery, the oldest Christian monastery in Iraq, by the jihadist group Islamic State (IS). The monastery, known as Deir Mar Elia, stood on a hill near the northern city of Mosul for 1,400 years before its alleged demolition in late 2014, soon after IS seized the city.

Analysts suggest that the images indicate the monastery was demolished between August and September 2014. Stephen Wood of Allsource Analysis told AP that the satellite images published on Wednesday showed that the stone walls have been "literally pulverized."
