Bulldozers, heavy equipment, sledgehammers, and possibly explosives were used to destroy the monastery completely.

St Elijah's Monastery was believed to have been constructed by Assyrian monks in the late 6th Century and was later claimed by a Chaldean Catholic order. In 1743, its monks were given an ultimatum by Persian forces to convert to Islam. They refused, and as many as 150 were massacred.

The destruction of the monastery is part of IS's campaign against religious minorities in Iraq and neighboring Syria. The group has seized their property, forced them to convert to Islam, pay a special tax, or flee. IS has also demolished a number of monasteries and churches, as well as renowned pre-Islamic sites including Nimrud, Hatra, and Nineveh in Iraq and Palmyra in Syria.

The monastery attracted all the people from Mosul - Christians and Muslims. It became a spiritual place for Christians to visit and have religious ceremonies. Father Paul Thabit Habib, a Catholic priest from Mosul, stated that the monastery "became a very important place for the history of the Church in Iraq."

In the 1970s, the monastery became a base for the Iraqi Republican Guard. In 2003, one of its walls was damaged by the impact of a T-72 tank turret that was hit by a missile during the US-led invasion of Iraq. The US Army used the monastery as a base itself, before a chaplain recognized its importance, and a commander ordered it to be cleared.

The destruction of St Elijah's Monastery is a significant loss for Iraq's Christian history. Due to security reasons, journalists and archaeologists cannot go to IS-controlled areas, making it difficult to verify the status of ancient sites. However, IS has not released any video on its propaganda outlets showing the demolition of this particular ancient site. More than 100 churches and monasteries have been razed to the ground in Mosul and the predominantly Christian villages surrounding it since they took control of the area in 2014.

Title: Trump-Media Relationship: A Contentious but Symbiotic Bond

Article:

WASHINGTON -- The relationship between President Donald Trump and the mainstream media has been characterized by a love-hate dynamic, with the President frequently criticizing the media, referring to them as the "enemy of the American people." In response, the media has not shied away from counterpunching.

"We are not fake news," said Jeff Mason, President of the White House Correspondents' Association. "We are not failing news organizations, and we are not the enemy of the American people."

The tension between the two parties was evident from the president's first press conference, a testy affair marked by verbal sparring. Trump exclaimed, "The public does not believe you people anymore!"

A Media Research Center study indicates that 89% of the Trump coverage by major media networks is negative. Corey Lewandowski, former Trump campaign manager, believes this treatment is deliberate.

"They want to highlight what they perceive to be failures," Lewandowski said. "This is exactly what they did during the campaign. They said the president would never run, that he would never be successful, the campaign was in shambles."

Lewandowski added, "But it was not. It was not sophisticated enough. But the American people stepped up and said, 'we want Donald Trump' and voted for him."

Lewandowski stated that all the president wants is a fair portrayal and the whole story to be told. "When he does a long interview with a major publication like The New York Times or The Wall Street Journal, all he asks for is don't edit it. Just print it verbatim, and if you do that, he believes that to be a fair interview," he told the news outlet.

The mainstream media has pushed back against this portrayal. Paul Farhi, media reporter for The Washington Post, stated, "I think Trump makes a very big show of disliking us, disrespecting us, and disparaging us, but I think in fact, secretly, or maybe not so secretly, really likes us."

Farhi continued, "He loves the attention, has used that attention for his own advancement, and has really courted the media in a lot of ways."

Trump courts the media, sending handwritten notes of praise or criticism. Farhi asserts that Trump is a media-savvy individual who knows how to leverage the media to disseminate his message.

"Trump is a very sophisticated media animal," Farhi said. "He has worked with the New York media, which is the most intense for decades. He knows his way around and he knows how to utilize the media to get his message out."

The question now is whether this daily soap opera drama will continue for the next four years. Jake Sherman with Politico stated there is no reason to believe anything will change.

"Donald Trump is 70 years old," he noted. "He's not going to change, so if we're looking for some sort of major course correction or a major shift in dynamic, we're not going to get that. He is who he is, and you're not going to change that at this point in the game."

One potential development could be Trump's efforts to change the country's libel and slander laws to make it easier to sue reporters and media outlets over their stories. This could mark the next level in an escalating conflict with no clear end in sight.

Title: Congressional Democrats Criticize Obama Administration Over NSA Surveillance Programs

Article:

Congressional Democrats have criticized the Obama administration following revelations that the National Security Agency (NSA) broke privacy rules and overstepped its authority thousands of times since 2008. The details were reported late Thursday in The Washington Post, based on an audit and other secret documents provided by NSA leaker Edward Snowden.

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi called the latest reports "extremely disturbing." Rep. Mike Thompson, D-Calif., a member of the House Intelligence Committee, said, "Reports that the NSA repeatedly overstepped its legal boundaries, broke privacy regulations, and attempted to shield required disclosure of violations are outrageous, inappropriate, and must be addressed."

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said he planned to hold another hearing in the wake of the report. "The American people rely on the intelligence community to provide forthright and complete information so that Congress and the courts can properly conduct oversight," Leahy said in a statement. "I remain concerned that we are still not getting straightforward answers from the NSA."

The Obama administration has repeatedly stated that Congress was thoroughly briefed on the programs revealed by Snowden in June. The two programs, which vacuum up vast amounts of metadata and global Internet usage data, have been a source of controversy and concern for many Americans.

Proposed legislation to dismantle the programs was narrowly defeated last month in the House, and at least 19 other pending bills are aimed at restraining NSA's powers or changing how the agency is regulated, according to a count kept by the ACLU.

Obama sought to soothe concerns by promising to consider reforms to NSA surveillance a week ago. "It's not enough for me to have confidence in these programs," he said at a White House news conference. "The American people have to have confidence in them as well."

The most serious incidents included a violation of a court order and unauthorized use of data about more than 3,000 Americans and green-card holders. Most of the infractions revealed late Thursday involve unauthorized surveillance of Americans or foreign intelligence targets in the United States, both of which are restricted by law and executive order, according to the May 3, 2012 audit, and other top-secret documents.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, backed up the administration on its claims, releasing a lengthy statement on Friday afternoon claiming that most the compliance problems at the NSA happen when the agency inadvertently collects records on a non-American who enters the U.S., a point when the NSA is supposed to follow different procedures.

The White House issued a statement saying, "the majority of the compliance incidents are unintentional." The statement also directed questions to the National Security Council, and NSC spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden directed questions to the NSA. NSA spokeswoman Vanee Vines said the number of incidents in the first quarter of 2012 was higher than normal, and that the number has ranged from 372 to 1,162 in the past three years.

Title: Obama Urges Congress to Revive Economic Stimulus Legislation

Article:

President Obama has called on Congress to reconsider a set of legislative proposals aimed at stimulating the economy, which were initially proposed in September. The initiatives include investments in infrastructure, tax breaks for small businesses, and funding for teachers, firefighters, and other public sector workers.

In a statement on Friday, Obama cited economic headwinds from Europe as a reason for the renewed push. The European debt crisis and the resulting economic malaise are adding to concerns that American exports may slow.

Congressional Republicans declined to pass the measures last year, and until recently, the Obama administration had joined them in moving on to other debates. However, a series of unfavorable economic reports, particularly on the labor market, have sparked concern that the economy is starting to slow, and further fiscal stimulus may be needed to maintain growth rates.

The current Congress, known more for its partisanship than its legislative abilities, is unlikely to heed Obama's call. Lawmakers will recess in July and already face deadlines on student loan and highway funding bills. They will return from recess to face the so-called fiscal cliff.

The "cliff" includes the expiration of the Bush tax cuts, middle-class protection from the Alternative Minimum Tax, and more than 50 "temporary" tax breaks for individuals and businesses that are set to run out. It also includes nearly $1 trillion in across-the-board spending cuts across many areas of the federal budget. These would take a significant bite out of defense and non-defense spending.

A number of stimulus measures, such as the payroll tax cut and extended unemployment benefits, will also be ending. Congress must act before the end of the year.

Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, speaking to members of Congress on Thursday, said the body should move quickly to resolve the issue. Bernanke stated that going over the cliff would "pose a significant threat to the recovery." He added that uncertainty over the issue's resolution, largely in Congress's hands, could "undermine business and household confidence."

Despite the pleas from Bernanke and Obama, lawmakers are unlikely to move quickly on legislation that would provide further stimulus or certainty to markets. Republicans find the prospect of further spending to be anathema, and election year politics is unlikely to allow for compromise. Every House seat, one-third of the Senate, and the presidency are up for grabs in November.

Obama, perhaps acknowledging that his plea for action will fall on deaf ears, suggested that Congress will be held accountable. "If Congress decides despite all that that they are not going to do anything about this simply because it's an election year, then they should explain to the American people why," he said.

Title: Tectonic Shift in U.S. Gun Policy: A Year After Parkland Shooting

Article:

One year after the tragic shooting in Parkland, Florida, a significant shift in U.S. gun policy has occurred, marked by the implementation of "red flag" laws in nine states, bringing the total to 14. These laws allow for the temporary seizure of weapons under various circumstances, such as domestic battery or social media threats. According to Adam Winkler, author of "Gunfight: The Battle Over the Right to Bear Arms in America," this shift has resulted in approximately 140 million Americans living in states leaning towards more gun control, compared to about 112 million previously.

Robert Spitzer, author of "The Politics of Gun Control," notes that the rhetoric of the gun rights movement, which had previously co-opted the language of civil rights, has become less effective due to the increased number of mass shootings and the implementation of gun control measures. He states, "We don't have tens of thousands of people being rousted in the middle of the night by the police [to take their guns]... That rhetoric gets dulling and not very effective after a while."

President Trump has appointed two justices known for their pro-gun rights views, and a gun rights case originating from New York City is set to be heard this spring. However, the powerful appeals from Florida shooting survivors, including former Representative Gabrielle Giffords, a mass shooting survivor herself, have led to what Giffords calls a "tectonic shift" in U.S. gun policy. This shift comes as the National Rifle Association (NRA) has faced challenges with financing and has become embroiled in the investigation of Russian meddling in U.S. political affairs.

These charts illustrate the impact of the youth movement sparked by the Parkland shooting on political thinking and the balance between the Second Amendment and public safety in the U.S.

Title: Republican Party Shifts Stance on Immigration: A Look at the New Statement of Principles

Article:

In 2012, the Republican Party's stance on immigration, as exemplified by Mitt Romney's opposition to the Dream Act, garnered 27% of the Latino vote, leading to a reevaluation of their policies on issues significant to Hispanics. The new statement of "principles on immigration" issued by congressional Republicans, however, does not reflect the same sentiment.

The statement, released recently, acknowledges the plight of individuals brought to the U.S. illegally as children and advocates for a path to legal residence and eventual citizenship for those who meet certain requirements, such as paying back taxes, passing background checks, and learning English.

The 2012 party platform had been critical of any form of amnesty and had promised steps to encourage "self-deportation." However, the new statement accepts that these individuals could live legally and without fear in the U.S. under specific conditions.

On the issue of citizenship, the Republicans' stance differs from President Barack Obama's, who aims to create a new avenue for the undocumented to be naturalized. Yet, the Republicans do not rule out eventual citizenship and address the most pressing concerns of the undocumented: ending their fear of deportation and allowing them to work legally.

The statement's call for securing the borders and implementing E-Verify, a system that would require the federal government to confirm the employment eligibility of every new hire in America, has drawn criticism. Economist John Cochrane of the University of Chicago and the Hoover Institution has argued that such a system could potentially silence opponents by controlling their ability to earn a living.

The congressional Republicans' new stance on immigration represents a significant shift, offering legal status to millions of people but not assuring them eventual citizenship. This compromise, while authentic, perpetuates the fantasy of eradicating illegal immigration by empowering government. However, it marks progress towards reality, and time may reveal if the Republicans will fully embrace this new approach.

Title: European Union Imposes Tough Economic Sanctions on Russia, Citing Ukraine Conflict

Article:

The European Union (EU) has adopted a series of tough economic sanctions against Russia in response to the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine. The measures, coordinated with the United States, include an arms embargo and a ban on the sale of dual-use and sensitive technologies, such as advanced energy technology equipment relevant for deep sea and Arctic drilling.

Under the financial sanctions, Russian state-owned banks will be prohibited from selling bonds or equities with a maturity of over 90 days in European capital markets. Additionally, eight individuals close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and three entities have been added to the list of people and companies subject to EU-wide asset freezes and travel bans.

The new sanctions come as Ukrainian forces reportedly make rapid gains near the site where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed on July 17. According to reports, Ukrainian forces are attempting to split the territory held by pro-Russian rebels into two parts between the major cities of Donetsk and Luhansk, and to cut off supply lines from Russia to the rebels.

Igor Girkin, a Russian citizen who is the top defense official in the separatist Donetsk People's Republic, stated on Monday that more than 100 wounded separatist fighters had been evacuated to Russia. Meanwhile, the self-proclaimed Prime Minister of the separatist republic, Alexander Borodai, left the rebel-held territory for Moscow on Monday, sparking speculation that the rebels may be fleeing the city.

The EU measures were decided at a meeting of ambassadors from the bloc's 28 member countries. The new sanctions will take immediate effect and will be codified in legal language and published on Thursday. The new names to be added to the travel ban and assets freeze list should be known on Wednesday.

The Western nations are demanding Russia halt the alleged supply of arms to Ukrainian separatists and other actions that destabilize the situation in eastern Ukraine. The EU official stated that the approach will be under constant review and can be adjusted in light of new developments. Normally, sanctions are in place for one year.

French President Francois Hollande stated that Western leaders "regretted" that Russia has not effectively pressured separatists to negotiate nor taken expected concrete measures to assure control of the Russian-Ukrainian border. Neither set of penalties is expected to fully cut off Russian economic sectors from the West, an option U.S. officials have said they are holding in reserve in case Russia launches a full-on military incursion in Ukraine or takes a similarly provocative step.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov stated that any sanctions imposed by the U.S. and European countries on Russia would not be effective. "We will overcome any difficulties that may arise in certain areas of the economy, and maybe we will become more independent and more confident in our own strength," he said, according to Reuters.

Title: Donald Trump to Visit Seven States for Five Rallies on Sunday

Article:

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump will visit seven states on Sunday, holding five rallies in a series of events leading up to the finish of the 2016 election. The campaign schedule includes stops in Colorado, Iowa, Minnesota, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Virginia.

Trump will begin the day in Denver, Colorado, following a rally in Reno, Nevada, on Saturday. He will then travel to Sioux City, Iowa, for a rally at the Sioux City Convention Center at 12:00 p.m. Central Standard Time (CST).

From Iowa, Trump will proceed to Minnesota, a state where the race is closer than expected. The latest ███/Gravis poll shows Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton tied in Minnesota. Trump will address supporters at the Sun Country Airlines Hangar at 2:00 p.m. CST.

Following the Minnesota rally, Trump will travel to Michigan, where he will hold a rally at the Freedom Hill Amphitheater in Sterling Heights, north of Detroit, at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time (EST).

Next, Trump will travel to Moon Township, Pennsylvania, near Pittsburgh, where he will hold a rally at the Atlantic Aviation hangar at 8:00 p.m. EST.

Finally, Trump will travel to Virginia, where he will hold his last rally of the day at the Loudoun Fairgrounds at 9:30 p.m. EST. He will then fly to Sarasota late Sunday night, completing his seven-state Sunday.

Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton will be addressing two events on Sunday: a get-out-the-vote event with LeBron James in Cleveland, Ohio, and another rally in Manchester, New Hampshire, at the Whittemore Center Arena with President Barack Obama at 3:00 p.m.

Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███, has a new book titled "See No Evil: 19 Hard Truths the Left Can't Handle." The book is available from Regnery through Amazon. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Title: Senate's Attempt to Repeal and Replace Obamacare Fails, Leaving Future of Affordable Care Act Uncertain

Article:

The Senate's effort to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has failed, leaving the future of the healthcare law uncertain. Here's what the death of the "repeal and replace" bill could mean for you.

While Republicans have argued that Obamacare is collapsing under its own weight, independent analyses suggest a different conclusion. The focus of the debate primarily concerns the health insurance marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act for people who don't get coverage through an employer or a government program like Medicare or Medicaid. Approximately 7% of the country buys coverage on the individual market.

If the law is not changed, the marketplaces will be largely stable in most parts of the country, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. Participating insurers are on track to have their best year in the marketplaces since they began in 2014, according to the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation.

However, some major players, such as Anthem, plan to no longer offer coverage in many places next year due to uncertainty about federal policy. Yet, Centene, another insurer, is expanding its coverage areas. Centene CEO Michael Neidorff said Tuesday the company's marketplace business "continues to be particularly strong."

Still, those buying coverage on the exchanges are likely to have fewer options next year. There are more than 24,000 people currently buying insurance on the exchanges who live in counties which might not have a participating insurance provider, according to preliminary insurance filings. Final decisions won't be made until fall.

"The individual insurance market has been stabilizing, but it needs continued support and can be undermined," tweeted Larry Levitt, senior vice president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, on Friday. "Congress could play a big role in shoring them up and improving affordability."

Premiums continue to be out of reach for some people, particularly those who don't qualify for federal subsidies. And the cheapest plans come with high deductibles that can also make it difficult to access coverage.

The pool of people using the exchanges has been sicker and older than anticipated, leading to higher premiums and fewer insurance companies willing to participate. One reason there aren't more younger, healthier people buying insurance on the exchange is due to one of the ACA's most popular provisions: the requirement that insurers let young adults stay on their parents' plans until age 26. The Obama administration also allowed people to keep their pre-ACA plans longer than originally anticipated, which kept some healthier people from moving to the marketplace. Insurers complain that the ACA's penalties for not having coverage are too lenient, and that it's too easy for people to enroll only when they anticipate needing care.

Do Republicans share some of the blame for existing problems? In 2014, Congressional Republicans limited the funding in one part of the ACA that helped offset extreme losses by insurers as the marketplaces were being started. Republicans also took the Obama administration to court to block payments to insurance companies for subsidies that reduce deductibles and co-payments for lower-income customers.

The administration has kept insurance companies guessing about whether it will continue to reimburse them for the cost-sharing subsidies. The administration has also eased enforcement of the requirement that most people have insurance. Those acts are the main drivers of the premium increases sought by insurers for next year, according to the consulting firm Oliver Wyman. The uncertain future of the cost-sharing subsidies is the main factor Anthem CEO Joseph Swedish cited Wednesday when telling investors the company may pull out of more state exchanges unless Washington takes steps to stabilize the market.

If Democrats and Republicans want to improve the marketplaces, what could they do? Besides ending the dispute over the cost-sharing subsidies, lawmakers could also continue one of the other industry supports which was only supposed to be temporary. That program essentially subsidizes the cost of the sickest customers, which would reduce premiums. Experts have proposed many other changes, including expanding premium subsidies, giving insurers incentives to sell plans in counties that would otherwise lack coverage, and making families eligible for premium subsidies if plans offered by an employer aren't affordable. Some of those changes would be easier to pass than others, and Majority Leader Mitch McConnell warned Friday morning that Republicans will not pass a "bailout" for insurance companies.

Most of the gains in insurance coverage since the ACA was passed have come through the law's expansion of Medicaid eligibility, even though 19 states have chosen not to expand the program. But more states are expected to do so. If the law isn't changed, 80% of the population could live in states that expanded Medicaid by 2026, CBO has estimated.

States that haven't expanded may be more likely to if they can get permission from the Trump administration to not follow some Medicaid rules. Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price has told governors he's eager to approve alternative Medicaid models. But advocates for the poor could challenge any actions like work requirements that they think go beyond what's allowed without changing the law.

Title: Democratic Victories in Virginia and New Jersey Signal Potential Republican Losses in Suburban Areas Ahead of 2018 Congressional Races

Article:

The recent election victories by Democrats in Virginia and New Jersey indicate a potential loss for the Republican party in suburban areas, as President Donald Trump's unpopularity could negatively impact the party in next year's congressional races.

The results from Tuesday, particularly in Virginia, suggest that Trump's strategy of catering to a loyal but limited base has not enabled him to broaden support for his presidency or his party. Democrats were elated, believing that control of the U.S. House of Representatives, currently controlled by Republicans, and perhaps even the Senate, might be up for grabs in next year's elections.

Some Republicans shared this view after their party's candidates did poorly among independent, college-educated, women, and minority voters in suburban areas. "Unless we get our act together, we are going to lose heavily," said Republican Senator John McCain on Wednesday. Democrats would need to pick up 24 seats next year to retake control of the House. Should that happen, Trump's policy agenda would be effectively dead, and the administration would come under greater scrutiny.

The win by Democrat Phil Murphy in New Jersey's governor's race came as no surprise due to the unpopularity of outgoing Republican Governor Chris Christie. However, Ralph Northam's 9-point victory over Republican Ed Gillespie for governor in swing-state Virginia was larger than expected.

Trump quickly tried to distance himself from Gillespie's poor showing, stating on Twitter that the Republican candidate "worked hard but did not embrace me or what I stand for." Still, Trump's leadership record appeared to motivate Democrats to vote in record numbers in Virginia, with exit polls showing that many came out simply to express their displeasure with the president.

"Trump is turning off more voters than he's bringing in," said Rodell Mollineau, a Democratic strategist in Washington. "His base is strong, but it isn't growing." During his first year in office, Trump has consistently played to a base of passionate supporters, many of them older white men who live in rural areas declining in population, and has shown little inclination to reach out to the majority of voters who disapprove of him.

Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster based in Virginia, said the party was on a risky track. "Republicans have traded fast-growing upscale suburban counties for slow-growing or declining rural areas. That is not a formula for long-term success."

There may also be signs of slippage in Trump's political base. In Virginia, Gillespie campaigned hard on immigration and crime - two hot issues with the president's supporters - but did worse than expected in some rural and suburban areas that Trump easily won last year. In rural Dickenson County, considered to be the heart of Trump country in Virginia, Gillespie's margin over Northam was almost 7 percentage points less than Trump's margin of victory over Democrat Hillary Clinton last year.

Trump won the city of Virginia Beach in 2016 by 3 points, but Gillespie lost to Northam there by 5, a swing of eight points. More critically, Gillespie was blown out by Northam in northern Virginia's populous suburbs, where Trump also struggled in the presidential race. "The suburbs came out in full force," said Matt Mackowiak, a Republican strategist. "They appear to be very motivated to try and deliver a message to Trump."

In growing Loudoun County, outside of Washington, Democrat Barack Obama barely edged out Republican Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential race. On Tuesday, Northam buried Gillespie there by almost 20 points. "I'm worried," said Ari Fleischer, a former White House spokesman for Republican President George W. Bush, to Fox News on Wednesday. "Democrats came out in huge numbers yesterday in the races, and if they have that kind of enthusiasm going into 2018, it's going to be very tough sailing for Republicans."

Gillespie, a longtime Washington insider and lobbyist, tried to keep his distance from Trump personally even as he adopted some of his more combative campaign rhetoric. It was a strategy that failed, and Mackowiak said the result reflected Trump's historically low approval rating. "I don't think the White House was worried about that before, but now I think they have to be."

The five-day Ipsos tracking poll has Trump hovering around 35% approval nationally, with close to 60% of respondents disapproving of his performance in office. A person familiar with Trump's political operation dismissed the election results on Tuesday as having anything to do with the president, noting that both New Jersey and Virginia were won by Clinton in 2016. Andrew Surabian, an adviser to the pro-Trump political group Great America Alliance, said Gillespie lost because he was exactly the kind of establishment Republican that Trump voters have rejected. "Ed Gillespie's campaign went down in flames because he failed to fully embrace the president or his agenda," Surabian said, "and without a coherent message and an authentic messenger, Republican candidates will not be successful moving forward."

Title: Michigan's Plan to Send Vote-by-Mail Applications to All Registered Voters: Legal Implications and Funding Concerns

Article:

President Donald Trump has criticized Michigan's plan to send absentee ballot applications to all of its 7.7 million registered voters, claiming it is illegal and without authorization. The Trump campaign has a legal case against the state sending unsolicited vote-by-mail applications to voters, as the key issue lies in the term "unsolicited."

The New York Times, in its own fact-check, notes that a Trump campaign official cited a 2008 Michigan case in which a judge stated that local clerks could not send absentee ballot applications to a limited universe of voters. However, the Times adds that this was before a 2018 ballot initiative that amended the state's constitution to allow absentee voting for any reason.

The 2018 amendment, known as Proposition 3, does not explicitly authorize state authorities to send unsolicited applications. It allows voters to apply to vote by mail for any reason and grants state election authorities the authority to make absent voter ballots available for voting in person at additional times and places. However, it does not authorize state authorities to make voting by mail more available than required or to send unsolicited applications.

In the 2008 case, Fleming v. Macomb, the Michigan Court of Appeals held unanimously that while private entities, including political parties, may send unsolicited absentee ballot applications to their members, the state itself cannot. The court referred to Michigan's election statute, which, even after the 2018 amendment, does not provide the express authority for state or local officials to mail ballot applications to voters who have not requested them first.

The Times' fact-check claims that the 2008 case is no longer applicable because it involved sending applications to a limited universe of voters. While that was one of the issues in the lawsuit, it was not the basis for the court's decision. The fact that voters can already print ballot applications at home also suggests that the state did not contemplate a need to authorize officials to mail unsolicited applications.

Therefore, President Trump's claim that Michigan's effort "was done illegally and without authorization" has a solid legal ground, well-rooted in precedent and the text of the Michigan election statute. As for funding, it is possible that Trump could withhold other, future funding to the state, though that could prove more politically damaging than the risk of voter fraud itself.

Title: Criticism Mounts Over Obama Administration's Deportation Policy Results

Article:

Immigrant advocacy groups have criticized the Obama administration's recent findings that a policy designed to reduce the deportations of otherwise law-abiding illegal immigrants has had minimal effect. The government's ongoing review found that fewer than 2 percent of the more than 400,000 pending deportation cases have been halted.

The Obama administration announced a shift in focus to the deportation of convicted criminals, people who pose a clear risk to national security, and others who defraud the visa system last year. The administration's immigration policies have drawn criticism from all sides. Republicans argue that the administration is trying to circumvent immigration laws to grant amnesty and blocked the Senate's passage of the DREAM Act bill in 2010.

Immigrant advocates and Latino leaders have criticized Obama for increasing the pace of deportations beyond that of the Bush administration. The Obama administration's tougher enforcement has led to the deportation of a record 1.1 million people in the last three years. The deportations have compounded Latinos' frustrations over Obama's failure to fulfill his 2008 campaign promise of pushing an immigration overhaul through Congress, as well as the failed DREAM Act.

Critics argue that the stepped-up enforcement continues to target people who are supposed to be protected under the new policy. They say ICE is not effectively applying its newfound discretion, in part by declining to offer the full range of options called for in the new policy even though people in a majority of cases meet the standards.

Crystal Williams, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, said on the call that most people are being offered administrative closure without the option to obtain work: "It's putting your file on a shelf. That's it. No other possibilities are being offered, like the settlement of cases, adjustment of status."

As a result, critics say, the new policy likely will clear no more than 5 percent of the cases. ICE Director John Morton told NPR's Weekend Edition Saturday that the targeting of serious criminal offenders is driving the deportation numbers. He said roughly 216,000 criminals were removed last year.

Title: House Democrats Vow to Investigate Allegations of Trump-Cohen Collusion in Moscow Project

Article:

WASHINGTON – Two House Democratic committee chairmen have vowed to investigate allegations in a published report that President Donald Trump personally ordered his former attorney and fixer Michael Cohen to lie to Congress about a potential real-estate development in Moscow.

Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.), chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, tweeted, "We know that the President has engaged in a long pattern of obstruction." He continued, "Directing a subordinate to lie to Congress is a federal crime. The @ HouseJudiciary Committee’s job is to get to the bottom of it, and we will do that work."

Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), who chairs the House Intelligence Committee, also vowed to "do what’s necessary to find out if it’s true." He tweeted, "The allegation that the President of the United States may have suborned perjury before our committee in an effort to curtail the investigation and cover up his business dealings with Russia is among the most serious to date."

The report, published by BuzzFeed News, claims Trump directed Cohen to mislead Congress about when negotiations to launch a condo project in Russia's capital ended, as well as the extent of Trump's involvement in the deal. It later fell apart.

Trump did not comment directly on the claim, but retweeted a Fox News story that mentioned Cohen has been convicted of perjury and fraud, and is reportedly under investigation over other matters.

"Lying to reduce his jail time!" Trump tweeted. "Watch father-in-law!"

Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani called Cohen "a convicted criminal and a liar," according to a statement. "Any suggestion – from any source – that the President counseled Michael Cohen to lie is categorically false."

As of Friday afternoon, BuzzFeed, which cited two unnamed law enforcement officials for its report, has not independently confirmed the report.

The report further claimed that the office of special counsel Robert Mueller investigating Trump's Russia ties has additional evidence about the alleged deception backed up by "interviews with multiple witnesses from the Trump Organization and internal company emails, text messages, and a cache of other documents."

Cohen previously testified he falsely told Congress that Trump’s attempt to get the Moscow project off the ground concluded in January 2016 when he actually continued to pursue the project through June 2016. Cohen pleaded guilty in November to lying to Congress on this matter.

He is now cooperating with Mueller's probe and agreed to appear before the House Oversight Committee on Feb. 7 before he begins a three-year prison term in March for crimes that include arranging for payments during the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign to silence women who claimed they had extramarital affairs with Trump.

BuzzFeed's story, if true, is significant because Trump consistently denied on the campaign trail having had any financial links to Russia. In fact, since 2016, Trump has publicly repeated more than two dozen times that he has "nothing to do with Russia."

"There was no talking to Russia. There was no phone calls. I didn’t make phone calls to Russia. I didn’t receive phone calls. I didn’t have meetings. I didn’t have texts. I didn’t have anything," he said aboard Air Force One in September.

Reached out to the White House and the special counsel's office at the Department of Justice for comment but received no immediate response.

Democratic leaders reacted with anger and concern but also caution, pledging to investigate and establish the accuracy of the BuzzFeed report.

At least one lawmaker called for Trump's impeachment if the report's accuracy is proved.

"If the @Buzzfeed story is true, President Trump must resign or be impeached," said Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), a member of the House Intelligence Committee.

Lanny Davis, Cohen’s legal and communications adviser, issued the following statement after the BuzzFeed report.

"Out of respect for Mr. Mueller’s and the Office of Special Counsel’s investigation, Mr. Cohen declined to respond to the questions asked by the reporters and so do I," Davis told the media outlet.

Giuliani shot down the report Thursday night, saying in a statement, according to a tweet from Washington Post reporter Philip Rucker: "If you believe Cohen, I can get you a great deal on the Brooklyn Bridge."

Title: Global Spread of Novel Coronavirus Continues: 31,400+ Infections Reported Worldwide

A thermal camera monitor displays the body temperature of a visitor arriving at the ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, February 6, 2020. Ten additional individuals have been infected with a new virus on one of two quarantined cruise ships, according to health officials in Japan. Simultaneously, China reported 73 more deaths and announced that the first group of patients will begin taking a new antiviral drug. (AP Photo/Lee Jin-man)

As of Friday in Beijing, the latest figures reported by health authorities worldwide indicate that the viral outbreak, which originated in China, has infected over 31,400 people globally.

In China, the death toll has reached 636, with 31,161 confirmed cases on the mainland. Hong Kong has reported 22 cases, including one death, and Macao has reported 10 cases. The majority of the deaths have occurred in central Hubei province, where the new type of coronavirus was first detected in December.

Title: Speaker Paul Ryan Announces Planned Vote for Trump in November, Offers Policy Agenda

Article:

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-WI) has announced his intention to vote for the Republican Party's presumptive nominee, Donald Trump, in November. In an op-ed published in his Wisconsin hometown's Walworth County Gazette Xtra, Ryan emphasized the importance of the election as a choice between two visions for America, rather than a personal endorsement of Trump.

Ryan's statement, delivered during Congress's Memorial Day recess, lacked the theatrical flair typically associated with Trump's campaign. In the op-ed, Ryan wrote, "Donald Trump can help us make it a reality."

Ryan has reportedly grown weary of questions about Trump and has attempted to shift the focus of discussions to issues such as the opioid crisis. In an interview with the Associated Press, he expressed hope that the constant clarification about his stance on Trump is now over.

Ryan has previously criticized Trump's policy ideas and tone, notably his proposal for a Muslim ban. However, he told the AP, "My hope is that I won't have to speak out in the future on a case-by-case basis."

Trump, in response, told The New York Times that he was "pleased" with Ryan's endorsement and described their relationship as good. He also acknowledged that Ryan's endorsement was delayed due to Trump's initial position as a presumptive nominee, which was expected to go to the convention.

Ryan's op-ed primarily addressed the Republican Party's policy agenda, rather than directly endorsing Trump. He answered a question about the party's policy priorities if a Republican president were in office, discussing topics such as tax code, executive overreach, party unity, and eventually, his reluctant assertion that he would vote for Trump in the November election.

Reuters reported that Ryan did not use the word "endorse" in his op-ed, and an aide later clarified on Twitter that Ryan's move should be seen as an endorsement. Ryan's criticisms of Trump's policy ideas and tone have been well-documented, but his nod to the Trump campaign represents a declaration that the Republican Party will continue, and the speaker of the House would like to move forward as well, as he told the AP.

Title: Defense Policy Chief John Rood Resigns Amid Impeachment Inquiry Ties

Article:

John Rood, the Undersecretary of Defense for Policy, will step down from his position at the end of this month, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday, confirming earlier reporting. Rood, who joined the administration in 2018, was involved in approving $250 million in security assistance for Ukraine, aid that was temporarily withheld by the White House last summer.

The Pentagon's statement follows reports that Rood was asked to resign after losing the support of top national-security leadership. Administration officials told Bloomberg that senior national-security officials had lost confidence in Rood's ability to execute President Donald Trump's agenda. Sources told Foreign Policy that he was asked to resign after Trump lost confidence in him following a string of departures of senior Pentagon policymakers.

In a tweet on Wednesday morning following reports of Rood's resignation, the president wished Rood well and thanked him for his service. Rood's resignation letter, a copy of which was obtained by NBC, reveals that Trump requested his resignation. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper thanked Rood in a separate statement.

While the specific reason for Rood's resignation is still unclear, multiple reports have noted his connection to the security aid to Ukraine that became the focus of impeachment proceedings. In his role at the Pentagon, which involved building partnerships and encouraging defense cooperation with US allies and partners, Rood certified to Congress that Ukraine was eligible to receive $250 million in security assistance. That aid was temporarily withheld at the White House's direction last summer.

The Trump administration has argued that it withheld the aid because of concerns about corruption, but Trump was accused of using the aid to pressure Ukraine to advance his political aims. In May, before the president decided to withhold the aid, Rood said in a letter to lawmakers that he "certified that the Government of Ukraine has taken substantial actions to make defense institutional reforms for the purposes of decreasing corruption, increasing accountability, and sustaining improvements of combat capability enabled by U.S. assistance."

The letter, which was leaked in September, undermined the administration's argument. Rood expressed concern about withholding aid to Ukraine in an email to Esper following Trump's July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky that set in motion Trump's impeachment. In the email, Rood wrote that "placing a hold on security assistance at this time would jeopardize this unique window of opportunity and undermine our defense priorities with a key partner in the strategic competition with Russia."

Ukrainian forces are fighting Russian-backed separatists in the country's eastern region. Trump was impeached by the House of Representatives on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress and acquitted by the Senate earlier this month. Since his impeachment, Trump has taken steps to remove some officials from their posts.

Title: Marco Rubio Gains Momentum in New Hampshire After Strong Iowa Finish

Article:

In the aftermath of the Iowa caucuses, Florida Senator Marco Rubio's campaign has gained momentum in New Hampshire. On the night following the caucuses, Rubio addressed an enthusiastic crowd of over 700 supporters at Exeter's town hall. The candidate delivered his familiar stump speech, which resonated with the audience following his surprising third-place finish in Iowa.

Rubio emphasized his family's immigrant, working-class roots, stating that his parents would drive him through affluent Las Vegas suburbs and remind him that, despite his father being a bartender and his mother a maid, they could achieve financial success and own a house in the one country where such success was possible.

Rubio is positioning himself as a candidate uniquely qualified to unite Republican voters and reach out to lower-income and minority communities that have historically delivered Democratic votes. He stated, "If I'm our nominee, we will win, and the Democrats know this." He further added, "They do not want to run against me. There is a reason why the Democrats, and in particular Hillary Clinton, attack me five times for every time they want to attack someone else. They know that if I'm our nominee, they lose."

Republicans have drawn comparisons between Rubio and former President Barack Obama, as both candidates have centered their pitch around a powerful personal narrative that taps into the American dream and the appeal of a telegenic first-term lawmaker and his young family. However, this comparison has also been a point of criticism, with other Republicans arguing that Rubio is too inexperienced.

Critiques have been particularly pointed from the three governors Rubio is trying to outpace in the "establishment lane" – John Kasich, Jeb Bush, and Chris Christie. Bush compared Rubio and Texas Senator Ted Cruz to "back-benchers who have never done anything of consequence in their lives." Christie has begun referring to Rubio as "the boy in the bubble," mocking both Rubio's youth and his repetitive speeches.

In response to Christie's critique, Rubio's campaign held several brief press availabilities during Wednesday's town hall swing. The four-way tussle among Rubio, Kasich, Christie, and Bush is intense, as the stakes are high. Republican power-brokers are concerned about the possibility of a Donald Trump or a Ted Cruz nomination.

All four campaigns are banking on elected officials and high-powered donors to rally around the winning campaign in New Hampshire. A repeat strong showing from Rubio would likely secure him as the establishment's preferred candidate. Rubio is aware of the anti-Washington and anti-establishment sentiment this year and is quick to point out the irony. He stated, "I can tell you that when it comes to the establishment, which is, people who have been involved in politics for a long time, they did not want me to run for president, and they did not want me to run for Senate five years ago." However, in a Trump- and Cruz-dominated primary, party power-brokers are desperate for someone to rally around. If Rubio performs well for a second week in a row, he is likely to be that candidate.

Title: Investment-Based Student Loans Offer Alternative to Traditional Loans

Article:

A new approach to student loans, known as Income Share Agreements (ISAs), is gaining traction as a potential solution to the rising student debt crisis. Unlike traditional loans, ISAs involve investors providing funds to colleges, which in turn offer free or partially free education to students. The students then pay the college a certain percentage of their future income upon graduation.

Beth Akers, co-author of the book "Game of Loans," explains that ISAs allow colleges to ensure students only pay if they are successful. Andrew Hoyler, a professional pilot who received an ISA from Purdue University, will pay the university 8% of his income for 104 months. Hoyler states that after the 104-month term ends, if he still owes money, it will be forgiven.

The terms for ISAs vary based on the student's major. For a $10,000 ISA, English majors must pay 4.58% of their income for 116 months, while math majors, who are more likely to secure higher-paying jobs, pay just 3.96% for 96 months. Akers notes that ISAs provide students with information about the potential earnings of different majors.

Critics argue that ISAs may discourage students from pursuing less profitable majors, but proponents argue that this is simply a way for investors to recoup the money they've invested. Hoyler agrees, stating that the security of knowing he'll never pay back more than he can afford is worth the potential higher payments for some students.

Some politicians have expressed support for government-backed student loans, arguing that they save taxpayers money. However, the Brookings Institution found that 28% of students do not even know they have a loan. Critics argue that the market would make better judgments and prevent students from starting their adult lives under a burden they may never escape.

ISAs have been criticized as predatory, but Hoyler points out that if a student does not have a job, they do not pay anything. Paul Larora, another Purdue ISA recipient, states, "We don't know who the investor is, but I'd love to give him a hug or buy him a beer!"

Akers explains that colleges act as middlemen, ensuring that no one takes advantage of students. She argues that forcing banks out of the loan business and relying on government-backed loans is not the solution. Instead, she suggests allowing actual private lenders, who have skin in the game, to make loans and assess loan risk. This would encourage lenders to tell students which majors might lead to higher-paying careers and warn them about the potential difficulties of certain majors.

In conclusion, ISAs offer a potential alternative to traditional student loans, with investors taking on the risk of student loan defaults and students only paying if they are successful. While ISAs have been criticized as predatory, proponents argue that they provide students with valuable information about the potential earnings of different majors and offer a more flexible repayment structure.

Title: Dual Responses: Rand Paul and Marco Rubio Deliver Tea Party and Official GOP Responses to State of the Union Address

Article:

In the aftermath of President Obama's State of the Union address on Tuesday, two Republican responses were delivered, one by Kentucky Senator Rand Paul and the other by Florida Senator Marco Rubio. While Rubio delivered the official Republican response, Paul delivered a response sponsored by the Tea Party Express.

Jenny Beth Martin, co-founder of the national Tea Party Patriots, stated that both Paul and Rubio are elected officials who are fighting for tea party values of fiscal responsibility and constitutionally limited government. However, the Republican Party's choice of Rubio, a son of Cuban immigrants, to deliver the official response has marked him as the establishment's chosen spokesman, and as such, acceptable as a potential 2016 presidential nominee if he decides to run.

Rubio's spokesman, Alex Conant, stated that having high-profile responses from both Rubio and Paul is beneficial for the Republican Party. "We're glad Sen. Paul is doing his speech tonight. As far as we're concerned, the more Republicans that are responding to the president, the better," Conant said.

Paul unofficially launched his 2016 nomination bid with a visit to Israel last month in the company of some 40 American evangelicals and several prominent Jewish Americans. For those closely monitoring his actions, it was no surprise that he elected to give what he calls his own "tea party" response to the president, or that he doesn't explicitly deny that his move is an intentional clash with Rubio.

Paul, however, doesn't view his speech as competing with Rubio but rather "as an extra response." Yet, Paul doesn't explicitly say his speech isn't intended to draw contrasts with Rubio on a variety of hot issues, from immigration to foreign aid.

Paul taped his response on Tuesday afternoon at the National Press Club in downtown Washington, and it will air on all major news cable networks and affiliates except Fox. The feed will be streamed on www.teapartyexpress.org and <https://www.redstate.com/>.

Some in the press and in GOP official circles are calling Rubio the new face of the GOP. However, Paul has rejected this idea, stating, "I don't think anybody gets to choose who is the face is or say you or someone else is the face. I think we do the best to promote what we believe in."

Tea Party Patriots' other co-founder, Marc Meckler, now president of Citizens for Self-governance, argued that "it's hard to legitimately call Rubio 'establishment' when he beat down the establishment to take out Charlie Christ." Rubio's voting record in the Senate and the stands he has taken there generally comport with tea party values, according to Meckler.

However, Meckler then recounted his observations of what may be a growing rift between Rubio and the tea party, with some tea party groups expressing skepticism and a lack of accessibility from Rubio. This sentiment has been attributed by some Republican operatives, such as Karl Rove, to the tea party's role in nominating conservative GOP candidates who then get trounced by Democrats in general elections.

Title: Ukraine Repels Attack at Donetsk Airport, Russia Sends Aid Convoy Amidst Ceasefire Tensions

Article:

Ukrainian military forces repelled pro-Russian separatists at Donetsk airport on Saturday, marking a resurgence of fighting in the eastern part of the country, a week after a ceasefire agreement was reached. A volley of rockets struck residential buildings near the airport, but no casualties were reported, according to a statement posted on the City Council website.

Tensions escalated further as Russia sent a second convoy of trucks into Ukraine without its consent. The fighting prompted Ukraine's Prime Minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, to assert that despite the truce, his country remains in a state of conflict with its powerful neighbor.

Russian President Vladimir Putin, whose country annexed most of the Crimean Peninsula from Ukraine in March, has consistently denied that Russian troops have entered eastern Ukraine. However, he defends the Russian-speaking minority's right to defend themselves.

A convoy of about 245 trucks, reportedly filled with nearly 2,000 tons of humanitarian aid, crossed the Russian border and into Ukraine. The first trucks delivered shipments of cereals, sugar, medicines, and warm clothes, among other items, to the eastern Ukrainian city of Lugansk, according to a report by the Russian news agency ITAR-TASS.

Residents in Lugansk reportedly found five-liter containers of drinking water particularly joyful, as they had been without water for over a month. The last of the trucks crossed back into Russia around 6:30 p.m. Moscow time "without incidents," according to the report.

In August, Ukrainian officials called the first convoy of humanitarian aid from Russia an invasion of the country, and protested any attempts by Russia to unilaterally bring in the aid. Eventually, Russia allowed its trucks to cross into rebel-held territory without the oversight of the International Red Cross, contrary to an agreement signed between Ukraine and Russia.

Ukrainian officials' silence on the second convoy indicates a significant shift in the mood in the Kiev government, where President Petro Poroshenko has been making efforts to prove that the ceasefire deal, riddled by violations since its imposition last week, has yielded improvements on the ground in east Ukraine.

However, in his speech on Saturday, Yatsenyuk stated that important government-proposed reforms to benefit the entire country have been stymied by the ongoing conflict. "If we stop the war, if we contain Russia — we will get the chance to attract international investors, because it is not an easy job to attract an international investor when you have in your country already Russian tanks and Russian artillery," he said.

Title: CBS News Reporter Faces Internal Criticism for Aggressive Pursuit of Benghazi Story

Article:

CBS News correspondent Sharyl Attkisson, known for her relentless pursuit of the Fast & Furious scandal, is reportedly facing criticism from her own organization for her aggressive coverage of the Benghazi story. According to Politico, CBS News executives view Attkisson's Benghazi reporting as wading dangerously close to advocacy, with some of her stories failing to air and leaving her feeling marginalized and underutilized.

Attkisson's coverage of the Benghazi story has been a point of contention within CBS News, with executives expressing frustration over her pursuit of the issue. This tension has led to discussions about Attkisson's departure from CBS, as reported in an April article by Politico.

The internal conflicts within CBS News provide important context for the current situation. Ed Morrissey, a political commentator, noted that Attkisson's Twitter feed went silent during today's hearings, leading to speculation about the reasons behind this silence.

The Benghazi story, which involves the 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, that resulted in the death of four Americans, including the U.S. Ambassador to Libya, has been a contentious topic in the media. Some argue that the story is being dismissed by the mainstream media as a right-wing conspiracy, while others view it as an important issue that deserves scrutiny.

Attkisson's reporting on Benghazi has made it difficult to pigeonhole the story as a right-wing obsession, as her work has been covered by CBS News, an organization that holds a platinum reputation in left-leaning media circles. This has reportedly led to questions about her integrity and marginalization within the organization.

The controversy surrounding Attkisson's coverage of the Benghazi story highlights the challenges faced by journalists who pursue stories that are not in line with the mainstream narrative or the political leanings of their organization. It also underscores the importance of maintaining journalistic integrity and objectivity in the face of internal and external pressure.

Title: District of Columbia's New Gun Registration Renewal Requirement Sparks Controversy

Article:

The Metropolitan Police Department in Washington D.C. has proposed new rules that will require all legal firearm owners in the city to renew their gun registration certificates in person at police headquarters. This renewal process, which starts on January 1, 2023, has sparked controversy and criticism from gun owners and legal experts.

Under the new rules, anyone with a gun registered before 2011 will have to go to police headquarters to be fingerprinted, photographed, provide proof of address, pay a fee, and confirm they may still legally possess the firearm. The Firearms Registration Section will then create a new registration certificate—now in the form of an ID card—for each gun.

The renewal process was initially supposed to be done online and by mail, but the police did not retain any of the fingerprints or photos taken until March 2013. The police propose scheduling everyone in three-month windows based on the individual's birthday, and they intend to set up an online system to make an appointment. However, the department is still trying to finalize a system to accept credit cards for the $13-per-gun fee.

Critics argue that the renewal process is onerous, unnecessary, and a potential trap for the unwary. Stephen P. Halbrook, the lead attorney for Heller v. District of Columbia, also known as "Heller II," stated that "Re-registration is onerous and completely unnecessary and is a trap for the unwary. Fail to re-register for whatever reason, and you’re committing a crime—possession of an unregistered firearm. This is plain harassment for exercise of a constitutional right."

The registration-renewal requirement is already being challenged in court through Heller v. District of Columbia, which takes on the entire registration law that was enacted in 2009 after the Supreme Court overturned the District's 30-year-old handgun ban in the original Heller decision.

The controversy surrounding the new gun registration renewal requirement has raised questions about the effectiveness of such measures in improving public safety. Critics argue that the low number of registered firearms in the city, estimated to be approximately 30,000 for a city of 600,000, indicates that most law-abiding people do not go through the registration process. Additionally, criminals are not showing up at police headquarters to offer up their fingerprints or take a written test before buying guns.

Emily Miller, senior editor of opinion for The ███ and author of "Emily Gets Her Gun," has criticized the new requirement as a clear violation of the Founding Fathers' intent that the Second Amendment would prevent government tyranny. Once the government knows about every single gun owned by each citizen, then an armed populace is no longer a deterrent.

The Metropolitan Police Department has not issued a statement regarding the controversy surrounding the new gun registration renewal requirement. The deadline for citizens to comment on the regulations is December 15, 2022.

Title: Alabama Senate Candidate Roy Moore Threatens Lawsuit Against Washington Post Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

Alabama Republican Senate candidate Roy Moore has announced his intention to sue The Washington Post over a report alleging sexual misconduct, including pursuing relationships with teenagers, when he was in his 30s. In a campaign speech in Huntsville, Alabama, on Sunday night, Moore stated, "These attacks [on my character and reputation] are false and untrue, and for which they will be sued."

The Washington Post's report, published on Thursday, was based on interviews with more than 30 people. The report alleged that Moore had sexual contact with a 14-year-old girl when he was 32, and three other women claimed he pursued them when they were between the ages of 16 and 18. The woman who was 14 at the time claimed Moore took her to his house, undressed her, and touched her, which could have constituted sexual offenses due to her age, but the statutes of limitations in effect during that time have passed.

None of the other three women told The Post that Moore sexually harassed, assaulted, or forced them into a relationship. Alabama's legal age of consent is 16. Moore has denied the allegations since they were published. He called the claims "completely false" on Friday during an appearance on Sean Hannity's syndicated radio show.

Speaking at a Veterans Day event at the Mid-Alabama Republican Club in Birmingham on Saturday, Moore called the allegations "fake news" and "yet another attack on my character and reputation in a desperate attempt to stop my political campaign for the United States Senate." He added that the alleged incidents happened nearly 40 years ago and called them "very hurtful to me personally -- I have the highest regard for the protection of young children." Moore also stated that he has never provided alcohol to a minor and has "not been guilty of sexual misconduct with anyone."

Moore added that there were ongoing "investigations" looking into the motivations behind the Post article, and promised "revelations" about the story to come in the next few days, though he did not provide further specifics. A number of Republicans have withdrawn their endorsements of Moore following the Washington Post article, including the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which severed a joint fundraising agreement that benefits Moore's campaign.

The Washington Post has not commented on the matter since the story was published. This article has been updated to reflect The Post's decision to not comment.

Title: NBC News Drops Balanced Approach to Climate Change Discussion on "Meet the Press"

Article:

NBC News has decided to no longer treat climate change as a debate with two opposing sides, as stated by host Chuck Todd during Sunday's episode of "Meet the Press." The program featured an hour-long panel discussion on the consequences of climate change, but Todd's opening remarks drew criticism for characterizing the nature of the climate debate inaccurately.

Todd declared, "We're not going to debate climate change, the existence of it. The earth is getting hotter, and human activity is a major cause. Period." He further added, "We're not going to give time to climate deniers. The science is settled even if political opinion is not."

Skeptics of the most alarmist climate change scenarios argue that the term "denier" is misleading, as it implies parallels to those who deny historical events such as the Holocaust or the September 11, 2001, terror attacks. They contend that while it is accepted that burning fossil fuels increases carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere, there is a wide range of scientific opinion on matters such as the extent of human influence on gas levels, the likelihood of various consequences, the impact of other factors on the climate, and the quality and extent of historical climate data.

Todd's Sunday statement was preceded by video clips of dramatic weather events from the past year, though climatologists emphasize the difference between "weather" and "climate." Scientists are typically reluctant to attribute specific weather events to human-induced climate change.

The panel on Sunday included non-scientists offering their opinions, such as California Governor Jerry Brown, Representative Carlos Curbelo, and potential Democratic presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg. Curbelo expressed concern about the one-sided discussion, stating, "We need to stop covering the debate and start covering the story so that people see that this is real, and so that politicians take a more pragmatic approach and find solutions that are actually achievable."

Politicians such as Senator Bernie Sanders praised the show, with Sanders taking to Twitter to offer "congratulations to Chuck Todd and Meet the Press for holding a serious discussion about climate change." Sanders questioned, "Will this be a breakthrough moment for mainstream TV?"

Title: NRA Executive Vice President Warns of Potential Gun Control Measures as Obama Prepares to Sign Executive Orders

Article:

In an email sent to supporters late Tuesday evening, National Rifle Association (NRA) Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre expressed concern over potential new gun control measures as President Obama prepares to sign up to 19 executive orders. LaPierre's email emphasized that the focus is not on protecting children or reducing crime, but rather on "banning your guns."

Last week, the NRA attended a White House meeting that was marketed to the public as an "open discussion" about improving school safety. However, LaPierre alleged that the meeting was a "dirty lie," as the administration did not address gun owners' concerns or consider practical solutions for ensuring school safety.

According to LaPierre, the administration's true intentions are to "blame" gun owners, "vilify" them, "bully" them, and "strip" them of their Second Amendment rights. The proposed legislation, he claimed, would ban certain guns, register ammunition purchases, and require gun owners to register their firearms with the government.

LaPierre urged supporters to renew or upgrade their NRA membership as soon as possible, stating that the current situation is a "fight of the century" and that the NRA needs their support more than ever. He provided a link for online renewal or upgrade at www.NRA.org/StandAndFight.

The email also addressed the media's portrayal of gun owners and the NRA, stating that members have been called "terrorists" and faced personal threats. LaPierre vowed to challenge these attacks and defend the right to self-defense and the Right to Keep and Bear Arms.

The email concluded with a call to action, emphasizing the need for gun owners to stand together in the face of these proposed measures. LaPierre expressed gratitude for the support of his fellow members, stating that their strength and commitment are crucial to the NRA's efforts.

Title: Clinton Reaffirms Commitment to Gun Control and Criminal Justice Reform in Campaign Speech

Article:

In a campaign event on Saturday, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton reiterated her stance on gun control and criminal justice reform, two key issues that have been central to her primary campaign. The event, which was attended by some mothers who have lost children to gun violence or police clashes, comes as the Clinton campaign shifts its focus to the general election against Republican nominee Donald Trump.

Clinton's remarks on gun control were made in response to comments made by Trump during a previous event, where he suggested that Clinton's policies could put women in danger, particularly in rough or bad communities. Clinton's campaign has previously highlighted the stories of mothers who have lost children to gun violence or police encounters in evocative television ads.

In her speech, Clinton reaffirmed her support for stricter gun laws and background checks for all purchases. A poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News in January found that 57 percent of respondents wanted stricter laws governing gun sales, and 88 percent favored background checks for all purchases.

In addition to gun control, Clinton also addressed the issue of criminal justice reform. She vowed to end the "school to prison pipeline" that disproportionately affects black men and pledged to "end the era of mass incarceration" and "rebuild the bonds of trust between law enforcement and communities." These issues could resonate with voters in California, particularly in cities like Los Angeles and Oakland, ahead of the state's June 7 primary.

Clinton also spoke about the need to address racial disparities in the criminal justice system, stating, "Something is wrong when so many Americans have reason to believe that our country doesn't consider their children as precious and worthy of protection as other children because of the color of their skins."

The Clinton campaign's focus on gun control and criminal justice reform has helped her win broad support among African-Americans during the primary campaign. As the general election approaches, it remains to be seen how these issues will continue to shape her campaign and her policy proposals.

Title: The Emergence of a Religious Left: A Focus on Buttigieg and the LGBTQ+ Community

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the emergence of a religious left, with Pete Buttigieg at the forefront, is gaining traction among progressive voters. This shift is particularly notable among those who have celebrated the "rainbow wave" of LGBTQ+ political candidates, five years after the legalization of same-sex marriage and in the midst of ongoing battles against the Trump administration's policies on transgender rights.

Buttigieg, an openly gay candidate, running for president alongside his husband, Chasten, is seen as a powerful symbol by many. For individuals who have faced discrimination based on their sexual orientation, this representation is significant. In the words of one voter, "Identity matters... Buttigieg is gay. These facets of their identities mean that they can understand the powerless, as victims of power, and that they can understand the alienated, having been marginalized."

Buttigieg's campaign is also resonating with Christians whose faith is more liberal on issues such as LGBTQ+ rights, women's rights, racial reconciliation, and diversity. This approach is not expected to win over white evangelicals and white Catholics who align with Trumpism, but rather, it appears to be targeting a majority of Americans who believe in a more inclusive Christianity.

The religious left, including Buttigieg, Booker, and Warren, are advocating for a return to the core values of Christianity, emphasizing generosity towards the poor, welcoming to the stranger, and treating people with dignity, rather than focusing on sexuality. This shift is seen as a counterbalance to the conservative political agenda that has been promoted by some evangelical Christians in the past.

In the political arena, the focus on sexuality has led to a disproportionate emphasis on homosexuality, a concern raised by these religious leaders. They argue that this focus has resulted in a deeply regrettable fixation, and that religion should provide a critical perspective on society, not be used to justify pre-determined political positions.

The emergence of a religious left, with Buttigieg as a symbol, is a developing story in American politics. The implications of this shift remain to be seen, particularly in the context of the ongoing impeachment investigation against President Trump. While the evidence against Trump is circumstantial, it is not considered weak. Criminal investigations often rely on circumstantial evidence, and in the absence of an explicit quid pro quo proposal, the context and circumstances may become the focus of the investigation. Whether this evidence is sufficient to lead to Trump's removal from office is a matter yet to be determined.

Title: Guam Residents Carry On with Daily Activities Amid North Korea Tensions

Article:

Guam, a U.S. territory, experienced a relatively normal Saturday at Home Depot, despite the ongoing international tension between the United States and North Korea. The island, which has been in the international spotlight due to North Korea's threats, saw a slight increase in purchases of items typically associated with disaster preparedness, such as bottled water and batteries.

However, the majority of customers were shopping for everyday items, according to Home Depot loss prevention manager Andrew Guilliot. He noted that while there was a slight increase in purchases of items like bottled water, generators, batteries, tarps, and plastic were not seeing significant spikes.

The calm demeanor of Guam residents was also evident in other areas. The University of Guam Kids Fishing Derby saw a strong turnout of about 40 registered children, their families, and a handful of unregistered participants. Residents also went spear fishing, attended football practice, visited beaches, and crowded malls.

Some residents, such as Ordot resident David Lessard, 55, were considering disaster preparedness. Lessard, who lived through the Mount Pinatubo volcanic eruption in the Philippines in 1991, was looking into stocking up on canned goods and bottled water.

However, the general sentiment among Guam residents seemed to be one of calm and normalcy. Dededo resident Vicente Bautista, 62, who heard similar threats in 1977 when he was an Army infantryman near the Demilitarized Zone, believed that North Korea was merely trying to show off and did not have the technology to back up its threats.

Guam Chamber of Commerce issued a simple statement on Friday, stating, "It is business as usual on Guam." This sentiment was echoed by many residents, with Dededo resident Mike Soderquist, 44, stating that he was just out shopping and had plans for a barbecue later in the day.

Despite the ongoing tension, Guam's leaders have received assurances from President Trump and White House Chief of Staff Gen. John Kelly. Guam Governor Eddie Calvo said in a video message that the assurances gave him great comfort. The island's leaders and residents remain hopeful that the situation will de-escalate peacefully.

Title: Rand Paul's Healthcare Stance: A Study of Principle and Expediency

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a prominent figure in the Republican Party, has been vocal in his opposition to compromises on healthcare reform that do not involve full repeal of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). In an interview with Neil Cavuto of Fox News, Paul expressed his disappointment with the Republican Party's decision to vote in favor of maintaining parts of Obamacare.

The article explores the potential intersection of Paul's principles and political expediency, suggesting that his opposition to compromises may be driven by a combination of genuine convictions and strategic maneuvers to avoid accountability.
