The article draws parallels between Paul's stance and that of his father, Ron Paul, a longtime Texas congressman known for his opposition to many bills on constitutional and libertarian grounds.

The article highlights instances where Paul's actions seem to contradict his stated goals, such as his opposition to association-exemption provisions that were already included in the healthcare bill. The article also mentions Paul's history of opposing earmarks, a practice his father was known for, despite voting against spending bills that contained his district's pork barrel projects.

The article concludes by noting that while it is difficult to definitively determine the motivations behind Paul's actions, his actions during the healthcare reform process suggest a pattern of moving away from opportunities for progress when they appear to align with his goals. The article also mentions Paul's proposal for a clean repeal of Obamacare, a stance he has maintained despite previously warning against such an approach.

The article does not take a political stance and presents the information in a neutral and factual manner, avoiding personal opinions, subjective statements, or speculation.

Title: U.S. Defense Secretary Defends Diversion of Funds for Border Wall at Munich Security Conference

Article:

MUNICH, Germany (AP) — U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper defended his decision to divert billions of dollars in funding for Navy and Air Force aircraft and other military programs to help pay for President Donald Trump's promised wall on the U.S.-Mexico border during a press conference on the first day of the Munich Security Conference in Munich, Germany, on Friday, Feb. 14, 2020.

Esper was asked about criticism from Democrats and Republicans in Congress, including Rep. Mac Thornberry, a Republican from Texas, who called the diversion of funds contrary to the constitutional authority of Congress.

"Border security is national security," Esper said. "And national security is our mission."

He added, "The action we took is legal under the law, and so it should be no surprise, and I'll just leave it at that for now."

Esper spoke on the sidelines of an international security conference in Munich.

The Pentagon announced on Thursday that Esper approved shifting $3.8 billion in funds that Congress had previously authorized for F-35 fighter aircraft and other military programs. The money is being diverted to help the Department of Homeland Security build portions of the border wall. The Pentagon indicated that more such actions could be coming to provide additional funding for Trump's signature campaign promise.

The action drew sharp rebukes from Democrats as well as Republicans.

"Today's reprogramming request confirms once again that the President is obsessed with fulfilling a campaign promise at the expense of our national security," Rep. Adam Smith of Washington, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement. "This administration has already stolen billions from the Department of Defense in order to begin building the president's vanity wall and today they are doubling down on bad policy."

Last year, despite congressional opposition, Trump faced no consequences when making similar transfers by cancelling or postponing dozens of military construction projects to free up $3.6 billion.

In reaction to Thursday's Pentagon announcement, Thornberry, the top Republican on the committee and a supporter of wall construction, said that while the administration's constitutional role is to recommend how tax dollars are spent, final choices are made by Congress.

"Once those choices have been made, the Department of Defense can not change them in pursuit of their own priorities without the approval of Congress," he said. "Attempts to do so undermine the principle of civilian control of the military and are in violation of the separation of powers within the Constitution. The re-programming announced today is contrary to Congress' constitutional authority, and I believe that it requires Congress to take action."

Trump, while campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, repeatedly promised that Mexico would pay for the wall, but Mexico refused.

Title: Democrats' "Better Deal" Agenda: A New Package of Old Ideas

Article:

In a speech at a rally in Huntsville, Alabama, on September 22, 2017, President Trump asserted that the Republican Party's traditional policies might be sufficient for the midterm elections, but they would not be enough in the long term. This article examines the Democratic Party's response, focusing on their "Better Deal" agenda, which critics argue is a rehash of the New Deal policies that have defined the Democratic Party for much of the last century.

The New Deal, a series of programs, jobs projects, and reforms introduced during the Great Depression, has been a cornerstone of the Democratic Party's policy vision. The Fair Deal and the Great Society, both continuations of the New Deal, were proposed by Presidents Harry Truman and Lyndon B. Johnson, respectively.

After the September 11 attacks, Senator Charles Schumer, a New York Democrat, wrote in the Washington Post that the attacks marked the end of the era of shrinking federal government. He argued for a "new New Deal" to address the new challenges the nation faced.

Despite the Democrats' criticism of the Republican Party's stale ideas, they have repeatedly returned to the well of the New Deal, a policy framework that was established four years after the invention of sliced bread. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, who is a child of the New Deal, has been a proponent of its principles.

The Democrats' "Better Deal" agenda, unveiled in 2018, is a rehash of the New Deal, according to critics. House Democratic Caucus Chairman Joe Crowley, when asked for a fresh idea during a Fox News Sunday interview, responded with a new infrastructure plan, but one that would have the federal government shoulder a larger share of the costs compared to President Trump's plan.

The New Deal was never a coherent program, but rather a mixed and ad hoc response to the economic crisis of the 1930s. Raymond Moley, FDR's right-hand man during much of the New Deal, described the programs as a collection of miscellaneous items in a boy's bedroom, assembled by an interior decorator.

The Democrats' reliance on the New Deal framework may unify Democratic politicians, but it does little to address the divisions within the party's voter base. The time will come when the "Better Deal" will no longer be enough, and the Democrats will need to embrace new ideas and approaches to remain competitive.

Title: Congress and President Trump Negotiate Budget Deal, Addressing DACA and Immigration Policy

Article:

Congress is currently in negotiations to pass a budget deal that would maintain government operations without using the status of hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants, often referred to as "Dreamers," as bargaining chips. However, it is expected that President Trump may reconsider his threat of deportation for these individuals only if Congress considers significant cuts to legal immigration, marking the first deep reductions since the 1920s.

The proposed changes by President Trump are based on a nativist, zero-sum perspective that views immigration as detrimental to the United States. This perspective contradicts American tradition, principles, and evidence suggesting benefits for the country.

The programs under consideration for cuts are designed to promote diversity and humanity in legal immigration. One such program is the lottery system, which grants visas to individuals from countries underrepresented as sources of American immigrants. The other program is family-based immigration, which offers visas to close relatives of citizens and legal residents.

President Trump, who has frequently portrayed immigrants as terrorists and criminals, has recently focused his fear-mongering on the diversity visa program. Last month, his Department of Homeland Security released a report alleging that those entering the country via the lottery were more likely to be tied to terrorist attacks. However, a report by the Cato Institute found that lottery visa holders were responsible for only eight of the 3,037 Americans murdered by foreign-born terrorists since 1975.

Immigrants selected through the lottery do not bypass security checks or education requirements. They must have at least a high school education or two years of experience in skilled work, and they undergo criminal, national security, and medical checks. The 50,000 recipients of the visas are not guaranteed permanent residence, but rather a chance to proceed through the rest of the immigration process.

Title: House Democrats Consider Boycotting Benghazi Investigative Committee; GOP Leaders Push for Bipartisan Probe

Article:

House Democrats are deliberating the participation in a special investigative committee on the Benghazi attacks, with some members considering a boycott of the investigation. The discussions took place behind closed doors on Wednesday, and Democratic leaders declined to disclose their future plans after the meeting.

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., stated, "One day at a time," when asked about the committee's structure. Some rank-and-file Democrats argue that participating in the select committee would improperly legitimize what they view as a political effort, while others believe that abstaining would prevent them from influencing the investigation's direction and narrative.

According to several sources, based on Wednesday's meeting, it appears that Democrats are leaning toward not participating. GOP leaders outlined the particulars of the select committee on Tuesday evening, setting the stage for a comprehensive probe into various aspects of the U.S. response and internal communications following the attack.

House Speaker John Boehner stated, "It's not going to be a sideshow, it is not going to be a circus." The committee will consist of seven Republicans and five Democrats, a move that has rankled Democrats. Pelosi and her deputy, Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., objected in a letter to Boehner, calling for an even split between Democrats and Republicans and a "real and equal voice" in issuing subpoenas, questioning witnesses, and other areas.

In their letter, Pelosi and Hoyer expressed concern that the principles outlined in the draft resolution provided by the GOP leaders had been rejected. They called on Boehner to reconsider the approach before bringing the measure to the House floor for a vote.

Republicans argue that the select committee is essential, particularly in light of revelations that the Obama administration withheld relevant emails for months before their release as part of a lawsuit last week. The committee will have subpoena power and may order depositions to be given under oath. A final report is required, though some of it may be classified. The next step will be for the House to vote on the committee, and for members to be chosen.

Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-S.C., has already been selected to chair the committee. Among other priorities, the committee will seek to answer what was done in response to the Sep. 11, 2012 attack, including efforts to rescue U.S. personnel. Four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens, died in the assault on the U.S. compound. The committee will have subpoena power and may order depositions to be given under oath. A final report is required, though some of it may be classified. The next step will be for the House to vote on the committee, and for members to be chosen.

Title: Trump Administration to Reshape Title X Family Planning Program, Potentially Affecting Planned Parenthood

Article:

The Trump administration has the opportunity to reshape the Title X family planning program, a federally funded initiative that has long been a target of conservative critics. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is setting the terms for obtaining grants under Title X, a program that provides family planning services to millions of low-income individuals.

Teresa Manning, the deputy assistant secretary of the office of population affairs at HHS, which oversees Title X, is a prominent anti-abortion advocate and a former lobbyist for the National Right to Life Committee. Manning, who has been critical of Title X in the past, now has the opportunity to reshape the program to align with the administration's anti-abortion views.

Audrey Sandusky, communications director for the National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA), which represents Title X grant recipients, stated, "This is the administration's first attempt to really kind of redefine what they want the family planning program to look like." Sandusky added, "We anticipate some attempt to undercut the program."

Supporters of Title X worry the administration will freeze out clinics that also provide abortions, restrict the types of services performed at clinics, limit access to some types of birth control, or reduce funding for the program. Meanwhile, anti-abortion advocates are hoping the administration will resurrect Reagan-era regulations that banned Title X providers from offering abortion referrals and counseling and from encouraging, promoting, or advocating abortion as a method of family planning.

Steve Aden, chief legal officer and general counsel at Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion advocacy group in D.C., stated, "The best thing for health care and for women is that they receive [family planning services] in a setting that's devoid of the possibility of Planned Parenthood pushing quote unquote options, when what they're doing is referring them to the abortion facility."

The Trump administration's intent will be clear when HHS issues a funding opportunity announcement for the Title X grants. The conditions are expected to differ from those set by the Obama administration, perhaps significantly. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimated that Planned Parenthood and its affiliates receive about $60 million a year through the Title X program. In 2017, Congress appropriated $286 million total for the grants.

Kinsey Hasstedt, a senior policy manager at the Guttmacher Institute, which supports abortion rights, said it would be naive to think the Trump administration wouldn't take the opportunity to "put a flag in the ground" on Title X. Hasstedt stated, "The administration has shown its cards to some degree in its opposition to abortion and providers who offer or are affiliated with abortion."

President Trump signed a bill earlier this year allowing states to defund Planned Parenthood for political reasons, reversing a last-minute rule signed by former President Obama. The Trump administration's fiscal 2018 budget request also would have excluded Planned Parenthood affiliates from all forms of federal funding, but that provision has yet to pass Congress. That leaves Title X as the most plausible route for the administration to crack down on abortion providers.

While federal dollars, including Title X grants, can't be used to pay for abortions, critics argue that the money is fungible and could still indirectly support the procedure if it goes to groups that perform abortions like Planned Parenthood. That's the argument for resurrecting Reagan-era restrictions requiring a physical and financial separation between Title X projects and abortion services, including separate waiting and examination rooms, separate staff, and separate accounting records.

Restoring these regulations could take months, but groups that support them say it would make certain that absolutely no federal funds go toward abortion. David Christensen, vice president of government affairs at the Family Research Council, stated, "Doing this would not prevent organizations like Planned Parenthood necessarily from getting Title X funds. It would mean though that the Title X family planning program would have to be physically and financially separate from an organization's abortion activities."

Guttmacher's Kinsey stated that the possible changes to Title X would have a big impact on women, especially those living in underserved communities. "Any attempt to undermine this program or the providers or women's access to affordable care would be a huge setback and would definitely impact these women in these communities and represents a really unacceptable disruption of the program," Kinsey said.

Title: FBI Director James Comey Criticizes Wikileaks, Echoing CIA Head Mike Pompeo's Remarks

Article:

FBI Director James Comey testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee regarding the FBI's investigation into potential ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. During the hearing, Comey expressed criticism towards WikiLeaks, distinguishing it from legitimate news sources.

Comey stated, "It crosses a line when it moves from being about educating a public to intelligence porn, just pushing out information...just to damage the United States." He added, "There's nothing that even smells journalist about some of this content." Comey also noted that during legitimate investigations, the focus would usually fall on leakers.

Comey's comments on WikiLeaks seem to mirror CIA head Mike Pompeo's criticisms of the organization, made just a couple of weeks prior. In a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, Pompeo declared, "We can no longer allow [Julian] Assange and his colleagues the latitude to use free speech values against us."

It is important to note that no official should define journalism, as this implicitly sanctions government action against whistleblowers and other leakers. However, the irony of the FBI director, an agency with a history of illegal and ineffective subterfuge, criticizing media legitimacy, is noteworthy.

In a four-year period, the FBI authorized criminal activity by confidential informants over 22,000 times. The FBI's criticism of WikiLeaks comes during a time when the current president has publicly expressed antagonism towards the press, calling for the "loosening" of libel laws regarding public figures and elected officials, and declaring war on the media.

The relationship between Comey and President Donald Trump is complex, with Trump publicly opposing Comey over the latter's refusal to recommend charges against Hillary Clinton. The spectacle of the two figures, each with their own controversies, adds to the intrigue of the ongoing investigation.

While it is inappropriate to expect U.S. officials to embrace WikiLeaks and other sources that reveal government activities, there is no doubt that WikiLeaks has forced transparency in ways that have greatly benefited the public.

Title: Ross Perot, Billionaire and Independent Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89

Article:

Ross Perot, the billionaire businessman who mounted two unsuccessful third-party presidential campaigns in the 1990s, died Tuesday, according to family spokesman James Fuller. He was 89. Perot died after a five-month battle with leukemia, Fuller said.

Perot, a self-made billionaire by his mid-50s after selling a controlling interest in the data processing business he founded to General Motors for $2.5 billion, gained national recognition for his colorful political career. His Texas twang, populist platform, and frequent television appearances made him one of the more memorable political figures of the 1990s.

In the 1992 election, Perot garnered nearly 19% of the vote and finished third behind Bill Clinton and incumbent President George H.W. Bush. For years, Bush blamed Perot for his defeat, stating in a 2012 HBO documentary that he believed Perot "cost me the election." However, election experts and scholarly research have challenged that theory, with The New York Times finding Perot's effect on the election's outcome to be "minimal," and The Washington Post reporting Clinton would have still won by a large margin if Perot had not run.

In 1995, Perot created the Reform Party, and the following year, he received 8% of the vote in the presidential election as the party's candidate. Following his second and final bid for the presidency, Perot served as president and CEO of Perot Systems Corporation, which he founded in 1988. He was the head of the company until 2000, when he passed the title on to his son, Ross Perot Jr. Nine years later, Dell Incorporated bought Perot Systems for $3.9 billion, resulting in a net gain of about $400 million for the Perot family.

Aside from his business and political careers, Perot also received national attention for his efforts during the Vietnam War to create better conditions for US prisoners of war. He traveled to Laos, where he met with ambassadors from Russia and North Vietnam, and was awarded the Medal for Distinguished Public Service by the Department of Defense in 1974 for his efforts. In 1979, when two EDS employees were taken hostage during a revolution in Iran, he organized and paid for a successful private mission called Operation Hotfoot to rescue the men and bring them home.

"In business and in life, Ross was a man of integrity and action. A true American patriot and a man of rare vision, principle, and deep compassion, he touched the lives of countless people through his unwavering support of the military and veterans and through his charitable endeavors," Fuller said in a statement. "Ross Perot will be deeply missed by all who loved him. He lived a long and honorable life."

Henry Ray Perot, who later legally changed his name to Henry Ross, was born on June 27, 1930, in Texarkana, Texas, where his father ran a cotton mill. By the time he was 7 years old, Perot was an accomplished horseman and a budding businessman. His father was training him to make a profit by buying and selling bridles.

Perot graduated from the Naval Academy in 1953 and spent four years at sea. After the Navy, Perot worked as a salesman at IBM before starting his own corporation, Electronic Data Systems (EDS), in 1962 with a $1,000 loan from his wife, Margot. The company grew quickly, and when the company went public in 1968, Fortune magazine put Perot on its cover, calling him the "fastest, richest Texan." He later sold a controlling interest in EDS to General Motors, becoming a billionaire and GM's single largest stockholder and a director. He netted approximately $750 million in 1986 when he resigned from the General Motors board of directors as part of a buyout agreement and sold his GM shares.

Although he had never held public office, by the early 1990s, Perot, sensing an opportunity for an outsider campaign with an anti-Washington message, was openly talking about a presidential run. Speaking to CNN's Larry King in 1992, he said that if he were to launch a campaign, he would run as an independent and "get both parties' heads straight."

"I was down in Texas taking care of business, tending to my family, (but) this situation got so bad that I decided I better get into it," he later said during a presidential debate. At one point during the summer of 1992, Perot dropped out, stating he could not win and that staying in the race would only create problems for the electoral process. His withdrawal came shortly after he stumbled during a speech at the NAACP, where his comments on unemployment were interpreted as patronizing and insensitive.

"Few people in this country have been able to live the American Dream to the extent that I have," Perot said when he re-entered, adding, "Neither political party has effectively addressed the issues that concern the American people."

Title: GOP's Use of the "Nuclear Option" in Supreme Court Nomination: A Look at American Political History and the Impact on Senate Politics

Article:

The ongoing debate surrounding the confirmation of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court has sparked discussions about the Republican Party's potential use of the so-called "nuclear option" to bypass a filibuster and confirm the nominee with a simple majority vote. This move, while not unprecedented in American history, represents a high degree of partisanship in the post–World War II era, according to Brian Balogh, co-host of the BackStory With the American History Guys podcast and a professor of history at the University of Virginia.

The Senate Republicans are expected to move to a vote on Gorsuch's nomination on Thursday, with Senate Democrats planning to filibuster to block the vote. In response, the Republicans may change the rules of the Senate to eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations, requiring only a simple majority of votes for confirmation. This move has been met with disapproval from both parties, but it is likely to occur.

The gradual ratcheting up of partisanship in the Senate has been underway since the 1980s, according to Sarah Binder, a professor of political science at George Washington University and the author of "Stalemate: Causes and Consequences of Legislative Gridlock." Binder explains that this particular move is part of a long-term parliamentary arms race between the two parties, with the Republican use of the nuclear option being a natural response to previous episodes where the minority has exploited the rules and the majority has fought back.

The use of the nuclear option will make bipartisan cooperation in the future even harder, as neither party will have incentives to compromise. The removal of institutional incentives to compromise or move towards a more consensual position across party lines will likely lead to a more scorched-earth policy, according to Balogh.

In order to address the partisanship problem, there are two solutions: either the voters stop rewarding extremism or lawmakers discover mutually beneficial compromises. Binder suggests that, despite the current polarized climate, lawmakers can still find issues on which both parties can win by enlarging the policy pie and giving each party its preferred outcome. Balogh agrees, stating that the American public will have to decide that they care more about effective governance than their party allegiances.

In conclusion, the Republican use of the nuclear option in the Supreme Court nomination process is a significant event in American political history, representing a high degree of partisanship in the post–World War II era. The move will make bipartisan cooperation more difficult, and the future of the Senate will depend on the American public's willingness to reward compromise or the ability of lawmakers to find mutually beneficial compromises.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Debate: Analysis of the Second Night

Article:

The second night of the 2020 Democratic presidential debates took place on Thursday, with ten candidates participating. The debates were broadcast on YouTube.

According to several media outlets, Senator Kamala Harris and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg were considered the winners of the debate, while Senator Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joe Biden were considered the losers.

Senator Bernie Sanders, who was expected to perform well following a solid showing in the previous debate, was criticized for his aggressive and short-on-details approach. His Medicare-for-all plan and free college plan were subject to criticism, particularly from Mayor Buttigieg, who argued against subsidizing college for billionaires' children. Sanders' performance was described as wearing thin as the debate progressed.

Former Vice President Joe Biden faced criticism, particularly from Senator Kamala Harris, on the issue of race. Harris was praised for her tough and measured approach, demonstrating her ability to challenge not just fellow Democrats but also President Trump in the future.

Senator Kamala Harris and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg were highlighted as the standout candidates of the night. Both candidates were praised for their leadership skills, policy acumen, and authenticity, traits that are attractive to voters regardless of gender, race, or sexual orientation.

Senator Kamala Harris' strong performance was marked by her clear and measured answers, direct and pointed shots, and personal examples. Her challenge to former Vice President Joe Biden on the issue of race was particularly notable.

Mayor Pete Buttigieg's big challenge came when he was asked about the ongoing lack of minority representation on South Bend's police force. He admitted his failure to address the issue and spoke about his community's pain, accomplishments, and future plans. His self-criticism was praised as rare and thoughtful in politics.

The debate was also marked by Senator Elizabeth Warren's solid performance, and Senator Amy Klobuchar's strong showing, particularly on the issue of healthcare.

In conclusion, the second night of the 2020 Democratic presidential debates saw Senator Kamala Harris and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg emerge as the standout candidates, with Senator Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joe Biden facing criticism for their performances. The debates provided a valuable opportunity for the candidates to showcase their policies, leadership skills, and authenticity to the American public.

Title: Boeing Experiences First Annual Loss of Commercial Airplane Orders in Decades

Article:

Boeing, the aerospace giant, ended 2020 with a negative order count for commercial airplanes, marking the first time this has occurred in decades, according to a report by CNBC. The company reported a loss of 87 airplane orders, indicating more cancellations than new orders.

The high rate of cancellations is a sign of the ongoing impact of the crisis surrounding the 737 Max, an airplane involved in two fatal crashes that claimed the lives of 346 people. Boeing's order book for the troubled jet shrank by 183 planes, with much of the decline attributed to the bankruptcy of low-cost overseas airlines like India's Jet Airways and Vietnam's VietJet. However, ongoing issues with getting the 737 Max certified led to insufficient demand to offset the losses.

There was a 90 percent drop in orders for 737 models during the year, according to CNN. Boeing barely had any firm orders for the Max after the grounding in mid-March, and other models also suffered a 29 percent drop in new orders.

American Airlines extended its cancellations for the 737 Max until June 4th, after previously targeting April 7th. The carrier has repeatedly pushed back the date as Boeing continues to struggle to secure regulatory approval for the 737 Max.

The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the grounding of all Boeing 737 Max jets after two deadly crashes in October 2018 and March 2019. Both crashes have been linked to a piece of software known as the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) that Boeing had installed on the 737 Max.

Recently, Boeing has been embroiled in a new controversy involving internal messages in which employees discussed the problems with the 737 Max in ways the company characterized as "completely unacceptable." In the chats and emails released by congressional investigators, employees mocked regulators, expressed concerns about flying the 737 Max themselves, and described interactions with FAA officials as cover-ups.

The messages reveal Boeing's attempts to reduce the amount of simulator training required by the FAA to certify pilots for the 737 Max. Last week, the company announced it would recommend simulator training for pilots of its 737 Max jets after previously stating that such training was unnecessary.

Boeing originally sold the 737 Max to carriers on the promise they wouldn't have to pay for pilot training on simulators, which can be costly for airlines. Instead, pilots who were certified to fly on the 737 Next Generation planes took a short course on an iPad to fly the Max, according to The New York Times.

Title: Economic Recovery Slows as Infection Surges Impact Small Businesses and Employment

Article:

Recent data from employment platform ZipRecruiter and small business software provider Homebase indicate a slowdown in job postings and small business openings in June, following a significant improvement in May. The Homebase data showed a nearly 40 percent improvement for small business activity in May, which fell to 6 percent across all of June.

States experiencing infection surges, such as Texas, have reported layoffs and business closures, even before officials reimpose some restrictions on economic activity. Foot traffic to retailers and other businesses declined in the third week of June in several large cities across southern states, where infections have spiked, according to an analysis of Safegraph.com data by researchers at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.

Furthermore, data from 40 million households compiled by the financial firm Commerce Signals shows that after weeks of improvement, credit and debit card spending declined at the end of May across most states. This pattern, which economists have been dreading, represents a departure from the "rocket ship" recovery that President Trump promised in June.

Federal Reserve officials have warned publicly that the recovery appears perilous and highly dependent on public health. "The path forward for the economy is extraordinarily uncertain and will depend in large part on our success in containing the virus," Fed Chair Jerome H. Powell told a House committee on Tuesday. "A full recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to re-engage in a broad range of activities."

The next few months of recovery could be rocky even if the current infection surge abates. Job losses have slowed but remain at levels higher than in any previous recession, and a growing share of workers now report they have been laid off permanently, rather than temporarily furloughed. A significant share of small businesses have still not reopened, even as states increasingly lift restrictions on their operations, suggesting some of them may be shuttered for good. By many measures, business activity and employment remains down by a quarter or more from pre-crisis levels.

Title: Trump Declares Hillary Clinton as "Real Enemy" in Exclusive Interview

Article:

Presumptive Republican nominee for President, Donald Trump, declared former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton as his main adversary in an exclusive interview with ███ on Tuesday evening. The interview took place before the polls closed in Indiana, as Trump was securing the GOP nomination for the presidency.

Trump's interview aimed to unify the Republican Party and focus on Clinton, the likely Democratic nominee, whom he referred to as the "real enemy." He stated, "The real enemy is Hillary Clinton and four more years of essentially Obama." Trump criticized Clinton's positions on trade deals like NAFTA and the Trans Pacific Partnership, her opposition to securing the U.S. border with Mexico, and her stance on a strong American military.

Trump expressed confidence in his ability to bring jobs back to America, stating that NAFTA, signed by Clinton's husband, is the worst economic development deal in U.S. history. He asserted that Clinton would not be able to compete with him on jobs and the economy, the border, or the military.

Regarding his vice presidential pick, Trump indicated that he would choose a political figure, rather than a businessperson, to help navigate the political landscape and get things done in Congress. Trump did not reveal any potential running mates but stated that he would close the nomination process before making a vice presidential selection.

Trump also attributed the high Republican primary turnout and low Democrat turnout to his strong performance in the general election. He claimed that the high turnout was a sign of his electability, stating, "It's up more than 70 percent... This week we'll break the all-time record with many states left." Trump also suggested that he would have had more votes than Clinton if he had faced only one serious competitor during the primaries.

Title: GOP Senator Criticizes President Trump's Border Wall Funding Demand as a "Made-Up Fight"

Article:

Senator Bob Corker, a Republican from Tennessee, has criticized President Trump's determination to secure funding for a border wall, labeling it as a "made-up fight." In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union," Corker stated, "This is a made-up fight so the president can look like he's fighting, but even if he wins, our borders are going to be insecure."

Corker, a frequent critic of the president, argued that the White House is proposing the wrong solution, suggesting that the focus should be on more sophisticated technology. He compared the situation to suggesting the use of the Wright brothers' technology in the Pentagon instead of modern stealth fighters.

"It's not just about the money, it's what we're spending it on," Corker said.

The current stalemate between President Trump and Democratic leaders over the border wall funding has led to a partial shutdown of the federal government. Corker asserted, "We could secure our borders. We could solve this problem. This is a made-up fight."

In a tweet on Sunday, President Trump stated that technology is fine but that the wall is essential, saying, "It is only a good old fashioned Wall that works!" The president also tweeted, "The only way to stop drugs, gangs, human trafficking, criminal elements and much else from coming into our Country is with a Wall or Barrier."

The ongoing debate between the president and Democratic leaders continues as they seek a resolution to the funding impasse.

Title: House Oversight Committee Schedules Vote to Consider Contempt Charges Against Attorney General Eric Holder

Article:

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has scheduled a vote for next week to consider holding Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress over the controversial Fast and Furious gun-tracking operation. The vote is scheduled for June 20.

Committee Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) released a 64-page memo in early May outlining the case for holding the attorney general in contempt. Issa's argument is based on Holder's failure to respond to an October 2011 subpoena for internal Justice Department documents on the operation.

The Obama administration has not asserted Executive Privilege or any other valid privilege over these materials, and it is unacceptable that the Department of Justice refuses to produce them, Issa said in a statement Monday, accusing Holder of having "failed to meet his legal obligations." He said the Justice Department has "obstructed the investigation," adding that the department "can still stop the process of contempt" by delivering key documents.

In a separate statement, House Speaker John Boehner said the department is "out of excuses." The Justice Department maintains that it has cooperated with the investigation and provided thousands of documents. Holder has testified before the committee at least eight times about Fast and Furious, most recently on Thursday before the House Judiciary Committee.

In a statement, Justice Department spokeswoman Tracy Schmaler called the scheduled vote "unfortunate and unwarranted." She said there had been "ongoing discussions" with committee staff about a "mutually acceptable resolution" to their information requests.

"From the beginning, Chairman Issa has distorted the facts, ignored testimony and flung inaccurate accusations at the attorney general and others, and this latest move fits within that tired political playbook that has so many Americans disillusioned with Washington," she said.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney on Monday also noted that Justice has provided 7,600 pages of documents to date and provided testimony during "hours and hours" of congressional hearings. He suggested the vote next week is political.

At Thursday's hearing, Issa grilled Holder in a particularly heated exchange where he accused the attorney general of failing to answer questions about the investigation.

"Have you and your attorneys produced internally the materials responsive to the subpoenas?" Issa asked.

"We believe that we have responded to the subpoenas," Holder began.

"No. Mr. Attorney General, you're not a good witness. A good witness answers the question asked," Issa snapped.

The Fast and Furious program oversaw sales of nearly 2,000 firearms to suspected Mexican drug cartels in an attempt to trace gun trafficking. But the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) recovered only 567 of the guns. Most controversially, many of the guns were found at violent crime scenes, including at the shooting of Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

The Republican leadership initially hedged on fully supporting Issa's case due to concerns that charging the attorney general in contempt in an election year could backfire. At the same time, they tried to allay concerns from conservatives -- particularly freshmen -- who called for Holder's resignation.

Six House Republican freshmen wrote to the leadership on May 18 to push for a contempt of Congress resolution against Holder. Hours later, Boehner, R-Ohio, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, R-Va., and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., issued a letter to Holder demanding that he fully cooperate with the Oversight Committee investigation. They also warned that "if necessary, the House will act to fulfill our constitutional obligations in the coming weeks."

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Monday that the latest announcement is "straightforward and necessary."

"Contempt is the only tool Congress has to enforce a subpoena," he said.

But Issa's Democratic counterpart on the House oversight committee, Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., called the committee's action "unfortunate."

"I am guardedly optimistic that a path forward exists that will serve the legitimate interests of the Committee in conducting rigorous oversight, protect the legitimate interests of the Department in its ongoing investigations and prosecutions, and avoid the needless politicization of this very serious issue," he said in a statement.

Holder would join only one other attorney general, Janet Reno in 1998, to be held in contempt by the Oversight Committee. The last time the House voted to find an executive branch official in contempt was in 2008 over the U.S. attorney firings controversy. It passed a resolution against White House Chief of Staff Joshua Bolten and former White House counsel Harriet Miers for failing to provide internal documents. Miers also refused to comply with a subpoena to appear at a hearing. The House Judiciary Committee also found White House adviser Karl Rove in contempt later that year over the same issue.

Title: Age Differences in Attention to COVID-19 News Among U.S. Adults

Article:

A survey conducted by Pew Research Center's Election News Pathways project revealed that 92% of U.S. adults were closely following news about the COVID-19 pandemic in late March. However, significant differences in attention to the pandemic emerged by age, particularly between the youngest and oldest Americans.

More than two-thirds of adults ages 65 or older (69%) said they were following news of the pandemic very closely, while about four-in-ten Americans between the ages of 18 and 29 (42%) reported the same level of attention. Those adults ages 30 to 49 and ages 50 to 64 fell in between.

These differences persisted over time. As the public's attention to news about the coronavirus outbreak grew from the first half to the second half of March, the growth was not equal across all age groups, with attention among the youngest cohort remaining behind others.

The survey was administered from March 10-16, 2020, among 8,914 U.S. adults, and again from March 19-24 among 11,537 adults. In this short period, overall attention to news about the outbreak remained extremely high, with the share following it very closely rising from 51% to 57% over this period.

Some age groups intensified their attention, while others did not. The portion of those ages 30 to 49 and ages 50 to 64 following the news very closely grew about 10 percentage points. On the other hand, the portion of those ages 18-29 and 65 and older following coronavirus news very closely remained largely unchanged.

From mid to late March, the percentage following COVID-19 news very closely grew among middle-aged groups, while youngest adults remained least engaged. The share of those ages 30 to 49 who said they were following coronavirus coverage very closely rose 10 percentage points, from 44% to 54%. Among people ages 50 to 64, the percentage following news about the pandemic very closely rose by nine points – up from 54% to 63%.

Attention among those ages 65 and older did not change much between the two time periods, but this may largely be due to their very high level of interest from the outset. Even during the first survey, fully two-thirds said they were following news very closely, something that could reflect both the news consumption habits of senior citizens as well as warnings that they were among those most vulnerable to the new virus. In the March 16-24 survey, that number remained largely unchanged at 69%.

However, the increasingly sobering news of the pandemic had little impact on the group paying the least attention, those 18 to 29 years of age. Four-in-ten said they were following news about the virus very closely in the first survey, a figure that remained almost the same later in March (42%).

Overall, the youngest adults, those ages 18 to 29, are the least likely to say they are following news about the coronavirus very closely, while the oldest adults ages 65 and older are the most likely to do so. This level of engagement remained consistent from mid to late March.

These measures and more can be explored further in the Election News Pathways data tool, where all of the data associated with this project is available for public use. For more information on the research on public opinion of COVID-19, visit the dataset. The data from this analysis comes from a survey conducted March 10-16, 2020, and a survey conducted March 19-24, 2020. For the March 10-16 survey, see the survey questions and methodology, or access the dataset. For the March 19-24 survey, see the survey questions and methodology, or access to the dataset.

Title: House Budget Committee Approves GOP's ObamaCare Repeal and Replacement Plan

Article:

The House Budget Committee approved the Republican's ObamaCare repeal and replacement plan on Thursday morning in a 19-17 vote. Three Republicans, Dave Brat (Va.), Mark Sanford (S.C.), and Gary Palmer (Ala.), voted against the bill.

The three dissenting Republicans are members of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, which opposes the bill due to its similarities to the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare). Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) stated that the Budget panel's action brings Republicans "another step closer toward keeping our promise to repeal and replace ObamaCare."

The bill will now move to the House Rules Committee, where leadership may make amendments to address concerns from both conservatives and moderates. The Rules Committee will be the final stop before the bill reaches the floor. House Freedom Caucus Chairman Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) has announced he will offer an amendment to leadership on Friday, but has not disclosed its content.

In her opening remarks, Budget Chairwoman Diane Black (R-Tenn.) encouraged conservatives to stay engaged in the process and work towards improving the proposal. The committee approved four non-binding recommendations from Republicans, including a work requirement for able-bodied adults enrolled in Medicaid and a plan to gear the refundable tax credits towards low-income individuals.

Under the current GOP plan, the credits are based on age, not income, for individuals making up to $75,000. After that, for every $1,000 someone's income increases, they would lose $100 in tax credit. Some Republicans have expressed concern that the tax credits are too generous for those with higher incomes and do not provide enough assistance for older, low-income individuals.

The work requirement, as well as adjusting the tax credits to provide more help to lower-income individuals, could help bring moderates onboard. The work requirement is generally supported by both conservatives and moderates.

Another motion approved by the committee would recommend giving states the option to accept their Medicaid funding through block grants. The current GOP plan only allows per-capita caps. Members of the Freedom Caucus are pushing for changes to the legislation, warning that the bill creates a new entitlement program by providing refundable tax credits to help people buy insurance. They also want the changes to Medicaid in the legislation to take effect earlier.

The White House has stated it is working with leadership on a manager's amendment to the bill, but has not provided details. The Republican Study Committee wants the bill to include a quicker Medicaid freeze and work requirements for Medicaid recipients. The chairman of the House Freedom Caucus has also announced he will offer an amendment to leadership on Friday that he claims could address both conservative and moderate concerns.

House Republican leaders have a narrow margin for error once the healthcare bill reaches the floor. At least 15 Republicans have stated they will vote against the bill or are leaning against it, according to CQ Roll Call's Whip List, while many more are undecided. Twenty-two defections would be enough to defeat the bill on the floor.

In the Senate, some Republicans are privately expressing hope that the House bill will fail, given the challenges they could face in trying to pass the measure.

Title: Sanders' Improved Chances in Democratic Primary, but Obstacles Remain

Article:

Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate, has reportedly raised approximately $34.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2019, bringing his total fundraising to nearly $100 million. This places him ahead of all other candidates in fundraising, a factor that historically has been indicative of primary success.

According to data from the past 14 primary elections where an incumbent was not running, candidates who led in fundraising at this point have gone on to win the nomination nine times. Even when a candidate is trailing in national polls, as Sanders currently is, the leader has won three out of five times. This includes past candidates like Democrat Bill Clinton in 1992 and Republican Mitt Romney in 2012.

Joe Biden, however, leads in endorsements from members of Congress and governors, with 33 such endorsements. Historically, candidates who lead in endorsements at this point have a strong track record of winning primaries, having gone on to win the nomination 10 out of 14 times. When a candidate like Biden leads in the polls and endorsements, they have won 7 out of 9 nominations.

Sanders is reportedly preparing to differentiate himself from his fellow Democratic candidates by highlighting contrasts on key issues, such as the Iraq War, where Sanders opposed the invasion and Biden supported it. Sanders' strategy is to use these contrasts to attract votes from other candidates. The question remains whether Sanders will use these critiques in television ads in states like Iowa and New Hampshire as the voting dates approach.

Some caution that Sanders may face challenges in taking down Biden on the Iraq War issue, as he was unable to do so in the 2016 primary against Hillary Clinton. The issue may be less potent than it once was, and Sanders may face competition from other candidates, such as Pete Buttigieg, who is perceived as authoritative on national security and can criticize Trump for using a 'bone spur' deferment to avoid the Vietnam War.

Others argue that Sanders is well-positioned to use the escalating hostilities in the Middle East as an opportunity to highlight his alternative policy. Sanders has a long record as an anti-war activist, dating back to the Vietnam War. In 2016, he gained traction by contrasting his vote against the Iraq War with Hillary Clinton's vote in favor. In the current race, Sanders has staked out a radical foreign policy that includes ending the 'forever wars', using aid money as leverage to push Israel to negotiate with the Palestinians, and making climate change a cornerstone of American foreign policy.

The difficulty for Sanders is that if he raises the salience of foreign policy, he will have to argue against not only Trump but also former President Barack Obama. The safer course for Sanders would be to focus on domestic policy, where his popular policies distinguish him enough to potentially carry him to victory. However, Trump's recklessness might make that safer path impossible, as the United States is already in a de facto war with Iran. If that war becomes a large-scale conflict, Sanders may have no choice but to run as the only true anti-war candidate.

In the absence of a coordinated effort to stop Sanders' ascending campaign from former President Obama's top lieutenants, some have interpreted this as a lack of a 'NeverBernie' movement. With less than a month before voting begins, Obama has declined to offer a preferred pick to take on President Trump in 2020, only occasionally expressing concerns about moving too far left and reminding voters to be 'rooted in reality' when exploring nominee options.

Title: U.S. Senate Leaders Disagree on Witness Testimony for Impeachment Trial of President Trump

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. senators are in disagreement over the shape of an impeachment trial for President Donald Trump, with Republican leader Mitch McConnell stating he has not ruled out hearing from witnesses, as Democrats have demanded.

In an interview with "Fox & Friends" on Monday, McConnell stopped short of agreeing to a Democratic request for the Senate to agree ahead of time to take testimony during the trial expected to begin in early 2020. He cited the 1999 impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton, a Democrat, as a model.

"We haven't ruled out witnesses," McConnell said. "We've said, 'Let's handle this case just like we did with President Clinton.' Fair is fair."

During the 1999 trial, senators went through opening arguments, had a written question period, and decided what witnesses to call. There was limited testimony by video. Allowing witness testimony, particularly from current and former administration officials, was likely to prolong the trial and could bring up new evidence damaging to Republican Trump, who was impeached by the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives last week.

Chuck Schumer, the top Democrat in the Senate, said the trial must include witnesses. He urged his Senate colleagues to call for the release of relevant Trump administration documents.

"It's hard to imagine a trial not having documents and witnesses. If it doesn't have documents and witnesses, it's going to seem - to most of the American people - that it is a sham trial, a show trial," Schumer said at a press conference in New York.

The House voted along party lines to impeach Trump on two charges over his pressuring Ukraine to announce an investigation of former vice president Joe Biden and Biden's son. Biden is a potential Democratic candidate to run against Trump in the November 2020 election. Hunter Biden was on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.

Trump was charged with abuse of power and obstructing Congress' investigation. He has said he did nothing wrong. There is little chance Trump will be convicted and removed from office by the Republican-controlled Senate.

Trump on Monday accused Democrats of delaying tactics and urged for a quick conclusion to the impeachment process. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has not yet transmitted the articles of impeachment to the Senate, a bid to pressure Senate Republicans to reach an accord with Schumer on trial rules. McConnell said the Senate could not take any action until it receives the articles.

"What right does Crazy Nancy have to hold up this Senate trial? None! She has a bad case and would rather not have a negative decision. This Witch Hunt must end NOW with a trial in the Senate, or let her default & lose. No more time should be wasted on this Impeachment Scam!" Trump said on Twitter.

Schumer has requested to have four witnesses subpoenaed for the trial. The White House blocked all four, including acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney and former national security adviser John Bolton, from testifying during impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives in December.

Title: Rep. Ayanna Pressley Introduces Resolution for Impeachment Inquiry into Supreme Court Justice Kavanaugh

Article:

Rep. Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.), a member of the "Squad" in the U.S. Congress, is planning to introduce a resolution on Tuesday calling for an impeachment inquiry into Supreme Court Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh. The resolution comes in response to a New York Times report that included a new allegation of sexual misconduct from Kavanaugh's college years, although the alleged victim later stated that the incident did not occur.

In a statement, Pressley expressed support for Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez, two women who came forward during Kavanaugh's confirmation process. "I believe Christine Blasey Ford. I believe Deborah Ramirez," Pressley said in a statement shared by Boston.com reporter Nik DeCosta-Klipa, which Pressley retweeted from her official Twitter account. "It is our responsibility to collectively affirm the dignity and humanity of survivors."

The resolution calls for the House of Representatives to investigate whether impeachment proceedings should be initiated against Brett Kavanaugh. It also requests that the House Judiciary Committee conduct depositions and take affidavits, with subpoenas issued as necessary.

Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.), who heads the House Judiciary Committee, has not expressed support for impeaching Kavanaugh. However, he stated that impeaching the president is currently a top priority for his committee.

GOP leaders have criticized the renewed allegations against Kavanaugh, with Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) stating that the situation is not normal political behavior. Several Democratic presidential candidates, including Sens. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Cory Booker (D-N.J.), South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg, former Rep. Beto O'Rourke (D-Texas), and former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro, have called for Kavanaugh's impeachment following the initial Times report.

The original Times piece, adapted from a forthcoming book, asserted that a Kavanaugh classmate, Max Stier, witnessed Kavanaugh with his pants down at a different drunken dorm party, where friends allegedly pushed Kavanaugh's penis into the hand of a female student. By late Sunday, the paper had revised its story to include the fact that several friends of the alleged victim said she did not recall the reported sexual assault in question.

Title: NSA Taps into Google and Yahoo Data Links, Report Says

Article:

The National Security Agency (NSA) has reportedly tapped directly into communications links used by Google and Yahoo to move large amounts of email and other user information among overseas data centers, according to a report by The Washington Post. The report, based on secret NSA documents leaked by former contractor Edward Snowden, appears to show the agency has used weak restrictions on its overseas activities to exploit major U.S. companies' data to a far greater extent than previously realized.

The operation, code-named MUSCULAR, reportedly gained access to a cable or switch that relayed the traffic through an unnamed telecommunications provider. The interception occurs outside the United States, which means there is no oversight by the secret intelligence court.

Google chief legal officer David Drummond expressed outrage over the reported program, stating, "We are outraged at the lengths to which the government seems to have gone to intercept data from our private fiber networks, and it underscores the need for urgent reform." Google recently began speeding its efforts to encrypt internal traffic, but the company reportedly was not aware of the program.

Like other companies, Google and Yahoo constantly send data over leased and shared or exclusive international fiber-optic telecommunication lines as they synchronize information. The newly disclosed program, operated jointly with the United Kingdom's Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ), amassed 181 million records in one recent 30-day span, according to one document reported by The Washington Post. However, it is unavailable how much of that included material from U.S. residents, how the agency redacted data on them, or how much of the information was retained.

An NSA spokesperson stated that the suggestion in the Post article that the agency relies on a presidential order on foreign intelligence gathering to skirt domestic restrictions imposed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and other laws "is not true." The statement also denied that the agency collects vast quantities of U.S. persons' data from this type of collection.

NSA Director General Keith Alexander, when asked about the latest report, stated that the agency did not have unfettered access to Google and Yahoo servers. He also did not directly address whether the agency intercepts such traffic in transit. The NSA is known to tap undersea cables.

A Yahoo spokeswoman stated, "We have strict controls in place to protect the security of our data centers, and we have not given access to our data centers to the NSA or to any other government agency." Yahoo reportedly will begin encrypting users' email as it moves to the company, but it declined to say whether it would go further and keep email encrypted as it moves within Yahoo.

The report is likely to add to growing tensions between the U.S. intelligence establishment and the tech companies, which have been struggling to assure customers overseas that they need not fear U.S. spying. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy stated he would ask for an administration briefing on the program because millions of U.S. residents could have had their communications monitored daily. Leahy also stated he would be asking whether this report is accurate, what legal authority the government is using, and how they are protecting the privacy rights of law-abiding Americans.

Title: Tea Party Conservatives and Healthcare Reform: A Long-Term Effort to Defund and Repeal the Affordable Care Act

Article:

On Capitol Hill, Tea Party conservatives have found allies in their efforts to defund and potentially shut down the government over the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, founder of the House Tea Party Caucus, stated on the eve of the potential shutdown that "this is exactly what the public wants." However, not all advocacy groups are fully aligned with the defunding campaign. For instance, Americans for Prosperity, a group financed by the Koch brothers and active in health care television advertisements, is more focused on sowing public doubts about the law rather than defunding it.

Tim Phillips, the president of Americans for Prosperity, stated that the group aims to spend "tens of millions" of dollars on a multi-front effort that includes preventing states from expanding Medicaid under the law. The group's goal is not to defund the law but to repeal it. "We want to see this law repealed," Mr. Phillips said.

In August, a "Defund Obamacare Town Hall Tour" was held at the Hilton Anatole in Dallas, Texas, featuring Tea Party movement stars Senator Ted Cruz and former South Carolina Senator Jim DeMint. Cruz, who led the defunding effort, declared, "You're here because now is the single best time we have to defund Obamacare." Cruz later delivered a 21-hour monologue against the law on the Senate floor in September.

The tactic of defunding legislation through spending bills is not new in Washington. For years, Congress has attached the Hyde Amendment to spending bills, banning the use of federal money for most abortions, except in cases of incest and rape. After the Affordable Care Act passed in 2010, former Republican congressman Todd Tiahrt proposed defunding parts of the law. He discussed the idea with Speaker John Boehner's staff while the Supreme Court was considering the law's constitutionality.

Title: Judge Dismisses Defamation Lawsuit Against Former British Spy Christopher Steele in Washington DC

Article:

A judge in Washington DC has dismissed a defamation lawsuit against former British spy Christopher Steele, who compiled a dossier alleging links between Donald Trump and the Kremlin. The lawsuit was filed by three Russian oligarchs who claimed Steele defamed them by writing that they tried to influence the 2016 US election.

Steele's lawyers argued that the legal action was frivolous and an attempt to silence him. On Monday, a judge agreed, stating that Steele has a right to his opinion. Lawyers for Russian billionaires Mikhail Fridman, Petr Aven, and German Khan had argued that Steele was not entitled to free speech protections under the First Amendment to the US Constitution, as he is not a citizen of the United States. However, Judge Anthony Epstein disagreed, writing in his judgment that "advocacy on issues of public interest has the capacity to inform public debate, and thereby furthers the purposes of the First Amendment, regardless of the citizenship or residency of the speakers."

The judge also cited Washington DC's anti-SLAPP law, which prevents parties from filing lawsuits to tamp down on opposing political views. Steele's American lawyer, Christy Hull Eikhoff, said the court had shown support for the first amendment and the "profound national principle" that debate should be "uninhibited, robust, and wide open."

This is a significant victory for Christopher Steele, who had argued through his lawyers that the owners of Alfa Bank, referred to as "Alpha" in the dossier, were trying to intimidate him into silence. The court in Washington DC said Steele should have the same guarantees of free speech – under the First Amendment to the US Constitution – as American citizens. Specifically, the court said, he should get the protection given by legislation designed to stop lawsuits being used by rich individuals to stop public debate.

Alfa's owners accused Steele of acting maliciously or recklessly when he wrote a headline about "cooperation" between "Alpha" and the Kremlin in the US presidential election. However, the judgment states that this headline represents Steele's opinion based on what his sources were telling him about the Alfa oligarchs' long relationship with Vladimir Putin, including the claim that they sent him "large amounts of illicit cash" when he was deputy mayor of St Petersburg.

It is true, as the court notes, that the dossier "does not present any direct evidence that Alfa interfered in the election." The FBI has been investigating whether a computer server in Trump Tower was communicating with one belonging to Alfa Bank during the campaign. It is not known what, if anything, the FBI found.

Lawyers for the Russian billionaires told the BBC in a statement they would probably appeal the decision. The three billionaires have previously brought a defamation case against Fusion GPS, the Washington DC-based research company that hired Steele. The dossier, containing salacious allegations against President Donald Trump, was first published by BuzzFeed in January 2017.

President Trump has repeatedly dismissed the Steele dossier on Twitter as "fake" and "fraudulent." He has also called Steele a "lowlife" and claimed that the document was financed by his 2016 presidential rival, Hillary Clinton.

Title: CNN's Handling of Sanders-Warren Debate Allegation Sparks Controversy

Article:

In the latest Democratic debate, a controversy arose regarding an allegation that Sen. Bernie Sanders (I–Vt.) privately told Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D–Mass.) that a woman could not win the presidency during a 2018 meeting. The allegation, which surfaced over the weekend, was based on unnamed sources, likely members of the Warren campaign.

Sanders vehemently denied making such a comment, and the issue was brought up during the debate. In an exchange with CNN's Abby Phillip, Sanders reiterated his denial, stating, "I never said that." When asked, "You're saying that you never told Senator Warren that a woman could not win the election?" Sanders responded, "Correct."

In a subsequent question, Phillip asked Warren, "What did you think when Sen. Sanders said a woman could not win the election?" However, Phillip did not directly ask Warren about Sanders' alleged comment, instead presuming its truth.

Following the debate, CNN ran a headline, "Sanders denies saying a woman can't be president," which some interpret as implying that Sanders is denying an objective reality, despite the lack of evidence supporting the allegation and the absence of a specific inquiry into Warren's recollection of the statement.

The exchange and subsequent headline have sparked criticism, with some accusing CNN of implicitly taking Warren's side and missing an opportunity to shed light on the rare dispute between Sanders and Warren. The controversy has been a topic of discussion among Sanders' most fervent online supporters.

Title: Intelligence Community's Refusal to Brief Congress on Russian Election Interference Sparks Controversy

Article:

Tensions on Capitol Hill escalated on Wednesday night as a scheduled House Intelligence Committee briefing on alleged Russian interference in the U.S. election was canceled due to the intelligence community's alleged "intransigence." Representative Peter King (R-N.Y.), a member of the committee, expressed his displeasure to Fox News' "The Kelly File," stating, "It's their job to come. They don't have any choice. They have to come in, especially when they have created this."

The initial request for a closed, classified briefing was made by Chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) to the FBI, CIA, Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and National Security Agency. However, according to Fox News, CIA Director John Brennan declined to provide a briefer, citing the full review requested by President Obama. The other agencies did not respond to the committee's request, which is unusual given the panel is the most-senior committee with jurisdiction.

In a statement, Nunes expressed his concern, stating, "The Committee is deeply concerned that intransigence in sharing intelligence with Congress can enable the manipulation of intelligence for political purposes."

Representative King highlighted the irony in the lack of cooperation, stating, "The consensus was that there was an attempt by the Russians to put a cloud over the election, to create disunity. Well, that's what's happening right now, but it's the intelligence community that's doing it."

King also noted that lawmakers have not received any assessment from the CIA that Russia interfered to help Donald Trump win the presidency over Hillary Clinton, allegations first reported by The Washington Post on Friday.

In a late Wednesday statement, the intelligence community defended its position, noting that senior administration officials regularly provide "extensive, detailed classified and unclassified briefings to members and staff from both parties on Capitol Hill." The statement added that they are focusing on the review ordered by President Obama on foreign efforts to influence U.S. elections.

King, referring to recent press reports, said, "It's almost as if people in the intelligence community are carrying out a disinformation campaign against the president-elect of the United States." He added, "It's absolutely disgraceful, and if they're not doing it, then it must be someone in the House or the Senate who's leaking false information, and there should be a full investigation of this."

A Washington Post report on Friday, citing anonymous sources, said the CIA determined Russia interfered in the election with the purpose of helping Trump's campaign. However, as Nunes first noted in a letter on Monday, Director of National Intelligence James Clapper told their committee on Nov. 17 that the intelligence community lacked strong evidence connecting Russia to the WikiLeaks disclosures.

Further details about the "full review" Obama ordered from his intelligence agencies regarding Russian interference were not available at the time of publication. Fox News reported that the review is being led by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence and is a multi-agency effort. Investigators plan to take existing intelligence and reconstruct what happened, with a focus on whether there is new intelligence that substantiates analysis that the interference was designed to ensure a Trump victory, or whether a review of the existing intelligence with "fresh eyes" leads to new conclusions.

Title: White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus Responds to Allegations of Intelligence Leaks by Evelyn Farkas

Article:

White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus joined Hugh Hewitt for a Thursday morning interview, where one of the subjects touched on was the allegations made by Evelyn Farkas, formerly the Defense Department's top Russia expert under President Obama. Farkas is now calling for an independent investigation of the President's ties to Moscow.

In an interview on MSNBC's 'Morning Joe' on March 2nd, 2017, Farkas appeared to admit to leaking sensitive information about potential spying on President-elect Trump and his transition team. Fox News ran a story on this titled: "Former Obama official discloses rush to get intelligence on Trump team."

In the Farkas statement in question, she said:

"I had a fear that somehow that information would disappear with the senior [Obama] people who left, so it would be hidden away in the bureaucracy... that the Trump folks – if they found out how we knew what we knew about their... the Trump staff dealing with Russians – that they would try to compromise those sources and methods, meaning we no longer have access to that intelligence."

Following this, President Trump tweeted: "Terrible! Just found out that Obama had my 'wires tapped' in Trump Tower just before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!" on March 4th, 2017.

During the interview, Hugh Hewitt asked Priebus about Farkas' statement. He responded:

"It's just an incredible statement, you know, and how, what it means and what she meant by that, and whether that has anything to do with the issues in regard to surveillance of Trump transition team members is something that we need to figure out this morning and throughout the day."

Priebus also expressed his personal reaction, stating: "It's almost, it's so cavalier and unbelievable that I just wonder whether this person knows what the heck she's talking about."

When asked if Director Comey would be interested in Farkas' statement, Priebus replied: "I hope that the intelligence committees and agencies are interested in all of these things."

Radio hosts Sean Hannity and Mark Levin both mentioned the story Wednesday afternoon. The original clip from MSNBC's 'Morning Joe' is available for viewing.

Title: Reflecting on 50 Years Since Martin Luther King's Speech: A Call for Ending Race-Based Judgment

Article:

Fifty years after Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s iconic "I Have a Dream" speech, the author argues that it is time for Americans to stop basing their judgments on skin color. The article discusses the persistence of race-related issues in America, noting that racism, like other human vices, has been a constant feature throughout history.

The author shares personal experiences, including their parents' immigration to the United States and their own political career in Louisiana, to illustrate that people are more interested in an individual's beliefs and actions rather than their skin color. The author also points out that younger generations seem to pay less attention to skin color than previous generations.

However, the article acknowledges that while significant progress has been made in race relations, there are still setbacks. The author laments the shift away from the "melting pot" concept, where individuals from diverse backgrounds blend into a unified American culture, towards a focus on hyphenated identities.

The author suggests a return to the "melting pot" idea, emphasizing the unity of Americans as a shared identity, rather than focusing on differences in heritage, ethnicity, or skin color. The article concludes with a call for Americans to move past their "separateness" and embrace a more unified, color-blind society. The author emphasizes treating others as individuals and celebrating diversity while resisting the politically correct trend of emphasizing differences.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Endorses Hillary Clinton as Democratic Nominee and Expresses Readiness for Vice-Presidential Role

Article:

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has endorsed Hillary Clinton as the Democratic Party's presidential nominee and expressed her readiness to serve as Clinton's running mate. In an interview on MSNBC, Warren was asked by Rachel Maddow if she would accept the vice-presidential nomination, to which she responded affirmatively.

Warren's endorsement came shortly after she praised Clinton as a "fighter with guts" who would keep Donald Trump from reaching the White House. In an interview with the Boston Globe on Thursday, Warren endorsed Clinton, stating, "I'm ready to jump in this fight and make sure that Hillary Clinton is the next president of the United States and be sure that Donald Trump gets nowhere near the White House."

Warren also praised Bernie Sanders, Clinton's primary opponent, for running an "incredible campaign" and bringing millions of people into the democratic process. She described Sanders' campaign as "powerfully important" and noted that he had thrust important issues into the spotlight.

President Barack Obama and Vice-President Joe Biden have also given their endorsements to Clinton's candidacy. In a video recorded on Tuesday, Obama stated, "I'm with her. I don't think there has ever been someone so qualified to hold this office." Biden, in a speech on Thursday, seemed to give his endorsement, referring to "... whoever the next president is – and God willing it will be Hillary Clinton."

Warren, a favorite of the progressive left who taught constitutional law at Harvard, is seen as a possible running mate who could help entice back a disaffected left that has been excited by Sanders but ambivalent about Clinton. Warren has been especially critical of Donald Trump, attacking him in a series of speeches and setting herself up for a prominent and pugilistic role in the presidential election, whether she is on the ticket or not.

Earlier on Thursday, at a speech to the American Constitution Society in Washington DC, Warren criticized Trump as "just a businessman who inherited a fortune and kept it rolling along by cheating people."
