She described Trump as "a loud, nasty, thin-skinned fraud who... serves no one but himself" and said his attacks on Gonzalo Curiel, the federal judge presiding over the Trump University suit, were "exactly what you would expect from somebody who is a thin-skinned racist bully."

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Arizona Immigration Law: Implications for Presidential Race

Article:

The recent Supreme Court ruling on the Arizona immigration law, which struck down much of the state's enforcement efforts, has sparked discussions among political strategists regarding its potential impact on the 2012 presidential race. While the ruling initially seemed to be a setback for Republicans, some GOP strategists believe it could benefit Mitt Romney by providing an opportunity to criticize the Obama administration's handling of illegal immigration.

Brad Blakeman, former deputy assistant to President George W. Bush and a public policy professor at Georgetown University, suggested that Romney should use the ruling to emphasize the president's creation of a "constitutional crisis" on immigration. Blakeman argued that the federal government's failure to enforce immigration laws allows Arizona's struggle with its own law to highlight the need for a federal approach, which Romney claims to offer.

Romney is advised to assert that Obama should have pursued a more bipartisan approach to create a "fair, just, and equitable comprehensive policy." Blakeman believes the ruling will help Romney in the general election, but the candidate must clearly communicate to the American people that Obama created a constitutional crisis by failing to lead on immigration reform with both houses of Congress.

President Obama, on the other hand, argues that Republicans have consistently blocked immigration system reforms. In a recent address to Latino officials in Florida, Obama stated that "politics" prevented the passage of the DREAM Act, which would have allowed some illegal immigrants who arrived in the U.S. as children to remain. Obama has since implemented a similar policy administratively.

Other political strategists suggest that the ruling will give Romney an opportunity to appeal to his supporters but will not significantly impact the election. Don Fowler, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, stated that supporters of the Obama administration, which sued to block the Arizona law, will continue to back Obama despite Monday's ruling. Conversely, Fowler said, those who support Romney will remain loyal, as the country is divided on the issue of illegal immigration.

Ben Golnik, a Republican strategist based in Minnesota, stated that Monday's "split decision" provides Republicans with ammunition to bolster claims that the Obama administration has poorly handled national immigration issues and has a weak record on border security. Romney, in a statement issued after Monday's ruling, appeared to follow this advice by criticizing Obama's lack of leadership on immigration and the president's failure to present an immigration plan during his first year in office.

The Supreme Court ruling upheld one provision of Arizona's law, requiring law enforcement to check immigration status during routine stops for those they suspect may be in the country illegally. However, the ruling struck down three other provisions, including one that allowed Arizona's law enforcement to arrest those they think might be guilty of a deportable offense.

Other analysts contacted by FoxNews.com, including former South Carolina GOP chairman Van Hipp, Jr., suggested that Romney should now focus on the national security aspects of securing the border. Hipp argued that Romney's campaign must keep its message focused on national security, as the immigration issue brings it to the forefront. Romney is encouraged to emphasize why he supports securing the southern border to maintain national security.

Title: Shifting Landscape of Gay Marriage Support in the United States

Article:

As the United States Supreme Court prepares to hear arguments in two gay marriage cases this week, the political landscape on this contentious social issue is rapidly evolving. Recent headlines reflect this shift: "Support for gay marriage is soaring" (Washington Post), "Why Republicans Are Saying ‘I Do’ to Gay Marriage" (Time), "The Normalization of Gay Marriage" (The Atlantic), "Millennial Support For Gay Marriage Hits All-Time High" (Huffington Post).

The changing public opinion, as depicted in these stories, poses particular challenges for Republicans. Sen. Rob Portman of Ohio, who recently voiced his support for same-sex marriage due to his son's homosexuality, has faced support from fellow Republicans, albeit with disagreement on his stance. New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, who is up for re-election this year and is a potential 2016 presidential candidate, has grappled with the issue of "conversion therapy," a controversial practice aimed at changing homosexual individuals into heterosexuals.

Ohio Gov. John Kasich initially expressed support for civil unions but later retracted his statement through a spokesperson. Sen. Saxby Chambliss of Georgia attempted to sidestep the issue with a humorous remark that drew laughter: "I'm not gay, so I'm not going to marry one." Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, has leaned on his libertarian/states' rights ideology, stating, "I don't want the government promoting something I don't believe in, but I also don't mind if the government tries to be neutral on the issue."

Ken Mehlman, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee and head of the 2004 Bush re-election campaign who came out as gay in 2010, has gathered signatures from 131 prominent Republicans to file a friend-of-the-court brief in one of the Supreme Court cases challenging California's Proposition 8, a 2008 ballot measure that defines marriage as a legal union of one man and one woman.

When asked on Fox News Sunday if he could envision the next Republican nominee for the White House supporting gay marriage, political strategist Karl Rove responded affirmatively. Margaret Hoover, a former George W. Bush White House aide and leading Republican Party operative, agrees, stating, "At the rate this issue is changing within the party, I think it's not out of the question."

According to polls, support for gay marriage is increasing more rapidly among the public than among Republicans. The latest Washington Post/ABC poll reports that 58% of Americans support allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry, compared to 32% in 2009 and 47% in 2012. Among "millennials" (individuals born after 1980), support has soared to 70% from 51% when President Obama took office in 2009. The Post/ABC poll also finds that 81% of adults under 30 support same-sex marriage.

The Republican Party is well aware of this shift in public opinion, having lost this demographic in the 2012 presidential election, when the party platform advocated a marriage amendment to the Constitution and defended the Boy Scouts of America's ban on gay scouts and troop leaders. Today, the party's efforts to rebrand itself adopt a softer tone regarding gay rights as part of an overall effort to appear (if not become) more inclusive.

At the Conservative Political Action Conference last weekend, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, another potential 2016 presidential candidate, criticized his party for appearing "anti-everything," including "anti-gay." Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus echoed this sentiment in comments to reporters this past week.

"I think Senator Portman made some pretty big inroads last week," Mr. Priebus said. "I think it's about being decent. I think it's about dignity and respect, that nobody deserves to have their dignity diminished, or people don't deserve to be disrespected. I think that there isn't anyone in this room – Republican, Democrat, in the middle – that doesn't think that Rob Portman, for example, is a good, conservative Republican. He is. And we know that."

Title: Fauci's Support for China Travel Restrictions Contradicts Trump's Claims

Article:

During an interview with Maria Bartiromo on Fox News Business, President Trump claimed that Dr. Anthony Fauci disagreed with his decision to restrict travel from China and later agreed that the move saved hundreds of thousands of lives. However, this contradicts statements made by both Trump and Fauci in the past.

At a coronavirus task force press briefing on April 13, Trump was asked if he and Fauci were "on the same page." Trump responded, "Yeah, we have been from the beginning." During the same press briefing, Fauci discussed the responsiveness of the Trump administration to the recommendations made by the task force. He mentioned that the travel restriction was one of the recommendations they made.

In the early stages of the pandemic, Fauci stated that a China travel ban was "not something that I think we're even considering," according to New York Times interviews with White House aides and Fauci himself. By January 30, leading public health officials in the federal government were recommending travel restrictions with China to President Trump. Aides also told the Wall Street Journal that it was Fauci, CDC Director Dr. Robert Redfield, and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar who convinced the initially-skeptical Trump to make the decision.

Fauci supported the travel restrictions publicly as well. At the task force press briefing on the day the restrictions were announced, Fauci said that the restrictions were implemented to "make sure we mitigate, as best as we possibly can, this risk." On February 3, the day after the restrictions took effect, Fauci stated on CNBC that the travel restrictions would "dampen down" coronavirus cases in the United States.

On February 7, Fauci told reporters that the positives of travel restrictions with China outweighed the negatives and that "this decision was not made lightly." During the February 29 coronavirus task force press briefing, Fauci repeated the value of the travel restrictions, stating that without them, the U.S. would have had "many, many more cases" to deal with.

On March 15, Fauci said, "The president's decision to essentially have a major blocking of travel from China, that already had an effect of not seeding the way, in Europe—Italy did not do that." On March 22, Fauci said the U.S. was "not necessarily at all" on the same trajectory for coronavirus cases as Italy, citing Italy's decision not to "shut out as well the input of infections that originated in China" early on as a possible reason the country was hit particularly hard.

Fauci has consistently agreed with the travel decision. Indeed, a wide variety of reporting and his public statements make clear he was an early advocate for such restrictions in internal government coronavirus discussions. Based on all available information, Trump was not accurate to say that Fauci criticized the president's decision to restrict travel with China.

Title: Grand Jury Impaneled in Mueller Investigation: A Routine Procedure or Sign of Intensifying Inquiry?

Article:

The Wall Street Journal's recent report of special counsel Robert Mueller impaneling a grand jury in Washington has sparked widespread media attention, with cable networks and online platforms abuzz with discussions about the Russia investigation. The Journal described the move as a sign that Mueller's inquiry is growing in intensity.

However, it is essential to note that the convening of a grand jury is a common practice for prosecutors, and it would have been unusual for Mueller not to use one in this investigation. In fact, as the Journal story acknowledges, a grand jury was already in place, across the river in Alexandria, that the FBI was utilizing in this case before Mueller's appointment.

The association of "grand jury" with "indictment" in the public mind may lead to speculation about potential indictments, but it is crucial to remember that a prosecutor's ability to indict does not necessarily imply that charges will be brought against the president or his inner circle. The outcome of the investigation remains uncertain, and even Mueller himself may not yet have determined whether any actions rise to the level of an indictable offense.

The Washington Post reported that the grand jury's existence indicates that investigators are continuing to aggressively gather evidence in the case. USA Today stated that the move would grant Mueller, a former FBI director, significant power to subpoena documents and compel witnesses to testify under oath.

Ty Cobb, the president's lawyer, told the Post that the grand jury's existence could potentially accelerate the resolution of Mueller's work. This sentiment makes sense, as grand jury proceedings are intended to be confidential.

However, the existence of the grand jury has primarily fueled media speculation, with leaks about the investigation being common, as with the Washington Post's publication of the transcripts of President Trump's January calls to the leaders of Mexico and Australia, following earlier leaks of those conversations.

While the grand jury could potentially pose a serious threat to the White House, its existence has, for now, primarily created an orgy of media speculation. It is essential to remain vigilant and informed, but it is equally crucial to maintain a clear understanding of the facts and avoid jumping to conclusions.

Title: The Weekly Standard's Fact-Checking of ThinkProgress' Article on Brett Kavanaugh's Stance on Roe v. Wade

Article:

In a recent turn of events, Ian Millhiser, justice editor at ThinkProgress, has expressed discontent with The Weekly Standard, a right-leaning magazine, for labeling one of his articles as "false." The article's headline, "Brett Kavanaugh said he would kill Roe v. Wade last week and almost no one noticed," is, at the very least, quite misleading.

ThinkProgress is a left-leaning news site published by the Center for American Progress. The site has previously expressed concerns about Facebook granting fact-checking powers to an explicitly conservative media outlet, a privilege shared by only four other organizations: the Associated Press, Factcheck.org, Politifact, and Snopes.com. Articles tagged as false could potentially lose "80 percent of future traffic," according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and thus the stakes are high for media organizations.

According to Millhiser, "At its peak, Facebook provided as much as 40 percent of ThinkProgress' traffic." Facebook's recent algorithm changes have reduced the amount of traffic it sends to most news outlets, but it still accounts for between 10 to 15 percent of their readers. The difference between keeping these readers and losing them could determine whether ThinkProgress can hire more reporters to continue reporting on subjects that The Weekly Standard may have ideological disagreements about.

As a legal matter, Facebook is treading on dangerous ground by providing no oversight of its own "fact-checking" operation. In the landmark case New York Times v. Sullivan, the Supreme Court held that a media outlet can be liable for defamation if it publishes false information "with knowledge that it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not." By deferring to The Weekly Standard's "expertise and process," Facebook acted with reckless disregard of whether The Weekly Standard's article was false or not.

Millhiser appears to believe that (1) The Weekly Standard erred in labeling the article false, (2) Facebook erred in granting The Weekly Standard this power in the first place, and (3) by refusing to correct these errors, Facebook may have exposed itself to liability for defamation.

Claim #2 is a judgement call, and I cannot say whether it's correct. Maybe giving ideological groups fact-checking powers was not a good move for Facebook. I won't tackle that topic here.

However, claims 1 and 3 collapse if The Weekly Standard's fact-checkers made the right call regarding the "false" article. Let's take a look.

Again, the headline is "Brett Kavanaugh said he would kill Roe v. Wade last week and almost no one noticed." But Millhiser's article makes a more nuanced argument. As he summarizes it in the follow-up post:

Kavanaugh cited in his confirmation hearing the "Glucksberg test" —which refers to Washington v. Glucksberg, a 1997 Supreme Court decision establishing that the Constitution does not protect a right to physician-assisted suicide. Under Glucksberg, courts should determine which rights are protected by the Constitution by asking which rights are "deeply rooted in this Nation's history and tradition." Kavanaugh also said in 2017 that "even a first-year law student could tell you that the Glucksberg's approach to unenumerated rights was not consistent with the approach of the abortion cases such as Roe vs. Wade in 1973, as well as the 1992 decision reaffirming Roe, known as Planned Parenthood v. Casey." Our article also cited law professors Jim Oleske and Jamal Greene, both of whom reached similar conclusions regarding Kavanaugh's embrace of Glucksberg.

Does this information imply that Kavanaugh would be inclined to overturn Roe v. Wade? A reasonable person might infer that this is so. The article concludes with this statement: "Judge Kavanaugh appears to be telegraphing his belief that Roe, Obergefell, and the Supreme Court's decision in Lawrence v. Texas, which provides that the government can not prosecute consenting adults for having sex, were not correctly decided."

If the headline had said that Kavanaugh had "appeared to be telegraphing," or "hinted at," or even "heavily suggested" he would kill Roe v. Wade, that would be one thing. But "said" is a strong word. It makes it sound like Kavanaugh directly stated his intention to kill Roe v. Wade.

In his follow-up, Millhiser concludes that this all hinges on the definition of the verb "said." So he turns to the dictionary, which does indeed list "indicate, show, and communicate" as possible definitions for the word. However, "said" is generally used as a synonym for indicate, show, and communicate when the subject of the sentence is a thing that cannot use words. That look in your eyes can say a great deal, but not literally—a "look" does not use words. People, on the other hand, do use words, so when writers describe a person as having said something, it's implied that they did so with their mouths.

This may seem like nitpicking, but we're in the midst of an intense news cycle revolving around the question of whether Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade. A headline that straightforwardly claims he admitted he would do so is manipulating readers' expectations, and thus the claim should have been hedged in the headline—even just a little bit—as it was in the article. If the claim is The Weekly Standard was wrong to say this headline is false, then I rate this claim: Mostly false.

Title: NRA Warns of Intensified Threat to Second Amendment Rights

Article:

At the National Rifle Association's (NRA) annual meeting in Houston, leaders issued a warning to members about the potential threat to their gun rights from President Barack Obama and gun control advocates. The speakers used strong language to emphasize that they believe liberals will exploit future shooting tragedies to push for stricter gun control measures.

Jim Porter, who is set to become the group's president on Monday, stated, "Revenge is what is motivating the president's unremitting challenge to gun owners today. Obama is meeting and plotting with the who's who of the gun ban movement."

NRA Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre described the recent Senate vote to block background check legislation as "but one skirmish in what can only be defined as one long war against our Constitutional rights." He added that the group is "in the midst of a once in a generation fight for everything we care about."

LaPierre also announced that the NRA has grown to a record 5 million members following the aftermath of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. He declared, "So we don't care if it is round one, round two or round 15, the NRA will go the distance. We will never give up or sacrifice our constitutional freedom. Not one single inch!"

Chris Cox, the group's chief lobbyist, quoted an old Margaret Thatcher line, stating, "We are stronger right now than at any time in our 142-year history, but the fact is we have to be stronger because right now our freedom is under attack like never before."

LaPierre concluded his speech by stating, "We will never surrender our guns. Never. By the time we're finished, the NRA must and will be 10 million strong." The speakers emphasized that victories in politics are never final, quoting an old Margaret Thatcher line.

Title: Senators Propose Federal Standards for Electric Grid Security Following California Substation Attack

Article:

In the aftermath of a sniper attack on a California electrical substation last year, lawmakers are advocating for the imposition of federal standards to protect the nation's electric grid from potential attacks. The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday that Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) and her fellow senators plan to request the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to establish minimum security standards for critical substations.

The attack on Pacific Gas & Electric's Metcalf transmission substation on April 16, 2013, involved the severing of AT&T fiber-optic lines to disrupt phone and 911 service, and gunfire into a PG&E substation, causing outages. The incident, which had not been widely publicized until The Wall Street Journal's report on Wednesday, involved intruders lifting heavy manhole covers, climbing under the road, and cutting AT&T fiber-optic cables, temporarily disabling 911 and phone services. In a 19-minute period, gunmen fired more than 100 rounds into substation equipment, disabling 17 of 20 large transformers, causing approximately $16 million in damage. No arrests have been made in the case.

During an oversight hearing in December, Representative Henry Waxman (D-Calif.) described the incident as an "unprecedented and sophisticated attack on an electric grid substation with military-style weapons." He withheld details of the incident to avoid harming the investigation but added he had been in touch with the FBI about it.

Congress is currently discussing a proposal that would grant the FERC the power to write and impose interim rules on grid defenses. The utility industry would still be able to influence any permanent requirements, according to The Wall Street Journal. Representative Trent Franks (R-Ariz.) stated, "The last thing I want to do is regulate any industry," but added that utilities must do more to protect the grid for the sake of national security.

Under current law, the commission has to accept or reject proposals written by an industry-dominated group but cannot alter them, according to the report. Some utility industry executives told The Wall Street Journal it would be difficult to come up with rules for improving security that would work in both urban and rural areas. Lisa Barton, executive vice president of transmission for American Electric Power, stated, "One size fits all may not get you true resiliency," adding that increasing protections could be costly. "I'm not saying it is not worth it," she said.

Title: White House Summons Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein for Meeting Amidst Russia Investigation Tensions

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who has been in the crosshairs of President Donald Trump due to his role in the expanding Russia investigation, was summoned to the White House for a meeting with the president on Thursday. The meeting, though seemingly arranged quickly, was described by a White House official as a discussion regarding "routine department business."

Rosenstein, who is Attorney General Jeff Sessions' deputy and was appointed by Trump, was spotted leaving the West Wing on Thursday afternoon. However, a White House official downplayed the meeting's significance, stating, "Rod Rosenstein met with the president at the White House regarding routine department business."

The meeting came at a sensitive time for Rosenstein. Trump, outraged over the FBI's raid of personal lawyer Michael Cohen's office this week, has been publicly expressing his frustration with Rosenstein, Sessions, and Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Trump's attack on Rosenstein is in reference to how the deputy attorney general signed a FISA surveillance warrant for former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The president has repeatedly decried the Department of Justice and FBI's efforts to obtain that surveillance warrant.

The meeting between Rosenstein and Trump lasted about an hour, during which they discussed document production to Congress, according to Justice Department officials. Rosenstein was accompanied by FBI officials and also met with White House Counsel Don McGahn.

Some Trump supporters have been urging him to remove Rosenstein. Former federal prosecutor Joseph diGenova told Fox News' "Hannity" on Wednesday, "Rod Rosenstein is so incompetent, compromised, and conflicted that he can no longer serve as the deputy attorney general."

Despite this pressure, Trump, on Thursday, tweeted that he agrees with his legal team in cooperating with Mueller's probe. "I have agreed with the historically cooperative, disciplined approach that we have engaged in with Robert Mueller (Unlike the Clintons!)," the president tweeted.

Other supporters, including former adviser Stephen Bannon, have publicly encouraged Trump to stop cooperating with Mueller's requests. Earlier on Thursday, Trump denied seeking to shut down Mueller's Russia probe, stating, "If I wanted to fire Robert Mueller in December, as reported by the Failing New York Times, I would have fired him. Just more Fake News from a biased newspaper!"

Title: Experts Adopt Harm-Reduction Approach to Protests Amidst Rising COVID-19 Cases in Certain States

Article:

A divide among political groups regarding the reopening of the economy and the potential risks associated with protests following the death of George Floyd has emerged. As new hotspots of COVID-19 cases are reported in Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, and Utah, some experts attribute the spike in part to increased testing, while others point to the recent reopening of businesses and public spaces in these areas.

The nationwide protests have also raised concerns about their potential role in the spread of the virus. However, it is currently too early to determine whether the protests will lead to a widespread outbreak, as the differences between outdoor and indoor exposure play a significant role in transmission. Outdoor protests may not pose as great a risk as indoor gatherings, and arrests and detainment in police vans or jail cells could potentially contribute to the spread of the virus more than the protests themselves.

Some argue that the protests, which have been ongoing since the death of George Floyd, should not be encouraged or endorsed if they lead to a significant increase in COVID-19 infections and deaths. On the other hand, protesters are reportedly aware of the risk of transmission and are taking precautions to minimize it.

Public-health experts have adopted a harm-reduction approach to the protests, offering recommendations to help people protest as safely as possible. Some experts have gone further by providing masks and other protective gear on-site. The approach reflects the longstanding goal of public-health experts to maximize the health of the population across all aspects of life.

Experts have emphasized that eternal lockdowns were not the only option for combating the pandemic. Once areas managed to get initial case spikes under control through widespread social distancing, a new phase of control should have been initiated with widespread testing and contact tracing. The initial lockdown period was intended to avoid the worst possible scenario, but the U.S. did not use that time to prepare for managing the pandemic in the future. As a result, the weeks that have passed since reopening have been wasted, according to some experts.

Jeff Shaman, an infectious disease modeler at Columbia University, stated, "We managed to disrupt our economy [and] skyrocket unemployment, and we didn't control the damn virus."

Title: House Immigration Reform Gains Momentum as Bipartisan Group Nears Bill Release

Article:

The Republican-led House of Representatives is set to delve deeper into immigration reform this week, aiming to catch up with the Senate on the primary domestic policy issue of the year. A bipartisan group in the House, which has been working on the issue for four years without releasing any proposals, is on the verge of producing a bill.

The House Judiciary Committee will hold its first immigration markup on Tuesday, focusing on an enforcement-centered bill that Democrats have expressed disapproval of. Meanwhile, the all-Democratic Congressional Hispanic Caucus will meet with Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) on Wednesday, with immigration being a key topic of discussion.

Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D-Ill.), head of the CHC immigration task force, stated in an interview on Monday, "He's the speaker of the House, the leader of the House and of the Republican Conference. He wants to get comprehensive immigration reform; we want to get comprehensive immigration reform passed. We should form a pact. Let's cement it this Wednesday."

The dual-track approach could signal actual momentum on House immigration reform, which has lagged significantly behind Senate efforts. The Senate is considering the bipartisan Gang of Eight bill on the floor and may vote on it before the July 4th recess.

The House group, now composed of three Republicans and four Democrats, appears poised to unveil its bill as early as Wednesday, although a later release in the week or early next week is more likely. Negotiators are still meeting for final touches and to review the language that has come back from the House legislative counsel.

The four Democratic negotiators—Reps. Xavier Becerra and Zoe Lofgren of California, John Yarmuth of Kentucky, and Gutierrez—will update all House Democrats at a caucus meeting on Tuesday. The group's Democratic members are also having smaller briefings with different members throughout the week, including meetings with the Congressional Black Caucus and the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus on Tuesday, and New Democrats and the Congressional Progressive Caucus on Wednesday.

A Democratic aide noted, "Democratic members are seeking input from their caucus on the bipartisan agreement the working group is drafting into legislative language. It's their hope that once all the i's are dotted and the t's are crossed, they will be able to introduce the measure with support from both sides of the aisle."

However, the focus will be on the meeting between Boehner and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, believed to be the first time a Republican House speaker has met with the group, which is composed of all Democrats.

Title: White House Warns of Potential $200 Billion Consumer Spending Drop in 2013 Due to Failed Middle-Class Tax Cut Extension

Article:

The White House has issued a warning to Republican lawmakers, stating that consumer spending could decrease by nearly $200 billion in 2013 if Congress fails to approve an extension of tax cuts for the middle class by the end of next month. The warning was accompanied by a report from the National Economic Council and the Council of Economic Advisers, which analyzed the impact on retailers if taxes increase on January 1 for families earning less than $250,000 per year.

The report suggests that allowing middle-class tax rates to rise and failing to pay for a short-term "patch" of the Alternative Minimum Tax could cut the growth of consumer spending by 1.7 percentage points in 2013. The White House believes that Democrats and Republicans should collaborate to renew middle-class tax cuts to provide economic certainty.

The Council of Economic Advisers estimates that consumers could spend nearly $200 billion less next year due to higher taxes, approximately four times the amount spent during the "Black Friday" weekend in 2011. The administration released the report on "Cyber Monday," the busiest online shopping day of the year, to potentially build support for President Obama's position in negotiations with Congress to avoid the "fiscal cliff," a mix of tax increases and automatic spending cuts set to take effect in January.

The administration's release of the report appears to be a calculated move to garner support for President Obama's position in negotiations with Congress to avert the fiscal cliff. Mr. Obama is urging lawmakers to first approve an extension of tax cuts for the middle class and to address tax rates for wealthier families later, which could result in an automatic tax increase on January 1 for households earning more than $250,000.

In a statement, the office of White House press secretary Jay Carney said, "While the president is committed to working with Congress to reach compromises on areas of disagreement, there is no reason to delay acting where everyone agrees: extending tax cuts for the middle-class." Carney added, "There is no reason to hold the middle-class hostage while we debate tax cuts for the highest income earners."

Lawmakers from both parties have expressed optimism about reaching at least a temporary deal with the White House before the end of the year. Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona said in a Sunday interview on CNN, "I think it's likely that there will be a solution — not a final solution by any means, and not a big solution — but will get us through the end of the year into next year with a plan for trying to deal with these issues long-term over the course of the next Congress." Kyl added, "That will require compromise."

Title: Legal Uncertainty Surrounds Detention of U.S. Citizens as Enemy Combatants

Article:

The legality of detaining U.S. citizens arrested on domestic soil as enemy combatants remains unclear, despite the absence of known links between the recent Boston bombing suspect, Mr. Tsarnaev, and Al Qaeda. This issue has been a subject of debate among lawmakers, with some, like Senator Lindsey Graham, believing it to be lawful, while others disagree. Neither Congress nor the Supreme Court has definitively resolved the question.

During the Bush administration, the Supreme Court upheld the indefinite military detention of Yaser Esam Hamdi, an American citizen captured carrying a weapon on the Afghanistan battlefield. However, the court never resolved the case of another American, Jose Padilla, who was held as an enemy combatant for several years after his arrest in Chicago. Two different federal appeals courts disagreed about the lawfulness of holding someone like Mr. Padilla in indefinite detention without trial, and the Bush administration transferred him back to the civilian court system before the Supreme Court took up the case.

In the Hamdi ruling, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote, "There is no bar to this nation’s holding one of its own citizens as an enemy combatant." However, she also limited the decision to Mr. Hamdi's "narrow circumstances" and stated that indefinite detention for the purpose of interrogation is not authorized.

Senator Graham suggested that the purpose of holding Mr. Tsarnaev as a military detainee would be to question him at length without a lawyer. The Obama administration has stated it would use a public-safety exception to the Miranda rule to question him for a period without informing him of his rights to remain silent and have a lawyer. However, Mr. Graham argued that this would at best gain only a few days before a lawyer intervened.

Mr. Graham also acknowledged that ultimately Mr. Tsarnaev must be transferred back to the civilian criminal justice system for prosecution, as the statute authorizing military commissions does not apply to U.S. citizens. Mr. Graham, one of the leading Republican voices opposing the torture of terrorism suspects, emphasized that interrogation as an enemy combatant would not involve inflicting suffering on Mr. Tsarnaev to make him talk, and that anything he said in military detention should not be used as courtroom evidence.

However, Mr. Graham rejected the view that the Federal Bureau of Investigation might be equally or more effective than intelligence officials at persuading Mr. Tsarnaev to provide information, even with a defense lawyer at his side. He argued that law enforcement officials would disrupt the dynamic of building a rapport with a prisoner by their presence. "That is, to me, the dumbest way to induce someone to talk," he said of such tools and tactics of law enforcement officials. "I want intelligence officials trained in the intelligence process to have a chance to talk to him, without a lawyer."

Title: Biden Rallies in Detroit Ahead of Michigan Presidential Primary

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden held a rally in Detroit on Monday, seeking votes, volunteers, and campaign contributions ahead of Michigan's presidential primary. Addressing a crowd of approximately 1,000 people at Renaissance High School, Biden emphasized the importance of Michigan in the upcoming November election, stating, "Michigan, I’m counting on you in a big way."

Biden, who has garnered significant support from the African American community, was joined at the rally by U.S. Senators Kamala Harris of California and Cory Booker of New Jersey. The event took place in a city where 82% of residents are African American.

Senator Cory Booker spoke at the rally, expressing support for Biden, stating, "And there is one man who is ready to go to the center of the arena, who has the best shot to beat Donald Trump, the best one to heal the soul of America and bring dignity back to the office. And that person is one person, Joe Biden."

Protesters carrying Green New Deal signs disrupted the rally, chanting, "Joe has to go." They were escorted out of the gymnasium. Biden responded, "The Bernie Bros are here," telling security to let the protesters leave peacefully.

Lt. Gov. Garlin Gilchrist, who is supporting Biden, received some boos from the crowd when he took a swipe at Hillary Clinton's 2016 campaign.

Biden emphasized the importance of the election, stating, "This election isn’t about a battle for the soul of the Democratic Party, it’s a battle for the soul of America." He also reminded the crowd of the $2.5 billion investment the Obama administration made to help restore the Great Lakes.

Before the rally, Biden attended a $1,000-per-person fundraiser at the Detroit Athletic Club, hosted by some of Michigan's biggest political names, including former Gov. Jim Blanchard, Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan, and Detroit businessman Dennis Archer Jr.

Biden's rally at Renaissance High School was the biggest event of the day. It featured a raucous crowd that cheered throughout, a marching band, and signs emblazoned with "Joementum" and "Michiganders love Biden!"

Despite Biden's late arrival in the state and minimal organization on the ground, his numbers soared in several polls released on Monday. In a poll of 400 Michigan voters done by the Lansing polling firm EPIC/MRA last week for the Free Press, Biden had opened up a 24-point lead over Sanders, gaining a 51%-27% margin in the final days before Tuesday's presidential primary election.

However, Sanders was in the same position in 2016, down by 26 points to rival Hillary Clinton before the primary and ended up pulling out a narrow victory.

In Grand Rapids, Biden spoke at the Cherry Health Heart of the City Community Health Center to a small audience of media and Cherry Health officials, discussing the expansion of community health centers across the country due to the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare. Biden stated that he hopes to build on that in the White House.

Title: Media Trust and the Trump Presidency: A Look at the Challenges Facing the News Industry

Article:

The election of Donald Trump as the 45th President of the United States has presented a unique challenge for the media, an industry grappling with declining trust and revenue. According to a Gallup poll in September 2016, only 14% of Americans have "a great deal" of trust in the news media to report the news fully, accurately, and fairly. Combining this with the 18% who have "a fair amount" of trust, only a third of the country's trust is in the news media.

The media's treatment of President Trump during the campaign is believed to be a significant factor in this distrust, particularly among his 63 million voters. The media's coverage of Trump was often criticized as mean and petty, in contrast to the celebratory coverage given to President Barack Obama in 2008, the first black president.

Instead of seizing the opportunity to rebuild trust with disenchanted readers and viewers, major media outlets have continued to antagonize Trump's supporters. For instance, a week after Trump's election, The New York Times led a chorus of news outlets reporting chaos in the Trump transition team. However, the transition went smoothly, and Trump appointed a competent Cabinet from Day One.

Meanwhile, the New York Times itself has faced internal challenges, with layoffs and plans to rent out parts of its building to offset ad revenue losses. This is just one example of the lost opportunities to reach out to disenchanted readers and viewers.

The media is based in liberal strongholds such as Washington, New York, and Los Angeles, and is staffed by people who either never lived in the nation's interior or who left due to dislike for their hometowns. Last summer, the Columbia Journalism Review published a column urging reporters to abandon the pretense of objectivity to stop Trump.

In the 2016 election, 243 newspapers endorsed Hillary Clinton, while 20 endorsed Trump. If newspapers had any significant influence, it would have been a 50-state shutout for Clinton. Instead, it was a 30-state sweep for Trump.

Rather than offering constructive advice for restoring the media's integrity, the Columbia Journalism Review's editor, Kyle Pope, urged the media to double down on their approach. Pope published an open letter to the president on January 17, protesting Trump's plan to treat the media poorly in his presidency, similar to the media's treatment of him during the election.

Instead of offering sober advice to an industry in need of adult guidance, Pope played to the crowd of reporters who believe they have constitutional license to treat a duly elected president like a second-class citizen. Pope's approach may have been popular among anti-Trump reporters, but it has not helped the media's financial situation, with layoffs and office space rentals becoming common.

Don Surber, a retired newsman who lives in Poca, West Virginia, and is the author of "Trump the Press," which covered the 2016 Republican nomination process, offers a different perspective. In February, he will publish "Trump the Establishment," which covers the general election. Surber suggests that the media should knock off the anti-Trump tweets, stop looking for trouble where there is none, and start playing the game straight. Until news organizations do, they will continue to face financial challenges.

Title: White House Hosts Social Media Summit for Conservative Personalities, Discusses Free Speech Concerns

Article:

President Donald Trump convened a meeting with prominent conservative social media figures at the White House on Thursday, expressing concerns about alleged suppression of conservative voices by big tech firms. Trump stated that his administration is exploring regulations and legislation to protect free speech, though specific measures were not detailed. He also announced plans to summon major social media companies to the White House for discussions in the coming weeks.

During the event, Trump criticized big tech firms for allegedly censoring conservative voices, stating, "We’re not going to be silenced." He also mentioned fluctuations in his own Twitter followers as a concern. The First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution enshrines freedom of speech.

Trump, who frequently criticizes mainstream media for what he terms "fake news," has made social media a key component of his political campaigns. However, he and other Republicans have long claimed that online platforms employ tactics to silence conservative voices, allegations that major social media companies have denied.

The gathering in the East Room included several members of Trump’s cabinet and White House team, as well as his son Donald Trump Jr., along with dozens of pro-Trump online personalities. Among those called to the stage were Lila Rose, an anti-abortion activist who has been blocked from Pinterest; California lawyer Harmeet Dhillon, who has represented conservatives in free-speech lawsuits; and Lynnette Hardaway and Rochelle Richardson, better known as Diamond and Silk.

Carpe Donktum, a pro-Trump online persona who was recently suspended by Twitter for eight days over a video depicting Trump as a cowboy attacking CNN journalist Jim Acosta, commented that the face-to-face event could unite online conservatives.

In freewheeling remarks, Trump discussed the power of social media and criticized traditional media, which stood at the back of the room. He stated, "We hardly do press releases anymore. If I put it out on social media, it’s like an explosion."

Trump acknowledged criticism about the online behavior of some conservative users of social media, saying, "Some of you guys are out there - but even you should have a voice." He also commented on the content created by some conservative users, stating, "The crap you think of is unbelievable - it’s genius, but it’s bad."

In the past, Trump has threatened retaliatory action related to free speech. In March, he signed an executive order requiring U.S. colleges and universities to maintain "free speech" on campus if they want to continue receiving federal research funds. Last September, he suggested that the license of television network NBC could be challenged over its news reporting.

Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat, criticized the meeting, stating, "Instead of focusing on combating Russian social media misinformation, punishing anti-competitive practices, or protecting Americans’ data and privacy, the president has invited trolls, conspiracy theorists, anti-Semites, and the whole comments section to the White House."

Trump suggested that he might invite some of the conservative social media users back to the White House for the meeting with major social media firms. Three tech officials stated they had no knowledge of the meeting before Trump announced it.

Facebook Inc, Twitter Inc, and Alphabet Inc’s Google declined to comment on Trump’s announcement that he would bring them to the White House for a meeting. The Internet Association, a trade group representing major tech firms like Facebook, Twitter, and Google, stated, "Internet companies are not biased against any political ideology, and conservative voices in particular have used social media to great effect."

Republicans in Congress have held numerous hearings on the issue of alleged conservative bias on social media outlets. Republican Senator Josh Hawley, who is working on proposed legislation on the issue, took the stage briefly on Thursday to air his complaints. "They’ve gotten rich off of their special privileges from government. They want to keep those, they shouldn’t discriminate. They shouldn’t censor," Hawley said.

A Senate panel chaired by Republican Ted Cruz is scheduled to hold a hearing titled "Google and Censorship through Search Engines" featuring Google’s vice president of public policy, Karan Bhatia, on Tuesday.

Title: Pope Francis' Approval Ratings Drop Amidst Polarizing Reactions in the United States

Article:

Pope Francis, during his first visit to the United States this month, has seen a decline in approval ratings, according to Gallup, from 76% in 2014 to 59% currently. The Pope's message of compassion, care for the planet, and rejection of opulent living has elicited a range of emotions, including love, admiration, scorn, and fear.

An article titled "Why so Many People Think Pope Francis is the Antichrist" appeared on Charisma News, reflecting the conflicting sentiments towards the Pope. In response, various conspiracy theories have emerged, such as the claim that a Jesuit priest predicted Pope Benedict's resignation and that Pope Francis could be "demonically inspired."

The decline in approval ratings is attributed to the discomfort that many Americans feel due to Pope Francis' challenging their beliefs and values. Sister Donna Markham, the president of Catholic Charities, stated, "He's nudging me, as he is lots of us, to think about some uncomfortable things and how we might be better human beings in our world today, and that's hard."

Pope Francis' criticism of unfettered capitalism and his emphasis on caring for the poor has been met with resistance, particularly by conservatives who view him as a Marxist promoting wealth redistribution. R. Albert Mohler Jr., the president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, described the Pope's words as dangerous and a source of division within Roman Catholicism.

On the other hand, Pope Francis' stance on moral issues, such as climate change, immigration, and the treatment of the poor, resonates with progressives. However, his opposition to same-sex marriage, women priests, married priests, divorce, birth control, and abortion remains a source of contention.

The Rev. Thomas Bohlin, vicar of Opus Dei, suggested that Pope Francis is not intending to change any doctrine but rather to shift the emphasis and the way people perceive religion.

Pope Francis' ability to evoke strong, often conflicting, reactions may stem from his refusal to be easily categorized and his emphasis on personal introspection and responsibility rather than personal gain. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio noted, "I don't think he thinks about his work in terms of favorability. I think he thinks about telling the truth."

Title: Suspect in Pennsylvania State Trooper Ambush Captured After 48-Day Manhunt

Article:

After a 48-day manhunt in northeast Pennsylvania, authorities apprehended 31-year-old Eric Frein, the suspect in the sniper ambush attack that resulted in the death of a state trooper and the injury of another on Sept. 12. The capture occurred at an abandoned Poconos airplane hangar, where Frein had reportedly been hiding.

Frein, who had evaded capture in the thick, cave-strewn Pocono Mountain woods, was spotted late Thursday by a team of U.S. marshals assisting in the manhunt. He surrendered quietly, providing his name to the authorities. Police noted that Frein was clean-shaven and in better health than expected, with a cut on his nose that was not caused by police. There were conflicting reports about whether Frein was armed at the time of his arrest.

The capture took place at the Birchwood Pocono Air Park in Tannersville, Pa., approximately 30 miles from Blooming Grove, where the shootings occurred. Frein was transported to the Pike County Correctional Facility from the barracks early Friday morning. He is scheduled to appear in court at 9 a.m. this morning.

Troopers used the handcuffs of the slain officer, Cpl. Bryon Dickson, to manacle Frein. Police also used Dickson's cruiser to transport Frein to a cell at the Blooming Grove barracks, the same police safehouse he attacked near midnight on Sept. 12 before disappearing into the deep woods.

Prosecutors plan to seek the death penalty amid a litany of murder and bomb-making charges. However, Frein's motives remain elusive, with police only describing his alleged actions as "pure evil." Frein was a standout on his high school rifle team, and his father, an Army officer, had said Frein "doesn't miss." He had been jailed for 109 days in the mid-2000s for larceny stemming from a war-reenactment festival in New York.

Police believe Frein had planned the attack and escape for years. They found hints that he had researched information about evading police online. For 48 days, he managed to stay just ahead of the manhunt, partly due to the extreme caution exhibited by searchers.

Some civilian tracking experts noted that police manhunt methods had fallen short, and officials acknowledged that the combination of thick geography and concerns about another sniper attack on searchers had slowed the manhunt down. The surrounding hill communities expressed concerns about Frein's ability to cause further harm even as residents complained about area lockdowns and school closings.

The manhunt atmosphere created a sort of police state, according to Scranton, Pa., Times-Tribune columnist Chris Kelly, raising important questions about law enforcement's authority to curtail the rights of innocent citizens. The shooting and manhunt occurred in a year of anti-police protests in New York City and Ferguson, Mo., over cases where unarmed black men were killed by white police officers. Police fraternal organizations have been warning in recent years of an uptick in ambush assaults on law enforcement and courts.

Frein had become a ghostly presence in the quiet Pennsylvania township where he grew up. When police had sighted him, he would disappear into the thicket. Some speculated that Frein perhaps was "on a beach somewhere." Police, however, never considered ending the manhunt, which was estimated to be costing more than $1 million per week. After Frein's capture, local officials also made sure to inform everyone that Halloween was no longer canceled.

Title: President Trump Refuses to Discuss Police Violence Against Black People, Defends Confederate Flag

Article:

WASHINGTON — In an interview with CBS's Catherine Herridge on Tuesday, President Donald Trump refused to answer a question about police violence against Black people, instead pointing out that white people are also victims of police violence.

When asked why Black Americans are still dying at the hands of law enforcement, Trump responded, "And so are white people, so are white people." He continued, "What a terrible question to ask. So are white people, more white people by the way, more white people."

According to a Washington Post database tracking fatal police shootings in the United States, white people make up roughly half of the people shot and killed annually by police. The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that roughly 76 percent of the country is white while only 13 percent is Black. The Washington Post database shows that the rate at which Black people are shot and killed by law enforcement is twice as high as that of white people.

During the interview, Trump also defended the Confederate flag, stating, "It's freedom of speech." When asked if he would be comfortable with his supporters displaying the Confederate flag at political events, Trump said, "I'm comfortable with freedom of speech."

NASCAR announced in June it would ban Confederate flags from its events after Darrell "Bubba" Wallace Jr., the only black driver in the racing association's top series, called for change in the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd.

Trump has been criticized for his insistence on protecting monuments that honor Confederate leaders who fought to protect slavery and uphold white supremacy. Trump went as far as to threaten to veto Congress's annual defense authorization bill if it contained language to rename U.S. military bases honoring Confederate commanders, such as Fort Bragg in North Carolina, Fort Benning in Georgia, and Fort Hood in Texas.

Trump signed an executive order at the end of June to protect federal monuments after statues memorializing the Confederacy and some of the nation's Founding Fathers were vandalized.

Title: Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin Questions Voter Fraud in Gubernatorial Election, Requests Recanvass

Article:

Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin expressed concerns about potential voter fraud in the state's gubernatorial election on Wednesday, as he trailed his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Andy Beshear, by approximately 5,000 votes in unofficial results. Bevin requested a recanvass of the results in his race against Beshear, who claimed victory.

Bevin alleged irregularities in the election, citing "thousands of absentee ballots that were illegally counted," voters being "incorrectly turned away," and malfunctioning voting machines, according to Politico. He also stated that his team was gathering affidavits and other information to better understand the election's outcome.

The recanvass, a check of the vote count to ensure the results were added correctly, is scheduled for next Thursday. Kentucky does not have a mandatory recount law, so if Bevin decides to pursue a recount, he would need a court's approval.

The gubernatorial race was part of a strong night for Republicans in Kentucky, with GOP candidates winning races for state attorney general, secretary of state, auditor, agriculture commissioner, and treasurer. The nearly clean sweep by Republican candidates for Kentucky's top jobs followed President Trump's Monday night rally on their behalf.

Bevin's refusal to concede defeat has not been met with universal agreement among Kentucky Republicans. State Representative Jason Nemes wrote on social media, "Governor-elect Beshear is entitled to the democratic legitimacy that comes with loser's consent. So let's go through the process honorably and expeditiously and give it to him." Republican strategist Scott Jennings referred to Beshear as Kentucky's next governor, wishing him "godspeed" and saying he "ran a good race."

President Trump, in a Twitter message Wednesday, focused on his role in the Kentucky elections, stating, "Our big Kentucky Rally on Monday night had a massive impact on all of the races. The increase in Governors race was at least 15 points, and maybe 20!" Turnout in Kentucky was up by nearly 50 percent over the state's 2015 governor's race, increasing from 974,000 voters to more than 1.4 million. The number of voters Tuesday equaled turnout in Kentucky's 2014 race for U.S. Senate, rare for an election in an odd-numbered year.

Title: North Carolina Passes Voter ID Law, Joining 10 Other States in Requiring Voter Identification

Article:

The Republican-dominated North Carolina House approved a measure on Thursday night that requires residents to present photo identification to vote, joining 10 other states that have similar laws in place. The measure, which passed the state's Senate a day earlier, aims to prevent voter fraud, according to Senate President Pro Tempore Phil Berger.

In the past two years, at least 11 states have approved laws requiring voters to show identification at voting booths. However, critics argue that the measure is an attempt to disenfranchise poor, minority, and disabled voters.

The American Civil Liberties Union of North Carolina stated that the measure "attacks democracy at its core" by making it harder for eligible voters to cast their ballots. The group cited provisions such as eliminating pre-registration for 16 and 17-year-olds, and disallowing the use of college IDs at the polls as particularly burdensome for young and elderly voters.

Proponents of the bill argue that having a valid, government-issued photo identification is a reasonable, modern-day necessity to ensure voter integrity. A poll this year showed that more than 72% of North Carolina residents support requiring voters to show photo ID before casting their ballot, according to Berger.

Last month, the Supreme Court voted to halt the enforcement requirements of the Voting Rights Act, which had required some states with a history of voter discrimination to get "precleared" by the federal government before making any changes to voting laws. North Carolina was among those states. The high court's ruling essentially allows states to make adjustments to voting laws without "preclearance" from the federal government.

Attorney General Eric Holder expressed displeasure with last month's change in the Voting Rights Act. "For nearly five decades, preclearance served as a potent tool for addressing inequities in our election systems," he said. "Although preclearance originated during the Civil Rights Movement -- and was informed by a history of discrimination -- the conduct that it was intended to address continues to this day."

Holder said he has directed the Justice Department to ask a Texas federal court to subject the state to a condition similar to preclearance rights. He stated that there is evidence of racial discrimination in the state, and thus it should be forced to go through a federal preapproval before implementing voting changes.

States that may wish to implement their voter ID laws may still face another hurdle, as civil rights groups and even the federal government could seek legal action to block the laws under Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, another part of the law that works to prevent discrimination.

Title: Court Decision on Bridgegate Scandal: Federal Law Does Not Criminalize Partisan Use of Government Authority

Article:

The United States Supreme Court has ruled that the actions taken in the Bridgegate scandal, in which New Jersey officials realigned toll lanes for political purposes, do not constitute a federal crime under current law. The officials did not obtain any money or property, but instead used their governmental authority for corrupt and fraudulent reasons to make life difficult for the constituents of their political opponent.

The Court's decision is not unprecedented, as it has previously vacated the conviction of a former Virginia governor who exchanged access to meetings for political donations. In both cases, the Court has expressed concerns about the potential for prosecution over ordinary, if untoward, government conduct.

The Court's rulings in these cases have concluded that federal criminal law does not currently prohibit the defendants' conduct. It remains unclear whether Congress could pass a law criminalizing such behavior, as the Court has expressed significant constitutional concerns with the federal government's attempts to prosecute government officials for taking bribes.

The Court's conservative justices have also invalidated several statutes designed to combat public corruption, citing that money in politics is a common aspect of government and potentially enshrined in the Constitution. The Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission and McCutcheon v. FEC cases are examples of this, as the Court dismissed the idea that large campaign expenditures give rise to the appearance of corruption.

The Court's decision on the Bridgegate scandal comes at a time of very public government corruption during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Recent examples include the president's claims that he instructed Vice President Mike Pence not to return the calls of unappreciative governors, and that he sent ventilators to Colorado because of Republican Senator Cory Gardner. The Democratic governor of Michigan, Gretchen Whitmer, has alleged that the federal government has encouraged businesses not to provide any support to the state. The president, Senator Mitch McConnell, and the Department of Justice have openly acknowledged that their views on coronavirus-relief packages are based on the political affiliation of the states in need.

Title: Unusual Coalition: Democrats and Tea Party Activists Align Against McConnell in Kentucky Primary

Article:

In an unexpected move, Democrats and Tea Party activists in Kentucky are reportedly collaborating to potentially oust Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell in the 2014 GOP primary. The goal is to soften McConnell's position in a general election, where Democrats still hold a voter registration advantage, or to nominate a weak candidate who may lose in the general election.

Keith Rouda, a field organizer with the liberal group MoveOn and the Democratic super PAC, Progress Kentucky, stated, "We are doing a lot of reaching out to some of the tea party folks across the state. What we’re finding — at least in this stage of the race — we’re finding that our interests align. It’s unusual."

Progress Kentucky has begun circulating petitions urging Republicans to enter the race, and Democratic donors active in Kentucky and national politics are reportedly willing to provide financial support to a Tea Party candidate. However, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee and the Kentucky Democratic Party are not currently involved in these efforts, according to officials.

Sarah Durand, president of the Louisville Tea Party, said Democratic donors and activists have expressed a willingness to spend seven figures in a GOP primary to support a candidate challenging McConnell. The challenge for Tea Party groups, Durand said, is to recruit a candidate who wouldn't hand the seat to the Democrats, despite widespread dissatisfaction among Tea Party leaders with McConnell's three-decade tenure in Washington.

Durand expressed concern about the potential outcome of a primary challenge, citing the example of former Senator Dick Lugar, who was defeated in the 2012 primary and subsequently lost the seat to a Democrat. "I guess the fear would be ending up in the Dick Lugar situation where you oust the incumbent and end up with a Democrat," Durand said. "But I really think if Sen. McConnell can’t garner some enthusiasm within the tea party, which is going to be very difficult at this point, then he’s going to have a really tough road ahead in this election cycle."

Behind the scenes, McConnell and his campaign staff are reportedly taking steps to counter any primary challenge. McConnell's staff has attended over 100 Tea Party meetings in the state over the past two years, and the leader himself has spoken at three Tea Party rallies, including one with Senator Rand Paul in the state capital of Frankfort last August.

McConnell has also held face-to-face meetings with several Tea Party activists, including Durand and her fellow activists, and has been quick to bring under his wing the two biggest forces in Tea Party politics in the state: Paul and freshman Representative Thomas Massie (R-Ky.), who was initially seen as a potential primary threat to McConnell.

Title: World Leaders Gather in Manhattan as Climate Change Debate Persists

Article:

World leaders have gathered in Manhattan for a meeting, with the Tuesday weather forecast predicting sunny skies and temperatures in the 70s. During the meeting, President Obama expressed concerns about climate extremes and urged world leaders to address the issue. However, the success of his appeal remains uncertain.

The debate over climate change has been a contentious issue, with some arguing for carbon sacrifices to combat global warming, while others maintain that giving up affordable energy sources that emit carbon dioxide hinders prosperity. European nations, in particular, have been criticized for their inconsistent approach to global warming, with some nations advocating for action while others have been labeled as fair-weather global warmists.

The debate over climate change has been a recurring theme in movies and television shows, but its prominence has waned in recent years. According to historian Benjamin Schmidt of Northeastern University, mentions of climate change in films and television shows have decreased significantly since 2006, with such mentions often appearing as jokes or in animated shows.

Despite the ongoing debate, some argue that the planet's ice levels are in balance, and the oceans are not rising. This perspective challenges the widely held belief that human activities are causing the Earth's climate to change dramatically.

Critics of the climate change narrative argue that the Earth is a resilient planet that has survived various natural disasters throughout history. They question the assumption that a few extra emissions of carbon dioxide, a substance that promotes plant growth, could throw the planet out of balance.

The meeting in Manhattan is expected to continue, with world leaders discussing various strategies to address climate change. However, the success of these discussions remains uncertain, and the debate over climate change is likely to continue.

Title: Congress Urged to Limit Executive Authority in Cuba Policy Changes

Article:

President Obama's decision to establish diplomatic ties with Cuba has sparked debate in the U.S. Congress, with lawmakers expressing concerns over the potential implications of the move. The release of American hostage Alan Gross, who was imprisoned in Cuba for five years, is welcomed, but the exchange of three Cuban spies for Gross is criticized for establishing a moral and legal equivalency, as the spies were convicted for actions leading to the death of an American in the 1990s.

The U.S. Congress asserts that President Obama lacks the authority to lift the embargo on Cuba, allow trade, let tourists to visit, or grant Cuba access to capital markets. The Helms-Burton Act of 1996 grants Congress the power to override any executive action to lift the embargo.

To lift the embargo, the Cuban government would need to grant the Cuban people rights such as association, speech, and political activity, which President Obama reportedly failed to secure in his conversation with Cuban dictator Raul Castro. Congress can also set statutory criteria that must be met before the administration can remove Cuba from the State Department's list of state sponsors of terrorism.

Senators have threatened to place a hold on any ambassador nominated to serve in Cuba unless the Cuban government is no longer a threat to the U.S. and has decided to grant freedom to its people. Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) has already stated his intention to do so.

Congress is also considering using policy riders in the upcoming DHS appropriations debate in February and the Fiscal Year 2016 appropriations process to deny the president funds for setting up relations.

Critics argue that President Obama's approach to Cuba has been feckless, with little to show for substantial concessions made to the Communist regime. After five years of negotiations, President Obama ended exactly where Raul Castro's demands began. Senator Marco Rubio described President Obama as the worst negotiator since Carter.

President Obama's statement was filled with communist talking points, such as the claim that Cubans are poor and unfree due to the embargo, or that Cuba was a U.S. colony. These claims are disputed, and yet President Obama made them.

Congress is urged to act to limit the potential damage of the Cuba policy changes, as critics argue that President Obama may move on to the next item on his policy agenda without making substantial concessions from the Cuban government.

Title: Trump Calls for Muslim Nations to Combat Extremism in Historic Speech in Riyadh

Article:

In a historic speech on Sunday, President Donald Trump addressed leaders from across the Middle East and North Africa, urging them to take the lead in eradicating extremist Islam within their own countries. The speech, delivered in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, marked the beginning of the president's first foreign trip as the head of state.

Trump vowed that the United States would be a strong partner in the fight against terrorism but emphasized that Muslim nations must take the lead by promoting religious tolerance and rooting out extremists, even from within mosques and religious schools.

"There can be no coexistence with this violence. There can be no tolerating it. No accepting it. No excusing it and no ignoring it," the president said. He described the ongoing battle as a struggle between good and evil, stating, "Our goal is a coalition of nations who share the aim of stamping out extremism and providing our children a hopeful future that does honor to God."

The president also called for a unified front to combat and isolate Iran, a common enemy of many in the room. Trump's speech represented a significant departure from the anti-terror and foreign policy of the Obama administration, which was criticized by many Muslim countries for the Iran nuclear deal, which they saw as emboldening Tehran.

The speech provided a political win for Mr. Trump at home, as the media focus briefly shifted from accusations and investigations of collusion with Russia. However, Mr. Trump did not use the phrase "radical Islamic terrorism," a term he harshly criticized President Obama for not using during his presidency.

During the campaign, when Mr. Trump often used rhetoric that risked offending Muslims, he stated that Mr. Obama would never be able to defeat an enemy he refused to name. Mr. Trump did refer to "Islamists" and "Islamic terror," making clear the source of the extremism. But he stressed, as did Mr. Obama and President George W. Bush before him, that the United States was not at war with Islam.

"I stand before you as a representative of the American people to deliver a message of friendship and hope and love," he said. "That is why I chose to make my first foreign visit a trip to the heart of the Muslim world, to the nation that serves as custodian of the two holiest sites in the Islamic faith."

The speech, which touched on sensitive topics for Muslims, appeared to be well-received. Mr. Trump garnered an early endorsement from Saudi King Salman, who introduced him with a plea for unity in the fight against extremism.

While Mr. Trump's message was blunt and at times grim about the struggle against evil, the president delivered it with a tone of respect for the assembled leaders and optimism that they would prevail.

"We are not here to lecture. We are not here to tell other people how to live, what to do, who to be or how to worship," said the president. "Instead, we are here to offer partnership—based on shared interests and values—to pursue a better future for us all."

The strategy Mr. Trump outlined included denying territory or safe havens for extremists and cutting off financial streams to groups associated with terrorism. He stressed that more than military action, a message of religious tolerance and anti-violence had to come from political and religious leaders in the Muslim world.

"It means standing together against the murder of innocent Muslims, the oppression of women, the persecution of Jews, and the slaughter of Christians," said Mr. Trump. "Religious leaders must make this absolutely clear: Barbarism will deliver you no glory. Piety to evil will bring you no dignity. If you choose the path of terror, your life will be empty, your life will be brief, and your soul will be fully condemned."

He continued, "Heroes don't kill innocents; they save them."

Turning words into action, Mr. Trump and King Salman agreed to establish the Terrorist Financing Targeting Center as a hub for efforts to counter terrorist fundraising.

In the United States, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich compared Mr. Trump's speech to President Reagan's famous Westminster address to the British Parliament that set the stage for the defeat of the Soviet Union.

"You have the president of the United States surrounded by the largest alliance we've ever seen in the Muslim world, talking and articulating about a practical and realistic idealism they are going to move forward together to create a better world," he said on Fox News. "Just as Reagan set at a key moment in the defeat of the Soviet empire, Trump is now setting the key moment in the defeat of terrorism."

Title: Major Cities Worldwide on High Alert Amid Terror Threats

Article:

In the wake of chilling terror threats, major cities in Europe and the United States have heightened their security measures. New York City and Brussels, in particular, are on high alert.

New York City conducted an extensive active-shooter drill, with a focus on the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio praised the city's first responders, stating, "They're ready to protect us." In Brussels, the Belgian Prime Minister, Charles Michel, extended the highest alert level due to an "imminent threat."

In Brussels, a major railway station was evacuated for a suspicious package on Sunday, but no explosives were found. The city experienced further security concerns in the tourist district, with streets being sealed off. Belgian Interior Minister Jan Jambon acknowledged the real threat, stating, "There is a real threat, and we will make every effort day and night to face it."

Several suspects linked to the November 13 Paris attacks are being sought in Belgium, with the manhunt focusing on Salah Abdeslam, a Belgian national who is believed to have fled Paris after the attacks. One of Abdeslam's brothers died in the attacks, and another brother made a plea on Belgian TV for Salah Abdeslam to surrender.

In jittery Paris, an explosion at the central Gare du Nord train station was found to be a bird electrocuted on the rails. French police also released a photo of a man they believe was one of three terrorists who died outside the national stadium during the November 13 attacks, seeking the public's help in identifying him.

French authorities have decided to continue the detention of a man who had housed some of the attackers. Jawad Bendaoud admitted loaning his now infamous Saint-Denis apartment to the suspected ringleaders but has said he did not know his guests were avowed jihadists.

Rome and Milan were placed on alert after the foreign ministry warned that St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City along with some sites in Milan might be potential terror targets. In Los Angeles, a Southwest Airlines flight from Indianapolis arrived an hour late after making an unscheduled landing in Kansas City due to suspicious behavior. In Washington, D.C., Police Chief Cathy Lanier suggested residents should consider taking action, including shooting, if they find themselves in the midst of a terror attack.

No imminent, credible threat was reported for Washington or New York, but security was tight across both cities. U.S. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes discussed New York City, stating, "We don't know what we don't know. They've gotten very good at hiding from intelligence services across the world."

Title: Senate Acquits President Trump in Impeachment Trial

Article:

Senator Lisa Murkowski announced on Monday that she will vote to acquit President Donald Trump on both articles of impeachment this week, dashing hopes of Democrats who had anticipated the moderate Republican might join them in their effort to remove the president before the 2020 election.

Murkowski, a senator from Alaska, criticized Mr. Trump for his behavior but also stated that the House had mishandled the case against him, making it impossible for him to receive a fair trial in the Senate. She expressed a preference for the House to have pursued censure instead.

Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, considered the most likely Democrat to side with Mr. Trump, stated on Monday that he had not yet decided how he will vote on Wednesday. However, he also expressed a desire for Congress to have tried censure, stating that the president's dealings with Ukraine were not "perfect," as Mr. Trump has insisted.
