With his acquittal looking increasingly likely, House Democrats made a last-ditch appeal to senators on Monday, arguing that the only way to constrain Mr. Trump is to vote to convict him on both articles of impeachment.

Representative Adam B. Schiff, the top impeachment prosecutor, said during the appeal that the president lacks character, has broken every boundary of decency, and has "betrayed" the country, subverting national security to his political whims.

With closing arguments now over, senators have two days to ponder their votes ahead of Wednesday afternoon's final action. The House voted to impeach Mr. Trump on December 18 on two articles: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

The first article accuses the president of abuse of power stemming from a July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, during which Mr. Trump requested a corruption probe into a political rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden, and Democrats' activities in 2016, while withholding financial aid to Ukraine.

A second article accuses the president of obstruction of Congress for claiming immunity from the House's probe and blocking witnesses and documents that Democrats sought. No Republicans voted for the articles in the House, marking the first time the impeachment of a president has happened on a purely partisan basis.

The president's allies have argued that Mr. Trump had the authority to request a probe into possible corruption, stating that Mr. Biden's son Hunter sat on the board of a Ukrainian energy company, receiving about $50,000 a month from Burisma, though he lacked expertise in the industry.

Democrats say Mr. Trump abused his position and that there is no basis to question the Bidens' behavior. During the House impeachment inquiry, Democrats picked the witnesses to be called and blocked the president's team from calling its own witnesses or cross-examining the Democrats' choices.

No witnesses testified that they heard the president condition aid on Ukraine investigating the Bidens, but several said they believed it to be the case based on circumstantial evidence. Democrats said those in the know, such as former National Security Adviser John R. Bolton and acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, rebuffed attempts to get them to appear.

Mr. Bolton has since said he would testify to the Senate and has written a book that reportedly says he was asked by the president to help facilitate a meeting between Ukrainian officials and his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, who was allegedly part of the pressure campaign to start corruption investigations in Ukraine focused on the Bidens.

Senators will have all day Tuesday to make remarks on the chamber floor about the impeachment proceedings, and will cast their final vote on whether to acquit Mr. Trump the following afternoon. Meanwhile, Mr. Trump will deliver the State of the Union address on Tuesday night with the pending acquittal vote less than 24 hours away.

Democrats on Monday pivoted away from arguments over documents and witnesses and said the country's national security and fairness of the 2020 presidential election is at stake should Mr. Trump be left in office. "Your duty demands you convict President Trump," said Representative Jason Crow, Colorado Democrat. "In America, no one is above the law—even those elected president of the United States."

Mr. Schiff said there is a "100%" chance the president will "continue trying to cheat in the election until he succeeds." The impeachment charges arose after a whistleblower complaint surfaced in August about Mr. Trump's July phone call with Mr. Zelensky, asserting there was a quid pro quo in requesting the corruption probe while withholding the military aid.

Title: Midterm Elections Shift Focus: Foreign Policy and Islamic State Threat Overshadow Domestic Issues

Article:

The 2014 midterm elections have experienced a significant shift in focus, with the rise of the Islamic State (ISIS) causing both Democrats and Republicans to emphasize their hawkish stance on national security and terrorism. The focus on foreign policy issues has temporarily overshadowed the partisan sparring over ObamaCare and multiple scandals that have dominated headlines and threatened to define the Obama administration.

With just nine weeks remaining before voters decide the makeup of the next Congress, ISIS, Ukraine, Gaza, and Boko Haram have replaced the IRS, Benghazi, NSA data-gathering, and the VA on the lips of candidates and the minds of voters. The result is a race that looks much different than the last off-year midterm cycle.

Four years ago, Fox News polled voters on their top issues at the ballot box, with the economy at the top and Iraq at the bottom. While the economy still matters, recent polling shows voters want a tougher approach to foreign policy as ISIS militants wreak havoc in northern Iraq and Syria and threaten western interests.

Candidates are responding to this demand. Sen. Mark Warner (D-Va.), who faces a Republican challenge from former GOP chairman Ed Gillespie in November, on Wednesday urged the Obama administration to present a "clear strategy" for "eliminating" the Islamic State threat.

"The United States should not take any military options off the table, because stopping ISIL is in the national security and foreign policy interests of the U.S. and our European allies," Warner said in a statement.

The sudden focus on foreign policy poses a challenge for both parties. Republicans, who have been pulled in an isolationist direction by Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) and budget-minded Tea Party groups, are adjusting their tone. Even Paul, while saying President Obama must make his case for military action to Congress, told Fox News on Wednesday that the terror group has "absolutely" declared war on America.

For Democrats, the focus on the Middle East allows candidates to, at least briefly, get off the defensive on ObamaCare and administration controversies ranging from Benghazi to IRS targeting. However, the furor over terror threats means there's less room for Democratic candidates to tout modest domestic gains like job creation or the rebound of the stock market. And new polls show that the president suffers in public opinion on foreign affairs, leaving Democrats once again putting distance between themselves and the commander-in-chief.

Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-N.H.), who's in a race against former GOP Sen. Scott Brown, did exactly that when she issued a Twitter rebuke of the president on Wednesday after he said the goal is to make the terror group "manageable."

"Do not believe ISIL is'manageable,' agree these terrorists must be chased to the 'gates of hell,'" she tweeted. The comment was a reference to Vice President Biden's vow, at an event with Shaheen, to pursue the militants "to the gates of Hell."

Lara Brown, associate professor of political management with George Washington University, said the economy—and the "languishing recovery"—likely will remain a top issue in the fall. However, she described voter perceptions of Obama's leadership abroad as a factor.

"I think that puts Democrats, especially those that are more moderate...in a more difficult position, because they need the president to take a strong stand so they can say they are standing behind the president," she said.

Brown said the president could still "get back on top" of the narrative. "To a certain extent, the jury's out on where we are on this," she said.

A fresh GWU poll underscored the president's vulnerability on the subject. The poll of 1,000 likely voters, taken Aug. 24-28, showed 58 percent disapprove of his handling of foreign affairs. A Pew Research Center and USA Today survey also showed 54 percent see Obama as "not tough enough" on security issues. That's a turnaround from when Obama ran in 2012 in part on the successful mission to take out Usama bin Laden.

The same Pew poll showed dramatically changing attitudes toward America's role in the world, after years where fatigue from the Afghanistan and Iraq wars appeared to be setting in. The share of Americans who now say the U.S. does "too little" to address world problems roughly doubled since November 2013, to 31 percent. The share who say the opposite fell sharply, from 51 to 39 percent. The survey of 1,501 adults was taken Aug. 20-24.

As Democrats try and toughen their tone, Republicans are doing the same—and going after the president for a strategy they say is in shambles. Brown, Shaheen's opponent, said this week that America's enemies have been "emboldened by the Obama administration's incoherent foreign policy."

Brown released a scathing web video juxtaposing Biden's 2012 claims about Obama's "strength" with ominous footage of Islamic militants and the president's recent gaffe where he said "we do not have a strategy" yet to address ISIS in Syria. The ad ends with the text "Obama Biden—a foreign policy failure."

Title: Analysis of Key Senate Races in the 2018 Midterm Elections

Article:

John Waage, political analyst for ███ News, has analyzed the poll numbers for the upcoming midterm elections, focusing on the key Senate races that could determine control of the Senate. Democrats need to win two seats to take control, but they face an uphill battle due to the need to hold on to six states where they are facing tough challenges from Republicans.

The Kavanaugh confirmation battle may have an impact on some of these races. The fight over Kavanaugh's nomination, due process issues, and the concept of innocent until proven guilty has reportedly made a difference in the polls, according to Waage.

In North Dakota, incumbent Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D), who voted against Kavanaugh, is down double digits against challenger Kevin Cramer (R). In Missouri, Josh Hawley (R) has been targeting the Kavanaugh treatment, and he is giving incumbent Sen. Claire McCaskill (D) a tough fight. In Montana, Sen. Jon Tester (D) is the incumbent facing Matt Rosendale (R), and that race is nearly a dead heat.

In West Virginia, incumbent Sen. Joe Manchin (D), who voted for Kavanaugh, is holding onto the lead there in the aftermath of that vote. The Republicans are defending seats in Arizona and Tennessee, where Sen. Jeff Flake and Sen. Bob Corker are retiring from their seats. In Tennessee, Marsha Blackburn (R) now has a 14-point edge against Phil Bredesen (D) in the latest New York Times poll, even after pop singer Taylor Swift came out against Blackburn. In Arizona, Martha McSally (R) is facing Kyrsten Sinema (D) and has pulled up to a tie or is even a little ahead.

In Texas, Sen. Ted Cruz (R) has increased his margin over Beto O'Rourke (D). However, Democrats have pumped millions of dollars into that fight, and O'Rourke has much more campaign funding than Cruz. Democrats are also hoping to take away the Republican-held seat in Nevada, where Jacky Rosen (D) is facing incumbent Sen. Dean Heller (R), but Heller has a slight lead in recent polls there.

Waage predicts that based on the current polls, Republicans would gain two Senate seats if the election happened today. The possibility of a House takeover is more likely for Democrats than a Senate takeover, but it all comes down to voter turnout. Waage believes that even if Democrats win control of the House, it will be by a very slim margin. "Both bases are mobilized," he says, "Republicans weren't before the Kavanaugh hearings, but they are now."

Title: Senate Clears Path for Immigration Bill, but House Outcome Uncertain

Article:

A bipartisan immigration bill that offers a 13-year path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants in the United States has cleared a significant legislative hurdle in the Senate. The bill, which addresses a highly charged issue with significant political implications for both parties, received a strong majority vote on Tuesday, with 82 senators in favor and 15 against.

The 1,076-page measure, which was hammered out by a bipartisan group of senators known as the "Gang of Eight," now faces an arduous journey through the legislative process. While both supporters and opponents expect the bill to pass the Senate, some Republicans, including Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, have expressed concerns about its prospects in the Republican-controlled House.

President Barack Obama and Democrats are pushing for the bill to fulfill a promise to Hispanic Americans, a key voting bloc, to address the limbo of the 11 million immigrants living illegally in the country. In a bid to build momentum for the proposal, Obama emphasized that the bill would increase spending on border security, require undocumented immigrants to undergo background checks, learn English, pay taxes, and pay a penalty before pursuing a 13-year path to citizenship.

Sen. John Cornyn of Texas, the chamber's No. 2 Republican, who voted for opening debate, questioned the bill's focus on granting permanent legal status to undocumented immigrants without sufficient border security measures. Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Florida, a member of the bipartisan "Gang of Eight" and a potential GOP presidential contender in 2016, has also expressed concerns about border security and is pushing for amendments to make Congress, not the executive branch, responsible for deciding if security metrics at the border have been met before other aspects of the reform bill are triggered.

The vote on the Rubio amendment is expected to be closely watched as floor action unfolds over the next three weeks. Other planned amendments will involve stepped-up security checks of people entering the country, temporary visas for high- and low-skilled workers, and other technical provisions.

In the House, a bipartisan group has been working on a separate immigration plan, but the effort suffered a setback last week when a key member dropped out of the negotiations. Previous efforts to pass immigration reform fell short in the last decade, despite being a priority of President George W. Bush. Now, Obama has made the issue a major priority of his second term.

Title: Trump Nominates Representative Ryan Zinke as Interior Secretary

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has selected first-term Republican U.S. Representative Ryan Zinke of Montana as his nominee for the position of Interior Secretary. The announcement was made by a senior transition official on Tuesday.

Ryan Zinke, a former Navy SEAL commander, will be tasked with leading the Interior Department, which employs over 70,000 people and manages more than 20 percent of federal land, including national parks such as Yellowstone and Yosemite.

Zinke's selection was unexpected, as some Republican officials had hoped he would challenge Democratic U.S. Senator Jon Tester of Montana in the 2018 elections. Initially, Trump had considered nominating U.S. Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington state for the position.

Zinke, who is 55 years old, is a proponent of keeping public lands under federal ownership, a stance that contrasts with some within his Republican Party who favor privatization or state control. It remains unclear where Zinke stands on increasing drilling and mining on federal lands, a promise made by Trump during his presidential campaign.

Trump's official energy platform calls for onshore and offshore leasing on federal lands, eliminating the coal leasing moratorium, and opening shale energy deposits. It is unclear whether Zinke's nomination signals a shift in policy regarding federal land use for energy development.

Congresswoman McMorris Rodgers, who was previously rumored to have been picked for the post, stated on Tuesday that she had never been offered the job. McMorris Rodgers had met with Trump at his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, shortly after the president-elect began his Cabinet search.

Zinke was an early supporter of Trump and has voted for legislation that weakens environmental safeguards on public land. However, unlike other candidates who were considered for the interior secretary position, Zinke opposes the transfer of public lands to the states, a stance that aligns with Trump's.

Trump has expressed opposition to transferring public land to the states, stating that he believes the land should be protected rather than sold for energy or commercial development. In July, Zinke resigned as a delegate to the Republican nominating convention due to the party platform's call for transferring public lands to the states.

Public land comprises more than 30 percent of Montana, according to the Montana Wilderness Association. The League of Conservation Voters, which ranks lawmakers on their environmental record, gave Zinke an extremely low lifetime score of 3 percent. The Wilderness Society, a leading conservation group, expressed concern over Zinke's support for logging, drilling, and mining on public lands.

The Interior Department also oversees the Bureau of Indian Affairs and handles tribal policy. Under the Obama administration, the department played a significant role in efforts to limit fossil fuel development in some areas in an attempt to curb the effects of climate change. It remains to be seen how Zinke's nomination will impact these policies.

Title: Harvey Weinstein Indicted on Rape Charges in Manhattan

Article:

Harvey Weinstein, the former Hollywood producer, was indicted on charges of first- and third-degree rape in one case and a first-degree sex act in a second case by a Manhattan grand jury on May 30. The charges stem from allegations made by two women, one of whom he is accused of raping and another of forcing to perform oral sex.

Weinstein surrendered to authorities in New York on May 25 and was arraigned shortly thereafter. Bond was set at $10 million or $1 million cash, which he paid with a cashier's check. Weinstein was also required to relinquish his passport and wear a GPS monitoring system. He is only permitted to travel between New York and Connecticut.

In a press conference on Friday, Weinstein's lawyer, Ben Brafman, reiterated Weinstein's contention that he did not engage in nonconsensual sexual activities. Weinstein is expected to enter a plea of not guilty.

The indictment comes two days after reports that federal prosecutors had begun a sex crimes investigation into Weinstein and that a state grand jury had convened to hear evidence in sexual assault allegations against the producer.

One of the women pressing charges against Weinstein is Lucia Evans, who confirmed to the New Yorker's Ronan Farrow that she is the accuser in the first-degree rape charge. Evans alleges that in 2004, when she was an aspiring actress, Weinstein forced her to perform oral sex on him at the Miramax office in Tribeca, just blocks from the NYPD precinct where Weinstein turned himself in on Friday.

Actress Paz de la Huerta told Vanity Fair that Weinstein raped her in 2010 at a Manhattan hotel, but her allegations are not part of the charges expected to be filed against Weinstein. However, she may testify if asked.

Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance will be faced with the decision of whether to prosecute Weinstein, under public pressure from critics of his previous decision not to prosecute Weinstein in connection with a 2015 sexual assault allegation, and from the #MeToo movement more generally.

In a statement Wednesday after the indictment, Vance said, "This indictment brings the defendant another step closer to accountability for the crimes of violence with which he is now charged."

Weinstein's connection to Vance could play a role in the future of this case. In 2015, Weinstein was investigated by the NYPD, and model Ambra Battilana Gutierrez reported to police that Weinstein had grabbed her breasts and tried to reach up her skirt during a meeting at his Tribeca office. Despite a recording in which Weinstein appeared to admit to the incident, Vance's office decided not to press charges.

Weinstein's defense team during the investigation included two other Vance donors, Linda Fairstein and Elkan Abramowitz, who was also Vance's former law partner, according to the New York Times. Vance was reelected in November after running unopposed and in January announced that he would no longer accept donations from lawyers with pending cases before his office.

The issue of donations matters not just for the previous Weinstein case but for the current one. Weinstein has hired high-powered defense attorney Ben Brafman to represent him this time around. Brafman's firm has donated about $4,600 to Vance in the past, the Times reports. And Vance has declined to prosecute two high-profile Brafman clients accused of rape in the past: lawyer Sanford A. Rubenstein in 2015 and French politician Dominique Strauss-Kahn in 2011.

Now, of course, critics are watching Vance for any sign of favoritism toward Weinstein. And the rise of the #MeToo movement means public opinion around the case may look different than it did for, say, Strauss-Kahn.

We don't yet know how all these conflicting forces will come into play at a trial, if the case goes that route. What we do know is that the man whose name has become inextricably linked with #MeToo has been arrested and will likely soon be charged. Whatever happens next, the whole country will be watching.

Title: Fed Chairman Warns of Economic Recession if Budget Crisis Not Averted

Article:

Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke painted a grim picture of the U.S. economy during his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, warning that a budget crisis could lead to a recession and the loss of 1.25 million jobs in 2013. The Fed is prepared to take further action to support the economy if unemployment remains high, but Bernanke did not specify any imminent steps or actions.

The economy is currently growing modestly but has weakened, with manufacturing slowing, consumers spending less, and job growth averaging 75,000 per month in the April-June quarter compared to 226,000 per month from January through March. The unemployment rate remains at 8.2 percent.

Bernanke's most urgent concern is the potential economic impact of the budget impasse in Congress, which could result in tax increases and deep spending cuts at the end of the year. If no agreement is reached, the Congressional Budget Office has warned that a recession would occur, and 1.25 million fewer jobs would be created in 2013.

The economy, after growing at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the second half of 2011, slowed to roughly 2 percent from January through March and likely weakened further in the April-June period. Congress needs to resolve its impasse well before the year ends to reduce uncertainty and boost household and business confidence, Bernanke said.

The potential job losses from the budget cuts could be as high as 2 million, according to a report released Tuesday by the Aerospace Industries Association. A separate report Tuesday highlighted the budget crises many states are facing due to shrinking federal revenue.

Republicans in Congress are demanding deeper spending cuts, while extending income tax cuts for everyone. Democrats want to extend the tax cuts for middle- and lower-class Americans but let them expire for people in the highest-income brackets. Bernanke stopped short of telling Congress what steps to take, challenging them to think broadly.

The economy's challenges go beyond the budget impasse, Bernanke said. Lawmakers must also produce a long-term plan to shrink federal budget deficits to avoid a potential financial crisis marked by rising interest rates. Stocks rose sharply despite Bernanke's grim assessment.

Bernanke also addressed Europe's debt crisis, stating that the Fed has been working with U.S. banks to ensure they have taken steps to prepare for a potential crisis. He expressed hope that European leaders would find solutions but acknowledged the risk of a more serious financial blowup.

Investors had hoped Bernanke would signal another round of bond purchases, but they seemed to shrug off the downbeat outlook and focused on stronger earnings reported by companies like Mattel and Coca-Cola. At least one senator implored Bernanke to take action now, stating that the Fed is the only game in town and urging Bernanke to take whatever actions are warranted. Even if the Fed announces another round of bond purchases, some economists question how much it might help, as mortgage rates and other key borrowing rates are already at record lows.

The Fed's policymaking committee last met on June 19-20, during which it extended a program that shifts its bond portfolio to try to lower long-term interest rates and reiterated its plan to keep its key short-term interest rate near zero until at least late 2014. Minutes of the June meeting show that Fed officials were open to taking further action but were divided over whether the economy needs help now. Former Fed official Roberto Perli, managing director at the research firm International Strategy & Investment, doubts the Fed will take action at its next meeting on July 31-Aug. 1, preferring to wait for more evidence of where the economy is headed. However, if growth and job creation continue to weaken, Perli says, Fed policymakers might unveil another round of bond purchases at its Sept. 12-13 meeting.

Title: New York Times Allegation Against Brett Kavanaugh: A Closer Look at the Details and Corroboration

Article:

A new allegation of sexual misconduct against U.S. Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh has surfaced in a forthcoming book by Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly. The book, titled "The Education of Brett Kavanaugh: An Investigation," is set to be released on Tuesday, but an excerpt was published in the New York Times on Sunday, September 13.

The new allegation, which echoes an on-the-record allegation made by Kavanaugh's Yale classmate Deborah Ramirez in 2018, is that during his freshman year, Kavanaugh's classmate Max Stier saw him with his pants down at a different drunken dorm party, where friends allegedly pushed his penis into the hand of a female student.

However, the authors provide no clear details about the logistics of the alleged incident, such as who the friends are, who the female student is, or if there were any witnesses besides Stier. The authors only write that Stier notified senators and the FBI about the account, but the FBI did not investigate, and Stier has declined to discuss it publicly.

The book's authors corroborated the fact that Stier made the allegation to the FBI, but they give no indication that they have corroborated any details of the alleged incident. Mollie Hemingway, who obtained a copy of the book before its release, notes that the woman Max Stier named as having been allegedly victimized by Kavanaugh and friends denies any memory of the alleged event.

The new allegation is supposed to help lend credence to Ramirez's on-the-record allegation that Kavanaugh exposed himself as a college freshman at a party. Pogrebin and Kelly sum up Ramirez's allegation: "She and some classmates had been drinking heavily when, she says, a freshman named Brett Kavanaugh pulled down his pants and thrust his penis at her, prompting her to swat it away and inadvertently touch it. Some of the onlookers, who had been passing around a fake penis earlier in the evening, laughed."

Pogrebin and Kelly downplay Ramirez's own doubts about whether Kavanaugh did what she now alleges, choosing rather to lard up their New York Times story with details that are supposed to demonstrate how under-privileged Ramirez was. None of these details corroborates her accusation against Kavanaugh.

As I wrote last October, here's why Ramirez's allegation was dubious: Deborah Ramirez is the Yale classmate of Kavanaugh's who now claims that Kavanaugh exposed himself as a college freshman at a party. Ramirez's claim was already dubious because (1) named eyewitnesses deny the allegation and (2) Ramirez herself wasn't sure in recent weeks if Kavanaugh had done what she now alleges. "Ms. Ramirez herself contacted former Yale classmates asking if they recalled the incident and told some of them that she could not be certain Mr. Kavanaugh was the one who exposed himself," the New York Times reported. Ramirez was only willing to make the allegation, the New Yorker reported, after "six days of carefully assessing her memories and consulting with her attorney."

Pogrebin and Kelly write that a couple of students say they had heard about the alleged incident in the days after it allegedly occurred, but the authors provide no indication there is any first-hand witness to corroborate the allegation. We already knew before Kavanaugh was confirmed last October that the "corroborating" source for Ramirez's claim, classmate Kenneth Appold, was not present when the alleged incident occurred, but Appold told the New Yorker he was "one-hundred-percent-sure" he heard about it from an eyewitness. Shortly before Kavanaugh was confirmed, the New Yorker reported that Appold's supposed eyewitness "said that he had no memory of the incident."

Update 9/16: Late yesterday, the New York Times "updated" their article to note that it initially "did not include" the information that the alleged victim did not recall the alleged assault.

Title: Government Shutdown Halts Key Budget Reports, Leaves Fiscal Data Uncertain

Article:

The ongoing government shutdown has resulted in key agencies ceasing the production of budget information, including reports on deficits, spending, and the economy, which could aid Congress in its deliberations on these issues. The exact financial implications of the shutdown, whether it will result in savings or additional costs, remain uncertain due to the absence of these reports.

Three significant reports have already been canceled due to the shutdown. Last week, the Labor Department postponed the release of the September jobs report, and the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) and the Treasury Department announced they would not be completing their monthly budget reviews. As a result, the government is unaware of the final deficit for fiscal year 2013, which ended a week ago.

"Because a lapse in appropriated funds has caused CBO to largely shut down its operations, the Monthly Budget Review will not be published today or during the duration of the government shutdown," the agency stated.

The shutdown has also delayed another CBO report, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, an organization that studies fiscal issues. This report, initially scheduled for this month, would have provided tax and spending options for reducing the deficit.

"The irony of this whole thing is we just shut down our means to have those budget options to avoid the shutdown," said Marc Goldwein, senior policy director at the committee.

As the shutdown enters its second week, all parties are contemplating the political and fiscal repercussions. The 1995 and 1996 shutdowns reportedly cost the government $1.4 billion, equivalent to $2.1 billion in today's dollars, according to a Clinton-era budget office report. The primary expense was back pay for furloughed employees.

The cost of the current shutdown remains uncertain, with some analysts suggesting it could save money due to program suspensions and reduced employee numbers, while others argue that it requires funds to shut down and restart operations.

"That makes sense because it is costing money to mothball and open things, and shutdowns involve that," said Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former CBO director and now president of the American Action Forum. However, he noted that the cost of a shutdown is "not a lot of money" in relation to the federal budget.

The longer the shutdown persists, the more reports are likely to be delayed. The problem for federal agencies is that budget analysts have been furloughed as part of the 800,000 federal employees whose jobs were deemed non-essential for protecting life or property. At the CBO, only about 10% of agency employees are working, focusing on bills actively under consideration in Congress.

Sen. John Cornyn (R-TX) stated that the lack of information benefits the White House, as it conceals unfavorable budget data. "Discovered another reason why WH likes the'shutdown.' The Congressional Budget Office won't publish reports due to lapse of funds. Guess the WH thinks no news on fiscal matters is good news," Mr. Cornyn said in a Twitter message.

Mr. Holtz-Eakin acknowledged that the lack of data is detrimental but not catastrophic. "In general, policymakers have very little feel for how the economy's doing in real time. At best, you're getting something that's a month old, and this will make that worse," he said. He also suggested that the economic damage estimates might be overblown.

Even amid the shutdown, some numbers continue to emerge. The Treasury Department is still producing the Daily Treasury Statement, which shows the status of the federal debt, and last week, the department released a politically charged report arguing that approaching the debt limit could cause the worst recession since the Great Depression.

In the report, titled "The Potential Macroeconomic Effect of Debt Ceiling Brinkmanship," the administration argued that the 2011 debt fight, when Congress raised the limit at the last minute, provided only a taste of the potential damage if the limit isn't raised and the government defaults.

The general lack of information has left private analysts to fill the gap with their own calculations and data. For example, the Alliance for American Manufacturing has solicited anecdotal stories from workers about their job searches in lieu of the official jobs report. The Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank, issued a report suggesting that if the government continued spending without regard to the deficit, the economy might have added 260,000 jobs.

Analysts stated that the data for the September report were collected in the middle of last month and could still be compiled. However, they expressed concern that if the shutdown continues into the middle of October, it could impair the department's ability to collect data for this month's report.

Title: Trump Nominates Heather Nauert, Former Fox News Anchor, as U.N. Ambassador

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced his intention to nominate Heather Nauert, the current State Department spokeswoman and former Fox News host, as the United States' next ambassador to the United Nations. If confirmed by the Senate, Nauert will replace Nikki Haley, who is set to leave the post at the end of the year.

Nauert joined the State Department in April 2017, having previously worked at ABC and Fox News. She did not travel extensively with her first boss at the department, former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, but has been more active under current Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

Nauert's nomination has been met with some criticism, particularly over a tourist-like Instagram post from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, during a trip focused on the killing of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. There have also been other missteps, such as citing D-Day, the Allied invasion of Normandy against the Nazis, as an example of America's strong relationship with Germany.

Despite these criticisms, Nauert has been a strong defender of President Trump at the podium, a fact that Trump has acknowledged. "She's excellent, she's been with us a long time, she's been a supporter for a long time," Trump said of Nauer on Nov. 1.

The State Department previously held daily briefings, but this has been scaled back to two a week, at most. Nauert, 48, has been balancing her job in Washington, D.C. with her family in New York. Before joining the Trump administration, she had no government or foreign policy experience, though she did work on some overseas assignments for ABC, including in Baghdad.

Title: Proposed Measures to Address Central American Migration Caravans and U.S.-Mexico Border Security

Article:

The ongoing migration caravans from Central American countries, primarily Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, have been a contentious issue in the United States. These groups, often numbering in the thousands, are traveling through Mexico with the aim of reaching the U.S. border. The author suggests several strategies to address this issue, focusing on economic and political measures.

1. Economic Leverage: The author proposes utilizing economic leverage against Mexico, a country that currently allows these migrant caravans to pass through without significant intervention. The U.S. could impose taxes on remittances sent by Mexican nationals living in the U.S. illegally, or even halt these transfers altogether. This could serve as a deterrent for Mexico, as it relies heavily on remittances from its citizens living in the U.S.

2. Employer Sanctions: The author suggests imposing severe fines on employers who hire illegal immigrants. This would make it difficult for illegal immigrants to find work, reducing their incentive to come to the U.S. This measure could be coupled with work requirements for welfare recipients, especially during periods of full employment.

3. Addressing Corruption in Latin America: The author argues that the U.S. should take a more active role in Latin America, offering aid only to governments that demonstrate a commitment to controlling their borders and addressing corruption. The author suggests cutting off aid to corrupt governments and supporting reform-minded leaders who are willing to fight corruption and promote positive change within their countries.

4. Brazilian Elections and the Bolsonaro Factor: The author discusses the upcoming Brazilian elections and the potential impact of candidate Jair Bolsonaro, who is running on an anti-corruption platform. The author suggests that Bolsonaro's victory could serve as a model for other countries in the region, encouraging them to fight corruption and promote positive change.

In conclusion, the author proposes a multi-faceted approach to address the issue of migration caravans from Central America. This approach includes economic measures, such as taxes on remittances and employer sanctions, political measures, such as aid conditionality and support for reform-minded leaders, and strategic engagement with countries in the region, such as Brazil. The goal is to make the U.S. a less attractive destination for illegal immigrants and to encourage positive change in their home countries.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Pushes for Rush Vote on 1,200-Page Amnesty Bill Amidst Transparency Concerns

Article:

In a move reminiscent of the Obamacare debate, the U.S. Senate is facing criticism for a rushed process in the passing of the Gang of Eight's 1,200-page amnesty legislation. The vote, scheduled for 5:30 pm, is not solely on the Corker-Hoeven amendment, as previously thought. Instead, it is a vote on a procedural motion by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to end debate on a 1,200-page substitute bill, which has been merged with the Corker-Hoeven amendment.

Senator Marco Rubio has expressed his opposition to the process, stating that he would not support a rushed and non-transparent approach. He has also issued a challenge to the bill's sponsors, questioning their commitment to extensive, open debate and expressing concern about passing the bill before members return to their constituents during the July 4th holiday.

Senator Jeff Sessions, in a statement, noted that the bill, like Obamacare, risks being passed without thorough vetting. He emphasized that the amnesty bill lacks sufficient provisions for border security, a concern shared by many Americans. Sessions' statement suggests that a vote for the bill would not necessarily equate to a vote for security.

Former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin has also weighed in on the issue, criticizing the Gang of Eight in a piece for Breitbart. The race is on as the Senate grapples with the amnesty bill, with transparency and border security at the forefront of the debate.

Title: President Trump Endorses Grassley's Immigration Legislation, Encourages Support for Four Pillars of Immigration Reform

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed his support for Senator Chuck Grassley's immigration legislation and the four pillars of the White House Immigration Reform and Border Security Framework. In a statement, the President praised Grassley's bill for addressing the four pillars: a lasting solution for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA), ending chain migration, cancelling the visa lottery, and securing the border through building the wall and closing legal loopholes.

The Grassley bill, co-introduced with Senator Tom Cotton, provides a path to citizenship for 1.8 million DACA recipients, allocates $25 billion for border security and wall funding, and limits family-based migration while eliminating the diversity visa lottery. It remains unclear if the President has suggested changes to the original version of Grassley's legislation. Currently, no Democrats have publicly stated their support for this measure, and Republicans would need nine Democrats, if all Senate Republicans support Grassley's bill.

In addition to Grassley's bill, President Trump expressed encouragement by developments in the House, pointing to House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte and House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Michael McCaul's legislation. Goodlatte's bill, unveiled last month, takes a tougher stance on illegal immigration enforcement and addresses the future of DACA recipients, allowing beneficiaries to be eligible for 3-year renewable permits to stay in the U.S.

Of the 70 security points included in the Trump administration's immigration wish list sent to Congress in October, half are not included in Goodlatte's bill. However, the bill does contain much of what the President has said he wants to see in an immigration bill, including a plan to fund the border wall and to end the chain migration system as well as the visa lottery program.

Goodlatte's bill also includes a long-term plan for DACA recipients that outlines a potential path to citizenship while not necessarily favoring DACA recipients over other immigrants seeking citizenship. President Trump hailed Goodlatte's bill as "a good starting point" for his administration to accomplish its immigration goals.

The President suggested that with the budget deal behind him, his focus is on "enacting responsible and commonsense immigration reform that delivers for the American People."

Title: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's Decision to Step Down from Senior Royal Roles: A Reflection of Britain's Troubled History

Article:

The decision of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry to step down from their roles as senior royals and pursue a more independent path has been met with a mix of reactions, with some viewing it as a bold move and others expressing surprise. The couple's decision has been linked to their experiences within the British royal family, which has a history rooted in colonialism, the slave trade, and policies of racial discrimination.

The legacy of Britain's colonial past, characterized by a global construct based on a doctrine of white supremacy, has been a contentious issue. The country's role in the slave trade, the recruitment of people from the Caribbean and Africa for low-paid work, and subsequent discrimination in education and housing, continues to resonate today. The recent scandal surrounding the wrongful deportation of black British people serves as a stark reminder of this troubled history.

Meghan's decision to join the royal family, symbolically linked to this history, was perplexing to many black British people. The couple's decision to step back and protect their son, Archie, from the negative attention they have received, has been interpreted as a response to the challenges they have faced within the royal family.

The couple's actions, such as not giving Archie a title from birth and rumors of a potential relocation to southern Africa, were signs that they would not conform to traditional royal norms. In recent months, they have bypassed official royal channels and communicated directly with the press, as seen in Meghan's admission of finding royal life "hard" and Harry's revelation about the impact of his mother's death on his desire to protect his family.

The British press, which has been critical of the couple, has expressed shock at this move. However, for those who have been following the couple's actions closely, this decision may not have come as a surprise. The clues, it seems, have been there for some time for anyone willing to observe them.

Title: UN Imposes New Sanctions on North Korea in Response to Missile Tests; Regime Vows "Thousands-fold" Revenge

Article:

The United Nations has imposed new sanctions on North Korea in response to its recent tests of intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM). The sanctions, which were unanimously approved by the UN Security Council on Saturday, could reduce the regime's annual export revenue by a third, targeting key revenue earners such as coal, iron, lead, and seafood, but not oil.

In a statement carried by the official KCNA news agency, the North Korean government described the sanctions as a "violent violation of our sovereignty" and part of a "heinous plot to isolate and stifle" the country. Pyongyang threatened to take "righteous action," describing the sanctions as a crime for which the United States would pay "thousands of times."

The new sanctions forbid China, Russia, and other countries from hiring any more North Korean laborers, whose remittances help fund the regime, and prohibit joint ventures with the country and any new investment in existing business partnerships. The US ambassador to the UN, Nikki Haley, described the measures as "the single largest economic sanctions package ever levelled" against North Korea.

The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, said on Monday that North Korea should halt missile launches if it wanted to negotiate. In a telephone call on Monday, US President Donald Trump and his South Korean counterpart, Moon Jae-in, agreed that Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs "pose a grave and growing direct threat" and vowed to apply maximum pressure on the regime.

North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-un, is aware of the fate of other dictators who lack nuclear weapons. Much of the regime's domestic legitimacy rests on portraying the country as under constant threat from the United States and its regional allies, South Korea, and Japan. To support the claim that it is in Washington's crosshairs, North Korea cites the tens of thousands of US troops lined up along the southern side of the demilitarized zone – the heavily fortified border dividing the Korean peninsula. Faced with what it says are US provocations, North Korea says it has as much right as any other state to develop a nuclear deterrent.

The White House said in a statement that Trump and Moon had agreed that advances in North Korean missile technology, achieved despite eight rounds of multilateral sanctions in the past 11 years, posed "a grave and growing direct threat to the United States, South Korea, and Japan, as well as to most countries around the world." In an hour-long phone call on Monday, the leaders said they would continue to apply pressure to the North. Joint US-South Korean military exercises this month are expected to provoke an angry response.

Moon, who supports cautious engagement with North Korea, told Trump the door should remain open to dialogue, provided Pyongyang agreed to abandon its nuclear program. In a Twitter post, Trump said he was "very happy and impressed with 15-0 United Nations vote" on the sanctions, but China has said any punitive actions targeting North Korea must "avoid bringing disaster" to the economically fragile state.

In a front-page commentary on Monday, the overseas edition of the ruling Communist party's official People's Daily said sanctions must be employed with precision. "Sanctions to the greatest possible extent must avoid causing negative impacts to ordinary people and to third countries, and avoid bringing disaster to the country in question's normal and legal trade and business exchanges with the outside world, people's normal lives, and the humanitarian situation," the paper said.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Consequential Tenure Marked by Controversial and Groundbreaking Decisions

Article:

In a nearly six-year tenure that has been one of the most significant in United States history, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. announced his resignation on Thursday, stating he will remain in office until his successor's confirmation. As the first African-American to serve as the nation's top law enforcement official, Holder made history the moment he took office.

In a position that rarely encourages boldness and in the face of a frequently hostile Congress, Holder has consistently staked out strong and laudable legal positions on many of the most contested issues of our time. However, his tenure is marred by the role the Justice Department played in matters of secrecy and national security under his leadership.

Same-Sex Marriage
In 2011, Holder announced that the Justice Department would no longer defend the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defined marriage under federal law as between a man and a woman. The law was unconstitutional, he said. This critical moment foreshadowed both President Obama's own "evolution" on same-sex marriage the following year and the Supreme Court's 2013 ruling invalidating an important part of the law. Since the court's decision, nearly two dozen federal courts have struck down state bans on same-sex marriage throughout the country, and the Supreme Court has been asked again to rule on whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage—a question it dodged in 2013.

Voting Rights
Holder successfully fought discriminatory voting restrictions around the country before the 2012 elections. When the Supreme Court gutted the core of the Voting Rights Act in 2013, he was quick to find new ways to challenge discriminatory laws. Shortly after the ruling, the Justice Department joined lawsuits challenging new restrictions like strict voter-ID requirements and cutbacks to voting hours in North Carolina and Texas. In both states, Republican-controlled legislatures imposed rules that most heavily burden poorer and minority voters, who tend to vote Democratic.

Title: Trump Expands on Foreign Policy Stances in Anti-Terrorism Speech

Article:

In a measured and scripted address at a rally in Youngstown, Ohio, on Monday, Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, refrained from making wild, ad hoc accusations, marking a shift in his campaign's unpredictable trajectory. However, the speech's implications could resonate for days or weeks to come, as Trump emphasized the threat of radical Islamic terrorism and expanded upon his controversial foreign policy statements.

Trump proposed that the U.S. collaborate with Russia in "coalition operations" to fight ISIS, a significant departure from the current Obama administration's policy. He acknowledged Russia's stake in the outcome in Syria, emphasizing their battles with Islamic terror. This suggestion, if implemented, would likely alter the U.S.'s long-standing position regarding Russia's support for Syria's embattled president, Bashar al-Assad.

The speech's most repeated phrase was Trump's proposal for "extreme vetting" of immigrants or refugees from regions plagued by terrorism. This process would involve questions about their adherence to a "tolerant" way of life and agreement with U.S. values regarding women's rights, the rule of law, and the primacy of the U.S. Constitution.

Critics on social media questioned the feasibility of such a test, suggesting it could be easily manipulated. They also noted similarities between this approach and Trump's previously proposed temporary ban on the entry of non-citizen Muslims into the U.S., which has been criticized as a form of religious discrimination.

Trump also distanced himself from his previous statement advocating for the U.S. to withdraw from NATO unless other members increased their financial contributions. He acknowledged NATO's new anti-terrorism initiative and suggested that this might justify the U.S.'s continued membership.

Trump's allies praised the speech, with former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani stating, "He has the temperament to win." Critics, however, such as President Obama's former speechwriter Jon Favreau, tweeted, "That speech was a reminder that Prompter Trump will always be just as dishonest and incompetent as Twitter Trump."

-End of Article-

Title: House Speaker Paul Ryan Ends Congressional Session After 25-Hour Democratic Sit-In on Gun Control

Article:

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) adjourned the House of Representatives early Thursday morning following a 25-hour sit-in led by congressional Democrats, who were unsuccessful in their attempt to force a vote on gun control measures. The sit-in, which began around 11:30 a.m. on Wednesday, unfolded on the House floor with little advance warning.

During the sit-in, Democrats repeated their chant "No bill, no break!" and waved papers with the names of gun violence victims written in black. A core group of Democrats remained on the House floor for several hours, wrapped in blankets and resting on pillows. The sit-in ended early Thursday afternoon, hours after Republicans held a final vote on the Zika response and sent lawmakers home until July 5.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) declared that the Democrats had made "some progress" in dramatizing the arguments for action to stem gun violence, despite the failure to conjure a vote. House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer (D-MD) stated that the public should not be satisfied with a Republican majority that shut down the House and disregarded "the unfinished business of the American people."

Republicans, on the other hand, claimed that their colleagues had accomplished nothing other than disrupting the business of the House to score political points. The sit-in was a response to the shooting rampage at a Florida gay nightclub earlier this month that killed 49 people and injured 53 others. The mass shooting followed similar tragic incidents over the past years, including the school shooting in Newtown, Connecticut.

The sit-in was reminiscent of a 1960s-style protest, as some lawmakers sat on the floor, others in their seats. The House chamber grew increasingly chaotic as the night wore on, and some lawmakers took breaks on pillows and blankets. C-SPAN broadcast live video streamed on Periscope and Facebook from lawmakers' accounts, as the cameras in the House gallery were turned off for most of the protest.

In the past, both parties have staged similar protests. In 2008, Democrats controlling the House at the time turned off the cameras amid a GOP push for a vote to expand oil and gas drilling. Republicans occupied the floor, delivering speech after speech, while Pelosi, then the House speaker, sent lawmakers bolting to their August recess. Pelosi at that time had ordered the cameras turned off.

The sit-in was not the first instance of agitation for action caused by gun violence in the Capitol. Last week, a Senate filibuster took place in response to the same cause. The sit-in, led by Georgia Rep. John Lewis, who had participated in the civil rights sit-ins in the 1960s, marked "some progress" in the lawmakers' efforts to get the attention of the nation to recognize the need for a vote on gun control legislation. Lewis is also backing the controversial legislation to keep people on the no-fly list from getting guns.

Title: Trump Delivers Polished Address to Congress, Aims for Bipartisan Cooperation

Article:

In his debut speech to Congress, President Donald Trump awarded himself a C or C+ in terms of messaging, stating, "I would give myself a C or a C+ [on communication]." The speech, delivered on Tuesday night, was described as the most polished and optimistic address of Trump's political career thus far.

Rep. Michael McCaul (R-TX), chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, noted, "This speech was a new face on the president that looked very presidential." After nearly six weeks in office, Trump's supporters hope he is finding his stride and learning from his early stumbles.

The next phase of Trump's political journey now moves to Congress, where he will embark on the delicate task of trying to pass a budget, and legislation on health care, tax reform, and immigration. The success of these endeavors remains to be seen.

Trump's speech contained many of the touchstones of a typical State of the Union address, including calls for healing, hope, and bipartisanship in the name of a common national purpose. He also addressed recent acts of vandalism and threats against Jewish targets and the shooting of two Indian men in Kansas last week, following criticism that he was slow to speak out against such attacks.

Embedded in Trump's agenda, Democrats warn, is the threat of mass deportations, the gutting of environmental protections, and the loss of health coverage for millions of newly insured low-income Americans. The travel ban, which temporarily barred travel to the US by citizens of seven largely Muslim countries and suspended Syrian refugee resettlement, was not discussed in the speech.

Trump's speech also emphasized his campaign theme of "America first," including a major increase in defense spending, a pull-back from multilateral trade agreements, the border wall, and tax cuts for corporations and the middle class. He expressed support for NATO, but also signaled a retrenchment of America's role on the global stage.

The speech won early high marks from the American public, with 7 in 10 Americans who tuned in saying it made them feel more optimistic about the country, according to a CNN poll. However, these are early days for the mercurial Trump, and it's anybody's guess as to whether he can maintain the more presidential posture he adopted Tuesday night.

Throughout the campaign, Trump's inflammatory rhetoric was a point of contention. However, his supporters and family members urged him to tone it down. Now, his supporters have a more positive message to point to. Republican strategist Ford O'Connell points to a particular moment of "optimism and compassion" in Tuesday's speech: "Everything that is broken in our country can be fixed. Every problem can be solved. And every hurting family can find healing and hope."

Not all Democrats were moved by Trump's message. Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR) dismissed his talk of clean air and water as "empty" words. He was also unimpressed by the president's inclusive language. "It's just a rehash of everything we've heard before," said Senator Merkley, one of the chamber's most liberal members.

Democrats are in the minority on Capitol Hill, and they have pledged to do everything they can to block a Trump agenda that aims to undo key parts of President Obama's legacy. However, Republicans are hopeful. "Trump's overall goal of the address was to instill in Congress the 'will to govern,' to compromise where possible in an effort to get things done on behalf of the American people," writes Mr. O'Connell in an email. "It's not an easy task in a broken, bipartisan town like Washington, D.C. But on this night, he succeeded."

Title: Unemployment Rate Rises as Job Growth Slows in May

Article:

The United States unemployment rate increased from 8.1 percent to 8.2 percent in May, according to a report released by the Labor Department on Friday. The slowdown in job growth was significant, with only 69,000 jobs created during the month, marking the weakest growth in a year. This is far below the 115,000 jobs previously reported for April and a fraction of the 226,000 jobs added each month during the first quarter.

The construction industry, which had seen unusual job gains in the winter due to mild weather, reported a loss of jobs in May. The business services sector, a vital sector that has created 1.4 million jobs since the end of the recession, also saw a loss of 1,000 jobs. However, the health care, transportation, and wholesaling sectors reported healthy job gains.

John Silvia, chief economist at Wachovia Securities, commented, "This is a major disappointment. There was major weakness in construction." The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped more than 150 points at the start of trading Friday morning, reflecting Wall Street's expectations of twice the reported job gains.

Chris Williamson, economist at Markit, suggested that the slowdown could be due to payback after stronger-than-usual hiring earlier in the year due to warmer-than-normal weather in the winter months. However, he also noted that it could indicate a "fundamental" slowdown in the economy that will lead to further rises in the unemployment rate.

Dan North, chief economist at Euler Hermes, described the spring slowdown as "an ugly trend in this most important of indicators." He predicted that the report will provoke a "heated" political debate about the health of the U.S. economy.

Republicans quickly seized on the news as evidence that President Obama's economic policies are not effective. House Speaker John Boehner, Ohio Republican, stated, "President Obama's failed policies have made high unemployment and a weak economy the sad new normal for families and small businesses."

However, Alan B. Krueger, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, argued that the report shows "the economy is still growing, but it is not growing fast enough." He attributed the slowdown to "headwinds" from the European economic crisis and the spike in gasoline prices this spring, which is now on the wane.

In addition to the slowdown in job growth, the rise in unemployment also reflected a surge in people looking for work but unable to find jobs. About 642,000 more people went on a job hunt last month, but only 422,000 of those landed jobs, according to the department.

Aparna Mathur, economist at the American Enterprise Institute, noted that the job market has fallen into a spring slump for the second year in a row. She suggested that one underlying source of friction is the millions of long-term unemployed people who lack the technical skills needed to fill many of the jobs that are coming open, creating a situation where both employers and the unemployed cannot find what they need and want.

Title: President Trump Denies Campaign's Russian Connection, Accuses U.S. Intelligence Community of Leaking Information

Article:

President Donald Trump has denied allegations that his associates had contact with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign, labeling the reports as "non-sense." In a series of tweets on Wednesday, the president accused the U.S. intelligence community of illegally leaking information to news outlets.

"This Russian connection non-sense is merely an attempt to cover-up the many mistakes made in Hillary Clinton’s losing campaign," Mr. Trump tweeted. He also claimed that the "real scandal" is that the intelligence community is giving out classified information "like candy."

The president's tweets come after multiple news outlets, including CNN and The New York Times, reported Tuesday that Russian officials were in contact with members of Mr. Trump's team during the campaign. According to CNN, advisers close to Mr. Trump were in "constant communication during the campaign with Russians known to US intelligence."

Among those reportedly communicating with Russian nationals was former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort. Mr. Manafort denied that he ever knowingly talked to any intelligence official "or anyone in Russia regarding anything of what’s under investigation."

"I have never had any connection to (Russian President Vladimir) Putin or the Russian government before, during or after the campaign," he told CNN.

Mr. Trump and his team have consistently denied any contacts between the campaign and Russian officials ahead of November's election. The reports come on the heels of the resignation of former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. The White House said Tuesday that Mr. Flynn misled Vice President Mike Pence and others about the nature of his conversations with Russia's ambassador to the U.S. after the November election but before Mr. Trump was sworn into office.

Title: California Primary Election: Clinton and Sanders Battle for Delegates in Upcoming Contest

Article:

With the California primary election set for Tuesday, the race for Democratic delegates remains uncertain as Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders vie for one of California's 475 delegates. In a recent interview on CNN's "State of the Union," Clinton expressed confidence in her chances, stating, "I believe, on Tuesday, I will have decisively won the popular vote and I will have decisively won the pledged delegate majority."

Sanders, however, has expressed a different perspective, telling reporters in Los Angeles that it is unlikely Clinton will secure enough pledged delegates to claim victory on Tuesday night. He suggested that the Democratic National Convention could potentially become a contested convention, with no candidate having enough pledged delegates to claim a clear victory.

The "Bernie or Bust" movement, in which some Sanders supporters have pledged not to vote for Clinton in the general election if she is the nominee, could potentially pose a challenge to Clinton's campaign. A Quinnipiac University poll indicates that 25% of Sanders supporters would not vote for Clinton if she were the nominee against presumed Republican nominee Donald Trump. In California, where the USC Dornsife/LA Times poll indicates that Clinton trails Sanders 43% to 44%, only 65% of Sanders supporters in the California primary have stated they would definitely support Clinton in a Clinton-Trump face-off.

As of Sunday, following Puerto Rico's primary, Clinton holds 1,809 delegates and 548 superdelegates, totaling 2,357. To secure the nomination, Clinton needs at least 2,382 delegates. In the upcoming Democratic primaries on Tuesday (when party voters head to the polls in California, New Jersey, the Dakotas, Montana, and New Mexico), 694 delegates, including 475 delegates in California, will be at stake.

Sanders has also been campaigning aggressively in California, criticizing Trump while also emphasizing the ongoing nature of the Democratic race. "If we can win, and win big here in California and in the other states, and in Washington D.C., we are going to go into the Democratic convention with enormous momentum," Sanders told supporters during a rally outside the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. "With your help, I believe, we will come out with the nomination."

Title: U.S. Policy Debate on Egypt Crisis: No Consensus on Response to Military Takeover

Article:

As the political crisis in Egypt unfolds, President Barack Obama and other U.S. politicians are under pressure to clarify the U.S. response to the chaos in Cairo. The administration has so far declined to describe the situation as a coup d'etat, instead expressing concern without committing to a clear course of action.

The argument over the U.S. response to the Egyptian crisis is complex and has scrambled traditional partisan and ideological lines. A coalition that supported the Iraq intervention a decade ago, consisting of ardent Israel supporters and pro-democracy idealists, has begun to fray. Israel supporters are generally in favor of the ousting of President Mohamed Morsi and his Muslim Brotherhood government, while democracy advocates argue that his regime, despite its flaws, was legitimately elected and has now been illegitimately overthrown.

There is no consensus among traditional establishment voices. The Washington Post editorial page has criticized Obama's response as "feckless," while The New York Times has praised his "appropriate caution."

Under U.S. law, the $1.3 billion in American military aid that goes to Egypt must be suspended if Morsi's forcible ouster and the arrest of his allies are formally declared a coup.

This article outlines the emerging Washington camps on the upheaval in Egypt and what the United States ought to do about it. It is important to note that many people who have expressed views so far have done so with a tentativeness that suggests their views may change. Furthermore, some people fall naturally into more than one group.

There are those who find the military takeover preferable to the status quo under Morsi, with both Republicans and Democrats in this camp preferring to keep U.S. aid flowing as a way of maintaining influence within the Egyptian power structure and, with luck, coaxing the generals before too long to restore the Egyptian constitution and civilian rule.

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) is one such voice, stating, "The Egyptian military has long been a key partner of the United States and a stabilizing force in the region, and is perhaps the only trusted national institution in Egypt today."

Others argue that the Egyptian military is known for a self-protective, self-dealing culture that insulates it from accountability to civilian authority. However, the military is regarded as a force against religious radicalism and in favor of regional stability.

David Brooks, writing in The New York Times, suggests that the military takeover may bring Egypt back to a bloated and dysfunctional state, but argues that radical Islam, the main threat to global peace, has been partially discredited and removed from office.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Criticize Debate Format for Lack of Policy Discussion

Article:

Following the second round of U.S. Democratic presidential debates in Detroit, Michigan, on July 31, 2019, several candidates, including former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Kamala Harris, expressed frustration with the debate format, which they felt did not allow for in-depth policy discussions.

Senator Harris, who faced a series of attacks on her record during the debate, stated that the limited time allotted for each candidate to answer a question (60 seconds) and rebut an attack (30 seconds) prevented a thorough exploration of policy issues. "It can be a frustrating process. There are so many of these issues that can not be captured in 60 seconds," Harris said.

Biden, the Democratic front-runner, who faced criticism over healthcare, immigration, and criminal justice reform, echoed Harris' sentiments, stating that it was difficult to explain complicated topics in less than one minute. "That's not a debate. I understand why it has to be that way, but I'm looking forward to getting to a place where we can actually exchange ideas," he said.

The crowded field of more than two dozen candidates vying for the Democratic nomination has led to back-to-back nights of debates featuring 10 candidates each, resulting in rapid-fire exchanges that frustrated both candidates and viewers. Former presidential candidate Mike Huckabee criticized the "game show rules" of the debate, stating, "These people are trying to be president - not win a Buick!"

The Democratic National Committee has increased the fundraising and polling requirements to qualify for participation in an effort to reduce the number of candidates on stage for the next debate, which is not scheduled until September.

Biden and Harris both stated that they were not surprised to be the target of attacks from all directions during the debate. Harris commented, "If you're considered a front-runner, you should be prepared to take a hit. So there was nothing about last night that surprised me."

Biden criticized the debate's focus on past policies, particularly those of former President Barack Obama, who remains the most popular figure in the Democratic Party. "I hope in the next debate we can talk about how we can fix the things that Trump has broken, not how Barack Obama made all these mistakes, because he didn't," Biden said.

Harris and Biden clashed early in the debate over their healthcare plans, with Harris criticizing Biden's proposal for leaving too many people uninsured and Biden ridiculing Harris' plan as not requiring a middle-class tax hike. Senator Cory Booker, who clashed with Biden on criminal justice records, stated at a Detroit rally that the strife would eventually be forgotten, saying, "We may be having a primary debate right now, but we know we are going to close ranks behind the candidate."

Title: Moore Accuses Washington Post of Political Agenda Amid Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

Alabama Republican Senate nominee Roy Moore has denied allegations of pursuing romantic relationships with teenage girls, accusing The Washington Post of having a "political agenda." During a campaign appearance in Birmingham on Saturday, Moore stated, "In the next few days, there will be revelations about the motivation and the content of this article."

The Washington Post reported on Thursday that Moore, the former chief justice of Alabama's Supreme Court, pursued relationships with four teenage women dating back to the 1970s when he was in his early thirties and single. Moore has denied the allegations, though he admitted on Sean Hannity's radio show that "after my return from the military, I dated a lot of young ladies."

One woman told The Washington Post she was 14 when the 32-year-old Moore asked her out and made sexual advances. Top Republicans, including President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have stated that Moore should drop out of the race if the allegations are true. However, Moore has shown no sign of doing so.

On Saturday, Moore insisted the accusations about his conduct "nearly 40 years ago" are "completely false and untrue." He also accused The Washington Post, which has endorsed his Democratic opponent Doug Jones, of "yet another attack on my character and reputation in a desperate attempt to stop my political campaign for United States Senate."

The story has reportedly inflicted significant damage to Moore's campaign ahead of next month's special election for the seat once held by Attorney General Jeff Sessions. There have been discussions of possible write-in campaigns from other Republicans, but nothing has materialized as of yet.

Earlier on Saturday, President Trump, who has been traveling in Asia over the past week, did not seem interested in commenting further on the situation, stating he's been too busy reading documents and has not had time to catch up on television news coverage about Moore.

Title: Washington Post Removes Controversial Cartoon Depicting Senator Cruz's Children

Article:

Senators Ted Cruz (R-Texas) and Marco Rubio (R-Florida) have been engaged in a contentious campaign trail over the past few weeks, vying for support in the Republican primary field. However, a recent event has united the two senators, as they have come together in condemnation of a controversial cartoon published by The Washington Post.

On Tuesday, The Washington Post published a cartoon by Ann Telnaes, the paper's editorial cartoonist, which depicted Senator Cruz dressed as Santa Claus accompanied by his two daughters, who were dressed in red outfits and appeared to be "trained monkeys," as Cruz described.

In response to the cartoon, Senator Cruz tweeted, "Classy. @washingtonpost makes fun of my girls. Stick w/ attacking me -- Caroline & Catherine are out of your league." Rubio also expressed his disapproval, tweeting, "Wash Post cartoon featuring @tedcruz's children is disgusting. The Post saying the kids are 'fair game' is even worse."

The Cruz campaign swiftly turned the cartoon into a fundraising appeal, characterizing it as an attack on Cruz and his family from the "liberal media." The first line of the email from Cruz's campaign, which included a screen grab of the cartoon, read, "I'm sickened... I knew I'd be facing attacks from day one of my campaign, but I never expected anything like this."

Following the backlash, The Washington Post removed the cartoon and issued an editor's note from Fred Hiatt, stating, "It's generally been the policy of our editorial section to leave children out of it. I failed to look at this cartoon before it was published. I understand why Ann thought an exception to the policy was warranted in this case, but I do not agree." The headline still stood, reading, "Ted Cruz uses his kids as political props (updated with statement)," but the cartoon was replaced with the editor's note.

Title: Cautious Optimism Surrounds Timeline for Coronavirus Vaccine Development

Article:

The development of an effective vaccine for the coronavirus is the only known means to end the ongoing pandemic. Over 100 potential vaccines are currently in various stages of development, with some already in human trials. The U.S. government's "Operation Warp Speed," launched in May, aims to have millions of doses available by the end of the year. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation's top infectious disease expert, expressed "cautious optimism" that a vaccine could be ready by early 2021.

Experts suggest that the virus will continue to spread until approximately 70% of the population has developed immunity. Achieving this level of immunity, known as "herd immunity," through a vaccine is considered the quickest and safest method, as opposed to waiting for enough people to become infected.

However, there are significant reasons to be skeptical of the idea that a game-changing vaccine is just a few months away, experts say. Developing a vaccine by the end of the year or even by next summer would break the record for the fastest vaccine ever developed, which currently stands at four years. Even if this milestone is achieved, drug companies will still need to produce hundreds of millions of doses and distribute them to the people who need them.

Some experts worry about investing too much in a best-case scenario, suggesting that a more prudent approach would be to prepare for a multi-year timeline by developing effective systems of testing, tracing, and therapeutic medicines. There is also concern that the idea of a vaccine being imminent may be hindering the implementation of necessary virus mitigation measures.

Additionally, there is a risk that rushing development may lead to an unsafe vaccine reaching the market, increasing anti-vaccine sentiment among the public, and potentially undermining herd immunity. There is also the possibility that any new vaccine may not be entirely effective or may provide immunity only for a short period of time.

"An approved coronavirus vaccine won't do any good if people aren't willing to roll up their sleeves for it." - Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

A vaccine will not be a magic solution, but it is still the best path out of the pandemic. "If you're imagining there'll be one golden day when a vaccine is approved and the pandemic will be over — Finally! We can all crowd into one another's living rooms and resume choir practice again — I'm afraid it won't be quite like that. But it will be the beginning of the end. There's much to be hopeful about, and enormous challenges lie ahead." - Caroline Chen, ProPublica

"It would be a shame if production and supply chain bottlenecks, such as the ones faced for medical supplies, slow down vaccine availability after discovery. Production must be done globally to prevent bottlenecks, hoarding, and to facilitate efficient distribution of vaccines to local clinics." - Krishna B. Kumar, Mahshid Abir, and Christopher Nelson, The Hill

Waiting on a miracle cure in the future is causing unnecessary deaths right now.
