"Like an overly optimistic doctor, some policymakers are banking on a future vaccine that, at best, may arrive in 2021 while people are sick and dying now and the economy continues to be hobbled with an unclear path forward to stability. The tragedy is that there is a playbook that can reduce the number of cases and deaths right now." - Eric Schneider, Los Angeles Times.

Title: Lindsey and Annie's Journey: A Story of Personal Growth and Feminism

Article:

In an account shared by Lindsey and Annie, two individuals with contrasting political views and perspectives on feminism, the duo recounts their experiences and the impact they had on each other's lives.

Lindsey, a former Republican, shared her interest in politics and her upbringing in a socially liberal, fiscally conservative household. She attended the University of Oklahoma and, at the time, found it more practical to align with the Republican Party in the South. However, she is no longer a registered Republican, citing a shift in the party's stance that no longer aligns with her comfort.

Annie, on the other hand, shared her relationship with the Democratic Party, which she found similar to Lindsey's relationship with the Republican Party due to familial influences.

Their first significant interaction occurred during a summer internship in Washington D.C., where Lindsey's understanding of feminism was challenged. Initially, she held a misconceived notion that feminism was about giving undeserved opportunities to women. Through conversations with Annie and other colleagues, Lindsey came to understand the importance of feminism in challenging unacceptable treatment and recognizing her own worth.

Annie, in turn, learned from Lindsey the importance of embracing her womanhood and body confidence at a young age. Lindsey's self-assured demeanor and comfort with her sexuality inspired Annie to be more comfortable with her own body and sexuality.

The account concludes with both individuals acknowledging the significant impact each had on the other's personal growth and understanding of feminism.

Title: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Laments Partisanship in Congress, Discusses Personal Life

Article:

U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg expressed her disapproval of partisanship in Congress during a talk at Stanford University on Monday, stating that she hoped it would return to a time when the legislative body worked for the good of the country and not just along party lines. Ginsburg did not address the nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court seat vacated by the late Justice Antonin Scalia or President Donald Trump's travel ban, which could potentially be heard by the high court.

Ginsburg did, however, express a desire to change the Electoral College, a comment that received applause from the packed church. She did not elaborate on her reasons for this desire.

During the presidential campaign, Ginsburg had stated that she presumed Democrat Hillary Clinton would win and have the opportunity to make a few appointments to the court. She had also called Trump a "faker" who "really has an ego" in one interview.

Ginsburg recalled Monday that she received bipartisan support for her nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court, with Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch being her most ardent supporter. "I think today he wouldn't touch me with a 10-foot pole," she joked.

Ginsburg, who is the leader of the court's liberal wing and the oldest justice on the court, has survived pancreatic and colon cancer, causing concern among liberals about her health and the future of their causes if President Trump gets an opportunity to replace her or any of the other liberal judges on the bench.

Ginsburg supporters have joked about steps she could take to stay healthy, such as eating more kale. Asked by a Stanford student who else should eat more kale in Washington, D.C., the justice quipped, "Justice Kennedy." Anthony Kennedy, who is 80 and is considered a swing vote, is the second oldest justice on the Supreme Court.

Ginsburg has shown no signs of slowing down and has said she has a personal trainer who leads her through hour-long workouts that include push-ups and weights. She said family plays a large part in her life, and she does not admit defeat. "The attitude is I'm going to surmount this whatever it is," she said.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling Leaves FCC Free to Modify Indecency Policy, Protecting Children from Broadcast Content

Article:

In a unanimous 8-0 decision, the Supreme Court has ruled that the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) did not provide fair notice to networks when enforcing its indecency rules, effectively vacating fines imposed on Fox Television Stations and ABC. The ruling leaves the FCC free to modify its current indecency policy, with the potential to protect children from indecent broadcast content.

The ruling in FCC vs. Fox Television Stations did not address the central question of whether the FCC's indecency rules, which regulate the use of profanity or fleeting nudity on air, violate the First Amendment. Instead, the court focused on the FCC's due process violations.

Representative Fred Upton (R-Mich.), chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, issued a statement following the ruling, reminding media executives to exercise responsibility when using public airwaves to broadcast content into family homes.

FCC Chairman Julius Genachowski, in a statement, acknowledged the ruling's potential impact on the FCC's current indecency policy, stating that the commission is reviewing the decision, which appears to be limited to procedural issues related to actions taken several years ago. Genachowski also assured lawmakers that the FCC will continue to protect young TV viewers in accordance with First Amendment principles.

Senator Jay Rockefeller (D-W.Va.), chairman of the commerce committee, praised the ruling, stating that it leaves the FCC's authority to protect children from indecent programming intact. The ruling means that Fox and ABC will not face FCC fines and sanctions in their cases, and it signals that the FCC should revisit and potentially modify its policy.

The ruling stems from a series of court findings initiated by the FCC's decision to change the indecency rules following rock star Bono's impromptu utterance of an expletive during his acceptance speech at the 2003 Golden Globe Awards on NBC. Since the FCC changed its rules, it decided not to fine NBC at the time. The specifics of the FCC's next steps are currently unclear.

Title: U.S. Stock Markets Reach New Highs Amid Easing Trade Tensions, Dollar Weakens

Article:

U.S. stock benchmarks reached new highs on Thursday, following news from China about potential tariff and currency moves that could ease trade tensions. The S&P 500 Index closed at a record high, led by the technology, health-care, and financial sectors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also reached a new peak, with 28 of 30 constituents showing positive gains. Most European and Asian shares also increased.

Trade conflicts that had caused stock market volatility earlier in the week have since subsided. China is reportedly planning to reduce the average tariff rate it imposes on imports from the majority of its trading partners as early as next month. On Wednesday, Premier Li Keqiang stated that China's government would not devalue its currency to boost exports amid the trade war.

The yield on 10-year Treasuries remained above 3%, near its high for the year. The greenback weakened after a report suggested that the U.S. and Canada are unlikely to reach a deal on NAFTA in Washington this week. Jobless data was solid but did little to alter the overall sentiment. The pound surged after August retail sales came in higher than expected.

"The dollar has generally strengthened on tariff fears, especially against EM currencies," said Pravit Chintawongvanich, an equity derivatives strategist at Wells Fargo Securities. "What you're seeing today is the opposite of that. EM equities and DM equities ex-U.S. are catching up. Today is a continuation of the risk-on theme we've seen in the last couple of days."

Equity markets have remained resilient in the face of rising bond yields, suggesting that investors are comfortable with the outlook for corporate earnings and global growth despite the increase in borrowing costs and trade tensions. Ahead of the Fed meeting next week, some other central banks took center stage on Thursday, with Norway's policy makers raising interest rates for the first time in seven years as the SNB kept deposit rates unchanged.

Elsewhere, emerging-market assets continued to rally off the lows seen earlier this month, with the rand among the leading developing-world currencies as the South African Reserve Bank held its key interest rate at a two-year low. Norway's krone retreated as investors viewed the central bank's rate trajectory as dovish, while the Swiss franc strengthened.

West Texas crude dropped after U.S. President Donald Trump resumed his criticism of OPEC on Twitter. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies will meet in Algiers this weekend. The S&P 500 Index gained 0.8% as of 4 p.m. New York time to its highest on record. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1% and also reached a record high. The MSCI Emerging Market Index jumped 0.9% to its highest in more than two weeks. The Dollar Spot Index decreased 0.4% to its lowest in eight weeks. The Japanese yen sank 0.1% to 112.41 per dollar. The yield on 10-year Treasuries rose less than one basis point to 3.07%. Germany's 10-year yield decreased two basis points to 0.47%. Britain's 10-year yield fell two basis points to 1.585%. The Commodity Index rose 0.6%, approaching a six-week high. West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.4% to $70.80 a barrel. LME copper fell 0.6% to $6,082.00 a metric ton.

Title: Israeli Government Denies Entry to U.S. Reps. Tlaib and Omar Amid Boycott Controversy

Article:

Israeli officials have blocked U.S. Reps. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) and Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) from entering the country as part of a planned visit. The move has sparked a significant outcry from Democratic lawmakers in Washington, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling it a "sign of weakness" and Omar accusing Israel of implementing "Trump's Muslim ban."

In a statement, Omar said, "It is an affront that Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu, under pressure from President Trump, would deny entry to representatives of the U.S. government."

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu defended the decision, stating that Tlaib and Omar's itinerary "revealed that they planned a visit whose sole objective is to strengthen the boycott against us and deny Israel's legitimacy." Netanyahu noted that the Palestinian organization that planned the visit, MIFTAH, supports the boycott movement, and that people associated with the group have supported terror against Israel in the past.

The decision was made by Interior Minister Arye Deri and announced earlier Thursday by deputy foreign minister Tzipi Hotovely, despite prior assurances that the congresswomen would be allowed in.

Omar and Tlaib were among 17 members of Congress who voted against a resolution condemning the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement in July. This was after Omar introduced a resolution of her own that encouraged the use of boycotts as a political tool.

Israel welcomes critics, but not those who support boycotts of the Jewish State, according to Netanyahu. He confirmed that Deri would consider permitting Tlaib to visit her Palestinian family members if she filed a humanitarian request and promised not to promote boycotts of Israel while she visits.

The U.S. ambassador to Israel put out a statement of support for the decision, but Democratic lawmakers and even Israel's Washington allies were critical. Notably, pro-Israel lobby AIPAC tweeted that while they disagree with Omar and Tlaib's positions, "We also believe every member of Congress should be able to visit and experience our democratic ally Israel firsthand."

Democrats expressed strong opposition to keeping Omar and Tlaib out. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) said, "Banning Congresswomen Omar and Tlaib from entering Israel and Palestine is a sign of enormous disrespect to these elected leaders, to the United States Congress, and to the principles of democracy."

Israeli media reported earlier on discussions of barring the freshman congresswomen due to their support for the anti-Israel BDS movement. Israeli law states that those supporting boycotts of the country may be denied entry. Waivers can be granted for diplomatic figures, however. In July, Israel’s U.S. ambassador said the country would not bar U.S. lawmakers out of “respect” for Congress and Israel’s longtime “alliance” with the U.S. Trump expressed frustration about the decision last week, The Washington Post reported.

Netanyahu faced pressure from Democratic leaders and some U.S.-based Israel advocacy groups that were advising against barring the congresswomen, the Post reported. The Jerusalem Post reported Thursday that Netanyahu met Wednesday with Deri, Foreign Minister Israel Katz, Public Security Minister Gilad Erdan, National Security Council leader Meir Ben-Shabbat, and Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit to discuss the matter. On Thursday, before the formal denial, Israeli Channel 13’s Barak Ravid reported that, according to officials, Netanyahu had been considering allowing Tlaib and Omar to enter Israel, but only to travel within the territories controlled by the Palestinian Authority. Tlaib and Omar had been scheduled to arrive in Israel on Friday.

Title: FDA Launches Criminal Probe into Vaping-Related Illnesses as Cases Surpass 530

Article:

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has initiated a criminal investigation into the recent surge of vaping-related illnesses, which has reached 530 confirmed cases as of September 17, according to health authorities. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported this increase on Thursday, with cases reported in 38 states and one territory.

As of Thursday morning, the CDC reported seven deaths resulting from vaping-related illness, with more expected. By Thursday evening, the Missouri Department of Health confirmed the first death in Missouri, making it the eighth nationwide.

Mitch Zeller, director of the FDA's Center for Tobacco Products, stated that the criminal probe will not focus on personal vaping-related product use but will investigate the products themselves, their sources, and their usage.

The cause of the outbreak remains undetermined, with no consistent product, substance, or brand identified in all cases. Most, but not all, patients reported a history of using e-cigarette products containing THC, a psychoactive chemical found in cannabis.

The FDA has collected over 150 vaping product samples for forensic analysis, testing them for traces of nicotine, THC, and other cannabinoids, opioids, cutting agents, additives, pesticides, poisons, toxins, and more. While vitamin E acetate has been found in some samples, no singular compound has been identified in all the samples.

Officials have warned consumers against purchasing vapes off the street or modifying vape products. Dr. Anne Schuchat, principal deputy director at CDC, urged consumers to take these recommendations seriously.

Of the reported cases, about three-fourths of those diagnosed with an illness have been male, slightly over-representative of males in the general vaping population. Young people have been particularly affected, with more than half of the sick being under 25, and 2 out of 3 cases being people between 18 and 34 years old.

In Illinois, which has seen 69 reported cases and one death, health officials are turning to the public for help in cracking the case. Dr. Jennifer Layden, chief medical officer and state epidemiologist for the Illinois Department of Public Health, is asking Illinois residents who have recently vaped to fill out an online, anonymous survey regarding their vaping habits.

As e-cigarette maker Juul faces lawsuits across the country, politicians, businesses, and individuals are taking action against the vaping industry. A new congressional caucus aimed at curbing the nation's teen-vaping epidemic was announced by U.S. Reps. Diana DeGette (D-CO), Raja Krishnamoorthi (D-IL), and Peter King (R-NY) on Thursday.

Last week, President Donald Trump announced plans to ban the sale of flavored vaping products in an effort to discourage young people from using e-cigarettes. Michigan became the first state to ban sales of flavored e-cigarettes in stores and online, citing health concerns related to vaping. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo called for a ban a week later, and other cities are now considering similar measures.

CBS, WarnerMedia, and Viacom announced this week that they will no longer run advertisements for e-cigarettes on their networks. Many young people who previously vaped are taking to social media to warn their peers about the dangers of e-cigarettes, with Miami teen Chance Ammirata, who was hospitalized with a vaping-related illness, posting about his journey with the hashtag "#lunglove."

"The fight has just begun," Ammirata said in a recent post.

Title: European Military Observers Detained in Ukraine Possibly to be Exchanged for Pro-Russian Activists

Article:

A pro-Russian insurgency leader in eastern Ukraine, Vyacheslav Ponomarev, has suggested that a team of European military observers detained in the region could be released in exchange for jailed pro-Russian activists. Ponomarev, self-proclaimed people's mayor of Slovyansk, a city 90 miles west of Russia, described the detained observers as "captives."

According to the Associated Press, Ponomarev stated, "As we found maps on them containing information about the location of our checkpoints, we get the impression that they are officers carrying out a certain spying mission."

Ukraine's state security service issued a statement Saturday claiming that "the official representatives of the OSCE are being held in inhuman conditions" and that "among those detained is a person who needs immediate medical help," according to Russia Today.

The German-led, eight-member team was traveling under the auspices of the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe when they were detained. Germany's Defense Ministry said it had lost contact with the team, which included five Ukrainians.

Tim Guldimann, OSCE's special envoy for Ukraine, told German public radio WDR on Saturday that "efforts are being made to solve this issue." He declined to elaborate.

Meanwhile, Ukraine's acting prime minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk met with Pope Francis at the Vatican, but escalating Ukrainian-Russian tensions prompted him to return home instead of staying for the canonization ceremony on Sunday.

Francis gave Yatsenyuk a fountain pen, telling him, "I hope that you write 'peace' with this pen."

In a joint statement released Friday night by the White House, the United States and other nations in the Group of Seven agreed to "move swiftly" to impose additional economic sanctions on Russia in response to its actions in Ukraine. The G-7 nations say they will act urgently to intensify "targeted sanctions." The statement also says the G-7 will continue to prepare broader sanctions on key Russian economic sectors if Moscow takes more aggressive action. The White House says U.S. sanctions could be levied as early as Monday.

Further details regarding the conditions of the detained observers, the potential prisoner exchange, and the specific actions that prompted the G-7's response were not available in the provided source text.

Title: FBI Investigates "Targeted Attack" on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Offices in Texas

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has classified the shooting incident at the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) offices in San Antonio, Texas, as a "targeted attack." Several shots were fired at around 03:00 local time (08:00 GMT) on Tuesday, with two neighboring buildings also coming under fire. No injuries were reported, according to the FBI's statement.

The FBI is currently reviewing surveillance footage as part of its investigation into the shootings. No arrests have been made, and investigators are searching for suspects, according to U.S. media reports.

In a statement, ICE attributed the shootings to "political rhetoric" and "misinformation" about the Trump administration's detention policies. ICE, under the Trump administration, has faced heavy criticism for its treatment of undocumented immigrants held at detention centers near the U.S.-Mexico border.

Daniel Bible, ICE's director for San Antonio, stated, "This disturbing public discourse shrouds our critical law enforcement function and unnecessarily puts our officers' safety at risk."

Christopher Combs, head of the FBI's San Antonio operations, described the shootings as "cowardly, brazen, violent acts." He added that those responsible for firing the shots "did some research" because they "knew what floors ICE was on, and they hit those."

According to Mr. Combs, all the shots found were on the floors where ICE had offices, calling the incident "a very targeted attack." He also noted that, although no one was injured, "we could be here today talking about the murder of a federal official" had the bullets "gone two inches in another direction."

Bullet holes can be seen in several windows at the buildings located near Brookhaven Drive, north-east San Antonio. A picture tweeted by Ken Cuccinelli, acting head of Citizenship and Immigration Services, shows a bullet hole in a window at one of the offices targeted.

The building primarily used for executive and administrative purposes, ICE said. According to the Washington Examiner, the shooting is the latest of four recent attacks at ICE facilities across the country. The three previous incidents occurred in Washington D.C., Tacoma, Washington, and Aurora, Colorado, within days of each other in July, the website reported.

Given the current climate, FBI investigators fear there could be more attacks, Mr. Combs said. "We cannot allow political discourse to lead us to the point of violence, where federal employees, innocent people doing their jobs, are put in harm's way," he stated.

Title: Bernie Sanders Announces Conditional Withdrawal from Democratic Primary

Article:

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has announced that he will withdraw from the Democratic primary if, by the time of the Democratic National Convention, former Vice President Joe Biden has a plurality of delegates. The Democratic primary candidates require a majority (1,991 delegates) to secure the nomination.

Projections indicate that it is unlikely for any candidate to achieve a majority during the primary. If no candidate obtains a majority, the primary proceeds to a second ballot, during which superdelegates can vote. Superdelegates, who make up about 15% of all delegates, include major elected officials, former presidents or vice presidents, and prominent members of the Democratic National Committee.

Sanders has stated that he will concede the nomination to Biden, even if Biden only has a plurality, rather than a majority, of delegates. In doing so, Sanders aims to avoid a contested convention, where a person with fewer votes could potentially win the nomination.

"I think it would be a real, real disaster for the Democratic Party," Sanders said of a contested convention. "People would say 'the person who won the most votes didn't get selected.' Not a good idea."

This decision could be interpreted as Sanders maintaining his dislike of superdelegates and his loyalty to the will of the people. However, it is more likely that Sanders is setting a standard for the convention that he hopes Biden will follow if Sanders enters the convention with a plurality.

Currently, Biden has 596 delegates, while Sanders has 531. Biden has gained 581 of his 596 delegates in the past seven days with significant wins in South Carolina and on Super Tuesday.

Title: Bernie Sanders Defines Democratic Socialism as Human Rights, Including Living Wage and Free College Tuition

Article:

In a CNN town hall speech on Monday, Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders outlined his interpretation of democratic socialism, emphasizing human rights such as a living wage and free college tuition for all Americans.

"When I talk about democratic socialism, what I'm talking about are human rights and economic rights," Sanders said.

CNN's Wolf Blitzer, who moderated the event, asked Sanders to respond to President Trump's repeated criticisms of socialism, with the president stating during his State of the Union address earlier this month that "America will never be a socialist country."

Sanders responded by stating that the direction of the country is moving towards socialism whether the president approves or not.

"If I am elected president, we will have a nation in which all people will have health care as a right, whether Trump likes it or not," the senator said. "We are going to make public colleges and universities tuition-free. We are going to raise the minimum wage to a living wage of at least $15 an hour."

Sanders continued, "And whether Trump likes it or not, when I talk about human rights, you know what that also means? It means that our kids and grandchildren have the human right to grow up in a planet that is healthy and habitable." He added that it is a disgrace and an embarrassment that the U.S. has a president who rejects science and denies the reality of climate change.

During the Q&A, Sanders was asked by a woman in the audience to explain why democratic socialism is preferable to capitalism.

"Right now we have a nation which prides itself on a lot of political rights," Sanders explained.

The senator stated that while constitutional rights like freedom of speech and freedom of religion are "enormously important," it is a problem that there are no economic guarantees.

"We don't have guarantees regarding economic rights," he said. "We've got to understand that everybody needs a decent paying job, that people need health care, that people need an education... These are not radical ideas."

"So what democratic socialism means to me is having in a civilized society with the understanding that we can make sure that all of our people live in security and in dignity," he added.

Title: Cruz and Kasich Announce Strategic Partnership to Block Trump from Reaching 1,237 Delegates

Article:

Republican presidential candidates Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and Ohio Gov. John Kasich announced their primary strategy on Sunday, a move that both candidates had previously sworn off: an official partnership. The two candidates have agreed to divide some of the remaining primary states and not compete with each other in three states.

Senator Cruz, for example, largely avoided campaigning in New York, where polls showed he was trailing Trump in the run-up to the April 19 primary, and instead looked west to California. Governor Kasich cut his losses in the South, choosing to campaign in Vermont and Massachusetts instead (where he had better poll numbers) the week before South Carolina's primary.

Sunday's announcement is a new political twist. Both Cruz and Kasich have released formal statements to clearly share their plan with American voters. Kasich's campaign announced in a press release Sunday night that "Keeping Trump from winning a plurality in Indiana is critical to keeping him under 1,237 bound delegates before Cleveland," where the Republican National Convention will be held July 18-21. "We are very comfortable with our delegate position in Indiana already," the campaign stated, "and given the current dynamics of the primary there, we will shift our campaign’s resources West and give the Cruz campaign a clear path in Indiana."

Cruz and Kasich have been fighting for the #NeverTrump vote since the field shrunk to three candidates last month. However, until recently, Cruz was fighting for a conventional nomination, while Kasich has long banked on a contested convention. Now, after the probability of a Cruz pre-convention was shrunk to nearly nil by the New York primary, the two candidates share the same #NeverTrump goal: block Trump from reaching 1,237 delegates before the Republican National Convention in July.

"Having Donald Trump at the top of the ticket in November would be a sure disaster for Republicans," said Cruz's campaign manager Jeff Roe in a statement Sunday. "To ensure that we nominate a Republican who can unify the Republican Party and win in November, our campaign will focus its time and resources in Indiana and in turn clear the path for Gov. Kasich to compete in Oregon and New Mexico, and we would hope that allies of both campaigns would follow our lead."

Trump responded to the announcement on Twitter, calling the alliance a "collusion" and "desperation."

While Cruz and Kasich's strategy is surprising—and a first for modern presidential elections—their specific allocation of Indiana, Oregon, and New Mexico might be perplexing. The choice of these three states can't be defended by primary dates. Five Northeastern states hold primaries on Tuesday. Indiana's Republican primary is on May 3, followed by Nebraska and West Virginia before Oregon's primary on May 17. And New Mexico's primary occurs on the last primary voting day for Republicans, June 7.

These three states are not exactly rich with delegates. Indiana has 57 delegates up for grabs, which is not insubstantial but is also less than Pennsylvania's 71 the week before. And on Kasich's end of the agreement, he is looking to gain Oregon's 28 delegates and New Mexico's 24. Of the five GOP primaries on June 7, New Mexico has the least amount of delegates, led by California's 172 delegates and New Jersey's 51.

Instead, the Cruz-Kasich alliance highlights the importance of Indiana. This late in the race, with Trump so close to 1,237, Indiana's 57 delegates could be a game changer. A Cruz win in Indiana is the best prospect for a contested convention.

"[Indiana] is likely to be the biggest battleground in coming weeks, given both the closeness of the race and the huge haul of delegates," explains Politico's Shane Goldmacher last week. "If Trump is to get to 1,237 delegates, he would likely need to win Indiana. Without it, his best mathematical alternative would be either to flip a likely Cruz state—Montana or South Dakota—or to sweep almost all 172 of California's delegates, a tall task."

Despite a polling blackout in Indiana because of a state law that prohibits automated polling, it's looking like a good state for Cruz. The Upshot's demographic-based model has Cruz leading Trump 43 to 40 percent with Kasich trailing at 16 percent. And two anonymous polling groups told Politico last week that Cruz and Trump were in a statistical tie, both with 32 percent. Giving Oregon to Kasich also makes sense for the #NeverTrump duo, as early polls predict Kasich winning that primary over Cruz and Trump.

"It may sound strange," adds The New York Times' Nate Cohn, "but when you start gaming out the rest of the primary contest, it's hard to avoid the conclusion that [Trump's] quest to reach a majority of delegates before the convention could all turn on Indiana." "If you divvy up the states by expected results," he continues, "Mr. Trump wins big in the East and West Virginia, loses the winner-take-all rural Western states, and earns his expected share of proportional delegates in Washington, Oregon, and New Mexico."

This puts Trump 175 delegates short of the nomination. If Kasich needs a contested convention for a chance to win the presidential election, and Cruz winning Indiana is the best chance for a contested convention, then giving Indiana to Cruz is the best option for both sides of the #NeverTrump fight.

Title: President Obama Meets with Labor Leaders to Discuss Fiscal Cliff Avoidance

Article:

President Barack Obama convened with labor leaders at the White House on Tuesday, marking the first of several meetings aimed at preventing automatic tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect at the beginning of the new year. The meetings follow Obama's re-election last week, and the question now is whether the president can translate his electoral success into policy-shaping achievements.

The 62 million Americans who voted to re-elect Obama in 2012 are aware that he seeks to impose higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans. This stance was made clear during stalled budget negotiations with congressional Republicans last year and throughout the lengthy presidential campaign.

During his victory celebration in Chicago last week, former White House Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel, now the city's mayor, suggested that the election results could pave the way for the kind of compromise President Clinton achieved with a Republican Congress when he was re-elected in 1996.

Since the election, Republican House Speaker John Boehner has shown some willingness to collect more tax revenue from the wealthy, provided it can be done without raising tax rates. Obama has expressed encouragement over Boehner's newfound flexibility, but he is not passively waiting for congressional Republicans to align with the majority of voters' views.

Obama stated during an interview with Univision in late September that public pressure from outside Washington can be an essential tool in moving a reluctant Congress. He suggested he might turn to the public more frequently in the future to exert such pressure.

The president noted that maintaining voters' attention during a lengthy debate over tax policy can be challenging, as he discovered during his first term when he abandoned his pledge to hold health care talks on national television. However, Obama expressed determination to engage more consistently with the American people during his second term.

Obama told voters in Ohio shortly before Election Day that their involvement is crucial for the democratic process to function effectively. This week's meetings with labor leaders and CEOs are part of Obama's efforts to gather support as he enters negotiations with Congress, and not just from his grassroots supporters who carried him to a second term.

Title: Obama Administration Orders Public Schools to Comply with Transgender Students' Facility Access

Article:

The Obama administration has announced that it will send a decree to all U.S. public schools, requiring them to allow transgender students access to facilities consistent with their gender identity. This move escalates the ongoing national debate on LGBT rights, sparked by North Carolina's controversial "bathroom bill."

The Justice Department and the Department of Education will send the decree, a copy of which was obtained by ███, on Friday. The letter provides guidelines to school districts across the country on how to protect transgender students from discrimination.

The letter, first reported by the New York Times, states that schools have legal obligations to protect transgender students and risk federal funding if they do not comply. The letter does not add new legal requirements but offers extensive guidelines on ensuring fair treatment and appropriate facility access for trans students.

The letter states, "A school may provide separate facilities on the basis of sex, but must allow transgender students access to such facilities consistent with their gender identity." It also specifies that transgender students cannot be required to use facilities inconsistent with their gender identity or to use individual-user facilities when other students are not required to do so.

The notice also makes clear that transgender students must have access to facilities "even in circumstances in which other students, parents, or community members raise objections or concerns." It further states, "As is consistently recognized in civil rights cases, the desire to accommodate others’ discomfort can not justify a policy that singles out and disadvantages a particular class of students."

A lengthy document attached to the letter provides examples of policies and emerging practices for supporting transgender students and offers guidelines on privacy, confidentiality, anti-bullying, and other issues affecting LGBT students.

U.S. attorney general Loretta Lynch said in a statement, "There is no room in our schools for discrimination of any kind, including discrimination against transgender students on the basis of their sex." She added, "This guidance gives administrators, teachers, and parents the tools they need to protect transgender students from peer harassment and to identify and address unjust school policies."

The announcement comes as the justice department and North Carolina move forward with a high-profile legal battle over the state's bathroom law. Lynch has stated that the law amounts to "state-sponsored discrimination" and has caused transgender people to suffer "emotional harm, mental anguish, distress, humiliation, and indignity."

The law, HB2, effectively forces trans people to use restrooms that correspond to the sex assigned to them at birth, which critics say is unenforceable and a clear violation of the US Civil Rights Act. It also blocks cities from passing local anti-discrimination laws aimed at protecting LGBT people.

Republican Governor of North Carolina, Pat McCrory, has defended the law as a privacy measure, accusing the federal government of a "baseless and blatant overreach" of its power. The state risks losing as much as $4.8bn in government funding by refusing to repeal the law.

The fight over trans rights extends beyond North Carolina. A federal appeals court in Virginia recently ruled that barring a transgender boy from using the boys' bathroom was a civil rights violation, and school officials in Chicago and Oregon have recently outlined protections for trans students.

Title: House and Senate Face Impasse as Fiscal Cliff Deadline Looms

Article:

In a high-level telephone conference call, House Republican leaders have called on the Senate to act and have indicated a willingness to bring any last-minute legislation the Senate produces to the House floor. The statement, issued on behalf of Speaker John A. Boehner and his three top lieutenants, states that the House will take action on any Senate-passed legislation, but the Senate must act first.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, however, has called on House Republicans to pass an existing Senate measure that would prevent tax increases on household income up to $250,000. In a statement, Reid criticized House Republicans for their "Tea Party bills" and accused them of obstruction.

As of Thursday evening, Senators will return to the Capitol with no immediate legislation to consider. The House is scheduled to be gaveled into session at 2 p.m., but since Speaker Boehner has not called the members back to Washington, it is likely to be gaveled back into recess shortly thereafter.

The focus has shifted to Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader and a deal-making veteran. Democrats are seeking assurances from McConnell that he will not use procedural tactics to delay any potential bill for an interim solution to avert the fiscal crisis.

Don Stewart, a spokesman for McConnell, stated that no one from the White House or from Reid's office has reached out to begin negotiations. Democrats argue that McConnell is well aware of their proposed solution: the same Senate bill that passed in July, which extends all the expiring Bush-era income tax cuts on incomes below $250,000, sets the tax rate on dividends and capital gains at 20 percent, and stops the alternative minimum tax from rising to hit more middle-class taxpayers. Democrats also propose adding an extension of expiring unemployment benefits and a delay in across-the-board spending cuts while negotiations on a broader deficit reduction plan slip into next year.

Democrats now suggest that Republicans are content to wait until after the January deadline. On Jan. 3, Boehner is likely to be re-elected speaker for the 113th Congress. After that roll call, he may feel less pressure from his right flank against a deal.

The Senate may simply be out of time. Without unanimous agreement, Reid would have to take procedural steps to begin considering a bill. He could then be forced to press for another vote to cut off debate before final passage. If forced to jump through those hoops, the 112th Congress could expire before final votes could be cast.

Representative Jim Himes, Democrat of Connecticut, said on CNBC on Wednesday, "I think there's some chance that we get a deal done in the early weeks of January, which technically means you're going over the cliff."

Lawmakers from both parties suggest that McConnell could be the key to a resolution. He has played the role of adjudicator for Congressional Republicans before, during last year's fight over a payroll tax extension and the battle between Democrats and Republicans over how, or if, to pay for an emergency disaster financing bill.

With days to spare, McConnell must decide whether to allow on the Senate floor the Democrats' bill to extend expiring tax cuts. If passed without a filibuster, that legislation could force the House speaker's hand and quiet his raucous Republican conference. Alternatively, McConnell, who is up for re-election in 2014 and would like to avoid a primary fight, could stand back quietly and hope that Boehner and President Obama somehow manage to put together a deal that saves him the trouble.

If McConnell cannot come to the rescue, there is another hope: Starbucks. Howard Schultz, the company's chief executive officer, asked baristas who work in Washington-area Starbucks to scrawl "Come Together" on coffee cups for the rest of the week to generate enthusiasm for a compromise.

Title: Online Donations Fuel Democratic House Campaigns, Countering GOP Advertising Assault

Article:

Hundreds of thousands of online donors are contributing substantial amounts of money to Democratic House campaigns at an increasing rate, countering a late-summer advertising offensive by the Republicans that aims to preserve their majority in the House of Representatives.

Republicans have traditionally relied on their outside-money advantage in the battle for the House, with the Congressional Leadership Fund (CLF) pledging to spend $100 million in 2018. The super PAC's strategy is to attack Democrats early and often, launching a series of TV attack ads in 15 districts before Labor Day. However, the influx of online money to Democratic candidates has allowed them to air their own TV ads earlier than ever, blunting the GOP's game plan.

According to a review of TV spending totals shared with ███, Democrats in nearly 20 districts aired TV ads first to define themselves before facing GOP attacks, while CLF went on the offensive first in seven districts. The sustained cash flow has extended Democrats' already formidable edge in the fight for control of the House. Democratic House candidates raised more than $35.8 million online in August, according to a ███ analysis of Federal Election Commission data from ActBlue, the Democratic online fundraising platform. This is nearly six times the amount raised online by House Democrats in August 2016, during the last election.

The gains have been broadly distributed: 14 Democratic challengers raised at least half a million dollars via ActBlue in August, while another 38 brought in at least $250,000 online.

"For a number of years, Democrats searched for our answer to the Koch brothers and found our own billionaire," said Jesse Ferguson, a former Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee staffer and Democratic consultant. "In reality, it's a 67-year-old grandmother on a fixed income who's donating $25 every month to candidates."

Among those leading the way was Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA officer running in Virginia who raised $790,000 online in August. Spanberger saw a fundraising spike after it was revealed that CLF had obtained her confidential security clearance application while conducting research on her employment history, according to her campaign.

By the time CLF used the information to attack Spanberger on TV on Sept. 6, the Democrat had already aired nearly 900 positive TV spots in her race against GOP Rep. Dave Brat, according to data from Advertising Analytics.

"Our ads helped set the baseline of who I am, and that was probably very helpful in combating those attacks," Spanberger said in an interview with ███. "The juxtaposition of the visuals of the ads, ours showing me as a normal person and theirs, are just scary."

CLF has continued its attacks with more TV ads, highlighting Spanberger's stint as a substitute teacher at the Saudi-funded Islamic Saudi Academy in Mount Vernon, Va., and calling it "Terror High." A Republican familiar with polling in the district said that "the race was trending in the wrong direction, and that ad helped stabilize things."

CLF spokeswoman Courtney Alexander said Democrats have been "forced to spend whatever they have raised responding to attack ads which are putting Democratic candidates on defense and setting the terms of these races," adding that "no first-time candidate wants their first ad to be a response ad, and that's what we have seen repeatedly from Democrats across the country as they are forced to scramble to answer for their records as the truth comes out."

Spanberger called the ads "ridiculous," adding that the attack has "fallen flat." She's just one of many Democrats bringing in big money and pouring it right back into mass communication with voters. Overall, ActBlue—which surpassed $1 billion raised in 2018 on Aug. 2—had its biggest month ever in August, bringing in $100 million to candidates and progressive organizations. Other top House fundraisers that month included Sharice Davids, who raised over $782,000 online for her campaign against Rep. Kevin Yoder (R-Kan.), and Jared Golden, who brought in over $729,000 online for his campaign against Rep. Bruce Poliquin (R-Maine).

The money came after months of groundwork by campaigns and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. The DCCC placed digital staffers in each of its regional political teams for the first time this election, according to a DCCC aide, helping campaigns grow online and be prepared to capitalize on viral moments and other opportunities.

The resulting well-funded campaigns have put House Democrats in an unusual position: They and their allied outside groups are currently outadvertising the GOP in some battlegrounds.

"Candidates and Democratic groups have been running even or we have an advantage in paid communications on the air in many of the top 25 to 30 districts across the country," said Charlie Kelly, executive director of House Majority PAC, the Democratic House super PAC. "Time and time again, Democratic enthusiasm is off the charts."

These August online fundraising totals track with Democratic candidate performance over the past year. A whopping 56 Republican House incumbents raised less money than their Democratic challengers during the second quarter, along with 16 congressmen with less cash on hand than their Democratic opponents.

"This is the manifestation of a larger problem—the massive enthusiasm gap," said one Republican consultant working on House races, granted anonymity to speak candidly. "Republicans and our outside groups are raising a lot of money, too, but we can no longer say or think we can rely on just our super PACs, because now Democrats have money as well. Everyone has money."

But the money is no guarantee of success. Amy McGrath, a former combat pilot who's challenging Rep. Andy Barr (R-Ky.), also caught fire online early by telling a compelling personal story in TV ads. Her first campaign video has received nearly 2 million views on YouTube, and public polling shows the first-time candidate jumped ahead in public polling.

However, CLF aired TV ads featuring a clip of McGrath saying, "I don't know that I'm different than the Democratic Party nationally," then cut to a voter saying, "When I first saw Amy McGrath's ads, I thought she was a moderate, but now we know the truth."

CLF released a polling memo earlier this month, showing that an early lead built by McGrath had evaporated. (A recent poll conducted by The New York Times also shows a tied race.) "Now, 66 percent of voters see her as a liberal, compared to 39 percent in June," the CLF polling memo reads.

Title: West Hollywood Council Votes to Urge Removal of Donald Trump's Hollywood Walk of Fame Star

Article:

The West Hollywood City Council has voted unanimously to urge the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce to remove U.S. President Donald Trump's star from the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The vote, which took place on Monday evening, is largely symbolic as the council has no jurisdiction over the Walk of Fame, which is located in neighboring Hollywood.

The resolution, announced by West Hollywood Mayor John Duran, states that the man honored by the star does not reflect the values of West Hollywood, one of the country's most liberal corners. The resolution cites allegations by several women who claim that Trump sexually harassed them, which he has denied, and points out his policy of separating asylum-seeking migrant families at the U.S. border with Mexico, a policy that was recently scrapped.

The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce has never removed a star from the Walk of Fame, which honors celebrities from the entertainment industry. In a statement, Leron Gubler, the chamber president, said there are no plans to remove any stars from the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The council's request will be considered at the chamber's next meeting, he said.

Trump's star was added in 2007 in recognition of his television work prior to his entry into politics, including his hosting of the NBC show "The Apprentice" and his producing of the Miss Universe beauty pageants. The star has become the setting for various anti-Trump protests since Trump announced his presidential run in 2015, and has been vandalized twice by men with heavy tools, only to be swiftly repaired.

Title: Top 24 Politically Correct Moments of the Decade: A Review

Article:

The following is a list, in no particular order, of 24 notable instances of politically correct moments that have occurred in the last decade. These instances highlight various cultural, social, and educational trends that have emerged in response to perceived insensitivities and microaggressions.

1. A college diversity-training course taught that it was culturally insensitive to expect people to be on time, as "time may be considered fluid" in other cultures.
2. A piece in Everyday Feminism argued that the term "trigger warning" could be re-traumatizing for individuals who have experienced military, police, or other forms of violence, and suggested using "content warning" instead.
3. A Brooklyn College of City University of New York professor was accused of sexual harassment for stating that effort was 10 percent of the grade.
4. A campus survey included a trigger warning to caution college students that it may contain "anatomical names of body parts."
5. University researchers demanded that people accept those who "identify as real vampires" to prevent anti-vampire discrimination.
6. A Seattle-area councilman was concerned about the city hosing poop off of its sidewalks because he thought that it might seem too racially insensitive.
7. A bathing-suit advertisement was criticized for being "sexist" because it depicted a woman in a bathing suit.
8. Some feminists decided that "pussyhats" were both racist and transphobic, due to the fact that not all women have vaginas, and not all vaginas are pink.
9. A professor claimed that the small chairs in preschools are sexist, "disempowering," and "problematic."
10. College students decided against bringing a camel to school for a "Hump Day" event, due to concerns about racism.
11. A school in Seattle reportedly insisted that Easter eggs be called "spring spheres."
12. A group of Berkeley students insisted that they could not take their in-class exam due to their lack of privilege.
13. The phrase "long time, no see" was reportedly declared to be "derogatory" toward Asians.
14. A college newspaper changed its name from "The Bullet" because its editors were concerned that that name was too dangerous.
15. Lecturers were warned that capital letters might scare students and that they should avoid using them.
16. A campus-wide email told white students to stop wearing hooped earrings, because doing so was cultural appropriation.
17. A campus Christian club was found guilty of discrimination for requiring its leaders to be Christians.
18. Oxford University law students were told that they didn't have to learn about rape or violence law if they found it too triggering.
19. Undergraduate law students were reportedly allowed to leave during any lessons about such material if they felt uncomfortable.
20. A liberal author demanded that "normal people" avoid wearing any kind of red hat, because all red hats can be too scary.
21. A piece in The New York Times argued that the adverb "very" has "deprived" "most women" "of self-satisfaction and appreciation."
22. A liberal author demanded that "normal people" avoid wearing any kind of red hat, because all red hats can be too scary.
23. Evergreen State University told professors to take student protesters' feelings into account when grading them.
24. Several colleges and universities either canceled or adapted performances of The Vagina Monologues over concerns about excluding women without vaginas or due to the fact that a white lady wrote it. One school, Southwestern University in Texas, canceled theirs for another reason: because a white lady wrote it.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya in Response to Execution of Coptic Christians

Article:

Egypt has launched a series of airstrikes against Islamic State (ISIS) targets in Libya in response to the execution of 21 Coptic Christian citizens by the extremist group. The airstrikes, announced on state radio on Monday, targeted ISIS's weapons caches, training grounds, and camps in Libya.

The airstrikes were described as a means of "avenge[ing] the bloodshed and to seek retribution from the killers." Egyptian President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi vowed revenge for the execution, which was captured in a five-minute propaganda video released on Sunday.

In the video, the Coptic Christians from Egypt are paraded onto a beach, each accompanied by a masked jihadist. They are then forced to kneel as one jihadist addresses the camera in English. "All crusaders: safety for you will be only wishes, especially if you are fighting us all together," he says. "Therefore we will fight you all together."

The Egyptians are then forced to lay face-down in the sand and are simultaneously beheaded. The same jihadist speaker then points to the sea and says, "We will conquer Rome, by Allah's permission."

The men were not in Libya to fight ISIS. Rather, they were in the country to make a living when they were kidnapped in two separate incidents in December and January from the city of Sirte.

In addition to Egypt's airstrikes, Libya's air force also carried out its own airstrikes in the eastern city of Darna, which an ISIS affiliate took over last year. According to Libyan air force commander Saqer al-Joroushi, there were casualties among individuals, ammunition, and ISIS communication centers. He also reported that roughly 40 to 50 militants were killed.

Further airstrikes are planned for today and tomorrow in coordination with Egypt, according to al-Joroushi. The Associated Press reports that Egypt has already carried out a second wave of airstrikes in Darna.

Title: Covington Catholic Student Nick Sandmann Defends Actions During Controversial Confrontation

Article:

In an interview with NBC's "Today," Nick Sandmann, the Covington Catholic High School student at the center of a controversial confrontation with Native American activist Nathan Phillips, defended his actions during the incident.

According to Sandmann, both he and Phillips were exercising their First Amendment rights during the confrontation that took place on Friday. Videos from the incident show that another protest group, the Black Hebrew Israelites, had been taunting the Covington Catholic students. Phillips and his group approached the boys, stopping in front of Sandmann.

Sandmann stated that the students had received permission from chaperones to shout school chants to drown out the insults from the Black Hebrew Israelites. He felt threatened, despite being in a much larger group, as the protesters were adults, and he "wasn't sure what was going to happen."

"In hindsight, I wish we had just found another spot to wait for our buses, but at the time, being positive seemed better than letting them slander us with all of these things," Sandmann said.

In other interviews, Phillips explained that he went toward the boys to defuse what he saw as a tense situation between the Black Hebrew Israelites and the students.

Sandmann also stated that his group should have walked away once the Native American activists came to them, but he "didn't want to be disrespectful to Mr. Phillips" if he was trying to have a conversation.

Sandmann, who can be seen staring back at Phillips with what some have described as a smirk in the videos, said he was not intending to be disrespectful. In his view, he was trying to show that he wouldn't be moved to "any further reaction of aggression."

"As far as standing there, I had every right to do so," he said. "I can't say that I'm sorry for listening to him and standing there."

Phillips, who has done several interviews since the incident went viral, disputes Sandmann's version of events. He contends that Sandmann locked eyes with him and approached him.

"I have read the statement from Nick Sandmann, the student who stared at me for a long time. He did not apologize, and I believe there are intentional falsehoods in his testimony," Phillips said.

Covington Catholic High, an all-boys school, closed on Tuesday for safety reasons and reopened on Wednesday, although parents do not have to send their sons to school for the time being. The details of the school's reopening plan were not available in the provided text.

Title: Nepal's Muslim Community Faces Rise in Islamophobia Amid Indian Hindu Nationalist Agenda

Article:

Nepal, a country with a Muslim population of approximately 4 percent, has historically maintained peaceful coexistence with its Hindu majority. However, recent events suggest a rise in Islamophobia, allegedly fueled by India's Hindu nationalist fundamentalists and Islamophobic media.

The Indian government's shift towards Hindu nationalism, under Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and his association with the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh organization, has reportedly strengthened the New Delhi establishment's efforts to remake Nepal as a predominantly Hindu nation. In 2006, Nepal became a secular country after the ousting of the old constitutional monarchy, aided by a more secular Indian government that helped former Maoist rebels to a peace deal and into mainstream politics.

However, the spread of Islamophobia in Nepal has been facilitated by the large number of Hindi speakers and the wide range of Indian TV available. A series of incidents in April 2021, exacerbated by yellow journalism in Nepal, have led to the rapid spread of nasty rumors.

On April 16, a few rupee bills were found scattered in Janakpur, southern Nepal. A claim that two Muslim women had scattered the bills after spitting on them spread quickly, based on a CCTV video that showed the bills dropping out of their pockets. Islamophobic posts claiming the women had deliberately spit on the bills to spread the coronavirus went viral.

The police tested the two women for COVID-19, and the initial quick test produced a positive result from one of the women. This sparked further hateful posts, but it later turned out that the test had been wrong, and further testing gave negative results. In reality, the two women had just returned from the bank and had dropped the notes accidentally.

A week earlier, on April 10, India's right-wing media, particularly Hindi news channels, circulated sensationalized news that Pakistan might have sent coronavirus-infected Muslim men to India via Nepal. They coined a new term: "corona-jihad." The claims were based on an unverified and largely unsourced report sent by the state of Bihar to the Indian Home Ministry, which included false claims that Jalim Miya, a Muslim politician in Nepal, was behind the supposed plot and that the group of men were taking paracetamol to suppress their fevers and pass undetected. Miya explained exasperatedly that there was no such plot and was backed by Nepal's central government.

Nepal's Muslims are concerned about the rise in Islamophobia but hope their friends and neighbors will stop things from getting worse. They point to the failure of the 1992 riots around the destruction of the Babri Masjid, a mosque built on a site also revered by Hindus in Ayodhya, India, to spread over the border. However, there has been a steady rise in attacks against Nepali Muslims on social media. The majority of Nepalis, however, continue to reject the attempts to whip up hatred, and there have been no reported physical assaults on Muslims.

Hajji Abdullah Miya, a former member of the Hajj Committee of Nepal, told a local media outlet, "Especially after the rise of Modi, the attitude towards Muslims in India has changed. In any case, the general tendency to portray Muslims negatively is old in India. India used to spread rumors against the Muslims of Nepal to create animosity with the Indian Muslims. Whether in the name of mosques and madrassas in the Terai border region or on other issues, India has always attacked Nepali Muslims."

As Nepal continues to grapple with the COVID-19 pandemic, the Hindu nationalist agenda from India is likely to persist. The hashtag #RIPIndianMedia trended in Nepal, reflecting the damage done to the image of Indian media in the country. Yet, even Nepali journalists, online news portals, and the public have engaged in Islamophobic posts and tweets, contributing to the viral spread of #IslamophobiaInNepal.

Title: Kashmiri Boy's Death Acknowledged Four Months After Abrogation of Article 370

Article:

In Indian-administered Kashmir, the family of 17-year-old Osaib Altaf Marazi, who was found dead in the Jhelum river on August 5, 2019, has struggled for five months to prove his death and secure a death certificate. Osaib's death was the first reported in the wake of the abrogation of Article 370 of the Indian constitution, which granted special status to the Muslim-majority region.

On the day of the abrogation, roads across Kashmir were blocked, and checkpoints manned by Indian paramilitary forces were set up. A tense atmosphere descended upon the region as phone networks, internet services, and TV channels were blocked to prevent Kashmiris from protesting against New Delhi's decision to scrap Kashmir's limited autonomy.

Osaib's older brother, Suhail Ahmad Marazi, was not home on August 5. He later gathered witness accounts of what happened to his brother in the moments before his death. According to Suhail, Osaib was with his friends and together they walked a short distance from their home in Palpora village on the outskirts of Srinagar when they were surrounded by paramilitary forces.

"They were 10 boys. As they reached the middle of a footbridge, they saw CRPF personnel running after them from both sides. They were scared and jumped into the river," Suhail told ███. "The other boys who were present at the spot told us that Osaib held onto the edge of the bridge for a few seconds before the armed men hit him with a stick on his head and hands and he slipped into the waters."

At home, Saleema was doing chores when boys from the neighborhood came running and knocked at her window. "They said Osaib had been martyred," Saleema recalled, overcome by emotion. "I wait for him every day and call his name every time when I serve the dinner. He was afraid to sleep alone."

Osaib's body was handed over to the family for burial, but the hospital refused to issue a death certificate. Officials at Shri Maharaja Hari Singh hospital in Srinagar asked the Marazi family for a First Information Report (FIR), a police complaint, to certify Osaib's death.

"From the hospital, I went to one police station and then another, and both said that they will not be able to register the FIR as the area does not come under their jurisdiction," Suhail said. "It was a helpless situation."

In September, after two child rights activists, Enakshi Ganguly and Shanta Sinha, filed a petition in India's Supreme Court to investigate cases of rights violations involving children in Kashmir, the court tasked the juvenile justice committee with investigating cases involving minors who were being detained in the region.

In the midst of their struggle to prove Osaib's death, his family was shocked by a written submission by police to the juvenile justice committee admitting that they had detained 144 minors.

"Osaib Altaf, the incident as reported has been found to be baseless as no such death has been reported to the police authorities as per verification report received from the field formations," the police report said.

The family then approached the lower court to request the FIR. "We approached the court because how can they deny our child's death?" Suhail Marazi said. "While we were mourning at home, every week we had to go to the court as well."

Last month, the police finally submitted a report to the court admitting Osaib's death by drowning. "It is prayed that on 05-08-2019, the deceased Osaib Marazi aged about 24 years allegedly drowned in river Jhelum," said the status report submitted by the Parimpora police station to the court. Osaib's school records show he was 17, not "about 24" as the police claimed. He was a grade 12 student at a local school.

"No one gets justice here, and we do not hope for it either. But we want that we should be provided the death certificate," said Suhail, adding that they will continue to fight for the certificate. "Our neighbor Danish was killed the same way in 2016, and even they did not get any justice. They [the police] have found a new way to kill children in Kashmir."

Authorities in Kashmir, who now come directly under India's interior ministry, have denied any killings took place in the wake of the August 5 decision. However, local human rights group Jammu and Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society (JKCCS) said, in its 2019 human rights review, that six civilians had been killed by the Indian armed forces.

One of the civilians was 17-year-old Asrar Firdous Khan from Soura, Srinagar, who was playing cricket with his friends on August 6 when soldiers shot him in the head several times with pellets, according to his family. Asrar's medical records showed his death occurred due to pellet injuries to his skull, but the police refuted that, saying he was killed when a stone was thrown at him. The police did not specify who threw the stone.

While Osaib's family continues to struggle for acknowledgement of his death, Saleema struggles with her pain and longing. "I want to tear my heart open to find my son. It seems the light of my eyes has gone away."

Title: Clinton Campaign Denies Access to Print Pool Reporter, Stirring Transparency Concerns

The Hillary Clinton campaign has faced criticism for denying access to a print pool reporter on Monday, reigniting concerns about the campaign's commitment to transparency. David Martosko, the U.S. political editor for London's Daily Mail, was denied access to the campaign's events in New Hampshire.

Martosko reported arriving at the campaign's breakfast stop only to be told he would not be allowed to pool the day's events. Pool reporters are responsible for sending reports from the trail to the rest of the press corps. According to Martosko, he was told, "So I'm afraid it's a no. You're not on the list."

When asked if the print pooler was being prohibited from getting on either of the pool vans, the campaign's press aide replied, "I'm afraid that's right." When asked why, she responded, "All I know is what Harrell has told me. I got an email saying the print pooler would be changed for today. Sorry."

Denied a ride in the pool van, Martosko decided to drive to the first campaign stop in Rochester on his own. However, he was not admitted to the event's location, the YMCA of Strafford County, despite being sent back multiple times. It is unclear who denied him entry, but it is reported that the head of Clinton's Secret Service detail expressed disapproval upon learning of Martosko's presence.

The Clinton campaign has not responded to requests for comment regarding the incident. The campaign's traveling press secretary, Nick Merrill, provided an explanation to Martosko, who relayed it in a report on The Daily Mail's website. Merrill stated that the campaign's position is that the Daily Mail does not qualify because it has not yet been added to the White House's regular print pool.

Merrill added that the campaign is "trying to follow the same process and system the White House has." He also stated that the decision had "nothing to do" with the campaign considering the Daily Mail foreign press and that the campaign does not consider the Daily Mail foreign press.

The Clinton campaign has not commented further on the incident, but Merrill later insisted that his reasons were not based on the foreign-press question, but that the campaign simply wanted a day to "have a conversation" about how to proceed. The campaign stated that they are working to create an equitable system and have had concerns expressed by foreign outlets about not being a part of the rotation.

Title: Fox News Analyst Discusses Shift in Mueller Investigation Focus to Clinton Campaign

Article:

On Tuesday, during Fox News Channel's "Tucker Carlson Tonight," network senior political contributor Brit Hume reacted to Tucker Carlson's earlier report suggesting that the investigation by special counsel Robert Mueller has expanded to include elements of Hillary Clinton's campaign and Donald Trump's 2016 presidential opponent. Hume stated that this could change the focus and character of the probe, potentially implicating long-time Washington, D.C. Democrats.

Carlson questioned Hume about the implications of Paul Manafort's work for the Podesta Group, representing Russian interests before joining the Trump campaign. Hume noted that the Podesta brothers, Tony and John, are central figures in the Democratic Party and Clinton's political endeavors.

Carlson expressed surprise that, despite Manafort's work for the Podesta Group, this connection had not been discovered by other news organizations during the past 11 months. Hume suggested that the quality of journalism may have been a factor in this oversight, as well as the journalists' focus on a specific storyline.

Hume also discussed the broadened scope of Mueller's investigation, which is now reportedly investigating the extent and depth of Russian efforts to influence American policy for several years. He noted that if the information about the Podestas is accurate, it could be disappointing for Democrats, who have been vocal about Russian interference in the election.

Carlson and Hume also discussed the Uranium One matter, suggesting that the Obama administration's efforts to seek a closer relationship with Russia may have put American security at risk. They also mentioned that the information comprising the now-famous dossier, which was published by BuzzFeed, was reportedly paid for by the Democratic National Committee and the Hillary Clinton presidential campaign.

Hume concluded that the tide may be turning in the political and journalistic landscape, as more information about the Clinton campaign's connections to Russia comes to light. He also expressed concern for the Podestas in light of these revelations.

Title: Sanders, Buttigieg, and Warren Lead in New Hampshire Primary; Biden, Warren Face Challenges

Article:

In the New Hampshire primary, Bernie Sanders emerged as the winner, bolstered by strong performances in the state's largest cities. He led his main rivals in Manchester by over 2,000 votes, and in Concord and Nashua by 500 votes each. Pete Buttigieg performed well in communities south of Manchester, in Boston suburbs, and in college towns such as Hanover, home of Dartmouth College.

Joe Biden, who was once the national front-runner, finished fourth in Iowa and fifth in New Hampshire. Elizabeth Warren, the neighboring state's senator who claimed almost a third of the Democratic vote in an October poll, edged out Biden for fourth place by less than a percentage point.

Sanders, who garnered more than a third of the votes among those who preferred a candidate who agreed with them on major issues, and three times as many votes among those who supported replacing America's health care system with a single-payer plan, now faces an 11-day slog to the next contest in Nevada and an 18-day wait for the South Carolina primary. Both Sanders and Warren will have to convince donors and supporters they can regroup and rebuild their campaigns to secure a win.

There were troubling signs for both Biden and Warren in Tuesday's outcome. Warren, who is known for her detailed policy plans, struggled among those who prioritized electability over plans. Among the 33% of voters who preferred a candidate who agreed with them on major issues, more than a third chose Sanders, and only a small fraction chose Warren. Among the three in five voters who supported replacing America's health care system with a single-payer plan, three times as many chose Sanders over Warren.

Both Biden and Warren took steps Tuesday to distance themselves from the New Hampshire results, even before the polls closed. Warren stayed in New Hampshire to concede, offering kind words to Amy Klobuchar and pledging to fight on. In a memo to supporters, Warren campaign manager Roger Lau wrote that Warren's candidate remains "the consensus choice of the widest coalition of Democrats in every corner of the country." He stated that Warren's formidable campaign organization was poised to win delegates across most of the states and districts that will vote on Super Tuesday, and that her ceiling is higher than Biden's, Sanders's, or Buttigieg's.

Each campaign will now have to convince its chief supporters that its candidate still has a path to the 1,990 delegates necessary to win the convention. Without the support necessary to sustain national field organizations and seven-figure television budgets, any candidate's campaign withers and dies; when a candidate loses or falls short of expectations, those financial problems mount even more rapidly.

Warren, too, faces the challenge of breaking through for the first time. She does not lead in polls in Nevada, South Carolina, or most Super Tuesday states—the last poll she led was an October WBUR-MassInc survey of her home state's voters—and it is unclear where she will secure her first win.

"The road to the Democratic nomination is not paved with statewide winner-take-all victories. This is not a race for governor, the U.S. Senate, or the state treasurer's office," Lau wrote in his memo. "This is a district-by-district contest for pledged delegates awarded proportionally."

Title: The Evolution of Census-Taking: From Ancient Arrowheads to Modern Data Collection

Article:

The United States is currently conducting its population census, a once-a-decade effort to count every individual residing within its borders. Over 150 other countries will join in this world census round, centered on 2020, with around 90 percent of the world's population already counted.

While the modern census may seem unspectacular in terms of technology, the American questionnaire asks just seven questions of each person, with a few additional questions for each household as a whole. This amounts to approximately 45 GB of data for the entire U.S. population, a volume that could be carried on a base model iPhone 11 if it weren't for the strict confidentiality.

The challenges of this year's census are significant, but they are social, political, logistical, and now public-health related, rather than strictly technological or scientific. However, census-taking was not always this straightforward. For centuries, counting its people was one of the most technologically complex procedures a state could undertake.

Census-taking likely arose independently in many places, and it is not possible to point to a first census. Although writing is now integral to data recording, analysis, and reporting, census-taking certainly predated it. An early example can be found in the story of the Scythians, nomadic warriors who lived in Central Asia in the first millennium BCE. To count his people, their king, Ariantas, had each Scythian bring an arrowhead. The number of arrowheads was then counted to determine the population size.

Proto-literate societies could conduct censuses of great complexity. The Inca, who dominated Andean America at the time of the Spanish conquest in the 15th century CE, recorded elaborate census statistics in connection with taxation, despite lacking what we would recognize as writing. Instead, they used knots tied in complex bundles of colored strings called khipu to encode information. Of the thousand khipu that exist in museums today, two-thirds contain numerical data, and at least 50 are thought to pertain to censuses.

The most important ancient census, from a modern perspective, was surely that of Rome. Romans adopted the census late in the city's regal period, shortly before the more familiar republic was declared in 509 BCE. They gave the procedure the name we now use (from the Latin cēnsēre, "to assess") and made it fundamental to their social order. The censors, the officeholders who conducted the census, determined each Roman citizen's position in an elaborate class hierarchy. This, in turn, dictated how that citizen and his family lived, how he could dress, how the law treated him, and how he could exercise political power. In principle, this stratification of Roman society was performed every five years. Each head of household would be called upon, in turn, to make his declaration. He would give his full name, that of his father—or patron, in the case of a freed slave—and his age. He would report his marital status and, if applicable, the name of his wife and the number, names, and ages of his children. He would then move on to an account of his property. This would proceed by tribe until it was complete. The censors were appointed for an 18-month term, and sheer logistics suggest the count must have taken most of this time.

Title: Secret Service Lapses in White House Security: A Look at Recent Incidents and Their Implications

Article:

Two incidents of security lapses at the White House have come to light, raising concerns about the effectiveness of the Secret Service in protecting the President and his family.

In a recent incident, an intruder, Omar J. Gonzalez, managed to breach the White House security on September 19, 2014.
