According to a report by The Washington Post, a plainclothes surveillance team tasked with preventing such incidents failed to notice Gonzalez. The attack dog that was supposed to be released did not respond, and the front door of the White House was left unlocked. An alarm box at the entrance was muted due to its annoyance to the usher's staff who work nearby. The agent who eventually tackled Gonzalez was off-duty and happened to be in the vicinity at the time. The first family was not in the building at the time of the incident.

In a 2011 incident, a man named Oscar Ortega-Hernandez parked his car about 700 yards from the White House and fired a semiautomatic weapon into the upstairs residence area. One of the Obama's daughters was home at the time. Some Secret Service officers thought there might have been an attack, but their supervisor decided it was just backfire from a vehicle and ordered them to stand down. It took four days for the Secret Service to understand that there was an armed attack, and only after a housekeeper discovered broken glass and chipped cement. The public and Congress were never properly informed.

The President and First Lady, Michelle Obama, were reportedly furious when they were told of the incident several days later. Several lawmakers noted at the hearing that the damage could have been unimaginably bad if the attackers had been organized terrorists rather than deranged individuals. Considering that President Obama has received three times the number of threats as his predecessors, there should be greater security for this White House.

The budget and size of the Secret Service have fallen in the last few years. In 2011, the agency had about 6,900 staff positions; it now has about 6,600. Its budget fell from $1.9 billion in 2012 to $1.8 billion in 2013, in part because of automatic cuts demanded by Congress, and it has gone up only slightly since then. Though money cannot be the only reason for these errors, people inside the agency say the cuts have led to staff burnout, low morale, and unmonitored posts.

President Obama now has to decide whether Secret Service Director Julia Pierson is capable of protecting him and his family, as well as the nation's reputation. However, at a minimum, he has to insist on an independent, top-to-bottom review of the Secret Service, not one conducted by officials trying to protect themselves or their agency.

Title: California Bill to Limit Vaccine Exemptions Advances, Sparks Debate on Individual Rights

Article:

A bill in California that would restrict vaccine exemptions for students to only those with a valid medical reason has moved a step closer to becoming law, though it still faces several hurdles. The bill was introduced in response to a measles outbreak linked to nearly 150 infections traced back to Disneyland in late December.

Outside the Capitol building in Sacramento on Wednesday, the bill sparked a debate between supporters and opponents, with both sides expressing concerns about individual rights and responsibilities. Opponents, some wearing American flags, argued that eliminating the personal belief exemption infringes on their ability to make decisions that are best for their children.

Lisa Cadrein of Los Angeles, an opponent of the bill, expressed fears that vaccines could harm her daughter. "I am afraid that her big beautiful blue eyes will not focus on me anymore, and she won't be the kid that she is," Cadrein said.

However, scientific studies show no link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorder. Inside the hearing, parents also discussed the importance of protecting their children from those who are not vaccinated.

Democratic Sen. Lois Wolk, a member of the Senate Health Committee, spoke in favor of the pro-vaccine parents. "Our individual rights are not without limits, and in this particular case, your insistence on your right really could harm my children or my grandchildren," Wolk said.

The health committee in California's Senate passed the bill 6-2 on Wednesday. The proposed legislation still has many more hearings before it could become law. Similar legislation to limit families' rights to opt out of mandatory vaccinations has been considered in Washington, Oregon, and North Carolina, but all efforts have stalled so far.

This story is part of NPR's reporting partnership with Capital Public Radio and Kaiser Health News.

Title: White House Press Secretary Advocates for School Reopening, Cites Study on COVID-19 Risk in Children

Article:

White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany has asserted that "the science is on our side" in support of President Donald Trump's push for the physical reopening of schools amid coronavirus concerns. During a press briefing on Thursday, McEnany argued that the risk of critical illness due to the novel coronavirus for children is "far less" than the seasonal flu, citing a study published by JAMA Pediatrics.

McEnany stated that the "science should not stand in the way" of schools reopening, a remark she later claimed had been taken out of context by the media. Trump has been vocal about advocating for schools to physically reopen over the past week, threatening funding to schools and stating he would put pressure on governors to reopen schools in their states.

Health experts have pointed to the risk of children contributing to the spread of the coronavirus. A number of school districts have moved forward with plans that incorporate virtual learning in the fall to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19, including public schools in Richmond, Va., which announced Wednesday they would have full virtual learning in the fall.

McEnany argued that the physical reopening of schools is essential for the wellbeing of students and their parents, citing potential issues such as a lack of reporting of abuse, mental depression, and suicidal ideations when students are not in school.

Trump has forcefully advocated for schools to reopen, arguing that the risk to children remains low. Last week, he stated, "We’re going to be putting a lot of pressure on: Open your schools in the fall." Trump has praised Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis for directing schools to reopen in the fall, despite a large surge in coronavirus cases in the state.

The study cited by McEnany on Thursday found that "severe illness in children is significant but far less frequent than in adults" and that preexisting medical conditions seem to be an "important factor" with respect to children who contract the disease.

Trump has been accused of eschewing the advice of public health experts, including by Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan, who penned a scathing op-ed criticizing the president's response to the coronavirus on Thursday. Trump last week criticized the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines for reopening schools as "very tough" and "expensive."

Title: The New York Times Acknowledges Cautious Approach in 2016 Report on FBI's Trump-Russia Investigation

Article:

The New York Times has issued a correction to a 2016 article regarding the origins of the FBI's investigation into potential links between the Trump campaign and the Russian government. The original article, published on October 31, 2016, was cautious in its language and downplayed the case due to law enforcement officials' advice.

In the closing weeks of the 2016 presidential campaign, The New York Times reporters were informed by law enforcement officials that the FBI had scrutinized some of Donald Trump's advisers but found no proof of any involvement with Russian hacking. The resulting article reflected this caution and stated that agents had uncovered no "conclusive or direct link between Mr. Trump and the Russian government."

The key fact of the article—that the FBI had opened a broad investigation into possible links between the Russian government and the Trump campaign—was published in the 10th paragraph. The article's tone and headline, "Investigating Donald Trump, F.B.I. Sees No Clear Link to Russia," gave an air of finality to an investigation that was just beginning.

The Times disclosed in the middle of the updated article that during the 2016 probe, dubbed "Crossfire Hurricane," at least one government informant met several times with two Trump campaign aides, Carter Page and George Papadopoulos. This has become a contentious point, with Mr. Trump's allies questioning whether the FBI was spying on the Trump campaign or trying to entrap campaign officials.

President Trump tweeted yesterday that if it's true, "this is bigger than Watergate!"

The paper's portrayal of the FBI's judgments—and even misjudgments—is sympathetic. The FBI was aggressive in the Hillary Clinton investigation, with James Comey discussing the probe and later its reopening, because everyone there thought she would win and they might be criticized for going soft on her. The FBI was cautious on Trump because everyone thought he would lose.

In the Times narrative, the FBI was just starting to scrutinize possible links between Trump associates and Russia and did not have enough evidence to go public. Beyond that, "anything the FBI did publicly would only give fodder to Mr. Trump's claims on the campaign trail that the election was rigged."

Trump yesterday linked to a National Review piece by Andrew McCarthy, who argued that the paper's analysis was "bunk." He said the Hillary probe was a criminal investigation involving her email server, while Trump was subjected to a counterintelligence probe in the hope of turning up evidence to use against him.

The extent of the FBI's knowledge and actions during the Trump investigation is still a matter of debate, with some viewing it as a quiet, diligent investigation, while others see a bogus investigation that unfairly put Robert Mueller on Trump's trail.

Title: Hillary Clinton Makes History as First Female Presidential Nominee of a Major U.S. Party

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the wife of former President Bill Clinton, made history on Thursday as the first woman to accept the presidential nomination of a major U.S. political party at the 2016 Democratic National Convention. The theme of the evening was "Stronger Together," and Clinton's speech focused on differentiating herself from her rival, Donald Trump, in terms of foreign policy and economic leadership.

Clinton's speech largely avoided topics such as faith, religious liberty, and abortion, but she did mention her Methodist faith and referenced her mother's admonition to "do all the good you can, for all the people you can, in all the ways you can, as long as ever you can."

Chelsea Clinton, Hillary's daughter, also made history as the child of two presidential candidates from the same party. In her speech, Chelsea expressed her pride in her mother and gratitude for being her daughter.

Hillary Clinton's focus during her speech was to unite the party and appease supporters of her former opponent, Bernie Sanders. She praised President Barack Obama and affirmed her support for his legacy. Clinton also took aim at Donald Trump, criticizing his campaign and presenting her own vision for the country.

Trump, in turn, took to Twitter to criticize Clinton, stating that "no one has worse judgment than Hillary Clinton - corruption and devastation follows her wherever she goes."

Clinton made multiple promises throughout her nearly one-hour speech, including her plan to support local forces in taking out ISIS, creating more good jobs with rising wages in the United States, and working with Sen. Bernie Sanders on education. She also promised to make college tuition free for the middle class and debt-free for all, and to liberate millions of people who already have student debt.

Clinton also addressed foreign policy, attacking Trump's ability to handle complicated foreign affairs and promising to provide the necessary leadership. She ended the night on a note of promise for the future, telling Americans, "We are stronger together."

Title: Theresa May's Third Brexit Defeat Marks a Shift in Strategy Amidst Looming Deadline

Article:

Britain finds itself in a precarious yet opportunity-filled situation following Theresa May's third consecutive Brexit defeat in the House of Commons on Friday. The margin of defeat was significantly smaller than the previous two on January 15 and March 12, with a majority of 58 votes rather than the previous 230 and 149. This latest defeat primarily concerned the withdrawal agreement portion of the EU-UK deal, rather than the deal in its entirety.

In essence, this was, in all but name, the third "meaningful vote" on the Brexit deal this year, with all three resulting in the same outcome. In her comments following the latest defeat, Prime Minister May seemed to leave open the possibility of a fourth attempt. However, this would be unprecedented, as the limit for such attempts has arguably been reached.

One reason for May's persistence in putting the deal before parliament multiple times was to maintain some semblance of the Brexit process. The date set by May two years ago for Britain's departure from the EU was March 29. Her repeated misjudgments, including her refusal to engage with remain supporters and the loss of her majority in 2017, meant that the deadline was not met. However, May was attempting to demonstrate to leave voters that, despite obstacles, it was not her who was obstructing Brexit. With a pro-leave crowd outside parliament, May was trying to shift the blame onto Labour and her own hardliners.

The attorney general, in the beginning of the debate, stated that the primary reason for trying again was procedural. May needed to get her deal through in order to move back the latest Brexit deadline from April 12 to May 22. This might have allowed time for the final tranche of withdrawal legislation to pass without the UK becoming involved in the European parliament elections. However, with the current state of affairs, this is unlikely to occur. Britain now faces a choice between a no-deal exit in two weeks or a much longer delay to Brexit, during which the UK will probably participate in the EU elections.

May also had more partisan reasons. The revolt by MPs last Monday, in which they took control of parliament from the government, opened up the possibility that opposition MPs and pro-European Tories might soften the deal, revoke article 50, or insist on a second referendum. Many Conservative MPs were alarmed by this prospect. With May also promising to step down if her deal was adopted, more than 40 of her MPs switched to support a deal they had previously rejected. This was to no avail, but Downing Street seems to have calculated that it should bank these switchers in order to make things easier for the deal if they try a fourth time.

However, a fourth attempt now seems unlikely. May's defeat has cleared the way for a different approach. This week's indicative votes are unfinished business, with new versions to be presented to MPs on Monday. The movers have learned from their defeats, something May seems incapable of doing. Two propositions – in favor of a customs union and for a second referendum on the final deal – are very much in play. If the Commons can rally behind these, the EU summit on April 10 should be asked to grant the UK a longer extension of article 50 to cement a different form of deal, with a public vote on it at the end.

It is ironic that May's third defeat may have finally created space for a very different approach from the one she has followed for three years.

Title: Report Alleges Labor Secretary Nominee Thomas Perez Made "Quid Pro Quo" Deal with St. Paul Leaders

Article:

A congressional Republican report has alleged that Labor Secretary nominee Thomas Perez, in his previous role as Assistant Attorney General, made a "quid pro quo" deal with leaders of the Minnesota city of St. Paul in 2012. The deal, according to the report, involved dropping a contentious lawsuit in exchange for the Justice Department staying out of whistleblower cases brought against the city.

The report, obtained in advance by Fox News, claims Perez "manipulated" federal law and "pushed the limits of justice to make this deal happen." The allegations could impact Perez's pending confirmation hearing, scheduled for this Thursday.

The report, titled "How Assistant Attorney General Thomas Perez Manipulated Justice and Ignored Rule of Law," is a joint effort by minority leaders of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Republican-led House's Judiciary and Oversight and Government Reform committees.

The report states that the Justice Department's decision to opt out of the whistleblower cases potentially cost taxpayers as much as $200 million—the amount the government could have won had it pursued damages in the case. The other end of the alleged deal was for the Justice Department not to get involved in cases against the city of St. Paul that alleged the city received millions in Department of Housing and Urban Development funds but failed to file the requisite paperwork regarding the hiring of low-income workers.

The report also alleges that Perez's actions were motivated by a concern that the Supreme Court would strike down a major element of civil rights enforcement if it reviewed a case involving St. Paul's appeal to the Supreme Court, on a case in which property owners said the city made extraordinary efforts, through strict code enforcement, to condemn their properties. The owners said reducing the amount of affordable housing for minorities violated the federal Fair Housing Act—by what is known as "disparate impact."

The "disparate impact" provision, which the report described as legally questionable, prohibits housing policies that end up discriminating against certain groups even if those policies are not blatantly discriminatory.

Congressional Democrats have disputed the allegations, putting out a statement and memo of their own late Sunday refuting the details. The statement said the "overwhelming evidence" indicates Perez and others "acted professionally to advance the interests of civil rights and effectively combat the scourge of discrimination in housing." They said the decision not to intervene in the suit against St. Paul was based on expert recommendations.

The Justice Department has also disputed the allegations, claiming that the department held three staff briefings, heard 24 hours of additional testimony, and reviewed 1,400 pages of documents before deciding not to intervene. The department maintains that the litigation decisions made by the department were in the best interests of the United States and were consistent with the department's legal, ethical, and professional responsibility obligations.

Title: Partisanship and Intelligence Agencies: A Historical Perspective on the Debate over FBI and CIA's Role in the Russia Probe

Article:

The recent debate over the appropriateness of scrutinizing the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in the origins of the Russia probe has been met with polarized opinions, reflecting a long-standing partisan divide in the United States. This article provides a historical perspective on the evolving relationship between politics and intelligence agencies in the U.S.

Before the upheaval of the late 1960s and early 1970s, there was a time when many Americans held unquestioning faith in federal law-enforcement agencies. However, this faith has since been eroded, and the notion that the intelligence community is above politics has become outdated. The intelligence community's role has always been a matter of politics by other means, as demonstrated by the events of the past few decades.

Attorney General William Barr's decision to launch an investigation into the origins of the Russia investigation has sparked controversy, with Democrats expressing concern about what they perceive as an attempt to shift the narrative from Trump's alleged collusion with Russia to an unprecedented probe of a presidential campaign. The investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller failed to prove the collusion allegations, and Barr's attempt to determine whether the probe was an abuse of power is seen as a reasonable course of action by some, but a significant problem for Democrats who are pursuing the impeachment of President Trump.

The debate has led to criticism from Democrats and Trump administration critics, with CNN crime-and-justice reporter Shimon Prokupecz stating that it is "troubling" that the Department of Justice is questioning the work of CIA agents. However, this criticism ignores the historical precedent of investigations into the activities of the intelligence community, particularly during the political ferment of the 1970s and '80s, when congressional committees led by Democrats such as Frank Church and Otis Pike conducted far-reaching investigations that embarrassed the intelligence establishment.

In the past, it was Republicans defending the FBI and CIA against Democrats' charges that these agencies were out of control. However, since the summer of 2016, when the intelligence establishment seemed to join forces to raise alarms about Russian meddling in the presidential election and allegations of Trump-campaign collusion, Democrats have acted as if Langley and Quantico are beyond reproach. By contrast, Republicans who had been stalwart CIA and FBI defenders suddenly became bitter critics, demanding transparency and sometimes floating conspiracy theories about the intelligence community's activities.

Sensible people of either party will always seek to balance deference to the intelligence community's mission, which often requires a fair degree of secrecy, with an understanding that all government officials and agencies must be kept on a tight leash lest they abuse the power vested in them. The ongoing debate over the Russia probe serves as a reminder of the need for transparency and accountability in the intelligence community, and the importance of maintaining a healthy skepticism towards government agencies, regardless of political affiliation.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Pushes for Immigration Legislation, Despite Opposition

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner is persisting in his efforts to pass immigration legislation, despite opposition from some members of his own party and skepticism from Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell. Last week, rank-and-file House members sent a message that President Obama is not a reliable partner for legislation, causing concern among top proponents, including Paul Ryan.

Rep. Jeff Denham of California, who has met with Boehner on the issue, stated that immigration is part of the House Republican agenda and that no decisions have been made on whether to move forward. Boehner's office has released several documents outlining the GOP's principles on immigration, which include eliminating the ability for the administration to arbitrarily decide which laws to enforce.

Immigration advocates outside Congress have been relatively pleased with the principles and their reception by the GOP. Frank Sharry, founder and executive director of America's Voice and one of the nation's leading proponents for immigration reform, noted that few House Republican caucus members have publicly opposed the policy.

However, the push for immigration legislation is facing resistance from conservatives, causing significant doubt within Boehner's leadership team. GOP Whip Kevin McCarthy, who supports moving forward on the issue, is feeling the heat from his conservative district, which has a significant anti-amnesty sentiment. Meanwhile, Majority Leader Eric Cantor has put effort into a GOP version of the DREAM Act, but is keeping an eye on his right flank in case Boehner retires at the end of this Congress.

In response to Denham's claim that floor time has been scheduled for immigration bills, Cantor spokesman Rory Cooper stated, "There has been nothing scheduled as of now." Ryan, meanwhile, confirmed that he had met secretly with top Democrat Sen. Chuck Schumer on immigration but dismissed the importance of the session.

The issue is complicated, as some lawmakers who support the principles are not in favor of moving forward on legislation. In many cases, members only implied their stance on the underlying question rather than explicitly stating it. The result of a meeting among lawmakers on the issue seems to have changed Ryan's tone in the days afterward.

Conservative heavyweights like Reps. Tom Price and Jeb Hensarling have come out strongly against moving forward, and the result of the meeting seemed to change Ryan's tone in the days afterward. One conservative lawmaker warned Boehner that he is "out for a walk with nobody tagging along."

Rep. Tom Cotton, a freshman member running for Senate in Arkansas, stated that he does not anticipate legislation will come to the floor. Meanwhile, Sen. Marco Rubio, another Gang of Eight member, was more pessimistic, stating that the House should not move forward in 2014. Sen. Lindsey Graham, another Gang of Eight member, argued that Republicans can trust Obama to enforce any immigration bills they send him, as 80% of Americans want to secure the border, and the Democratic party would be politically damaged if they did not.

Title: Jeb Bush Raises Political Profile Amidst 2016 Presidential Speculation

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has been the center of political speculation as he voices his opinions on current issues, fueling rumors of a potential 2016 presidential run. On Monday, Bush appeared on NBC's "Today" show, discussing topics such as immigration reform, the 2013 sequester, and budget crises.

Bush, who has remained relatively quiet since his brother, former President George W. Bush, left the White House, has recently released a new book titled "Immigration Wars," outlining his stance on granting illegal immigrants legal status but not a pathway to citizenship. He is also a featured speaker at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) 2013, taking place in Washington from March 14 to 16.

During the interview with Matt Lauer, Bush expressed optimism about finding a consensus on immigration but emphasized the need to resolve budget matters to focus on immigration reform and energy policy. When asked about a potential 2016 run, Bush neither confirmed nor denied the speculation, stating, "That's way off into the future... I'm not going to declare it today either."

Another potential 2016 contender is Chris Christie, but CPAC organizers have reportedly snubbed the popular New Jersey governor, who gave the keynote address at the 2012 Republican National Convention. Bush expressed surprise at Christie's exclusion, attributing it to his handling of budget issues related to Hurricane Sandy and his criticism of House Republicans.

Bush clarified that CPAC's snub of Christie was not due to his public appearances with President Barack Obama after Hurricane Sandy or his criticism of House Republicans. Instead, Bush suggested the issue was the governor's advocacy for a $60 billion spending deal that was not directly related to Sandy recovery, with House Republicans eventually agreeing to funding for Sandy recovery.

Bush expressed his admiration for Christie, stating, "I think Gov. Christie is a part of the future of the Republican Party for sure, and whether he's going to CPAC or not is not really changing that."

Title: Mitt Romney and Donald Trump Engage in a Public Spat over Tax Returns

Article:

In a series of tweets on Thursday, former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney responded to a barrage of insults from Donald Trump, the current GOP frontrunner, regarding the latter's tax returns. The war of words between the two began on Wednesday during a Fox News interview, where Romney suggested that there might be something amiss in Trump's tax returns.

"We're now, you know, in late February and we still have not seen either Donald Trump's or Marco Rubio's or Ted Cruz's taxes," Romney told Fox's Neil Cavuto. "Frankly, the voters have a right to see those tax returns before they decide who our nominee ought to be."

Regarding Trump's tax returns specifically, Romney stated they "are likely to be a bombshell." Trump, however, has only said that his campaign will "make that determination over the next couple of months."

Trump's response to Romney's comments was swift and acerbic. In a series of tweets, he referred to Romney as "a losing candidate" and "one of the dumbest and worst candidates in the history of Republican politics." He also implied that Romney was jealous of him and questioned his loyalty.

Trump's tweets included:

* "Mitt Romney, who totally blew an election that should have been won and whose tax returns made him look like a fool, is now playing tough guy."
* "Another tweet explained that the photo, of Trump glaring as he looks up from signing a stack of papers, depicted him'signing a recent tax return.'"
* "He labeled Romney 'one of the dumbest and worst candidates in the history of Republican politics' in a tweet. He punctuated that message with another insult: 'Dope!'"
* "Later, in another post on the social media platform, Trump promised that he was 'going to do what @ MittRomney was totally unable to do- WIN!'"

Trump's anti-Romney tirade also grew to encompass another figure in the Republican establishment, opponent Marco Rubio. The attacks will likely continue on the Republican debate stage Thursday night, where the remaining five GOP candidates will gather for their last bout before the Super Tuesday nominating contests.

Trump has also effectively crowd-sourced the art of the insult to his considerable Twitter following, and he has made it a point to repost his followers' attacks. Some of these tweets include:

* "@ahernandez85a: @realDonaldTrump Mr Tough Guy Romney should be backing Trump like Trump backed him last time # NoLoyalty" - Donald J. Trump ( @realDonaldTrump ) February 25, 2016
* "@conservativevin: @ahernandez85a Romney should have been a tough guy with Obama. He cowered and lost. BADLY! He's not relevant!" - Donald J. Trump ( @realDonaldTrump ) February 25, 2016

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder Faces Congressional Scrutiny Over AP Phone Records, Alleges Republican Conduct as "Shameful"

Article:

In a heated exchange at a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday, Attorney General Eric Holder accused Republican Rep. Darrell Issa of withholding information from Congress and called his conduct "shameful." The hearing, which focused on a new set of scandals, included allegations against the Department of Justice (DOJ) regarding the handling of a government leak to The Associated Press (AP).

The AP, along with several lawmakers, claim that the DOJ infringed on the constitutional rights of the press by secretly obtaining two months' worth of phone records. During the hearing, lawmakers attempted to get answers from Holder, but he repeatedly rebuffed questions by claiming he was not involved in the decision-making process.

Rep. James Sensenbrenner, among a group of bipartisan lawmakers, pressed Holder on the secret collection of telephone records. Holder stated that he had recused himself from the case because "I am a possessor of information eventually leaked." He also noted that he was unable to answer questions about why the DOJ failed to negotiate with the AP prior to obtaining subpoenas, a standard practice in these cases.

Holder testified that all the decisions made in the case fell on Deputy Attorney General James Cole's shoulders. Sensenbrenner suggested having Cole testify before the House Judiciary Committee, but Cole's testimony would likely yield few answers due to his inability to discuss ongoing cases.

Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., expressed concern about the government's actions, stating, "I am troubled by the notion that our government would pursue a broad array of phone records over a period of time." However, like Sensenbrenner, he was unable to pull any new information about the AP case from Holder.

On Monday, AP President and CEO Gary Pruitt disclosed the government's action in a letter to Holder, which was made public. In the letter, Pruitt called the collection of phone records at four AP bureaus a "massive and unprecedented intrusion" of the news agency's freedom of press rights granted under the U.S. Constitution.

The AP case has sparked bipartisan outrage, with members of both parties publicly questioning the government's actions. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus called for Holder's resignation, stating, "Freedom of the press is an essential right in a free society." Holder acknowledged Priebus' calls for his resignation during his opening remarks, but again noted that he was not behind the subpoena.

New York Sen. Charles Schumer plans to reintroduce legislation that would protect journalists from revealing their sources. The bill, which was brought up in 2009, has since stalled in Congress.

Under Holder's command, the DOJ has prosecuted more government officials for alleged leaks under the World War I-era Espionage Act than all of the AGs who came before him – combined. The Obama administration has been aggressive in going after government workers leaking classified information, with the White House bringing indictments against five workers and the Defense Department pursuing a sixth case against the U.S. Army soldier accused of sending classified documents to the anti-secrecy online group WikiLeaks.

Title: Texas Senator Ted Cruz Announces 2016 Presidential Bid: A Look at His Strengths as a GOP Candidate

Article:

Texas Senator Ted Cruz has officially declared his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, making him the first major contender to enter the race. Here are several compelling reasons why Cruz is considered a strong GOP presidential candidate for 2016:

1. Early Start: Cruz is expected to begin his campaign immediately, rather than launching an exploratory committee, a strategy often employed by potential candidates.

2. Tea Party Support: Amy Kremer, former head of the Tea Party Express, told The Associated Press that Cruz's announcement will "excite the base in a way we haven't seen in years."

3. Opposition to Obamacare: Cruz is one of the party's most vocal opponents of the Affordable Care Act, having spoken for over 21 hours on the Senate floor in an attempt to defund the act in September 2013.

4. Strong Stand on Immigration: In December, Cruz defied GOP leaders to force a vote on opposing President Barack Obama's executive action on immigration, although the strategy ultimately failed.

5. Perceived Independence: Cruz is seen as more independent than other potential GOP candidates, as demonstrated by his defiance of party leaders on immigration.

6. Mainstream Republican Stance: Unlike some fellow candidates, Cruz is firmly in the mainstream of Republican voters on nearly every issue, unlike some fellow candidates such as Jeb Bush, who supports legalization for undocumented immigrants, and Rand Paul, who supported normalizing relations with Cuba.

7. Campaigning Ability: Cruz scored one of the biggest upsets in the 2012 election when he defeated David Dewhurst in the Texas GOP primary. Dewhurst, who was Governor Rick Perry's lieutenant governor, spent over $20 million of his own money but could not overcome the Cruz campaign.

8. Potential Appeal to Hispanic Voters: Cruz's father was born in Cuba, and Cruz is the first Hispanic U.S. Senator from Texas.

9. Past Election Success: Cruz contends that the GOP needs a strong conservative to win the general election, citing past elections as evidence.

10. Bipartisan Appeal: Cruz could potentially appeal to disillusioned voters from both parties.

11. Legal Background: Cruz has a strong legal background, having earned his law degree at Harvard University and clerked for Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist.

12. Campaign Asset: Cruz's wife, Heidi Cruz, is expected to be a significant asset in the campaign. She worked on George W. Bush's 2000 presidential campaign, served at the National Security Council under Condoleezza Rice and at the Treasury Department, and most recently was a managing director for Goldman Sachs in Houston. She has taken an unpaid leave to help her husband's campaign.

Title: Major Companies Explain Payments to Michael Cohen's Essential Consultants LLC

Article:

Multiple media outlets have confirmed reports that Michael Avenatti, Stormy Daniels' attorney, claimed that the Michael Cohen-affiliated shell company, Essential Consultants LLC, received large sums from companies potentially affected by Trump administration decisions. Essential Consultants LLC, a single-member LLC solely owned by Cohen, was created and registered in Delaware less than a month before the 2016 election.

Here are the explanations provided by the companies for their payments to Michael Cohen's Essential Consultants LLC:

1. Korean Aerospace Industries, a defense contractor, paid $150,000 for "legal consulting concerning accounting standards on production costs." The company stated it was unaware of Cohen's connection to Donald Trump.

2. AT&T paid Cohen $600,000 for "understanding how the President and his administration might approach a wide range of policy issues, including regulatory reform at the FCC, corporate tax reform, and antitrust enforcement."

3. Novartis, a Swiss pharmaceutical company, hired Cohen to "advise the company as to how the Trump administration might approach certain U.S. healthcare policy matters, including the Affordable Care Act." However, Novartis did not meet with Cohen until a month after the contract was signed, and they decided not to engage further with him.

4. Columbus Nova, a New York investment firm, paid Cohen $500,000 to work as a business consultant for potential sources of capital and potential investments in real estate and other ventures. Columbus Nova's CEO is the cousin of a Russian billionaire named Viktor Vekselberg, who controls the Renova Group. The Renova Group's website previously listed Columbus Nova as a subsidiary, but the pages containing this information have since been taken offline. Columbus Nova's attorney stated that any insinuation that the payment to Cohen was related to Vekselberg is "patently untrue."

These four entities paid a company with no known employees millions of dollars for advice about accounting standards, telecom reform, tax policy, antitrust law, the Affordable Care Act, and high-end investment opportunities during the same period that the company was also involved in nondisclosure payments to a pornographic actress and a Playboy playmate. One of the companies that paid Cohen is now downplaying a previously disclosed connection to a Russian billionaire affected by economic sanctions.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Refers Michael Avenatti and Julie Swetnick to Justice Department for Criminal Investigation

Article:

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley has referred attorney Michael Avenatti and his client, Julie Swetnick, to the Justice Department for a criminal investigation in response to Swetnick's unsubstantiated allegation that Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh participated in a gang-rape ring while in high school.

The referral comes amidst the heated, partisan battle over Kavanaugh's confirmation, sparked by Christine Blasey Ford's allegation of sexual assault. Avenatti publicized Swetnick's claim that Kavanaugh routinely organized drug-and-alcohol-fueled gang rapes at high-school parties.

Swetnick presented those allegations to the Committee on September 26 in a sworn statement, but later backed off her claims during an October 1 interview with NBC News, conceding that she never witnessed Kavanaugh spike anyone's drink or participate in gang rape.

In a lengthy letter to Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Grassley outlined his rationale for the investigation, stating, "When a well-meaning citizen comes forward with information relevant to the committee's work, I take it seriously. It takes courage to come forward, especially with allegations of sexual misconduct or personal trauma." He added, "But in the heat of partisan moments, some do try to knowingly mislead the committee. That's unfair to my colleagues, the nominees, and others providing information who are seeking the truth."

Grassley continued, "Ignoring this behavior will just invite more of it in the future." He emphasized that the law prohibits such false statements to Congress and obstruction of congressional committee investigations.

In response to the referral, Avenatti expressed enthusiasm on Twitter, stating, "Maybe if Grassley was actually a lawyer that knew something about the law, he would realize what he has done. He just opened up Pandora's box as it relates to Justice Kavanaugh's conduct. It is Christmas in October!" and "Ironically, Senator Grassley now is interested in investigations. He didn't care when it came to putting a man on the SCOTUS for life." Avenatti has yet to issue a formal statement regarding the referral.

Title: President Trump Discusses Various Topics in "60 Minutes" Interview

Article:

In a wide-ranging interview with "60 Minutes" that aired on Sunday, President Donald Trump addressed a range of topics, including North Korea, Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination process, the 2016 election, and climate change.

During the interview, Trump and "60 Minutes" anchor Lesley Stahl engaged in a series of exchanges, with Trump at times verbally sparring with her. One particularly tense exchange ended with Trump telling Stahl, "In the meantime, I’m the president – and you’re not."

Regarding climate change, the conversation revolved around the aftermath of Hurricane Michael, one of the most powerful hurricanes in U.S. history. Trump stated, "I think something’s happening. Something’s changing and it’ll change back again. I don’t think it’s a hoax, I think there’s probably a difference. But I don’t know that it’s manmade."

When Stahl pressed Trump on the issue, he responded, "I’m not denying climate change. But it could very well go back. You know, we’re talking about over millions of years."

Trump also expressed trust in North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, stating, "I do trust him, yeah, I trust him." However, he qualified this by saying, "That doesn’t mean I can’t be proven wrong about (denuclearization)."

First lady Melania Trump's comments about not trusting everyone in the White House were also brought up, with Trump agreeing, "I feel the same way."

Trump maintained that there was interference in the 2016 election, but he emphasized that Russia was not the only country involved. "They meddled. But I think China meddled, too," Trump said when asked if Russia had run interference in the last presidential election.

When discussing the contentious Brett Kavanaugh Supreme Court nomination process, Trump lamented the Democrats' treatment of Kavanaugh and expressed a desire for national unity, but felt that Democrats were not ready to heal.

To close the interview, Trump was asked about finding his "sea legs" as president. He stated that he found it "a little surreal to say I’m President of the United States" in the beginning, but quickly added, "Now, I very much feel like POTUS. I do. I feel like the president."

Title: Trump's Struggle to Pass AHCA: Lack of Understanding of GOP Concerns and Focus on Winning

Article:

President Donald Trump faced challenges in securing the support of GOP congressmen for the American Health Care Act (AHCA) due to a perceived lack of understanding of their concerns. Despite numerous attempts to persuade lawmakers, including meetings at the White House, phone calls, and threats, the bill was ultimately not passed.

The AHCA was withdrawn by President Trump and Speaker Paul Ryan on Friday afternoon. Earlier in the week, Trump had emphasized that failure to pass the bill could cost the GOP their majority in the 2018 midterm elections. However, the bill's failure to pass could also potentially cost the GOP their majority if a replacement plan was perceived as inadequate by voters.

The House Republicans who refused to vote for the bill were not motivated by a lack of desire to replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). Instead, they were primarily concerned about the content of the bill and its potential impact on consumers. Some felt that the AHCA would not lower premiums enough, while others objected to the bill's similarities to Obamacare.

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated that the bill would reduce insurance costs in the long term but increase them in the first three years. This raises questions about whether voters would support the GOP in the 2018 midterm elections if a replacement plan passed but premiums remained high.

Some House Republicans also objected to the AHCA's requirement for comprehensive coverage, arguing that it adds to the costs of insurers and raises premiums. On the other hand, consumers value comprehensive coverage.

It appears that President Trump was more focused on securing a win than on understanding the specific details of the legislation that made GOP lawmakers reluctant to vote for it. An unnamed House GOP aide told CNN that Trump "either doesn't know, doesn't care, or both" about the details of the legislation.

In the Los Angeles Times, Michael Steel, a former GOP leadership aide, offered a portrait of a president who is both eager and clueless. Steel stated that Ryan has learned that his wonky style of communication is wasted on Trump due to the president's lack of interest in policy details. However, Trump has come to value the president's eagerness to exert pressure on wavering Republicans.

In conclusion, President Trump's focus on winning rather than understanding the details of the AHCA may have contributed to the bill's failure to pass. This lack of focus on the details may have denied Trump the victory he sought so desperately.

Title: Obama Chooses Least Bad Option in Syria: Limited Strike Over No Action or Regime Change

Article:

President Barack Obama appears to have chosen the least bad option in Syria, opting for a limited military strike against the Assad regime rather than doing nothing or pursuing regime change. This decision comes after a large chemical weapons attack in the country, which has been met with international condemnation.

The choice of a limited strike is seen as a risky move, but it is considered less risky than doing nothing or attempting regime change. If Obama does not act, he risks being perceived as ineffective, according to Aaron Miller, a former U.S. State Department official.

The option of doing nothing is not a viable one, as Obama had previously drawn a red line against the use of chemical weapons by Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. The recent chemical attack is reportedly the largest single deployment of chemical weapons since Saddam Hussein used them against the Kurds in 1988, and over 100,000 Syrians have died in the ongoing civil conflict.

The administration's actions and statements in the past few days have been described as the most well-advertised and telegraphed military action in modern warfare. Secretary of State John Kerry's powerful statement of moral outrage and the president's PBS interview have created a strong commitment to strike.

However, the president has avoided the option of a more robust policy, such as the use of no-fly zones, extensive use of U.S. air and missile power to degrade the regime, and military support for the opposition. This approach has been advocated by some U.S. senators and interventionists, who argue that Syria poses a major threat to U.S. interests and that only a takedown of the Assad regime will address the problem.

The president's decision to avoid this option is due to the general problem of an open-ended military commitment and the lack of correlation between the use of U.S. military power and its relation to the end state. Syria is in the throes of a brutal civil war, with more than 1,000 disparate rebel groups, many of which are allied with extremist groups. A victory of the latter would be a blow to U.S. interests. Ousting Assad would not be cheap or easy, and the post-Assad environment could be unstable and lack a credible central authority.

The limited strike option is far from ideal, as it is unlikely to change the arc of the battlefield balance. There are also other downsides, such as the potential for escalation and the danger of a response by Hezbollah or Syria against Israel. The use of force without a real strategy can also undermine American credibility.

Despite the risks, the president's actions leave him no other choice, given the apparent use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime and the international outcry that followed. The president's decision to act is a departure from his previous reluctance to use military force, and he may face opposition from some members of Congress and international allies.

Title: Analysis: Sanders' Electability in the 2020 Presidential Election

Article:

Recent polling data suggests that Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders may be more electable than some Democrats fear. National and swing state polls indicate that Sanders is tied with or beating President Donald Trump, contradicting doomsday warnings about his potential nomination and subsequent general election performance.

A Quinnipiac Poll from last week shows Sanders leading Trump in Michigan and Pennsylvania. A CBS News/YouGov poll shows Sanders beating Trump nationally, while a Texas Lyceum poll indicates that Sanders performs better against Trump in Texas than any other Democratic candidate, losing by just three points.

Sanders' strong online presence is another factor that sets him apart. He has larger followings on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and other platforms than his rivals, and has demonstrated new media sophistication that others lack.

Sanders' loyal base is another significant advantage. His supporters consistently donate to his campaign and attend rallies, and their dedication is evident in elections. Sanders is the best-funded non-billionaire in the Democratic field, and his supporters' loyalty could be a deciding factor in the election.

Sanders' self-proclaimed big government socialism has not deterred voters, as 45% of the electorate does not seem to be concerned with Trump's outlandishness.

Peter Hamby, who works for Snapchat and writes for Vanity Fair, argues that Democrats may be underestimating Sanders' electability. Hamby suggests that instead of questioning Sanders' electability, one should ask if Sanders is the most electable Democrat in the 2020 election. He posits that Sanders' celebrity status, both old-school and new-age, makes him well-suited to compete with Trump in the current political climate.

In conclusion, while it is impossible to predict the outcome of the 2020 presidential election with certainty, the evidence suggests that Sanders may be more electable than some Democrats fear. His strong polling numbers, loyal base, and media savvy position him as a formidable opponent to President Trump. However, it is essential to remember that voter preferences can be unpredictable, and the final outcome will depend on various factors, including the candidates' performances in debates, campaign strategies, and unforeseen events.

Title: Texas Legislature Passes Restrictive Abortion Bill, Prompting Promise of Legal Challenge and Protests

Article:

The Texas Legislature has passed an omnibus abortion bill, one of the most restrictive in the nation. The bill, which is expected to be signed into law by Governor Rick Perry, will ban abortions after 20 weeks, require abortion doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, and mandate that all abortions take place in surgical centers.

The Republican majority in the Texas Legislature passed the bill unchanged just before midnight, with all but one Democrat voting against it. The bill's passage followed more than 2,000 demonstrators filling the Capitol building in Austin to oppose the bill, with state troopers removing six protesters from the Senate chamber for attempting to disrupt the debate.

Governor Perry stated, "Today the Texas Legislature took its final step in our historic effort to protect life." He added, "This legislation builds on the strong and unwavering commitment we have made to defend life and protect women's health."

Democratic Senator Royce West, speaking on the Senate floor, vowed, "There will be a lawsuit. I promise you."

Democrats offered 20 amendments to the bill, ranging from exceptions for rape and incest to allowing doctors more leeway in prescribing abortion-inducing drugs. However, Republicans rejected these amendments.

The bill is part of a series of measures across the nation championed by anti-abortion groups, aiming for a constitutional challenge to Roe vs. Wade, the U.S. Supreme Court decision guaranteeing a woman's right to decide on an abortion before the fetus is viable outside the womb.

The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, to which Texas falls under, has shown a willingness to accept more stringent limits on abortions. Passing the law also appeases Christian conservatives, who make up the majority of Republican primary voters.

However, the measure has sparked protests in Texas not seen in at least 20 years, with thousands of abortion rights supporters flooding the Capitol to draw out normally boring committee hearings and disrupting key votes. Protesters finished a filibuster started by Democratic Sen. Wendy Davis of Fort Worth by jeering for the last 15 minutes of the first special session, effectively killing the bill.

Title: EPA Collusion with Environmental Groups Alleged in "Sue and Settle" Lawsuits

Article:

A study by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has found that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has given radical environmental groups a significant role in drafting environmental regulations, while excluding the people and industries most likely to be affected. The EPA has reportedly collaborated with groups such as the Sierra Club, WildEarth Guardians, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Center for Biological Diversity, and the Environmental Defense Fund.

This collaboration is facilitated through a legal technique known as "sue and settle," in which environmental groups file lawsuits against federal agencies, resulting in "consent decrees" that are settled in closed-door meetings. The settlements are then implemented without a public comment period, allowing the EPA to enact regulations favored by the environmental groups.

The result is a regulatory regime that imposes costs on industries and consumers while granting economically damaging policy prescriptions to radical environmental groups. For example, a settlement between the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Center for Biological Diversity over endangered-species rules could lead to federal control over private lands in several oil- and natural gas-producing states, potentially threatening thousands of private landowners' leases.

The "sue and settle" litigation is reportedly taking a toll on industries, consumers, and state treasuries across the nation. A suit filed by WildEarth Guardians has led to eight states spending millions to comply with EPA regulations to improve visibility in national parks and wilderness areas. A "sue and settle" case involving the Navajo Generating Station is expected to raise electricity costs for Arizonans by an estimated 20 percent a year.

The EPA's alleged collusion with environmental groups and its use of the "sue and settle" method of promulgating regulations has raised questions about the agency's accountability and direction. Critics argue that the EPA's focus on environmental regulations may be prioritizing a green ideology over its primary mission of protecting human health and the environment based on the best available scientific information.

Former Republican member of the House of Representatives Bob Beauprez has criticized the EPA's actions, stating that science has taken a back seat to a green ideology that puts politics before "we the people." The American Traditions Institute has also sued the EPA for failing to respond to a Freedom of Information Act request for details about these questionable alliances.

Title: Senate Unveils Sweeping Budget Deal, Faces Uncertainty in House

Article:

The United States Senate is on the verge of passing a two-year budget agreement that would increase defense and domestic spending by over $400 billion. However, the bill faces a potential roadblock due to Sen. Rand Paul's (R-Ky.) demand for a vote on restoring the 2011 budget caps. The Senate was unable to pass the bill before a midnight deadline, leading to a partial government shutdown.

The budget agreement, negotiated by congressional leaders, hit a snag when Sen. Paul demanded a vote on reinstating the 2011 budget caps, which limited congressional spending. Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell refused to allow the vote, and Paul refused to back down. Paul's right to object will elapse at 1 a.m., and the Senate will proceed to vote on the measure, which includes short-term federal funding through March 23. However, federal funding from the last short-term spending bill expires at midnight.

The 652-page budget bill, if approved, would then go to the House, where it faces stiff opposition from both liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans. The measure eliminates the budget caps, paving the way for Congress to increase defense spending by $165 billion and domestic spending by $131 billion over the next two years. The bill is also packed with other fiscal provisions, including a major disaster relief package for regions affected by last year's devastating storms and a one-year suspension of the debt limit.

President Trump has endorsed the deal, stating, "Republicans and Democrats must support our troops and support this Bill." Senate Democratic Leader Charles Schumer of New York and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell have both championed the agreement as a bipartisan breakthrough that would end the cycle of short-term spending bills.

The bill's fate in the House remains unclear, with both Democrats and Republicans facing internal party divisions over the deal. Defense hawks and moderate Republicans view it as a strong compromise that will provide a much-needed boost to the military, while conservatives criticize it as a budget-busting proposal that will further sink the country in a sea of red ink.

Democrats are also conflicted because while the deal would increase spending for their favored domestic programs, the agreement does nothing to protect the DREAMers, undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children. House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi delivered an 8-hour speech on the House floor, objecting to the budget plan's failure to protect DREAMers.

If conservative Republicans in the House oppose the agreement, House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) will need a significant number of Democratic votes to get it passed. However, Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-Md.), the Democratic whip, urged his members to line up in opposition to the deal.

If the bill passes both chambers, it would give Congress six weeks to craft a spending bill for the rest of 2018 that meets the new budget targets before the government runs out of money again.

Title: FBI Investigation of Hillary Clinton's Email Server: A Turning Point in the Clinton's 35-Year Career

Article:

The ongoing investigation into Hillary Clinton's private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State has been a recurring theme in her political career, with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) playing a significant role in several of her scandals. This investigation, which has been a topic of intense scrutiny for months, is now being recognized as a potential turning point in the Clinton's 35-year career of navigating legal controversies.

The article discusses the author's perspective on Clinton's continued association with Huma Abedin, a long-time aide, despite her husband, Anthony Weiner, being embroiled in multiple scandals. The author questions Clinton's judgment in keeping Abedin on her staff, given Weiner's history of sexting and the subsequent revelation of classified documents on his laptop.

The article also recounts instances of Clinton's interactions with the FBI, dating back to the 1980s in Arkansas, when FBI Special Agent I.C. Smith questioned her role in fundraising for her husband, Governor Bill Clinton. The author also references the 1997 Congressional inquiry into the Clintons, during which then-FBI Director Louis Freeh compared his experiences with the Clintons to his work on organized crime cases in New York City.

More recently, the article mentions the investigation led by FBI Director James Comey, who, in July, did not recommend indictment but did state that Clinton had lied to the bureau in her testimony and that her handling of classified information was "extremely careless." This statement, along with Comey's subsequent letter to Congress, has been a point of contention in the 2016 presidential race.

The article concludes with a reference to former assistant FBI director James Kallstrom's description of the Clintons as a "crime family," a characterization that echoes Freeh's remarks from 1997. The author asserts that the FBI's investigation of Clinton's email server is a significant development in the Clintons' long history of legal controversies, with the investigation's impact becoming increasingly apparent even to Washington's political establishment.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Indiana Abortion Remains Law, Sparking National Debate

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States upheld an Indiana law on Tuesday that requires the burial or cremation of fetal remains following an abortion. The decision has further fueled the ongoing national debate on abortion.

The debate on abortion has become increasingly polarized, with extremist views dominating the discourse on both sides. In recent years, the political left has shifted from advocating for the "safe, legal, and rare" stance, as proposed by former President Bill Clinton, to becoming more comfortable with more liberal abortion policies.

On the liberal side, the zeitgeist trend is toward an almost celebratory, in-your-face tone, as seen in the movement "Shout Your Abortion," and the passage of abortion-rights-expanding bills in states like Virginia, New York, and elsewhere.

The right has responded with its own extreme counterpart, as evidenced by the recent Alabama law, which bans abortion except to protect the life of the mother and imposes serious penalties for abortion providers.

The debate on abortion also involves a science-based argument, with advancing neonatal research and technology revealing more details about life in the womb. This has complicated the issue, as it denies the luxury of thinking about the fetus as a clump of cells beyond the early weeks of pregnancy.

The silent majority of Americans, often referred to as the squishy middle, is being held hostage by the intractable extremities on both sides. Extremists on both sides are fixated on principle and purity, not on pragmatism, compromise, and real-world concerns.

The issue of abortion solves itself for moderates in simpler terms: Banning abortion is out of the question because it will only drive it underground, but most moderates can manage their moral discomfort enough to be okay with abortion early in the pregnancy, in cases of rape, incest, and for the life of the mother, and in rare, wrenching cases, later-term abortion to protect the life of the mother.

The phrase "the life of the mother" has meaning, and when supplemented with "the health of the mother," as in the New York law, pro-lifers express concern about the potential abuse of the exception.

In conclusion, the Supreme Court's decision to uphold part of the Indiana law marks a small victory in the ongoing battle over abortion rights. The debate on abortion remains complex and contentious, with both sides holding strong, often extreme views. As the debate continues, it is crucial to respect the science, consider the real-world implications, and find a way to protect both the rights of the unborn and the autonomy of women.

Title: Lawmakers Call for Trump Administration to Outline Syria Strategy Following Missile Strikes

Article:

Following the U.S. missile strikes in Syria in response to a chemical weapons attack by Syrian President Bashar Assad, lawmakers on Capitol Hill are urging the Trump administration to outline a broader strategy for the region.

Senate Armed Services Chairman John McCain (R-Ariz.) told MSNBC on Friday that the current situation in the Middle East is "the challenge of Bashar al-Assad, and then we have also got the challenge of ISIS." He added that there is "a lot more to go."

Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) urged the administration to collaborate and elaborate on the strategy moving forward. "In the days ahead, I am committed to working with the administration to continue developing a counter-ISIL strategy that hastens the defeat of ISIL and establishes objectives for dealing with the Assad regime in a manner that preserves the institutions of government in an effort to prevent a failed state," he said.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) stated that it is "incumbent on the Trump administration to come up with a strategy and consult with Congress before implementing it."

Senators were scheduled to hold a classified briefing with military and intelligence officials on Friday afternoon. The Senate adjourns for a two-week Spring recess, while the House has already left town for the break.

Some Democrats, as well as at least two Republicans, are questioning the strikes' constitutionality. The military action is reviving debate over Congress's role in the matter and whether the president needs to obtain congressional authorization for any prolonged military engagement in the region.

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.), who favors a more isolationist foreign policy approach, wrote on Twitter that the president needs Congressional authorization for military action as required by the Constitution. Rep. Justin Amash (R-Mich.) echoed Paul's remarks, stating that airstrikes are an act of war and that the Constitution vests in Congress the power to commence war.

Rep. Barbara Lee (D-Calif.), a prominent liberal supporter of Congress passing a new authorization for the use of military force (AUMF), characterized the airstrikes as "an act of war." She tweeted, "I was the lone vote against 2001 AUMF. Syria strikes are far beyond the scope of this war authorization. Speaker Ryan needs to bring a vote."

President Trump, like President Barack Obama before him, has launched airstrikes against ISIS targets using the 2001 war authorization Congress passed after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, as legal justification. However, lawmakers are split over whether that justification covers attacks against the Assad government.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) stated that the strike was "appropriate and just" and signaled that he also wants the Trump administration to consult Capitol Hill lawmakers on the matter. "I look forward to the administration further engaging Congress in this effort," he said.

Title: President Trump Signs Legislation to Reverse CFPB Auto Lending Discrimination Guidelines

Article:

President Donald Trump on Monday signed legislation that will undo a 2013 effort by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to discourage discrimination in auto lending. The CFPB guidelines outlined steps that lenders should take to address discrimination by auto dealers, who often determine the terms for car loans that they help facilitate for their customers.

With the backing of auto dealers and lenders, Republicans who drove the rollback argued that the CFPB should have followed formal rule-making procedures and sought more public feedback before issuing the guidelines. The 2010 Dodd-Frank law prohibits the bureau from regulating auto dealers. The CFPB guidance was addressed to lenders that fall under the bureau's jurisdiction.

CFPB acting Director Mick Mulvaney praised the move to rescind what he called a "misguided" initiative by his predecessor, who was appointed by President Barack Obama. "I am heartened that the people, through their elected representatives, have corrected this instance of Bureau overreach," Mulvaney said in a statement.

Democrats and consumer watchdogs warned that, in addition to encouraging unfair lending practices, the rollback opened a whole new front in Republicans' deregulation drive under Trump that would be felt well-beyond the CFPB. This marks the first time that lawmakers have successfully used their authority under the Congressional Review Act to kill a regulatory action taken by an agency several years in the past, rather than within a brief window outlined by the 1996 law.

The congressional move was also novel because the law was used to take down regulatory guidance instead of a formal rule under the Administrative Procedure Act. Agencies issue informal guidance to advise businesses about how laws and rules are being implemented.

Amit Narang, regulatory policy advocate at Public Citizen, stated, "This controversial abuse of the CRA should never have been allowed to happen in the first place." He added, "By signing it, President Trump is turning his back on consumers by giving auto dealers license to discriminate against minorities."

Mulvaney, who also serves as the White House budget director, said the bureau will "continue to fight unlawful discrimination at every turn." The CFPB said the process clarified that a number of its other guidance documents may be considered rules subject to the Congressional Review Act, and it will "confer with congressional staff and federal agency partners" to identify additional documents to submit to Congress.

Title: Strong Economy Favors Trump's Reelection Bid, but Uncertainty Remains

Article:

The latest job creation figures, with 266,000 jobs added in November and the unemployment rate at a 50-year low, indicate a robust economy that could potentially favor President Donald Trump's reelection bid in 2020. However, the relationship between the economy and presidential approval is complex, and Trump's overall job approval remains low.

In a CNN poll released last month, Trump's overall job approval was 42%, while 54% disapproved. However, when respondents were asked about Trump's handling of the economy, 52% approved, and 40% disapproved. This is the only area in the poll where a majority of respondents approved of the job Trump is doing.

President Trump has consistently touted his economic successes on Twitter, emphasizing the record-breaking performance of the stock market and the economy. In a series of tweets on Friday, he wrote, "Stock Markets Up Record Numbers...It's the economy, stupid." This phrase, coined by Democratic strategist James Carville during the 1992 presidential campaign, has been a recurring theme in American politics, highlighting the significant impact of the economy on voters' decisions.

Incumbent presidents have historically faced difficulty losing reelection when the economy is strong. Presidents such as Jimmy Carter, George H.W. Bush, and Gerald Ford have lost reelection bids due to weak or faltering economies. The only other president in the last nine decades to lose a bid for reelection was Richard Nixon, but his case was unique due to his decision to pardon the man he replaced in office.

Voters consistently cite the economy as the most important issue affecting their vote. In the 2016, 2012, and 2008 presidential elections, a majority of voters identified the economy as the most pressing issue. Therefore, if voters believe a president is doing a good job on the economy, they are more likely to reelect that person to keep the economic growth continuing.

However, President Trump's overall job approval numbers have not shown a majority approving of his job performance overall. Additionally, Trump's tendency to stray from a focused message could potentially impact his chances of winning reelection. Despite the strong economy, Trump's approval numbers on the economy have been strong for much of the past few years, but his overall job approval numbers have not reflected this.

In conclusion, the strong economy could potentially favor Trump's reelection bid, but his overall job approval numbers and his tendency to stray from a focused message could impact his chances of winning reelection. The economy is Trump's "trump card" with voters, but the question remains whether he knows how and when to play it effectively.

Title: Republican Party's Shift in Strategy: Winning vs. Moral Integrity in Alabama Senate Race

Article:

In the ongoing Alabama Senate special election, the Republican Party is grappling with the possibility that Roy Moore may secure a victory next Tuesday. This realization has sparked a series of events, with President Donald Trump endorsing Moore and several senators retracting their initial criticisms of the embattled Senate nominee.

On Monday, President Trump endorsed Moore via a tweet and a phone call, urging him to "go get 'em!" In response, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky stated, "I think we're going to let the people of Alabama decide a week from Tuesday who they want to send to the Senate, and then we'll address the matter appropriately."

Utah Sen. Orrin Hatch, traveling with Trump in Utah, further explained Trump's endorsement of Moore, stating, "I do not think he had any choice but to do that. You know he needs every Republican he can get so he can put his agenda through." Hatch also addressed the allegations against Moore, stating, "Many of the things he allegedly did are decades ago. So it's hard to -- that's a decision that has to be made by the people in that state."

The shift in stance from Republican senators, who initially condemned Moore and called for his withdrawal from the race, is a response to Moore's denial of the allegations and his continued commitment to the race. Additionally, polling suggests that Moore's numbers have rebounded after an initial dip following the allegations, making him a seemingly strong contender.

This strategy of prioritizing winning over moral integrity has been criticized by some Republicans, such as 2012 GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney and pollster Matthew Dowd. Romney tweeted, "Roy Moore in the US Senate would be a stain on the GOP and on the nation," while Dowd stated, "After going all in for Roy Moore, the President, the White House, the GOP, and any of their enablers has zero moral authority to talk about Weinstein, Franken, Conyers, etc."

The issue at hand is the potential long-term damage to the Republican Party's moral standing if they prioritize winning over moral integrity. As Dowd pointed out, "Winning and power are means to an end. That end is accomplishing the policy goals that a party stands for. Winning is not a goal to be achieved via governance."

The risk for the Republican Party in Alabama is that, by justifying Moore's behavior for the sake of winning, they may sacrifice their moral high ground and potentially damage their reputation in the long term. However, if the people of Alabama elect Moore, it remains unclear whether the Senate would move to expel him, as the last senator to be expelled was in 1862 for supporting the Confederacy.

Title: Senate Rebukes Trump Administration Over ZTE Deal with China, Adds Amendment to Defense Bill

Article:

Members of the U.S. Senate are set to deliver a stinging rebuke to President Donald Trump's efforts to normalize trade with China, as they have added an amendment to the annual defense policy bill that aims to reverse the administration's softening of penalties on Chinese telecom company ZTE. The amendment, co-sponsored by Sens. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), and Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), prohibits the entire U.S. government from purchasing or leasing equipment from ZTE and a similar telecom company, Huawei, cited for national security risks.

The amendment, if passed, would restore penalties on ZTE imposed in March 2017 after the company was caught selling equipment to Iran and making false statements assuring it had disciplined executives. The punishments included a fine and a seven-year ban on ZTE's ability to purchase U.S. parts.

John Cohen, a former acting undersecretary for intelligence at the Department of Homeland Security, stated that ZTE represents a major challenge for U.S. counterintelligence authorities. "China's intelligence agencies regularly embed eavesdropping and other collection tools in technologies sold by Chinese tech firms. China's intelligence services also collaborate with these Chinese tech firms to achieve other intelligence objectives. Allowing ZTE to resume operation will likely cause great concern amongst those intelligence professionals responsible for protecting our national security," Cohen, an ABC contributor, said.

The White House has yet to weigh in on this latest development, but Trump tweeted late last month that the deal with ZTE was more than what his Democratic predecessors had accomplished. While the White House has defended its ZTE deal as tougher than the original, the administration's handling of the ZTE issue has been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle.

Senate Republicans were also upset that the administration had publicly rebuked Canada during the G7 meeting by refusing to endorse a joint statement and accusing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of negotiating in bad faith. While Canada had already previously announced retaliatory steel and aluminum tariffs on the U.S., it seemed to be Trudeau's comments at a press conference, in which he said Canada would not be "pushed around," that upset the president and his advisors.

Some Senate Republicans are working on a bill that would check the president's ability to impose tariffs on the basis of national security concerns, as he did in the Canada case, without congressional approval. However, the bill, co-sponsored by Sens. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), appears to face procedural hurdles and may not be added to the defense policy bill.

Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) noted that some Republicans are opting to give the administration space to negotiate with Canada and other partners in the near term, and that it would be best not to try to rein in the president's authority at the same time. "There's clearly a concern with a lot of sort of free trade conservatives in our conference about the present track that we're on and where it could end up going. But I think at the moment everybody is giving the president the benefit of the doubt," Thune said.

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Progressive Lawmakers Plan to Leverage Banking Ties for Policy Change

Article:

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) has been making headlines this month for her aggressive questioning of Wells Fargo CEO Timothy Sloan during a House Financial Services Committee hearing. The freshman lawmaker grilled Sloan over Wells Fargo's involvement in financing projects that have been criticized, such as the detention of migrant children and projects countering the climate change agenda.
