According to Politico, Ocasio-Cortez and other progressive lawmakers are planning to use similar tactics to advance their anti-Second Amendment agenda and bypass the legislative process. The lawmakers aim to pressure financial institutions into taking a stand on contentious issues like climate change, gun violence, and immigration by "shaming" them and leveraging their seats on the House Financial Services Committee and social media following.

Ocasio-Cortez admitted to Politico that part of her strategy to bring about change is to apply pressure on banks through means other than legislation. She stated, "There's more than one way to skin a cat, and not everything has to be done through legislation explicitly. We can also use the tools that we have here to pressure change in other ways as well."

If history is any indication, this strategy could prove successful. JPMorgan and Wells Fargo announced earlier this month they would cut ties with prisons following pressure from Ocasio-Cortez and progressive activists. Last year, the plan was also effective against the National Rifle Association (NRA). In the aftermath of the Parkland, Florida, massacre, millions of Americans boycotted the NRA, which led First National Bank to sever ties with the pro-gun organization, which supplied the NRA with its branded credit card.

Karen Shaw Petrou, a managing partner at Federal Financial Analytics, told Politico that banks are particularly susceptible to public pressure. "Banks are acutely sensitive about their reputations because they are in a business acutely susceptible to severe and sudden customer attrition if consumers vote with their wallets," she explained. "As a highly regulated business, banks are also acutely aware of how changing reputations alter their political-risk profile and what Congress can do to them when and if desired."

Title: Global State of Civic Engagement: A Look at Recent Experiments and Findings

Article:

Researchers worldwide are exploring various methods to measure civic engagement, or the level of community involvement, as demonstrated by a recent experiment in Perth, Australia. In this experiment, researchers left 300 letters on the streets, half of which were stamped and half not. Of the 300 letters, 92 of the stamped ones were delivered compared to 42 of the unstamped ones. The aim of the study is to understand why certain communities have higher levels of civic engagement than others, and what factors contribute to building trust and fostering neighborly connections.

Similar experiments have been conducted in other locations, such as Birmingham, Alabama, where local volunteer groups received small grants of less than $2,000 for neighborhood improvement projects, like removing graffiti. This initiative, funded by the national group Love Your Block, led to a decrease in crime due to increased social cohesion in these neighborhoods.

Civic engagement encompasses a wide range of activities, from community service to voting and even posting a found letter. At its core, civic engagement is characterized by qualities of hope and trust that extend beyond family and friends. While democratic politics and national elections are often considered the primary measures of civic engagement, President Obama emphasized in a 2019 United Nations address that democratic politics should be driven by civic engagement from the bottom up, rather than governance by experts from the top down.

In a 2016 survey of 140 countries, Gallup ranked countries based on the proportion of their population inclined to give back to their communities. Surprisingly, the top ten countries on the Gallup index included more than just wealthy countries. Myanmar topped the list, with Sri Lanka and Indonesia not far behind.

The survey also found that the most common form of giving back to a community was helping a stranger in need (44%), followed by donating money (27%) and volunteering (20%).

Civic engagement is crucial for social peace and economic prosperity, and finding ways to build more of it can have far-reaching benefits. One potential method to encourage civic engagement could be for cities and towns to drop a few letters on the street to see how many are delivered, as demonstrated in the Perth experiment.

Title: U.S. Places Hold on World Health Organization Funding for Review Amidst Criticism of Handling of Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

President Donald Trump announced Tuesday that the United States is placing a hold on funding to the World Health Organization (WHO) for 60 to 90 days, pending a review, following accusations of mismanagement and cover-up in the organization's handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

During a briefing in the Rose Garden, Trump stated, "With the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have deep concerns whether America’s generosity has been put to the best use possible." He added, "If we cannot trust them, if this is what we will receive from the WHO, our country will be forced to find other ways to work with other nations to achieve public health goals."

The WHO's 2018-2019 budget was approximately $6 billion, with the U.S. being the biggest donor, contributing more than $400 million last year. According to Trump, American taxpayers provided between $400 million and $500 million per year to the WHO, while China contributes roughly $40 million annually.

Trump's specific complaints, which led to the decision to freeze U.S. funding, include the WHO's failure to obtain, vet, and share information in a timely and transparent manner, its failure to investigate credible reports from Wuhan that conflicted with the Chinese government's official accounts, and its delay in declaring a public health emergency, among other issues.

Over the past week, officials within the White House's Office of Management and Budget have been working on a menu of options for how to snub the WHO. The most likely route is to reprogram U.S. funding that was allocated to the WHO, moving it to other international organizations that can administer it for comparable purposes, officials said. A more dramatic, but less likely, approach is to send a rescissions package to Congress, rescinding from the federal budget funds already allocated to the WHO.

Antonio Guterres, secretary-general of the United Nations, to which the WHO reports, issued a statement, "Now is a time for unity in the global battle to push the COVID-19 pandemic into reverse, not a time to cut the resources of the... WHO, which is spearheading and coordinating the global body’s efforts."

The U.S. is the largest contributor to the WHO, providing between $400 million and $500 million per year. The WHO's 2018-2019 budget was approximately $6 billion.

Title: EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson's Alias Email Account Awarded Training Certificates

Article:

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) awarded training certificates to the fictional staffer "Richard Windsor," an alias used by former EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson, for completing various technology and ethics training courses, according to documents disclosed last week. The alias, [email protected], was a controversial email address used by Jackson, who resigned earlier this year amid questions about compliance with open-records laws.

The new records suggest that Jackson used the alias more extensively than previously known, including for required agency computer training under the fake identity. The Windsor account was awarded certificates for completing online email records management training, the 2010 "No FEAR Act Training Module," and a "Cybersecurity awareness training" course in 2011, with a score of 83%.

Jackson was also recognized as a "scholar of ethical behavior" each year from 2010 through 2012. The only training Jackson appears to have done under her own name was for cybersecurity awareness in 2010.

Christopher Horner, a researcher and senior fellow at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, who made the open-records request that led to the release of the certificates, stated, "At least her alter ego was up on the law and ethics of federal record-keeping."

In a letter acknowledging Horner's repeated prodding, EPA official Eric W. Wachter, director of the office of the secretariat, stated that it was not unusual for Jackson to get certified under her alias, as that was the account she was signed in as when she took the online testing.

EPA officials stated that Jackson kept the secondary address because her main email was published on the agency's website, and she needed a way to conduct agency business that wouldn't get lost in a flood of emails from the public that went to that official account. EPA said previous administrators, including those under Republican President George W. Bush, also had secondary emails for internal use.

However, Republicans countered that Jackson took the secondary email further than any of her predecessors, as she did not attach her real name to her secondary account. In response to a request from The ███, EPA officials could not say whether those prior administrators ever got certified under any of their aliases.

In a set of emails released to Horner earlier this year, it appears that Jackson used the email to pretend she really was Windsor. Horner argues that the secondary email matters because it wasn't clear that EPA was searching those records in response to open-records requests for Jackson's emails. Horner said that EPA didn't really begin to produce emails from the Richard Windsor account until after he exposed that address.

EPA contends that it did search the Windsor account as part of open-records requests. However, the agency has acknowledged it has fallen short in many transparency areas. In April, acting Administrator Bob Perciasepe wrote a letter telling all agency employees that they must do a better job of storing emails and computer instant messages, as required by law. He said all employees would have to retake training classes.

Title: The Legal Minds Behind the Health Care Case: Rivkin, Casey, McCollum, and Clement

Article:

The Supreme Court's upcoming decision on the future of President Barack Obama's health care reform law is poised to leave a significant impact on the court under Chief Justice John Roberts. However, the case also has the potential to define the careers of several legal minds who played a pivotal role in its inception.

In 2009, when Congress began debating health care reform, the individual mandate, the requirement for nearly all Americans to buy health insurance, was not a significant issue. This changed when a group of conservative legal scholars, including Rivkin and Casey, constitutional lawyers at the law firm Baker Hostetler, began writing articles suggesting the mandate could be the bill's real legal weak spot.

An op-ed by Rivkin and Casey in The Wall Street Journal in September 2009 served as the catalyst for the legal challenge to the mandate. After reviewing the health law, Rivkin and Casey concluded that the mandate was beyond the constitutional power of the federal government.

When it became clear that the 2010 health law was going to pass with a mandate, several states hired Rivkin and Casey to represent them in a lawsuit against the federal government. This lawsuit, which now includes 26 plaintiff states and the National Federation of Independent Business, was filed the day Obama signed the bill into law.

Rivkin represented some states in the district court and won, with Judge Roger Vinson ruling that the mandate was unconstitutional, and that the entire law should fall. Rivkin is confident the Supreme Court will rule against the mandate, arguing that the Obama administration has never defined a "limiting principle."

Bill McCollum, the Florida attorney general who hired Rivkin and Casey and filed the states' lawsuit against the health law, credits the Rivkin-Casey op-ed with sparking his interest in the issue. McCollum, who was working with then-South Carolina Attorney General Henry McMaster, asked his fellow attorneys general if they wanted to join. McCollum reported a significant level of interest, with one Democratic attorney general coming close but ultimately deciding not to join at the last minute due to political concerns.

McCollum, who always thought the constitutional issue would wind up in the country's highest court, was surprised by the suit's intense partisanship. Paul Clement, a former Solicitor General of the United States, represented the National Federation of Independent Business in the Supreme Court. Clement is also expected to play a significant role in the upcoming decision.

The Supreme Court's decision on the health care case is anticipated to define the court under Chief Justice John Roberts and potentially shape the careers of several legal minds who helped bring the case to the Supreme Court.

Title: Trump Disagrees with Fauci on School Reopening, Criticizes Political Motives Behind Slower Economy Reopening

Article:

In an interview with Fox Business Network's Maria Bartiromo, President Donald Trump expressed his belief that his political opponents want a slower reopening of the economy not due to the coronavirus threat, but to harm him politically in the November election. Trump also criticized Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), on the measures needed to reopen schools.

When asked if he thinks his political opponents want him to keep the economy closed going into the presidential election, Trump responded, "Yeah, I do. I do. I think it's a political thing." Trump also disagreed with Fauci on the reopening of schools, stating, "I totally disagree with him on schools."

In the same interview, Trump criticized Fauci's testimony about reopening schools during a hearing with the Senate Health Committee. Fauci did not necessarily weigh in on whether schools should open, but said it's unlikely a vaccine would be ready in time for the school year.

Trump also noted the United States' progress on coronavirus testing, a major benchmark many experts and governors have said is necessary to hit before moving to lift stay-at-home orders and business closures. Trump also highlighted that young people tend not to get as sick due to the coronavirus and have lower death rates.

However, this point, when made by Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., in the Tuesday Senate hearing, was a concern for Fauci. Fauci expressed that "We should be humble about what we do not know" and that "particularly when it comes to children, because the more and more we learn, we're seeing things about what this virus can do that we did not see from the studies in China or in Europe."

Trump also noted that Fauci has supported his earlier move to restrict travel from China in the earlier stages of the coronavirus outbreak. Fauci, in Senate testimony, warned of new coronavirus outbreaks if states jump "checkpoints" to reopen.

Trump also criticized the Chinese government, which knew about the coronavirus outbreak when it signed a trade deal with Trump in January. Trump stated, "I'm very disappointed in China, I will tell you, right now."

Trump has been pushing to reopen the economy as quickly as possible, emphasizing the harmful economic effects of keeping businesses closed and people out of work. However, Trump acknowledged health effects of keeping people under stay-at-home orders for such a long time, stating, "You know, people are dying this way too... they're dying of this closure... where they're in their house or their apartment... they're not allowed to go out."

Trump's comments come despite conservative reopening guidelines released by his own administration that Fauci emphasized need to be followed in his Tuesday testimony. Fauci warned that prematurely lifting coronavirus restrictions, closing schools and businesses, and limiting travel would lead to "suffering and death" and "turn the clock back instead of going forward."

Title: Republican Presidential Candidates Grapple with Immigration Policy as Key 2016 Campaign Issue

Article:

The 2016 presidential campaign is gearing up, and the issue of immigration is emerging as a significant challenge for the Republican party. The Republican field features a diverse range of positions on the question of handling the millions of people residing in the U.S. illegally, in contrast to the Democratic candidate, Hillary Clinton, who has advocated for a pathway to citizenship for many illegal immigrants.

Clinton's stance has been forceful, while the Republican field is characterized by a multitude of voices. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who once supported a path to citizenship, now advocates for legal status instead. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who was an architect of a broad immigration bill that included a citizenship path, now favors a piecemeal approach. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has reversed his stance on the issue, now opposing a pathway to citizenship, a position he previously supported.

Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is a critic of offering citizenship to illegal immigrants, but has not clarified whether they should eventually be allowed to earn legal status. Former Texas Governor Rick Perry and former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee both advocate for tightening border security, but are vague about subsequent policy.

An Associated Press-GfK survey released on May 6 found that 53% of respondents support a path to citizenship, while 50% expressed support for a path to legal status. Among Republicans, only 4 in 10 support allowing immigrants who arrived as children, along with parents of citizens or permanent residents, to legally remain.

The current stances of GOP candidates also present a campaign issue for Clinton, who, while campaigning this week in Nevada, stated that the Republicans' refusal to embrace a pathway to citizenship would relegate millions of people to underclass status.

Immigration is a crucial issue for Hispanic voters, according to Javier Palomarez, president and CEO of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. "Immigration is a unifying issue," he said. "Any candidate who can not speak to that is going to have an uphill climb."

Palomarez, whose group is engaging with presidential candidates from both parties, noted that GOP candidates are evolving on this complex issue and are moving away from some of the inflammatory rhetoric used in the past, such as Mitt Romney's 2012 call for illegal immigrants to "self-deport."

The dynamic within the Republican primary electorate differs significantly from the general-election landscape. For Jeb Bush, past support for a pathway to citizenship could potentially hinder his bid for the GOP nomination. Now, he focuses on granting legal status short of citizenship and overturning President Barack Obama's executive actions.

Senator Rubio, who is Cuban-American, helped write the 2013 Senate bill that included a path to citizenship for many illegal immigrants, enhanced border security, and other sweeping changes to the immigration system. He distanced himself from the legislation after it died in the House. Now, Rubio emphasizes the importance of border security and states that nothing can be done to put illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship until Americans are convinced the border is secure.

Walker earlier supported immigration legislation that offered a chance at citizenship to people here illegally. He has since renounced that position and argues that the jobs of U.S. citizens could be threatened by giving citizenship to illegal residents and even, potentially, by expanding legal immigration.

Responding to Clinton's call for a pathway to citizenship, Walker stated on Twitter that her "full embrace of amnesty is unfair to hardworking Americans & immigrants who followed the law to achieve these rights."

Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.) seemed to signal openness to granting legal status to undocumented workers last year, but he ended up voting against the Senate immigration bill that included such provisions, stating it did not do enough to secure the border.

Senator Cruz opposes citizenship for illegal immigrants, but at a session last week with the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, he deflected questions about whether he would support a pathway to legal status. Cruz stated that politicians should stay focused on advancing policies where there is consensus.

Title: Media's Portrayal of Hillary Clinton as 'Inevitable' Sparks Controversy

Article:

The media's portrayal of Hillary Clinton as an inevitable presidential candidate has sparked controversy, with some criticizing her for projecting an aura of inevitability. The media's depiction of Clinton began shortly after the 2012 election, with numerous magazine covers, interviews, and polls suggesting her as the front-runner for the Democratic nomination.

However, this narrative has faced criticism, with some arguing that Clinton is repeating the mistakes she made in 2008 by building a campaign machine before having a clear message. Barack Obama's former advisers and strategists have warned that Clinton's strategy is not effective, stating that she should avoid being perceived as the pre-emptive nominee.

White House pollster Joel Benenson and 2012 Obama campaign spokesman Ben LaBolt have expressed their concerns, stating that Clinton's top-heavy operation and lack of a clear message could harm her campaign. They argue that activists, donors, and voters prefer to see candidates fighting for every vote, rather than being perceived as inevitable.

Despite these criticisms, Clinton's lead in early polls against potential Republican opponents remains significant. A CNN poll showed her with a 55-39 lead over Chris Christie, while she leads every other major GOP contender by at least 15 points. However, it is important to note that early polls are largely meaningless.

Clinton's strategy of remaining low-profile until she officially announces her candidacy is a common tactic for front-runners. However, her unique political persona, as a potential first female president, wife of a controversial ex-president, and a political persona that overshadows all possible rivals, has led to a level of media attention that is unprecedented.

One of the criticisms leveled against Clinton is her lack of a warmer public persona. In an attempt to address this, Clinton has made an effort to show her warmer side, such as a Super Bowl tweet that poked fun at Fox News. However, this attempt has been met with overanalysis and criticism.

The biggest challenge Clinton will face, according to some analysts, is that by 2016, many people may be sick of her. She may be perceived as a status quo incumbent, running for a third Obama term, while the Republicans are promising change. This is why a lower-profile 2014 makes sense for Clinton, allowing her to retool for the Twitter age and avoid being overshadowed by the ongoing controversy surrounding the ObamaCare job loss report and the Senate's investigation into the Internal Revenue Service.

Title: White House Warns of Air Travel Delays and Reduced Airport Hours Due to Budget Cuts

Article:

The Obama administration has released a list of potential consequences if upcoming spending cuts, known as the sequester, are implemented. The list includes increased forest fires, workplace deaths, and potential chicken shortages, as well as significant air travel delays and reduced hours of operation or temporary closures of some airports.

Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood warned of these air travel delays during a briefing, suggesting that smaller airports, such as the one at golfing paradise Hilton Head, South Carolina, might have to reduce hours or close temporarily.

The Department of Transportation's budget for 2013 is $74.2 billion, and the automatic spending cuts would reduce this by $1 billion, equating to a cut of less than 1.4 percent. It is worth noting that even if the cuts are implemented, the Department of Transportation will spend more money this year ($73.2 billion) than it did last year ($72.6 billion).

Secretary LaHood stated that the Department of Transportation cannot find ways to save $1 billion without sending air traffic controllers home and that they cannot operate effectively with a budget that is larger than the budget they had last year. However, this raises questions about the government's ability to find relatively modest savings without cutting essential services.

When asked about finding alternative ways to cut without furloughing air traffic controllers, LaHood responded, "This has to be a part of it. DOT has 55,000 employees. The largest number of those employees are at the FAA, and the largest number of those employees are controllers, and they're all over the country. There has to be some impact in order to save a billion dollars. A billion dollars is a lot of money."

It is important to note that although the cuts are set to take effect on March 1, most of the impact will not be felt until weeks or even months after that date. Federal employees will receive 30 days' notice that they may have to take unpaid leave (furlough). The first furloughs can therefore not happen until March 31 at the earliest. For employees of the Department of Transportation, the most they will be asked to take is one unpaid day off every two weeks.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney defended the administration's warnings, stating, "I think all of those things come from reduced, you know, numbers of people fighting fires, you know, reduced numbers of people doing inspections of our food, reduced numbers of people, you know, engaging in air traffic control." Carney added, "I mean, those are just the facts."

For more information on the potential consequences of the spending cuts, readers are referred to a list compiled by Chris Good of ███.

Title: Donald Trump Jr. Met with UAE and Saudi Arabian Representatives in 2016

Article:

Washington ( ███ ) - Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of the U.S. President, met with an envoy representing the crown princes of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Saudi Arabia in August 2016. The meeting was first reported by The New York Times on Saturday and was later confirmed by an attorney representing Trump Jr.

The meeting, held on Aug. 3, 2016, was a chance for the envoy to offer help to the Trump presidential campaign, according to The New York Times. The newspaper said the meeting was arranged by Erik Prince, the founder and former head of private military contractor Blackwater, who also attended the meeting. Joel Zamel, a co-founder of an Israeli consulting firm, was also in attendance.

Alan Futerfas, Trump Jr.'s attorney, said on Saturday that nothing came of the meeting. "Prior to the 2016 election, Donald Trump Jr. recalls a meeting with Erik Prince, George Nader, and another individual who may be Joel Zamel. They pitched Mr. Trump Jr. on a social media platform or marketing strategy. He was not interested and that was the end of it," Futerfas said in an emailed statement.

A company connected to Zamel also worked on a proposal for a "covert multimillion-dollar online manipulation campaign" to help Trump, utilizing thousands of fake social media accounts, the New York Times report said.

The envoy, Lebanese-American businessman George Nader, told Trump Jr. that the crown princes of Saudi Arabia and the UAE were eager to help his father win the 2016 presidential election, the paper said.

Since 1974, the United States has barred foreign nationals from giving money to political campaigns and it later barred them from donating to political parties. The campaign financing laws also prohibit foreign nationals from coordinating with a campaign and from buying an ad that explicitly calls for the election or defeat of a candidate.

The Saudi and UAE embassies in Washington did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The Wall Street Journal last month reported that investigators working for U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller had met with Zamel, and that Mueller's team was looking into his firm's work and his relationship with Nader.

Mueller is investigating whether Russia meddled in the presidential election and if Moscow colluded with the Trump campaign, as well as whether Trump committed obstruction of justice by trying to thwart the U.S. Department of Justice probe. Trump has denied any collusion with Russia and has called the Mueller investigation a "witch hunt."

The New York Times report said the meetings are an indication that other countries besides Russia may have offered help to Trump's presidential campaign. Mueller's investigators have questioned witnesses in Washington, New York, Atlanta, Tel Aviv, and elsewhere regarding possible foreign help to the campaign, the report said.

Peter Carr, a spokesman for Mueller's team, declined to comment on the report.

Zamel's attorney, Marc Mukasey, said in a statement to ███ that his client "offered nothing to the Trump campaign, received nothing from the Trump campaign, delivered nothing to the Trump campaign, and was not solicited by, or asked to do anything for, the Trump campaign."

"Media reports about Mr. Zamel's engaging in'social media manipulation' are uninformed," Mukasey added. "Mr. Zamel's companies harvest publicly available information for lawful use."

Kathryn Ruemmler, Nader's lawyer, told the paper that her client "has fully cooperated with the U.S. special counsel's investigation and will continue to do so."

Erik Prince, who is also the brother of U.S. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, could not be immediately reached for comment.

Title: U.S. and China Resume Trade Talks Amidst Ongoing Disagreements and Uncertainty

Article:

President Donald Trump criticized China for its alleged unwillingness to purchase American agricultural products, accusing the nation of "ripping off" the U.S. as negotiations resumed in Shanghai following a three-month hiatus. Trump stated on Twitter that China has not shown signs of buying agricultural products, contradicting the expectation that they would start purchasing these products now.

Trump also mentioned that the U.S. has "all the cards" and warned that if he is re-elected in 2020, China will face a much tougher deal. He referred to Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden as "Sleepy Joe."

China's state media refuted Trump's comments without naming him, stating that China has no intention of "ripping off" the U.S. and has not done so. The People's Daily, the Communist Party's flagship newspaper, criticized the U.S. for threatening China into making concessions, suggesting that this tactic will ultimately fail.

Stocks slid earlier in the day following Trump's criticism, with the S&P 500 Index closing lower for a second consecutive day. China's imports of U.S. soybeans dropped to the lowest level since at least 2004.

The U.S. delegation, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, arrived in Shanghai for another round of talks with their Chinese counterparts. The talks are scheduled to continue on Wednesday in China's bustling port city.

Expectations for a breakthrough in the trade talks remain low, with the two sides further apart than they were three months ago when negotiations broke down. China is pushing for compromise, with state media underlining this week that the U.S. should meet China "halfway."

It is unclear what triggered Trump's latest outburst. U.S. soybean exports to China slumped in the first half of the year to the lowest level in more than a decade, while pork sales in June decreased from the previous month.

China has stated that the purchase of American farming products will be contingent on the U.S. following through on Trump's pledge to allow American companies to resume sales to Huawei Technologies Co. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that he has received more than 50 applications for special licenses for companies to do business with Huawei, and that he and Trump met with "supply chain" representatives last week. The administration put the Chinese telecommunications giant on a trade blacklist in May, which means American firms need a special license issued by the Commerce Department to ship to the company.

The Shanghai talks should help determine whether China will resume negotiations from a draft text agreed before the impasse in May, or wait for the 2020 election, or propose another solution. Michael Pillsbury, director of the Center on Chinese Strategy at the Hudson Institute, stated on Tuesday that this could be a "real suspense."

Title: Infowars' Alex Jones Shouts at a Pile of Manure During Trump-Cruz Rally

Article:

During a campaign rally in Houston, Texas, on October 22, 2018, Infowars' Alex Jones was seen shouting at a pile of manure, which he addressed as if it were Beto O'Rourke, the Texas Democrat challenging incumbent Republican Senator Ted Cruz. The incident occurred before the rally, a few blocks away from the venue.

The rally, ostensibly organized to support Senator Cruz, was also attended by President Donald Trump. However, Cruz seemed to be an afterthought throughout the event, with speakers mentioning him only in general terms. The focus was primarily on criticizing O'Rourke and portraying him as a radical caricature.

Trump, who earlier in the day referred to Cruz as "Beautiful Ted," had a few kind words for Cruz at the rally but was more animated talking about other Republican politicians or subjects. The president spent a significant amount of time discussing the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh and his administration's record of appointing justices.

In a separate incident, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is reportedly going after a website that sold abortion-inducing drugs. The website, Aid Access, has been shipping the drugs from an Indian pharmacy to women in the U.S. for the past six months, in response to what the site's founder said was an overwhelming demand from American women. The FDA is investigating the website for allegedly bypassing the strict distribution protocol for the drug mifepristone, which can only be distributed at pre-approved clinics, hospitals, and private practices.

Title: President Obama Declares "Captive Nations Week" Amidst Syria Crisis, Criticism of Response

Article:

In the midst of growing criticism over his response to the political and humanitarian crisis in Syria, President Barack Obama signed a proclamation on Monday declaring "Captive Nations Week." The proclamation, which has been a routine practice by presidents since Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1959, makes no direct reference to the Syrian conflict.

In the proclamation, President Obama stated, "As individuals rise to demand their universal rights, the United States stands with them in pursuit of equality, justice, and freedom." He further declared, "And as long as there are people who live in the darkness of oppression, America will remain their steadfast friend, linked by a common dream and our common ideals."

The Syrian crisis, where forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad have reportedly killed nearly 15,000 civilians in 16 months of open revolt against the regime, is not mentioned in the proclamation.

Douglas Feith, a former undersecretary of defense in the administration of President George W. Bush, criticized President Obama's handling of the Syrian crisis. In an article published Monday in the Wall Street Journal, Mr. Feith stated that the Obama administration has not taken significant action, such as establishing humanitarian "safe zones" on Syria's Turkish border, providing arms to the rebels, or supporting NATO military strikes against Assad's forces.

Russia, a key ally of the Syrian regime, accused the West of attempting to use blackmail to secure a new U.N. Security Council resolution that could allow the use of force in Syria. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov stated that the Kremlin has no intention of supporting a British proposal to enact U.N. sanctions to resolve the crisis.

The U.S. has consistently supported sanctions, which the Obama administration has stepped up as the crisis has deepened. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton also worked with the U.N. Security Council and U.N. envoy Kofi Annan on a June 30 accord calling on Syrians to come up with a political transition.

A mandate for a U.N. observer force is set to expire on July 20, and Mr. Lavrov accused the West of using the deadline as a bargaining chip. "To our great regret, there are elements of blackmail," Mr. Lavrov said. "We are being told that if you do not agree to passing the resolution under Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, then we shall refuse to extend the mandate of the monitoring mission."

Mr. Feith criticized President Obama for ceding U.S. sovereignty to the United Nations in the debate. "By refusing to act on Syria, the president is missing an opportunity to advance U.S. security interests in the Middle East, while benefiting Iran, the principal sponsor of the Assad regime," Mr. Feith said. "And by suggesting that America lacks international legal authority to act, he is undermining U.S. sovereignty."

In the "Captive Nations" proclamation, President Obama reaffirmed America's commitment to supporting oppressed peoples. "America renews our abiding ties to all peoples who struggle to claim their inalienable rights," the president said. "As strongly as my administration condemns tyranny, we embrace emerging democracies and welcome the chance to work with those who seek to restore their people's liberty."

Title: Bipartisan Call for International Investigation into China's Handling of COVID-19

Article:

A bipartisan push for an international investigation into China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has emerged on Capitol Hill, with Republicans calling for accountability over the Communist Chinese Party's (CCP) alleged cover-up of the virus.

Representative Elise Stefanik (R-NY) and Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO), two rising stars in the Republican party, have proposed a resolution to launch an international investigation into the CCP's handling and cover-up of the virus, which has turned into a global health pandemic.

Senator Hawley stated in a release, "Since day one, the Chinese Communist Party intentionally lied to the world about the origin of this pandemic. The CCP was aware of the reality of the virus as early as December but ordered laboratories to destroy samples and forced doctors to keep silent. It is time for an international investigation into the role their cover-up played in the spread of this devastating pandemic. The CCP must be held to account for what the world is now suffering."

Representative Stefanik is introducing the resolution in the House of Representatives. She stated, "There is no doubt that China’s unconscionable decision to orchestrate an elaborate coverup of the wide-ranging and deadly implications of coronavirus led to the death of thousands of people, including hundreds of Americans and climbing. This Resolution calls for China to provide compensation for the harm, loss, and destruction their arrogance brought upon the rest of the world. Simply put – China must, and will, be held accountable."

The legislation's purpose is to not only investigate the knowledge that the CCP had, and declined to share, about the virus, but also to condemn the widespread harm caused by the Chinese government. As of now, Democrats have refused to concede any criticism toward the CCP for the large hand it played in the spread of the virus. However, the communist regime must be held to account for its intentional negligence.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Condemns Rep. Don Young's Use of Offensive Term

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner, a Republican from Ohio, has condemned the use of the term "wetbacks" by Representative Don Young, a senior member of the Republican Party from Alaska, in a statement released on Friday. Young's remark, followed by a quick apology, comes at a sensitive time for the Republican Party in its relationship with Hispanic voters.

In November, Latinos voted overwhelmingly for President Obama, and the GOP is currently navigating calls for changes in immigration law, with more party leaders now backing a so-called path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, a position opposed by many conservatives.

Young used the term "wetbacks" in describing Hispanic migrant workers who used to work on his father's family ranch. He made the comments in an interview released Thursday with an Alaska radio station.

"My father had a ranch. We used to hire 50 or 60 wetbacks and — to pick tomatoes," Young said. "You know, it takes two people to pick the same tomatoes now. It's all done by machine."

In a later statement, Young, 79, who has spent four decades in Alaska's only U.S. House seat, said he "meant no disrespect" in using the term, a slur for Mexicans crossing illegally into the United States. The Alaska Dispatch reported the apology:

"During a sit-down interview with Ketchikan Public Radio this week, I used a term that was commonly used during my days growing up on a farm in Central California. I know that this term is not used in the same way nowadays and I meant no disrespect."

Migrant workers play an important role in America's workforce, and earlier in the interview, Young discussed the compassion and understanding he has for these workers and the hurdles they face in obtaining citizenship. America must once and for all tackle the issue of immigration reform, he added.

Title: Justice Department Declines to File Federal Civil Rights Charges Against NYPD Officer Involved in Eric Garner's Death

Article:

The Justice Department on Monday declined to file federal civil rights charges against New York Police Department (NYPD) officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was involved in the chokehold death of Eric Garner in 2014. The decision comes one day before the fifth anniversary of Garner's death and the expiration of the statute of limitations.

Garner, a 43-year-old father of six, was ruled a homicide in August 2014. His dying words, "I can't breathe," on July 17, 2014, became a national rallying cry for demonstrations about police treatment of minorities. Eric Garner's mother, Gwen Carr, after a meeting with federal prosecutors in Brooklyn, stated, "The Justice Department has failed us."

A Staten Island grand jury chose not to indict Officer Pantaleo on any state criminal charges four months after Garner's death. The Justice Department's decision was made by Attorney General William Barr, who took the Eastern District of New York's recommendation not to prosecute over the department's civil rights division's recommendation to move forward with a prosecution.

According to a senior official, the decision was made due to the Justice Department's inability to establish the willful intent requirement. The official stated that the legal analysis surrounding Pantaleo's actions would have been different had he been a civilian that had engaged in a chokehold against Garner.

Patrolmen's Benevolent Association (PBA) President Patrick J. Lynch commented, "In both cases, a careful review of the facts led investigators to the truth, although Mr. Garner’s death was an undeniable tragedy, Police Officer Pantaleo did not cause it." Lynch further stated, "Scapegoating a good and honorable officer, who was doing his job in the manner he was taught, will not heal the wounds this case has caused for our entire city."

The PBA President also expressed confidence that if the NYPD decides the disciplinary case on the facts, free of improper political influence, that Officer Pantaleo will be fully exonerated of any wrongdoing.

Title: Twin Explosions Near Iranian Embassy in Beirut Kill 20, Stir Regional Tensions

Article:

Two explosions near the Iranian embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday have left at least 20 people dead, including an Iranian official, in what some observers are calling a clear sign of deepening sectarian divisions across the region. The attacks are believed to be motivated by the ongoing civil war in Syria.

The incidents occurred in the southern Jnah district, where the Iranian embassy is located. According to The Los Angeles Times, a "chaotic scene" unfolded after two suicide bombers—one on foot and one in a car—detonated their explosives. The BBC reports that at least 100 people were injured, and the Iranian ambassador to Beirut confirmed the death of Iranian cultural attache Ebrahim Ansari, who had been in his post for only a month.

The perpetrators of the attack are not yet clear, but the Lebanese Sunni jihadi group the Abdullah Azzam Brigades has reportedly claimed responsibility, according to the BBC. The group is said to have sent a "clear message."

The area has been hit by a series of attacks in recent months, and Lebanon as a whole has witnessed cross-border rocket attacks by Syrian rebels into Shiite areas, deadly car bomb attacks against Sunni and Shiite targets, sectarian clashes, and several roadside bomb attacks against suspected Hezbollah vehicles, according to a report by The ███.

Lebanon's Prime Minister Najib Mikati told state news agency NNA that the aim of the blast was to "stir up the situation in Lebanon and use the Lebanese arena to convey messages."

Iran and Hezbollah, Lebanon's largest political group, are major backers of the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad. Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, recently announced that the group would continue to send its militiamen to Syria to fight alongside government forces, drawing condemnation from anti-Assad groups in both Lebanon and Syria. Lebanese officials, keen to avoid their nation being drawn into Syria's civil war, have declared a policy of neutrality in the Syrian war.

The attacks took place in the context of the Syrian government aggressively pushing back against rebel fighters on three fronts, including one in the region of Qalamoun along the Lebanese border, according to The New York Times. There have long been fears that if fighting in Syria continues, it will drag Lebanon into chaos.

Hezbollah's involvement in supporting the Syrian government is countered by the involvement of Sunni Lebanese fighting in Syria on behalf of the rebels. In addition, Lebanon, a country of about 4 million people, is now host to upwards of 1 million Syrian refugees.

The Monitor's Nicholas Blanford wrote a series on the regional stakes of Syria's war and noted that if there is one outright "winner" there, it could critically affect Lebanon's stability. It is difficult to envisage an ideal outcome for Lebanon if one side or the other triumphs in Syria. If the Assad regime manages to cling to power and reduce the threat posed by the rebels, Hezbollah will remain strong in Lebanon, and the cross-regional alliance between the Shiite group and its backers in Damascus and Tehran will endure. Such a scenario will deepen Sunni grievances in Lebanon and leave unresolved the continuing domestic debate over Hezbollah's status. If the Assad regime falls and is replaced by a Sunni regime that moves closer to Saudi Arabia and the Sunni Gulf, Hezbollah will be isolated from Iran and will feel dangerously vulnerable. Any move by a newly emboldened Sunni community in Lebanon against a Hezbollah that still would be determined to retain its arms could exacerbate an already precarious security climate. Perhaps the best scenario for Lebanon is a negotiated solution in Syria which compels rival actors to make compromises.

However, despite attacks and bombings on Lebanese soil, Syria still isn't tipping Lebanon toward its own civil war, according to The Monitor's Nicholas Blanford.

Title: AOC Acknowledges Age Limit for Vice Presidency, Discusses Endorsement of Sen. Bernie Sanders

Article:

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) expressed her desire to serve as vice president in a recent Spanish-language interview, but acknowledged that her age disqualifies her from holding the position. The U.S. Constitution stipulates that the vice president and the president must be at least 35 years old.

In the interview with "Noticias Telemundo" correspondent Guadalupe Venegas, Ocasio-Cortez, a 30-year-old freshman congresswoman, stated, "It would be an honor to be vice president, but I can't because I'm not old enough."

Ocasio-Cortez delivered a keynote address at Sen. Bernie Sanders' (I-Vt.) Spanish-language town hall in Las Vegas on Sunday. She endorsed Sanders for the White House in October and could play a significant role in his efforts to secure Nevada's large Latino vote, differentiating him from fellow progressive Sen. Elizabeth Warren.

Ocasio-Cortez worked as a community organizer for Sanders during the last presidential campaign, marking her first experience organizing for an election. She described this experience as an important part of her decision to run for Congress.

In the same interview, Ocasio-Cortez, whose mother is Puerto Rican, emphasized the importance of preserving her Spanish language. She stated, "If we are first- or second-generation, it is important that we cultivate our language. I must speak and practice more to improve my own Spanish. Our language is the link with our families and our communities."

Ocasio-Cortez had previously expressed nervousness about hosting the town hall in Spanish due to her infrequent use of the language. She also discussed her personal journey over the past year and a half, having worked as a waitress and bartender in a taqueria before being elected as a congresswoman.

"Last year I worked in a taqueria, as a waitress and as a bartender, and now I am a congresswoman," she said. "That is a huge change. But my values are the same. And we are saying the same thing we were saying last year: that we must fight for working families, for health insurance, for education for all children, and a fair salary."

Title: U.S. Secretary of State Warns Russia of Consequences for Actions in Ukraine

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry issued a stern warning to Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday, urging him to reverse his actions in Ukraine or face "grave" and "costly" consequences from the international community. Kerry's statement, delivered in the State Department briefing room, marked the most detailed and direct warning from U.S. leaders regarding Russia's activities in Eastern Ukraine.

Kerry outlined a list of covert and destabilizing actions he said Russia has pursued against Ukraine over the past week, including disciplined paramilitary groups occupying Ukrainian government buildings, arrests of undercover Russian intelligence agents, and the kidnappings and murders of local Ukrainian officials and journalists.

President Obama, on a four-nation tour of Asia, also warned of tougher economic sanctions from the West and stated, "We are ready to act." Obama's comments followed Putin's Thursday warning to the Ukrainian government that it would face "consequences" for moving against pro-Russia separatists in Eastern Ukraine.

Appearing to presage deeper Russian intervention, Putin said Russia would "have to react to such developments." Ukrainian security forces, attempting to clear roadblocks and take back barricaded government buildings in Eastern Ukraine, killed as many as five separatists on Thursday.

Kerry's statement suggested a final warning shot, as the U.S., Russia, the European Union, and Ukraine had been meeting last week to forge a stabilization plan to end the Ukraine standoff. However, while the Kiev government was complying with the plan, Kerry said Russia was escalating activities designed to undermine and provoke the Kiev government.

Kerry's statement offered numerous examples of the subversion he was referring to, such as paramilitary groups in new but unmarked uniforms occupying Ukrainian government buildings, arrests of undercover Russian intelligence agents, and the kidnappings and murders of local Ukrainian officials and journalists.

Insisting that the world is not being fooled by Russia's "propaganda" and "President Putin's fantasy" of peaceful but besieged Russian-speaking protesters, Kerry said, "Russia is stoking the very instability they say they want to quell."

Putin and other Russian officials have dismissed the impact of existing or potential Western sanctions on the Russian economy. However, Kerry offered statistics suggesting the Russian economy is already hurting from sanctions imposed over the Crimea annexation. He also cited some Russian officials acknowledging the blow sanctions have already struck, particularly to foreign investment and the confidence of foreign investors in considering Russia in the current climate.

However, some analysts are less confident than Kerry appears to be that the "international community" will be united in imposing a new round of broader sanctions on sectors of the Russian economy. Experts considering sanctions at a Washington forum sponsored by the Center for Strategic and International Studies on Thursday underscored that Western Europe remains reliant on Russian energy and is likely to find it difficult to replace that energy in time for next winter.

Additionally, some experts note that the European Union is not united on imposing broad sector sanctions, and that some Europeans could be sympathetic to a Russian claim, if it moved into Ukraine, that it acted to restore order where a civil war threatened.

"I can imagine the Russians claiming they acted to stop the unrest and reestablish order, and if they take that to the Germans and maybe some others, that could fall on some sympathetic ears, and we could see some breaks in a united Western front," says Nikolas Gvosdev, a specialist in Russian security affairs at the Naval War College in Newport, R.I. "That would put Obama in a tough spot."

Title: U.S. Urged to Provide Diplomatic Support for Guaidó, Avoid Military Intervention in Venezuela

The Venezuelan crisis has escalated as the Maduro regime continues to destabilize the country, with the United Nations estimating over 5 million Venezuelan refugees by the end of this year. The United States is urged to provide diplomatic and logistical support for Juan Guaidó, the interim president recognized by many world governments, while avoiding military intervention.

Guaidó, who has not been arrested by the Maduro regime despite recent arrests of hundreds of opponents, is facing increased pressure as Tuesday's actions may prompt the regime to take action against him. The odds of Guaidó ending up dead, in jail, or in the presidential palace are seen as significantly higher due to the escalating conflict.

The key to resolving the crisis appears to be whether the military will abandon the regime, as officers and soldiers who join the revolt risk being targeted if the government prevails. Those who remain loyal to Maduro may face less severe consequences if he falls, as the new government may find it more urgent to bring them on board than to punish them.

The U.S. posturing is seen as potentially tainting the opposition, and there is concern that strong words may lead Guaidó and his supporters to believe that Washington will use force on their behalf. This could induce them to take unwise risks and potentially lead to U.S. involvement in a foreign conflict where interests and understanding are minimal.

In the 2020 U.S. presidential race, Elizabeth Warren is noted for providing more detail on Medicare financing than her competitors, including Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg. However, her Medicare plan, which forces people to join, is seen as a weakness due to the sizable public anxiety about radical changes to the health care system. Warren is urged to come up with a reassuring transition plan soon.

Finally, the impeachment inquiry against President Trump is focused on the circumstances and context of his actions, as there is no explicit quid pro quo proposal regarding the restarting of aid. The investigation will determine whether there is enough evidence to support impeachment and removal from office.

Title: US Senate Passes Tax Cuts Bill, Marking First Major Legislative Victory for President Trump

Article:

The United States Senate has passed a sweeping tax cuts bill, marking President Donald Trump's first significant legislative victory. The package, which represents the biggest tax overhaul since the 1980s, was passed by a vote of 51 to 49 after a series of amendments in a marathon session.

The bill, known as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, sees a significant reduction in the corporate tax rate, from 35% to 20%. The measures were passed despite a non-partisan Senate Joint Committee on Taxation warning that the bill would add $1tn (£742bn) to the budget deficit over a decade.

The House of Representatives passed a similar bill last month and will now need to merge their legislation with the Senate's version before it can be signed into law by the president. The House and Senate must then smooth out differences in their bills and vote on the compromise.

President Trump, speaking at a New York fundraiser on Saturday, said, "So last night we passed in the history of the country, the largest tax cuts and reform... We're going to grow the country, we're going to grow jobs. We're going to be growing everything."

The move is a significant victory for President Trump, who has faced challenges in getting major legislative movement in Congress, including his promise to repeal and replace Obamacare. His presidency has also been marked by an independent investigation into Russian attempts to influence the 2016 US election and possible collusion with his campaign team. On Friday, former national security adviser Michael Flynn became the Trump administration's most senior member to be charged in the investigation.

The Senate, a seemingly insurmountable roadblock for the Republican agenda for much of this year, has at last given its assent to a major piece of legislation. The bill was not without controversy, with Senate negotiators making last-minute amendments to the massive bill up until the final votes were taken.

Most Americans across all income levels would see modest tax breaks until 2026, and the Senate Joint Committee on Taxation said after that families earning under $75,000 a year would likely face higher taxes. Some opponents highlighted a measure that would end a requirement introduced under Obamacare for most taxpayers to buy health insurance or face a fine.

The final draft of the bill went through several changes in order to bring reluctant Republicans on board. Republicans have a 52-48 majority in the Senate. Under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the corporate tax rate would be permanently lowered from 35% to 20%, while future foreign profits of US-based firms would be mainly exempt from tax.

Title: Congressional Delegation Tours Tornillo Tent City, Calls for Closure of Immigrant Teen Facility

Article:

A group of five Democratic members of Congress, led by Representative Beto O'Rourke, toured a remote tent city in West Texas on Saturday where approximately 2,700 immigrant teenagers are being held at a daily cost of around $1 million. The lawmakers urged the nonprofit running the facility not to renew a federal contract that expires on December 31, a move that could potentially shutter the camp.

The group, which included Senators Mazie Hirono of Hawaii, Jeff Merkley of Oregon, Tina Smith of Minnesota, and California Representative Judy Chu, was not allowed to speak to the children in a meaningful way during the visit. O'Rourke, a potential 2020 presidential candidate, expressed concern about the children's lack of engagement and described the facility as a "child prison."

Tornillo, located just outside El Paso, Texas, has taken on a permanent feel with soccer fields, a dining facility, and separate sleeping quarters for boys and girls. The facility was initially intended to be a temporary solution during an alleged emergency situation on the U.S.-Mexico border, but it has since grown in size and taken in more children.

O'Rourke made no mention of his potential White House aspirations after making his fourth visit to the camp. He noted the area's remote location, stating that it was intentionally isolated to keep the American public unaware of the conditions within the facility.

The lawmakers reported that the contractor running the facility, BCFS Health and Human Services, has cost taxpayers $144 million since its opening. The Democrats urged BCFS Health and Human Services to refuse to renew its contract with the U.S. government, but they were unsure where the children would be transferred if the facility were to close.

The lawmakers described touring the tents housing the teenagers but were only able to ask light questions. O'Rourke reportedly asked a few of the children about their countries of origin, and they responded with Guatemala and Honduras. The children reportedly assured him that the conditions were "OK."

Tornillo opened in June as a temporary facility amid the Trump administration's description of an emergency situation on the U.S.-Mexico border. Since then, the contract keeping it open has been renewed, and the number of children being held inside has grown, though the rate of growth has been difficult to determine.

The lawmakers reported that many of the teenagers have family members already in the United States who wish to take them. However, federal authorities have conducted fingerprinting and background checks on would-be "sponsors," resulting in 170 apprehensions on possible immigration violations. The contractor also reported that 1,300 children have relatives ready to take them but have remained at Tornillo due to unexplained federal delays.

Public pressure could potentially force federal authorities to close Tornillo, according to O'Rourke, but in the meantime, federal policies are causing the country to "turn our backs on these people." The Associated Press previously reported that the Trump administration waived FBI fingerprint checks for caregivers and experienced short-staffing in mental health workers at Tornillo.

Title: Trump's New Negotiating Strategy Yields Government Reopening, Raises Questions for Democrats

Article:

The three-day government shutdown ended Monday night, with President Donald Trump adopting a more reserved approach during the impasse. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) criticized the president, stating, "The great deal-making president sat on the sidelines." However, it was Schumer who ultimately led a retreat on the shutdown, a move that many Democrats attributed to the White House's new strategy.

Politico reported that the president's "stand-back-and-watch" approach was effective, putting pressure on Senate leaders to reach an agreement to reopen the government without White House intervention. This strategy reportedly delivered Trump a significant victory.

In his new book, "Media Madness: Donald Trump, The Press, And The War Over the Truth," Fox News "MediaBuzz" host Howard Kurtz reveals that Trump aides have coined a term for the president's tendency to act against advice: "Defiance Disorder." The phrase refers to Trump's apparent compulsion to act against the advice of his advisers, leaving his team to manage the fallout.

During the government shutdown negotiations, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) advised Trump not to engage with Democrats like Schumer to strike a grand bargain. Instead, Trump followed McConnell's advice, and the new strategy proved successful.

The government shutdown strategy's failure also sparked a mini-civil war within the ranks of congressional Democrats. Rep. Luis Gutiérrez (D-Ill.), a strong advocate for immigrants, criticized Senate Democrats for blinking during the standoff. Rep. Gwen Moore (D-Wis.) questioned the Senate's motives, while House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) confirmed their concerns.

After a year in office, Trump aides believe they have new tools in their negotiating arsenal. One White House aide stated, "No one is saying Trump won't be Trump, and he knows how to pivot and attack better than anyone. But he is also figuring out that timing is everything, and you sometimes have to wait and let your adversaries trip over themselves."

Democrats have historically dealt with a president who overreacts to taunts and provocations. However, they lost this time due to the president's change in tactics and his ability to outmaneuver them. As the midterm elections approach, Democrats may come to realize that the 71-year-old Trump has learned new tricks and may surprise them again.

Title: Romney Shifts Focus Away from Foreign Policy Controversy in Virginia Rally

Article:

In a rally held in Fairfax, Virginia on Thursday, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney attempted to refocus his campaign on economic and military issues, following a controversy over his criticism of President Obama's handling of events in Libya and Egypt. The rally was held a day after Romney's remarks on the Libyan and Egyptian unrest sparked a debate.

Romney began his speech by expressing his condolences for the four American diplomats who lost their lives in the recent attacks, including Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other embassy staffers. He emphasized the tragic loss of these individuals who had served the country with distinction.

During the speech, a heckler interrupted, questioning Romney's politicization of the Libya situation. The crowd attempted to drown out the heckler with chants of "Mitt" and "U-S-A!". In response, Romney said, "I would offer a moment of silence, but one gentleman does not want to be silent, so we're going to keep on going."

President Obama, meanwhile, traveled to Golden, Colorado on Thursday, where he spoke about improving the economy and vowed to find those responsible for the death of Ambassador Stevens. He stated, "I want people around the world to hear me: To all those who would do us harm, no act of terror will go unpunished. It will not dim the light of the values that we proudly present to the rest of the world."

In a development on Thursday, Libyan officials informed the U.S. that four individuals were in custody in connection with the attack.

During his speech in Virginia, Romney reiterated his vision of a strong United States that "shapes events" in the world. He emphasized the importance of a strong America in shaping global events.

Title: Vandalism Reported at Catholic Church in New Haven, Connecticut, Part of Ongoing Trend of Church Desecration in the U.S.

Article:

A Catholic church in New Haven, Connecticut, has reported vandalism, marking another incident in a series of church desecrations across the United States. Pastor John Paul Walker of St. Mary's Parish, which comprises both St. Mary's Catholic Church and St. Joseph's Catholic Church, announced in a Thursday Facebook post that St. Joseph's Church was vandalized between 9 p.m. on Wednesday and 6 a.m. on Thursday.

The Archdiocese of Hartford also confirmed the incident via a Facebook post, stating that "a person or group of persons had painted anarchist and satanic symbols on the doors of St. Joseph Church in New Haven."

Pastor Walker wrote in his post that this incident appears to be part of a trend of desecrating Catholic spaces across the nation, citing incidents in Chattanooga, Queens, Boston, Sacramento, and Ocala. He described the underlying motive of these sacrilegious attacks as an attempt to intimidate and instill fear in those who worship Christ.

The pastor expressed confidence in the resilience of the Catholic faith, which has endured for over 2,000 years, and stated that the church would continue to pray for the conversion of hearts of those who wish to terrorize them. He did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The New Haven police did not immediately respond to requests for comment from ███ News Foundation on the matter.

This report follows the confirmation by Fr. Wilbert Chin Jon of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Calgary on Thursday that vandals spray painted and used marker or chalk to deface a statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus at Sacred Heart Church in Calgary, Alberta on Tuesday around 1:30 a.m.

Numerous other statues of the Virgin Mary have also been vandalized throughout the country.

Title: Trump's Job Approval Rating Drops Amid Economic Concerns and Recession Fears

Article:

A new poll by ABC News and The Washington Post shows a decline in President Donald Trump's job approval rating, with six in ten Americans expressing concerns about a potential recession and higher prices due to the trade war with China. Trump's approval rating has dropped from a career-high 44% in July to 38% currently, marking a significant decrease in public support.

The poll indicates that Trump has slipped by 5 percentage points specifically on his handling of the economy, with 46% now approving of his economic management compared to 51% in midsummer. Furthermore, only 35% approve of his handling of trade negotiations with China, and 60% are concerned that the trade dispute will raise the price of goods they purchase.

The overall rating of the U.S. economy, at 56% positive, has decreased from 65% last fall in this poll. Notably, 60% of respondents see a recession as very or somewhat likely in the next year, which is close to the 69% who expressed similar concerns in November 2007, prior to the Great Recession.

In another measure, Trump receives far more criticism than credit for his economic stewardship. Americans by nearly a 3-1 margin, 43-16%, say his trade and economic policies have increased rather than decreased the chance of a recession in the next year.

Economic attitudes are found to be highly partisan, with 90% of Republicans rating the economy positively, compared to 52% of independents and 33% of Democrats. One in three Republicans sees a recession as very or somewhat likely in the next year, while this rises to 60% of independents and 83% of Democrats.

The statistical analysis, called regression, supports these findings. Controlling for demographics, partisanship, and political ideology, seeing a recession as more likely independently predicts lower approval for Trump, as do both being concerned about paying more because of the trade dispute with China and holding more negative views of the economy overall.

Economic anxiety is nearly as high in the red states Trump won in 2016 as in the blue states, with 58% in red states seeing a recession as very or somewhat likely, compared to 63% in blue states. Trump's overall approval rating is underwater in the red states, 43%, compared to 32% in the blue states.

The president's approval rating varies widely among groups, with significant declines in approval among urban residents, college graduates, and women. Trump's approval rating is 47% among men, 30% among women, and he has lost 10 points among urban residents, 9 points among college graduates, and 8 points among women since July.

Trump's approval rating among white men who don't have a college degree remains high at 69%, but he has lost 12 points among non-college white women, to 42%, and 15 points among college-educated white men, to 34%. College-educated white men and women now express similar levels of criticism towards the president.

Lastly, Trump has 82% approval among Republicans, back near his career average after peaking at 87% in July. Trump's approval rating is 8% among Democrats, and among independents, it is 36%.

This ABC News/Washington Post poll was conducted from September 2-5, 2019, among a random national sample of 1,003 adults. The results have a margin of sampling error of 3.5 points, including the design effect. Partisan divisions are 28-24-37% Democrats-Republicans-independents. The survey was produced for ABC News by Langer Research Associates of New York, New York, with sampling and data collection by Abt Associates of Rockville, Md. See details on the survey's methodology here.

Title: Senate Considering Additional Sanctions on Iran's Nuclear Program

Article:

The United States Senate is currently discussing potential further sanctions against Iran in response to concerns about Iran's nuclear program. If diplomatic efforts fail to persuade Iran to dismantle or significantly reduce its nuclear program, the new sanctions would provide the President with the authority to swiftly and decisively pressure Iran into a mutually acceptable agreement.

Historically, the Senate has played a significant role in shaping American foreign policy, with key decisions such as the Alaska Purchase in 1867, the United Nations' establishment in 1945, the Marshall Plan in 1948, and the authorization of World War I, World War II, and the Persian Gulf Wars.

The Senate's role in foreign policy has been instrumental in the careers of numerous influential politicians, including J. William Fulbright, Chuck Percy, Jacob Javits, John Kerry, Joe Biden, and Hillary Clinton.

The current discussion on additional sanctions against Iran stems from the potential threat a nuclear Iran poses to regional stability and global security. Iran is reportedly close to developing an atomic bomb, which would significantly increase its influence in the Middle East and potentially threaten countries such as Israel, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates.

Domestically, the Iranian nuclear program enjoys broad support among the Iranian population, with 80% of Iranians favoring the program. Nuclear weapons would also deter any potential Western intervention, as seen in 1941 and 1953, when the Iranian regime was not overthrown.

A nuclear Iran could trigger an arms race in the Middle East, with several countries likely acquiring nuclear weapons. This would embolden radical Islamist forces in the region and discourage more moderate, pro-American states, potentially leading to increased instability.

By 2020, Iran may possess Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles (ICBMs) capable of reaching the East Coast of the United States. Before then, Iran may be able to target Western and Central Europe with nuclear weapons.

The diplomatic effort to dismantle the Iranian nuclear program is crucial to American national security, as tough sanctions have already brought Iran to the negotiating table for the first time. Iran's economy is highly vulnerable to economic sanctions, as indicated by its low ranking in various global economic and business indices.

The effectiveness of sanctions in compelling Iran to negotiate has been demonstrated in the past, such as during the 1987 Iran-Iraq War, when Grand Ayatollah Khomeini ended the war under extreme economic pressure. Similarly, the American invasion of Iraq in 2003 led to a slowdown in Iran's nuclear program.

The new round of sanctions is expected to provide President Obama with the leverage needed to compel Iran to dismantle its nuclear weapons program.

Title: U.S. Accuses Qatar of Cheating on Airline Subsidies, Raising Concerns for Trade Deals

Article:

The Trump administration has imposed additional tariffs on selected goods imported from China, following through on the president's campaign promise to secure fair trade deals. Critics argue that tariffs, which are essentially taxes, lead to higher prices for U.S. consumers and provide a safe haven for inefficiencies, shielding markets and manufacturers from the need to innovate and increase productivity.

However, the administration's strategy seems to have yielded results, as new trade deals are being discussed with Europe, Japan, Mexico, and Canada. The tariff strategy has been successful in the past, and the administration claims it is a short-term measure to pressure China into protecting American intellectual property.

Meanwhile, the U.S. is facing a different challenge with Qatar, a self-proclaimed U.S. ally and host to the largest American military base in the Gulf. Qatar is allegedly circumventing an Open Skies agreement, which aims to enable open entry into a nation's airspace, by operating Air Italy, a carrier it purchased a 49% share in and rebranded.

Air Italy, which offers bargain-rate flights to several U.S. cities, is using Qatari aircraft, financing, and personnel, leading U.S. carriers and lawmakers to accuse Qatar of cheating on the agreement. American advocates on Capitol Hill, including Senators Ted Cruz (Republican) and Bob Menendez (Democrat), are urging the Trump administration to take action against Qatar.

If Qatar Airways continues to use Air Italy as a proxy, it could send a message to other major U.S. trading partners that they can agree to trade deals and cheat without consequences. This issue underscores the need for the U.S. to hold Qatar accountable, not just for its own actions but for the message it sends to other nations.

Title: Indictment Alleges Negligence in Jeffrey Epstein's Death, Citing Overtime Shift Lapses by Correction Officers

Article:

An indictment has been unsealed, alleging negligence in the death of Jeffrey Epstein, the financier who was found dead in his jail cell on August 10, 2019. The indictment, released on Thursday, details the actions of two correction officers, Tiffany M. Doe (Ms. Noel) and Thomas B. Kiernan (Mr. Thomas), on the night of Epstein's death.

According to the indictment, Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas were both working overtime shifts on the day of Epstein's death. Ms. Noel, a correction officer since 2016, and Mr. Thomas, who started in 2007, were supposed to check on Epstein and other inmates every half-hour.

The indictment states that Epstein was escorted into his cell by Ms. Noel and another guard shortly before 8 p.m. Inmates were locked in their cells for the night by 10 p.m., but the indictment alleges that between 10:30 p.m. and the following morning, Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas did not perform their duties. Instead, they reportedly sat at their desk, browsed the internet, and moved around the common area. They also allegedly signed "count sheets" stating they had checked on inmates multiple times overnight, when they had not.

The indictment further claims that when Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas entered Epstein's cell the following morning, they found him unresponsive with a noose around his neck. When a supervisor arrived, the guards admitted they had not properly performed their duties.

Kathleen Hawk Sawyer, the director of the Bureau of Prisons, released a statement saying the agency is taking the allegations of misconduct "very seriously" and that they "will be responded to appropriately."

The indictment does not specify the nature of the charges against Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas. The full details of the indictment are yet to be made public.

Title: White House Announces Executive Order to Raise Minimum Wage in New Federal Contracts

Article:

In a significant move, President Obama will announce during his State of the Union address tonight that he will sign an executive order raising the minimum wage in new federal contracts from the current national minimum of $7.25 an hour to $10.10 an hour. The change applies only to new federal contracts and not to renewals of existing agreements.

The announcement comes as the White House, under the leadership of senior adviser John Podesta, is reportedly adopting a more executive-focused approach to governance. According to Podesta, the White House and the Justice Department agree that Obama has the authority to take such executive actions in the coming year, where there is agreement between the two bodies.

During the State of the Union address, which begins shortly after 9 p.m. ET, Obama will also renew his push for an increase in the federal minimum wage for all workers.
