In addition to discussing the executive order, Obama will make the case for a bilateral security agreement with Afghanistan, and touch on signs of economic recovery, outlining the administration's plans for continued growth.

The White House has been proactive in using executive orders to advance its agenda, particularly in areas such as retirement security, climate change, and energy transformation. Podesta stated that across a wide range of topics, there is a lot that Obama has the authority to do. However, there will likely be arguments about whether some such actions usurp congressional powers and are therefore unconstitutional.

For further preview of the State of the Union address, please refer to this post from It's All Politics: 5 Things To Expect In Obama's State of the Union Address. The White House will provide live blogging and streaming of the speech and NPR's coverage. Come back as the time approaches.

Title: Putin Claims Convincing Trump on Russia's Non-Involvement in U.S. Election

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on Saturday that he believes he managed to convince President Donald Trump that Russia did not interfere in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. The discussion regarding Russian meddling in the election was the primary topic during the first face-to-face meeting between the two leaders on Friday.

During the meeting on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, Mr. Putin reiterated his denials that Moscow was involved in the election interference. "He asked many questions on that subject," said Mr. Putin. "I answered those questions as best I could."

Mr. Putin provided his assessment of Mr. Trump's reaction during a press conference in Hamburg. The meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Putin was overshadowed by the ongoing controversy surrounding Russian interference in the election and unsubstantiated allegations of Trump campaign collusion.

President Trump has faced criticism for expressing doubt about Russian interference in the election, despite several U.S. intelligence agencies believing Russia was responsible. Mr. Trump stated on Thursday that he believed Russia was involved but that other countries or individuals could also have been involved.

The interference included the spread of disinformation during the campaign, as well as hacking into emails at the Democratic National Committee and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign officials, exposing embarrassing information. However, there is no evidence that the efforts impacted the outcome of the election.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who attended the meeting, said Mr. Trump opened the discussion by pressing Mr. Putin about election interference and a "very robust and lengthy exchange" ensued. "The president pressed President Putin on more than one occasion regarding Russian involvement," he said.

The highly anticipated sit-down, which was scheduled for 30 minutes but lasted for 2 hours and 15 minutes, also covered a Syrian cease-fire agreement, Russia's disputed annexation of Crimea, and the fight against ISIS and radical Islamic terrorism.

Mr. Putin stated at the press conference that he believed he and Mr. Trump could cooperate on a range of issues. "As for personal relations," said Mr. Putin, "I think that they are established." He added, "I think that if we continue building our relations like during our conversation yesterday, there are grounds to believe that we'll be able to — at least partially — restore the level of cooperation that we need."

Correction: An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated that Mr. Putin delivered his remarks in an interview with the Russian news network RT. In fact, he delivered his remarks at a press conference.

Title: Iowa Caucuses Reveal Next President Will Not Be a Governor

Article:

The Iowa caucuses have narrowed the field of potential Republican presidential candidates, with the next president unlikely to be a governor. This development is surprising, as a year ago, many predicted the next president would be a Republican governor.

Initially, the frontrunners were expected to be former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, or Texas Governor Rick Perry. If these candidates failed to gain traction, Ohio Governor John Kasich, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee were ready to step in. Perry, in particular, had a strong narrative, having created more jobs in Texas than all other states during his tenure as governor.

However, Walker, Jindal, and Huckabee have since dropped out of the race, leaving Bush, Kasich, and Christie as the remaining contenders. These three candidates combined received approximately the same number of votes as surgeon Ben Carson, who finished in fourth place. Despite Bush spending millions in Iowa, these three candidates are considered nonentities. They are now pinning their hopes on a strong showing in New Hampshire, with Kasich being the only one with a viable chance.

The decline of the governors can be attributed to the public's disdain for politicians and their experience becoming a liability. Even their successes were dismissed. The more John Kasich boasted of his impressive budget-balancing feats, the more conservatives concluded that he had been in office for too long.

Jeb Bush, who was arguably the most qualified for the Oval Office, was criticized for his perceived lack of conservatism despite his record of tax cuts, school choice initiatives, and pro-life stance. The governors' campaigns were also criticized for being tone-deaf to voter anger, with Bush's focus on fundraising and Kasich's acceptance of Medicaid funds from Obamacare being particular points of contention.

Despite the current political climate, governing effectively should not be a liability. Governors have demonstrated their ability to cut taxes, balance budgets, and implement reforms. The art of politics involves finding common ground and working with opposing parties to achieve policy goals. Ronald Reagan, a steadfast conservative, was able to make deals and achieve bipartisan support for his policies.

The three remaining candidates, Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio, have yet to govern. While they are admirable in their own right, the lack of governorship experience is a concern. It remains to be seen whether one of these candidates will tap a governor as their running mate to balance their lack of executive experience. The talent pool of governors is deep, and there are many capable individuals who could contribute to a successful administration.

Title: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Sets Final Deadline for Trump Tax Returns

Article:

In a letter to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on Saturday, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal (D-Mass.) set an April 23 deadline for the IRS to provide President Donald Trump's tax returns. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has stated that the administration is studying the legal questions involved, without confirming whether they will meet the deadline.

If the deadline passes without the documents or a resolution to the dispute, House Democrats and the Trump administration could potentially face a court battle. The administration missed an earlier April 10 deadline, with Mnuchin citing consultations with the Justice Department regarding the law and the legitimacy of Neal's request.

Under the tax code, Neal is entitled to receive the six years of business and personal returns of Trump that he requested, according to Neal's letter to IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig. Neal argued that the law clearly entitles him to the requested tax returns and return information.

In his letter, Neal stated, "It is not the proper function of the IRS, Treasury, or Justice to question or second guess the motivations of the Committee or its reasonable determinations regarding its need for the requested tax returns and return information."

If the IRS fails to hand over the records by the April 23 deadline, Neal has indicated he may issue a subpoena or seek to enforce the law in federal court. The legal question would extend beyond the language of the statute and consider the extent of constitutional constraints on legislative inquiries.

Matthew Leas, an IRS spokesman, declined to comment on Neal's letter. Mnuchin stated that Treasury officials are working diligently on the legal issues, and he expressed concerns about the potential weaponization of the IRS.

"This is a decision that has enormous precedence in potentially weaponizing the IRS," Mnuchin said at the conclusion of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings in Washington. "The implications of this is way beyond, in my mind, a congressional oversight issue and a president issue. The issue is, I feel a responsibility that we get this right and the IRS does not become weaponized like it was under the Nixon administration."

Trump has broken with four decades of precedent by refusing to release his tax returns. He has stated that he would release his returns after an audit is complete. Although a public release might complicate his audit, no law prevents Trump from revealing his returns at any time.

Neal has used the president's argument against a voluntary release and turned it into his rationale for a mandatory handover of the returns, arguing that the committee needs to determine if the IRS is conducting the audits properly. Neal has also requested administrative files relating to any audits of the president or some of his business entities.

A subsequent committee vote would be required to publicly release all or part of the returns. The administration has not formally denied Neal's request, but Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, has stated that Democrats would "never" receive the returns. Trump's personal lawyer, William Consovoy, has urged the IRS to resist the request.

Title: Stock Market Suffers Significant Drop, Led by Technology Sector and Apple

Article:

The stock market experienced a substantial decline on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing down 264.26 points, or 1.5%, at 16,945.80. This marks the fourth consecutive day of triple-digit moves for Wall Street. The Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 32.31 points, or 1.6%, to finish at 1,965.99. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite ended down 88.47 points, or 1.9%, at 4,466.75.

The decline was primarily driven by a 3.8% drop in Apple Inc. (AAPL) shares, which closed below $98. The tech giant's shares have fallen for two consecutive days due to reported issues with its new phones and operating system.

The Dow gained 154 points on Wednesday, but all other triple-digit moves since it set a new closing high on Friday have been downward. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 have also been down for four out of the past five sessions.

The rising volatility on Wall Street is causing concern, as the stock market had previously enjoyed a long period of relatively uneventful trading earlier in September. The "fear gauge," a measure of volatility, jumped 25% on Thursday.

Analysts are worried about the buildup of complacency among investors and the approach of what could be a disappointing third-quarter earnings season, potentially leading to more trouble in the weeks ahead. However, the current losses are relatively minor, with the Dow and S&P both down roughly 2% from their record highs set last week.

In economic news, durable goods orders plunged 18.2% in August, largely due to a sharp drop in aircraft orders. Orders for durable goods excluding the volatile transportation category rose 0.7%. Applications for unemployment benefits rose 12,000 to a seasonally adjusted 293,000 last week, despite the rise, applications remain near pre-recession levels.

Asian markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei index jumping 0.3% to 16,734.14 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index falling 0.6% to 23,768.13. European markets were trading lower, with Britain's FTSE 100 dropping 1% and Germany's DAX falling 1.6%.

Title: Alternate Campaign Reality: Romney Leads in Unskewed Polls, According to Online Source

Article:

In an alternate political landscape, Mitt Romney is leading in nearly every national poll released in September, according to a specific website, unskewedpolls.com. This online source adjusts public polling data to include more Republicans in the sample.

While the traditional political narrative portrays Romney trailing in various national polls, this parallel universe presents a different story. In this alternate reality, Romney is predicted to win by 4 or 5 points in states like Florida, Ohio, Virginia, Nevada, and Pennsylvania, according to conservative pundit Dick Morris on Fox News.

Conservative talk radio host Rush Limbaugh also suggests a more sinister motive behind the media and university polls, claiming they are designed to depress and suppress Republican voter turnout. He argues that these polls are intended to convince the public that the election is already over.

The divide between Republican political consultants and conservative media figures is well-documented. Operatives must operate in the real world due to their job requirements, while media figures like Morris and Limbaugh have different motivations, such as building their email lists and audience. They often criticize the mainstream media to appeal to their conservative audience.

The website unskewedpolls.com is not the only example of this alternate campaign reality. Texas Governor Rick Perry has also referenced the site on Twitter, praising its "unskewed" information. However, it is important to note that arbitrarily reweighting polls is considered wildly unscientific by professional pollsters and political analysts.

Title: Trump Legal Team Leans Against President's Interview with Mueller's Team

Article:

President Donald Trump and Special Counsel Robert Mueller's potential interview could mark a significant development in the ongoing Russia investigation. The interview could be the final and most important question in the prolonged standoff between Trump and Mueller.

Critics view Mueller's investigation as a significant distraction for the White House, as the president navigates complex issues such as international trade and a historic summit with North Korea's Kim Jong Un. On the other hand, Mueller's supporters argue that he needs to complete his investigation.

One of the key figures in the investigation, former FBI director James Comey, is expected to face scrutiny in an upcoming report by the Justice Department inspector general. According to ABC, a source claims the draft report labels Comey as "insubordinate" for his actions during the Hillary Clinton email probe.

Comey played a role in initiating Mueller's probe, having leaked some of his conversations with President Trump in an attempt to prompt a special counsel investigation into Russia.

The investigation has raised several questions, including whether the president has the power to pardon himself, a topic that has divided legal experts. However, the most pressing issue remains whether the president will agree to an interview with Mueller's team. Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, stated in an exclusive interview with ███ Founder Pat Robertson that the legal team is leaning against the interview.

"I have to just be honest," Giuliani said. "We're leaning toward not [agreeing to testimony]. But look, if they can convince us that it would be brief, it would be the point, there are five or six points they have to clarify. And with that, we can get this over, this long nightmare for the American public over."

If Mueller subpoenas Trump to testify, it would not be due to Giuliani's team accepting the subpoena, and this could lead to a lengthy legal battle potentially reaching the Supreme Court. The full interview with Rudy Giuliani can be watched on The 700 Club on Thursday.

Title: John W. Dean Discusses Watergate: A Comprehensive Account of the Mother of All Modern Political Scandals

Article:

John W. Dean, former counsel to the president during the Nixon White House, discusses his book "The Nixon Defense: What He Knew and When He Knew It" and his biweekly column for Verdict at Justia.com. Dean was interviewed by Wolf Blitzer on CNN during the 6 p.m. hour on Wednesday, and the story of Watergate will be featured on CNN's "The Seventies" at 9 p.m. ET on Thursday.

Dean, who was in the middle of the Watergate scandal during his tenure as White House counsel, has spent the past 40 years studying the extensive record of the Watergate scandal as it has gradually surfaced in testimony, autobiographies, diaries, released documents, secret tape recordings, FBI investigative files, grand juries, Senate Watergate and House impeachment committees, and extensive federal court civil and criminal records.

Dean questions whether the nation wants to repeat the mistakes of the 1970s, particularly Watergate. The scandal began on June 17, 1972, with the arrest of five burglars dressed in business suits, carrying new $100 bills and electronic bugging equipment, during President Richard M. Nixon's re-election campaign. When one of the men arrested was identified as the director of security for the Committee to Reelect the President, suspicion immediately focused on the Nixon White House.

As the cover-up unfolded, Dean, who was out of the country at the time, returned to Washington and understood that a cover-up was being launched. He learned that the same men involved in the Watergate break-in had undertaken an earlier operation for the White House by breaking into and ransacking the files of a psychiatrist treating Daniel Ellsberg, who had leaked the Pentagon Papers a year earlier.

Dean states that while he has never found any evidence that Nixon knew in advance of or ordered the Watergate break-in, he does know that Nixon had ordered an earlier break-in at the Brookings Institution when he believed they had a copy of the Pentagon Papers. The tapes and written documents show that had the Watergate burglars not been arrested at the Democratic headquarters on June 17, they would have gone on to their true mission that night, which was to break in and bug the campaign headquarters of Nixon's Democratic opponent, Sen. George McGovern of South Dakota.

Watergate did not end with Nixon's resignation and departure from the White House on August 9, 1974. Rather, it played out for many months more in headline-grabbing events during the cover-up trial of his top aides, including former chief of staff H.R. "Bob" Haldeman, former top domestic affairs adviser John D. Ehrlichman, and former attorney general John N. Mitchell, who would be found guilty of perjury and obstruction of justice on January 1, 1975.

Dean admits his own guilt in the cover-up and believes that only the truth can help the nation learn from the past. He was unwilling to write the bogus report about Watergate that the President wanted him to write and told him everyone involved needed to resign. He was fired, and when the President and his former colleagues sought to make him their scapegoat, it did not work out so well - Dean had the truth on his side, as the tapes proved.

This segment of CNN's series on the 1970s tells this story as it happened. CNN, Playtone, and HBO have not only told the story honestly but have uncovered video footage of the events long buried in archives, bringing to life memorable moments from these historic events. The program is informative, engaging, and accurate.

Title: US Calls for De-escalation as G7 Agrees on Swift Sanctions Against Russia Over Ukraine

Article:

The United States has reported that Russian military aircraft have entered Ukrainian airspace on multiple occasions, amid escalating tension in eastern Ukraine. A Pentagon spokesman has called for Russia to "de-escalate the situation." The statement was issued as the Group of Seven (G7) industrialized countries agreed on Saturday to swiftly impose new sanctions on Russia over Ukraine.

The G7 joint statement emphasized the need for Russia to take "concrete actions in support of the Geneva accord." However, they noted that Russia has yet to comply with the agreement, which was signed last week, calling for separatists to vacate official premises and surrender their weapons.

The G7 statement also expressed concern over the seizure of international observers by separatists in Ukraine. Negotiations are currently underway to secure the release of these observers, who were seized by separatists.

Russia has tens of thousands of troops stationed along its border with Ukraine, with pro-Moscow separatists occupying official buildings in a dozen eastern towns, defying the government in Kiev. Russia has accused the West of attempting to seize Ukraine.

On Friday, Pentagon spokesman Col. Steven Warren stated that Russian aircraft had entered Ukrainian airspace several times within the past 24 hours. He provided no further details but urged Moscow to take "immediate steps to de-escalate the situation."

U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel previously described Russian activity along the Ukrainian border as "dangerously destabilizing" and "very provocative."

Last weekend, Ukraine and Russia reached an agreement in Geneva, calling for separatists to leave official premises and give up their arms. The pact included an amnesty for those who left peacefully. However, pro-Russian activists have so far refused to comply with the demands.

The unrest in Ukraine began last November over whether the country should lean towards Moscow or the West. Last month, Russia annexed Ukraine's mainly ethnic-Russian Crimean peninsula, following a referendum in the region that supported joining the Russian Federation but was deemed illegal by the West and Kiev.

On Friday, Ukraine's interior ministry reported that armed separatists had seized seven representatives from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), as well as five Ukrainian army personnel and a bus driver. Pro-Russian leaders in Sloviansk confirmed the bus had been stopped near the town of Sloviansk and were checking the identities of those on board.

The self-proclaimed mayor of Sloviansk, Vyacheslav Ponomaryov, stated that at least one passenger had been carrying maps showing separatist checkpoints in the area, which suggested "their involvement in espionage."

Tensions have risen in recent days as Ukraine launched military raids to regain occupied buildings. At least two separatists have been killed in these raids, which Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov described as a "bloody crime." Mr. Lavrov repeated the accusation made previously by Moscow that Ukraine is waging a war against its own people.

Title: Trump's China Policy: A Closer Look at the Challenges and Potential Consequences

Article:

President Donald Trump's policy agenda, particularly his stance on trade with China, has been a subject of concern for many, with fears of a potential trade war and its impact on the global economy. During his meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping this week, Trump reiterated his concerns about alleged unfair trade practices by China.

While a full-blown trade war between the two largest economies would have immediate and negative consequences for workers and consumers worldwide, the global trade system has deep-seated flaws that are related to China, not Trump. For years, China has been welcomed into global trade linkages, with the expectation that it would play by the rules of commerce as other nations do. However, trade experts argue that China has not lived up to these expectations, violating both the letter and spirit of global trade rules.

Trump's election win, in part, stemmed from the resonance of his critique of trade policies as harmful to U.S. workers. While outside experts may not share the president's broad brush, some argue that a tougher stance toward China is needed. A damaging trade war may not be the most likely outcome, and the "just be patient" strategy carries its own deep risks.

Robert Atkinson, an economist who studies the ties between global trade and national economic performance, argues that China is a unique challenge due to its size and its determination to leverage its market power to acquire a leadership role in advanced industries, from aerospace to computing. When Beijing doesn't play by accepted rules, the damage to other nations, including the U.S., is considerable.

Under President Barack Obama, the office of the U.S. Trade Representative ramped up its engagement on alleged violations by China. The USTR's annual report covering 2016 lists settlements reached with China last year over subsidies, taxes, or other policies in industries including aircraft, autos, financial information, wind power, and green technologies. This signifies that progress can be made when pressure is applied.

However, critics of China's trade policies argue that much more needs to change. One of the biggest sore spots is the way foreign companies doing business in China are pressured to transfer knowledge to Chinese partner firms in industries such as aerospace. The World Trade Organization prohibits countries from making such demands, yet the Chinese arrangements are, in practice, hard to prosecute.

Edward Alden, a trade expert at the Council on Foreign Relations, notes that the issues are not just about manufacturing jobs but about making China a fairer partner for the world. Jamie Dimon, CEO of the banking firm JPMorgan Chase, also singled out China for "serious trade issues" in his annual letter to shareholders.

As Trump and Xi met at the Trump-branded Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, there were few early signs of either progress or breakdown. The outcome of their discussions remains uncertain, with Trump himself stating that "we've had a long discussion already, and so far I have gotten nothing, absolutely nothing. But we have developed a friendship – I can see that – and I think long term we are going to have a very, very great relationship and I look very much forward to it."

The friendly comment raises questions about whether Trump will go soft on China, as some critics suggest some of his predecessors have. However, it's too early to gauge the tenor of Trump's policies, with his trade team still incomplete and some of his appointees differing in tone. One crucial decision will be how much to seek a broader international coalition to press China. Trump has voiced a penchant for bilateral dealing and dealmaking, but many experts argue that working with allies is more effective than working alone.

Atkinson argues that the goal isn't to block China's development but to insist on a rule-of-law system under which all parties can benefit. Coupled with innovation policies to maintain America's dynamism at home, such a strategy could avert the potential loss of key industries. "When we have pushed the Chinese in the past, in a respectful but firm way with our allies, we have prevailed," Atkinson says.

Title: Iowa Caucus Results Signal Long-Term Struggle for Democratic Party

Article:

The results of the Iowa Democratic caucus have shown a close race between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, with Clinton narrowly winning by a margin of 0.3 percentage points. The victory, however, has been described as a statistical tie, with Clinton receiving 49.9% of the vote and Sanders receiving 49.6%. The margin of victory in the delegate count was decided by six coin tosses, which have been a source of controversy among Sanders' supporters.

Clinton's victory has been met with criticism and complaints from Sanders' supporters, who allege irregularities and biased coin tosses. A crushing defeat would have been worse for Clinton, but this close result has not been much better. The nature of this victory has led to lawyerly qualifications and caveats from Clinton's campaign, and her supporters have been criticized for overselling the win and appearing disconnected from reality.

The close results of the Iowa caucus have raised concerns about the Democratic Party's future. The ghost of Eugene McCarthy, a left-wing senator who challenged President Johnson in the 1968 New Hampshire primary, has been invoked as a reminder of the potential for a left-wing candidate to challenge a sitting president. However, in this case, Clinton is not an incumbent president, and the close results in Iowa and New Hampshire may not have the same impact.

The close results in Iowa have effectively ended any possibility of a Democratic savior entering the race to challenge Clinton and Sanders. With Clinton's victory in Iowa, it is likely that she will go on to lose in New Hampshire and then grind out a victory over many months, potentially antagonizing Sanders' supporters. The Democratic Party is now stuck with the candidates they have, and the close results in Iowa have raised concerns about the party's ability to unite and win in November.

Jonah Goldberg, an American Enterprise Institute fellow and National Review contributing editor, is a member of ███'s Board of Contributors. In addition to its own editorials, ███ publishes diverse opinions from outside writers, including its Board of Contributors. To read more columns like this, go to the Opinion front page.

Title: US Deploys Additional Troops to Southern Border, Bringing Total to 4,300

Article:

The United States Department of Defense has announced the deployment of an additional 2,000 troops to the U.S.-Mexico border, bringing the total number of troops stationed there to approximately 4,300. The soldiers will assist border-patrol agents, carry out surveillance work, and install miles of razor wire.

The decision comes amidst President Donald Trump's ongoing battle with Congress over funding for a proposed wall along the border. The President has emphasized the need for such a measure to curb illegal immigration. The President's insistence on including wall funds in the U.S. budget led to the longest government shutdown in U.S. history. A temporary deal was struck last month to reopen government departments, but the President has threatened to initiate another shutdown or declare a national emergency if his demands are not met. The current agreement expires on February 15.

President Trump is expected to address the issue in his annual State of the Union speech on Tuesday. The U.S. Department of Defense initially announced that 3,750 extra soldiers would be sent to the border, with many replacing troops already there. The first deployments took place in November.

According to a Pentagon statement, these troops will perform tasks such as providing a mobile surveillance capability through September 2019 and emplacing approximately 150 miles of concertina wire between ports of entry. Last Thursday, President Trump tweeted that extra forces were being sent to the border to stop migrants traveling in "caravans" and threatening an "invasion." He reiterated his claims on Sunday, tweeting, "If there is no wall, there is no security."

President Trump has repeatedly described the situation on the Mexican border as a "crisis," although his critics have dismissed the use of troops as a political stunt. It is worth noting that President Barack Obama sent some 1,200 National Guard soldiers to guard the boundary, while President George W. Bush deployed about 6,000 troops to help Border Patrol agents in what was called Operation Jump Start.

In related news, officials in Texas recently revealed that nine migrants on hunger strike at an immigration detention center were being force-fed. Immigration officials are using plastic nasal tubes to feed some of the men, but relatives claim this is causing severe nosebleeds and vomiting. The detainees have refused food in protest against conditions at the El Paso Processing Center. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) says a federal judge authorized the force-feeding last month.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Practices During Tenure as Secretary of State Found to Disregard Cyber Security Guidelines

Article:

In a report by the State Department's Inspector General (IG), it has been found that Hillary Clinton, during her tenure as Secretary of State, disregarded cybersecurity guidelines when she used a private computer server for official communications. Clinton has continued to deny any wrongdoing and has falsely claimed that she turned over all her emails to the State Department after leaving office.

However, it was discovered that Clinton, or members of her team, deleted about 30,000 of these emails before an investigation began. The IG's report criticizes Clinton, stating that she should have preserved any federal records she created and received on her personal account by printing and filing them with the related files in the Office of the Secretary.

The IG's report also mentions that Clinton did not comply with the Department's policies that were implemented in accordance with the Federal Records Act. The report suggests that Clinton should have surrendered all emails dealing with Department business before leaving government service.

The IG's report also highlights Clinton's resistance to government requests for access to her server, which was located in her Chappaqua, N.Y., home, with another discovered at an unsecured location in a Denver bathroom closet. Marcel Lazar, a Romanian computer hacker known as "Guccifer," claimed to have hacked into Clinton's servers. Lazar pled guilty to the charge before a Virginia judge this week.

Hillary Clinton has claimed that she only used private email for her daughter's wedding and yoga classes. However, this claim has been met with skepticism, as high-ranking government officials are aware of the regulations governing their tenure while in office and their responsibilities for the handling of records once they leave it.

The IG's report also refutes Clinton's defense that she complied with the necessary notifications when a user suspects compromise of a personally owned device containing personally identifiable information. The IG found "no evidence" that Clinton or her aides complied with this requirement.

For years, the Clintons have been accused of skirting laws and practicing disinformation, obfuscation, changing the subject, non sequiturs, and other tactics to block their enrichment or achievement of political goals. This time, it is crucial that Hillary Clinton is not allowed to evade accountability for her actions, and her incidents of malfeasance should not be rewarded by being elected as the President of the United States.

Title: President Obama to Deliver Major Economic Speech in Midwest, Avoids Detroit Bailout Discussion

Article:

President Barack Obama will travel to the Midwest this week to deliver a major speech on economic revival, bypassing Detroit, which has been a subject of controversy due to its bankruptcy status and the ongoing debate over a potential federal bailout. The president will visit Galesburg, Illinois, and Warrensburg, Missouri, to promote his domestic agenda, with an address at Knox College in Illinois.

The speech, set for Wednesday, will outline the president's vision for rebuilding an economy that prioritizes the middle class and those striving to join it. White House senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer stated that the president's speech will "kick off a series of speeches that will lay out his vision for rebuilding an economy that puts the middle class and those fighting to join it front and center."

The speech is also intended to help the president regain control of his second term, which has been overshadowed by scandals such as Benghazi, secret surveillance, and the abuse of Internal Revenue Service powers. According to Pfeiffer, the president will discuss economic steps he will take on his own, steps that Congress should take, and actions that private industry can accomplish to bolster the economy. He also aims to set the terms of the debate for upcoming budget and debt limit battles with Congress.

The plight of Detroit, facing over $18 billion in debt and significant pension obligations, has dominated economic news in recent weeks. Detroit filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection on Thursday. Some, including former "car czar" Steven Rattner, have called for federal intervention, but the White House has not indicated plans to provide financial aid to the city.

Vice President Joe Biden expressed less certainty, stating that "we don't know at this point" whether the administration can help Detroit. He added that aides are studying the details. In April, Detroit's emergency manager, Kevyn Orr, met with senior White House officials, but no formal bailout request was made, and no offer was put on the table.

The bankruptcy filing was approved by Michigan Governor Rick Snyder, a Republican, but a judge in Michigan ruled on Friday that the bankruptcy filing violates the state's constitution and must be withdrawn. The state's Attorney General, Bill Schuette, is appealing the ruling.

During his re-election campaign last year, Mr. Obama emphasized his role in saving Detroit's auto industry with an $80 billion federal bailout in 2009. However, Michigan's congressional delegation has not pushed for a federal bailout for the city.

In addition to the economic speech, President Obama will use the stops in Illinois and Missouri to make his case for spending on infrastructure and for universal preschool programs. He is also expected to highlight the economic benefits of comprehensive immigration reform. The White House chose Knox College as the site of Mr. Obama's speech because it was the same place where he delivered his first economic speech on the national stage as a U.S. senator in 2005.

Title: Moderate House Republicans Call for Compromise on Government Shutdown

Article:

Some House Republicans, facing challenging reelection prospects in 2014, are softening their stance on the government shutdown, advocating for compromise and moving away from the fight over defunding Obamacare.

Virginia Rep. Scott Rigell stated, "Republicans fought the good fight. The fight continues but is not advanced by a government shutdown that damages our economy and harms our military." He called for a "clean CR" to reopen the government. Pennsylvania Rep. Pat Meehan said, "I came to Washington to fix government, not shut it down. At this point, I believe it's time for the House to vote for a clean, short-term funding bill to bring the Senate to the table and negotiate a responsible compromise."

New Jersey Rep. Jon Runyan also expressed a similar sentiment, stating, "Enough is enough. Put a clean (continuing resolution) on the floor and let's get on with the business we were sent to do."

Lawmakers like Rigell, Meehan, and Runyan, who represent moderate districts, may have the most to lose if the American public turns against the House GOP's role in the shutdown. Rigell's military-heavy district, encompassing the Hampton Roads area, was narrowly carried by President Barack Obama in 2012. Mitt Romney won Meehan's suburban Philadelphia district by a slight margin. Obama carried Runyan's south central New Jersey district by four percentage points.

Rigell, Meehan, and Runyan join two other Republicans from moderate districts – New York Rep. Peter King and Pennsylvania Rep. Charlie Dent – who have been vocal in trying to persuade the House GOP to abandon its fight.

New Jersey Rep. Frank LoBiondo, who represents an Atlantic City-area seat that Obama won by eight percentage points, has expressed discontent with the House GOP's strategy. The 10-term congressman was quoted in the Philadelphia Inquirer as saying, "At a certain point, if the strategy is not going to get us a result or a conclusion, I'm not going to go along with it...I want to see a result. The bigger fight's coming on the debt limit."

Another endangered Republican, Illinois Rep. Rodney Davis, stopped short of urging his party to concede but emphasized his desire to reach an agreement. Davis, a freshman incumbent who represents a nearly evenly divided district between Democrats and Republicans, stated, "Like most of those I represent, I remain opposed to Obamacare, but a government shutdown is absolutely unacceptable."

A host of vulnerable GOP incumbents have faced criticism from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which, on Tuesday, launched an automated call campaign criticizing them and 60 other Republicans over the shutdown. The DCCC also labeled Davis as a member of the "Too Little, Too Late Caucus."

Title: American Health Care Act Addresses Key Obamacare Issues, Despite Criticism from Conservatives

Article:

The American Health Care Act, the first iteration of the Republican plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), has faced criticism from conservatives since its inception. The editors of Investor's Business Daily argue that the bill "supports all the key elements of Obamacare." However, a closer examination of the bill reveals that it addresses several key issues that conservatives have long been advocating for.

The American Health Care Act repeals the individual mandate, effective after December 31, 2015. This means that Americans who failed to buy health insurance coverage last year will not owe any penalties, fines, or taxes to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The bill also repeals the employer mandate, which will no longer require employers to provide health insurance coverage to their employees.

The bill also eliminates several stealth taxes imposed by Obamacare. For example, it eliminates the tax on over-the-counter medications, a tax that was previously hidden within the Affordable Care Act. The bill also repeals Obamacare's cap on contributions to Flexible Spending Accounts (FSAs), which were unlimited before the advent of President Obama's "signature domestic achievement." This cap was particularly hard on parents of special needs children, many of whom used FSAs to pay for special needs education.

The bill also eliminates the high medical bill tax, the tax on early withdrawals from Health Savings Accounts (HSAs), and the medical device tax, a natural-born job killer. The list goes on, with the bill addressing numerous issues that conservatives have long been advocating for.

Despite these positive attributes, conservatives and libertarians have been critical of the bill. One point of contention is the 30% premium surcharge that the bill would allow insurers to charge patients who wait until they are ill to buy coverage. However, it is important to note that this surcharge is an incentive for individuals to make informed choices about their health care, rather than an outright requirement to buy health insurance.

Another point of contention is the bill's tax credits and subsidies. However, it is important to note that the bill's tax credits are designed to help individuals and families afford health insurance, rather than the unworkable system of subsidies under Obamacare.

The American Health Care Act also defunds Planned Parenthood and reforms Medicaid, two provisions that conservatives have long been advocating for. The benefits of defunding Planned Parenthood are obvious, as the taxpayers will no longer be forced to fund the world's most notorious abortion mill and purveyor of infant body parts. The Medicaid reforms, which include a Medicaid per capita block grant and an increase in the amount of money individuals can contribute to HSAs, are a crucial part of conservative healthcare policy.

In conclusion, while the American Health Care Act is not perfect, it addresses several key issues that conservatives have long been advocating for. If conservatives hold out for full repeal and cling to the fantasy of a free market replacement plan, there is a real danger that Obamacare will never be repealed. Instead, it is important for conservatives to recognize the positive attributes of the American Health Care Act and work towards further reforms to achieve a truly free market healthcare system.

Title: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula Claims Responsibility for Charlie Hebdo Attack, French Authorities Investigate Paris Kosher Market Siege

Article:

Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) has claimed responsibility for the deadly attack on French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo last week, according to a video released on Wednesday. The attack, which left 12 people dead, was years in the making, an AQAP leader said in the video, claiming U.S.-born cleric Anwar al-Awlaki was the mastermind behind it. Al-Awlaki, who was a spokesman for AQAP before a U.S. drone strike killed him in Yemen in 2011, is believed to have had ties with the gunmen who attacked the magazine.

Intelligence analysts have been trying to piece together whether the gunmen met al-Awlaki on trips to Yemen, a theory that could be bolstered by the new video's claim. AQAP did not claim responsibility for Friday's deadly siege at a kosher grocery store in Paris, but praised it.

French security services have identified a suspected accomplice in that attack, according to the French newspaper Le Parisien. Police sources cited by the newspaper said one line of investigation is that the accomplice, a man from a Paris suburb, may have driven gunman Amedy Coulibaly to the kosher supermarket, where Coulibaly later shot dead four people. Coulibaly was killed in a police raid to end the siege. Said and Cherif Kouachi, the brothers who authorities say were behind the Charlie Hebdo attack, are also dead.

Investigators' efforts to track down possible suspects tied to last week's attacks are continuing. Charlie Hebdo's new edition hit newsstands Wednesday, a week after authorities say terrorists Said and Cherif Kouachi burst into its newsroom and gunned down staffers. The cover features a cartoon of the Prophet Mohammed crying. All 3 million copies sold out quickly, but more copies are coming soon, the magazine said.

The claim of responsibility for the deadly attack on the magazine came in a video showing AQAP commander Nasr Ibn Ali al-Ansi, with pictures of the Kouachis in the background. Al-Ansi praised the attack, saying it was revenge for Charlie Hebdo's depictions of Mohammed. Al-Ansi blamed not only Charlie Hebdo, but also France and the United States.

U.S. authorities said they think the video is authentic. But they were not ready to say that AQAP helped carry out the assault. "We're not there yet. There are good indicators that the group was behind the attack, but the intelligence community is still assessing," a senior administration official told CNN.

Investigators believe Cherif Kouachi left Yemen with as much as $20,000 from AQAP to carry out attacks, a U.S. official said. Le Parisien's report said investigators identified Coulibaly's suspected accomplice using keys for a motorbike discovered in an apartment they raided over the weekend. Also found inside the apartment, according to Le Parisien: a stash of weapons, explosives, and two ISIS flags.

Coulibaly purportedly told authorities before he was killed that he belonged to ISIS. Police also suspect the man may have been responsible for shooting and wounding a jogger last week—an attack that the Paris prosecutor has said could be tied to Coulibaly because the ammunition used was the same as ammunition found at the scene of the kosher market attack, Le Parisien said. Paris police would not comment to CNN on the contents of the report.

Le Parisien says Coulibaly's accomplice, who the newspaper did not name, is suspected to have fled France, possibly for Syria. Officials have also said they believe Hayat Boumeddiene, Coulibaly's widow who may have played a role in the attacks, has fled to Syria.

With France on its highest level of alert, 10,000 troops have deployed across the country. Thousands of police officers are on patrol, including hundreds assigned to protect Jewish schools. Since the attacks, dozens of cases have been opened in France against people accused of expressing support for terrorism since the attacks, the Justice Ministry said. It's unclear how many people are blamed for the 54 infractions. The cases include investigations involving phone threats, cyberattacks, and Facebook posts, the ministry said. Some are in prison awaiting trial, some have already been convicted, and some have been released with a notice of a court date, ministry spokesman Pierre Rance said.

Justice Minister Christiane Taubira "considers that words or actions of a racist or anti-Semitic nature, or that cause hateful, violent, or discriminatory behavior, or advocate terrorism, or target security forces must be fought and pursued with the utmost vigor," her office said in a statement. She "asked prosecutors to exercise extreme reactivity in the conduct of public action against the perpetrators of such crimes," the statement said.

With concerns on the rise, a controversial French comedian was accused of publicly supporting terrorism, French media reported. Dieudonne M'bala M'bala, known as Dieudonne, was arrested in Paris, according to media reports, which tied his arrest to a recent Facebook post from the comedian. "Je suis Charlie Coulibaly," the post said, combined the last name of one of the terrorists involved in last week's attacks with the widely used phrase expressing solidarity with victims. On Monday, Dieudonne issued a statement with his stance on the terror attacks. "Since the beginning of last year, I have been treated as public enemy number one, when all I try to do is make people laugh, and laugh about death," he wrote in a letter to the French interior minister. "Because death laughs at us all, as Charlie knows now, unfortunately."

Title: Political Campaigns Employ Personalized and Targeted Emails for Fundraising

Article:

Political campaigns are increasingly using personalized and desperate-sounding emails to make final fundraising pleas, according to a recent report by FoxNews.com. One such email, with the subject line "Need to reach you," mimics the tone of a plea from a stranded friend or family member.

Bill Scheel, part of the campaign for Arizona Democratic gubernatorial candidate Fred DuVal, acknowledges that such emails are part of a trend to connect with potential donors in a more specific way. "We want to be as personal as possible," he told FoxNews.com. "It's all part of a tremendous science that is now very important to campaigns."

However, Scheel notes that the DuVal campaign draws the line at sending "doom and gloom" emails, such as one this summer from the Tea Party Patriots that began with the line, "The tears are starting to flow." Scheel argues that such messages send the wrong message and that the DuVal campaign focuses on sending positive and upbeat messages.

Former Bush campaign and White House aide Taylor Griffin argues that the science goes beyond subject lines to include email content and all of social media. He points out that technology has been a game-changer in voter contact, allowing campaigns to personalize and segment messages to specific voters based on their interests and issues.

Campaigns typically hire firms that specialize in voter outreach, including phone canvasing, culling voter rolls, and acquiring membership lists. For example, a straightforward, pro-gun message could be sent to potential voters listed in the membership rolls of a Second Amendment advocacy group.

Griffin also highlights the power of Facebook in crafting narrowly focused messages to potential voters. Candidates can place a specific ad on the Facebook homepage of specific, potential voters based on their Internet profiles, which includes their shopping habits and websites they have visited.

One email that particularly resonated with message-weary voters this year began with the subject line, "Would You Like Us to Leave You Alone?" This inbox chestnut was sent eight days before election night by the Conservative Campaign Committee. The email's narrative, while initially compelling, eventually transitioned to a standard fundraising pitch.

Scheel understands how such emails could frustrate recipients, but notes that the DuVal campaign and others allow recipients to unsubscribe. He also points out that too many unopened or rejected emails can create problems for campaigns with Internet watchdogs. "It's not to our advantage to keep sending emails that people won't open," Scheel said.

Title: GOP Health Care Reform Bill in Jeopardy as Key Senators Express Opposition

Article:

Two prominent Republican senators have admitted that the initial GOP bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is likely "dead." The statements were made during interviews on Sunday, July 2.

Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) suggested in a televised interview on CBS that it may be time for Republicans to collaborate with Democrats to create a new health care reform proposal. "I think my view is it's probably going to be dead," McCain said of the GOP bill. If Democrats are involved, he said, it does not mean they control the process; it means their amendments will be considered. "That's what democracy is supposed to be all about," McCain added.

Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-LA), speaking on "███ Sunday," told Chris Wallace, "We don't know what the plan is. Clearly, the draft plan is dead. Is the serious rewrite plan dead? I don't know."

Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-IA) also expressed pessimism, signaling on Twitter late Saturday that Republicans would lose their Senate majority if they do not pass health care legislation. Grassley added that the party should be "ashamed" for not being able to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

President Trump used Twitter on Sunday afternoon to urge Republicans to fulfill their pledge to repeal the health care law. "For years, even as a 'civilian,' I listened as Republicans pushed the Repeal and Replace of ObamaCare. Now they finally have their chance!" Trump tweeted.

At least 10 GOP senators have expressed opposition to the initial bill drafted by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY). Republicans hold a 52-48 majority in the Senate, and Democrats stand united against the bill. With just three GOP defections, the bill would be doomed. The weeklong July 4 recess only raised more doubts among senators as many heard from constituents angry about the GOP bill and the prospect of rising premiums.

McConnell last week said he would introduce a fresh bill in about a week, aiming to scuttle and replace much of former President Barack Obama's health care law. However, McConnell also acknowledged that if the broader effort fails, he may turn to a smaller bill with quick help for insurers and consumers and negotiate with Democrats.

Sen. Ted Cruz's (R-TX) plan, which aims to lower premiums for healthy people, has drawn support from the White House and some conservatives in the House. However, his proposal has limited appeal to Republican moderates such as Grassley, who told Iowa Public Radio that it may be "subterfuge to get around pre-existing conditions."

Cruz, on Sunday, sought to dismiss Grassley's criticism as a "hoax" being pushed by Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer. Cruz insisted that people will be able to get the coverage they need at an affordable price. Cruz cast his plan as a compromise to unify the Republican party on a GOP health bill.

"When it comes to repealing Obamacare, what I think is critical is that Republicans, we've got to honor the promise we made to the voters that millions of Americans are hurting under Obamacare," Cruz said. "In my view, failure is not an option," he added.

Title: New Book on Fox News Executive Roger Ailes Sparks Controversy Ahead of Release

Article:

A new book titled "The Loudest Voice in the Room," authored by New York Magazine contributing editor Gabriel Sherman, is set to be published by Roger Ailes and Rupert Murdoch's AP Random House on January 21. The book promises to offer a controversial new perspective on Fox News.

In anticipation of potential backlash, the publisher and author are reportedly preparing for it, with a new website promoting the book also serving as a source for countering misinformation throughout the book's release. According to the website, Sherman conducted over 600 interviews with individuals who have interacted with Ailes, including hundreds of Fox News insiders.

The website features caricatures of many in Ailes' world, from Rupert Murdoch, dubbed "The Mogul," to "Champ," described as Ailes' guard dog. The book's release coincides with USA Today's Michael Wolff's piece, "The Unbeatable Roger Ailes," which focuses on Fox News' 2013 ratings triumphs. Last year, Fox's audience outpaced both MSNBC and CNN combined.

The cable news audience, despite the attention it receives for its potential political influence, is relatively small. The average Fox prime-time audience in 2013 was little over a million people, while MSNBC's 2013 non-election-year prime-time viewership was 640,000, and CNN's was 568,000. The book, which has been in the works for over two years, does not include interviews with Ailes.

In August, after Brian Lewis, a senior adviser to Ailes, was fired, Sherman speculated that it meant Ailes was "more isolated than ever before" — an assertion that Fox News executives quickly refuted. The exact details of Ailes' involvement in the book are unavailable.

Title: Iowa Democratic Leadership Remains Split on Clinton's Presidential Bid, Expressing Concerns Over Electability and Fundraising Ties

Article:

The state of Iowa, which derailed Hillary Clinton's presidential aspirations in 2008, is once again proving to be a challenging ground for the former First Lady as she prepares for a new presidential campaign. A report in Monday's Wall Street Journal revealed that Iowa's Democratic county leaders are reluctant to coalesce behind Clinton and have expressed concerns about her ability to win a general election and her fundraising ties to Wall Street firms and corporations.

Many county officials have expressed a preference for senators such as Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bernie Sanders of Vermont to enter the race, although they are divided over whether any of these candidates could gain traction and overtake Clinton. Jennifer Herrington, chair of the Page County Democrats in southwest Iowa, stated, "My heart wouldn't be in it for Hillary to the extent that it might be if it was a different candidate. I admire Hillary, she'd be a great president, but you know, she isn't my first choice I guess."

Iowa's Democratic electorate mirrors its Republican counterpart, as demonstrated in the 2012 election when Mitt Romney came in a narrow second place behind former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum. For all of Romney's 24.5% of the Iowa vote, another three-quarters backed a non-establishment candidate. A narrow loss for Clinton in Iowa could spell disaster for her second presidential bid, but a serious challenge to Clinton seems remote at this point.

However, some Democrats who want to see Clinton challenged in a primary are also laying the foundations to blame her for a 2016 defeat if a challenge does not materialize. Local Democrats note that the energy, donations, and political infrastructure acquired during a contested primary also become critical tools to use in the general election. Without these, the Democratic nominee is likely to be at a disadvantage when the vibrant and ideologically diverse GOP concludes its primary contest.

While the argument that a party that undergoes a contested primary is a stronger party is a valid contention, Clinton is unlikely to welcome a serious challenge. Memories from Iowa in 2008 are still fresh, and anti-Clinton forces, too, seem resigned. Those disaffected liberals who are prepared to accept her coronation are also preparing to consign the name Clinton to history's dishonorable scrap piles should she lose. It would be a bitter irony that the name Clinton, one which for the last 20 years has been associated with reviving the moribund Democratic brand, might soon become synonymous with its destruction.

Title: Churches Face Financial Crisis During Holy Week Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The traditional Holy Week commences tomorrow with Palm Sunday, and across the United States, many churches are closed, either voluntarily or by government decree. This closure has led to a financial crisis for numerous churches that rely almost entirely on donations from worshippers for their survival.

The Archdiocese of Newark (New Jersey) has established an online GoFundMe donation page, allowing anyone to contribute to specific parishes or a more general "Parishes in Need Fund." Cardinal Joseph W. Tobin stated in a statement on the page, "Our parishes face increased risk of financial shortfalls due to the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and its effects on everyday life."

Holy Week is a significant source of donations for these churches, with a substantial portion of the funds used to support charitable work. Priests and clergy provide food for hungry families, pay rent for those in need, and fund various other charitable activities made possible by these donations.

Bishop Robert Casey of the Archdiocese of Chicago expressed concern, stating, "It's a homecoming time for us, but it's also a very important fundraising time that allows us to continue with our mission and our ministries. This Holy Week will be especially worrisome for our parishes."

In addition to funding charitable needs, donations are crucial for payroll, church employees, and third-party employee contracts, including maintenance workers and cleaning staff. Father Paul Vigil of St. Timothy's Catholic Church in Los Angeles stated, "The last thing we want to do is lay off anyone or furlough especially during this time."

The Archdiocese of Los Angeles is encouraging parishes and schools to avoid furloughs and layoffs and is calling on parishioners to support extending unemployment benefits to church workers, who, in many states, do not have access to state unemployment insurance.

With tightened economic circumstances, asking parishioners to donate during difficult times has always been challenging. Father Vigil added, "When families barely have enough to put food on the table and keep a roof over their heads, as much as they may love the church, they just can't give what they might normally give."

Despite the challenges, churches will continue their work, having survived previous economic downturns, wars, and now the COVID-19 pandemic. The historical generosity of the American people will help them persevere, with enough devout believers to continue what they see as God's work on earth.

Title: U.S. President Donald Trump Accused of State-Sponsored Murder of Iranian General Qassim Suleimani

Article:

The assassination of Iranian Major General Qassim Suleimani, a high-ranking official of the Iranian government, has been labeled as a state-sponsored murder following the U.S. drone strike last week. The incident has sparked controversy and accusations that President Donald Trump is a murderer, with some arguing that this action violates the long-standing U.S. assassination ban.

The assassination ban was established in the 1970s following the Church Committee's investigation, which revealed that the CIA had secretly attempted to assassinate foreign leaders, including Cuba's Fidel Castro. At the time, the assassination ban was not the accepted practice of a democracy that aimed to serve as a role model for the world.

However, over the past two decades, both Republican and Democratic presidents have worked to skirt the assassination ban by taking advantage of new technologies to find and kill individuals worldwide. To do so without violating the ban, presidents have relied on compliant government lawyers to issue secret legal opinions that provide legal cover for their actions.

The Clinton administration initiated this practice in 1998, in response to the bombings of two U.S. embassies in East Africa by Al Qaeda. The White House launched cruise missile strikes against what they claimed were terrorist training camps near Khost, Afghanistan, with the primary target being Osama bin Laden. At the time, the New York Times reported that the action did not violate the assassination ban because the target was the "command and control infrastructure" of Al Qaeda, which was interpreted as its leadership, including bin Laden.

After 9/11, political concerns about the assassination ban were largely set aside due to overwhelming public support for the new global war on terror. However, the government's lawyers still worried about the assassination ban and other rules and regulations governing the use of state-sponsored violence. This led to the passage of the Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF) by Congress just days after 9/11, which has provided the basic legal authorization for counterterrorism strikes ever since.

The Bush and Obama administrations have used the AUMF and other legal backstops to kill at will, with the killing campaign claiming countless innocent lives, destabilizing nations, and being largely counterproductive. The U.S. has gained public and legal support for targeted killings, but only for what it described as the asymmetric fight against terrorism and non-state actors.

However, the Trump administration's drone strike to murder Qassim Suleimani, who was not a "non-state actor," has crossed a clear line. Suleimani was the head of the Quds Force, the elite external operations arm of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, which operated with impunity throughout Iraq under his leadership. He ran Iran's ground campaign against ISIS in Iraq, in parallel to the American air campaign, and employed Shia militias and their ruthless tactics to defeat the cult-like group.

The U.S. has taken credit for the victory over ISIS in Iraq without admitting that it relied heavily upon Suleimani's horrific paramilitary actions and his strategic acumen. Suleimani was more than a special forces commander or spymaster; he was Iran's most important envoy and served as Tehran's intimidating political fixer throughout the Middle East.

Title: Trump's Policy Stances Suggest a Shift Away from Traditional Republican Orthodoxy

Article:

In his bid to secure the support of Republican skeptics, Donald Trump, the presumptive GOP nominee for the 2016 presidential election, faces a challenge as his policy positions on several key issues align more with the Democratic party. On matters such as trade and national defense, Trump's policy proposals could potentially place him to the left of Hillary Clinton, his likely Democratic opponent.

Trump, who is often considered a classic Republican, criticizes environmental and corporate regulations, advocates for lower tax rates, and maintains a firm stance on opposing abortion rights. However, the billionaire businessman does not fit neatly into a traditional ideological box.

"I think I'm running on common sense," Trump said in a recent interview with The Associated Press. "I think I'm running on what's right. I don't think in terms of labels."

One of Trump's most significant departures from Republican orthodoxy is on trade. While the party's 2012 platform considered trade "crucial for our economy" and a means to create more American jobs, Trump has vowed to renegotiate or abandon existing trade deals, such as the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the pending Asia-Pacific pact.

Trump's stance on Social Security also sets him apart from the Republican Party. He has stated that he has no plans to scale back Social Security benefits or raise the qualifying retirement age, aligning with Clinton's position.

Trump's tax plan, released last fall, called for lowering the tax rate for the wealthiest Americans from 39.6% to 25% and reducing the corporate tax rate from 35% to 15%. The plan, which was met with criticism from outside experts for disproportionately benefiting the rich and increasing the federal deficit, appears to be evolving as Trump now suggests that his plan was merely a starting point for negotiations and that he would like to see the middle class benefit more from any tax law changes.

Trump's policy positions on the minimum wage are also inconsistent. While he has stated that wages are too high and does not support a federal minimum wage, he has also acknowledged the difficulty of surviving on the current minimum wage of $7.25 an hour and expressed openness to revisiting the issue.

On foreign policy, Trump has sought to portray Clinton as a hawk who would lead the country into conflict too easily, while his own "America First" approach appears to lean more toward isolationism. Clinton, on the other hand, advocates for a combination of diplomatic, legal, economic, political, and cultural tools to expand American influence, and believes the U.S. must be an active participant on the world stage, particularly as part of international alliances such as NATO. Trump has criticized NATO, questioning the structure that sees the U.S. pay for most of its costs.

Trump's policy positions, which have been described as contradictory at times, have been met with criticism from both sides of the political aisle. However, Trump has maintained that his proposals are open to negotiation and subject to change, particularly if they benefit the middle class more.

Title: St. Louis Couple Surrenders Rifle to Police After Confrontation with Protesters

Article:

A husband and wife in St. Louis, who gained national attention after brandishing firearms at protesters outside their home, have surrendered a rifle to police following a search warrant execution. The incident occurred on Friday, as authorities investigated the June 28 confrontation between the couple and a group protesting police brutality and the city's mayor's actions.

The couple, Mark and Patricia McCloskey, were caught on video armed with a rifle and a handgun as they confronted the protesters in their affluent St. Louis neighborhood of Central West End. Images and videos of the incident circulated on social media during the Black Lives Matter protests that took place across the country following the death of George Floyd.

In a video of the incident, Mark McCloskey is heard yelling, "Get the hell out of my neighborhood. Private property. Get out."

The St. Louis Metropolitan Police Department stated in a Saturday statement that detectives executed a search warrant at the McCloskey residence, seizing a Colt, semi-automatic,.223 caliber rifle. Attorney Joel Schwartz, who now represents the McCloskeys, stated that the couple voluntarily surrendered the rifle and that a second weapon was turned over to the previous lawyer.

Schwartz maintained the McCloskeys' innocence, stating they are "law-abiding citizens that were well within their rights." The St. Louis Circuit Attorney's Office said the matter remains under investigation.

In a June statement, police described the McCloskeys as "victims" of trespassing and fourth-degree assault. The McCloskeys stated they were on their property when they heard a commotion coming from the street. When they went to investigate, they observed a large group of subjects forcefully breaking an iron gate marked with "No Trespassing" and "Private Street" signs.

Demonstrators were in the neighborhood to protest against police brutality and Mayor Lyda Krewson, a Central West End resident who had released the names and addresses of activists who want to defund the police. Krewson has since apologized.

Freelance photojournalist Daniel Shular, who was at the protest, previously told NBC News that he did not see anyone break the gate leading to the neighborhood and recalled seeing people simply walk through an open gate. Shular also stated that he saw at least one armed protester but said it's "not super out of the ordinary for the protests here."

Attorney Albert Watkins, the previous attorney for the McCloskeys, said last month that his clients are supporters of the Black Lives Matter movement and became fearful because white protesters were acting aggressively.

Title: Univision's Coverage of President Trump's Mount Rushmore Speech Sparks Controversy

Article:

Univision, a broadcast network known for its advocacy on immigration issues, has come under criticism for its coverage of President Donald Trump's Independence Day eve address at Mount Rushmore. The Trump campaign compared Univision's coverage to that of MSNBC's Spanish-language counterpart, Telemundo, while the network itself has been likened to a hybrid of TeleSur and Al-Jazeera, owned by the National Council of La Raza.

In its coverage, Univision portrayed Trump's Rushmore speech as a "campaign rally and 4th of July celebration" during a full-blown pandemic, where social distancing and mask-wearing were not strictly enforced. The network also highlighted the controversial nature of the speech, suggesting that instead of uniting the nation during a time of crisis, Trump's speech further divided it.

The network's report omitted significant portions of Trump's speech, including his mentions of Washington, Lincoln, Roosevelt, and Jefferson, as well as his proposed National Garden, and his denunciations of the radical left's attempts to erase history. This omission allowed Univision to frame Trump's speech primarily in terms of COVID-19 and Confederate monuments, aligning with the network's narrative.

Following the speech, Senator Tammy Duckworth (D-IL) dismissed Trump as spending all his time "talking about dead traitors." This reaction makes sense if one assumes that Duckworth was only exposed to Univision's report, which did not mention the movement to erase American history or the violent mobs that have vandalized statues of George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and Frederick Douglass.

In a subsequent incident, Tucker Carlson criticized Duckworth for her willingness to have a "conversation" on the erasure of George Washington, a slave owner, in the midst of the debate over symbols and racism. Univision's response to this criticism is telling, as it did not address the broader effort to cancel America's Founding or the violent mobs that have sought to vandalize American historical symbols. Instead, Univision appears to focus on the side of the monument debate that aligns with its interests.

Title: Investing in Ethical Corporations Proves Profitable During COVID-19 Crisis

Article:

In the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, a new "we are all in this together" ethic is emerging, as people adopt codes of behavior that emphasize neighborliness, social distancing, and community support. This shift in behavior is not limited to personal conduct but is also being observed in the business world, where the focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics is increasing.

ESG is a code of behavior in the business world that prioritizes long-term sustainability over short-term profits, addressing issues like climate change and inequality rather than focusing on the next quarterly report. During the coronavirus crisis, for instance, many workers are being furloughed instead of fired, and companies are donating equipment or finding other ways to help their communities. Some corporations are also suspending dividends to shareholders or postponing executive bonuses.

Recent research by Bloomberg Intelligence and RBC Capital Markets indicates that investors who have bought stocks in companies with strong ESG performance are outperforming other broad indexes this year. Moreover, money continues to flow into ESG mutual funds, according to Bank of America. In other words, as the global economy ebbs during the pandemic, ethical corporate practices are proving to be financially advantageous.

Looking ahead to the post-COVID-19 world, the British bank Barclays estimates that the use of ESG by investors may accelerate. Investors view the crisis as a prelude to potential economic hits in the future, such as climate change, and are looking to corporations to contribute to our collective resiliency.

Despite the current investor panic, many now see an upside to ethical values in companies over bottom-line profits. The virus crisis is serving as a catalyst for the adoption of more codes of behavior in capitalism.

Title: White House Deputy Director of Communications Discusses Economic Gains for Non-College Graduates and Blue-Collar Workers under Trump Administration

In an interview on SiriusXM's "███ Sunday" with host Matt Boyle, White House Deputy Director of Communications Adam Kennedy discussed the economic gains made by Americans without college degrees and those with a military background under President Donald Trump's administration. Kennedy highlighted the House of Representatives' passage of the United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement (USMCA) and the broader economy.

Kennedy stated that the president has prioritized American families and workers since day one, and this focus has been reflected in the economy and trade agreements such as the USMCA. He emphasized that the economy has been particularly beneficial for people without college degrees and those from military backgrounds, who have seen some of the largest gains.

According to Kennedy, blue-collar workers have yielded the largest economic benefits across Trump's presidential tenure, with non-supervisory manufacturing positions experiencing the highest wage gains. The USMCA, Kennedy explained, puts in place tougher labor standards for manufacturing, which will discourage factories from moving to Mexico or leaving the country. Instead, these provisions create a strong incentive for manufacturers to stay in the U.S.

Kennedy also noted that manufacturing is experiencing a resurgence in the U.S., after many had assumed it would never recover. He believes the USMCA will solidify and accelerate this growth.

Regarding the impeachment push by Democrats, Kennedy estimated that Republicans are unified in their opposition and expects this unity to continue in the Senate. When asked about the possibility of a bipartisan vote against convicting the president, Kennedy responded that it is more likely that there will be a bipartisan opposition to convicting the president and a partisan vote in favor of him, as Republicans have been incredibly unified on this issue, while Democrats are reportedly divided and fractured.

"███ Sunday" broadcasts live on SiriusXM Patriot 125 from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. Eastern (4 p.m. to 7 p.m. Pacific).

Title: Tacoma Proposes Gun Sales Tax, Sparking Debate Over Local Firearm Regulation

Article:

Tacoma, Washington, is considering a proposal to levy a high tax on gun sales, potentially making it one of a handful of U.S. cities to implement such a measure. This move opens a new front in the ongoing debate over the extent to which local governments can regulate firearms.

Under current Washington state law, cities and towns are prohibited from enacting their own gun laws. However, the proposed tax in Tacoma, which would collect $25 per gun sale to fund violence prevention programs, is modeled on a law in neighboring Seattle that has been upheld by the state supreme court.

Ryan Mello, the Tacoma city councilman behind the measure, stated, "I can't ban assault rifles in the city of Tacoma. I can't ban certain types of ammo in the city of Tacoma. I can't require safe storage. There's a lot I can't do, but the one thing I am not pre-empted from doing is reasonable taxation on firearms and ammunition."
