If nations involved in the Paris talks fail to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, temperatures could increase by almost 6 degrees Celsius this century, according to the Committee on Climate Change, an independent advisory body to the U.K. government on climate issues.

The consequences of a warming planet are already being felt in Alaska, which is warming twice as fast as the rest of the U.S. Rising temperatures have thawed frozen soil in some areas, leaving coastlines vulnerable to storms and tidal activity. Shishmaref, a remote village located 30 miles outside the Arctic circle, is losing as much as 9 feet of land per year—chunks of coastline that simply break into the sea.

Plant and animal habitats face a dire threat from warming temperatures. An increase of 4 degrees Celsius in average planetary temperatures could result in severe habitat loss for almost two-thirds of plant species and one-third of mammal species. Crop yields could also be significantly reduced, with a 60% reduction in maize and spring wheat yields, compared to a 40% reduction for other crops, according to the Committee on Climate Change.

More people will be threatened by a warming planet, even if nations meeting in Paris curtail carbon emissions. Vulnerable populations living near water or in arid areas will face massive disruptions to their way of life, as flooding and severe drought become more common.

* Coastal flood estimates assume that flood protections evolve with population and wealth.
* River flood estimates assume that protections do not evolve.

By 2050, an estimated 2 million to 13 million people each year will be exposed to coastal flooding, roughly equivalent to the population of New Orleans and southern Louisiana. River flooding could affect about 130 million to 250 million people each year, encompassing the entire South and part of the Northeast in the U.S., as well as the entire East and Midwest. Water stress could also impact 1.5 billion to 2 billion people each year, living in areas without enough usable water, almost five times the U.S. population, or six times the current U.S. population.

Human activity since industrialization has led to a significant increase in carbon dioxide emissions, a greenhouse gas that contributes to rising global temperatures. If carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise at their current rates, Earth's temperatures could increase dramatically in future decades, leading to catastrophic and irreversible climate change. The 10 largest emitters produced about 26.4 gigatons of carbon dioxide in 2013.

The largest emitters per capita are Qatar, Trinidad and Tobago, Kuwait, Brunei, and Aruba. The European Union, Russia, Canada, South Korea, Iran, the United States, China, Japan, Saudi Arabia, and India are among the largest overall emitters.

Countries responsible for two-thirds of global emissions have made commitments to curb their greenhouse gas production. China, the world's biggest carbon producer, has promised that its carbon emissions will peak by 2030. The United States, the second-largest emitter, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 26 to 28 percent relative to 2005 levels by 2025. The European Union aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 percent relative to 1990 levels by 2030. India aims to reduce the ratio of emissions to its GDP by 33 to 35 percent relative to 2005 levels by 2030.

Title: IRS Acknowledges Inappropriate Targeting of Conservative Groups During 2012 Election

Article:

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) acknowledged on Friday that it inappropriately flagged conservative groups for additional review during the 2012 election to determine if they were violating their tax-exempt status. Lois Lerner, who heads the IRS division that oversees tax-exempt groups, made the admission at a conference sponsored by the American Bar Association.

Lerner confirmed that organizations were singled out because they included the words "tea party" or "patriot" in their applications for tax-exempt status. In some cases, groups were asked for their list of donors, she said.

"That was wrong. That was absolutely incorrect, it was insensitive and it was inappropriate," Lerner said. "The IRS would like to apologize for that."

Lerner stated that the practice was initiated by low-level workers in Cincinnati and was not motivated by political bias. After her talk, she told The Associated Press that no high-level IRS officials knew about the practice. She did not say when they found out.

The IRS put out a written statement saying protocol was changed at the Cincinnati office in response to the rising number of applications for 501 (c) (4) groups. This classification grants tax-exempt status to social welfare groups. The agents tried to "centralize work" in response to the applications, leading to problems the agency claims have since been fixed.

In all, about 300 groups were singled out for additional review, Lerner said. Of those, about a quarter were singled out because they had "tea party" or "patriot" somewhere in their applications. Lerner said 150 of the cases have been closed and no group had its tax-exempt status revoked, though some withdrew their applications.

Many conservative groups complained during the election that they were being harassed by the IRS. They accused the agency of frustrating their attempts to become tax exempt by sending them lengthy, intrusive questionnaires. The forms, which the groups made available at the time, sought information about group members' political activities, including details of their postings on social networking websites and about family members.

Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) said he's "glad" to see the IRS apologize but said it's not good enough. "We need to have ironclad guarantees from the IRS that it will adopt significant protocols to ensure this kind of harassment of groups that have a constitutional right to express their own views never happens again," he said, adding that he would be discussing the matter with the IRS commissioner.

Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) said, "the fact that Americans were targeted by the IRS because of their political beliefs is unconscionable."

Title: McCarthy Advocates Senate Approval for Any Future Nuclear Deals, Cites Iran Agreement as Precedent

Article:

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy has suggested that any potential nuclear deal with North Korea should be submitted to the Senate for approval as a treaty. In an interview with MSNBC's Hugh Hewitt, McCarthy criticized the Obama administration's handling of the Iran nuclear deal, which was not treated as a treaty but rather an executive agreement. He argued that this approach made it easier for President Trump to withdraw the U.S. from the deal earlier this year.

McCarthy argued that treating nuclear deals as treaties would ensure their longevity and counter concerns about other countries' reluctance to negotiate with the U.S. due to Trump's withdrawal from the Iran deal. He stated, "The one thing I have found, if it's going to be long-standing, I think treaties are longer standing and supportive from administration to administration."

The California Republican also disputed the notion that Trump's withdrawal from the Iran agreement complicated negotiations with North Korea. He argued that it would be difficult to negotiate with North Korea to end its nuclear program while allowing Iran to develop weapons in the future. McCarthy compared Trump's approach to that of President Reagan in dealing with the Soviet Union, stating that Trump was willing to engage in negotiations when they were going in the desired direction but was also willing to withdraw when they veered off course.

Title: IRS Commissioner Defends Actions Amidst GOP Criticism in Congressional Hearing

Article:

Acting IRS Commissioner Steven Miller appeared before a congressional panel on Friday, facing intense questioning from Republicans who accused the agency of systemic abuse. In the first hearing investigating the IRS's practice of targeting conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status, Miller apologized for the "foolish mistakes" made by employees trying to be more efficient in their workload selection.

However, Miller strongly refuted Republican claims that the agency is politicized. He maintained that the practice of flagging key terms in applications for tax exemptions is legal and even praised a civil servant under heavy GOP criticism for working in the agency's scandal-ridden tax-exempt division before helping it implement the health care overhaul.

Miller also asserted that he did not lie to Congress, stating, "I did not mislead Congress. I answered the questions as they were asked."

The four-hour hearing left Republicans dissatisfied and seeking more information. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dave Camp (R-Mich.) expressed that Miller's answers were "not very complete." He added, "We’re not done. We found out about this a week ago, so we’re going to continue to examine."

Miller stepped down on Wednesday at the request of Treasury Secretary Jack Lew. However, Miller told lawmakers that he currently remains in the position as the agency transitions to a new leader. President Barack Obama announced on Thursday that Daniel Werfel, the current controller of the Office of Management and Budget, will succeed Miller as acting IRS commissioner next week.

Two things became clear during the hearing: the IRS did not inadvertently announce the targeting program last year as initially appeared, and Republicans are dedicated to expanding the scope of their investigation.

Miller indicated that agency officials had discussed how to talk about the controversial targeting program before Lois Lerner, the director of the agency's tax-exempt division, was scheduled to appear at an American Bar Association conference on May 10. Her comments that the agency was wrong to flag nonprofit applications if they included the terms "tea party" or "patriot" triggered a week-long firestorm.

"I believe we talked about that," Miller said, referring to the discussions in advance of Lerner's public appearance.

Republicans are also making it clear they don't intend to limit their investigations to the initial news that the IRS gave extra review to groups that used certain terms. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dave Camp is also drawing in other IRS actions that have had conservatives stewing for a long time, such as a March 2012 Huffington Post story that disclosed confidential donor information for the National Organization for Marriage.

Camp also cited a ProPublica article that said the IRS had leaked the applications conservative groups had submitted for tax-exempt status.

Meanwhile, Miller maintained the agency's insistence that no one at the IRS told the White House of its activities.

Miller's testimony did not seem to alleviate the outrage that has built among Republicans.

Title: Obama's Middle East Visit: Focus on Peace, Security, and Youth Engagement

Article:

President Barack Obama is embarking on a week-long trip to the Middle East, marking his first visit to Israel as President. The visit, which begins on Wednesday in Jerusalem, aims to improve relations with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and foster peace and democracy in the region.

Netanyahu, who was re-elected in January, formed a new coalition government on Friday, including the centrist Yesh Atid and pro-settler Jewish Home parties, but excluding the ultra-Orthodox Jewish parties for the first time in a decade.

The White House has downplayed expectations, stating that President Obama hopes to facilitate discussions between leaders to advance peace and security. Among the region's significant issues are ongoing peace negotiations between Israeli and Palestinian leaders and the effort to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons.

The White House is adopting a strategy to lower expectations to create space for frank peace talks between both sides. The administration is willing to continue playing a facilitating role, but face-to-face talks may be challenging if leaders continue with unilateral actions, such as Israel building settlements in East Jerusalem and the West Bank.

In his visit, President Obama will deliver a speech to an audience of Israeli students, engage in cultural stops, and meet with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and Prime Minister Salam Fayyad in Ramallah. The president will also make a 24-hour stop in Jordan, focusing on the Syrian conflict, where more than 450,000 Syrians have sought refuge.

Obama's visit to Israel may quell criticism that he was less supportive of the Jewish state than his predecessors, a charge leveled by some Republican lawmakers during the 2012 presidential campaign. In his talks with Jordan's King Abdullah, the president will attempt to support the country's efforts to liberalize its government and counter an Arab Spring-style movement.

The president's final stop will be at Petra, Jordan's fabled ancient city.

Title: U.S. House of Representatives Delays Vote on Impeachment Articles, Committee Chairman Cites Public Interest

Article:

WASHINGTON, D.C. - The U.S. House of Representatives has delayed a vote on whether to move forward with impeaching President Donald Trump. The Democratic head of the Judiciary Committee, Jerry Nadler, announced late Thursday that a vote would occur on Friday at 10 a.m. Eastern Time (1500 GMT).

Initially, the committee was expected to approve two articles of impeachment late on Thursday, setting up a vote by the Democratic-controlled House next week. However, as the clock ticked toward midnight, Nadler sent lawmakers home for the night, citing the American public's desire to witness the vote.

The delay in the vote has caused frustration among Republican leaders, who had planned to travel home on Friday and now need to adjust their schedules. Doug Collins, the top Republican on the Judiciary Committee, expressed his displeasure, stating, "This was the most bush league thing I have seen, forever."

The impeachment proceedings in the House Judiciary Committee extended into the evening as Republicans, led by Collins, offered a series of amendments with no hope of adoption. These amendments were intended to weaken the articles of impeachment, which accuse Trump of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

If the House impeaches Trump, he would then face a trial in the Senate. The Republican-led Senate is unlikely to vote to find the president guilty and remove him from office.

Title: Alabama Senate Election: Write-In Candidates Could Impact Outcome for Moore and Jones

Article:

The upcoming Alabama Senate election is expected to be a close race between Democratic candidate Doug Jones and Republican candidate Roy Moore. A strong turnout from rural white voters, a key demographic for Moore, is crucial for his success, while energizing African-American voters is important for Jones.

Small-population counties, stretching across the state's northern tier and just above the Gulf Coast, are likely to report early. Moore's performance in these counties will provide an early indication of his chances against Jones, who is expected to perform well in Alabama's cities later in the night.

If Moore achieves similar margins to those he secured in his Republican runoff victory in September, with over 60% of the vote in several rural counties, he is likely to claim victory. However, the presence of write-in candidates could lower the threshold for victory. If write-in candidates perform well, Jones may not need to capture over 50% of the vote to win Tuesday.

It is historically challenging for an Alabama Democrat to capture over 50% of the vote. However, Jones may not have to capture a majority to win due to the potential impact of write-in candidates.

Senator Richard C. Shelby, a Republican and the state's longest-serving lawmaker, used a national television interview Sunday to remind Alabamians that he had written in the name of another Republican rather than supporting Moore. His example could encourage others in the party to do the same.

Two write-in candidates have announced their bids: Lee Busby, a Republican and a retired Marine colonel from Tuscaloosa, and the University of Alabama football coach Nick Saban, who is widely considered an important figure in the state. The more Republicans or independents who write in the name of a third candidate, the lower the threshold Jones needs to reach to win. Depending on the number of write-ins, he could potentially win even if he only captures 48% of the vote.

Title: Republican Presidential Race: Trump Accuses Establishment of Taking Advantage of Country

Article:

In a special town hall with Sean Hannity on Wednesday, Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump criticized GOP lawmakers who are reportedly working against his campaign, labeling them as individuals "taking advantage of our country." The billionaire businessman referred to a conference held by the conservative American Enterprise Institute over the weekend, where the topic of stopping Trump from securing the Republican nomination was reportedly discussed. The conference was attended by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, House Speaker Paul Ryan, and other key Republican congressmen.

Trump stated, "I know all these people. These are people that are taking advantage of our country. They don't want to have strong borders. They want stuff flowing across the borders. They don't want to have taxation when countries treat us unfairly because they benefit from that."

Former GOP presidential candidate Jeb Bush is also reportedly meeting with Trump's rivals on Thursday ahead of a GOP debate in Florida, fueling speculation that he may be preparing to endorse a candidate challenging Trump. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, meanwhile, has denied multiple reports that he has discussed the possibility of dropping out before the winner-take-all contest in Florida's primary next week.

Rubio told Megyn Kelly, "I have never discussed dropping out with anyone on my team, or anyone on the planet Earth... I'm the only one who can beat Donald Trump in Florida." A poll released Wednesday showed Rubio trailing Trump by 23 percentage points among likely Republican voters in Florida.

Rubio also dismissed the possibility of forming a "unity" Republican ticket with Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, Trump's closest challenger in the delegate race. Cruz, who has opposed a possible convention fight between himself and Trump if neither man reaches the required 1,237 delegates during the primaries, has walked back his earlier opposition to a contested convention.

Cruz told Kelly, "Look, Reagan and President Gerald Ford battled it out at a contested convention [in 1976]... That's what conventions are for." However, Cruz restated his opposition to a so-called brokered convention, calling it "a fever dream of the D.C. establishment" and warning of "an open revolt" among Republican voters if it came to pass.

Cruz also criticized Rubio and Trump over immigration reform and the so-called "Gang of Eight" bill in 2013. Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who has staked his campaign's future on victory in next Tuesday's Ohio primary, told Greta Van Susteren that he would "probably not" pick up enough delegates in other contests to overtake Trump, but noted that voters had only "picked about half the delegates [so far] this year... anything is possible." A poll released Wednesday showed Kasich leading Trump by five percentage points among likely Republican voters in the Buckeye State.

Trump currently has 458 delegates, Cruz has 359, Rubio is a distant third with 151 delegates, and Kasich has 54. The next primary is in Florida on Tuesday, March 15.

Title: Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect Pleads Not Guilty to 30 Charges

Article:

Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev pleaded not guilty Wednesday to 30 counts of using a weapon of mass destruction in a federal court in Boston. The charges stem from the Boston Marathon bombing that occurred on April 15.

Tsarnaev, 19, entered not guilty pleas to 30 counts, including the use of a weapon of mass destruction, malicious destruction of property resulting in death, and bombing a place of public use resulting in death. He spoke in a Russian accent during the arraignment, his first public appearance since his arrest on April 19.

The arraignment was his first public appearance since he was arrested following the bombings. Tsarnaev wore a partially unbuttoned orange jumpsuit and a black t-shirt, and displayed a crooked smile to two sisters, both in Muslim garb, seated in the courtroom. He looked unable to sit still and had a cast on his left arm and hand.

Public defender Judy Clarke attempted to enter a single "not guilty" plea on Tsarnaev's behalf and have it apply to all counts in the indictment. However, Judge Marianne Bowler asked that Tsarnaev speak for himself and that all the charges be read aloud. Flanked by his two attorneys, Tsarnaev said only two words – "not guilty" – repeating them seven times as prosecutors read the charges against him. Each of the 30 counts could bring a life-in-prison sentence, with 17 being eligible for the death penalty if the government decides to seek capital punishment.

Tsarnaev's brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, was killed in a shootout with police following a massive manhunt three days after the bombings. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was captured the next day – wounded and bloodied from the shootout – after a Watertown homeowner noticed blood on his dry-docked boat. Police found the suspect hiding inside.

Authorities say the brothers were inspired by al-Qaeda publications and that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev left a confession in the boat justifying the bombings as payback for U.S. military action in Muslim countries. He wrote that the U.S. government was "killing our innocent civilians."

"I do not like killing innocent people," he said, but also wrote: "I cannot stand to see such evil go unpunished... We Muslims are one body, you hurt one you hurt us all."

Tsarnaev's arrest stunned those who knew him as a likable high school athlete in Cambridge, Mass., where he lived with his older brother after his parents left for Russia. The indictment also said that, sometime before the bombings, Tsarnaev downloaded Internet material from Islamic extremists that advocated violence against the perceived enemies of Islam.

Three people – Martin Richard, 8, Krystle Marie Campbell, 29, and Lingzi Lu, 23 – were killed by the bombs, which were improvised from pressure cookers. Authorities say the Tsarnaevs also killed Massachusetts Institute of Technology officer Sean Collier days later while they were on the run.

Title: House Democrats Plan Wide-Ranging Investigations and Potential Impeachment Proceedings

Article:

In the aftermath of the midterm elections, incoming House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) has revealed a list of at least 85 potential targets for investigations and subpoenas related to President Donald Trump. The incoming majority is expected to face resistance from the White House, potentially leading to legal battles that could reach the Supreme Court.

The power dynamics between the presidency, Congress, and the Supreme Court will be tested as top Democrats, who had previously avoided the topic during the campaign, now plan to explore possible grounds for impeachment. Robert Mueller's public report could serve as the catalyst for impeachment proceedings.

Tom Steyer, a liberal activist who spent over $100 million during the campaign to build support for impeachment, stated that those trying to delay impeachment discussions are the "outliers." According to Steyer, 80% of registered Democrats support impeachment.

Schiff, in an interview with "███ on HBO," stated that he aims to assist Special Counsel Robert Mueller and plans to release, with redactions of classified material, transcripts of dozens of interviews conducted during the Intelligence Committee's own Russia probe. These transcripts contain possible contradictions with other testimony and facts, potentially placing witnesses, including White House officials and alumni, in legal jeopardy.

Schiff stated, "I want to make sure that Bob Mueller has the advantage of the evidence that we've been able to gather." He added, "But equally important: that Bob Mueller is in a position to determine whether people knowingly committed perjury before our committee."

When asked about potential contradictions between the testimony of Roger Stone, a close ally of the Trump campaign, and emails that have surfaced since then, Schiff responded, "That is certainly the case."

Schiff also stated, "We're going to want to look at what leverage the Russians may have over the president of the United States."

Incoming House Appropriations Chair Nita Lowey of New York, a close ally of House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, has also signaled a willingness to investigate a wide range of issues, including the Space Force, hurricane relief in Puerto Rico, White House security clearances, White House use of personal email, and more.

Lowey stated, "We have our boxing gloves on. I'm ready. And so is Nancy."

Both Lowey and Schiff acknowledged a list of potential investigation targets provided by House Republicans as a starting point, with further probes expected into matters such as James Comey's firing, Attorney General Jeff Sessions' ouster, the Muslim travel ban, family separation policy at the border, discussions of classified information at Mar-a-Lago, administration dealings with North Korea and Saudi Arabia, and more.

President Trump has already signaled a confrontational stance, stating at his post-election news conference that if Democrats investigate him, the result will be "a warlike posture." When asked if he would investigate the Democrats, Trump replied, "Oh, yeah. Better than them."

For 225+ years, federal courts have upheld the Constitution's mandate of Congress as an equal branch of government, providing checks and balances on the executive. As House Democrats assume power, they have a strong position to carry out their investigative agenda.

Title: Republican Candidates Tap into Social Conservative Narrative of Victimhood and Oppression

Article:

In the ongoing race for the Republican presidential nomination, several candidates are echoing a narrative of victimhood and oppression that resonates with social conservatives. This narrative suggests that the forces of secularism are consolidating their gains and preparing to make it all but illegal to be a Christian.

In a speech at Jerry Falwell's Liberty University, Jeb Bush stated, "There are consequences when you do not genuflect to the latest secular dogmas." Bobby Jindal claims the left wants to "essentially outlaw firmly held religious beliefs that they do not agree with." Marco Rubio warns that opposing same-sex marriage could lead to the argument that the teachings of mainstream Christianity are hate speech. Mike Huckabee asserts, "We are moving rapidly toward the criminalization of Christianity."

While these assertions may seem extreme, they reflect the concerns of many on the religious right. They feel that the rapid change in public opinion and laws on gay rights, as well as broader societal shifts away from traditional values, is a threat to their beliefs.

According to recent data from the Pew Research Center, Christians made up 70.6 percent of the American population in 2014, down 8 points from just seven years before. Meanwhile, the population of the "unaffiliated" - atheists, agnostics, and people who do not identify with any religion in particular - has grown to 23 percent of the public. The trend is particularly pronounced among millennials, with only 56 percent identifying as Christian and 35 percent as unaffiliated.

This sense of being a minority in a society that no longer shares their values is not unique to conservative Christians. However, they have constructed an uplifting story for themselves, where their supposed persecution gives them nobility and heroism. They see themselves as courageous revolutionaries, underdogs fighting the odds on behalf of their principles and God's desires.

Liberals may dismiss this kind of rhetoric, but it is mostly sincere and will likely become louder as social progress continues in its current direction. It will be particularly interesting to see what the candidates say if the Supreme Court rules that gay people have a constitutional right to marry, as it may well do in a matter of weeks.

Title: Lugar Center Releases Bipartisan Index, Highlights Rising Political Polarization in Congress

Article:

The Lugar Center, a think tank founded by former Indiana Republican Senator Richard Lugar and Georgetown University's McCourt School of Public Policy, has released its inaugural Bipartisan Index, ranking members of Congress based on their cooperation across party lines. The rankings are based on lawmakers' sponsorship and co-sponsorship of bills and measure the degree to which they succeeded in attracting co-sponsors from the opposing party and crossed the aisle to co-sponsor others' bills during the last two Congresses.

According to a press release from the Lugar Center, as reported by Real Clear Politics, the Bipartisan Index offers the public an objective way to measure how frequently their members of Congress are cooperating with the other party on matters of policy. The Lugar Center aims to incentivize members of Congress to be more bipartisan when writing legislation and making co-sponsorship decisions, as well as keeping an open mind about legislation introduced by the other party.

The Lugar Center, which focuses on issues such as nonproliferation of weapons of mass destruction, global food security, foreign assistance effectiveness and global development, energy security, and enhancing bipartisan governance, plans to release lifetime rankings of each member of Congress dating back to 1993 later this year, according to Real Clear Politics.

However, the 112th and 113th Congresses were the most partisan since 1993, as reported by USA Today. The Lugar Center came up with historical average scores for members of the minority and majority parties, and then lawmakers in the last Congress were compared to the baseline to see whether they ranked above or below average.

Only a little more than one-third of those serving from 2013-2014 were ranked "bipartisan," according to USA Today, with top scorers in the Senate including Republican Susan Collins of Maine and Democrat Joe Manchin of West Virginia. Those ranked as least bipartisan included Republicans Ted Cruz of Texas and Tim Scott of South Carolina.

In the House, GOP Reps. Christopher Gibson and Peter King of New York ranked most bipartisan, while Reps. Tim Huelskamp, R-Kan., and Donna Edwards, D-Md., were least bipartisan.

The scores of presidential candidates in the Senate were all in the bottom half of the index, according to Real Clear Politics, including Florida Republican Sen. Marco Rubio, Kentucky Republican Sen. Rand Paul, Cruz, and independent Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.

"Right now, most citizens are unhappy with the lack of progress in Congress, the lack of legislation moving forward or — worse still — such tie-ups that the government may shut down or be threatened with being shut down from time to time," Lugar told USA Today.

The trend has been noted before. Tracking voting patterns since the early 1950s, CQ Roll Call has found that partisanship and polarization are driving legislative behavior more than in any other period since at least the start of the Eisenhower administration, according to USA Today. The Washington Post, reporting last month on a diagram of partisanship for each House of Representatives from 1949 to 2011, shows that starting in the 1990s, "the parties began pulling apart from each other, like a single cell dividing into two," and that "in the 2000s, there are hardly any links between the parties at all."

Title: Alabama Senate Race: Moore's Loyal Base Remains Steadfast Amidst Allegations

Article:

In the ongoing Alabama Senate race, Republican nominee Roy Moore has faced a wave of allegations regarding past sexual misconduct, causing some conservative voters to reconsider their support. However, Moore's long-time supporters, who have backed him in statewide races for chief justice, governor, and senator for two decades, remain steadfast in their allegiance.

Johnny Williams, a 77-year-old retired bus charter company owner, expressed his continued support for Moore. "I've seen him fighting at those fires, and I just believe in him," Williams said in an interview.

Ann Eubanks, a 68-year-old Birmingham resident who leads a tea party group, also voiced her support for Moore. "I am a policy voter," Eubanks said. "I refuse to send a far-left liberal Democrat to Congress. There's too much at stake in this country at this point with the balance of the Senate at critical mass."

Issues such as future Supreme Court nominations, repealing Obamacare, building the wall, and immigration proposals are key concerns for Eubanks and other Moore supporters, who believe the president will need every vote he can muster in the Senate to advance his legislative agenda.

Despite this loyal base, Moore is facing challenges in winning over other Alabama voters who typically vote Republican. Richard Barnett, a 66-year-old metals and welding company general manager, stated he was not a fan of Moore before the allegations surfaced and will not vote for him. Barnett, who has not voted for a Democrat since Jimmy Carter, may write-in Sen. Luther Strange, Moore's primary opponent, instead.

In some Republican communities, such as Hoover, Alabama, where Barnett resides, there is a noticeable lack of public support for Moore, with more visible support for Democratic nominee Doug Jones.

Winning over these voters could be crucial to Moore's victory. The Moore campaign is optimistic, as President Trump held a rally Friday night in Pensacola, Florida, just 25 miles from the Alabama state line, to encourage people to vote for Moore.

However, not everyone is enthused about the election. At a Waffle House in Birmingham, one waitress, Nona, expressed her reluctance to vote for any of the candidates on Tuesday, citing Moore's behavior as "not Christian."

Title: Tens of Thousands Gather at Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial to Commemorate 50th Anniversary of "I Have a Dream" Speech

Article:

Tens of thousands of individuals marched to the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial and down the National Mall on Saturday, commemorating the 50th anniversary of King's famous "I Have a Dream" speech. The event, which served as a tribute to a generation of activists who endured hardships such as fire hoses, police abuse, and indignities to demand equality for African Americans, emphasized the unfinished nature of King's dream.

Martin Luther King III, the oldest son of the slain civil rights leader, stated, "This is not the time for nostalgic commemoration. Nor is this the time for self-congratulatory celebration. The task is not done. The journey is not complete. We can and we must do more."

Eric Holder, the nation's first black attorney general, highlighted the significant role those who marched played in his career and President Barack Obama's presidency. "They marched in spite of animosity, oppression, and brutality because they believed in the greatness of what this nation could become and despaired of the founding promises not kept," Holder said.

Holder mentioned gays, Latinos, women, and the disabled as groups yet to fully realize Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream. Other attendees advocated for organized labor, voting rights, revamping immigration policies, and access to local post offices.

Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., the only surviving speaker from the 1963 March on Washington, criticized a recent Supreme Court decision that weakened a key anti-discrimination provision of the Voting Rights Act. Lewis was a leader of the 1965 march, where police beat and gassed marchers who demanded access to voting booths.

"I gave a little blood on that bridge in Selma, Ala., for the right to vote," he said. "I am not going to stand by and let the Supreme Court take the right to vote away from us. You can not stand by. You can not sit down. You've got to stand up. Speak up, speak out, and get in the way."

Organizers anticipated about 100,000 people to participate in the event, a precursor to the actual anniversary of the Aug. 28, 1963, march that drew some 250,000 to the National Mall and ushered in the idea of massive, nonviolent demonstrations.

Marchers began arriving early Saturday, many staking out their spots as the sun rose in a clear sky over the Capitol. By midday, tens of thousands had gathered on the National Mall.

Lynda Chambers, 58, gave up a day's pay to attend because her retail job does not provide paid vacation. Even as a 7-year-old at the time of the original march, she felt alienated and deprived of her rights. Remembering those feelings, she said, she was compelled to make the trip Saturday.

"I wanted to have some sort of connection to what I have always known, as far as being a black person," she said.

Longtime activist Al Sharpton, now an MSNBC host, implored young black men to respect women and reminded them that two of the leading figures in the civil rights movement of the 1960s were women.

Speakers frequently mentioned persistent high unemployment among blacks, which is about twice that of white Americans, and the acquittal of George Zimmerman for the shooting death of unarmed black teenager Trayvon Martin in Florida. Along the Mall, Martin's picture was nearly as ubiquitous as King's.

Nancy Norman, of Seattle, said she was disappointed more people who look like her had not attended. She is white. However, the 58-year-old said she was glad to hear climate change discussed alongside voting rights.

"I'm the kind of person who thinks all of those things are interconnected. Climate change is at the top of my list," said Norman. "I don't think it's one we can set aside for any other discussion."

Those in attendance arrived in a post-9/11 Washington that was very different from the one civil rights leaders visited in 1963. Then, people crowded the steps of the Lincoln Memorial and could get close to King to hear his "I Have a Dream" speech. Saturday's speakers were also on the memorial's steps, but metal barriers kept people away from the reflecting pool and only a small group of attendees was allowed near the memorial Saturday.

There was a media area and VIP seating. Everyone else had been pushed back and watched and listened to the speeches on big-screen televisions. Police were stationed atop the Lincoln Memorial. After the speeches, marchers walked from there, past the King Memorial, then down the National Mall to the Washington Monument, a distance of just over a mile.

On the day of the anniversary, President Barack Obama will speak from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. He will be joined by former Presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter. Churches and groups have been asked to ring bells at 3 p.m. Wednesday, marking the exact time King spoke.

Joseph Lowery, who founded the Southern Christian Leadership Conference along with King, urged the crowd to continue working for King's ideals.

"We've come to Washington to commemorate," the 92-year-old civil rights leader said, "and we're going home to agitate."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Initiates Key Vote on Gun Laws Following Newtown Shootings

The Senate Judiciary Committee has initiated a series of key votes on gun control legislation on Thursday, marking the first significant move in Congress to address firearm regulations since the tragic shootings at a Connecticut elementary school in December.

The Associated Press reports that the panel approved a bill making gun trafficking a federal crime, with the vote standing at 11-7. The bill, titled "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms," was sponsored by Committee Chairman Pat Leahy (D-VT). Sen. Charles Grassley (R-IA) was the only Republican to support the measure.

The committee is considering four pieces of legislation, including:

1. The "assault weapons ban of 2013," sponsored by Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-CA).
2. The "stop illegal trafficking in firearms" act, put forward by Committee Chairman Pat Leahy (D-VT).
3. New York Democratic Sen. Charles Schumer's "protecting responsible gun sellers act of 2013," which would expand background checks for gun buyers.
4. The "school safety enhancements act of 2013" from Sen. Barbara Boxer (D-CA).

The Democratic-controlled committee is expected to vote in favor of all four bills, meaning they would then be considered by the full Senate. However, the bills' prospects after that are uncertain, as reported by The Hill. The decision to stage separate votes rather than bundle the measures together allows centrist Democrats to selectively support elements of the proposed legislation.

The most controversial measure, the assault weapons ban, is not automatically included in the package, thereby preserving the prospects for less contentious reforms. The Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid (D-NV), has vowed to bring to the floor whatever Leahy can move through his committee. However, Reid is also a long-time opponent of tougher gun laws, including President Obama's push for a ban on assault weapons. Senate Republicans are also reportedly unified against most of Obama's gun-reform proposals.

Gun-control supporters are focusing on one element of Obama's package they see as low-hanging fruit: an expansion of the criminal background check system for gun purchases. The bills would also face uphill battles in the Republican-controlled House.

We will provide updates on the committee votes as they occur.

Title: New Polls Show Close Race Ahead of First Presidential Debate

Article:

Two days before the first presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney, a new poll indicates that most Americans see the incumbent as the favorite in the first showdown. According to an ABC News/Washington Post national poll released on Monday, 55% of likely voters believe President Obama will win the debate, with 31% predicting that Romney will be victorious.

The findings on this question from the new survey align with a CNN/ORC International poll conducted after the Democratic convention earlier this month, where 59% of likely voters said Obama would do a better job in the October debates, compared to 34% who favored Romney.

The first debate between the president and Romney will take place on Wednesday in Denver, Colorado. Vice President Joe Biden and Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, Romney's running mate, will face off once.

According to the Washington Post poll, 49% of likely voters say they would vote for President Obama if the election were held today, with 47% saying they would vote for Romney. The president's two-point margin is within the survey's sampling error. A new Politico/George Washington University Battleground poll also released on Monday indicates 49% for Obama and 47% for Romney among likely voters nationwide.

The two new surveys follow a Fox News poll released late last week, which indicated a five-point advantage for the president. A CNN Poll of Polls, which averages all three surveys together, puts Obama at 49% and Romney at 46% among likely voters.

The ABC News/Washington Post poll was conducted from September 26-29, with 1,001 adults nationwide, including 929 registered voters and 813 likely voters, questioned by telephone. The survey's sampling error for likely voters is plus or minus 4 percentage points. The Politico/George Washington University Battleground poll was conducted from September 24-27, with 1,000 adults nationwide questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

In other campaign news, Ann Romney is set to rally, while President Obama prepares for the debate across town. Romney also addressed foreign policy in his weekly podcast.

Title: Centrist Strategy Drives Historic Progress in Gay Rights Movement

Article:

John Avlon, a political commentator, asserts that the success of the gay rights movement, particularly the issue of same-sex marriage, is a historic milestone in the United States. The movement has gained significant momentum, with a majority of Americans now supporting same-sex marriage, a stark contrast to just 27% a decade ago.

Recent political endorsements of marriage equality by figures like Hillary Clinton, Jon Huntsman, and Rob Portman, as well as the increasing support among younger Republicans and evangelicals, reflect this shift in public opinion.

Avlon attributes this progress to a strategic shift in the movement's approach, moving away from divisive street theater tactics towards building bridges beyond the base. This includes outreach to Republicans and making conservative arguments for same-sex marriage.

Ted Olson, a former solicitor general under the Bush administration, and David Boies, who was Olson's opponent in the Bush v Gore Supreme Court case, are examples of this strategic shift. They argued that California's Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage, was unconstitutional.

Olson and Boies, a Republican and a Democrat respectively, emphasize the need to focus on common ground and broad principles rather than partisan politics and positional bargaining. Their partnership represents a dynamic approach to problem-solving, creating new coalitions and overturning decades of stereotypes about the split-the-difference impulse of the "mushy middle."

The movement's success is also attributed to strategic use of language, with terms like "freedom to marry" and "marriage equality" being preferred over "gay marriage." This emphasis on individual freedom and civil rights helps humanize the issue and create unexpected common ground.

Avlon suggests that this centrist strategy, which depolarizes issues and creates new coalitions, is effective and can be replicated in other areas to solve problems through addition rather than division. The shift in public opinion overturns centuries of established thought about marriage and reflects the durability and flexibility of the American democratic system.

Regardless of the Supreme Court's ultimate decision on the constitutionality of Proposition 8 and the Defense of Marriage Act, the movement of same-sex marriage from the margins to the mainstream has been achieved. The centrist model by which it moved forward can serve as a blueprint for future progress in other areas.

Title: Trump Legal Team Prepares Answers to Special Counsel's Questions in Russia Probe

Article:

New York ( ███ ) - President Donald Trump's lawyers are preparing responses to questions from the U.S. special counsel, Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. This development, first reported by CNN, indicates progress in the talks between Mueller and Trump's legal team regarding the president answering questions in the investigation.

Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani stated last month that Mueller wanted the president to commit to a follow-up interview if written questions were provided, a position Trump's legal team was resisting. The question of a potential interview has not yet been settled, but a source told ███ that Mueller is willing to accept written answers to questions without a commitment from Trump's lawyers over what comes next.

In an interview on Tuesday, Giuliani told ███: "We are not prepared to agree to more questions until the first group of questions are asked, answered, and somebody can explain to us why that isn't enough." Giuliani reiterated that Trump would be willing to answer questions on whether his campaign had colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 election, but not whether he had acted to obstruct the Russia probe.

In an NBC News interview last year, Trump tied his decision to fire FBI Director James Comey to the investigation into Russian election meddling. At the time of his firing, Comey was leading the probe. U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia interfered in the election to try to tip it toward Trump and away from his Democratic challenger, Hillary Clinton. Moscow has denied any interference, while Trump has denied any collusion with Russia and any obstruction of justice.

Title: Biden and Obama Continue Pursuit of Assault Weapons Ban Despite Senate Setback

Article:

In the face of Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's decision to allow only Senator Dianne Feinstein to offer her assault weapons ban legislation as an amendment, rather than granting it a full vote on the Senate floor, President Obama and Vice President Joe Biden remain hopeful that the ban will eventually pass.

During a recent interview, Vice President Biden expressed his continued support for the assault weapons ban, stating, "I am still pushing that it pass. We are still pushing that it pass." Biden recalled the initial resistance faced when the first assault weapons ban was attached to the Biden Crime bill in 1994, stating that it was declared dead several times.

When asked about the lack of Democratic support for the ban, Biden responded, "Look, last time we passed it we only had seven Republican votes in 1994." Biden emphasized that he does not find it logical to support a measure and declare that there is no possibility of it passing.

Vice President Biden's confidence stems from his past experience with the issue. Having been a key figure in the passage of the assault weapons ban once before, along with Senator Dianne Feinstein and others, Biden believes that the process may not necessarily unfold in one step. He cited the example of the assault weapons ban being part of the so-called Biden Crime Bill, which initially had 100,000 amendments removed, then reinstated, and eventually separated as the Brady Bill for background checks.

As the fight for gun control continues, the Department of Justice, ATF, and other regulatory agencies are expected to play a significant role in the ongoing efforts. Vice President Biden was recently in New York for an event with NYC Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who, like Biden, continues to advocate for more gun control measures despite Senator Feinstein's failure to secure Democratic support for her assault weapons legislation.

Title: Political Campaigns Adjust Schedules, Messages in Response to Colorado Shooting

Article:

Following the mass shooting at a Denver-area movie theater showing "The Dark Knight Rises," both President Barack Obama and Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney revised their campaign schedules. The shooting resulted in at least 12 deaths and numerous injuries.

President Obama, who had planned to hold Florida campaign rallies in Fort Myers and Orlando, canceled the Orlando event and transformed the Fort Myers appearance into a somber affair. Obama's speech focused on prayer, reflection, and the fragility of life, rather than political applause lines or campaign rhetoric.

Obama stated, "If there's anything to take away from this tragedy, it's the reminder that life is very fragile. Our time here is limited and it is precious. And what matters at the end of the day is not the small things, not the trivial things which so often consume us in our daily lives. Ultimately, it's how we choose to treat each other and how we love one another."

Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, addressed a crowd in Bow, New Hampshire, where he was initially scheduled for a campaign event. Romney's speech emphasized grieving, remembering, and helping those in need. He said, "Today is a moment to grieve and remember, and to reach out and to help, to appreciate our blessings in life."

Both the Obama and Romney campaigns pulled their political ads in Colorado out of respect for the victims and to avoid any appearance of crassness in a key battleground state. New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg also called on both candidates to provide specific details on how they would combat gun violence in the nation.

Title: U.S. Ebola Case Raises Questions About Government Transparency and Trust

Article:

The recent diagnosis of the first Ebola case in the United States has sparked controversy and raised questions about the government's transparency and trustworthiness. On Sept. 16, President Obama held a news conference at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta, where he stated that the Ebola situation in West Africa was "spiraling out of control" and that the chances of Ebola coming to America were "extremely low." However, on Sept. 20, Liberian Ebola carrier Thomas Eric Duncan arrived in the United States, just four days after the president's comments.

The Obama administration's handling of the Ebola crisis has been met with criticism, as some argue that the president's refusal to suspend flights into the United States from Ebola-infected countries may have contributed to the virus' arrival in the country. The administration's messaging has also been called into question, with some officials, including CDC Director Tom Frieden, repeating the narrative that Ebola could only be transmitted if one was in direct contact with blood or other bodily fluids of someone who is very sick.

However, this narrative was exposed as misleading when Dr. Frieden was asked to reassure viewers that Ebola was not "highly contagious" on CNN. Dr. Frieden was compelled to admit that standing within a three-foot radius of someone with Ebola poses a risk of infection, contradicting the CDC's previous guidelines.

The Ebola crisis has also highlighted the media's role in holding the government accountable. Some argue that the media's lack of curiosity about the truth has allowed federal officials to mislead the public, while others credit the media for exposing the truth and holding officials accountable.

Tammy Bruce, a radio talk-show host, author, and Fox News contributor, commented on the situation, stating, "Americans have been through a great deal since the Founding itself...Politicians do, however, have another reason to keep information from us: Each failure of the system exposes their incompetence."

The Ebola crisis has raised important questions about the government's transparency and trustworthiness, and the role of the media in holding the government accountable. As the situation continues to unfold, it remains to be seen how the government will respond and whether the public will regain trust in their leaders.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar's Remarks on Israel Spark Backlash, Allegations of Anti-Semitism

Article:

Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) has faced criticism from members of both political parties following her remarks about a prominent lobbying group allegedly paying members of Congress to support Israel. The controversy began after Omar responded to a Twitter post by journalist Glenn Greenwald criticizing House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) for threatening to take action against Omar and fellow freshman lawmaker Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) over allegedly anti-Semitic remarks.

In a series of tweets, Omar, who became the first Somali-American woman elected to Congress in November, quoted a 1997 rap song by Puff Daddy and responded to a tweet by Batya Ungar-Sargon, the opinion editor of The Forward newspaper, with "AIPAC!" referring to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC). AIPAC regularly has been accused by progressives of agitating for a conflict with Iran.

AIPAC responded to Omar's tweet, stating, "We are proud that we are engaged in the democratic process to strengthen the US-Israel relationship. Our bipartisan efforts are reflective of American values and interests. We will not be deterred in any way by ill-informed and illegitimate attacks on this important work."

Other freshman Democrat Max Rose of New York tweeted that Omar's statements "are deeply hurtful to Jews, including myself." In a statement, Rose said, "When someone uses hateful and offensive tropes and words against people of my faith, I will not be silent. At a time when anti-Semitic attacks are on the rise, our leaders should not be invoking hurtful stereotypes and caricatures of Jewish people to dismiss those who support Israel."

House GOP conference chair Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) called for House Democrat leaders to remove Omar from the House Foreign Affairs Committee, and Zudhi Jasser, a physician and President of the American Islamic Forum for Democracy, argued that removing Omar from the House Foreign Affairs Committee would be a "good first step, followed by a swift sanction against @IlhanMN for bigotry unfit for the US Congress with removal from all committees. Ignoring this would bring the 'bigotry of low expectations' to a new low for Muslims."

The Republican Jewish Coalition called on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) to take action against Omar and asked if other House Democrats would "care to comment on the outrageous anti-Semitism being spewed by one of your fêted members?"

Chelsea Clinton tweeted, "We should expect all elected officials, regardless of party, and all public figures to not traffic in anti-Semitism." Meghan McCain, daughter of late Arizona Senator John McCain, lauded Clinton for calling out anti-Semitism "on all sides, in all spaces, no matter how uncomfortable."

Omar's remarks are the latest in a long line of statements that critics have slammed as anti-Semitic. In 2012, she tweeted, "Israel has hypnotized the world, may Allah awaken the people and help them see the evil doings of Israel. # Gaza # Palestine # Israel." She did not apologize for posting the tweet until last month. In January, Omar argued in a Yahoo! News interview that Israel could not be considered a democracy and compared it to the Islamic theocracy in Iran.

Omar and Tlaib have faced criticism for their views on Israel in the past, and in February, Tlaib was barred from entering Israel due to her support for the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. Omar and Tlaib have both faced calls to resign from their positions in Congress over their views on Israel.

Title: Jeb Bush Denies Shift in Immigration Stance Amidst 2016 Presidential Speculation

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has vehemently denied allegations that he has changed his stance on immigration reform, as other potential 2016 Republican presidential candidates position themselves on the issue.

In interviews on Sunday talk shows, Mr. Bush reiterated his support for a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants, aligning himself with a bipartisan group of senators working on such legislation. His recent book, "Immigration Wars: Forging an American Solution," which outlines a "pathway to residency" for those in the country illegally, has drawn criticism from both the right and the left.

In his book, Mr. Bush suggests a path to residency rather than citizenship for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in the U.S., requiring them to leave the country and reapply if they wish to obtain U.S. citizenship. Senator Lindsey Graham, a member of the "Gang of Eight" and a South Carolina Republican, stated last week that such a stance "undercuts" the senators' efforts.

However, Mr. Bush maintains that he and Senator Graham are on the same page, and that his views on the issue have remained consistent despite earlier support for a pathway to citizenship. "I haven't changed," he said on CBS' "Face the Nation." "I support a path to legalization or citizenship so long as the path for people that have been waiting patiently is easier and costs less, the legal entrance to our country, than illegal entrance."

Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid criticized Mr. Bush last week, stating, "Let's wait for a few minutes and see how Jeb Bush changes his mind, again. His opinion on immigration is not evolving; it's devolving. He keeps going backwards."

President Obama, who had pledged to pass comprehensive immigration reform in his first term, has made the issue one of his top priorities for his second. However, Republicans working on the issue face a delicate balance between distancing themselves from the president and potentially alienating Latino voters. Republican Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Rand Paul of Kentucky criticized a leaked framework for immigration reform last month that included a path to citizenship. Mr. Rubio, whose parents emigrated from Cuba, supports a pathway to citizenship for those currently in the U.S. illegally, and Mr. Bush stated his views "absolutely" coincide with those.

Mr. Bush also dismissed the notion that the events of the past week or his book were motivated by political maneuvering for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination. "That's the Washington world, the world of everything has to have a personal political ambition, motive," he said. "That's not the case. The book was written last year at a time when the tenor of the debate on immigration was dramatically different than it is today."

Title: Colorado Democrats Advance Firearm Restrictions as National Debate Intensifies

Article:

In a politically charged atmosphere, Colorado Democrats have advanced firearm restrictions, as the debate over the proposed measures intensified on Monday. Hundreds of gun rights supporters gathered at the state Capitol, with car horns blaring throughout the day, while inside, advocates for gun control, including the husband of former U.S. Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and victims of mass shootings, urged lawmakers to pass universal background checks and implement more gun controls.

The state has become a focal point in the national debate over new gun laws in the wake of recent mass shootings, including an attack at a suburban Denver movie theater last summer, which brought to mind the Columbine High School shooting of 1999 for many in the state and across the nation.

Lawmakers in the politically moderate state are considering a package of gun control measures, including plans that would limit ammunition magazines to 15 rounds and expand background checks to include private sales and online purchases. Both measures cleared Democratic-controlled committees on 3-2 party-line votes but still need approval from the full Senate, which could debate the bills as soon as this week.

Retired astronaut and Navy captain Mark Kelly, the husband of Gabrielle Giffords, told lawmakers that he and his wife support the Second Amendment, but he said the right to bear arms should not extend to criminals and the mentally ill. Kelly compared the different background check requirements for private and retail sales to having two different lines at the airport, one with security and one without.

"Which one do you think the terrorist is going to choose?" he asked.

Giffords, a former Democratic congresswoman from Tucson, Ariz., was severely wounded in a mass shooting in January 2011 while meeting with constituents.

Gun control opponents say the proposals will not reduce violence. They argue that lawmakers should focus on strengthening access to mental health services for people who could be dangerous to communities.

The bill hearings were at times testy, and included some outbursts from the audience. After one bill passed, someone leaving the committee yelled "That sucks!" to lawmakers.

"I've never seen such unprofessional behavior," Democratic Sen. Irene Aguilar told the audience at one point.

Meanwhile, gun rights advocates complained that lawmakers limited testimony time and many did not have a chance to speak on proposals.

The commotion at the Capitol underscored the attention the debate has generated nationally from gun rights groups, such as the National Rifle Association, to victims' families and White House officials.

Several bills before state senators have already cleared the House. And because Democrats control both chambers of the state Legislature, some of the proposals have a strong chance of passing.

Other measures that picked up initial Senate approval would place new restrictions on gun ownership by people convicted in domestic violence cases, and another requires gun buyers to pay for their own background checks.

The state's Democratic governor, John Hickenlooper, supports magazine limits and expanded background checks. He has not indicated where he stands on other measures, including whether he supports a proposal that would hold sellers and owners of assault weapons liable for shootings by such firearms.

Gun rights supporters walked the Capitol halls wearing stickers that read, "I Vote Pro-Gun." Several dozen people outside the Capitol waved American flags as light snow fell, and a small plane flew overhead carrying a banner with a message for the governor, "HICK: DO NOT TAKE OUR GUNS!"

One of the nation's largest producers of ammunition magazines, Colorado-based Magpul, has threatened to leave the state if lawmakers restrict the size of its products. Its founder said smaller magazines can be easily connected to each other, and the company fears it would legally liable if people were to do that.

About 20 Colorado sheriffs opposed the expanded background checks and the magazine limits. Standing shoulder-to-shoulder in front of lawmakers in committee, they said that both bills were unenforceable.

"This bill just doesn't make any sense from our perspective," Pueblo Sheriff Kirk Taylor said about the bill to limit magazine sizes.

Victims who have lost relatives to gun violence say it's time for legislators to take action.

Tom Sullivan, whose son Alex was among the 12 killed in the Aurora, Colo., theater shooting, was among the people urging lawmakers to pass magazine restrictions.

"He was enjoying the movie one second, and then the next second he was dead," Tom Sullivan said.

Jane Dougherty, whose sister, Mary Sherlach, was a psychologist killed in the shooting rampage at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., has been lobbying Colorado lawmakers to pass new gun laws. She said she does not understand gun owners who worry the bills are putting a burden on their rights.

She said the Connecticut shooter used "the same type of weapon that we use in war" to "slaughter these babies" and asked lawmakers for stricter gun laws.

"We can not wait for yet another massacre to transpire," Dougherty said.

Title: Biden Reverses Stance on Abortion Funding Amidst Criticism from Democratic Rivals

Article:

Former U.S. Vice-President Joe Biden has reversed his stance on the Hyde Amendment, a law that restricts federal funding for abortions, following mounting criticism from his fellow 2020 Democratic presidential candidates.

At a Democratic gala on Thursday, Mr. Biden denounced the Hyde Amendment, stating he believed healthcare is a right. The party's current front-runner added that he made "no apologies" for having previously supported the amendment.

Elizabeth Warren and Beto O'Rourke were among those who had recently criticized his stance. Mr. Biden had long voiced support for the Hyde Amendment, a law passed in 1976, right after the Roe v Wade Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion across the U.S.

The Hyde Amendment, written by Henry Hyde, an Illinois Republican congressman, in 1976, states that "none of the funds contained in this Act shall be used to perform abortions except where the life of the mother would be endangered if the fetus were carried to term." This means that the vast majority of women receiving federal assistance through the low-income healthcare program Medicaid would be blocked from using that money for abortion services, which can often cost several hundred dollars.

In 1994, under Democratic President Bill Clinton, the Hyde Amendment was updated to include exceptions in cases of rape or incest.

Speaking at a gala by the Democratic National Committee in Atlanta, Mr. Biden said the amendment was now incompatible with his views on universal health coverage.

"If I believe health care is a right, as I do, I can no longer support an amendment that makes that right dependent on someone's ZIP code," Mr. Biden said. "I want to be clear. I make no apologies for my last position. I make no apologies for what I'm about to say."

Mr. Biden said he was "working through the finer details" of his healthcare plan and had been "struggling with the problems that Hyde now presents." He cited the recent push by conservative state legislatures nationwide to enact restrictions on abortion or an outright ban, as Alabama did, as one of the reasons for his policy change.

On Friday, University of Alabama trustees voted to return a $26.5 million gift after the donor called on students to boycott the institution over the state's abortion law, but the school told the Associated Press the decision was made due to the donor's demands about how the money would be used.

"Times have changed," the former vice-president said. "I do not think these guys are going to let up." He did not mention the attacks on his stance from his party members.

Mr. Biden is a practicing Roman Catholic who has previously said he personally opposes abortion, but does not think he should impose his religious beliefs on others.

Joe Biden's original opposition to taxpayer-funded abortion was not so much out of step with the American public as it was in conflict with the active and vocal base of the Democratic Party. It's a base that passionately, and with valid reason, feels that abortion rights in the U.S. are under the strongest attack in decades. They want to know that Democratic presidential candidates won't waver in support of the procedure's continued legality.

The former vice-president's position on the subject, while drawing ire and fire from opponents and advocates, was not necessarily a political liability, however, given that his support comes from more moderate Democrats and independents. In Mr. Biden, these voters may see a reflection of their own nuanced and sometimes conflicting views on abortion rights.

If Mr. Biden had held firm, the storm would have passed. Instead, he waffled. If this is how the Biden campaign will handle attacks on his lengthy record, the former vice-president could be in for a bumpy ride.

Much of Mr. Biden's support stems from the perception that he is a winning candidate who can stand up to - and defeat - Donald Trump. Too many fumbles, and that veneer of electability will strip away.

Many among the field of 24 candidates for the 2020 Democratic nomination - including Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and Jay Inslee - expressed support this week for repealing the law.

On Wednesday, both Mr. O'Rourke, a former Texas congressman, and Ms. Warren, a Massachusetts senator, directly criticized Mr. Biden's now-changed viewpoint.

Speaking to MSNBC during a televised town hall event, Ms. Warren said she felt Mr. Biden was wrong to support the amendment because "it's just discrimination" against poorer women.

Mr. O'Rourke told CBS News that Mr. Biden's viewpoint was "absolutely wrong."

"Perhaps he does not understand," he said, "who the Hyde Amendment hurts the most, lower income communities, communities of color."

The four female senators running for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination - Ms. Warren, Kamala Harris, Kirsten Gillibrand, and Amy Klobuchar - have co-sponsored a measure to revoke the Hyde Amendment. They also tweeted criticisms of the law this week, but did not name Mr. Biden.

Title: Iran Protests Spread, US, Allies Support Anti-Government Demonstrations Amidst Tensions in Region

Article:

Iranian leaders' apologies over the downing of a Ukrainian passenger plane last week have failed to quell the growing anti-government protests across the country. The airliner disaster occurred hours after Iran fired missiles at Iraqi military bases housing U.S. troops, in retaliation for a drone strike at Baghdad airport that killed Iranian commander Qasem Soleimani.

On Sunday, eight Katyusha rockets hit Iraq's Balad Air Base, north of Baghdad, wounding four Iraqi air force officers, according to an Iraqi military statement. No American or coalition forces were at the base when the rockets struck, a U.S. military official told CNN.

In Iran, demonstrators are calling for Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to step down and for those responsible for downing the plane to be prosecuted. Protests have now spread to other cities, including Shiraz, Esfahan, Hamedan, and Orumiyeh, according to Reuters.

U.S. President Donald Trump tweeted his support for the demonstrators, saying his administration will "continue to stand by you." Likewise, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu voiced his support for the protesters and called on European powers to increase pressure on the Iranian regime.

Iran previously denied U.S. claims that the country had shot down the plane before admitting the mistake on Saturday. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani said his country "deeply regrets this disastrous mistake" and his "thoughts and prayers go to all the mourning families." Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif blamed the disaster on "human error" and "US adventurism."

The protests came as Iran faces fresh criticism abroad for the temporary arrest Saturday of British Ambassador Rob Macaire. On Sunday, Macaire was summoned to the Iranian foreign ministry. According to the semi-official Tasnim news agency, Macaire was arrested while in the middle of a crowd of protesters in front of Tehran's Amir Kabir University. He was accused of instigating and directing radical and destructive demonstrations, and later released.

UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab called Macaire's arrest a "flagrant violation of international law" -- a sentiment echoed by the German and French foreign ministries. Iranian officials said Macaire was released as soon as his identity was confirmed.

The downed plane's victims included 57 Canadians, and the country's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau told a press conference Saturday that, "what Iran has admitted to is very serious." "Canada will not rest until we get the accountability, justice, and closure that the families deserve," Trudeau said.

Rouhani told Trudeau he was committed "to collaborate, to give closure to the victims, de-escalate tensions in the region and continue this dialogue," the Canadian PM said. Meanwhile, the Ukrainian general prosecutor's office said in a statement it was now investigating the incident as a possible case of "willful killing and aircraft destruction." The downing of the plane is being handled as a case of "violation of traffic safety rules" and "operation of air transport resulting in death." However, prosecutors said Iran's admission changed the scope to "liability for the willful killing of two or more people and the destruction of the aircraft."

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky tweeted that Iran's admission was a "step in the right direction." Iranian authorities are in possession of the two flight data recorders, also known as black boxes, which Ukrainian investigators got access to on Friday. They have yet to start examining the information, but have said it included communications between the pilot and Tehran flight control.

Title: President Trump Preemptively Warns Protesters Ahead of Tulsa Rally

Article:

President Donald Trump signaled on Friday that protesters, "anarchists," and those causing unrest will face a tougher response in Tulsa, Oklahoma, this weekend compared to Democratic-run cities across the country. In a tweet, Mr. Trump warned that protesters, "anarchists," agitators, looters, or "lowlifes" who travel to Oklahoma for his comeback rally on Saturday night will not be treated as they have been in cities like New York, Seattle, or Minneapolis.

The tweet did not distinguish between protesters demonstrating against racial injustice and those who have damaged property or occupied parts of cities following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody. White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany later clarified that the president was referring to protesters who are violent, "anarchists," and looters.

Tulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum, a Republican, agreed not to impose a previously ordered curfew on rally attendees, according to the Trump campaign. The Oklahoma Supreme Court also denied an attempt by local plaintiffs to block the rally from taking place. In a unanimous ruling, the state court stated that the petitioners did not establish a "clear legal right" to cancel the rally.

The Trump campaign expects tens of thousands of people to attend the rally at the Bank of Oklahoma (BOK) Center, with the president's first rally since early March, when the coronavirus began spreading in the U.S. The campaign will check attendees' temperatures, distribute hand sanitizer, and masks at the door, though wearing masks is optional.

Ms. McEnany stated she does not plan to wear a mask at the rally, citing it as a personal decision and her regular testing. The president is aiming to rejuvenate the economy after societal lockdowns aimed at controlling the virus and positioning himself as a "law and order" candidate who will not tolerate protests turning violent.

However, Mr. Trump continues to face criticism for his decision to stage a photo-op at St. John's Episcopal Church near the White House after police forcefully cleared mostly peaceful protesters from Lafayette Park on June 1. It remains unclear whether similar incidents will occur in Tulsa. Community organizers plan to observe the Juneteenth holiday over the weekend in the historic Greenwood district, which was known as Black Wall Street before a 1921 massacre.

Ross Baker, a political professor at Rutgers University, commented, "The president has been rattling his cage. He is desperate to break out of the physical confines of the White House and draw energy from an adoring crowd, which he is certain to get in Tulsa, where there is little chance of large counter-demonstrations." Mr. Baker added, "This is all about his own morale, which has been flagging since the Lafayette Square episode."

Title: 69-Year-Old Man Dies in Shootout with Police at Immigration Detention Center in Tacoma, Washington

Article:

A 69-year-old man identified as Willem Van Spronsen was shot and killed by police early Saturday morning after he allegedly threw incendiary devices at the Tacoma Northwest Detention Center, a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) facility in Tacoma, Washington. The Tacoma Police Department responded to the privately run detention center, which holds migrants pending deportation proceedings, at approximately 4 a.m.

According to police spokeswoman Loretta Cool, Van Spronsen caused a vehicle to catch fire and attempted to ignite a large propane tank and set buildings on fire. He was armed with a rifle, a satchel, and flares, police said. Officers called out to Van Spronsen, and shots were fired. Cool did not have specific details of what transpired, but she stated that the area is covered by surveillance cameras from the detention center. She did not know whether Van Spronsen fired at the officers.

After the gunfire, officers took cover, contained the area, and set up medical aid a short distance away, police said. Officers then located Van Spronsen and determined he had been shot and was dead at the scene. No law enforcement officers were injured. The four Tacoma police officers who fired their weapons have been placed on paid administrative leave as is standard in officer-involved shootings.

Authorities are still investigating the incident, and questions remain about the motive behind Van Spronsen's actions.
