Deb Bartley, a friend of Van Spronsen's for about 20 years, told the Seattle Times that she believes he wanted to provoke a fatal conflict. Bartley described Van Spronsen as an anarchist and anti-fascist, and believes his attack on the detention center was intended to provoke a fatal conflict.

Van Spronsen was accused of assaulting a police officer during a protest outside the detention center in 2018. According to court documents, he lunged at the officer and wrapped his arms around the officer's neck and shoulders, as the officer was trying to detain a 17-year-old protester. Van Spronsen pleaded guilty to the charge of obstructing police and was given a deferred sentence in October.

GEO Group, which runs the 1,575-bed Northwest Detention Center, released a statement to The Associated Press, saying, "Baseless accusations about how detainees are treated at our facilities have led to misplaced aggression and a dangerous environment for our employees, whose safety is our top priority. Violence of any kind against our employees and property will not be tolerated."

The detention center in Tacoma has modern amenities, including air conditioning, recreational activities, a bed for every individual, and medical care available at all hours, according to GEO Group. Last year, a federal judge ruled that Washington state could pursue its lawsuit seeking to force GEO Group to pay minimum wage for work done by detainees at the detention center.

In November, a Russian asylum-seeker who conducted a hunger strike to protest the conditions at the detention center died by suicide, the Pierce County Medical Examiner's Office ruled. Mergensana Amar, 40, was taken off life support after attempting to kill himself while in voluntary protective custody at the detention center on November 15, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement said.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Defends ISIS Assessments Amidst Political Controversy

Article:

In a memo to staff obtained by Fox News, the Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, praised his analysts for their work in bringing attention to the Islamic State's (ISIS) gains over the past two years. This praise comes amidst a heated debate following President Obama's comments to "60 Minutes" over the weekend, where he suggested that the intelligence community may have underestimated the threat posed by ISIS.

The ensuing controversy has led to a round of finger-pointing, with the White House distancing itself from any intention to blame the intelligence community. However, the White House is disputing accusations from Republican lawmakers and intelligence officials that Obama ignored ISIS warnings for months.

Rep. Michele Bachmann (R-Minn.) told Fox News on Wednesday that lawmakers on the House Intelligence Committee, on which she sits, had been warning the administration for years about the seriousness of the ISIS threat.

In the memo to staff sent Tuesday, Clapper made clear that his officers have been monitoring, assessing, and drawing attention to the expansion of ISIS for a while. He wrote, "I'm proud of the [intelligence community's] efforts over the past two years to monitor, assess, and call attention to the expansion of ISIL, and I know the president has found that work to be critical to developing his strategy."

Clapper noted that both he and Obama were on the same page in saying it was difficult to predict the "will" of Iraqi security forces to fight. He wrote, "Despite all we understood about the capabilities of ISIL and the Iraqi Security Forces, we have no intelligence tool that could have predicted the ISF's sudden collapse in northern Iraq and the resultant ease with which ISIL forces captured territory."

Clapper's claims about how their analysts have been drawing attention to ISIS for the past two years could fuel concerns that the White House was not taking those assessments seriously enough. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers (R-Mich.) has faulted "policy makers" for not confronting the threat.

When asked Wednesday about Clapper's role, Rogers suggested Obama missed key briefings, telling Fox News, "James Clapper has a tough job overseeing 16 intel agencies. I am more concerned about the president and the missed intel briefings."

Intelligence officials have told Fox News and other outlets that they were drawing attention for months to the ISIS threat but were ignored by the White House. On Tuesday, White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest pointed to Clapper's memo to rebut one anonymous quote to that effect in The New York Times.

"He put out a message to the intelligence community that directly contradicts the anonymous individual who's quoted in the New York Times," Earnest said, reading passages from Clapper's memo and saying the memo was "consistent" with Obama's comments on "60 Minutes."

Clapper previously had admitted that U.S. analysts both underestimated the Islamic State and "overestimated" the ability of the Iraqi army to fight them. However, the memo on Tuesday did not acknowledge underestimating ISIS, as Obama said on "60 Minutes."

Title: Obama to Warn Iran of Consequences Over Nuclear Weapons, Address UN General Assembly

Article:

President Barack Obama will deliver a stern warning to Iran on Tuesday, stating that the United States will take necessary actions to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons. The warning comes as part of Obama's address to the annual opening of the United Nations General Assembly this week.

According to Reuters, the president will emphasize the need for a united front against further attacks on U.S. diplomatic missions in Muslim countries. In his address, Obama is expected to say:

"America wants to resolve this issue through diplomacy, and we believe that there is still time and space to do so. But that time is not unlimited. We respect the right of nations to access peaceful nuclear power, but one of the purposes of the United Nations is to see that we harness that power for peace. Make no mistake: a nuclear-armed Iran is not a challenge that can be contained. It would threaten the elimination of Israel, the security of Gulf nations, and the stability of the global economy. It risks triggering a nuclear-arms race in the region, and the unraveling of the non-proliferation treaty. That is why a coalition of countries is holding the Iranian government accountable. And that is why the United States will do what we must to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon."

In addition to addressing the Iranian nuclear issue, Obama is also expected to pay tribute to Ambassador Chris Stevens, who died after a Sept. 11 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya.

Obama's address comes as the U.S. presidential campaign heads towards its finish. Republican rival Mitt Romney has criticized Obama's foreign affairs leadership in the lead-up to the president's speech.

Both Obama and Romney are scheduled to address the Clinton Global Initiative today. The U.N. webcasts its proceedings, and updates will be posted as the president and other leaders address the assembly.

Notably, Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu are also scheduled to speak at the General Assembly, on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

Title: International Community Rallies to Aid in Search for Abducted Nigerian Schoolgirls

Article:

The international community is rallying to aid in the search for 276 schoolgirls abducted by the militant group Boko Haram in Nigeria on April 14. The girls were taken from the Government Girls Secondary School in rural Chibok, about 80 miles (130 kilometers) west of Maiduguri and some 600 miles from the capital of Abuja.

President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria has vowed that Boko Haram's abduction of the schoolgirls will be the terror group's undoing. He made the statement at the opening of the World Economic Forum meeting in Nigeria's capital city of Abuja. Jonathan acknowledged offers of help from the United States, Britain, China, and France, all of which have offered help in the weeks-old search for the girls.

However, the task of recovering the girls appears to have grown more complicated with news that U.S. intelligence believes the girls have been split up. U.S. Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby, the Pentagon press secretary, stated that they think the girls have been broken up into smaller groups. He declined to detail how U.S. officials came to this conclusion.

Former UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown, the U.N.'s special envoy for global education, told CNN that the search must be expanded to Niger, Cameroon, and Chad to find information that could lead to the girls. Brown emphasized the importance of using the information to find the girls before they are dispersed across Africa, which is a very real possibility.

The girls have not been seen since their abduction, and on Sunday night, another kidnapping occurred in the village of Warabe, with villagers accusing Boko Haram militants of taking at least eight girls between the ages of 12 and 15.

Boko Haram, which translates to "Western education is sin" in the local Hausa language, has been known to kill Muslim clerics who dare criticize them. The United States has branded Boko Haram a terror organization and has put a $7 million bounty on its leader, Abubakar Shekau. Nigerian police also announced a reward of about $310,000 for information leading to the girls' rescue.

The Nigerian government has been under fire for its response to the abduction, with many criticizing government officials for failing to take action in the hours and days following the girls' abduction. Jonathan, who waited three weeks before speaking to the nation on the matter, and his security ministers have defended the response, saying efforts were underway but could not be disclosed publicly.

The United States is sending a team of law enforcement experts and military advisers to Nigeria to support the Nigerian efforts to rescue the girls. France said Thursday that it would send a "specialized team" to help. The British government is also sending a small team, according to Prime Minister David Cameron's office. Neither country said exactly what expertise their teams would bring. British satellites and advanced tracking capabilities will also be used, and China has promised to provide any intelligence gathered by its satellite network, according to the Nigerian government.

Seven members of the U.S. military are scheduled to arrive in Nigeria on Friday to join a team of advisers supporting the Nigerian efforts to rescue the girls. There are no plans to send U.S. combat troops, according to Kirby. Nigeria's top security officials have appealed to the public for help during a visit to the Chibok school on Thursday, according to a statement released by Nigeria's director of defense information. The chief of defense, Air Marshal Alex S. Badeh, called on members of the immediate community to provide security agencies with useful information that will lead to the rescue of the girls.

Title: Congressional Leaders and President Trump Fail to Reach Agreement on Government Shutdown

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - A meeting between U.S. congressional leaders and President Donald Trump on Wednesday failed to produce an agreement to end the 12-day partial government shutdown, with the president insisting on $5 billion in funding for a border wall and Democrats opposing the demand. Congressional leaders are expected to return to the White House on Friday, signaling the shutdown will likely continue into the weekend.

The White House convened the meeting to try to convince Democrats that funding a wall on the southern border with Mexico was a pressing security need. Instead, Democratic leaders cut off Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen's presentation and tried to press Trump to accept their offer.

"It just was not a credible presentation," Senator Dick Durbin said of the briefing. He added that Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi, who is expected to be elected House speaker on Thursday, insisted the conversation focus instead on the shutdown.

Pelosi said the House would proceed with plans to hold votes on Thursday, when they formally take control of the chamber from Trump's fellow Republicans, on legislation that would end the shutdown without providing the wall money sought by Trump.

"We're asking the president to open up government," Pelosi told reporters outside the White House after the meeting.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said afterward on the Senate floor that the chamber would not vote on the legislation, calling it a "political sideshow" and "total nonstarter."

Democrats say they want to fund most of the government through September, but allow for another month to negotiate wall funding by only partially funding the Department of Homeland Security, which is responsible for the wall. Schumer said Trump conceded that Republicans would lose leverage if they allowed the rest of the government to be funded.

"We asked him to give us one good reason... why you should continue your shutdown of the eight Cabinet departments while we are debating our differences on homeland security. He could not give a good answer," Schumer told reporters after the meeting.

In a tweet on Wednesday evening, Trump called the meeting "important" and said he would continue talks with Democrats "to pass a bill that secures our borders, supports the agents and officers on the ground, and keeps America Safe."

Trump's demand for $5 billion in funding for a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border triggered the shutdown affecting about a quarter of the federal government and 800,000 federal workers. Before meeting with lawmakers, Trump said the shutdown would last for "as long as it takes" as he pushes for wall money as part of any legislation to reopen agencies shuttered when their funding lapsed on Dec. 22.

"It could be a long time, or it could be quickly," Trump told reporters on Wednesday during a Cabinet meeting.

"We know that we have a challenge along the border," said Kevin McCarthy, the top House Republican. "We want to solve that issue. We want to make sure we open this government up. And I think at the end of the day, the president, listening to him, he wants to solve this as well."

Pelosi noted that the legislation being presented in the House had previously won backing in the Senate, which will remain in Republican hands in the new 2019-2020 Congress that convenes on Thursday.

But McConnell said previously that Senate Republicans would not approve a spending measure Trump does not support.

Trump made the border wall a key part of his presidential campaign. Before meeting with the Democrats, Trump called the border a "sieve," rebutted Pelosi's complaint that a wall was immoral, provided an estimate of the U.S. illegal immigrant population far higher than the figures most experts cite and made disputed comments about progress toward building a wall.

The visit by Pelosi and Schumer was their first to the White House since their sharp exchange with Trump in the Oval Office on Dec. 11 during which the president told them he would be "proud to shut down the government for border security."

The $5 billion Trump is seeking would cover only a portion of the money needed for a border wall, a project estimated to cost about $23 billion. Trump had said Mexico would pay for the wall, but Mexico has refused.

Title: West Point Graduation Ceremony Held In-Person Despite COVID-19 Outbreak, 1.5% of Graduates Test Positive

Article:

The United States Military Academy at West Point did not require an in-person graduation ceremony this year due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. However, President Donald Trump insisted on delivering an in-person commencement address to the 1,000-person graduating class on June 13, prompting Army leaders to alter their plans and summon cadets back to campus.

On Monday, the Army announced that 1.5% of the returning graduates, approximately 15 or 16 students, had tested positive for COVID-19. Army spokesperson Emanuel L. Ortiz stated in an emailed statement, "This was anticipated. None were symptomatic, and no cadet has contracted through person-to-person contact while under the Army's care."

The decision to hold an in-person ceremony, despite the ongoing pandemic, has been met with criticism. In March, as West Point leaders discussed whether to return students currently on spring break to campus, Trump announced his intention to attend the ceremony. The New York Times reported that academy officials were taken aback by the impromptu announcement and were forced to improvise after Trump "preempted their planning."

Secretary of Defense Mark Esper addressed Naval Academy graduates virtually last month, and Vice President Mike Pence spoke at a socially-distanced Air Force Academy commencement event with no spectators. Trump is expected to deliver a more pageantry-filled speech at West Point, the only service academy he has not yet addressed as commencement speaker.

Lt. Gen. Darryl Williams, the academy's superintendent, told reporters that returning cadets will be "segregated the entire time" into five cohorts, and no cohort will intermingle for 14 days. "They'll eat separately, they'll live separately," he said.

The Army has struggled to justify Trump's decision, which requires hundreds of future soldiers to return to a region of the country that has been hit especially hard by the coronavirus. Ryan McCarthy, the Army's top civilian leader, said cadets would have needed to return to campus anyway "to begin the process of the physicals they need, to take all of their clearance procedures, to clear barracks, get their personal items." However, that process could have been spaced out in a way that would have ensured greater safety for cadets.

Even academy alumni and parents were reportedly stunned by the decision. "There is no military need to do this," Jason Fritz, a 2002 West Point graduate, told the Washington Post. "This is a logistics nightmare, all just so the president has an audience to give a speech he wants to give."

The commencement speech has sparked an uproar on the West Point Parents Facebook group, where most posts tend to be anodyne calls for support for cadets and the Army. In a thread announcing Trump as the graduation speaker that appeared in April, when the decision was announced, several posters blasted the decision as both narcissistic and dangerous. "PLEASE PLEASE do not let your children go back for graduation. It's not worth their health or yours," one person wrote. But others contextualized Trump's mandate by comparing it to a typical order from a commander in chief, including ones that send cadets off to war. "For those who have not yet done so, use this time of social distancing to come to terms with the choice our children have made," another parent suggested, "and realize that this choice will likely put them in harm's way in some way, shape or form."

Title: Reddit Quarantines 'european' Subreddit, Sparking Debate on Free Speech and Censorship

Article:

Administrators at the popular online forum Reddit have quarantined a subreddit titled 'european', sparking a debate on free speech and censorship. Subreddits, or communities dedicated to specific topics, function as forums for users to discuss various subjects.

The quarantine of the 'european' subreddit occurred on May 12, 2016, as stated in a note on the subreddit's link. The note reads, "The administration has decided to censor free speech for Europeans and they quarantined the subreddit." The subreddit has been set to private, and the note adds that "You must be a moderator or approved submitter to visit." Visitors were also urged to continue their discussions on Voat, another online forum.

Recent allegations of bias in social media have come to the forefront, with the Reddit accusation following closely on the heels of anonymous claims that contractors at Facebook deliberately suppressed conservative news on the site's Trending Topics section. Facebook has denied any political bias, stating there is "no evidence" of the alleged activity.

Reddit stated that the 'european' subreddit violated the forum's content policy. In an emailed statement to FoxNews.com, Reddit explained, "Quarantines on Reddit are rare - there are thousands of vibrant conversations flourishing on the site every day." The statement continued, "Subreddits are quarantined only when the content is clearly offensive to the broader Reddit community."

Quarantining aims to prevent the content from being accidentally viewed by those who do not wish to do so. "A subreddit is quarantined when there are concerns that its content is extreme and could be offensive to people outside of that community," explained Reddit. "The quarantine process doesn’t end the conversation; it adds an opt-in measure so that people have the choice to join the conversation," it added.

Restrictions on a quarantined subreddit include requiring an explicit opt-in, requiring an account with a verified email address, no use of custom images, and the removal of revenue generation.

The 'european' quarantining has prompted a mixed reaction elsewhere on Reddit. Some users claim that racist views were expressed on the subreddit, while others argue that it hosted a range of opinions and emphasize the importance of open dialogue.

Reddit, which had over 277 million unique visitors last month, uses teams of volunteers to moderate subreddits. The forum updated its content policy last year, consolidating multiple rules and policies into a single set of guidelines.

A blogger with an interest in numbers, who uses the name Curious Gnu, recently analyzed a Reddit dataset of 4.6 million comments and noted that 78 percent of Reddit threads with over 1,000 comments mention Nazis or Hitler. The blogger found that around 2.6 percent of comments in the 'european' subreddit mentioned Nazis or Hitler, a slightly higher percentage compared to the 'AskHistorians' and 'history' subreddits, which had around 2.75 percent and 2.7 percent of comments referencing the topics, respectively.

Related: Reddit updates content policy, bans a 'handful' of groups that exist'solely to annoy' others; No censorship in Chinese Internet, says China's top censor.

Title: Justice Department Increases Investigations into Classified Information Leaks

Article:

The Justice Department has 27 ongoing investigations into leaks of classified information with a "political motive," Attorney General Jeff Sessions revealed Tuesday during his testimony before the House Judiciary Committee. This number is three times more than the agency had in the three years prior.

"Leaks have reached epidemic proportions," Sessions said. "We have 27 ongoing investigations, some of those involve leaks before President Trump took office, and some after."

Sessions added that before this year, it was only three per year—there were nine. He also stated that Reality Winner, a former National Security Agency contractor, had been charged for leaking classified information.

Winner is accused of leaking a classified intelligence report containing "Top Secret Level" information. The report, according to the Justice Department, contained classified defense information from an intelligence community agency. Winner was an avid supporter of Sen. Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign.

In July, the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee released a report that revealed the Trump administration was facing an "alarming" and "unprecedented" cascade of media leaks that posed a potential danger to national security. The report estimated that the administration has dealt with roughly one leak per day.

The report stated that leaks flowed about "seven times faster" under the Trump administration than during the first 126 days of both Obama's and George W. Bush's presidencies.

Title: US Designates North Korea as State Sponsor of Terrorism, Escalating Tensions

Article:

The United States has designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism, a move that escalates tensions between the two nations. President Donald Trump announced the decision during a Cabinet meeting on Monday, stating, "Should have happened a long time ago." The administration will reveal new sanctions against North Korea on Tuesday.

The designation places North Korea alongside Iran, Sudan, and Syria as the only countries on the state sponsors of terrorism list. The designation bars them from receiving US development assistance, bans defense sales to them, restricts exports of items that could potentially be used for military purposes, and also places tougher financial restrictions on them, according to the State Department.

However, the actual support for terrorism by North Korea, the reason for placing a country on the list, is debatable. Administration lawyers noted that North Korea had to commit more than one act of terrorism to warrant placement on the list. The Trump administration officials assert that the February assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's estranged half-brother in Malaysia was an act of terrorism.

There is no agreement within the administration as to whether the brutal death of Otto Warmbier, a 23-year-old US citizen released by North Korea this summer who returned home in a coma, constituted terrorism.

North Korea was previously on the state sponsor of terror list but was removed during talks designed to get the country to stop its nuclear program under President George W. Bush. However, North Korea tested a missile capable of hitting most of the US on July 28, and Trump's move can be seen as a return to a previous policy.

It is unlikely that this designation will stop North Korea's nuclear program. North Korea has no interest in giving up its nuclear program and is already heavily sanctioned by the US, China, and Europe. The Trump administration continues to ask China to put even more pressure on North Korea, especially since China accounts for about 90 percent of North Korea's trade. China recently sent an envoy to North Korea this month, a development Trump called a "big move" on Twitter.

Title: Green Party Candidate Jill Stein's Recount Effort and Governor McCrory's Fraud Allegations in North Carolina

Article:

Green Party candidate Jill Stein has raised over $4 million in three days for a recount in three critical Rust Belt states: Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, and Michigan. The recount is in response to what Stein called a "hack-riddled election." Meanwhile, Republican Governor Pat McCrory of North Carolina has refused to concede a loss in the state, claiming fraudulent votes gave his opponent, Attorney General Roy Cooper, the win on Election Day.

Experts suggest that both candidates' gambits are unlikely to change the election outcome, given the scant evidence to support the fraud claims. The divisive nature of the 2016 election, as evidenced by these actions, highlights the need for increased confidence in the electoral system, according to some election experts.

J. Alex Halderman, director of the University of Michigan Center for Computer Security and Society, has suggested that regular auditing of voting machines could provide safeguards against hackers and improve voter peace of mind. Halderman has demonstrated that some American voting machines can be hacked.

Stein's recount effort has been fueled in part by disgruntled Hillary Clinton voters, eager to blame conspiracy rather than voter sentiment for Clinton's Election Day loss to Donald Trump. Concerns were raised by a team of researchers, including Halderman, which found discrepancies in some key Wisconsin counties won by Trump. However, the Clinton campaign has remained silent on Stein's recount gambit.

In North Carolina, Governor McCrory is facing headwinds in his allegations of a broader voter conspiracy that put Cooper over the top. McCrory, who is more than 7,000 votes behind, is demanding a recount. Preliminary analyses suggest that at least one list of supposedly fraudulent voters was largely wrong, with most of the names listed as ineligible found to be valid voters. County election boards, run by Republicans, have also found little evidence of voter wrongdoing.

The willingness to invoke the potential of fraud has, to some extent, dovetailed with emerging cyberthreats to ring fresh alarm bells about the US voting system. At the very least, recent hacks of the Democratic Party and state voter registration systems suggest that those keen to disrupt the US system are probing its defenses.

Reforms suggested to improve the integrity of elections include bolder safeguards against insider wrongdoing, more federal funding to upgrade aging voting machines, and, critically, automatic paper-trail audits. About 70 percent of US voting machines leave a paper trail, but randomized checks are done only upon request.

"It is vital that we protect voters from the real threats to the integrity of elections," Myrna Perez, a law professor at the New York University School of Law, wrote in a Brennan Center report from earlier this year. "Fortunately, it is possible to protect election integrity without disenfranchising eligible voters."

Title: Trump and Pence Seek Momentum in Second Presidential Debate

Article:

In the upcoming second presidential debate on Sunday, Donald Trump is aiming to build on the momentum created by his running mate, Mike Pence, following the latter's perceived victory in the sole vice presidential debate on Tuesday. Pence's performance has been widely praised for outperforming his Democratic counterpart, Virginia Senator Tim Kaine, during the vice presidential debate.

The vice presidential debate has come as a breath of fresh air for Trump, who has faced a series of setbacks, including an ineffective debate performance, a public feud with a former Miss Universe, damaging tax revelations, and a steady decline in opinion polls.

At a rally in Henderson, Nevada, on Wednesday, Trump praised Pence, stating, "Mike Pence did an incredible job. I'm getting a lot of credit because that's really my first so-called choice; that's really my first hire, as we would say in Las Vegas."

The apparent success of Pence in the vice presidential debate is unlikely to significantly alter the course of the race, as vice presidential debates typically have minimal impact. However, the stakes are high, as Trump prepares to face Hillary Clinton in St. Louis on October 9.

Tobe Berkovitz, a Boston University professor specializing in political communications, commented, "How many times have all the pundits been interviewed saying, 'Trump is finally finished'? That must have happened 10 times. The problem now is the clock is running down. We'll be at four weeks, three weeks, two weeks. Can he pull the rabbit out of the hat one more time?"

With the second debate now of increased importance, there are reports that the Trump team is taking a more focused approach to debate preparations. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, an early Trump supporter and skilled debater, is said to be involved in the debate preparations.

However, some Republicans are skeptical about the extent to which Trump can make up ground at this stage. GOP strategist and Hill contributor Matt Mackowiak stated, "Now it's up to him. It's like coaching versus playing. Coaches can prepare you and they can have the right play calls. But at the end of the day, the player on the field has to go do it. So far, Trump has fallen short. He really needs to win decisively on Sunday."

Numerous recent polls have shown the scale of the challenge Trump faces. On Wednesday, a new poll from Monmouth University showed him trailing Clinton by 2 percentage points in Ohio, a historically favorable battleground state for the GOP nominee. Another new survey, from WRAL-TV and Survey USA, showed Trump trailing in North Carolina by 2 points. A national poll from Reuters/IPSOS gave Clinton a 6-point edge.

The data forecasting site FiveThirtyEight gave Clinton a 76.2 percent chance of prevailing in its "poll-only" forecast as of Wednesday evening, her highest rating by that measure since late August. However, the polls of the race have swung wildly before.

Clinton has twice led the RealClearPolitics national polling average by more than 6 points—in mid-June and early August—only to have Trump narrow those leads down to virtually nothing. Some Clinton critics maintain that she could yet be pushed off track by an external event, such as an unforced error or damaging disclosures from an organization such as WikiLeaks, which published embarrassing emails between Democratic National Committee staffers as the party's convention began this summer in Philadelphia.

A WikiLeaks news conference earlier this week failed to live up to the hype that surrounded it, casting doubt on whether the organization can follow through on its threats. Republicans also warn that Trump and his supporters cannot depend on a lucky break. The nominee himself, they say, needs to wrest back the initiative from Clinton.

"Hope is not a strategy," said Mackowiak. "More of the same is not going to change the trajectory of the race. He needs to demonstrate at this next debate that he is prepared to be president—and that he can force Hillary Clinton back on defense."

In 2012, President Obama gave a lackluster performance at his opening clash with GOP nominee Mitt Romney and fell sharply in the polls afterward. However, Vice President Biden acquitted himself well against Romney's running mate, future Speaker Paul Ryan, and Obama was much improved when he met Romney a second and third time.

Sunday's debate will be in a town-hall format, but there is no consensus among insiders as to whether that helps or hinders Trump. Some backers suggest it will make it easier for Trump to feed off the energy of the crowd. Skeptics counter that televised town halls are technically challenging, in terms of tone and body language, and that a small, mostly quiet audience creates a very different atmosphere from the rambunctious rallies where Trump thrives.

However, if Trump surpasses expectations and narrows Clinton's lead one more time, he would be hailed as the "turnaround master of the decade." As Tobe Berkovitz put it, "He would be the turnaround master of the decade if he pulls that off."

Title: Trump's Clemency Grants to Military Figures Sparks Controversy Over Military Discipline

Article:

President Donald Trump has granted clemency to three military figures embroiled in war crimes charges, a move that has sparked controversy and criticism from both sides. The Defense Secretary, Mark Esper, on Sunday fired the Navy's top official, Navy Secretary Richard Spencer, over allegations that Spencer proposed a deal with the White House behind Esper's back to resolve the case of Eddie Gallagher.

The pardons have been met with criticism from various quarters, with critics arguing that they undermine military discipline and send a message that U.S. forces will be allowed to get away with anything. The actions of the pardoned individuals, according to critics, qualify as war crimes.

Critics argue that the president has misused his power to give war criminals a free pass. Interfering in the process before one of these cases went to trial was wrong, and overruling the punishment meted out in the other two cases was even worse. The actions of the president, according to critics, undermine military discipline and send a horrible message that U.S. forces will be allowed to get away with anything.

Supporters of the president argue that the president has the power to pardon and that he is righting a wrong. They argue that the president should use his power more often in cases where guilt or a fair trial is in genuine doubt. However, they acknowledge that the use of this power comes with a cost, in this case, injury to the morality of a nation that once held its own to account.

The controversy has also raised questions about the president's role in military personnel decisions. Traditionally, presidents do not micromanage military personnel decisions at this level, and it is seen as bad for morale and can prove disruptive to the chain of command. The SEAL team, which has been shaken by a series of scandals in recent years, has been left to conduct its business in accordance with the rules.

In conclusion, the president's interventions in the cases of military figures undercut military leadership and dishonor the men and women who serve their country while upholding its values. The damage is compounding, with the commander in chief's corrupting influence ever widening. The president's actions have undermined principles that long have served as a bedrock for the armed forces, and by sanctioning illegal behavior, the president endangers the safety of our troops, giving our adversaries a green light to similarly mistreat men and women who serve honorably in our military.

Title: Republican Senators Oppose Motion to Dismiss Impeachment Charges Against Trump

Article:

WASHINGTON - Republican members of the U.S. Senate have expressed opposition to any attempt to dismiss the impeachment charges against President Donald Trump without a trial. The Democratic-led U.S. House of Representatives is expected to formally send the charges to the Senate this week.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) has vowed to help acquit his fellow Republican. Trump appeared to reverse his position on how the Senate should proceed, writing on Twitter that a full trial would give the Democrats who pursued impeachment undeserved credibility and signaling support for dismissal of the charges with no trial.

However, Republican Senator Roy Blunt stated on Monday that there is "almost no interest" among Republican senators for a motion to dismiss the House charges. Republican Senator Mitt Romney also expressed opposition, stating, "At this stage, the allegations that have been made are serious and deserve to be given consideration with the arguments for and against."

Senator Susan Collins, among a handful of Republicans whom Democrats hope to persuade to back their call for witness testimony, told reporters that she and a small group of colleagues were discussing a trial format that would allow lawmakers to vote on whether to include witnesses after hearing from each side and having the opportunity to pose questions.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi delayed sending the two articles of impeachment passed by the House on Dec. 18 to the Republican-led Senate, preventing McConnell from holding a quick trial right away that cleared the president. The House charged Trump with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The impeachment charges stem from Trump's request that Ukraine investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading contender for the Democratic nomination to face Trump in the Nov. 3 presidential election.

House Democrats will discuss on Tuesday how to move forward, with the chamber possibly voting to send the charges to the Senate later that day. Pelosi stated that the delay was meant to convince the U.S. public of the need to call witnesses in the Senate trial after Trump's administration blocked some current and former officials from cooperating in the House impeachment inquiry.

McConnell has yet to say definitively how the Senate will conduct the trial. He has not committed to allowing any witnesses or new documents in the proceedings and instead could steer the process toward a quick acquittal. McConnell has left open the possibility of deciding on witness testimony later in the trial. He has said he sees no chance of the Senate convicting Trump.

The Senate, which could open a trial rapidly after receiving the charges from the House, plans to meet daily except on Sundays each week to conduct the proceedings, likely beginning each day at noon EST (1700 GMT) and working until either 5 p.m. or 6 p.m. EST (2200 or 2300 GMT), according to congressional aides. The Senate is expected to vote to acquit Trump even though some moderate Republicans have bristled over McConnell's reflexive support for the president. Conviction and removal of Trump would require a two-thirds majority of those present in the 100-member chamber.

Title: Hillary Clinton Addresses Election Loss, Media Coverage, and Future Plans at Code Conference

 Article:

 In a speech at the Code Conference in California, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton acknowledged her campaign's missteps while attributing her loss in the 2016 presidential election to factors largely beyond her control.

 "I take responsibility for every decision I made, but that's not why I lost," Clinton stated.

 Clinton described the media coverage of her campaign as "unprecedented" and criticized the dissemination of "weaponized information" from fake news sites as significant factors in her unsuccessful campaign.

 "Over the summer we went and told anyone we could find that the Russians were messing with the election and we were basically shooed away," she said. "We could not get the press to cover it."

 Clinton specifically called out media coverage of her private email scandal, in which she used an unauthorized private email server to conduct communications during her time as secretary of state in the Obama administration.

 "They covered it like it was Pearl Harbor," Mrs. Clinton said of the press.

 Clinton also addressed social media, stating that sites like Facebook and Twitter have been "victimized by deliberate efforts to shape the conversation and push it towards conspiracies, lies, false information."

 In her commencement address at Wellesley, Clinton admitted that she had not been a "perfect candidate."

 "I never said I was a perfect candidate, and I certainly have never said I ran perfect campaigns -- but I do not know who is, or did," she said. "Were there things we could have done differently? You could say that about any campaign."

 As for her next move in politics, Clinton is getting involved with political action organizations such as "Onward Together," which she founded this month.

 "I'm not going anywhere," she said. "I have a big stake in what's happening to this country."

Title: Google Prioritizes Relevant and High-Quality Content Over Political Ideology, but Resource Disparities Affect Rankings

Article:

Google has stated that it is optimizing its search engine to prioritize relevant answers and high-quality content, rather than political ideology. However, the distribution of relevance and quality across the media may not be equal, leading to potential disparities in rankings.

To illustrate this, let's consider some markers of relevance (timeliness, impact, keyword density) and quality (originality, sourcing, depth). Applying a ranking algorithm to mainstream media, which includes large networks, newspapers, and digital sites that adhere to traditional journalistic values, would result in higher rankings due to their larger staffs, better-trained journalists, and deeper roots in the field.

For instance, The New York Times and The Washington Post have thousands of journalists combined, and The Times' subscription revenue surpassed a billion dollars last year. In contrast, many right-wing outlets are embedded within advocacy groups, such as The Daily Signal from the Heritage Foundation, or are small blogs without the human resources for original reporting. For example, HotAir, an outlet cited by Bolyard, has four editors (one of whom is pseudonymous), and The Blaze, another outlet Bolyard cited, is reportedly down to fewer than 50 employees. The Weekly Standard, another right-wing media organization, appears to have an editorial staff of only 35.

Some right-wing media organizations do not adhere to the standards of journalism recognized by the mainstream media, peddling conspiracy theories or engaging in ethically questionable reporting practices. Similarly, left-leaning outlets like Salon and DailyKos should not expect to compete with The New York Times on Google placement due to resource disparities.

Google's concept of relevance is caught in a loop between what people want and what they think it provides. Google sees pages as relevant if people engage with them, but people trust Google to serve up relevant content, so they engage with what Google shows them. Defining quality among journalism experts is challenging, and Google has had a difficult time defining what journalistic value means in machine-readable terms.

While some aspects of quality can be measured (e.g., the number of fresh quotes in a story from new sources, the number of links to other high-quality sites, the amount of time readers spend with a story, or the variety of readers engaging with a story), these indicators are not foolproof, and the algorithm will rank many great stories poorly. The system can, to a limited extent, be gamed, and it is far from perfect.

Title: Guide to Investigating Local Police Activities for Community Change

Article:

Protests against racism and police violence are taking place in cities across America, but the issue extends beyond urban areas. As a resident, you can contribute to the change you desire in your local community. One of the initial steps is educating yourself about the activities of your local police department.

Before embarking on this journey, it's essential to consider the efforts already being made by local black-led activist groups. Engage with these groups to learn about their activities and determine how you can offer support. Avoid duplicating efforts to ensure maximum impact.

To gather information and build support for reforms, such as abolishing the police, defunding the police, or requesting minor changes, it's crucial to investigate the actions of the police in your community. Investigative reporter Andrew Ford, in a guide provided by ProPublica, offers insights into this process, emphasizing that anyone can ask questions and make public records requests, regardless of employment at a media outlet.

To begin, familiarize yourself with the laws and policies that govern police operations in your area. In some cases, you can find this information through a simple Google search; in others, you may need to delve deeper. Ford suggests asking the department for its policies on practices of concern, such as restraining suspects, the use of pepper spray, or Tasers. You may also need to request rules set by a county or state authority. Request written copies, and be prepared to file a formal public records request, which will be described below. If there is no existing written policy, this may be a topic worth exploring.

One policy that may be useful is understanding the records retention policies, which outline what records must be kept and for how long. These may include police reports, use-of-force reports, 911 call recordings, and body camera footage. The Reporters' Committee for Freedom of the Press has a clickable map with body camera policies for many cities, and a list of state laws on 911 call recordings, to help you get started.

These tools will help you begin to understand the activities of the police in your area. Don't forget to also check with your local government, such as the town council, for information about how they allocate their budget and how much of it goes toward policing. Collaborate with other residents, make a plan, and work together to make your town safer.

For those seeking ways to advocate for black lives, a list of resources is available.

Title: U.S. Deploys F-22 Fighter Jets to South Korea for Joint Military Exercises Amid North Korea's War Threats

Article:

The United States has sent two F-22 stealth fighter jets to South Korea to participate in joint military exercises following North Korea's declaration that the Korean Peninsula is in a "state of war." The F-22 Raptors were deployed to Osan Air Base in South Korea from Japan on Sunday to support ongoing U.S.-South Korean military drills, according to a Pentagon spokesman.

George Little, the Pentagon spokesman, told reporters Monday that the exercise, known as Foal Eagle, is part of the air component of the drills. The U.S. military in South Korea urged North Korea to restrain itself in a statement released Sunday, stating that "provocations will only further isolate North Korea and undermine international efforts to ensure peace and stability in Northeast Asia."

Meanwhile, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un convened legislators Monday for an annual spring parliamentary session following a ruling party declaration that nuclear bomb building and a stronger economy are the nation's top priorities. The meeting of the Supreme People's Assembly follows near-daily threats from Pyongyang, including vows of nuclear strikes on South Korea and the U.S.

North Korea also threatened to shut down a border factory complex that is the last major symbol of inter-Korean cooperation, according to the Associated Press. The threats are seen as part of an effort to provoke the new government in Seoul to change its policies toward Pyongyang and to win diplomatic talks with Washington in order to gain more aid.

The White House stated that the U.S. is taking North Korea's threats seriously but has also noted Pyongyang's history of "bellicose rhetoric." On Thursday, U.S. military officials revealed that two B-2 stealth bombers dropped dummy munitions on an uninhabited South Korean island as part of annual defense drills that Pyongyang sees as rehearsals for invasion. Hours later, Kim ordered his generals to put rockets on standby and threatened to strike American targets if provoked.

Military analysts have said a full-scale conflict between North and South Korea is extremely unlikely, noting that the Korean Peninsula has remained in a technical state of war for 60 years. However, the North's continued threats toward South Korea and the United States have raised concerns that a misjudgment between the sides could lead to a clash.

In addition to the military exercise, the U.S. will fortify its defenses against a potential North Korean missile attack by adding more than a dozen missile interceptors to the 26 already in place at Fort Greely, Alaska, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has also announced.

Title: Apple Unveils Apple Pay, Apple Watch, and HealthKit Amid Privacy Concerns

Article:

Apple, the tech giant, has launched new products focused on mobile payments and health and fitness, with an emphasis on security and privacy. The products, unveiled a week after the nude celebrity photo hack, include Apple Pay, a mobile payment system, the Apple Watch, and HealthKit, an application framework open to third-party developers.

Apple Pay, introduced by Apple CEO Tim Cook, aims to revolutionize the credit card system with a system that allows users to complete transactions by holding their phone up to a retail sensor and using the Touch ID for authentication. The company emphasizes the security of the system, stating that it does not store credit card numbers, collect any retail transaction information, or share data with anyone.

The Apple Watch, which comes in three styles and various colors, features sensors that allow consumers to monitor their physical activity, including walking and running on flat and elevated surfaces. The device can also detect heartbeats and set fitness goals and rewards. Jony Ive, Apple's lead designer, stated, "You can share something as personal as your own heartbeat."

HealthKit, when combined with the Apple Watch, raises privacy concerns due to the sensitive nature of medical information. The HealthKit app will allow consumers to wear their health and fitness information on their sleeves with the new Apple Watch. In response to the celebrity hacking scandal, Apple announced new guidelines for HealthKit developers, prohibiting them from storing information in iCloud.

Apple is not the first company in the mHealth space, but aims to differentiate itself by prioritizing privacy and security. Morgan Reed, executive director of the Association for Competitive Technology, stated, "eHealth is going to be huge; $2.7 trillion of the American economy is spent on health care and hundreds of billions on health IT, and Apple wants a piece of that." Apple's new products are part of the company's efforts to redefine the market for "wearables" and potentially integrate these devices into the U.S. health care system.

Title: Ferguson Faces Unrest: Businesses Destroyed, Police Tactics Questioned

Article:

In the aftermath of Monday's episodes of violence in Ferguson, Missouri, along South Florissant Road, Rob Chabot, the owner of Mobile Eye Care Solutions, expressed dismay, stating, "They abandoned us completely." Chabot questioned the purpose of the state's response, saying, "For what cause? I don't know."

During a news conference, Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III also criticized the state's response. He noted, "Unfortunately, as the unrest grew and further assistance was needed, the National Guard was not deployed in enough time to save all of our businesses."

By Tuesday afternoon, the police reported 21 fires in and around Ferguson, at least 150 gunshots, and damage to 10 police cruisers. In some instances, firefighters were forced to retreat from fighting fires due to gunfire and objects being thrown.

The law enforcement's response has been questioned, with some criticizing their approach as too tame, while others defend it as necessary to de-escalate the situation. St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar and other officials defended their response, stating that they took steps to de-escalate the situation but that the magnitude of the violence was beyond their control.

Chief Belmar explained that the initial, hands-off tactics by the police were intended to allow protesters to demonstrate peacefully. However, he added that the situation ultimately grew so unstable that it required a more forceful approach.

Belmar stated, "I don't think we were underprepared, but I'll be honest with you, unless we bring 10,000 policemen in here, I don't think we can prevent folks that really are intent on destroying a community." However, he admitted that despite months of preparation and training, and a buildup of manpower, equipment, and technology, he had not foreseen the chaos that ultimately unfolded.

Among the more than 60 people arrested on various charges including second-degree burglary and arson, most were Missouri residents, marking a shift, some noted, from the unrest of the summer.

Title: FTC Issues Information Requests to Tech Giants Over Small Mergers

Article:

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has issued special orders to five major tech companies - Alphabet Inc's Google unit, Amazon.com Inc, Apple Inc, Facebook Inc, and Microsoft Corp - to provide information on mergers that were too small to report to antitrust regulators, the FTC announced on Tuesday.

The requests come as the Justice Department, the FTC, state attorneys general, and the House Judiciary Committee are all investigating the big tech platforms for potential anti-competitive behavior. The tech companies are accused of using their market dominance to protect their market share or to expand into adjacent markets.

FTC Chairman Joe Simons declined to rule out an enforcement action based on the results of the study, stating, "All options are on the table." The tech giants did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The agency asked for information about deals that were done between January 1, 2010, and December 31, 2019. The orders require each company to identify transactions that were too small to report to the FTC and the Department of Justice, which assess mergers to ensure they comply with antitrust law.

"The commission plans to use the information obtained in this study to examine trends in acquisitions and the structure of deals, including whether acquisitions not subject to (antitrust) notification might have raised competitive concerns," the statement said.

The tech giants have faced criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. Republicans have expressed concerns about what they perceive as a stifling of conservative voices on social media, while Democrats have expressed concerns about increasing consolidation.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, who is running for president, has explicitly called for federal regulators to undo "ant-competitive mergers," including Amazon's purchases of Whole Foods and Zappos, Facebook's purchase of WhatsApp and Instagram, and Google's acquisitions of Waze, Nest, and DoubleClick.

Alphabet spent $1 billion on an unspecified number of small acquisitions in 2019, according to securities filings. Many of these were companies working on artificial intelligence research and cloud computing services, areas in which Google is trying to innovate quickly and has sought to bolster hiring.

Apple has mostly made small deals valued at less than $500 million over the past decade, acquiring small companies working on key technologies such as augmented reality displays, camera sensors, and artificial intelligence software.

In fiscal 2019, Microsoft made 19 small acquisitions for a total of $1.6 billion, mostly in cash. Microsoft has sought to consolidate its position in the business software market, with major acquisitions such as the LinkedIn social network for business professionals and the code repository site GitHub. Since acquiring LinkedIn - which also fielded rival offers from Microsoft's competitor Salesforce Inc - Microsoft has begun integrating LinkedIn's social network data with Microsoft products such as its Outlook email program.

Title: US Vice President Reaffirms U.S. Commitment to Baltic States' Security Amidst Tensions with Russia

Article:

U.S. Vice President Mike Pence has reiterated the United States' commitment to the security of the Baltic states in the face of potential aggression from Russia. During a visit to Estonia, Pence labeled Russia as the region's biggest security threat, stating, "An attack on one of us is an attack on us all."

The remarks were made during a meeting with NATO allies, emphasizing the mutual defense principle of the alliance. The Baltic states - Estonia, Lithuania, and Latvia - gained independence following the breakup of the Soviet Union and have grown increasingly cautious of Russia since it annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

Recent tensions between the U.S. and Russia have escalated as a result of new U.S. sanctions against Russia, prompting a retaliatory move by Moscow to reduce the number of U.S. diplomatic staff. The vice president's visit to Estonia follows President Donald Trump's reaffirmation of the U.S.'s commitment to the mutual defense principle during a Washington press conference in June and a speech in Poland in early July.

In Tallinn, Pence stated, "Under President Donald Trump, the United States stands firmly behind our Article 5 pledge of mutual defense." He also emphasized the importance of a strong and united NATO, stating, "A strong and united NATO is more necessary today than at any point since the collapse of communism a quarter-century ago."

Russia is set to hold large-scale military exercises with its ally Belarus in the coming month. Additionally, the U.S. is currently holding its largest-ever joint military exercises with Georgia, a country that fought a war with Russia in 2008 and seeks to join NATO. Pence is scheduled to attend the drills in Georgia on Tuesday and later visit Montenegro, NATO's newest member.

Pence also warned that Moscow continues to "seek to redraw international borders by force, undermine democracies of sovereign nations, and divide the free nations of Europe, one against another." His visit to the region comes as Moscow announced that 755 staff must leave U.S. diplomatic missions in Russia, in retaliation over new sanctions imposed for Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 and Russian interference in the U.S. election.

In response to the move, Pence said, "We hope for better days, for better relations with Russia." He added, "Recent diplomatic action taken by Moscow will not deter the commitment of the United States of America to our security, the security of our allies."

Title: Actor Jussie Smollett Charged with Filing False Police Report in Chicago

Article:

US actor Jussie Smollett, known for his role in the television series Empire, has been arrested in Chicago and charged with filing a false police report. The actor had previously claimed he was the victim of a homophobic and racist physical attack in January.

Police suspect that Smollett, aged 36, paid two Nigerian brothers to stage the attack. The brothers, Ola and Abel Osundairo, are cooperating with the investigation, according to US media reports. They are due to appear in court later on Thursday. Smollett's lawyers earlier stated they would "mount an aggressive defense."

Doubts over Smollett's claim began to grow after police said they could not find any video footage of the alleged incident from surveillance cameras, and there were no witnesses. However, investigators managed to track two men who appeared on video footage near where Smollett said he had been attacked.

The brothers, who are Mr. Smollett's personal trainer and have worked as extras on Empire, were held for nearly 48 hours after they returned last week. They were released without charges after providing information that "shifted the trajectory of the investigation," police said.

A lawyer for the brothers, Gloria Schmidt, said they had chosen to testify because "there was a point where this story needed to be told." She added, "They manned up and said: 'You know what? We're going to correct this.'"

On Wednesday, CBS Chicago obtained footage that appeared to show two people buying materials, including ski masks, that had allegedly been worn by the actor's attackers.

Smollett turned himself in early on Thursday and is in custody of Chicago police, spokesman Anthony Guglielmi said. He faces felony charges for disorderly conduct and filing a false police report.

The actor is being temporarily held at the Cook County Jail and has been separated from other prisoners, which is common for notable inmates, according to Chicago media reports. If found guilty, he faces up to three years in prison and may also be forced to reimburse police for the cost of their three-week-long investigation.

Following the charges, Smollett's legal team released a statement saying, "Like any other citizen, Mr. Smollett enjoys the presumption of innocence, particularly when there has been an investigation like this one where information, both true and false, has been repeatedly leaked."

Smollett, who is gay, said he had gone out to buy food late at night in downtown Chicago when two white men hurled racial and homophobic insults at him. They allegedly punched the actor, poured a chemical substance over him, and put a rope around his neck. Smollett also claimed the men had told him "this is Maga country," apparently referring to President Donald Trump's "Make America Great Again" slogan. The actor said he had been "forever changed" by the alleged incident. An outpouring of support followed, including from Oscar winner Viola Davis and supermodel Naomi Campbell.

Title: U.S. Newspapers Unite in Defense of Freedom of the Press

Article:

More than 300 newspapers across the United States, including large publications like the New York Times and small local newspapers, ran editorials on Thursday in support of freedom of the press. The coordinated effort was led by the Boston Globe, with participants ranging from newspapers with circulations as low as 4,000 to larger publications. The Boston Globe encouraged editorial boards to participate regardless of their political point of view.

The Boston Globe's editorial board wrote, "The principle of a free press has protected journalists at home and served as a model for free nations abroad. Today it is under serious threat." In a recent poll, 48 percent of Republicans and 29 percent of Americans overall agreed with President Trump that the news media is the enemy of the people. Forty-three percent of Republicans and 26 percent of Americans said the president should be able to close news outlets for bad behavior.

The Globe's editorial board further stated, "To label the press 'the enemy of the people' is as un-American as it is dangerous to the civic compact we have shared for more than two centuries." Editorial boards around the country added their own words on Thursday.

The Chicago Tribune wrote, "A free press is the cornerstone of democracy. It is the only means by which the people can be informed and hold their elected leaders accountable." The Arizona Republic stated, "A free press is the guardian of democracy, the watchdog of the powerful, and the voice of the voiceless."

The president appeared to respond to the editorials on Twitter Thursday morning, stating, "THE FAKE NEWS MEDIA IS THE OPPOSITION PARTY. It is very bad for our Great Country.... BUT WE ARE WINNING!" He also tweeted, "The Boston Globe, which was sold to the Failing New York Times for 1.3 BILLION DOLLARS (plus 800 million dollars in losses & investment) or 2.1 BILLION DOLLARS, was then sold by the Times for 1 DOLLAR. Now the Globe is in COLLUSION with other papers on free press. PROVE IT!"

Title: Americans' Perceptions of Political Discourse and Trump's Impact

Article:

A recent survey has examined Americans' attitudes about the tone and nature of political debate in the United States, including President Donald Trump's impact on political discourse.

1. The survey found that large majorities of Americans (85%) believe that political debate in the country has become more negative, less respectful, less fact-based, and less focused on issues.

2. Donald Trump is a significant factor in people's views about the state of the nation's political discourse. A majority (55%) say Trump has changed the tone and nature of political debate for the worse, while fewer than half as many (24%) say he has changed it for the better. One-in-five Americans say he has had little impact.

3. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents overwhelmingly (84%) say Trump has changed political discourse for the worse. About half of Republicans and Republican leaners (49%) say he has changed it for the better, while 23% say he has changed it for the worse and 27% say he hasn't changed it much either way.

4. Eight-in-ten or more Democrats say Trump's comments often or sometimes make them feel concerned, confused, embarrassed, exhausted, angry, insulted, and frightened. While Republicans are considerably less likely than Democrats to report these negative reactions to Trump's rhetoric, about six-in-ten (59%) say they are at least sometimes concerned by his comments, while about half say they are at least sometimes confused (47%) or embarrassed (53%).

5. Majorities of Americans have strong feelings about what is acceptable for elected officials to say in political debate. Most agree that it is fine for an elected official to say their opponent is uninformed on the issues. However, 41% say it is never acceptable to say their opponent is anti-American, and another 31% say this is rarely acceptable.

6. Americans broadly agree that elected officials should avoid using heated language because it could encourage violence. Nearly three-quarters of Americans (73%) say this, while just a quarter believe that elected officials "should be able to use heated language to express themselves without worrying about whether some people may act on what they say."

7. While majorities in both parties say officials should avoid heated language, this view is more widely held among Democrats (83%) than Republicans (61%).

8. Republicans believe that the national climate for political discourse is more hospitable to Democrats than for the GOP. Nearly two-thirds of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (64%) think that "Democrats in this country are very comfortable to freely and openly express their political views," but only about a quarter (26%) think Republicans around the nation experience that same level of comfort.

9. Most Americans say there is not consensus in the public on what constitutes racist or sexist language. About six-in-ten Americans (61%) say people generally don't agree about what is considered to be racist language, while 38% believe that people do agree on this. Views about agreement over sexist language are roughly the same.

10. About two-thirds (65%) of Republicans and Republican leaners say people generally do not agree over the definition of racist language; 58% of Democrats and Democratic leaners say the same. Black people are somewhat more likely than whites and Hispanics to say people agree about what is considered racist language, although blacks, whites, and Hispanics are all more likely to say people do not agree on what kind of language is racist than to say that there is broad agreement.

Title: Trump's Trade War Escalation: Fact-Checking the President's Tariff and Hurricane Aid Claims

Article:

In escalating his trade war, President Donald Trump persists in his argument that tariffs are a pure win for the U.S. and a loss for China. However, this perspective overlooks the costs of tariffs being borne by Americans.

Trump has vowed to impose a blanket tariff of 25% on everything Americans buy from China. This would mean raising tariffs from 10% on $200 billion worth of goods by the end of the week and hitting an additional $325 billion in Chinese products with the same penalty "shortly."

In a tweet on Sunday, Trump stated, "For 10 months, China has been paying Tariffs to the USA of 25% on 50 Billion Dollars of High Tech, and 10% on 200 Billion Dollars of other goods. These payments are partially responsible for our great economic results."

However, this notion of a transfer of wealth from China to the U.S. isn't happening. According to a study by economists from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Columbia University, and Princeton University, the burden of Trump's tariffs on imports from China and other countries falls entirely on U.S. consumers and businesses that buy imports. By the end of last year, the study found, the public and U.S. companies were paying $3 billion a month in higher taxes and absorbing $1.4 billion a month in lost efficiency.

Money from tariffs is going into the federal treasury, but it's mostly, if not entirely, coming from U.S. businesses and consumers, not China, and it's not a driver of economic growth but rather a risk to it. That's why the stock market dropped on Monday.

A coalition of U.S. trade organizations representing retail businesses, tech, manufacturing, and agriculture sharply disputed Trump's statement. "For 10 months, Americans have been paying the full cost of the trade war, not China," it said. "To be clear, tariffs are taxes that Americans pay, and this sudden increase with little notice will only punish U.S. farmers, businesses, and consumers."

Trump invariably describes the U.S. trade deficit as money "lost" to other countries, an equation that ignores the value to Americans of what they've bought. "We've lost so much money with China," he told an audience in March. "We lose with everybody, almost." People are no more losing money than when they buy groceries—rather, they're spending it and getting food.

In another tweet on Monday, Trump asserted, "Puerto Rico has been given more money by Congress for Hurricane Disaster Relief, 91 Billion Dollars, than any State in the history of the U.S."

However, this claim is not true. The money that Congress has allocated to Puerto Rico for hurricane relief so far is nowhere close to $91 billion. According to the White House, Trump's $91 billion estimate includes about $50 billion in expected future disaster disbursements that could span decades, along with $41 billion already approved. Actual aid to Puerto Rico has flowed more slowly from federal coffers, about $11 billion so far.

The expected $50 billion in additional money is speculative. It is based on Puerto Rico's eligibility for federal emergency disaster funds for years ahead, involving calamities that haven't happened. The White House's $91 billion figure for Puerto Rico, even if correct, would not be the most ever provided for hurricane rebuilding efforts. Hurricane Katrina in 2005 cost the U.S. government more than $120 billion—the bulk of it going to Louisiana.

Title: Christie Vows Cooperation in State of the State Address Amid Ongoing Bridge Scandal Investigation

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie pledged cooperation with all inquiries into the ongoing "Bridgegate" scandal during his State of the State address on Tuesday. The speech, which took on national interest due to the investigations into the alleged political retribution, aimed to refocus the political focus away from the George Washington Bridge controversy.

In his address, Christie accepted ultimate responsibility for the alleged political retribution, stating, "Mistakes were clearly made, and as a result, we let down the people we are entrusted to serve." The governor's administration will cooperate "with all appropriate inquiries" to ensure the breach of trust does not happen again, he said.

Christie emphasized economic successes of his first term and called for cooperation from the Democratic-led state Assembly and Senate. In a span of 10 paragraphs, he used the word "we" 17 times in describing specific achievements such as job creation and economic growth.

Outlining a conservative agenda of no additional taxes and more law enforcement, the governor also proposed education reforms and programs to help drug offenders rejoin society. The most emotional moment came when Christie told the story of Craig Hanlon, a former drug addict from his hometown now working as a practicing attorney.

The New Jersey State Assembly committee investigating the bridge controversy made public more than 2,000 pages of documents last week, suggesting politics was behind the unannounced lane closures on the New Jersey side of the bridge last September that caused traffic gridlock in Fort Lee. The documents suggest that top Christie aides orchestrated the traffic mess to punish that town's mayor for not endorsing their boss, and that they allegedly tried to stonewall media inquiries into the matter.

Christie has fired one top adviser for her apparent role in the scandal and other key advisers have left their jobs. He has repeatedly apologized for being "blindsided" by what his aides and appointees were doing.

Federal officials are also looking at whether Christie improperly used Superstorm Sandy relief funds to produce tourism ads promoting the Jersey shore's recovery that starred him and his family. In the new inquiry, federal auditors will examine New Jersey's use of $25 million of the funds for the marketing campaign, according to New Jersey Democratic Rep. Frank Pallone.

While political observers say the bridge scandal is not good for Christie, the Sandy investigation has the potential to be more damaging to his national image since it was his signature achievement following the storm. On Tuesday, Christie did not specifically mention the audit by the HUD inspector general. In what might have been an ironic reference to Sandy funding, Christie praised the cooperative spirit in the state that helped its recovery from the storm, seeming to describe his own challenges now. "Let that spirit of Sandy be a powerful lesson to all of us, that when times are most difficult, cooperation and progress are possible," Christie said. "Indeed, I tell you, they're necessary."

Title: North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un Reappears, Sparks New Mystery Over Use of Cane

Article:

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has reemerged after a six-week absence, quelling rumors of his ill health or potential removal from power. However, a new mystery has arisen: the reason for his use of a cane.

Kim, last seen publicly at a Sept. 3 concert, was pictured on Tuesday, smiling broadly and leaning on a walking stick while touring the newly built Wisong Scientists Residential District and another new institute in Pyongyang, as part of his regular "field guidance" tours. The North Korean government did not disclose the exact date of the visit or address Kim's health status.

The appearance of Kim allows the country's extensive propaganda apparatus to continue its mission of glorifying the third generation of Kim family rule and to suppress rumors of a coup and serious health issues.

Before Tuesday, Kim missed several high-profile events he typically attends, and he was described in an official documentary last month as experiencing "discomfort." Archive footage from August showed him overweight and limping, leading to speculation in South Korean media that he had undergone ankle surgery. Some experts suggested he was suffering from gout or diabetes.

A South Korean analyst suggested that Kim broke his media silence to dispel external speculation about his control and to garner sympathy from the domestic audience by portraying a leader who works through pain. Cheong Seong-chang, an analyst at the private Sejong Institute in South Korea, described the appearance as "emotional politics meant to appeal to the North Korean people's sympathy."

Kim's use of a cane marks the first time a North Korean leader has been seen relying on such an aid, according to South Korean officials. Kim's father, Kim Jong Il, who reportedly suffered a stroke in 2008 and died of a heart attack in late 2011, was seen limping but never with a walking stick. The country's founder and Kim Jong Un's grandfather, Kim Il Sung, did not use a cane, said Lim Byeong Cheol, a spokesman from Seoul's Unification Ministry.

Cheong noted that Kim appeared to have lost about 22 pounds compared to pictures from May. He speculated that since Kim was holding a cane on his left side, he may have had surgery on his left ankle.

Kim's reappearance aims to demonstrate that he is in good health, though he may still be experiencing some discomfort, according to Cheong. The South Korean government has not detected any major problems.

In resuming public activity before fully recovering from his condition, Kim seeks to quickly quell rumors that his health problems are severe enough to threaten his status as North Korean leader, said Lim, the government spokesman.

"The cane aside, he looked to be in good health," Lim said.

Bruce Cumings, an expert on Korea at the University of Chicago, suggested that the recent absence was a deliberate attention-getting device. "The North has been on a diplomatic offensive in Europe and elsewhere, it feels isolated—and is, if we're talking about relations with Washington—all this puts them back on the front page," Cumings wrote in an email.

Title: Romney Proposes "Choose-Your-Own-Deduction" Tax Reform Plan Ahead of First Presidential Debate

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, has begun to outline specifics for his tax reform plan in anticipation of the first debate with President Obama, detailing a "choose-your-own-deduction" approach. During an interview with Fox Denver affiliate KDVR, Romney explained that taxpayers could select and claim deductions individually, with a potential cap of $17,000.

Romney suggested that taxpayers could fill a $17,000 "bucket" with the deductions they prefer, such as charitable, home mortgage, health care, or other deductions. He added that higher-income individuals might have a lower cap.
