A Romney campaign aide later stated that the $17,000 cap could change, and the tax rate cut could be offset by imposing a dollar cap on personal exemptions and reducing health care tax preferences.

The Romney campaign has not disclosed the exact cost of the 20% tax rate cut, but a separate source who worked with the deficit-reduction "supercommittee" on Capitol Hill estimated it could cost up to $1.7 trillion over 10 years. The Romney campaign aide described this figure as "possible."

Romney spokesman Kevin Madden stated that the ideas for offsetting the tax rate cut reflect suggestions that may be considered during discussions with Congress. Romney may present his "bucket"-list proposal during the first presidential debate on Wednesday night.

The Obama campaign has criticized Romney for not disclosing the specifics of his tax plan, with Deputy Campaign Manager Stephanie Cutter stating, "Romney has never explained how he would pay for his massive new tax cut for the wealthiest." Cutter also noted that Romney has not specified which deductions he would eliminate.

Both campaigns have managed expectations for the debate, with Obama's advisers claiming Romney has practice from the primary season, while Romney's advisers note that Obama is the only one on stage with general election debate experience. The debate, one of three this month, is a high-risk, high-reward event for both candidates.

The debate is scheduled for 9 p.m. EDT on Wednesday, October 3. Each campaign has allotted half of the six, 15-minute debate segments to topics related to the economy, with the remaining three segments focusing on health care, the role of government, and governing. The next debate is scheduled for October 16, and the lone debate for the vice presidential candidates is October 11.

Title: Facebook Announces Overhaul of Privacy Tools in Response to Criticism and Regulatory Changes

Article:

Facebook has announced a revamp of its privacy tools in response to intense criticism following the revelation that data from 50 million users was harvested and passed on to political consultancy Cambridge Analytica. The changes aim to make it easier for users to find and edit the personal information the company holds.

In a blog post, Facebook's chief privacy officer, Erin Egan, acknowledged the damage caused by the Cambridge Analytica revelations and stated the need for improved enforcement of the company's policies and better understanding of how Facebook works and the choices users have over their data.

The changes include a "simplified" settings menu, a new privacy shortcuts menu, revised data download and edit tools, and a new page called "Access Your Information." The revised tools allow users to review past interactions with the site, including things they have "liked" and the comments they have posted, with the option to make deletions. Users will also be able to download specific categories of data, including their photos, from a selected time range.

Although it is not mentioned in the blog, the BBC understands the firm also intends to make the link to fully delete an account more prominent. The changes are set to take effect before the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into force on 25 May, toughening the requirements on how organizations handle personal data.

Facebook insists the move has been in the works for months, but the company acknowledges the urgency of the situation. "Facebook recognizes it's clearly lost people's trust and it needs to get to work on regaining that," said Stephen Deadman, its global deputy chief privacy officer.

The question remains whether the social network should be more proactive in warning users about the data they are sharing. The new one-stop shop for privacy and security settings may not be enough for busy users to take back control without more nudging.

The changes come as Facebook faces fresh criticism from New Zealand's privacy watchdog, which has accused the firm of breaking local laws by refusing to provide data about a dispute involving one of its citizens. The man involved had wanted access to information about what others had written about him. Facebook has responded, stating, "We are disappointed that the New Zealand Privacy Commissioner asked us to provide access to a year's worth of private data belonging to several people and then criticized us for protecting their privacy."

Since the Cambridge Analytica scandal, Facebook's privacy practices have come under fresh scrutiny. The UK-based consultancy has denied using the data to aid President Trump's election campaign and claims it had deleted the information. However, the British company suspended its chief executive following other allegations. Nearly $80bn has been wiped off Facebook's market value since 16 March, when it revealed it had received reports that Cambridge Analytica had not destroyed data about millions of its US members, as demanded several years previously.

Title: U.S. Supreme Court Upholds Texas Abortion Restrictions, Sparking Controversy

Article:

The United States Supreme Court has declined to block controversial Texas abortion restrictions, which have been labeled as some of the strictest in the country. The court's 5-4 vote denied a request by Planned Parenthood to block a ruling by the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, allowing key parts of the Texas abortion law to remain in effect while the lawsuit challenging the restrictions moves forward.

The four liberal justices who voted in favor of the request expressed their intention to overturn the appeals court's Oct. 31 ruling that allowed the law to take effect. In its 20-page ruling, the panel of appeals court judges acknowledged that the law's provision requiring doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital may increase the cost of accessing an abortion provider and decrease the number of physicians available to perform abortions.

However, the panel stated that the U.S. Supreme Court has held that having "the incidental effect of making it more difficult or more expensive to procure an abortion can not be enough to invalidate" a law that serves a valid purpose, one not designed to strike at the right itself. The provision has led at least 12 clinics in the state to stop performing abortions since the ruling.

A spokeswoman for the Texas Attorney General's Office expressed satisfaction with the Supreme Court's ruling, stating, "These are commonsense - and perfectly constitutional - regulations that further the state's interest in protecting the health and safety of Texas women."

Republican Texas Gov. Rick Perry also expressed happiness with the court's decision, stating, "This is good news both for the unborn and for the women of Texas, who are now better protected from shoddy abortion providers operating in dangerous conditions."

The appeals court panel left in place a portion of a previous judge's order that prevents the state from enforcing the U.S. Food and Drug Administration protocol for abortion-inducing drugs in cases where the woman is between 50 and 63 days into her pregnancy. Doctors testifying before the court had said such women would be harmed if the protocol were enforced.

The appeals court's order is temporary until it can hold a complete hearing, likely in January. The restrictions gained notoriety when Democratic state Sen. Wendy Davis launched a nearly 13-hour filibuster against them in June. The law also bans abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy and beginning in October 2014 requires doctors to perform all abortions in surgical facilities.

During the trial, officials for one chain of abortion clinics testified that they've tried to obtain admitting privileges for their doctors at 32 hospitals, but so far only 15 accepted applications and none have announced a decision. Many hospitals with religious affiliations will not allow abortion doctors to work there, while others fear protests if they provide privileges. Many have requirements that doctors live within a certain radius of the facility, or perform a minimum number of surgeries a year that must be performed in a hospital.

Fox News' Shannon Bream and The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Title: China's COVID-19 Case Numbers: A Closer Look at Transparency and Reporting

Article:

As the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases continues to rise in the United States and other countries worldwide, the reported number of new cases in China, the source of the pandemic, has significantly decreased. Given China's history of secrecy, duplicity, and cover-ups, there is little cause to take the official figures at face value.

The National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, the department responsible for tracking statistics during the crisis, has been publishing daily updates since late January. The commission reported a rapid increase in cases from January 25, with the number of confirmed cases of the COVID-19 virus skyrocketing from 1,287 to 17,205 in just over a week. At that point, according to the commission, 189,583 people had been identified as having had close contact with infected patients.

The commission also acknowledged on January 26 that "More than 5 million people have left Wuhan due to the Spring Festival and epidemic." Given the timing and the annual festival's typical generation of nearly 3 billion trips, the "epidemic" was poised to sweep the nation of 1.3 billion people.

However, against all odds, the National Health Commission of China reported no new domestically acquired cases, attributing every new case as "imported" by those returning to China. Over the last half of March, despite the massive dispersion of Chinese citizens from the epicenter of the virus, Wuhan, the commission has reported barely one new domestically acquired case per day.

Despite compelling reasons for incredulity at China's official figures, the United Nations published an article titled "China shows COVID-19 Coronavirus can be ‘ stopped in its tracks.'" The article is based on an interview with a "WHO Representative in the country, Dr. Gauden Galea."

Dr. Galea has been in Beijing during the course of China's battle with COVID-19, except for a quick trip to Wuhan on January 21-22 before the city was even locked down, and the outbreak was still muted. The U.N. article goes on to say, "At the time, there was no overwhelming demand on the health services, though the situation had changed when Chinese and international health experts conducted a joint mission a month later."

Various media organizations have similarly relied on China's numbers for some dramatic headlines. On March 18, The New York Times declared, "China Hits a Coronavirus Milestone: No New Local Infections." While the article notes in passing that Chinese "officials initially concealed and mismanaged the outbreak," it goes on to flatly assert that "Beijing’s sledgehammer approach...worked to quickly lower the number of infections."

Eight days later, The Times, again based on China's "confirmed" numbers, told the world that "The U.S. Now Leads the World in Confirmed Coronavirus Cases." While the article says that "The Times is engaged in a comprehensive effort to track the details of every confirmed case in the United States, collecting information from federal, state, and local officials," apparently, the Times applied considerably less rigor to acquire information on China.

On Monday, however, came news that China's numbers have indeed been incomplete. The Wall Street Journal reported that "China said more than 1,500 people who were infected with the virus but haven’t shown symptoms weren’t included in its national tally of confirmed cases." This change so late in China's experience with the virus raises further questions about China's transparency, especially in light of some of the drastic measures the Communist government took early on to hush up the extent and seriousness of the epidemic.

If the past is any indication, the Chinese government will continue to hide the true consequences of the COVID-19 outbreak in that country as best it can. But the media and international health authorities would do well to view any data coming out of China with a more skeptical eye.

Title: Four Governors Reaffirm Opposition to Recreational Marijuana Legalization

Article:

Four governors, including two Republicans and two Democrats, have stated that their respective states will not follow the lead of Colorado and Washington in legalizing recreational marijuana. During an interview on CNN's "State of the Union," Texas Governor Rick Perry, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, was the first to express his opposition, stating a firm "no."

Perry, who has advocated for reducing penalties for marijuana use, has previously stated that current policies in Texas have contributed to a decrease in the state's prison population. He expressed concern about the potential consequences of criminalizing minor marijuana possession, stating, "The idea that a kid has one marijuana cigarette and you send him to prison, where they can learn to really be a hardened criminal, is not thoughtful public policy."

Indiana Governor Mike Pence, another potential White House contender, also expressed opposition to legalization. Pence, a Republican who took office last year, stated, "That's been my position for a long time and will continue to be."

Democratic Governor Dan Malloy of Connecticut indicated that his state has decriminalized small amounts of marijuana and has moved forward with medical marijuana, but he expressed reservations about fully legalizing the substance. "I think that's about as far as we go," Malloy said. He also cautioned against using tax revenue from marijuana sales as an incentive for legalization, stating, "They are two distinct issues. Let's not be enticed on that road because of money. It just doesn't make sense."

Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, a Democrat, also indicated that his state was not heading towards pot legalization but acknowledged that some in his state are starting to open up to the idea of medical marijuana. "I think our legislature might consider that, but I think to move beyond that at this point is a bridge too far," he said. Nixon added, "That bridge has not yet been built."

CNN's "State of the Union" airs Sundays at 9am ET. For more from State of the Union, click here.

Title: Obama's Off-Record Interview Reveals Immigration Reform and Grand Bargain Pledges

Article:

In a previously off-record interview with the Des Moines Register's editorial board, President Barack Obama made pledges for a second term, expressing confidence that Washington can strike a "grand bargain" on deficit reduction and immigration reform next year. During the conversation, the president took a swing at the Republican Party for alienating the Latino community, a fast-growing demographic group in the United States.

The Obama campaign released the transcript of the interview after the Des Moines Register's editor complained that the president's team had "handcuffed" the newspaper by insisting it be kept off record. In the interview, Obama discussed his plans for the economy, education, and energy development, while vigorously defending his term to date.

President Obama stated, "Should I win a second term, a big reason I will win a second term is because the Republican nominee and the Republican Party have so alienated the fastest-growing demographic group in the country, the Latino community. And this is a relatively new phenomenon." The Romney campaign responded by casting doubt on the president's editorial board comments, pointing to Obama's failure so far to pass comprehensive immigration reform despite pledges in 2008 to do so.

Campaign spokesman Alberto Martinez said, "It's a fascinating glimpse into how President Obama has taken the Hispanic community for granted for the past four years." Martinez added, "He's caught making secret promises to an editorial board in Iowa, which also happens to be a promise he made in 2008, a promise he failed to keep, and a promise he does not repeat publicly."

Much of the rest of the Des Moines Register interview was focused on policy discussions. The transcript was turned over and published after editor Rick Green revealed that the White House had demanded the conversation be kept out of print. The president also defended the health care bill as a measure aimed at treating the economy and expressed no regrets for not pursuing additional stimulus measures at the time he was pushing for the health care overhaul.

The Des Moines Register's decision on an endorsement will not be impacted by the initial snub, according to editor Rick Green. "That would be petty and ridiculous. We take far too seriously what's at stake this election and what our endorsement should say," Green wrote. Mitt Romney met with the editorial board in a barn in Iowa on Oct. 9, and the audio from that conversation was posted online.

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows in May, Suggesting Labor Market Losing Momentum

Article:

The U.S. job market showed signs of slowing in May, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 138,000, according to a report released by the Labor Department on Friday. The employment gains in the prior two months were revised downward, indicating a potential loss of momentum in the labor market despite the unemployment rate falling to a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.

The economy created 66,000 fewer jobs than previously reported in March and April. The manufacturing, government, and retail sectors experienced job losses in May. The manufacturing sector lost 4,000 jobs, the government sector lost 9,000 jobs, and the retail sector lost 6,100 jobs.

Despite the weaker-than-expected job growth, the economy may still create enough jobs for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates at its June 13-14 policy meeting. The economy needs to create 75,000 to 100,000 jobs per month to keep up with growth in the working-age population.

Economists at JPMorgan in New York, Michael Feroli, stated, "While the message was a little muddied today, the evidence generally suggests the labor market is cyclically tightening, and the Fed will need to continue to lean against that."

The employment report showed a decline in employment, with 429,000 people dropping out of the labor force. The jobless rate has declined five-tenths of a percentage point this year. The survey of households from which the unemployment rate is derived also showed a drop in employment.

Average hourly earnings rose 4 cents or 0.2 percent in May after a similar gain in April, leaving the year-on-year increase in wages at 2.5 percent. Job growth has decelerated from the 181,000 monthly average over the past 12 months as the labor market nears full employment.

Economists believe that companies might be holding off hiring amid worries about political scandals surrounding President Donald Trump and the potential impact on his economic agenda, including tax cuts and infrastructure spending.

Sung Won Sohn, an economics professor at California State University Channel Islands in Camarillo, stated, "Political uncertainty in Washington is another factor holding back the job market. The probability that any of the Trump stimulus would become reality has decreased significantly in recent weeks."

Economists had forecast payrolls increasing 185,000 last month and the unemployment rate holding steady at 4.4 percent. The modest payrolls gain could temper expectations of a sharp acceleration in economic growth in the second quarter after gross domestic product increased at a tepid 1.2 percent annualized rate at the start of the year.

There was some good news in the employment report. A broad measure of unemployment, which includes people who want to work but have given up searching and those working part-time because they cannot find full-time employment, fell two-tenths of a percentage point to 8.4 percent, the lowest since November 2007.

However, the labor force participation rate, or the share of working-age Americans who are employed or at least looking for a job, fell two-tenths of a percentage point to 62.7 percent. The volatile 16-24 age group accounted for much of the drop in the participation rate last month, suggesting a rebound is likely.

Manufacturing employment fell by 1,000 jobs last month as payrolls in the automobile sector dropped 1,500 amid declining sales. Construction payrolls rose 11,000 last month after decreasing by 1,000 jobs in April. Retail employment fell 6,100, declining for a fourth straight month, with department stores shedding 3,700 jobs.

Department store chains like J.C. Penney Co Inc, Macy's Inc, and Abercrombie & Fitch are struggling against stiff competition from online retailers led by Amazon. Nonstore retailers, including online merchants, hired 2,900 workers last month. Government employment decreased 9,000 last month, with state and local governments accounting for all the decrease.

Title: Indiana Primary: Cruz and Trump Face Off in High-Stakes Showdown

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz faces a critical test in Tuesday's Indiana primary, one of the last opportunities for the Texas senator to halt Donald Trump's momentum towards the GOP nomination. Cruz has been campaigning intensively in Indiana, securing the support of the state's governor and announcing retired technology executive Carly Fiorina as his running mate. However, Cruz's aides have expressed pessimism ahead of Tuesday's voting, preparing for a potential loss, although Cruz has vowed to continue his campaign if he has a viable path to victory.

Trump, on the other hand, has devoted more time to campaigning in Indiana than in most other states, underscoring his eagerness to eliminate his Republican rival and focus on Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton. While Trump cannot clinch the nomination with a big win in Indiana, a victory would make his path to the nomination easier and allow for more room for error in the remaining contests.

Republican leaders initially dismissed Trump as an entertainer who would fade once voting began. However, Republican primary voters have consistently supported Trump, granting him victories in every region of the country, including a string of six straight wins on the East Coast.

In the Democratic primary, Clinton and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders also faced off in Indiana's primary on Tuesday. Clinton holds a commanding lead over Sanders, having secured 91 percent of the delegates needed to win the nomination. This means Clinton can still win the nomination even if she loses every remaining contest.

Sanders has acknowledged that he faces a challenging path to overtake Clinton, one that depends on persuading superdelegates to back him over the former secretary of state. Superdelegates are Democratic Party insiders who can support the candidate of their choice, regardless of how their states vote. They favor Clinton by a nearly 18-1 margin.

Neither Clinton nor Sanders planned to spend Tuesday in Indiana. Sanders was making stops in Kentucky, which holds a primary in mid-May, while Clinton moved on to Ohio, a key general election battleground.

Clinton's team has begun deploying staff to states crucial for the November election and is also raising money for the fall campaign. Meanwhile, Trump lags behind Clinton in general election preparations, despite hiring more staff to strengthen his slim team.

A potential matchup between Clinton and Trump would pit one of the Democrats' most popular and highly-regarded figures against a first-time political candidate who is deeply divisive within his own party. Cruz and other Republicans have argued that Trump would be roundly defeated in the general election, denying their party the White House for a third consecutive term.

However, Trump is the only remaining Republican candidate who can secure the 1,237 delegates needed for the nomination through regular primary voting. Cruz, as well as Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who trails significantly in the delegate count, must try to block Trump in Indiana and the handful of other remaining states to push the race toward a contested convention.

In an unexpected strategy shift, Cruz and Kasich announced an informal alliance in Indiana. The Ohio governor agreed to halt spending money in Indiana to give Cruz a chance to compete head-to-head with Trump. Cruz has pledged to do the same for Kasich in Oregon and New Mexico, which vote in the coming weeks.

However, this strategy, which appeared to unravel even as it was announced, may have backfired. A recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist poll found that nearly 6 in 10 Indiana primary voters disapproved of the Cruz-Kasich alliance.

"After they made the alliance, their numbers tanked," Trump said Monday. "That's what happens when politicians make deals."

Title: Dueling Reports on Benghazi Attack Released by Democrats and Republicans

Article:

The investigation into the 2012 attacks on a diplomatic outpost and CIA annex in Benghazi, Libya, has resulted in competing and contradictory reports from Democrats and Republicans. The incident, which resulted in the death of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador Chris Stevens, has been the subject of a two-year investigation by members of the House from both political parties.

The primary objective of the investigation has been to examine the actions of senior U.S. military and civilian officials, including then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, to determine if they could have taken actions to prevent the loss of life. On Monday, the panel's five Democrats released their report, followed by the majority Republicans' findings on Tuesday.

In the Democratic report, the U.S. military and the former secretary of state are cleared of any wrongdoing. The report states that the U.S. military could not have done anything differently on the night of the attacks to save the lives of the four Americans who perished. The report also notes that the State Department's security measures were "woefully inadequate," but that Mrs. Clinton never personally turned down a request for additional security.

In contrast, the Republican report, led by House panel chairman Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina, states that the U.S. was slow to send help to the Americans in Benghazi "because of an obsession with hurting the Libyans' feelings." The report also accuses the Obama administration of "misleading the public over the incident and failing to protect U.S. personnel."

The Republican report, which labels Benghazi as the "wild east," also criticizes Clinton for her role in the incident. Additionally, the report questions whether street protests precipitated the attacks, stating that a number of eyewitnesses remained in almost constant contact with officials in Washington during the attack, but none of the eyewitnesses mentioned a protest.

The White House and the investigating panel are also at odds as to whether President Obama should answer questions already submitted by the panel for the president's consideration. The fact that the Democrats have released their own report, while sitting on the same panel as Republicans, serves to heighten the partisanship of the inquiry.

The dueling Benghazi reports could have political repercussions for presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Clinton, as the Benghazi investigation has already uncovered her use of a private email server to conduct government business, now the subject of an FBI investigation. The Democrats' report states that the cause of the attacks "remains unclear to this day," quoting testimony by David Petraeus, in which the former CIA director says, "To be candid with you, I am not sure that the amount of scrutiny spent on this has been in the least bit worth it."

Title: Obama Administration Issues Directive on Transgender Students' Bathroom Access in Schools

Article:

In a significant move, the Obama administration has issued a directive on Friday regarding transgender students' access to bathrooms and locker rooms in schools. The directive, formulated by leaders in the Education and Justice Departments, requires public schools to allow transgender students to use bathrooms and locker rooms that correspond with their chosen gender identity, regardless of whether their education records or identity documents indicate a different sex.

Attorney General Loretta Lynch stated, "There is no room in our schools for discrimination of any kind, including discrimination against transgender students on the basis of their sex." The directive aims to clarify how school districts that receive federal funding can comply with Title IX, a law that "protects people from discrimination based on sex in education programs or activities that receive Federal financial assistance."

Schools are obligated to treat students according to their chosen gender identity, and there is no requirement for students to present a medical diagnosis for the change, according to the directive. The Human Rights Campaign, a civil rights organization for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals, commended the move.

Chad Griffin, HRC President, stated, "This is a truly significant moment not only for transgender young people but for all young people, sending a message that every student deserves to be treated fairly and supported by their teachers and schools."

The directive comes amidst a societal debate over the definition of gender identity, with some conservatives viewing gender as purely biological and set at birth, while many in the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender community consider gender identity as more fluid and highly personal. This tension has come to a head this week in North Carolina, where the state is embroiled in a legal battle with the federal government over its so-called bathroom bill.

On Monday, the Justice Department sued North Carolina over its bathroom law, HB2, or the Public Facilities Privacy and Security Act, stating that the legislation is discriminatory. HB2 includes measures that prohibit public school students from using school facilities consistent with their chosen gender identity. The lawsuit advises the state to confirm it will not be moving ahead with the legislation.

Attorney General Lynch stated when announcing the federal lawsuit, "This action is about a great deal more than bathrooms, this is about the dignity and respect that we accord our fellow citizens." North Carolina responded with a countersuit, stating that the state was given an unrealistic amount of time to comply with the federally-imposed compliance deadline.

Title: Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli Challenges Court Ruling on State's Anti-Sodomy Law, Sparks Controversy

Article:

Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli has filed a legal petition challenging a recent court ruling that found Virginia's anti-sodomy law unconstitutional. The case, which has garnered national attention due to Cuccinelli's gubernatorial bid, involves a 47-year-old man, William Scott MacDonald, who was convicted of soliciting a sexual act from a 17-year-old girl.

A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit ruled on March 12 that Virginia's "Crimes Against Nature" statute, which banned oral and anal sex, violates the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. One judge dissented, agreeing with a lower court that the Supreme Court's ruling in Lawrence v. Texas on sodomy laws applied only to consenting adults.

Cuccinelli's position in the case is to uphold the conviction of MacDonald. LGBT advocates have expressed disappointment, stating the law is unconstitutional and anti-gay. However, Cuccinelli's spokeswoman, Caroline Gibson, stated that the case is not about sexual orientation but about protecting a 17-year-old girl from a 47-year-old sexual predator.

Cuccinelli's opponent in the gubernatorial race, former Democratic National Committee chairman Terry McAuliffe, has criticized Cuccinelli for focusing on "divisive" politics. McAuliffe's campaign stated that Cuccinelli is ignoring the economy and instead focusing on his ideological agenda.

The Cuccinelli campaign responded to McAuliffe's criticism with a statement, stating that it is "sad and unfortunate" that Democrats attack someone for protecting children from sexual predators. The campaign also noted that the case is about prosecuting a 47-year-old man who solicited sexual acts from a 17-year-old girl.

The controversy surrounding Cuccinelli's position on the anti-sodomy law has sparked debate, with some arguing that the case is unrelated to gay rights and is instead about protecting minors from predators. However, critics argue that Cuccinelli's intervention in the case opens the door to questions about his stance on sodomy laws in general, and his previous remarks on the subject will also be a point of contention.

UPDATE: Journalist Josh Barro has pointed to previous remarks from Cuccinelli on the subject of sodomy laws in general, which Cuccinelli will have to address as the case and his stance on sodomy laws in general may be a point of contention for voters who do not believe various sexual acts between consenting adults should be barred by law.

Title: President Obama Urges Optimism, Addresses Race Relations and Gun Violence in Wake of Dallas Shooting

Article:

In a press conference held in Warsaw, Poland, President Barack Obama urged Americans to remain optimistic about race relations in the United States, following the fatal shootings of two black males by police and the subsequent shooting of five Dallas law-enforcement officials by a gunman. The president emphasized that the actions of a few should not define the entire nation and that race relations have not reached a new low or regressed to the level of 1960s rioting.

Obama reiterated his commitment to addressing race relations, stating that he has revived the task force formed after the shooting of unarmed black teen Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, two years ago. The task force, which will include police officers, community and civil rights activists, and others, will discuss next steps.

The president acknowledged the decrease in violent crime in the U.S. over the past five, ten, and fifteen years. He also renewed his commitment to stopping gun violence, stating that it is crucial to address the issue of gun control in order to prevent further tragedies.

In the wide-ranging press conference, Obama also addressed topics such as Brexit, ISIS, and NATO. He spoke sympathetically of police officers in gun-filled communities, acknowledging the challenges they face when engaging with potentially armed individuals. He also expressed concern about the presence of guns in communities, citing the shooting of motorist Philando Castile during a traffic stop in suburban St. Paul, Minnesota, and the presence of an apparently legally owned gun in the car where the shooting occurred.

The president also addressed the Dallas sniper, Micah Johnson, a black Army veteran, as a "demented individual" and emphasized that such actions do not represent the values of the American people. He declined to label the Dallas shooting as a hate crime, stating that it is difficult to interpret the motives of mass shooters.

Obama also addressed the ongoing issue of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, stating that it is important for both sides to ensure the process is as sensible and orderly as possible. He reaffirmed the U.S.'s close friendship and commercial partnership with both the U.K. and the E.U.

In conclusion, President Obama emphasized the importance of addressing race relations, gun violence, and international issues in a thoughtful and measured manner, and called for unity and understanding in the face of adversity.

Title: Romney Outraises Obama in May Fundraising by Nearly $17 Million

Article:

Mitt Romney's presidential campaign raised $76.8 million in May, surpassing President Barack Obama's fundraising efforts by nearly $17 million. The Republican fundraising haul, the first full month that Mr. Romney and the Republican National Committee were in partnership, was nearly double the amount collected in the prior month.

President Obama's campaign announced on Thursday that its joint fundraising operation with the Democratic National Committee had raised $60 million in May. According to a statement from Mr. Romney's campaign, the campaign and the Republican National Committee ended May with $107 million in cash.

Spencer Zwick, Mr. Romney's national finance chairman, stated, "It is clear that people aren't willing to buy into 'hope & change' again. Voters are making an investment because they believe that it will benefit the country."

The surge in fundraising for Mr. Romney came after he clinched the delegates necessary to become the Republican nominee, allowing Republican donors who may have been on the sidelines during the primary process to contribute. It also paved the way for the Republican National Committee to link its operations and fundraising efforts with the Romney campaign.

Aides to Mr. Obama said they were not especially worried because they had expected Mr. Romney to have a good fundraising month. They stated that some Republican donors likely gave the maximum they could in May and will not be able to give again in the coming months.

The financial comparisons underscore the concern that Mr. Obama's campaign has expressed to supporters over the past several months about the need for stepped-up financial contributions. Democrats have warned that despite the president's fundraising prowess, he could be outspent during the upcoming months as Mr. Romney's spending is supplemented by historic levels of fundraising by outside political groups, particularly "super PACs."

Mr. Obama's campaign announced his total on Twitter Thursday morning, stating that the average donation was just over $50. The $60 million includes money raised directly by his campaign and by the Democratic National Committee.

The announcement by Mr. Obama comes two days after Republicans succeeded in beating back the recall of Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, who had a big lead over his opponent in campaign cash. Mr. Obama held a fundraiser with Hollywood celebrities, including the actor George Clooney, in early May, just after he announced his support for same-sex marriage. The event reportedly raised $15 million for Mr. Obama's campaign.

Democrats had worried whether Mr. Obama's public support for the issue would cost him support in important swing states like Virginia and North Carolina. However, the decision was hailed by supporters of Mr. Obama's in the gay community, and it appears to have bolstered fundraising for the president among wealthy members of that group.

Title: Low Gas Prices: A Boon for Consumers, but Concerns over Deflation Persist

Article:

Across the United States, gasoline prices have been steadily decreasing over the past few weeks, currently averaging around $3 per gallon. This downward trend has contributed to a minimal increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) last month, with the 12-month CPI rise at 1.7 percent, significantly lower than its historical average.

However, some economists express concern that prolonged decreases in energy prices could lead to deflation, a phenomenon last observed during the Great Depression of the 1930s. Deflation is considered a potential economic danger due to its destructive impact on businesses, housing, and investments.

To illustrate the risks, consider a factory owner who must purchase parts and raw materials, pay workers, and repay loans. If prices start falling, the owner may struggle to meet loan repayments, fulfill contracts with workers, or afford the inventory already on hand. This downward pressure creates a vicious cycle that can lead to a broad decline in the value of businesses, homes, and investments.

The source of the downward price pressure can be traced to weak economic growth in both Europe and China. As consumers and companies in these regions cut their energy and goods purchases, global prices fall. Central bankers and policymakers worldwide are taking steps to stimulate growth and prevent further price declines.

In the United States, the Federal Reserve, which sets interest rates, aims to maintain a 2 percent inflation rate. Given the deflationary pressures emanating from Europe, the Fed may hold off on increasing interest rates until the CPI rises significantly.

For most Americans, this situation means that wages and prices are stagnant, while interest rates remain low. While the danger of deflation looms, the drop in energy prices has so far benefited consumers. Many are enjoying the benefits of low inflation, such as cheap car loans and affordable gas, which can stimulate the economy by increasing travel and consumer spending power.

A case in point is Macy Gould, a Lexington, Ky. resident who graduated from college in May. She was delighted this past weekend when she refueled for about $2.83 a gallon. "Spending less on gas is a real help to me," she said, noting that a driving trip she wanted to make to St. Louis was previously unaffordable. Now, with gas prices significantly lower, "I'm hoping I can get that back on the calendar."

Title: Obama Stands Firm on Debt Ceiling, Gun Control in Final Press Conference of First Term

Article:

In his final press conference of his first term on Monday, President Barack Obama reiterated his stance that he will not negotiate over the debt ceiling, stating that Washington must increase the limit to pay its bills. The president described such brinkmanship as "absurd" and "irresponsible."

"The issue here is whether Washington will pay its bills," Obama said. "We are not a deadbeat nation."

The press conference, which lasted approximately 30 minutes, primarily focused on the debt ceiling and Obama's gun-control plans following the mass shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Connecticut, on December 14, where 26 lives were lost.

Obama, who has vowed to curb gun violence, reiterated his promise, stating, "If there is a step we can take that will save even one child from what happened in Newtown, we should take that step."

The president also suggested that gun rights groups may be exaggerating strong turnouts at gun shows to create fear among gun owners that the federal government is planning to confiscate their firearms.

In response, Andrew Arulanandam, a spokesman for the National Rifle Association, said, "The president should go talk to the people buying firearms and ask them why they're buying firearms."

Obama also clarified that some of his proposed changes can be implemented through executive action, while others will require legislation.

The president used the press conference to emphasize that raising the debt ceiling does not authorize more spending, but rather pays for bills that have already been incurred.

Republican leaders responded by stating that the debt limit debate is connected to spending, suggesting another round of intense negotiations when Congress returns later this month. House Speaker John Boehner stated, "The American people do not support raising the debt ceiling without reducing government spending at the same time."

Boehner's remarks contrasted sharply with those of Obama, who said near the start of the press conference that he won re-election on his plan, which separates the debt ceiling from talks about reducing the U.S. deficit through spending cuts and increasing tax revenue through closing loopholes.

Obama argued he has already reduced federal spending by $1.2 trillion over the past two years but remains willing to discuss more cuts, including some to Medicare.

However, the president acknowledged that the Republican-controlled House likely has enough votes to demand spending cuts be part of the debate, which would result in no increase to the debt limit and the country defaulting on its bills.

The House of Representatives returns to negotiate with the Democrat-controlled Senate and the White House on three fiscal matters with looming deadlines: the debt ceiling, massive federal spending cuts known as sequester, and a budget resolution.

The talks resume because Washington again failed after the November elections to reach a long-term solution to the country's debt and deficit issues.

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell stated that Obama and his allies need to get serious about spending, and that the debt limit debate is "the perfect time for it." The Kentucky senator also called the country's debt and deficit a "huge, huge problem."

On a question about Obama nominating only men to his Cabinet for his second term, the president told critics to wait until his selections are complete "before they rush to justice."

Title: White House Bans CNN Reporter Jim Acosta, Sparks First Amendment Debate

Article:

The recent ban of CNN reporter Jim Acosta from the White House grounds has sparked a debate over freedom of the press and the First Amendment. The ban, which followed a heated exchange between Acosta and President Donald Trump during a press conference, has been met with criticism from media outlets and legal experts.

According to reports, Acosta's behavior, described as "rude" and "terrible" by President Trump, did not prevent White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders and Trump from routinely calling on him during question and answer periods over the past 22 months. The White House could have easily avoided Acosta by ignoring his questions, but they regularly called on him, using his extended responses to create a public spectacle that has become a staple of their anti-press strategy.

The ban and subsequent lawsuit filed by CNN today demand that Sanders and Trump return Acosta's "hard pass" and allow him to roam the White House grounds. The lawsuit cites case law that prevents the White House from arbitrarily banning reporters from White House press facilities "for less than compelling reasons."

The original charge for barring Acosta, that he had placed his hands on a White House intern during the presser, has been disproved. Today, Sanders shifted her rationale for the ban, accusing Acosta of not surrendering the microphone when approached by the intern. However, Sanders acknowledges that Acosta's resistance was not an isolated incident.

The Acosta ban has turned him into a free speech martyr, with many, including legal analyst Andrew Napolitano, predicting that the matter will be resolved "quickly" in CNN's favor. The televised White House briefings, which have become political theater under Trump's management, have generated minimal news value, with many relying on reporters like Maggie Haberman who spend little time in the daily briefings waiting for news to arrive.

The Acosta-Trump faceoff has provided an entertaining sideshow, but it has also detracted from the primary purpose of journalism. The endless bickering between Sanders and the press corps and her obfuscations have become the story, rather than the news they are intended to report. The White House has yet to comment on the lawsuit or the ongoing debate over freedom of the press.

Title: Fourth Republican Senator Opposes Trump's Expected Nomination of Herman Cain for Federal Reserve, Possibly Jeopardizing Confirmation

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. President Donald Trump's anticipated nomination of former pizza chain executive Herman Cain to the Federal Reserve appears to be in jeopardy after a fourth Republican senator voiced opposition, potentially denying Cain the necessary support for confirmation in the post.

Senator Kevin Cramer stated, "If I had to vote today, I would vote no." If all Senate Democrats and the two independents aligned with them were to vote against Cain, he would fall short of the majority support he needs.

ABC News, citing sources familiar with the matter, reported late on Thursday that Cain was expected to withdraw his name from consideration in the coming days. Cain declined comment on the report.

Senators Mitt Romney, Lisa Murkowski, and Cory Gardner, all Republicans, have each reportedly said they would vote against Cain if he is nominated. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell withheld comment on Thursday on whether he would support Cain, saying he would wait to see "who is actually nominated."

Economists and critics have expressed concerns about loyalists of Republican Trump serving on the traditionally nonpartisan central bank. Cain has been a public advocate of many of Trump's policies, as has Stephen Moore, another person Trump has said he wants to nominate. Neither nomination has been formally sent to the Senate.

On Facebook earlier this week, Cain said the reason he was under attack as a nominee was because he is a conservative. Cain's bid for president in 2012 was derailed by accusations of sexual harassment that he has repeatedly denied.

White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow said earlier on Thursday that Trump intended to proceed with his plan to name Cain to the Fed's board of governors.

"I like Herman Cain," Trump told reporters on Wednesday. "As to how he's doing in the process, that I don't know... Herman is a great guy, and I hope he does well."

The president nominates members to the Fed's seven-member board of governors. He elevated Jerome Powell to chairman a year ago but has frequently criticized him for the Fed's interest rate increases. The nominations must be approved by the Senate. The central bank's other top policymakers head the Fed's 12 regional banks and are chosen by local boards of directors, not the president.

Related Coverage:
- U.S. Senate leader McConnell notes Republican worries over Cain serving on Fed
- Trump has slammed the central bank's 2018 rate hikes for thwarting economic growth and publicly pressed policymakers to change course.
- Central bank independence from short-term politics is seen as important to prevent influence that could lead to runaway debt, hyperinflation, and financial instability. The issue is a topic of conversation at the meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington this week.
- "Undermining central bank independence would be dangerous," Tobias Adrian, director of the International Monetary Fund's monetary and capital markets department, said in an interview on Wednesday with Bloomberg News.

Title: Secretary of State Kerry Advocates for Peaceful Resolution on Korean Peninsula, Reiterates U.S. Stance on North Korea

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Tokyo today, concluding the last leg of his Asia trip, with a focus on finding a peaceful resolution to the ongoing tensions on the Korean peninsula. During his meeting with Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida, Kerry reiterated the Obama administration's commitment to seeking a peaceful resolution and expressed the U.S.'s willingness to engage in direct talks with North Korea, provided Pyongyang takes steps towards denuclearization and negotiates responsibly.

Kerry's visit to Japan comes as North Korea has escalated its rhetoric towards Tokyo. On Friday, the regime singled out Japan as the potential first target in the event of a war on the Korean peninsula, raising concerns in a country that does not have a combat military but only self-defense forces. In response, Japanese Foreign Minister Kishida stated that Japan is prepared for such contingencies, including potential missile launches, but added that Tokyo would continue to pursue a "dialogue and pressure" policy.

Kerry's visit follows meetings with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang, during which both parties expressed confidence in China's willingness to pressure North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and calm tensions on the peninsula. In a joint statement, Kerry and Chinese State Councilor Yang Jiechi reaffirmed the U.S. and China's commitment to working towards the denuclearization of North Korea.

In North Korea, festivities continued for the 101st birthday celebration of founder Kim Il Sung, with Pyongyang hosting an international marathon. However, Pyongyang has not ceased its threats towards the outside world, denouncing South Korean President Park Geun-hye's offer of dialogue as a "cunning ploy" and an "empty shell." The Kaesong Industrial Complex, a joint economic project between the two Koreas, remains shut down after North Korea pulled out its 53,000 workers in response to tension-building measures in the past few weeks.

Analysts have speculated that North Korea may launch a mid-range Musudan missile before the April 15 celebration. In an effort to defuse tensions on the Korean peninsula, Park offered peace through dialogue on Thursday, a move welcomed by Kerry, who has repeatedly expressed his support for bilateral talks. Kerry stated that any missile launch would be a "huge mistake."

In related news, South Korean local media have questioned the whereabouts of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, who has not been seen in public for the past two weeks. This has prompted speculation that Kim may be toning down his fiery threats or posturing for a launch. Kim is expected to appear in a military parade in Pyongyang on Monday.

Title: U.S. Delegation to Sochi Winter Olympics Includes Openly Gay Athletes, High-Ranking Officials Absent

Article:

The United States will not be sending any high-ranking officials to the upcoming Winter Olympics in Russia, a move that is being seen as a snub to Russia. The U.S. delegation, however, will include openly gay athletes, such as tennis legend Billie Jean King and figure skater Brian Boitano, who will participate in the games' opening ceremonies on February 7.

The White House announced Tuesday that former Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano, White House aide Rob Nabors, and the U.S. ambassador to Russia will round out the delegation to the Sochi games. Billie Jean King, who was one of the first professional athletes to come out as gay in the 1980s, will join Boitano at the games' opening ceremonies.

Speed skaters Bonnie Blair and Eric Heiden, as well as openly gay hockey player Caitlin Cahow, will also attend the games, with Cahow appearing at the closing ceremony two weeks later. The absence of high-ranking U.S. officials amounts to a snub to Russia, whose relationship with the United States has fractured over the past year.

The selection of this delegation, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said Wednesday, sends the message that the United States is a diverse place. Carney pointed to Napolitano, a former Cabinet secretary, as evidence of the delegation's distinction. It's the first time in more than a decade that the President, vice president, first lady, or former president has not attended an Olympic opening or closing ceremony.

The absence of high-ranking U.S. officials is due in part to new laws in Russia banning gay "propaganda" -- a law critics say is so vague that anyone can be prosecuted for wearing a rainbow T-shirt or holding hands in public with someone of the same sex. The rift between the nations has also been fueled by the admission of NSA leaker Edward Snowden, who was granted temporary asylum in Moscow, and Russian President Vladimir Putin's use of Russia's veto on the United Nations Security Council to block action in Syria.

Obama canceled a meeting with Putin that was scheduled for September, though the two met as part of a larger group of world leaders at the Group of 20 conference in St. Petersburg. The President has been vocal in his criticism of the Russian policy, stating in August that he has "no patience for countries that try to treat gays or lesbians or transgender persons in ways that intimidate them or are harmful to them." During his visit to Russia earlier this year, Obama met with the leaders of Russian social activist groups.

Title: Governors Grapple with Health Care Decisions Following Supreme Court Ruling

Article:

Governors from across the United States convened in Williamsburg, Virginia over the weekend, with health care high on their agenda. The focus was on the federal health law, following the Supreme Court's recent ruling that granted states the option to expand their Medicaid programs.

Republican governors, in particular, expressed surprise by the Supreme Court's decision, which declared the health law constitutional but allowed states to decide whether to enroll most individuals earning more than approximately $15,000 per year in their Medicaid programs.

Utah Governor Gary Herbert stated, "A lot of us, certainly on the Republican side, believed it would be found unconstitutional. So I think it's just added more confusion to the issue rather than settling the issue." He further added that the November election would likely provide more clarity on the implications moving forward.

Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell, the meeting's host, declined to reveal his state's plans regarding Medicaid expansion, citing the need for more information. "Honestly, I don't think it's responsible for my state to make a decision now because there's still more information we need," he said.

Democratic governors, such as Delaware's Jack Markell, the incoming chairman of the National Governors Association, view the situation differently. Markell stated, "This is not political. This is a financial analysis of what does it mean to cover, in our case, an additional 30,000 people," and added that Delaware taxpayers would benefit from the expansion.

Unlike Republicans, who argue that the Supreme Court decision added confusion, Democrats, like Maryland's Martin O'Malley, maintain that the decision should have ended the debate. O'Malley stated, "I think most governors understand that the Supreme Court's decision was a final and clear ruling."

Some Democratic governors were less diplomatic in their comments. Vermont's Peter Shumlin criticized some of his Republican colleagues for not being honest about their intentions regarding the health law. Shumlin stated, "Have a spine. The American people are sick and tired of spineless politicians."

O'Malley of Maryland believes that many Republican governors will eventually accept the federal Medicaid funding for economic reasons, once the election is over. He stated, "Once the posturing of the election is past, I think that a lot of these governors are going to have a hard time going home to their doctors, nurses, hospitals and explaining to them why they are passing up an opportunity to transform these dollars into better economic uses for job creation in their states."

However, for many Republican governors, such as Nebraska's Dave Heineman, the issue is about more than just economic interests. "They all say it's free federal money. No, it's not. That's our tax dollars," Heineman said. "It's costing every one of us."

Behind the scenes, governors seemed to agree on one point: there are still many questions they want the federal government to answer as the health law's implementation progresses.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Digital Privacy, Pitting Microsoft Against U.S. Government Over Overseas Emails

Article:

The Supreme Court has agreed to hear a significant case on digital privacy, this time involving a dispute between the federal government and Microsoft over emails stored overseas. The case, which adds to the court's already busy term concerning technology and law, follows a similar case regarding cellphone location data.

The Microsoft case dates back to 2013 when U.S. prosecutors demanded Microsoft turn over emails linked to a drug-trafficking case, which were stored only on Microsoft servers in Ireland. Microsoft complied with the information it had stored in the United States but sued to block the warrant, arguing that U.S. law enforcement could not seize evidence held in another country.

In 2014, U.S. District Judge Loretta Preska ordered Microsoft to hand over the emails. However, last year, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit in New York reversed the decision and ruled in Microsoft's favor.

By agreeing to hear the case, the justices are taking on an issue they could have left alone, as there is no split among federal appeals courts. In addition, Congress is considering legislation that would fill in some blanks left by the Stored Communications Act of 1986, which did not address communications held overseas.

Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith argued that the court should have waited for Congress to act. "The current laws were written for the era of the floppy disk, not the world of the cloud," he said on his blog. "We believe that rather than arguing over an old law in court, it is time for Congress to act by passing new legislation."

However, the Trump administration urged the high court to take on the case. "Neither the absence of a circuit conflict nor the speculative possibility of eventual legislative action diminishes the acute and present need for this court’s review of a legally unsound decision that is frustrating important investigations around the country," it said in legal papers.

Thirty-three states weighed in on the government's side, arguing in a brief submitted by Vermont that the appeals court decision "is interfering with the ability of state and local law enforcement agencies to investigate and prosecute crime in their jurisdictions."

Microsoft argued that Congress is the proper forum to address the issue, noting that the Justice Department proposed a legislative fix before appealing the lower court ruling to the Supreme Court. "Revising a federal statute to account for the globalization of data is a job for Congress, not courts," Microsoft told the justices.

The company warned that the nation's technology sector would be harmed "if it becomes the conduit through which U.S. law enforcement can seize the private communications of every U.S. service provider’s customers, no matter where in the world those customers are located or their data is stored."

Title: Republican Governors Opt Out of Medicaid Expansion Under Affordable Care Act

Article:

In the aftermath of the Supreme Court's decision last month, several Republican governors have announced their intention to forego the Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act. On Monday, Texas Governor Rick Perry joined this group, stating that Texas will not participate in Medicaid expansion.

Perry's decision follows similar moves by other GOP state executives who have declined to offer Medicaid to individuals with incomes up to 133% of the federal poverty level. This year, that equates to approximately $15,000 for an individual or $25,000 for a family of three.

"We're not going to participate in any exchanges," Perry said on Fox News. "We're not going to expand Medicaid. We're just not going to be a part of, again, socializing health care in the state of Texas. And going in direct conflict with our Founding Fathers' wishes and freedom, for that matter."

Perry and his colleagues argue their rejection of the health law is primarily based on ideological reasons. The states' concerns stem from the fact that, when it comes to Medicaid, they do not appear to be on the hook for significant financial contributions.

According to Jeff Goldsmith, a health policy analyst who teaches public health at the University of Virginia, the Affordable Care Act provides 100% coverage for people newly eligible for Medicaid by the federal government in the initial years, and 90% in subsequent years. This compares to the rest of the Medicaid program, where the federal government pays an average of just under 60%.

However, states are not only concerned about the newly eligible population. Dennis Smith, secretary of the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and former head of the federal Medicaid program under President George W. Bush, states that this year, his state put more than a billion dollars into its existing Medicaid program. Even with enhanced federal match rates, Wisconsin had a $600 million budget shortfall.

Another concern for states is the so-called "woodwork effect." When major parts of the health law take effect in 2014, there is a worry that it will bring out of the woodwork the millions of people who are already eligible for Medicaid but are not currently enrolled. These individuals may discover cheaper health insurance options through the health exchanges, leading them to sign up for Medicaid instead.

Bruce Lesley, president of First Focus, an advocacy group for children and families, notes that many of these individuals signing up for Medicaid will not be part of the newly eligible expansion group, whose bills will be largely paid by the federal government. They will be regular Medicaid beneficiaries, and states will have to pay up to half their costs.

Goldsmith states that state officials are most concerned about the ease with which currently eligible but unenrolled Medicaid recipients can sign up. "It won't be an in-person visit, it won't be a 'bring six forms of ID,'" he says. "There will be an expedited—lubricated, if you will—process to get people onto the rolls, and I think that's the part that's giving state budget officers serious indigestion at this point."

Goldsmith notes that state officials he has spoken to worry that Medicaid, already the largest piece of almost every state budget, could end up dwarfing everything else. "The health and human services secretary of Louisiana told me that at full implementation, 48% of the citizens of his state would be on Medicaid," he says. "And I strongly suspect that [as] you go across the Southern tier of the United States, you'll see a lot of those states in the 30s. A third of their citizens eligible for or potentially enrolled in Medicaid."

Some states are already looking at cutting back their Medicaid programs. Wisconsin's Dennis Smith, who used to run the federal Medicaid program, states he interprets the Supreme Court decision as allowing this. However, the Obama administration disagrees. Last night, it sent a letter to all the nation's governors, noting that "the Court's decision did not affect other provisions of the law." An administration official confirmed that included the requirement that states maintain current eligibility levels until the year 2014.

Health advocate Lesley agrees with the administration. "Our reading of the Supreme Court ruling is [that] the opinion by Justice Roberts...cites basically a specific section of the law and basically changed the idea that the Medicaid expansion can no longer be a mandatory thing, but now is optional," Lesley says. "However, what it did not touch on was this idea of requiring states to maintain coverage. So we believe that that is absolutely still in place."

Title: Negotiations with Iran Remain Tough as Deadline Approaches; New Approaches Explored but No Proposal Reached

Article:

As the deadline for negotiations between the United States and Iran approaches, Secretary of State John Kerry has acknowledged the difficulty of reaching an agreement, stating, "These talks are not going to get easier just because we extend them." The talks, which involve six different nations, have been described as tough and are expected to remain so.

Officials have provided little detail about the new approaches being explored with Iran, only indicating that experts from the Energy Department's national laboratories will study them to determine if they, in combination with other steps, would provide at least a year's warning if Iran were to pursue a nuclear weapon.

The potential steps could include Iran committing to ship some of its nuclear stockpile to Russia, disconnecting some of the country's centrifuges in a manner that would take considerable time to reverse, and implementing output limits that can be verified by international inspectors. A European diplomat involved in the discussions described the process as having "a lot of moving parts," with the question being what the combined efforts amount to.

Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif stated late Monday that the new ideas do not represent a proposal by either side but rather a compilation of ideas exchanged between the negotiating parties. Zarif reiterated his commitment to maintaining the secrecy of the negotiating room and expressed concern over leaks from the discussions, which have been prevalent throughout the talks.

Secretary Kerry praised Mr. Zarif, acknowledging the challenges he faces in navigating Iran's complex political landscape and the uncertainty regarding how far Iran's supreme leader will allow him to go. The negotiations aim to end sanctions that have significantly reduced Iran's oil revenue, devalued its currency, and made overseas financial transactions difficult.

Title: Republican Senators Urge White House to Reject Union's Call for ObamaCare Subsidy Extension

Article:

Thirty-one Republican senators have written a letter to President Obama urging the rejection of union demands to extend ObamaCare subsidies to workers who already have job-based health coverage. The senators argue that such an extension is prohibited under the law.

The senators' letter, sent on Thursday, follows a report in a newspaper that unions, concerned about the law's other requirements potentially increasing health care plan costs, are seeking access to federal subsidies for lower-paid workers.

According to The Wall Street Journal, the Obama administration initially dismissed the idea of aiding workers in union-sponsored policies. However, a Treasury official, in the same article, stated that the issue is "the subject of pending regulations."

The senators, in their letter, disagree with the Treasury's stance, stating that it "ignores the letter of the law." They argue that several provisions in the health care law could increase the cost of coverage, including the elimination of caps on benefits.

The senators contend that workers with an employer-based plan cannot, under the law, receive subsidies intended for those who do not get insurance through their jobs. They cite a Congressional Research Service report stating that employer-sponsored coverage would "generally" make an employee "ineligible to receive a premium subsidy."

The subsidies, along with most major provisions of the health care law, are set to go into effect next year. According to The Wall Street Journal, approximately 20 million people are covered in plans run by unions and employers.

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah), and Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.) are among those who signed the letter to Obama. The senators suggest that concerns about rising premiums could be addressed by revisiting the taxes, fees, and other policies that contribute to premium increases, rather than considering an extension of subsidies not envisioned in the statute.

Title: Baltimore Police Brutality: A Detailed Account of Victims and Incidents

Article:

In the wake of the ongoing protests in Baltimore, a detailed account of police brutality incidents and their victims has emerged. Over the past four years, more than 100 people have won court judgments or settlements related to allegations of brutality and civil-rights violations. The city of Baltimore paid a total of $5.7 million to victims of police brutality between 2011 and 2014.

One of the victims, Venus Green, a 87-year-old grandmother, was a former teacher with two college degrees who spent her retirement years as a foster parent for needy children. In an incident that took place on her porch, Green was brutally treated by a white police officer who responded to an emergency call.

According to an 11-page letter detailing the incident for her lawyer, Green's grandson ran up to her crying for an ambulance. The officer became hostile, questioning the grandson and accusing him of lying. Green, who had no criminal record, defended her grandson, stating that he had run from a different direction and had called for the ambulance. The officer wanted to enter the basement, but Green, fearing her dogs would attack, refused. The officer then shoved Green against the wall, hit the wooden floor, and handcuffed her.

Green was thrown face-down on the couch, arrested, and complained of pain. An African-American officer later entered the house, saw Green sobbing, and had the handcuffs removed since Green was not violent. Green suffered a broken shoulder and did not face any charges. The payout in this case was $95,000.

The Baltimore Sun's article provides a detailed account of other victims of police brutality, including a 15-year-old boy riding a dirt bike, a 26-year-old pregnant accountant who had witnessed a beating, a 50-year-old woman selling church raffle tickets, and a 65-year-old church deacon rolling a cigarette. The incidents detail a frightful human toll, with officers battering residents who suffered broken bones, head trauma, organ failure, and even death during questionable arrests. Some residents were beaten while handcuffed, and others were thrown to the pavement.

The ongoing protests in Baltimore can be contextualized within this recent history of police brutality and the victims' stories. The full article can be found here.

Title: Obama Urges Direct Negotiations, No Preconditions in Israeli-Palestinian Peace Talks

Article:

President Barack Obama, during a joint appearance with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah, West Bank, on Thursday, emphasized the need for direct negotiations between Israeli and Palestinian leaders without preconditions. Obama stated that if negotiations are contingent on all issues being settled prior, there would be no purpose for negotiations.

Obama's remarks came amidst the backdrop of a morning rocket launch from the Hamas-controlled Gaza, two of which landed in southern Israel. The issue of Israeli settlements in the West Bank and the end to violence were key topics during the meeting between the two leaders.

While Obama discussed the settlement issue at length during his meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday, he did not endorse Abbas' position that ending settlements should be a prerequisite for peace talks. Instead, Obama reiterated the longstanding U.S. policy that continued settlement activity is not constructive or appropriate for advancing the cause of peace.

The President also addressed Israel's security concerns, referencing them on several occasions and citing the Thursday morning attack as an example. Obama's tone on the settlement issue was more restrained compared to his 2009 statement when he declared that the U.S. "does not accept the legitimacy of continued Israeli settlements."

In addition, Obama outlined the American role going forward as one of helping to "build confidence" and "rebuild a sense of trust" between the two parties. The President's visit to Israel and the Palestinian territories marks his first as President.

Title: NBC Sportscaster Bob Costas Clarifies Anti-Gun Remarks, Sparks Controversy

Article:

In an attempt to clarify his controversial anti-gun remarks during a Sunday Night Football broadcast, NBC sportscaster Bob Costas appeared on the O'Reilly Factor on Tuesday. The interview aimed to address the "misunderstanding" surrounding Costas' comments regarding the NFL player Jovan Belcher's shooting of his girlfriend.

Costas, who has faced heavy criticism for his comments, has repeatedly tried to shift the focus by stating, "I was quoting a column." However, when Costas made the remarks on Sunday, he explicitly acknowledged that he was quoting a column by Kansas City-based writer Jason Whitlock.

Furthermore, Costas attempted to distance himself from the notion that his comments were about gun control. However, when Costas expressed concern about the number of guns in America, it is reasonable to assume that he advocates for stricter gun control measures. Costas also incorrectly stated that Americans can easily purchase "automatic weapons," which requires special permits and rigorous background checks, and is not typically available at standard gun dealerships.

Costas also attempted to use the Aurora, Colorado, movie theater shooting to make political points, arguing that Colorado is a "carry state" and that patrons could have defended themselves if they were armed. However, the theater is a gun-free zone, and the shooter had a history of mental health issues that authorities failed to address before the tragedy.

Costas' suggestion that people defending themselves from a madman are playing "Dirty Harry" was also met with criticism. In response, it is important to recognize that America has two distinct gun cultures, each with its own unique history and purpose.

The first gun culture is deeply rooted in American history and the founding of the country. The Second Amendment was designed to ensure that an armed citizenry would prevent government tyranny. Historically, firearms have been used for collection, personal protection, hunting, sport, and celebrating American history. The firearms industry generates billions in tax revenue and employs millions of people.

The other gun culture is found in urban areas such as Chicago, Washington D.C., New York City, and Los Angeles. This culture is characterized by violent gun use within gangs and is often glorified in Hollywood films, rap music, and NBA parties.

In conclusion, it is essential for Costas to educate himself about the realities of American gun culture, guns, and gun laws before continuing to make controversial statements that may be misinterpreted or used to score political points.

Title: Senate Approves Funding Bill, Shifts Money for Slaughterhouse Inspections but Rejects White House Tours Restoration

Article:

The United States Senate voted on Wednesday to pass a bill funding the government through the remainder of the fiscal year, averting a potential government shutdown. The bill, which now returns to the House for final approval, includes significant changes to the budget sequesters, with funds allocated for full-time slaughterhouse inspections but no changes made to reopen the White House for public tours.

The 73-26 vote signals a growing consensus in Congress that the government shutdown showdowns of the past two years have not benefited either party. The bill, which funds basic operations through September 30, does not reverse the level of sequester cuts but does rewrite a few priorities, including restoring the military's tuition assistance programs and restoring funds for food inspections.

Without the additional funding, federal inspectors would have been furloughed, and meat-packing plants would not have been able to operate without on-site inspectors. This could have resulted in a significant decrease in U.S. meat production, with industry officials predicting a 2 billion pound decrease in beef and pork and a 3 billion pound decrease in poultry.

Senators added the inspection money back in by unanimous vote. "It was important that Congress act to prevent a potential crisis from developing in our nation's food supply," said Sen. Christopher A. Coons, Delaware Democrat. "Backlogs in food inspections could result in the shutdown of processing facilities and send devastating ripple effects through rural communities and straight to the shelves of every market and grocery in the country."

In a separate vote, senators declined to undo President Obama's decision to cancel White House tours, which he made earlier this month as one of the casualties of the budget sequesters. Sen. Tom Coburn, Oklahoma Republican, offered an amendment to restore White House tours, proposing to cut $8 million from spending on national heritage areas in the National Park Service budget.
