However, senators, led mostly by Democrats, rejected that plan, arguing that the money would hurt economic development in their home states.

Sen. Jack Reed, the Rhode Island Democrat who led the opposition, also said he doubted whether the money would go to reopen the White House. "Those tours are governed by the Secret Service, which is not part of this amendment, so that would not be affected," he said. Sen. Coburn countered that the tours were indeed at stake in the vote. "The National Park Service does have something to do with White House tours because they can take this money and reallocate it. It is not a Secret Service problem. It is a national park problem," he said.

The Senate defeated Mr. Coburn's amendment on a 54-45 vote, with nearly every Republican voting to reopen the White House and with almost all Democrats voting to back President Obama's decision. "We're focused on all the wrong things because it's all about the next election," said Sen. Coburn.

With the 2013 spending bill now cleared, the Senate turns its attention to the 2014 budget. House lawmakers have already begun that debate, with Republicans defeating three Democratic alternatives on Wednesday. The main Democratic substitute was killed on a 253-165 vote, with even 28 Democrats balking at the tax and spending increases. Hours earlier, Democrats tried to embarrass Republicans by refusing to cast votes on conservative Republicans' alternative. Rather than vote for or against the conservative budget, Democrats voted "present" - taking themselves out of the equation and making Republicans have to choose between backing the conservative blueprint, which calls for severe spending cuts, or to vote against it and risk the anger of tea party voters. The final vote was 132-104 against the conservative plan, with 14 Democrats and 118 Republicans voting against it, and just 104 Republicans voting for it. If the conservative budget had won the vote, it immediately would have become the official House budget, replacing the plan drawn up by Rep. Paul Ryan. Democrats wanted to force that situation, figuring the conservative budget would be too extreme for many moderate Republicans and therefore would ruin Republican efforts to pass a budget this year.

Title: Congressional Response to the Alleged Death of Jamal Khashoggi Remains Unclear Amid Midterm Elections

Article:

The suspected death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi has sparked a flurry of tough talk on Capitol Hill, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) stating that he "can't imagine there will be no response" to the incident. The U.S. and Saudi Arabia have a complex and pragmatic relationship, with both nations sharing aligned interests in the Middle East. However, the exact response from Congress remains unclear, as both houses are currently in recess for the midterm elections until November 13.

Senators from both parties have been vocal about Khashoggi's fate. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) suggested sanctions against Saudi Arabia, warning of a bipartisan backlash if the Saudis are found responsible for Khashoggi's death. Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) stated, "Murder is murder," while Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) criticized the U.S.'s perceived subservience to the Saudis.

However, the potential impact of Congress on Saudi Arabia is limited, as the U.S. needs a relatively stable presence in the Middle East beyond Israel and Jordan. The use of harsh words or sanctions against the Saudis could potentially inflame the kingdom and destabilize the region. As Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) noted, "If we can't draw a clear line, shame on us."

One potential action Congress can take is the imposition of Global Magnitsky sanctions, a tool that allows the U.S. to punish foreign powers for human rights abuses such as extrajudicial killings, torture, or detention. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) and the committee's top Democrat, Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), have requested an investigation into potential human rights abuses by Saudi Arabia. If the Trump Administration finds evidence of such abuses, the U.S. can impose sanctions.

The timeline for any action is unclear, as the current Congress will be in a lame-duck session after the midterm elections. It is likely that any prospective discipline for Saudi Arabia will be taken up by the new Congress in 2019.

The Khashoggi affair also raises questions about the Trump Administration's stance on violence against journalists, as President Trump has publicly praised physical violence against the press. This has led some to question the Administration's sincerity in addressing the Khashoggi case.

The future of Saudi Arabia-related discussions on Capitol Hill remains uncertain, with the departure of moderate Republicans and the complexities of the U.S.-Saudi relationship creating a challenging environment for meaningful action. The new Congress will tackle this issue after January 3, 2019.

Title: The Landscape of the American Gun Control Debate: A Closer Look

Article:

The ongoing debate on gun control in the United States is experiencing a shift, with students who survived the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School aiming to reshape the national discourse. Emma González, a senior at the school, recently addressed gun control advocates and politicians, stating, "We are going to be the last mass shooting."

The American gun control debate is often perceived as a stalemate, dominated by the influence of the National Rifle Association (NRA). However, there has been more action and gun violence prevention victories than many realize. Here is the current landscape that the Parkland students face as they demand new congressional action on gun control laws:

1. Gun Ownership: Between 55 million and 75 million Americans own guns, but the NRA only claims 5 million members, which is less than 10% of America's total gun owners.

2. Gun Ownership Distribution: Just 3% of American adults own half the country's guns. Most gun owners have one or two, but a tiny group of super-owners, who have an average of 17 each, collectively own half of the country's 256 million guns.

3. Gun Experience: Seventy-two percent of American adults have shot a gun, even though only 20-30% personally own a firearm. In contrast, 44% of American adults say they personally know someone who has been shot, either accidentally or intentionally.

4. Influence of the NRA: Twenty-nine percent of gun owners say the NRA has too much influence over gun laws, according to a recent Pew survey. However, overall, 55% of American adults say that the NRA has the "right amount" of power or even "too little" power over American gun laws.

5. Second Amendment Compatibility: Most gun control legislation being debated now is 100% compatible with the second amendment. The Supreme Court's 2008 Heller decision, a pro-gun-rights ruling, made it unconstitutional to completely ban Americans from keeping handguns in their homes for self-defense.

6. Previous Assault Weapon Bans: The 1994 American assault weapon ban did not accomplish much. The federal ban, which was allowed to lapse in 2004, allowed Americans to keep the military-style guns and ammunition they already owned. The law also defined "assault weapons" according to certain external features, allowing gun makers to tweak a few features and produce almost identical semiautomatic rifles that were compliant with the ban.

7. Focus on Universal Background Checks: Most American gun control groups agree that fighting for universal background checks on gun sales is the law that would do the most good. They have shifted their focus away from banning assault weapons to closing the loopholes in the federal background check system, which currently allows private sales between individuals with no background check.

8. Concerns about Moderation: Many gun control advocates worry the current movement is too moderate, and that it needs a more radical left flank. The NRA is often pushed to more extreme positions by smaller groups with even more hardline second-amendment views.

9. Racial, Economic, and Geographic Disparities: Black children 17 and under are 10 times more likely to be murdered with a gun than white children. About half of America's gun murder victims each year are black. The census tracts that saw the worst gun violence in 2015 represented about 1.5% of the country's total population, but 26% of the total gun homicides.

This article provides an objective overview of the current state of the American gun control debate, highlighting key statistics and trends. It is important to note that this article does not express personal opinions or political bias, but rather presents factual information for the reader's consideration.

Title: RealClearPolitics Poll Average Suggests Donald Trump's Support May Have Peaked

Article:

Kevin Drum, a political analyst, has observed a potential plateau in Donald Trump's poll numbers on RealClear Politics, suggesting that the Republican frontrunner may have reached his ceiling at 24.3 percent on August 5. Since then, Trump's numbers have dropped to 22.0 percent.

However, other poll aggregators, such as Pollster, run by The Huffington Post, show a less definitive trend, with Trump's climb not yet showing signs of slowing down significantly. The discrepancies between the two sources can be attributed to differences in the polls included and the methodology used to calculate the averages.

Despite the variations, both sources indicate that Trump's numbers have at least flattened, a trend that is likely to continue for the next several weeks due to the slow end-of-summer news cycle and the absence of significant ad buys before the next Republican debate.

Drum predicts that 25 percent will be the peak of Trump's support, but this does not necessarily mean a decline in his candidacy. In a field of 16 candidates, 20-25 percent still places Trump as a frontrunner, and he remains a polarizing figure among Republicans. With a substantial personal fortune, Trump can sustain his campaign for an extended period.

In conclusion, while it is possible that Trump has reached his peak in terms of poll numbers, it does not imply a swift decline. Trump's position in the race remains strong, and he is expected to remain a significant factor in the Republican primary race for the foreseeable future.

Title: Key Elements to Observe in Obama's Final State of the Union Address

Article:

In his final State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Barack Obama will deliver a speech that deviates from his past addresses, focusing on thematic and future-oriented topics rather than a laundry list of legislative proposals. The White House has promised a different approach, with President Obama stating that the speech will not only discuss the progress made, but also what needs to be done together in the coming years to ensure a stronger, more prosperous America.

1. Differences in the Speech's Content:
The speech will likely focus on big, unifying issues such as a minimum wage increase, tax reform for infrastructure investment, the Trans-Pacific trade agreement, and a criminal justice system overhaul. The White House is optimistic that Congress may approve these potentially bipartisan issues.

2. Legacy Shaping:
This valedictory speech will aim to frame Obama's accomplishments in the most positive light. He will discuss the recovery of the auto industry, improving employment, his initiatives on climate change, gun background checks, and reopening relations with Cuba. The guests joining First Lady Michelle Obama in the House chamber have been selected to represent the arc of Obama's presidency.

3. Aid to Hillary Clinton's Campaign:
The president is expected to frame the upcoming election in terms of economic growth and inclusivity, a theme that aligns with Hillary Clinton's campaign. He may also touch on hot-button issues that resonate with the Democratic base, such as climate change, gun control, immigration reform, or gay rights.

4. Thematic Emphasis:
The speech is not expected to be overtly political, but the subtext will likely convey a message of progress and the need to continue moving forward. The president may emphasize the need for a shared prosperity, a theme that has been a focus of Clinton's campaign.

5. Legacy Impact:
A well-received State of the Union address can provide a political boost. President Obama is hoping this speech will help improve his approval ratings, which have been in the mid-40s for months, and potentially aid Hillary Clinton's campaign and his own legacy.

Title: Clinton-Kaine Economic Theory on Great Recession Faces Fact-Checking

Article:

In the recent vice-presidential debate, Tim Kaine, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, reiterated an economic theory first presented by Hillary Clinton in the first presidential debate: that the Bush tax cuts of 2003 contributed to the Great Recession. This argument, however, lacks support from mainstream economic theories and empirical evidence.

The Keynesian view, a prominent school of economic thought, argues that deficit-financed tax cuts should stimulate the economy by encouraging spending. The Clinton-Kaine theory, in contrast, rejects this idea. Many economists argue that tax cuts that benefit the poor and middle-class deliver a bigger jolt to the economy, as such individuals tend to spend a higher fraction of their incomes. The Bush tax cuts of 2003 reduced rates for all tax brackets, but even if they had been geared solely to the rich, they would still have produced a stimulative impact on the economy, albeit a significantly diminished one.

Classical and monetarist views argue that only permanent reductions in taxes have a positive impact on wealth in the long-run. The Bush tax cuts expired after eight years, so classical and monetarist economists could debate whether they count as a temporary fiscal shock or not. However, neither school believes that tax cuts have a negative effect on economic activity.

The only plausible economic theory that could support the Kaine-Clinton argument is that deficit-financed tax cuts create recessions by expanding public debt to the point of fiscal insolvency, as happened in Greece. But that's not what happened in the Great Recession of 2008–2009.

Empirical work on the impact of tax cuts in isolation suggests that they almost always boost consumption and economic activity to varying degrees. University of Michigan economist Matthew Shapiro has found that over the last decade, tax cuts ranging from the initial tax-rate reductions enacted in 2001 under President Bush to the 2009 payroll-tax cuts under President Obama boosted economic activity to varying degrees.

It's important to note that income and wealth inequality are a separate matter. Few argue (and rightly so) that any of these tax cuts are self-financing. The continuing trend whereby the government takes in less than it spends has led to perennial deficits for 15 years. Such deficits could create fiscal drag on growth in the future, but that will only come in the form of higher taxes and lower growth, which again goes to show that tax cuts do not directly spur recessions.

The Clinton campaign's argument on the Great Recession bears many resemblances to the false argument spouted by Bernie Sanders in the primaries: that the repeal of Glass-Steagall created the financial crisis. Both theories propagate a lie, and the Clinton campaign's argument should not be allowed to stand. It's the latest in a series of political maneuvers meant to slander the other party at the expense of honest policy discussion.

Title: Federal Judge Overturns Trump's Attempt to Open Arctic and Atlantic Oceans to Oil and Gas Leasing

Article:

A federal judge in Alaska has overturned U.S. President Donald Trump's attempt to open vast areas of the Arctic and Atlantic oceans to oil and gas leasing. The decision issued late Friday by U.S. District Court Judge Sharon Gleason leaves intact President Barack Obama's policies putting the Arctic's Chukchi Sea, part of the Arctic's Beaufort Sea, and a large swath of the Atlantic Ocean off the U.S. East Coast off-limits to oil leasing.

Trump's attempt to undo Obama's protections was "unlawful" and a violation of the federal Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, Gleason ruled. Presidents have the power under that law to withdraw areas from the national oil and gas leasing program, as Obama did, but only Congress has the power to add areas to the leasing program, she said.

The Obama-imposed leasing prohibitions "will remain in full force and effect unless and until revoked by Congress," Gleason said in her ruling. Trump's move to put offshore Arctic and Atlantic areas back into play for oil development came in a 2017 executive order that was part of his "energy dominance" agenda.

The Trump administration has proposed a vastly expanded offshore oil leasing program to start this year. The five-year Trump leasing program would offer two lease sales a year in Arctic waters and at least two lease sales a year in the Atlantic. The Trump plan also calls for several lease sales in remote marine areas off Alaska, like the southern Bering Sea, that are considered to hold negligible potential for oil.

Obama had pulled much of the Arctic off the auction block following a troubled offshore Arctic exploration program pursued by Royal Dutch Shell. Shell spent at least $7 billion trying to explore the Chukchi and part of the Beaufort. The company wrecked one of its drill ships in a grounding and managed to complete only one well to depth. It abandoned the program in 2015 and relinquished its leases.

In a separate case, Gleason delivered another decision on Friday that blocks the Trump administration's effort to overturn an Obama-era environmental decision. Gleason struck down a land trade intended to clear the way for a road to be built through sensitive wetlands in Alaska's Izembek National Wildlife Refuge. The Obama administration, after a four-year environmental impact statement process, determined that the land trade and road would cause too much harm to the refuge to be justified. Trump's then Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke broke the law when he summarily reversed the Obama policy without addressing the facts found in the previous administration's study of the issue, Gleason ruled.

Title: Georgia Special Election Highlights Nationalized Local Elections and Party Loyalty

Article:

The special House election taking place in Georgia on Tuesday is a microcosm of a national trend, with the contest attracting significant media coverage, high-profile visits, and over $50 million in campaign funds, making it the most expensive House race in American history. Despite the intense focus, the outcome of this election will not determine the fate of either the Republican or Democratic parties in the near future.

The Georgia special election serves as an exaggerated version of the nationalized local election, a phenomenon that is expected to continue in 2018 and 2020. While there is only one other special election happening simultaneously in South Carolina, the closeness of the Georgia contest has drawn national attention and resources.

In the Georgia race, both candidates, Jon Ossoff (Democrat) and Karen Handel (Republican), have been cautious about positioning themselves as partisan crusaders. Ossoff's campaign focuses on cutting wasteful spending, reducing the deficit, and prioritizing high-tech and bio-tech research. Handel, despite a private fundraiser by President Trump, has emphasized her independence from the White House, stating that she represents the people of the 6th district and is not an extension of the White House.

However, if Handel wins, she will be an extension of the Republican agenda, as a vote for her is a vote for the GOP's legislative agenda, including repealing the Affordable Care Act, cutting taxes for the wealthy, rolling back environmental protections, boosting military spending, and more. Ossoff, on the other hand, is a Democrat who, for all his technocratic talk, will have limited ability to bring jobs to metro Atlanta, and his votes will primarily reflect his party affiliation.

In conclusion, the Georgia special election serves as a reminder that voters are essentially voting for a party, rather than an individual representative. The 6th district's choice between Handel and Ossoff will determine whether to advance the Republican legislative agenda and support President Trump or to stop GOP legislation and make a Democratic takeover one vote more likely. This election, like many others, is a referendum on the national parties and their agendas, and voters should be aware of the implications of their choices.

Title: House GOP Immigration Reform Faces Slow Death in Congress

Article:

Republican leaders are set to meet with their members on Wednesday to strategize their approach to immigration reform, which appears to be facing a slow and prolonged demise in the House of Representatives. The House plans to adopt a piecemeal approach, with a potential border-security bill this month and one or two smaller reforms per month in the fall.

In private discussions, top Republicans on Capitol Hill predict that comprehensive immigration reform will struggle to gain traction due to the predominantly white, conservative constituency of most House Republicans. This contrasts with the party's post-2012 efforts to address their perceived issues with Hispanic voters.

Rep. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) held a town meeting last week, during which every one of the 100 attendees argued against any immigration reform resembling the Senate-passed bill. Cotton expressed concern that even smaller, seemingly necessary reforms, such as a better tracking system for individuals in the country on visas, could become a "Trojan horse" for a larger package that prioritizes legalization over enforcement.

The momentum for a deal this Congress appears to be shifting against Republican and Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill. Sen. Marco Rubio, a key proponent of the immigration reform bill, was able to secure the support of only 13 fellow Republican senators. This week, the editors of the National Review and Weekly Standard published a joint editorial in opposition to the bill, and private GOP headcounts show only a small fraction of House Republicans would ever vote for anything resembling the Senate deal.

Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa), a leading voice in the House's anti-immigration reform caucus, held a meeting on Monday to argue against the bipartisan bill. King contends that the Senate's immigration plan would benefit "elites who want cheap labor, Democratic power brokers, and those who hire illegal labor." He asserts that the bill would harm the Republican Party, a sentiment that is widely shared among House Republicans.

The article does not provide information on the potential impact of this development on the broader immigration debate or the political landscape. It is unavailable whether other political parties or interest groups have expressed support for the piecemeal approach or the potential for further immigration reform legislation in the future.

Title: Conservatives Face Challenge in Revitalizing Family and Civic Institutions Outside of Government

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2018 midterm elections, the Republican Party has been confronted with a stark reality: the political influence of President Trump is subject to the laws of political gravity. Democrats made significant gains in the House, maintained their Senate losses, and won down-ballot races, indicating a shift in voter preferences, particularly among suburban voters.

Some Republican pundits are advocating for a new, policy-based form of Trumpism, focusing on addressing the bifurcation of opportunity based on education and the breakdown of the nuclear family. This approach is rooted in the work of conservative thinkers such as Ross Douthat, Reihan Salam, and Oren Cass, who argue for the importance of strong families and communities in promoting long-term prosperity.

Douthat, Salam, and Cass propose a combination of economic policies, such as regulatory reform and wage subsidies, to revitalize the labor market and strengthen families and communities. However, a fundamental question arises: is government intervention truly likely to lead to the revitalization of family and community? Or must the preconditions for economic thriving be in place first?

This question challenges the viability of political conservatism in the face of government-led intervention aimed at shoring up fundamental institutions. The limiting principle of such intervention is a matter of debate, with some suggesting that government intervention could go too far, as exemplified by Tucker Carlson's proposal to ban automatic driving due to potential job loss among blue-collar workers.

Constitutional philosophy suggests that the institutions that hold up a safe, stable, culturally solid, and community-oriented world cannot be created by government. Churches do not thrive because of government subsidies, and families do not thrive because of government subsidies. Instead, these institutions are built on shared values, not material incentives.

Therefore, the fundamental challenge for conservatism today is to convince Americans to re-engage with family and civic associations outside of government, as these institutions cannot effectuate such re-engagement themselves. Conservatives can focus on removing governmental disincentives toward family and community and work, as well as cultural disincentives, such as the left's focus on breaking down family structure, disdain for stay-at-home mothers, disparagement of religious Americans, and distaste for American cultural solidarity.

However, the moment conservatives try to build Trumpism around a policy of government do-gooderism, they risk exacerbating the very problems they seek to alleviate. Americans value family and community because they have values, not because family and community must be made more economically valuable. If we rely on material incentives to prop up our most vital social institutions, those institutions are likely to continue disintegrating—and to take the economic freedom we hope to promote in the end with them.

Title: Harvey Weinstein Released on $1 Million Bail, Faces Rape and Sex Charges

Article:

Disgraced film producer Harvey Weinstein has been released on a $1 million bail following his arraignment on Friday. He was charged in Manhattan court with rape, criminal sex act, and other sex-related charges stemming from encounters with two women. Weinstein surrendered to the New York Police Department and Manhattan District Attorney's office on Friday morning.

At the arraignment, Weinstein agreed to wear an electronic monitoring device, paid for at his own expense. He is only allowed to travel in New York state and Connecticut. If he desires to go to another state, he must seek permission. Weinstein has received a grand jury notice and by May 30 will decide whether to testify or not.

The victim has received an order of protection and will be identified to the court, prosecution, and defense but will otherwise remain anonymous. Weinstein turned himself in at NYPD's 1st Precinct around 7:30 a.m. ET, carrying books, including "Something Wonderful: Rodgers and Hammerstein's Broadway Revolution" and "Elia Kazan about the stage and film director." Weinstein was noticeably struggling to walk.

Weinstein left the station before 9 a.m. in handcuffs, headed to court for his arraignment. As Weinstein headed into the courthouse, AP reports he was questioned by the crowd. "You sorry, Harvey?" someone shouted. The question "What can you say?" was also raised. In reply, Weinstein softly shook his head and answered "No."

Weinstein has consistently denied any allegations of non-consensual sex. His lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said Friday that he would fight to get the charges dismissed, saying they are factually unsupported and constitutionally flawed. Brafman issued a statement to ███ following Friday's proceedings, reiterating his client's stance. "Mr. Weinstein has always maintained that he has never engaged in non-consensual sexual behavior with anyone. Nothing about today's proceedings changes Mr. Weinstein's position. He has entered a plea of not guilty and fully expects to be exonerated."

Police expressed their gratitude to Weinstein's accusers. "The NYPD thanks these brave survivors for their courage to come forward and seek justice," a statement read. "The arrest and ensuing charges are the result of a joint investigation between the NYPD and the Manhattan District Attorney’s Office."

Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. also thanked Weinstein's claimants for their courage in a statement shared to Twitter on Friday. "Thank you to the brave survivors who have come forward, our office’s tireless prosecutors, and our dedicated partners at @NYPDNews," he shared before urging those with additional accounts or information to reach out.

When discussing the accusations facing his client, Brafman reminded reporters Friday his job isn't "to defend behavior; my job is to defend something that is criminal behavior."

"Mr. Weinstein did not invent the casting couch in Hollywood," he declared, "and to the extent that there is bad behavior in that industry, that is not what this is about. Bad behavior is not on trial in this case; it’s only if you intentionally committed a criminal act, and Mr. Weinstein vigorously denies that."

Friday's events come nearly eight months after The New York Times exposed three decades of alleged sexual misconduct ranging from harassment to rape from accusers including Ashley Judd, Rose McGowan, Salma Hayek, Lupita Nyong'o, and Gwyneth Paltrow. Weinstein has been under investigation for months in New York, Los Angeles, and London.

Several of the actresses who have made allegations against Weinstein, including McGowan and Annabella Sciorra, applauded his impending arrest on social media. "The justice system has been something very elusive," McGowan said. "I hope in this case it works. Because it’s all true. None of this was consensual."

Weinstein became a larger-than-life figure in Hollywood as co-founder of the "mini-major" studios Miramax (started in 1979) and The Weinstein Company (2005), producing and distributing awards-friendly films such as Oscar best-picture winners The Artist and The King's Speech. The domineering studio head amassed tremendous influence with his strong personality, his ability to identify and champion artistic projects, and his track record of Oscar success—the latter cemented when Weinstein's Shakespeare in Love was a shock best-picture winner over Steven Spielberg's heavily favored Saving Private Ryan in 1999.

The Weinstein scandal has triggered a cascade of accusations against Kevin Spacey, Louis C.K., Louis Rose, Matt Lauer, and Morgan Freeman, among others.

Title: Mike Huckabee Affirms Presidential Ambitions, Rejects Speculation of Withdrawal for Jeb Bush or Others

Article:

Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee has declared that he will not withdraw from a potential 2016 presidential run due to the participation of other candidates, including his friend and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush. In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Huckabee stated, "I like Jeb. We're good friends. He'll be a very formidable candidate. But if I run for president... it's not going to be because someone else did or did not."

Huckabee, who finished second in the Republican presidential nomination race in 2008, winning the Iowa caucus and several Southern primaries, expects to make a formal declaration about his intentions for the presidential race this spring. He recently stepped down from his political talk show "Huckabee" on the Fox News Channel to explore another presidential run.

In response to those who have discouraged 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney from making another run for the White House, Huckabee argued, "It's wide open. Anyone could be a contender." He emphasized the unpredictable nature of politics, stating, "On any given day your campaign can implode for something that happens inadvertently or intentionally."

Huckabee concluded, "So you never say that someone is not a contender, that they can't make it. I hear that all the time about a lot of different people. Nobody knows. Voters will make that decision, and that's the way it ought to be."

Title: Police Accountability, Reform, and Militarization: A Look at the Challenges and Solutions

Article:

In the aftermath of George Floyd's death at the hands of a police officer, the nation is once again grappling with issues of police brutality and accountability. Protests, tear gas, mass arrests, and curfews have become common sights in cities across the country.

At ███, we have covered numerous stories about the police since our founding in 2014, including the challenges of police reform and the militarization of police departments. The following is a summary of some of the key issues and potential solutions that have emerged from our reporting.

When a police officer is accused of misconduct or brutality, the process varies depending on the jurisdiction. In more than a dozen states, police officers enjoy their own Bill of Rights, which can mean that an officer under investigation does not have to answer questions for up to 10 days, and the department must continue to pay their salary and benefits. The rules become less clear when it comes to joint task forces, where federal agencies like the U.S. Marshals recruit local police departments to track down fugitives or fight terrorism. In such cases, the local officers assigned to joint task forces may not have to follow their own department's rules, such as wearing a body camera.

Reforming troubled police departments is a complex issue with a long history. A deep dive into the Kerner Commission Report, which was aimed at prescribing solutions after the race riots of the 1960s, revealed the shortcomings of federal attempts at police reform. More recently, we explored the use of consent decrees, a tactic where the U.S. Department of Justice can sue local police departments to change through court-enforced reforms. Alternatively, a local department can voluntarily adopt federally recommended reforms. However, the results of these efforts often fall short, as demonstrated in Cincinnati, where the police department was celebrated for successful federal intervention, but residents in low-income and middle-class neighborhoods reported few changes.

Individual officers also face challenges when trying to change their departments' operations. One officer was fired for trying to de-escalate a fraught encounter and not reaching for his gun first.

To better understand the root causes of police violence, we spoke to a range of people who have immersed themselves in the issue. David Simon, creator of "The Wire," pointed to the drug war's role in changing policing in cities like Baltimore, where Freddie Gray was killed in police custody, sparking mass protests. Bryan Stevenson, author of "Just Mercy" and founder of the Equal Justice Initiative, explored the historic role of the police in enforcing white supremacy in America. We also spoke to those with searing personal encounters, such as Erica Garner, whose father, Eric Garner, died in Staten Island after a New York Police Department officer put him in a chokehold.

Another contributing factor to excessive use of force by police is the increasing militarization of many police departments. For decades, the Defense Department has been passing surplus military equipment to local law enforcement agencies for free and with little scrutiny. This equipment includes grenade launchers, machetes, and bayonets. Many of these military-grade weapons were deployed in Ferguson, where police used weapons of war against protesters. The Obama administration banned the program after the waves of protest following police tactics in Ferguson; President Donald Trump reinstated it.

Over the years, many police departments have explored options for crowd control during protests, including weapons labeled as "nonlethal" like bean bags and pepper balls, though they can inflict grievous harm. The militarization of police is not just a matter of equipment; in fact, as a Marshall Project story showed, nearly one-fifth of police officers have served in the military, where their training and experience can distort relations with the communities they serve.

To learn more about the reporting on policing in the days and weeks ahead, consider subscribing to our email newsletters.

Title: NBC's Chuck Todd Criticizes Involvement of Former Political Operatives in News Executive Roles

Article:

In an interview with the conservative news site Breitbart, NBC's "Meet the Press" host Chuck Todd criticized the involvement of former political operatives in news executive roles, seemingly taking a veiled shot at Fox News chief Roger Ailes, ABC's George Stephanopoulos, and potentially himself.

During the interview, Todd stated, "Look, it doesn't help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form." The news executive in question is likely Ailes, who was a media consultant for Republican presidents Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, and George H.W. Bush. However, Todd himself served as a staffer on Democratic Senator Tom Harkin's 1992 presidential bid, and Stephanopoulos, the host of ABC's "This Week" and Todd's direct competitor on Sunday mornings, was a senior advisor to Democratic president Bill Clinton.

In the Breitbart interview, John Nolte told Todd that conservatives view the media as a whole as a branch of the Democratic Party out to annihilate them. Todd responded, "That's a mindset I can't do anything about. There are some practitioners in the media that view things as a campaign. Look, it doesn't help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form. It's all winning and losing."

Todd's decision to speak to Breitbart, an aggressively conservative news and opinion site, reflects an effort to broaden the show's outreach. "This is a step in the rehabilitation of my business," Todd said at the top of the interview. "Talk to the critics. Talk to the skeptics."

Todd's predecessor, David Gregory, had not been as eager to engage with conservative critics. In an interview with The Huffington Post earlier this year, he stated, "I just made a decision... There are haters out there. I'm not going to engage those people, because they're not looking to have a dialogue with me over Twitter."

Chuck Todd's ratings have been declining since he took over the show, with ratings dropping each week.

Title: Debate on Tax Revenue Sources for Democrats Erupted by AOC's Proposal

Article:

The tax proposal by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has ignited a debate among Democrats regarding the source of additional government revenue. While there is general consensus on the need for new revenue due to the growing federal budget deficit, the specific methods for raising funds remain contentious.

Ocasio-Cortez, the 29-year-old Democratic representative from the Bronx, has garnered headlines with her suggestion of tax rates as high as 70 percent to finance the "Green New Deal." However, it is crucial to clarify that Ocasio-Cortez did not propose taking 70 percent of anyone's income. Instead, she suggested applying the rate only to earnings beyond $10 million, meaning those affected would pay a much lower share of their income overall.

Historically, top tax rates exceeding 90 percent were in place during the 1950s. However, through deductions and tax avoidance, "taxes on the rich were not that much higher" then, according to the conservative Tax Foundation. The top rate remained 70 percent as late as 1981, the first year of Ronald Reagan's presidency. Despite the high top rate, the most affluent 1 percent paid a far lower average rate of 30.5 percent, according to a Tax Policy Center analysis.

In the 2016 presidential campaign, self-described socialist Sen. Bernie Sanders proposed a 54.2 percent tax for incomes above $10 million, while Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton suggested 43.6 percent for those earning above $5 million.

The new House Democratic majority has avoided the tax issue in its initial legislative agenda. However, the party's growing field of 2020 presidential candidates will not have that luxury.

The only formally declared Democratic candidate, former Rep. John Delaney of Maryland, wants to finance infrastructure projects by raising the recently enacted 21 percent top corporate rate to 25 percent. Sen. Kamala Harris of California has proposed curbing income inequality by rolling back all the Trump tax cuts in favor of expanded tax credits for modest earners.

When asked about fair tax shares in the economy, Sen. Elizabeth Warren declined to specify her preferred rates but expressed a need for new revenue. Betsey Stevenson, a former economic adviser to President Barack Obama, favors other targets, such as eliminating the "step-up" valuation that lets some inherited assets avoid capital gains taxes and capping tax deductions for the wealthy.

The amount of revenue Democrats need depends on the new programs they ultimately pursue. Analysts have priced Sen. Bernie Sanders' "Medicare for All" plan at $32 trillion, while Sen. Sherrod Brown backs a far less expensive Medicare "buy-in" for 55 and over.

Republican resistance casts doubts on the prospects for new taxes in any event. Former Fed chairman Alan Greenspan warns a 70 percent top income tax rate would prove a "terrible mistake" by dampening economic activity.

As the party of limited government, the GOP opposes most new programs, regardless of how they're funded. With deficits ballooning following their tax cuts, GOP leaders suggest curbing the massive Social Security and Medicare programs. However, the demographic tidal wave of baby boomer retirements will swamp any politically feasible "entitlement reform."

Douglas Holtz-Eakin, who advised President George W. Bush, agrees that governments led by either party will eventually need more revenue. He prefers taxing consumption instead of income on economic grounds, though any new taxes will strain America's polarized political system.

"We will need all the economic growth we can get, we need to control spending, and we need to raise revenue," Holtz-Eakin said, recounting advice he recently gave House Republicans. "It's going to be ugly."

Title: Texas-Led Coalition of 26 States Challenges President Obama's Executive Amnesty

Article:

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton announced on Monday that Nevada and Tennessee have joined the state's legal challenge of President Barack Obama's executive amnesty, bringing the total number of states involved in the lawsuit to 26.

In a statement, Attorney General Paxton said, "Texas is proud to lead a coalition that now includes a majority of the United States standing up against the President's rogue actions." He further stated, "The momentum against the President's lawlessness continues to build with Tennessee and Nevada joining the effort to protect our states from the economic and public safety implications of illegal amnesty."

U.S. District Judge Andrew Hanen heard oral arguments in the case on January 15th, where Texas argued that Obama's amnesty would create a new wave of illegal immigration that would burden state governments. Texas attorney Andrew Oldham told Judge Hanen, "This is the second time they've done it in two years. Maybe they'll do it again in 2016."

Obama's lawyer, Kathleen Hartnett, disputed that claim, insisting that new arrivals will not come "on the expectation of receiving deferred action because they will be turned away." She added, "His policy only applies to people who have been here since 2012."

Judge Hanen is not likely to buy that administration argument. In a 2013 case, Hanen predicted that Obama's lax border enforcement policies would lead to a wave of illegal immigration. This prediction was confirmed in 2014.

Texas and the other 25 states are asking Judge Hanen to issue an injunction that would stop Obama from granting work permits before the program begins in May. If Obama's amnesty does stand, it will reportedly cost taxpayers billions in tax credits every year.

The full list of 26 states suing Obama over his executive amnesty includes: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Maine, Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, West Virginia, Wisconsin.

Title: Joey Gibson's Freedom Rally in San Francisco Canceled Due to Safety Concerns

Article:

Joey Gibson, leader of the group Patriot Prayer, announced the cancellation of his planned peaceful rally at Crissy Field in San Francisco on Saturday, citing safety concerns following opposition from various groups, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, local Democrats, and the antifa movement.

During a press conference on Facebook Live, Mr. Gibson stated, "It was the best thing to do for the city because the way it was set up is that a lot of innocent people were going to get hurt." He further explained that the event would have resulted in a "huge riot" due to the presence of radical activists from antifa and By Any Means Necessary.

A separate right-of-center event scheduled for Sunday in Berkeley, titled "No to Marxism in America," was also canceled by organizers due to fears of violence.

San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee urged residents to attend a rally at Civic Center Plaza instead, where thousands gathered for a "unite against hate" march, carrying anti-Trump signs and a large rainbow banner that read, "Rise and Resist!"

At a Saturday press conference, Mr. Lee commended the counterprotesters, stating, "The face of love and compassion dominated over hate speech and inciting of violence."

Ms. Pelosi had called on the National Park Service to reconsider Patriot Prayer's permit, describing the event as a "white supremacist rally." In response, Ms. Pelosi stated, "Reason has prevailed because the people of San Francisco have demonstrated our determination to protect the freedom of peaceful expression as well as public safety."

However, Mr. Gibson accused Ms. Pelosi and Mayor Ed Lee of stoking unrest by labeling the event as a white supremacy rally, despite most of the scheduled speakers not being white and Mr. Gibson himself being half-Asian. He also accused Democrats of hypocrisy regarding protester violence, stating, "You have a mayor who says that we’re hateful, we’re violent...he doesn’t mention one word about antifa."

The rally, billed as a "day of freedom, spirituality, unity, peace, and patriotism," was intended to exclude extremists, including Nazis, antifa, the Ku Klux Klan, and white nationalists, according to Mr. Gibson's assurances on Facebook. Despite these precautions, Mr. Gibson claimed he was menaced by antifa and By Any Means Necessary activists who followed the Patriot Prayer organizers and used Twitter to announce their whereabouts.

Mr. Gibson, who lives in Vancouver, Washington, started Patriot Prayer earlier this year to support President Trump but has since focused on fighting extremism on both the left and the right to promote peace and unity. His rallies in Portland and Seattle have attracted members of white-nationalist groups like Identity Evropa, which Mr. Gibson said he has tried to discourage.

The Southern Poverty Law Center, which does not list Patriot Prayer as a hate group, has criticized the rallies for attracting the "alt-right" while crediting Mr. Gibson for speaking out against white supremacists and neo-Nazis. Mr. Gibson concluded, "At the end of the day, I just want a small government, and then there will be no tyrants. And we will be free people in a free society who can respect one another."

Title: Harvard's Admissions Practices Under Scrutiny for Alleged Discrimination Against Asian Americans

Article:

In a controversial revelation, Harvard University, one of the most prestigious colleges in the United States, is under investigation for allegedly discriminating against Asian American applicants. The target group is not blacks or Jews, as it was in previous years, but Asian Americans.

After millions of dollars in legal fees, millions of records examined, and hundreds of hours of depositions and testimony, Harvard's once opaque admissions policies have been laid bare. The institution rates student applicants in three main ways: academic performance, extra-curricular achievements, and "personal qualities." While these criteria might seem fair if applied objectively, they are not.

Asian American applicants consistently score higher in the first two criteria – academics and extra-curricular activities, which can be objectively assessed – than white students, Latinos, and African Americans. However, Harvard justifies its Asian American quota with the help of the third criterion – "personal qualities," which include vague and largely subjective factors like "likability," "maturity," "integrity," and "effervescence."

According to Harvard's own internal reports, Asian American applicants are systematically marked much lower on this personality scale by Harvard admissions officers who almost never meet or interview applicants. Interestingly, the personality ratings given to Asian students by Harvard's own alumni interviewers, who actually meet the applicants in person, are vastly different. Alumni interviewers score Asian applicants as high as whites.

In other words, Harvard artificially and fraudulently downgrades Asians on "personality" to get the results it wants. And what Harvard wants is to suppress the number of Asian Americans admitted.

Based on the data that Harvard was forced to turn over, economist Peter Arcidiacono of Duke University concluded that with the same application profile in terms of test scores, extracurricular activities, and personality factors, an Asian American male applicant would only have a 25% chance of admission – versus 32% if white, 77% if Hispanic, and 95% if black.

In 2013, Asian Americans made up 19% of the incoming freshmen class. According to Harvard's own Office of Institutional Research, if the personality factors had not been rigged, that percentage would have been 43%.

Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 guarantees that "No person in the United States shall, on the ground of race, color or national origin, be excluded from participation in, or be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any program or activity receiving federal financial assistance."

Each year, Harvard takes hundreds of millions of dollars from the federal government. In Grutter v. Bollinger, the Supreme Court upheld the University of Michigan Law School's affirmative action policies, deciding that race could be used as a "plus factor" to achieve diversity, but never as a quota. Yet, by placing strict limits on the percentage of Asian American applicants it will admit, racial quotas are exactly what Harvard is using.

One strongly suspects this quota system is not limited to Harvard. In the last ten years, Asian American students have been limited to an 18-22% presence across the Ivy League. Or maybe that's just a coincidence.

Writing for the majority in Grutter v. Bollinger in 2003, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote that the Court "expects that 25 years from now, the use of racial preferences will no longer be necessary to further the interest approved today." With less than a decade to go, the Ivy League shows no indication that it's giving up on those racial preferences. Instead, these colleges have doubled down. Objective standards regarding admissions continue to be increasingly disfavored as the illegal goal of racial balancing is advanced.

This racial balancing is justified by the left's desire to achieve "racial diversity" – its insistence on seeing every person only through the prism of race, as if the most important thing any of us has to offer is the color of our skin.

Not long ago, that was called "racism." It's still called racism.

It needs to end, once and for all – for the sake of deserving Asian American students, for the sake of Harvard's own integrity, and for the sake of the American principle that the rules must be the same for everyone.

Chief Justice of the Supreme Court John Roberts said it best: "The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race."

It's time we did just that. I'm Lee Cheng, of the Asian American Legal Foundation, for ███.

Title: A Case for Mitt Romney's 2016 Presidential Bid: A Retrospective Analysis of the 2012 Election

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2012 presidential election, many believe that Mitt Romney's loss marked the end of his political career. However, one individual argues that Romney could potentially mount a successful comeback in 2016, citing three major moments from the 2012 election and a few philosophical adjustments.

The first point of contention is the response to Hurricane Sandy. The individual suggests that Romney should have visited areas affected by the storm, such as New York, Staten Island, Long Island, and New Jersey, to survey the damage, provide aid, and deliver a major policy speech on rebuilding the nation's infrastructure. This, they argue, would have showcased Romney's leadership and empathy, potentially turning the tide of the election.

The second point revolves around the second presidential debate, during which Romney was criticized for his response to the Benghazi attack. The individual contends that Romney should have seized the opportunity to challenge President Obama's account of the events, rather than appearing defensive.

The third point is the perceived tone-deafness of the Republican Party and its candidates, particularly in relation to cultural issues such as global warming, the environment, and alternative energy. The individual argues that Romney, if advised correctly and embracing the cultural zeitgeist, could emerge as a Reagan-like figure.

It is important to note that this article represents the opinion of one individual and does not necessarily reflect the views of all who supported Mitt Romney or the Republican Party during the 2012 election. The article does not provide any quantitative data or polling information to support its claims, and it is unclear whether these suggestions would have significantly altered the outcome of the 2012 election.

-End of Article-

Title: Wisconsin Governor Proposes Alternative to ObamaCare, Seeks Federal Approval

Article:

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has proposed a plan aimed at providing an alternative to the problems associated with ObamaCare. The plan, if approved, would allow Wisconsin's poor and uninsured individuals to purchase health coverage directly from insurers, bypassing the online "exchange" established by the Affordable Care Act (ACA).

The proposal, which has garnered support in the Wisconsin state house, was passed by the assembly with a majority, with six Democrats crossing party lines in support. However, the plan requires the approval of the Obama administration before it can take effect.

Governor Walker stated, "If they [the Obama administration] don't approve this, this is ultimately exposing that this is not really about access and this is not about affordability. It's about government playing a heavier hand in these kinds of decisions."

President Obama has criticized Republicans for complaining about health care issues without offering solutions. In a White House speech on Dec. 3, he said, "They [Republicans] haven't presented an alternative. If you ask many of the opponents of this law what exactly they'd do differently, their answer seems to be, well, let's go back to the way things used to be."

However, a number of Republican politicians have proposed alternatives to the ACA, including Representative Tom Price of Georgia, Senator Tom Price of Georgia, and Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin. These Republican plans are generally consumer-driven, according to Ed Haislmaier of The Heritage Group, a conservative think tank.

"The patient makes choices," says Haislmaier, contrasting the consumer-driven plan with a government-driven plan in which a third party buys coverage to fit the needs of the consumer.

Supporters of the president's plan argue that conservative counter-proposals lack the reach of the ACA. Economist Jonathan Gruber stated, "I've yet to hear a Republican alternative which covers nearly as many uninsured or even half as many uninsured, or offers evidence-based solutions to the health care cost crisis."

Title: House Judiciary Committee to Vote on Subpoenas for Mueller Report and Witnesses

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee has announced plans to vote on subpoenas this week, seeking the full, unredacted Russia report from Special Counsel Robert Mueller and related documents from several of President Donald Trump's former top advisers. The move comes as Democrats and the Justice Department continue to dispute the level of access to the report.

The committee, chaired by Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.), will vote on subpoenas on Wednesday. The vote would not automatically issue subpoenas but authorize Nadler to send them if he decides to do so.

Nadler stated, "As I have made clear, Congress requires the full and complete special counsel report, without redactions, as well as access to the underlying evidence." He added, "Attorney General Barr has thus far indicated he will not meet the April 2 deadline set by myself and five other committee chairs, and refused to work with us to provide the full report, without redactions, to Congress."

The committee will also authorize subpoenas related to a number of President Trump's former top advisers, including Steve Bannon, Hope Hicks, Reince Priebus, Donald McGahn, and Ann Donaldson. These individuals were key witnesses in Mueller's probe of possible obstruction of justice and were sent document requests by the Judiciary panel last month.

Nadler expressed concern about reports that documents relevant to Mueller's investigation "were sent outside the White House," potentially waiving executive privilege rights that would block document production. He stated, "To this end, I have asked the committee to authorize me to issue subpoenas, if necessary, to compel the production of documents and testimony."

Nadler sent requests to 81 people connected to Trump's political and personal dealings as he launched a wide-ranging investigation into possible obstruction of justice, public corruption, and abuses of power.

Attorney General William Barr, in a letter on Friday, stated that he is scrubbing the report to avoid disclosing any grand jury information or classified material, in addition to portions of the report that pertain to ongoing investigations or that "would unduly infringe on the personal privacy and reputational interests of peripheral third parties."

Democrats say they want all of that information, even if some of it cannot be disclosed to the public. They are citing precedents from previous investigations involving presidents and information disclosed about the Russia investigation to Republicans last year when they held the House majority.

If the committee does issue subpoenas, the path forward is uncertain. If the administration decides to fight, lawmakers could ask federal courts to step in and enforce a subpoena—a fight that could, in theory, reach the Supreme Court. Generally, such disputes are instead resolved through negotiations.

The Democrats could also formally ask Mueller to send the Judiciary committee evidence that could be used in possible impeachment proceedings against Trump. However, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, backed by the majority of her caucus, has said she is not currently supportive of impeachment.

Barr wrote in his summary that the special counsel did not find that Trump's campaign "conspired or coordinated" with the Russian government to influence the 2016 presidential election. He also stated that Mueller reached no conclusion on whether Trump obstructed the federal investigation, instead setting out "evidence on both sides" of the question.

Barr himself went further than Mueller in his summary letter, declaring that Mueller's evidence was insufficient to prove in court that Trump had committed obstruction of justice to hamper the probe.

Democrats say they want to know much more about both conclusions and they want to see the evidence unfiltered by Barr. Georgia Rep. Doug Collins, the top Republican on the Judiciary committee, stated, "Judiciary Democrats have escalated from setting arbitrary deadlines to demanding unredacted material that Congress does not, in truth, require and that the law does not allow to be shared outside the Justice Department."

Title: Republican Presidential Debate to Take Place Tonight in Manchester, New Hampshire

Article:

The next Republican presidential debate is scheduled for tonight at St. Anselm's College Institute of Politics in Manchester, New Hampshire. The debate will be broadcast on ABC, with coverage beginning at 8 pm Eastern. A live stream of the event can be viewed online at ABCNews.go.com.

After skipping the last GOP debate and losing the Iowa caucuses, Donald Trump has announced his attendance at this debate. Joining Trump will be Iowa caucus winner Ted Cruz and Iowa "media winner" Marco Rubio, whose competitive performance in the caucuses has boosted his chances of winning the nomination in the eyes of political elites. Ben Carson, who finished fourth in Iowa and whose campaign has been in decline for months, will also be present, although his campaign appears to be nearing its end.

In addition to these candidates, there are three others—Jeb Bush, John Kasich, and Chris Christie—who are hoping for a strong performance in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary to keep their campaigns alive. Bush, Kasich, and Christie, who are all considered establishment-friendly candidates, are viewed as rivals to Rubio, who performed better than them in Iowa. Expect these candidates to make a final effort to undermine Rubio during tonight's debate.

Conversely, the debate offers Rubio a significant opportunity to outshine his establishment rivals before the New Hampshire primary. If Rubio outperforms Bush, Kasich, and Christie in the Granite State, they are likely to exit the race soon, paving the way for Rubio to emerge as the mainstream Republican alternative to Trump and Cruz. If Rubio falters in New Hampshire, however, the race may remain uncertain for a while longer.

Since the GOP field has narrowed, there will be no undercard debate for candidates who are not polling as well this time around. Unfortunately, Carly Fiorina missed ABC's polling cutoff to qualify for this debate, making her and former Virginia governor Jim Gilmore the two remaining candidates who will be excluded.

Title: The Impact of Individual Voting in the U.S. Electoral College System

Article:

In a recent encounter, an American expressed support for Hillary Clinton for president despite his libertarian leanings. This individual, residing in South Carolina, acknowledged that his vote would not significantly impact the presidential race outcome due to the U.S. Electoral College system.

The Electoral College, a unique aspect of the American electoral system, determines the president based on a state-by-state tally of electoral votes rather than a national popular vote. In the closest state presidential election of the last half-century, New Mexico in 2000, the final margin for Al Gore was 366 votes, and this did not swing the national prize.

Individual influence on state-level electoral outcomes is highly unlikely. In the most recent election forecast, FiveThirtyEight estimates that Florida, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin have the highest chances of determining the election, with Florida having a 17.9% chance, followed by Ohio and Pennsylvania with 11.5% each, Michigan at 8.7%, and Wisconsin at 6.2%. When accounting for North Carolina, Virginia, Colorado, Minnesota, Georgia, Nevada, and Iowa, all with an estimated 2% chance or less, the probability that an individual's vote will determine the outcome is virtually zero.

Living in a red or blue state, where one's vote will not swing the election, removes one from the loop. This reality is not lost on the general public, which tends to vote for third parties more often in one-party states. Citizens recognize that they are not casting the deciding national vote but are fulfilling their patriotic duty and taking pride in exercising their right to vote.

The consequence of individual presidential votes is so unlikely that Americans invest less in researching their choice than the effort they put into selecting a smartphone data plan or their next Pokémon Go venue. This phenomenon is known as "rational ignorance."

Voting third party is often perceived as "throwing your vote away." However, living in a non-swing state can be seen as throwing one's vote away. One tactic to recapture some modicum of vote value is to pad the total for an upstart candidate. Additionally, supporting a third party can help put the system on notice that the Big Two political party choices are being rejected.

In this year's campaign, the presidential choices from the major parties are highly undesirable for some voters. Voting for a third party, such as the Libertarian Party, with an exceedingly slim chance of victory, can be the least complicated choice for those who feel this way. This allows voters to exercise their conscience without taking responsibility for the outcome.

Title: Trump and Pence Officially Announce Vice Presidential Partnership in New York

Article:

In a whirlwind 48-hour period, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump and his newly-announced vice presidential pick, Indiana Governor Mike Pence, shared the spotlight in a joint appearance at the Hilton hotel in midtown Manhattan on Saturday. The event, which was initially scheduled for a rollout of Trump's vice presidential pick, was ultimately unceremoniously announced on Twitter.

Trump, in a 30-minute address, focused on criticizing Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and commenting on recent global conflicts, including the attempted military coup in Turkey. He praised the Turks, stating, "Great people, amazing people. We wish them well. A lot of anguish last night, but hopefully, it'll all work out."

The event, which took place in the same location where Ronald Reagan announced his 1980 presidential bid, was filled with pomp and circumstance, reminiscent of a man meeting a mail-order spouse. Trump stated, "Indiana Governor Mike Pence was my first choice," despite reportedly struggling to choose between an establishment-pleasing pick and two men with whom he has a better rapport.

Pence, a disciplined, conservative Republican with close-cropped white hair and a strong mandible, represented a stark contrast to Trump. He read from prepared remarks, with designated moments for applause, and addressed policy differences that have played out on social media.

Pence told the crowd that Trump had called him with the decision on Wednesday night, which runs counter to the narrative Trump presented to the media on Thursday, during which time he proclaimed he hadn't made his "final, final decision."

Their policy differences have been evident, with Pence tweeting his support of the Trans-Pacific Partnership in 2014, something that Trump is adamantly against. In December 2015, Pence tweeted, "Calls to ban Muslims from entering the U.S. are offensive and unconstitutional," in response to an initial proposal from Trump that the United States place a temporary ban on Muslims coming to the country after the attack in San Bernardino. However, during his first interview as Trump's vice presidential pick, Pence expressed support for Trump's call to temporarily suspend immigration from countries where terrorist influence and impact represent a threat to the United States.

The official union of the two men has had a somewhat rocky start, with Pence making a less-than-enthusiastic endorsement of Senator Ted Cruz ahead of the Indiana primary. Their policy differences have been evident on social media, with Pence tweeting his support of the Trans-Pacific Partnership in 2014, something that Trump is adamantly against. In December 2015, Pence tweeted, "Calls to ban Muslims from entering the U.S. are offensive and unconstitutional," in response to an initial proposal from Trump that the United States place a temporary ban on Muslims coming to the country after the attack in San Bernardino. However, during his first interview as Trump's vice presidential pick, Pence expressed support for Trump's call to temporarily suspend immigration from countries where terrorist influence and impact represent a threat to the United States.

Before the two men appear together once again at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland next week, the governor is returning to Zionsville, Indiana on Saturday for what is billed as a "Welcome Home Rally" according to the Trump campaign. "Please note that Mr. Trump will not be in attendance," the media advisory reads.

Reactions to the event were positive, with Trump's former advisor Roger Stone stating, "It was strong. A winning ticket!" Michael Caputo, an adviser who resigned from Trump's campaign last month, echoed Stone's remarks, stating, "Pence's speech was solid, exceptionally well-written and delivered expertly. I think he made perfectly clear what he can do for this ticket. His speech was a rousing call to arms for Republicans and a full-volume defense of Donald Trump. Mission accomplished."

Title: House Republicans Vote to Cancel Obama's Deportation Amnesties, Sparking Political Debate

Article:

In a highly charged political and constitutional debate, the House of Representatives voted Thursday to repeal President Barack Obama's deportation amnesties, a move that House Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, described as an attempt to rectify an executive overreach that undermines the rule of law and the Constitution.

During the debate, Boehner read 22 quotes from Obama denying he had the power to act unilaterally to halt deportations. The president exercised these powers last year when he announced an amnesty for over 4 million illegal immigrants, granting them temporary legal status and work permits.

"We do not take this action lightly, but there is simply no alternative," Boehner said from the House floor. "This is not a dispute between parties, or even branches of government. The president’s overreach is an affront to the rule of law and the Constitution itself."

Democrats, equally vigorous in their defense of Obama, accused Republicans of mean-spiritedness with a series of votes to roll back Obama's November amnesty and a smaller 2012 amnesty for Dreamers, or young adults brought to the U.S. as children.

"As a country, we’re better than this. Shame on you," said Rep. Linda T. Sanchez of California, chairwoman of the House Hispanic Caucus.

The vote to cancel the November amnesty was 237-190, with seven Republicans joining Democrats in opposition. The vote to cancel the amnesty for Dreamers was less popular, passing on a 218-209 vote with 26 Republicans joining all Democrats in opposition.

White House officials and immigrant rights advocates feared the votes could send illegal immigrants back into the shadows. However, Cecilia Munoz, Obama's domestic policy director, said the White House will make it clear to illegal immigrants that the president won't be deterred.

"At the end of the day, we are confident we are going to be implementing these executive actions," she said.

The courts could have the final say, as several challenges have been filed, including one in Texas, where 25 states have sued, arguing that they will have to fund billions of dollars worth of services to illegal immigrants if the president's plans are allowed to stand. A judge will hold a hearing Thursday on the states' request for an injunction.

Wednesday's fight was part of the debate on a bill to fund the Homeland Security Department and its immigration enforcement mission through the end of the fiscal year. That bill cleared the House on a 236-191 vote.

Obama has vowed to veto the bill because it includes provisions canceling his amnesties, and Senate Democratic leaders said they will lead a filibuster to prevent the bill from even reaching the president's desk. This would leave homeland security funding in limbo, with a Feb. 27 deadline looming.

Rank-and-file House Republicans acknowledged Wednesday that they aren't sure about the next step. "I don’t know that there is a Plan B," said Rep. Peter T. King, a New York Republican who voted for the amendment to cancel the November amnesty but against the plan to scrap the Dreamer amnesty. "It’s a work in progress."

Mr. King said there are six weeks to go before the deadline, which gives all sides a chance to work out an agreement. House and Senate Republicans will gather Thursday and Friday in Pennsylvania for a policy retreat, where immigration is bound to take up much of the discussion.

Rep. Mario Diaz-Balart, a Florida Republican who opposed both amnesty amendments, said the effort was a waste because Republicans don't have the votes to override a presidential veto.

"I wish that wasn’t the case. I wish President Obama was not in the White House. But that’s the reality," he said.

All sides said Wednesday's votes were momentous political statements and served as a signal of how much the immigration debate has changed over the past year. House Republicans entered their annual policy retreat last year with Boehner announcing principles for tackling immigration, including legalizing the Dreamers and figuring out a solution for the rest of the illegal immigrant population. This year, Boehner led the charge to cancel the amnesty for Dreamers and to step up enforcement of immigration laws.

Republicans said the moves should be seen as statements on the Constitution and separation of powers, not as attacks on immigrants. Democrats, however, said Hispanic voters won't see it that way.

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat who has been a staunch advocate for legalizing illegal immigrants, chided Republicans for backtracking on Boehner's stance to legalize Dreamers.

"One year later, you want to take away from 600,000 Dreamers their right to live in this country. What happened? What happened?" Mr. Gutierrez said.

He vowed to make sure Hispanic voters punish Republicans for the votes: "The fruits of your action today will ultimately anger and outrage and [ mobilize ] the immigrant community throughout this nation."

Democrats pointed to missives from the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, the AFL-CIO, and Hispanic rights groups who all blasted the amendments. The bishops said deporting illegal immigrants would fracture families, and labor unions said the moves were "anti-immigrant."

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows in August, Unemployment Rate Decreases Due to Labor Force Exit

Article:

The U.S. labor market showed a slowdown in job growth last month, with the economy adding 96,000 jobs in August, according to the Department of Labor's report released on Friday. This figure is a decrease from the 141,000 jobs added in July.

Simultaneously, the unemployment rate fell to 8.1%, down from 8.3% in July. Economists polled by CNNMoney had expected 120,000 jobs to be added in August, and the unemployment rate to remain unchanged.

The decrease in the unemployment rate is primarily attributed to 368,000 people leaving the workforce, many of whom are young people. The labor force participation rate, which represents the percentage of the working-age population that is either employed or actively seeking employment, fell to 63.5%. This is a 30-year low.

Joseph LaVorgna, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank, commented, "These numbers are not very strong. The job market is improving, but only gradually." At least 150,000 jobs need to be created each month to simply keep pace with the growing population.

In addition to the large number of people leaving the workforce, LaVorgna identified two other disappointing signs: the number of hours people worked remained flat, and wages were stagnant.

The Labor Department also revised down the job numbers for the two previous months, resulting in 41,000 fewer jobs created than originally reported.

Scott Brown, chief economist at the investment management firm Raymond James, stated, "We're not losing jobs."

Employment in restaurants and bars increased by 28,000, a sign that people may have more disposable income. Professional and technical service jobs rose by 27,000, and the health care industry added 17,000 jobs.

However, August was particularly hard on the manufacturing sector, which shed 15,000 jobs, and the government sector, which lost another 7,000 positions.

With two months remaining before the election, the jobs numbers have become a talking point for both campaigns. The weak numbers could also increase the chances that the Federal Reserve will take more action to boost the struggling economy.

The overall job market still has a long way to go to recover from the financial crisis. Three years after the recession ended, roughly 12.5 million Americans remain unemployed, and 40% of them have been so for six months or more.

Title: NLRB's Position on Small Bargaining Units Sparks Controversy

Article:

The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) has come under scrutiny for its stance on small bargaining units, with critics arguing that the Board's position could lead to an undue proliferation of such units. The controversy stems from a brief filed by Acting General Counsel Lafe Solomon to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, in which the NLRB stated that employers' concerns about the multiplicity of small bargaining units being detrimental to their operations are "irrelevant" under U.S. labor law.

The NLRB's position was presented in defense of the Obama Board's highly controversial decision, Specialty Healthcare, which overturned 76 years of Board law by allowing unions to represent bargaining units of as few as two or more employees doing the same job in the same location. The Board's decision has been criticized for threatening an undue proliferation of bargaining units, a concern that has been voiced by Congress, state labor boards, and other nations for years.

Since its inception in 1936, the NLRB has recognized the potential negative effects of an undue proliferation of bargaining units, citing unnecessary work stoppages and inconsistency with the long-term goals of collective bargaining. During Senate debate in 1974 on extending the Board's jurisdiction to cover non-profit health care institutions, Senator Harrison A. Williams (D-NJ) acknowledged the Board's efforts to avoid unnecessary proliferation.

In 1989, the NLRB proposed adopting a rule that would make a single facility unit presumptively appropriate, citing concerns over disproportionate, unjustified costs and undue proliferation of units. Congress has also consistently taken a position against undue proliferation, cautioning the NLRB against creating unnecessary work stoppages and threatening patient care in the non-profit health care industry.
