The NLRB's brief draws from Congress's caution the preposterous conclusion that a multiplicity of bargaining units in all other industries is an "irrelevant" consideration under U.S. labor law. This conclusion has been met with criticism, as it contradicts Congress's admonition to the Board and the long-standing position of the NLRB.

Labor boards in other jurisdictions, such as Illinois and Canada, also recognize the dangers of micro-unions and seek to avoid them. The Ontario Labor Relations Board (OLRB) has stated that the proliferation of bargaining units is not conducive to collective bargaining stability, citing unnecessary work stoppages, impeded employee movement between jobs, jurisdictional disputes, and the costs of negotiating and applying multiple collective agreements.

The political leadership at the NLRB reflects the priorities of the President who appointed it. The same Acting General Counsel whose office authored this brief filed a lawsuit to stop The Boeing Company from building new Dreamliner aircraft in a $1 billion plant in South Carolina. The same NLRB that authorized micro-unions has issued decisions that have radically changed Board law to benefit unions without regard for their impact on workers and businesses, creating uncertainty and contributing to a chill on job creation.

Title: President Obama Remains Optimistic on Public Perception of Obamacare Despite Unfavorable Polls

Article:

In an interview with The New York Times, President Barack Obama expressed his belief that public opinion on the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, will improve as the law is implemented. Despite polls indicating that the majority of Americans dislike the health care policy, Obama suggested that once individuals are required to purchase health insurance or face a penalty, they will come to appreciate the law.

However, the President acknowledged the challenges in changing public opinion, stating, "But until then, when we’re getting outspent four to one and people are just uncertain about what all this means for them, we’re going to continue to have some polls like that." He further explained, "Me just making more speeches explaining it in and of itself won’t do it. The test of this is going to be is it working. And if it works, it will be pretty darn popular."

Despite a new public relations push, the President's optimism regarding winning over public opinion appears to be unrealistic, according to the article. Obama suggested that as people sign up for health insurance and the law functions effectively, its popularity will increase. He stated, "Over the course of six months to a year, as people sign up, and it works, and lo and behold, the people who already have health insurance are not being impacted at all other than the fact that their insurance is more secure and they are getting free preventive care, and all the nightmare scenarios and the train wrecks and the'sky is falling' predictions that come from the other side do not happen, then health care will become more popular."

The President's comments suggest a disconnect with the public's perception of Obamacare, as many Americans are aware of the potential implications of the policy. The article concludes without offering a definitive prediction on the future popularity of the Affordable Care Act.

Title: ObamaCare Enrollment Data Shows High Number of Previously Insured Americans

Article:

The majority of the more than 2 million Americans who signed up for health insurance under ObamaCare through the end of December were already enrolled in employer-sponsored plans or had previously bought their own coverage, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. Early data from insurers, brokers, and consultants suggest that the marketplaces are popular with consumers who were previously covered elsewhere, raising questions about the law's effectiveness in expanding coverage to millions of uninsured Americans.

A survey by management consulting firm McKinsey & Co. found that only 11 percent of consumers who purchased new coverage under ObamaCare were previously uninsured. The survey was based on a sampling of 4,563 consumers between November and January.

HealthMarkets Inc., an insurance agency that signed up about 7,500 people in exchange plans, reported that 65 of its enrollees had prior coverage. Fifteen percent of enrollees had their individual plans canceled, and 40 percent switched over from previous individual plans.

David M. Cordani, chief executive of insurer Cigna, told The Wall Street Journal that one of the intents of the law was to address the uninsured problem in the country. However, some insurers said the early data on newly insured consumers is falling short of expectations.

Insurers in Michigan expected 400,000 of the state's 1.2 million uninsured people to join private plans this year, according to an analysis provided by Michigan-based Priority Health. As of the end of December, only 76,000 people had signed up, many of whom were previously covered, according to the report.

Geoff Bartsh, vice president for policy at Minneapolis-based Medica Health Plans, told The Journal, "I don't know we're growing the number of people with insurance here, so much as we're just adding complexity."

Federal health officials told The Journal they do not yet know the number of people who have signed up for coverage through the exchanges who had insurance when they enrolled. Consumers have until the end of March 31 to purchase plans under ObamaCare.

Aaron Albright, a spokesman for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said, "We are in the middle of a sustained six-month open-enrollment period, and we have seen a strong interest in the product overall across the range of demographics so far. We are ramping up outreach activities so that more Americans learn how they can now benefit from affordable health insurance."

Overall, adults ages 55-64 were the most heavily represented in the signups, accounting for 33 percent of the total. Nationwide, the premiums paid by people in that demographic do not fully cover their medical expenses. Some are in the waiting room for Medicare, which starts at age 65.

Young adults from 18 to 34 are only 24 percent of total enrollment, according to the Obama administration's first signup figures broken down for age, gender, and other details. Enrolling young and healthy people is important because they generally pay more into the system than they take out, subsidizing older adults.

Title: Democratic Lawmakers Call for Gun Control Measures Following School Shooting in Connecticut

Article:

In the aftermath of the school shootings in Connecticut, several Democratic lawmakers and Independent Senator Joe Lieberman have called for a renewed discussion on gun control and mental health policies. The recent spate of mass shootings has prompted these politicians to revisit the issue of gun control, which was a hot topic in the early 1990s when Congress enacted a 10-year ban on assault weapons. However, since the ban expired in 2004, few Americans have shown support for stricter gun laws, with politicians citing pressure from the powerful gun-rights lobby.

Gun-rights advocates have remained largely quiet on the issue since the shooting that killed 20 children aged 6 or 7. The gunman, Adam Lanza, was reportedly carrying an arsenal of ammunition and used a high-powered rifle similar to the military's M-16.

Senator Joe Manchin, a lifelong member of the National Rifle Association, has been the most prominent gun rights advocate to speak after the shooting. Manchin, a conservative West Virginia Democrat, has expressed support for gun policy discussions and moving toward action on gun regulation. He agrees with New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who has advocated banning the sale of assault weapons.

President Barack Obama did not specifically address gun control during a Sunday night service in Newtown, Connecticut, but vowed to engage citizens in an effort to prevent future tragedies. He also questioned whether the nation is prepared to accept such violence as the price of freedom.

Senator Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., stated that the nation could be at a "tipping point" for gun control, with the potential for significant action. He and other Democrats, as well as Senator Joe Lieberman, have proposed banning the sale of new assault weapons and making it more difficult for mentally ill individuals to obtain weapons. Lieberman also suggested creating a new commission to examine gun laws, the mental health system, and the role of violence in media.

Senator Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., has announced plans to introduce legislation next year to ban new assault weapons and large-capacity magazines. She believes that reinstating the ban, despite opposition from the National Rifle Association and similar groups, is achievable.

Mayor Bloomberg has suggested that President Obama could use executive powers to enforce existing gun laws and support legislation like Senator Feinstein's.

Gun-rights activists have been largely absent from the discussion since the shooting, with only Representative Louie Gohmert, R-Texas, appearing on various Sunday talk shows. Gohmert defended the sale of assault weapons and argued that violence is lower in cities with lax gun laws and higher in cities with stricter laws.

Gun-control advocates dispute this claim, citing a study by the California-based Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence that found that states with the strongest gun laws have some of the lowest gun death rates.

In response to the shooting, the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence has called for increased funding for mental health services, universal background checks, and a ban on high-capacity magazines and assault weapons. The organization also advocates for the implementation of red flag laws, which allow law enforcement to temporarily seize firearms from individuals who pose a threat to themselves or others.

Title: Synagogue Shooting in Southern California: One Dead, Several Injured

Article:

Washington, D.C. - A shooting at a synagogue near San Diego, California, on Saturday has left one dead and several injured. The attack occurred at the Chabad of Poway synagogue, and the suspect, 19-year-old John T. Earnest, has been arrested and charged with murder.

Rabbi Yisroel Goldstein, who was present during the attack, described the incident as "unfathomable." He stated, "I faced death face to face." The youngest victim was eight-year-old Noya Duhan, who had recently moved from southern Israel, where her village was subject to rocket attacks from Gaza. The lone fatality was 60-year-old Laurie Kaye. Friends say Kaye stepped in front of the rabbi to stop Earnest.

An off-duty border patrol agent, Oscar Stewart, described his actions during the incident. "He dropped his weapon and he ran out of the sanctuary," Stewart said, referring to Earnest. Stewart also opened fire as Earnest drove away. Police eventually arrested Earnest about a mile from the synagogue.

In an open letter posted online under Earnest's name, he expressed a desire to kill Jews and praised the gunmen accused in the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting and recent mosque attacks in New Zealand. Police also suspect Earnest's involvement in an arson attack at a California mosque.

President Trump called Rabbi Goldstein to offer his condolences and condemned the shooting at a weekend rally in Wisconsin. "We forcefully condemn the evil of anti-Semitism and hate which must be defeated," said Trump.

Following backlash, the New York Times retracted a controversial cartoon published in its international edition that was criticized for containing anti-Semitic tropes. The World Jewish Congress called out the New York Times for the cartoon, stating, "The @nytimes has crossed a red line today by publishing a cartoon infused with anti-Semitic tropes."

Michael Rydelnik, an expert on anti-Semitism at the Moody Bible Institute, commented on the rise of anti-Semitism, stating, "It's like a contagious disease that always under the surface and sometimes it spurs up into epidemic proportions and then sometimes it recedes."

Earnest is expected to face federal hate crime charges in addition to the murder charge.

Title: Pelosi-Trump Tensions Escalate as Shutdown Continues, Security Concerns Arise in Congressional Trip Cancellation

Article:

The ongoing government shutdown has led to a significant escalation in tensions between President Donald Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, as the debate over border security continues. Democrats are reportedly acknowledging that they have allowed the President to define the terms of the debate, and are now working to articulate their own position more effectively.

Representative Ro Khanna, a Democrat from California, stated, "People want to make sure that it's clear that the Democrats do stand for border security, and not allow the president to determine how we talk about it. We can't cave to his vision for a wall, because of everything that it represents, but we also want to show that we're for something."

The issue arose during a meeting of the Democratic caucus this week, where Speaker Pelosi briefed rank-and-file lawmakers about her latest criticism of Mr. Trump over the shutdown. This included a letter requesting that he delay or cancel his State of the Union address this month due to the security measures that would have to be provided by federal workers working without pay.

In response, Mr. Trump prevented Ms. Pelosi from using a military plane for her trip. His letter announcing this step also disclosed her itinerary, which was kept confidential for security reasons, particularly when it involves travel to war zones and high-ranking leaders like the speaker, who is second in line to the presidency.

Speaker Pelosi addressed reporters at the Capitol, stating, "You never give advance notice of going into a battle area — you just never do." She added, "The people around him, though, should have known that. That's very dangerous."

After Speaker Pelosi rushed to salvage the trip by making alternative travel arrangements to fly commercial, her plans were revealed to reporters by people close to Mr. Trump who had been briefed. By dawn on Friday, facing a heightened State Department threat assessment and amid concern that the administration's leaks had further compromised the safety of those involved, Ms. Pelosi canceled the trip.

A White House official on Friday denied the charge, stating that there was no way for Ms. Pelosi to have kept her trip a secret and that any suggestion of a leak "is a flat-out lie."

Title: Obama and Pena Nieto to Discuss Immigration and Security Issues

Article:

President Barack Obama will meet with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto on Tuesday at the White House to discuss immigration and border security. The meeting's agenda includes finding ways to prevent a surge of migrants crossing the U.S.-Mexico border and minimizing the number of people attempting the dangerous journey.

The discussion will focus on Obama's immigration action and border security. The senior administration official stated that illegal immigrants already in the U.S. who aid their relatives in crossing the border will not be eligible for Obama's new deportation amnesty. Mexican consulates will play a key role in informing Mexican immigrants about who qualifies and who does not qualify for the executive actions.

Homeland Security and State Department officials are collaborating on a campaign to deter would-be illegal immigrants. The surge of child immigrants in 2014, despite Obama's action, led to an increase in illegal immigration last year. Before 2014, illegal immigration had been on a downward trend due to the economic slump and tightened enforcement.

The administration official reported that the U.S. has made significant progress in strengthening the border with Mexico, with Pena Nieto being an "important partner" in helping to stem the flow of illegal child immigrants last year. The official also stated that the number of illegal immigrants entering the country is at a historical low, with the last comparable numbers seen in the 1970s.

In addition to immigration and security issues, the leaders are expected to discuss other matters, including the ongoing drug wars and the embattled Mexican president's handling of the massacre of 43 students in Iguala in September. Human Rights Watch has urged Obama to press Pena Nieto to investigate and prosecute abuses by Mexican security forces.

The White House stated that the two leaders will emphasize the importance of expanding dialogue and cooperation between the United States and Mexico on economic, security, and social issues, as well as underscoring the deep cultural ties and friendship between the two countries.

Title: Obama Demonstrates Skill in State of the Union Address, Yet Challenges Persist in Policy Implementation

Article:

President Barack Obama, in his latest State of the Union address, displayed a deft hand in his delivery, as he navigated a speech that was not dominated by a strong hand or a clear disadvantage. The speech came amidst a backdrop of low approval ratings, a dismal national mood, and a series of political and policy setbacks.

In the lead-up to the speech, the president's approval rating was underwater, and the national mood was decidedly downbeat. Macroeconomic improvements seemed to have little impact on personal levels, and the "right-direction-wrong-track" poll question was negative. The speech followed a string of negative headlines, including the failure of gun control measures in the Senate, the stalling of immigration changes in the House, and revelations of government surveillance and data-gathering, all culminating in the rocky rollout of Obamacare.

On the foreign front, potential breakthroughs with Iran were overshadowed by civil war in Syria, the quagmire in Afghanistan, and renewed unrest in Iraq, Egypt, and South Sudan. However, the embattled president was not without cards to play on this night. Congress, with an even deeper trough in its public approval, bore the brunt of the opprobrium for the federal government's partial shutdown in October.

Polls showed strong public support for a higher minimum wage, extended benefits for the long-term unemployed, and new rules on immigration - precisely the policy fronts on which the president planned to press forward against strong Republican resistance. In other words, neither party came to this year's State of the Union table in a dominant position, though there surely were partisans on either side who thought they did.

In the media, many stressed the long fall the president had taken since his emergence as an almost magical persona in the presidential primaries six years ago. Now the cable TV stories asked: "Is Obama already a lame duck?" Yet most were quick to add that the GOP was hobbled by miscues and was so riven with factional debate that the official party response to the State of the Union (by Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers) was followed by two separate Tea Party retorts (by Sens. Mike Lee and Rand Paul).

Given this downbeat context, and noting the chief executive's rather lackluster public performances in recent months, expectations for this State of the Union were not nearly so high as they were last year. Then, the president was fresh off his re-election, replete with vindication and seeking fresh worlds to conquer. That contrast may have helped the president, who seemed to draw a kind of inspiration Tuesday night from the uninspiring circumstances of the moment.

For purposes of his one-hour address to the nation, the president once again proved himself a gamer. He was brisk and confident, the master of a text that was in preparation since November. Having telegraphed for days his intended emphasis on "income inequality," the president tacked slightly by talking instead of "inequality of opportunity." This caught Rodgers slightly off-guard. Her text was already written to say that opportunity was the important thing, not income. It's a subtle point, perhaps, but one that afforded the president a slight edge (and demonstrated again why it is better to be the king than the king's critic).

Obama also managed to avoid a remarkable, even breathtaking array of issues one might have thought he had to deal with. He declared Obamacare to be more successful than most people think, and really, how high a bar is that? He also slid past the National Security Agency scandal that has cost him dearly on the left, and he made no mention of the deportations that have so angered immigrants' rights groups.

Yes, he touched the various constituency buttons on issues such as climate change and environmental damage. And yes, he once again gave primacy to revamping the immigration laws. But here, as elsewhere in the speech, he showed deference to House Speaker John Boehner. Obama seemed to suggest he was still willing to deal with the Republican from Ohio, especially if Boehner is able to keep his often-unruly troops in line. The president implicitly saluted Boehner for doing so on the federal budget compromise vote in December.

In sum, the Obama who delivered the speech was a nimble and adaptable player. It is the tragedy of this presidency that, to date, he has not been nearly as adept at the less-dramatic business of actually dealing with the Congress, the federal bureaucracy, the media, or any of other power centers - including foreign governments.

The president has, in recent weeks, added new staff in critical positions, including senior adviser John Podesta, who is a veteran of Bill Clinton's later years in the White House, and new faces in the legislative affairs office. There is some cause for hope that these new players will help the president extend his talent for presentation to produce more successes in policymaking.

Title: Dallas Police Officer Amber Guyger Found Guilty of Murder in Death of Botham Jean

Former Dallas police officer Amber Guyger was found guilty of murder on Tuesday, according to The Dallas Morning News. The verdict came in the trial for the death of Botham Jean, who was killed in his own apartment by Guyger on Sept. 6, 2018.

The facts of the case were largely uncontested, but the verdict hinged on the interpretation of the "Castle Doctrine," which allows for the use of deadly force when one is threatened in one's own home.

On the evening of Sept. 6, an off-duty Guyger, who was returning home after a long shift, mistakenly entered Jean's fourth-floor apartment, which was directly above her own. Finding the door unlocked, she shot the 26-year-old accountant, who was eating a bowl of ice cream, because she assumed he was an intruder.

Guyger was initially arrested on a manslaughter charge, which was later upgraded to a murder charge after review from the district attorney's office. She spoke publicly on the incident for the first time when she took the stand as the first witness for the defense last Friday.

"I was scared whoever was inside of my apartment was going to kill me, and I'm sorry," Guyger said as she cried, her voice shaking. "I have to live with that every single day." Her defense centered around her making a tragic but honest mistake.

The lead investigator on the case, Texas Ranger David Armstrong, testified that in interviewing 297 of the 349 residents at the South Side Flats apartment complex where Guyger and Jean lived, 46 had accidentally entered the wrong floor and put their key in the door. Of those 46, 38 were from the third and fourth floors.

Prosecutors argued that Guyger acted rashly in her use of deadly force by not calling for backup and that she missed several signs she was on the wrong floor because she was distracted by sexually explicit messages from a fellow police officer with whom she was having an extramarital affair.

After the verdict was announced, attorneys for the Jean family held an impromptu press conference to praise the decision. Attorney Ben Crump said 26-year-old Jean was a "near perfect" person, and that "it shouldn't take all of [Jean's credentials] for unarmed black and brown people in America to get justice."

"This verdict is for Trayvon Martin, it's for Michael Brown, it's for Sandra Bland, it's for Tamir Rice, it's for Eric Garner, it's for Antwon Rose, it's for Jemel Roberson, for EJ Bradford, for Stephon Clark, for Jeffrey Dennis, Genevieve Dawes, for Pamela Turner," Crump said.

Jean's mother rejoiced as cheers broke out outside the courtroom when the verdict was announced soon after 10:30 a.m. "God is good. Trust him," she said. Guyger remained standing until the jury left after announcing the decision, then fell into her chair.

Title: Dallas Jury Convicts Former Police Officer Amber Guyger of Murder in Shooting of Botham Jean

Article:

A Dallas jury has convicted former Dallas police officer Amber Guyger of murder after she mistakenly entered the wrong apartment and shot dead its rightful occupant, Botham Jean, on October 1, 2019. The verdict came despite a jury instruction that allowed Guyger to argue the "Castle Doctrine" could apply to her actions.

Under the Castle Doctrine, the use of force is presumed reasonable if another person is "unlawfully and with force entering or attempting to enter your occupied home, car, or place of business." However, in this case, Guyger was the armed person unlawfully entering Jean's home. Jean had the right to shoot Guyger, while she had no right to shoot him.

The jury's verdict is significant, not just because justice was served in this tragic case, but also because it may signal a shift in some jurisdictions' interpretation of the "reasonable" use of force by police officers. In many jurisdictions, officers are required to show that they used deadly force based on a "reasonable" belief that the suspect presented a risk of inflicting deadly force or serious bodily harm. However, juries have often followed an unwritten code that virtually any expression of fear by a police officer justifies a shooting.

The jury's verdict in the Amber Guyger trial is a small data point that some juries in some jurisdictions may be rejecting this classic police defense that has been used to help officers escape accountability for unjustified shootings. In this case, Guyger attempted to use the fear defense, claiming she felt "pure fear" when she opened the door on a man eating ice cream on his own couch. However, her fear was not deemed reasonable, and the jury found her guilty of murder.

The jury's verdict is a vital correction to a culture that has sometimes allowed police officers to abide by a lower standard of behavior than the average citizen of the United States. The case highlights the importance of juries understanding the full scope of the risks inherent in lawful encounters when rendering verdicts, while also emphasizing the need for impartial and unbiased decision-making in the application of force by law enforcement officers.

Title: Democratic Operative Arrested for Alleged Battery on Nevada GOP Campaign Manager

Article:

A Democratic operative working for American Bridge 21st Century, a political action committee founded by David Brock and funded by liberal billionaire George Soros, was arrested Tuesday following an alleged battery incident involving the female campaign manager for Nevada GOP gubernatorial nominee Adam Laxalt.

Kristin Davison, the campaign manager for Laxalt's Nevada attorney general campaign, accused the operative, Wilfred Michael Stark III, 50, of grabbing and yanking her arm and refusing to let go. The incident left Davison "terrified and traumatized" and with bruises on her neck and arms, according to Davison and other officials for the Laxalt campaign.

The Las Vegas City Marshals arrested Stark Tuesday evening, and he remains in custody in the Las Vegas city jail. The city marshal's office stated that the arrest was classified as a citizen's arrest because the incident did not occur in the presence of the marshals. The office also noted that the incident was "an apparent result of an altercation involving Mr. Stark entering one of the rooms... and attempting to question Attorney General Adam Laxalt."

This is not Stark's first arrest. Earlier this year, Stark was arrested for allegedly assaulting the female press secretary for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke. The latest confrontation took place after a campaign event in East Las Vegas Tuesday evening.

According to Davison, a "very large man," later identified as Stark, "burst into the room where Adam [Laxalt] and I were talking with a camera." Davison stated that Stark was "very physical—pushing me, pushing into members of my staff, screaming."

During the altercation, Davison said Stark grabbed her right arm, twisted it behind her back, and bruised her neck. She also stated that Stark held her head against his chest for several minutes.

The Laxalt campaign issued a statement, calling the incident "disgusting" and stating that "Assaulting the female campaign manager of the opposing campaign is disgusting and it has no place in our system."

American Bridge, the political action committee for which Stark works, did not respond to a request for comment. It is unclear whether Stark was on the job for American Bridge during the confrontation. However, Stark lists himself as a reporter for the group on his LinkedIn page.

Stark has a record of arrests while working for American Bridge. In 2017, he was arrested for disorderly conduct at an event in Virginia while covering then-GOP gubernatorial candidate Ed Gillespie. He was found guilty of disorderly conduct in February of this year. The incident with Zinke's press secretary Heather Swift occurred in March at the Longworth House Office Building after a budget hearing before a House committee. Stark allegedly approached Swift and reportedly "used his full body to push" Swift as she tried to leave the room. Swift, who called the incident "terrifying," told police that she decided to press charges to help obtain a "stay-away order" against him.

"It's shocking to me that anyone in this business, no matter which party or issue you're working on, would keep someone on their payroll who has been consistently arrested for violence," Davison told ███. "This is a terrifying incident."

American Bridge was founded in November 2010 by David Brock, who also founded liberal watchdog group Media Matters. Soros is the largest donor to American Bridge, donating more than $2 million between 2015 and 2016. Soros is still involved with the group, most recently donating $300,000 in February and $80,000 last year.

Title: Kavanaugh and Blasey Deliver Prepared Testimonies in Senate Hearing

Article:

In the ongoing Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, Judge Brett Kavanaugh and Dr. Christine Blasey Ford have delivered their prepared testimonies.

Judge Kavanaugh, in his prepared remarks, acknowledged his high school behavior, stating, "I drank beer with my friends, usually on weekends. Sometimes I had too many." He further admitted, "In retrospect, I said and did things in high school that make me cringe now." However, he emphasized that the allegations against him are "far more serious than juvenile misbehavior."

Dr. Blasey, in her prepared testimony, expressed her apprehension about coming forward, stating, "I am here today not because I want to be. I am terrified." She plans to tell senators, "I am here because I believe it is my civic duty to tell you what happened to me while Brett Kavanaugh and I were in high school."

Dr. Blasey also addressed the defense by Judge Kavanaugh and his Republican allies who have asserted that she may be misremembering the identity of her assailant. She will say that their friend groups had "intersected" during her freshman and sophomore years of high school and that they had attended parties together.

Other significant disclosures related to Dr. Blasey's claims, such as the release of handwritten calendar notations from Judge Kavanaugh's high school days, affidavits from Dr. Blasey's friends and husband, and a copy of the polygraph test administered in August, were overshadowed by the day's continuing developments. The polygraph test indicated no deception.

Allies of both Dr. Blasey and Judge Kavanaugh have submitted letters attesting to their integrity. Protesters have prepared for rallies, and shadowy threats have flooded the phone lines and inboxes of key players in the drama.

Title: Fox News Anchor Shepard Smith Debunks Uranium One Allegations Against Hillary Clinton

Article:

Fox News anchor Shepard Smith on Tuesday evening presented a segment debunking the Uranium One allegations against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, a storyline that has been a recurring theme on the network during the 2016 election campaign. The segment, which used factual information and graphics, contradicted the network's previous coverage and sparked outrage among some Fox viewers.

Smith outlined the original accusations, made in a book by a journalist for the right-wing news website Breitbart, and Trump's use of these allegations to boost support during the campaign. He then systematically dismantled the claims.

The allegations centered around the sale of a Canadian company with large uranium mining interests in Wyoming to the Russian nuclear agency, and the Clinton Foundation receiving $140 million in donations from nine people involved in the business deal while Clinton was Secretary of State.

However, Smith explained that the deal required the approval of a committee formed from the heads of nine federal government agencies, and that President Barack Obama, due to the national security implications of Russia holding any US uranium interests, had the power to block the deal under rules written during the Ronald Reagan administration. Smith also pointed out that Clinton did not intervene to approve the deal and did not have the power to approve or block it.

Furthermore, Smith noted that none of the uranium mined in Wyoming by the Canadian company was exported to Russia, and the vast majority of the donations to the Clinton Foundation were made by a man who had already sold his stake in the uranium company in 2007, years before the Russian deal went through and about 18 months before Clinton became Secretary of State.

During the report, Smith appeared to stumble over his script several times, possibly due to the segment's departure from the network's usual coverage and the political leanings of many viewers. The segment came as Attorney General Jeff Sessions is under pressure from President Trump to appoint a special prosecutor to look into the old allegations, but Sessions hinted in a congressional hearing on Tuesday that there was no basis to do so.

The segment sparked outrage among some Fox viewers, with one posting on Twitter, "Get Shepard Smith off of Fox. He's arrogant and doing his own spin. Nobody knows how deep the left's conspiracy goes and Shepherd Smith has ZERO inside info because nobody trusts him. OUT!"

Despite the backlash, some Twitter users praised Smith's segment, with one tweeting, "Fox News reports on Uranium One. Shepard Smith uses detailed facts & graphs to explain why there is no reason to investigate. It is a false controversy meant to draw our attention from real issues within the Trump administration."

Title: Virginia Navigator Program Seeks $495,000 for Healthcare Enrollment Assistance

Article:

The Virginia healthcare navigation program has requested $495,000, accounting for approximately a third of the total navigator funds allocated for the state. This funding would cover the equivalent of seven and a half full-time navigators, necessary equipment, informational materials, marketing, and ongoing outreach events in five counties.

The federal government initially did not anticipate covering the cost of running the insurance markets in 34 states, resulting in only $54 million in funding for navigators in these states, transferred from a fund for public health prevention programs. The healthcare law had set aside significantly more money for states that built their own markets, assuming most would do so.

To address this gap, other organizations will also contribute to outreach and enrollment efforts. Approximately 1,200 community health centers nationwide, which provide medical care for the uninsured, have received a total of $150 million in federal funds to aid with outreach and enrollment. Virginia's health centers received $2.5 million.

In addition to navigators, insurance agents or brokers, and insurance companies selling plans through the markets, will also play a role in helping people sign up for coverage. Other organizations that did not apply for navigator funds will still educate the uninsured about their options, connect them with navigators, or guide them towards the new insurance markets.

Navigators, who will also assist small businesses and their employees in learning about and enrolling in health plans offered through the new markets, are prohibited from recommending specific health plans or receiving compensation from insurance companies. Navigators will undergo at least 20 hours of training and take a certification test.

With the upcoming rollout of the new insurance markets, there is a growing need for collaboration among various organizations to ensure the uninsured are informed about their options and can successfully enroll in health plans. The identities of the navigators are eagerly anticipated, as they will serve as key points of contact for other groups to partner with, refer individuals to, and strengthen outreach efforts.

Title: Election 2012: Candidates Focus on Mobilizing Core Supporters Rather Than Court Undecided Voters

Article:

In the final stretch of the 2012 presidential election, both candidates, President Barack Obama and former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, are focusing more on energizing their respective anti-Obama and anti-Romney coalitions rather than attempting to expand their voter bases with arguments about qualifications. This shift has led to a period of heightened partisanship and divisive exchanges between the candidates.

President Obama has been responding in kind, with harsh exchanges that include mocking Romney's character and accusing him of waging a "campaign of division and anger and hate." Romney, in turn, has accused Obama of disgracing the presidency.

For months, Romney attempted to make inroads among voters who were disappointed with, but not necessarily angry at, Obama. Republican groups ran television advertisements with a softer approach, encouraging voters to feel no guilt for not supporting Obama. However, after a summer of criticism from Democrats, Romney is now returning the scorching fire in an attempt to expand his support among Republicans who strongly oppose Obama.

According to strategists from both parties, the traditional balance between motivating core supporters without scaring off independent voters may be different in this election cycle. A series of recent polls in six swing states showed that only 5 percent of voters were undecided, and only about 1 in 10 likely voters who had chosen a candidate said they were open to switching.

Joel Benenson, the chief pollster for the president's re-election campaign, stated, "There is a smaller slice of undecided voters out there than usual." He added, "Republicans may think that their only chance of winning this is by maximizing their base, but I don't believe this election is a base election."

For Mr. Obama, there is an opportunity to capture some moderate voters who oppose the direction that Representative Paul Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, and other House Republicans have moved in. However, Mr. Obama still has to persuade some centrists that he can be trusted with the deficit and the economy and that he is not culturally out of step with them.

The strategic shifts by the candidates mirror a bigger change in the nature of the race. It is no longer solely a referendum on Obama's economic record; rather, it is a choice between approaches to the future of Medicare, the popular health insurance program for retirees, and the role and scope of government.

The Romney campaign is testing whether it can expand the successful Republican coalition from 2010, when the party, on the basis of an anti-Obama and very conservative message, won control of the House and expanded its strength at all levels of government. It is not simply a base strategy, aides said, but a plan to capitalize on the rejection of Obama's approach that they say is coursing through the country.

Neil Newhouse, the pollster for Romney, stated, "We're going to be able to make a very compelling argument to people in the middle that we need a change and Obama isn't the change they signed up for." He added, "When you really probe, people are upset with spending, the deficit, and the debt. It goes beyond jobs and the economy, and there is a sense things are out of control."

For Mr. Romney, several benefits of selecting Ryan have already become clear. He has drawn praise from conservatives, including those who have long been tepid. And he has become a stronger and more confident campaigner with a partner at his side, advisers say, who has an easygoing style that could help improve Romney's connection to voters.

The Romney campaign is taking pains to track down and quash any criticism in Republican circles about any potential downsides of Ryan on the ticket, including that the campaign debate over Medicare is fraught with risk for other candidates in the party.

Interviews with nearly a dozen Republicans on Congressional and Senate campaigns said in near unison that they worried that the economic focus of the race had been overshadowed. It is a question that may not be answered until Election Day. Will a surge of conservative enthusiasm for the Republican ticket outweigh any potential falloff among voters who supported Obama in 2008 and are open to changing their minds this year?

Mr. Brooks, the Iowa man who had counted himself in that category, said his mind was made up before Obama unexpectedly stopped by his table at the Pump Haus restaurant in downtown Cedar Falls on Tuesday. "We had no idea he was showing up," he said. "We really didn't talk politics."

Title: Rep. Michael Grimm Indicted for Alleged Tax Fraud and Employment of Illegal Immigrants

Article:

Prosecutors have released a damning indictment against Representative Michael Grimm, a former FBI agent, accusing him of hiding over $1 million in revenue from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) by paying employees, including illegal immigrant workers, in cash. The indictment, unveiled on Monday, includes over 20 charges related to a health food restaurant, Healthalicious, that Grimm ran from 2007-2010.

Loretta Lynch, the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, described the alleged conduct as "breathtaking" at a press conference and accused Rep. Grimm of "succumbing to the allure of easy money and cheating his way to success." The indictment threatens Grimm's political career, as he is a sophomore lawmaker and a key moderate voice in the House Republican conference.

The indictment alleges that Grimm paid some employees exclusively in cash and others partly in cash and partly through checks. The payroll processing companies working with Rep. Grimm would only see the payments given by check, and these were the only payments reported to a number of entities: his accountant, the IRS, the State of New York, the New York State Insurance Fund, and health insurance companies.

Through an unknowing accountant, Rep. Grimm is alleged to have hidden $1.3 million in profits. This allowed him to evade both federal and state taxes, pay less for workers' compensation insurance, pay less in health insurance coverage for employees, and hire illegal immigrants, who were paid exclusively in cash.

Rep. Grimm kept a set of spreadsheets showing the amount of money entering and leaving the restaurant that he shared with his accountant and payroll processing companies. He kept a second set of spreadsheets that showed the true profits of the restaurant and the true salaries of all employees.

Upon facing a congressional election, Grimm hired a manager to do much of the work he was once responsible for at the restaurant. This manager he communicated with through an AOL account. He sent the manager the second set of spreadsheets showing the restaurant's true profits via this account, committing wire fraud, the indictment alleges.

The indictment accuses Grimm of obstructing and impeding the due administration of the Internal Revenue Laws, aiding and assisting in the preparation of false and fraudulent tax returns, and lying under oath during a deposition for a lawsuit brought by former employees of Healthalicious who alleged they were being paid less than minimum wage.

In addition to the larger money hiding scheme, Grimm is also accused of knowingly hiring and continuing to employ workers who did not have legal residency status and accordingly did not have valid authorization to work inside the United States. As these individuals were not on the payroll, they did not receive health insurance, a crime of its own.

Rep. Grimm's attorney, William McGinley, has accused the government of a "politically driven vendetta against Congressman Grimm and not an independent search for the truth," denying the allegations.

Title: Senate Fails to Repeal Obamacare, Leaving Healthcare Law in Place

Article:

The Senate's attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, failed on Friday, marking a significant setback for President Donald Trump and the Republican Party. The vote was 51-49, with three Republican senators joining Democrats in opposition. The bill's defeat calls into question the Republican Party's ability to govern, as they control the White House, Senate, and House of Representatives.

Senator John McCain, who is currently undergoing treatment for brain cancer, cast the deciding vote. McCain, along with Senators Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski, voted against the legislation, joining Senate Democrats in unison.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, whose reputation as a master strategist was diminished, stated on the Senate floor after the vote that it was time to move on to other matters. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan, in a statement, said Republicans should not give up on healthcare but cited other pressing issues that needed attention, including major tax-cut legislation.

The Senate's healthcare failure comes as Trump has not had a major legislative victory after more than six months in office. The administration is currently mired in investigations into contacts between Trump's election campaign and Russia and high-level White House staff infighting. Trump had promised to get major healthcare legislation, tax cuts, and a boost in infrastructure spending through Congress in short order.

In addition to legislative agenda items such as spending bills for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 to avoid a government shutdown and raising the U.S. debt limit, the Senate's healthcare failure also leaves health insurers unsure of how long the administration will continue to make billions of dollars in Obamacare payments that help cover out-of-pocket medical expenses for low-income Americans.

Shares of health insurers, which had fought against the bill's proposed repeal of the mandate that Americans obtain insurance, were up following the vote. Hospitals, which had been concerned about big cuts in the Medicaid insurance program for the poor and disabled, saw mostly higher shares.

Senator Lindsey Graham met with Trump on Friday to discuss Graham's proposal to take tax money raised by Obamacare and send it back to the states in the form of healthcare block grants. Some lawmakers have urged a bipartisan effort to buttress the existing healthcare system, but it remains to be seen if a bipartisan approach can get off the ground.

Title: Shift in State Immigration Policies Reflects Changing Political Climate

Article:

The political climate surrounding immigration has seen a significant shift in the United States, with a decrease in the pursuit of broad immigration legislation at the state level. This change is attributed to evolving political currents and court decisions.

Immigrant-rights groups are now taking a more proactive approach, with states such as Colorado granting in-state college tuition rates to illegal immigrants and Illinois issuing driver's licenses to them.

Arturo Vargas, executive director of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials, commented on this shift, stating, "There has been a general reaction by folks to the impact that the Latino vote had in November — that people are thinking twice about the actions they take. Most of these pieces of legislation had been supported by Republican legislators, and I think people are thinking twice about whether this is a strategy the party wants to pursue."

Two years ago, the momentum was on the opposite side, with Congress stalemated and conservative states pushing for their own immigration laws to address the costs and potential safety concerns associated with illegal immigration. Arizona, in 2007, was a pioneer in this regard, implementing a law requiring businesses to use the government's voluntary electronic worker verification system and, in 2011, passing SB 1070, a law imposing state criminal penalties for illegal immigrants and requiring police to check the status of those believed to be in the country illegally.

Other states, including South Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, and Indiana, also passed similar laws. The Supreme Court upheld the worker verification law in 2011 and last year issued a major ruling allowing the police checks to continue, though it struck down the state criminal penalties for illegal immigration. The court also warned it could revisit the police checks if the law is implemented in a discriminatory fashion.

Currently, many states are awaiting further guidance from the courts and Congress. Ann Morse, who runs the National Conference of State Legislatures' immigrant policy project, reported that interest in immigration remains high at the state level, but there are no longer the big omnibus bills. Some states are debating new verification requirements for state services or for voting.

However, where there is clear momentum, it appears to be on the immigrant-advocacy side. Colorado's General Assembly passed a bill earlier this month granting illegal immigrants in-state tuition rates to state colleges, and lawmakers there introduced another bill to repeal a 2006 law requiring police to cooperate with federal immigration agents.

Other states have moved to grant driver's licenses to the young adult illegal immigrants who were given tentative legal status last year by President Obama. Several Republican attorneys general have stated that they consider immigration a national issue and want to see Washington take the lead on immigration reform.

Kris Kobach, the secretary of state in Kansas who was also a leading architect of Arizona's crackdown law, maintains that there is still an appetite to act. He believes that the states that were ready to take action in 2011 and 2012 have already done so, and other states are following their lead.

Kobach also expressed concern over President Obama's move to grant legal status to illegal immigrant young adults last year, stating that it created confusion about what other benefits they should be entitled to. He is leading a lawsuit by federal immigration agents challenging this policy.

Kobach stated that given President Obama's moves and the debate in Congress, state lawmakers who want to see a crackdown realize that the states are their only avenues for action. He also suggested that his home state of Kansas could repeal its in-state tuition rates for illegal immigrants.

Title: Senate Reaches Agreement for Vote on Gun Control Measures Following 14-Hour Democratic Filibuster

Article:

In a significant development, the United States Senate has reportedly agreed to hold votes on tighter gun control measures following a 14-hour filibuster led by Connecticut Democrat Chris Murphy and several colleagues. The filibuster, which took place in the Senate on Thursday, was initiated in response to the Orlando nightclub massacre.

Senator Chris Murphy (D-CT) announced the agreement in the early hours of Thursday, stating that Republican leaders had committed to holding votes on amendments to expand background checks and ban gun sales to individuals on the terror watchlist.

Murphy, who began his speech at 11:21 AM and continued for over 14 hours, had vowed to remain on the Senate floor until there was a signal of cooperation on gun control. As the filibuster continued, updates and messages of support were posted on social media using the hashtags #enough and #holdthefloor.

The Connecticut senator evoked the Newtown school shooting in his state in 2012 in a plea that came as the presumptive Republican presidential candidate, Donald Trump, said he would meet with the National Rifle Association (NRA) about the terror watchlist and gun purchases.

The election-year fight over gun control in the wake of the shooting at the Pulse gay nightclub in Orlando pits strong proponents of the second amendment right to bear arms against those arguing for greater restrictions on the ability to obtain weapons. Trump, who has the endorsement of the NRA, told a rally in Georgia: "I'm going to save your second amendment."

The Senate has not held a debate on gun control for several years, with the last significant changes to federal gun laws made in April 2007, when Congress passed a law to strengthen the instant background check system after a gunman at Virginia Tech who killed 32 people was able to purchase his weapons because his mental health history was not in the instant background check database.

Senator Murphy is seeking a vote on legislation that would let the government bar sales of guns and explosives to people it suspects of being terrorists. Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) offered a similar version of the amendment in December, a day after an extremist couple killed 14 people in San Bernardino, California, but the Republican-run Senate rejected the proposal on a near party-line vote. Murphy also wants a vote to expand background checks.

The Orlando shooter, Omar Mateen, was added to a government watchlist of individuals known or suspected of being involved in terrorist activities in 2013, but was removed from the database 10 months later. The NRA has stated it is willing to meet with Donald Trump and reiterated its support for a bill from the Texas Republican senator John Cornyn that would allow the government to delay firearms sales to suspected terrorists for up to 72 hours. However, Democrats and gun control activists argue that this bar is too high.

Separately, Everytown for Gun Safety, a gun control group backed by former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg, is reportedly working on a compromise with Pennsylvania senator Patrick Toomey, a Republican in a tough re-election race this year who has sought compromise in the past on gun control measures. By the end of the day, Toomey had introduced legislation that would direct the attorney general to create a new list of suspected terrorists who could be barred from buying weapons. However, Democrats immediately rejected that idea, stating it would create too much of a backlog.

Title: Trump Administration Exempts Keystone XL Pipeline from Executive Order on Steel Use

Article:

The Trump administration has decided to exempt the Keystone XL pipeline from an executive order signed in January that requires new pipelines, repairs, or retrofits to use U.S. steel "to the maximum extent possible." White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders stated that the pipeline, which has been in the works for a decade, is not covered by the executive order as it is already under construction.

The Keystone XL pipeline, first proposed by developer TransCanada in 2008, was rejected by the Obama administration in 2015 on environmental grounds. However, an executive order by President Trump in January smoothed the way for construction on the pipeline to recommence. The southern section of the pipeline, which does not cross an international border and does not require State Department approval, is already operational.

Allowing the pipeline to go forward is seen as a way for Trump to fulfill his pro-business campaign promises, while improving American infrastructure. The Institute for Energy Research reported that the Keystone XL pipeline added $5.7 billion to the economies of Oklahoma and Texas during the construction of the southern leg of the pipeline.

Trump's infrastructure upgrades were some of the most compelling features of his campaign platform. A January Gallup poll found that support for revitalizing infrastructure ran far higher among the American public than any of Trump's other campaign issues, with 69 percent of respondents rating it "very important."

The decision to exempt the Keystone XL pipeline from the steel executive order was initially threatened by Trump's populist program, encapsulated in the phrase, "Buy American and hire American." However, the Trump administration appears to have rolled back Trump's initial statement that the executive order would apply to Keystone, citing that the steel for the pipeline is already in place.

Supporters of the decision argue that it is a win for business and good economics, as using the cheapest inputs into any project will make the aggregate wealth richer. Critics may view the decision as a temporary demonstration of pragmatism rather than a shift in course. The Canadian government has also lauded the decision, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office calling it a "recognition that the integrated Canadian and US steel industries are mutually beneficial."

In addition, allowing Keystone XL to go forward may persuade TransCanada to drop a $15 billion NAFTA complaint against the US, which it brought after construction was suspended earlier this week. American steel will be a feature of future pipelines, Sanders emphasized. "Everything moving forward would fall under that executive order," she said.

Title: Mass Layoffs in the U.S. Increase as Businesses Cite Regulatory Burdens and Economic Concerns

Article:

In June, former President Obama stated that the private sector was doing fine. However, recent business headlines suggest a different reality, with mass layoffs becoming increasingly common. Last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported 1,316 "mass layoff actions" (affecting 50 workers or more) in September, resulting in the layoff of over 122,000 workers overall.

Some of the recent layoff activity is connected to the slowest period of earnings growth since the third quarter of 2009. Businesses are undergoing necessary restructuring in response to the stagnant European economy, but many are attributing the layoffs to the regulatory policies and schemes of the current administration.

Ohio-based auto parts manufacturer Dana Holding Corp. warned employees of potential layoffs due to "looming concern" about the economy. President and CEO Roger Wood specifically mentioned the burden of "increasing taxes on small businesses" and the need to "offset increased costs that are placed on us through new laws and regulations."

One example is Obamacare. The mandate will cost Dana Holding Corp., which employs some 24,500 workers, "approximately $24 million over the next six years in additional U.S. health care expenses." In Ohio, the firm's Toledo area corporate offices laid off seven white-collar employees last Friday, with more layoffs expected.

Similarly, Consol Energy announced its intent to idle its Miller Creek surface operations near Naugatuck, W.Va. The move will affect the company's Wiley Surface Mine, Wiley Creek Surface Mine, Minway Surface Mine, Minway Preparation Plant, and Miller Creek Administration Group, all in Mingo County, W.Va. The impasse in the permit approval process, caused by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), has led to the layoff of 145 Consol Energy employees at the end of the year.

In August, Robert E. Murray, founder and CEO of Murray Energy Corporation in Ohio, blasted the White House's anti-coal agenda for the layoffs and closure of his company's mine. He told CNN anchor Soledad O'Brien that "the many regulations that (Obama) and his radical appointees and the U.S. EPA have put on the use of coal, there are dozens of them and collectively by his own energy administration, have closed 175 power plants."

The impending 2.3 percent medical device excise tax has already had a significant impact on the medical device industry. Companies such as Stryker, Covidien, Zoll Medical Corp., and Cook Medical Inc. have announced layoffs and plant closures due to the tax.

The heads of Koch Industries, Westgate Resorts, and ASG Software Solutions have also informed their employees of the negative effects of Obama's economic policies. Left-wing groups have criticized the executives for exercising their political free speech, but they have remained silent while the White House allegedly bribed federal defense contractors into delaying federally mandated layoff disclosures before the election.

Truth suppression is a well-known tactic of the current administration. In 2010, the administration and its Democratic allies on Capitol Hill attempted to punish Deere, Caterpillar, Verizon, and ATT for disclosing the costs of Obamacare taxes on their bottom lines, even though they were simply following SEC disclosure requirements. The White House also tried to silence insurers who dared to inform their customers about how Obamacare was driving up premiums. This time, however, the administration's bully boys do not have enough whitewash and duct tape to cover up the past, present, and future devastation of the president and his economic demolition team.

Title: Common Core Faces Public Skepticism as Supporters Vow to Revamp Campaign

Article:

The Common Core, a set of academic standards aimed at elevating math, reading, and writing instruction across the nation, has faced a significant decline in public support, according to two recent national polls. The Education Next poll, released on Wednesday, also showed a steep drop in support among public school teachers.

Michael Petrilli, president of the Thomas B. Fordham Institute and a proponent of the Common Core, commented, "There's no denying that this is bad news for supporters of the Common Core."

In a positive development for Common Core backers, a district judge in Louisiana rejected Governor Bobby Jindal's attempt to repeal the standards by executive order. However, in Ohio, the Legislature is considering a bill to join the five other states that have repealed the standards in recent months.

Facing mounting opposition, Common Core supporters have vowed to revamp their campaign. They will unveil the first step on Friday, with Latino evangelical pastors from across the country rallying their congregations behind the Common Core.

The guest speaker at this event will be former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, who, six months ago, called Common Core "a toxic term because it's come to mean things that most of us can't stomach, like top-down federal intrusion into the local schools where you live." Huckabee's blog post title at that time was "Common Core is Dead."

The new polls indicate that over a year of high-profile opposition from parent activists, political figures, and celebrities has had a significant impact. The 46th annual PDK/Gallup poll, released on Wednesday, found that 80% of Americans have heard about the Common Core, and nearly half say they know at least "a fair amount" about the standards.

However, this increased familiarity has led to distrust, with 60% of respondents opposing the use of the standards in their community. Among these opponents, over three-quarters cited local teachers' lack of support for the standards and concern about limiting teachers' flexibility in the classroom as primary reasons for their opposition.

The PDK/Gallup poll, sponsored by Phi Delta Kappa International, a trade association for educators, surveyed 1,001 adults.

The Education Next poll, released on Tuesday, found that the term "Common Core" has become a divisive issue. When respondents were asked about the Common Core, only 53% supported the standards, down from 65% a year ago. However, when the term "Common Core" was not mentioned, and respondents were asked about "standards for reading and math that are the same across the states," support for the standards increased to 68%. This increase was consistent across political parties.

The Education Next poll also asked respondents who had heard of the Common Core a series of true/false questions about the standards. Large majorities got these questions wrong, incorrectly believing, for example, that the federal government mandates the use of the standards and that the Common Core strips away local control over textbooks.

Title: Trump Accepts Putin's Denial of Election Interference, Draws Criticism

Article:

President Donald Trump's meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday has sparked controversy, as Trump appeared to accept Putin's denial of any Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election. This move has been criticized, as the U.S. intelligence community believes the Kremlin orchestrated a sophisticated campaign to help Trump win the presidency.

According to Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, Trump told Putin that some in the United States were "exaggerating" the extent of Russia's influence on the election's outcome. This statement has been interpreted as Trump siding with Moscow in the ongoing domestic political debate.

The development is significant, as it seems Russia achieved its goal of having the Trump administration acknowledge that the Kremlin did not interfere in the election. The meeting took place amidst speculation about whether Congress would impose sanctions on Russia for its election meddling. Trump acknowledged the possibility of sanctions, but also expressed a desire to move past the issue.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated, "The president took note of the actions that have been discussed by the Congress. But I think the two presidents — I think rightly — focused on how do we move forward?"

The meeting's outcome has been anticipated by some analysts, as Russia was expected to emerge as a winner regardless of the meeting's content. The New York Times reported that Russia believed Putin would come out on top, either by the meeting producing no substantial results, or by Trump agreeing to work with Russia, which would portray the U.S. president as feckless due to Russia's defiance in Ukraine, Syria, and during the election.

The meeting also resulted in a ceasefire agreement in Syria's southwest, but the effectiveness of this agreement is unclear, as most of the fighting occurs in the east and north of the country, particularly in Raqqa. Critics argue that Trump may have done more damage by meeting with Putin than he would have by staying home.

In the aftermath of the meeting, Trump and Putin's focus on a Syria ceasefire has been overshadowed by Trump's tweet early on Friday morning, in which he questioned former Hillary Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta about the Democratic National Committee's server. Podesta, who is currently on a cross-country trip, responded by calling Trump a "whack job" and urging him to "get his head in the game."

Title: Whistleblower Lawyers Express Safety Concerns Amidst Calls for Identity Disclosure

Article:

Lawyers for the intelligence official who filed a whistleblower complaint against President Trump have expressed "serious concerns" for their client's safety, according to reports. A letter signed by the whistleblower's lead attorney, Andrew Bakaj, and sent to acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire pointed to Trump's call for "the person who gave the whistleblower the information" to be publicly identified, as reported by NBC News.

The letter, dated Saturday and made public Sunday, stated that events from the past week "have heightened our concerns that our client's identity will be disclosed publicly and that, as a result, our client will be put in harm's way."

Bakaj acknowledged that it was the unidentified whistleblower's source of information whom Trump's comment targeted, but he wrote that the distinction "does nothing to assuage our concerns for our client's safety." The lawyer also claimed that "certain individuals" had offered a $50,000 bounty for information about their client's identity.

The Washington Examiner, a conservative news outlet, reported last week that two right-wing activists had offered the sum for "credible information corroborating" the person's identity.

On Sunday, the president suggested in a tweet that he wants the whistleblower to be outed. "Like every American, I deserve to meet my accuser, especially when this accuser, the so-called 'Whistleblower,' represented a perfect conversation with a foreign leader in a totally inaccurate and fraudulent way," Trump wrote.

The lawyers also called on lawmakers to speak out for whistleblower protections and insist that retaliation against the official— "whether direct or implied"— would not be tolerated, according to Business Insider.

"Unfortunately, we expect this situation to worsen, and to become even more dangerous for our client and any other whistleblowers, as Congress seeks to investigate this matter," the letter said.

CBS News has reported that the whistleblower— identified by the New York Times as a CIA officer— was already under federal protection. However, Mark Zaid, a lawyer from Compass Rose Legal, tweeted that CBS "completely misinterpreted contents of our letter," saying the legal team had not yet reached an agreement with Congress regarding contact with their client.

Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.)— chairman of the House Intelligence Committee— told ABC's "This Week" on Sunday that he expected the whistleblower to testify "very soon" once security measures were implemented to protect the person's identity.

Last week, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would launch a formal impeachment inquiry in light of a July 25 phone call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. A rough summary of the conversation revealed Trump's apparent efforts to get Ukraine to dig up dirt on former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, who served on the board of a Ukrainian gas company.

On Thursday, the complaint by the whistleblower, who believed Trump was "using the power of his office to solicit interference from a foreign country" in the 2020 election, was released to the public. The intelligence community inspector general, Michael Atkinson, deemed the Aug. 12 complaint "credible" and of "urgent concern" and passed it on to Maguire, who testified before the House Intelligence Committee. Maguire said that both the whistleblower and the inspector general "acted in good faith throughout" and "have done everything by the book and followed the law."

Title: Democratic Party's Identity Crisis: Kamala Harris's Exit Highlights Party's Divide

Article:

The Democratic Party is grappling with an identity crisis, as evidenced by the recent withdrawal of Senator Kamala Harris from the 2020 presidential race. For years, Harris was known as the "female Obama," but her campaign struggled to gain traction in the primary field, with critics labeling her as a candidate trying to be all things to all people.

As the Democratic primary voters coalesced around candidates with sharper ideological profiles, Harris found herself struggling to convince loyalists in either camp that she would be a reliable voice for their issues. The primary has crystallized into a contest between the party's two wings, with Harris falling by the wayside, fully trusted by neither faction.

The first group, personified most intensely by former Vice President Joe Biden and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, are the Adjusters. They believe that the world was a pretty good place in October 2016, and that removing President Donald Trump from office represents a necessary course correction that will allow the country to proceed upon the path that Barack Obama had outlined during his presidency. "We made a mistake," they say. "Let's just fix it and get back to normal."

The other movement is led by the Revolutionaries, with Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders at the forefront. They see removing Trump from office as only the first step, which must be followed by sweeping, even radical change. Revolutionaries see Obama as an incrementalist and dismiss the Clintons as sellouts. They call for a much more dramatic overhaul, but one that unnerves risk-averse establishment Democrats who worry that such an ambitious agenda could drive centrist voters to Trump.

In addition to Biden and Buttigieg, the ranks of the Adjusters have recently been swelled by the addition of former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and former Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick to the race. Senators Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Cory Booker of New Jersey are part of this faction as well, as are the lower-tier candidates Michael Bennet, the Colorado senator, and John Delaney, a former Maryland congressman. All face a similar challenge of trying to excite primary voters with some variation of a more cautious agenda.

The rest of the primary candidates are Revolutionaries. Along with Warren and Sanders, nontraditional alternatives such as entrepreneur Andrew Yang, Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii, and impeachment activist Tom Steyer occupy this space as well, along with fading options like former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro and author Marianne Williamson. They might differ on the specifics of their policy prescriptions, but all advocate for a much more fundamental shift in the priorities of their party and the country.

Harris was the only Democratic candidate who made a serious effort to talk to voters in both groups. Lacking the skills of Obama and the experience of Bill Clinton, she was unable to convince either Adjusters or the Revolutionaries that she was one of them. Rejected by both, she now returns to the Senate, where the upcoming impeachment trial gives her the opportunity to burnish her credentials for a spot on the ticket or a Cabinet post.

The divide in the Democratic Party remains, even with Harris's exit. Just as in 2016, when many Sanders supporters stayed home instead of voting, or chose Trump or third-party candidates, a similar temptation will exist in 2020 if a moderate becomes the Democratic nominee. Conversely, the late Bloomberg and Patrick entries reflect growing worries in the party's centrist establishment wing about Democratic prospects in the general election.

The eventual nominee will not defeat Trump unless the Adjusters and Revolutionaries are able to put aside their differences. Harris's greatest contribution to her party this year may be to serve as a reminder of what could happen if that unity is not achieved.

Title: Obama Seeks Conclusive Proof of Chemical Weapons Use in Syria Before Taking Action

Article:

President Barack Obama is reportedly considering a potential shift in U.S. policy towards Syria, following intelligence assessments suggesting that chemical munitions, known to be in the possession of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's military, were used on a small scale in Syria.

During a press conference in Washington on Tuesday, Mr. Obama emphasized the need for more conclusive evidence before taking any action. "What we now have is evidence that chemical weapons have been used inside of Syria, but we don't know how they were used, when they were used, who used them; we don't have chain of custody that establishes what exactly happened," Mr. Obama said.

The President also expressed concern about rushing to judgment without solid evidence, stating, "If we end up rushing to judgment without hard, effective evidence, then we can find ourselves in the position where we can't mobilize the international community to support what we do."

Despite the lack of conclusive proof, officials have reported that the Pentagon has prepared a range of options for Mr. Obama, including airstrikes, commando raids, and the enforcement of a no-fly zone over Syria. The administration is also reportedly looking for ways to increase aid to the rebels.

Previously, President Obama had resisted calls to arm the rebels, including from David H. Petraeus, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. A proposal by Mr. Petraeus to provide arms to carefully vetted members of the opposition was shelved last fall, though several officials expect it to be revisited.

Title: Iranian Hackers Advance Capabilities in Cyberattacks, Pose Increased Threat to Critical Infrastructure

Article:

Over the past year, Iranian hackers have targeted the presidential campaign of former U.S. President Donald Trump, telecom companies, infrastructure systems, and more than 200 oil, gas, and heavy machinery companies worldwide. According to James A. Lewis, a cybersecurity expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, these hackers have developed the ability to disrupt critical infrastructure and have the capability to wipe data. The question now is which services, such as pipelines or dams, they may target next.

Iran is not yet considered at the top of the list of countries with the ability to cause widespread destruction via cyberattacks, Mr. Lewis and other experts said. However, Tehran has made significant strides since 2009, when a classified intelligence assessment concluded that it had the motivation but lacked the skills and resources to inflict harm.

Since 2010, when an Iranian nuclear facility was the target of a joint American-Israeli cyberattack, Iran has embraced such attacks as part of its strategy of "asymmetrical warfare." While the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps may never match the West in conventional warfare, its specialized teams have learned how much destruction they can cause to vulnerable systems, according to American intelligence assessments and private security researchers.

Over the past five years, American officials and cybersecurity experts have tracked Iranian hackers as they have significantly advanced their capabilities beyond wiping data to sophisticated attacks on financial networks, internet infrastructure, energy companies, and critical infrastructure sites like the Bowman Dam in Westchester County and the Energy Department's Idaho National Engineering Laboratory near Idaho Falls.

"They now have the ability to do serious harm," Mr. Lewis said. "As the conflict with the U.S. continues, they're going to be tempted. Expect to see a lot more testing of how far they can get into company networks, universities, federal networks, and smaller government networks in towns and cities."

On Friday, Iranian leaders issued strident calls for revenge against the United States after the killing of Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani in an overnight airstrike at the Baghdad airport. The potential for increased cyberattacks from Iran in response to this event cannot be ruled out.
