Title: New Book Alleges Hunter Biden's Business Deals with Foreign Governments and Oligarchs

Article:

Author Peter Schweizer's new book, "Profiles in Corruption: Abuse of Power by America's Progressive Elite," claims that Hunter Biden, son of 2020 presidential candidate Joe Biden, forged business deals with individuals and entities tied to the governments of Russia, China, and Kazakhstan, reportedly earning him hundreds of millions of dollars.

The book details how Hunter Biden and his business partner, Devon Archer, were deeply involved with an entity called the Burnham Financial Group. According to a copy of the book viewed by ███, Hunter and Archer, through Burnham, made foreign deals with governments and oligarchs.

One of those oligarchs was Nurlan Abduov, an associate of another Kazakh oligarch, Kenges Rakishev. Rakishev is the son-in-law of the former vice prime minister of Kazakhstan, Imangali Tasmagambetov. Tasmagamvetov was also formerly the defense minister, and is now the Kazakh ambassador to Russia.

The book alleges that an account Hunter regularly received funds from showed money arriving from a firm run by Rakishev in 2014. Additionally, Archer reportedly acted as a backchannel between Kazakhstan and then-Secretary of State John Kerry, according to the book.

Furthermore, Burnham had business deals with two mysterious Chinese companies — Kirin Global Enterprises Limited and Harvest Global Investors, according to Schweizer. Kirin Global Enterprise Limited was an investment vehicle run by Xiangyao (or Yaojun) "Larry" Liu and Guo Jianfeng, according to Schweizer. Harvest Global Investors was a Chinese investment firm linked to the government in Beijing.

Burnham also had a financial relationship with Russian Oligarch Yelena Baturina, a billionaire with extensive political connections in Moscow and links to Russian organized crime, according to Schweizer. Archer reportedly said Baturina invested $200 million into "various investment funds" with which he was involved.

The book also alleges that Burnham was involved in a $60 million fraudulent bond scheme to rip off union pension funds and the poorest Indian tribe in America, the Oglala Sioux. In May 2016, Archer was arrested in New York and charged with "orchestrating a scheme to defraud investors and a Native American tribal entity of tens of millions of dollars."

Although Hunter Biden was not charged, Schweizer writes, "his fingerprints were all over Burnham." The legitimacy that his name and political status as the vice president's son lent to Burnham was brought up repeatedly during the trial, he writes. That status was used as a means of both recruiting pension money into the scheme and alleviating investors' concerns, he writes.

Hunter Biden had an office at Burnham's New York City offices on Fifty-Seventh Street, and during the trial, numerous witnesses came forward describing Hunter's involvement with the firm, according to the book.

Schweizer writes that these deals have long been a pattern with the Biden family, including Hunter Biden: "With the election of his father as vice president, Hunter Biden launched businesses fused to his father's power that led him to lucrative deals with a rogue's gallery of governments and oligarchs around the world."

Title: Benghazi Committee Investigation: Focus on Pre-Attack Activities and Security Measures

Article:

The House Select Committee on Benghazi, established to investigate the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, that resulted in the death of four Americans, is set to hold a hearing on Thursday. The focus of the hearing is not expected to be on former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's emails, but rather on the underlying question of the purpose of the Americans' presence in Benghazi and the security arrangements in place.

The committee is expected to question the nature of the mission of the former special forces personnel in Benghazi, who were not typically involved in visa issuance or lost luggage tasks associated with consulates and embassy annexes. The committee will likely seek to clarify who Ambassador Christopher Stevens was supposed to meet in Benghazi and who was responsible for his security.

Another point of interest is the Libyan militia groups that the U.S. was partnering with and the process of vetting these groups. There have been unconfirmed reports suggesting that the Benghazi mission may have been a gun-running operation to transfer Qaddafi's abandoned weapons to Syrian rebels. The committee may question whether American contractors were involved in such activities.

The committee is also expected to delve into the weeks leading up to the attack, focusing on the repeated calls for increased security by Ambassador Stevens that were reportedly ignored. The absence of a rescue mission during the attack is another area of concern.

The committee will also question who made the decision to attribute the events of September 11, 2012, to a planned terrorist attack rather than a YouTube video sparking a demonstration that escalated.

The committee's investigation will also seek to determine whether the Libyan war was another example of the Obama administration's alleged affinity for moderately radical Islamists. The committee will examine whether the administration was willfully blind to the dangers posed by radical Islamists in Libya, Egypt, Syria, Iraq, and Iran.

The committee's inquiry comes amidst new evidence, including Ambassador Stevens' own emails, which may make it difficult for witnesses to evade questions. The hearing will mark the latest development in a long-running investigation that has yet to yield definitive answers.

Title: Norwegian Police Investigate Mosque Shooting as Act of Terrorism

Article:

A 21-year-old Norwegian man, allegedly expressing far-right views, opened fire at a mosque near Oslo, Norway's capital, on Saturday. The suspect, identified by reports as Philip Manshaus, was heavily armed and shot through a glass door to enter the Al-Noor Islamic Center.

The gunman was overpowered by a 65-year-old worshipper, who was injured in the confrontation. The shooting could have resulted in more casualties if the suspect had arrived a few minutes earlier, as there were more than a dozen people inside the mosque just 10 minutes before the incident. However, by the time the suspect arrived, only three older men remained, and one of them managed to disarm the shooter.

Following the mosque shooting, police found the body of the gunman's 17-year-old stepsister at his home in Baerum, west of Oslo. The gunman has been charged with the murder of the woman and is facing an attempted murder charge for the mosque shooting.

Police in Oslo are investigating the shooting as terrorism due to the gunman's apparent intent to instill fear. However, they emphasized that there is no evidence he was part of a larger network. Authorities stated that the suspect had expressed far-right views, including admiration for Vidkun Quisling, Norway's leader who collaborated with the Nazis during World War II.

Hours before the attack, a user with the same name as the alleged gunman posted on the 4chan messaging board, expressing admiration for the gunman who killed 51 people at two New Zealand mosques earlier this year. The post included a meme that described that gunman as a "saint" and praised the alleged El Paso, Texas, shooter for "reclaiming his country." The post was made on a new messaging board called Endchan and the older site 4chan.

Authorities ordered police to guard mosques in the city. As Muslims celebrated the beginning of Eid al-Adha on Sunday, many non-Muslims stood outside mosques in Oslo to stand guard. "This is not supposed to happen in Norway," Prime Minister Erna Solberg said. "Norway should be safe. All places of worship shall be safe."

This article has been updated with new information since its original publication.

Title: FBI Background Checks for Firearm Purchases Decline After December High

Article:

Following a record-breaking high in December, the number of background checks run through the Federal Bureau of Investigation's (FBI) National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has decreased year-over-year for the first time since October 2011. The decline in checks, which serve as a proxy for gun sales, suggests a waning interest in firearm purchases following the aftermath of the Connecticut school shooting and subsequent government push for new gun control measures.

In June, 1.3 million checks were performed through the FBI's NICS, a significant drop from the 2.7 million in December and a decrease of approximately 20,000 compared to the same month last year. This marks the first year-to-year drop in checks since October 2011.

David Chipman, a former agent for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives who now advises the gun control advocacy group Mayors Against Illegal Guns, attributes the decline to a saturation of gun purchases. "It seems that those motivated by fear to purchase a firearm over the past several months have acquired all of the guns they desire or can afford," he said.

NICS checks surged by nearly 500,000 in November compared to the previous year, surpassing the 2 million mark for the first time. In December, they increased by over 900,000, reaching an all-time high of 2.7 million. John Hudak, a fellow at the Brookings Institution who studies gun issues, attributes the spike to a sense of threat and the subsequent need for self-protection.

"People felt a threat. The need created by that threat was then satisfied. The shock and horror has died down in pretty dramatic fashion over the past few months," Mr. Hudak said.

In addition to the fear of personal threat, Mr. Hudak suggests that another factor driving the surge in gun purchases was the fear of government intervention in gun sales. This theory is supported by the defeat of a gun control bill in the Senate in mid-April, despite months of administration lobbying and President Obama's extensive use of the public "bully pulpit."

NICS checks are not a one-to-one correlation to gun sales, as some checks are performed on active concealed carry permits and other nonsale actions. However, the number of checks serves as a fairly decent, though imperfect, proxy for the number of guns sold.

The National Sports Shooting Foundation, the trade group for the guns and ammunition industry, keeps its own adjusted tally every month to account for such checks that don't translate directly into sales. According to Mike Bazinet, a spokesman for the group, low numbers in the middle of the year aren't out of the ordinary. By the group's metric, the adjusted June figure of 872,025 is actually an increase of 3 percent over June 2012 and the 37th straight month of year-over-year monthly increases.

Josh Horwitz, executive director of the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, cautions against reading too much into any comparisons with figures from December, as that month is always the biggest. Year-over-year, he points out, the number of checks increased from January through May and were basically flat in June, adjusting for permit checks.

"Months always vary in a pattern. They vary in the same way," he said.

The decline in NICS checks might signal to some that the issue is fading from the public eye, but President Obama and groups like Mr. Horwitz's have vowed not to let that happen. Immediately after the Newtown shooting, Mr. Obama rolled out an ambitious gun control package that included bans on semi-automatic rifles and high-capacity magazines and near-universal background checks. That package ultimately devolved into a compromise measure that would expand background checks to sales online and at gun shows. Even that measure failed to pass the Senate.

Mr. Obama and others have reassured advocates that they will revisit the issue. "The American people are there," Vice President Joseph R. Biden said last month. "In the meantime, the president is going to continue to take every executive action within his power to make schools safer for our children, churches safe places to worship, and significantly work on reducing the number of gun deaths in America. No matter how long it takes, we're determined to do something about it."

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Chief of Staff and Communications Director Depart from Congressional Office

Article:

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Chief of Staff, Saikat Chakrabarti, and Communications Director, Corbin Trent, are leaving their positions in her Congressional office following a series of controversies. Chakrabarti will depart on Friday, while Trent will remain as Congressional spokesman until the end of the month and then transition to Ocasio-Cortez's 2020 campaign.

Chakrabarti will join New Consensus, a nonprofit climate change group that promotes the Green New Deal. Trent will take on the same role in Ocasio-Cortez's 2020 campaign.

The Intercept first reported the departures, which were later confirmed by The Washington Post. Chakrabarti and Trent's aggressive tactics have reportedly made life challenging for Ocasio-Cortez in Washington.

One of the most significant controversies involved Chakrabarti's tweet likening moderate Democrats to "new southern Democrats," which was widely criticized as racially charged. He also targeted moderate Rep. Sharice Davids, a Democrat from a formerly red Kansas district, in a tweet that was seen as attacking a Native American woman of color.

In June, Trent generated negative press when he used profanity in a tweet directed at a potential Republican challenger.

Both aides joined Ocasio-Cortez's team after working on her successful primary campaign, where they served as leaders of the Justice Democrats, an insurgent group that aimed to replace Democratic incumbents with progressive candidates.

The finances surrounding the Justice Democrats have also attracted criticism, with three Federal Election Commission complaints filed by conservative groups due to an unusual setup in which money from the PAC flowed into two limited liability companies controlled by Chakrabarti.

Ocasio-Cortez and Trent have presented a positive image of the departures. In a statement, Trent said, "We are extraordinarily grateful for his service to advance a bold agenda and improve the lives of the people in NY-14. From his co-founding of Justice Democrats to his work on the Ocasio-Cortez campaign and in her official office, Saikat’s goal has always been to do whatever he can to help the larger progressive movement."

Ocasio-Cortez herself told The Intercept that Trent was "shifting to our campaign side so we can work on some ambitious comms projects we’ve been looking forward to working on."

Title: Honduras Signs "Safe Third Country" Agreement with U.S. to Process Asylum Seekers

Article:

Honduras has signed a deal with the U.S. government that could potentially return migrants seeking asylum in the United States to Honduras, in an effort to curb migration. This agreement, announced on Wednesday, follows similar agreements signed by El Salvador on September 20 and Guatemala on July 26.

The details of the implementation of these agreements have not been disclosed by the countries involved. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) official, who spoke to reporters on a conference call on condition of anonymity, stated that the Honduras deal aims to allow migrants to seek protection as close to their home as possible.

The Trump administration has implemented a rule on July 16 that bars most migrants from gaining U.S. asylum if they did not seek safe haven in a country they transited through first. This rule, which serves a similar purpose to the agreements, has faced legal challenges. Initially, a federal court blocked the rule from taking effect, but the U.S. Supreme Court allowed it to be implemented while the court challenges are ongoing.

The majority of migrants arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border are from the three northern triangle countries, and many turn themselves in to border officials to ask for asylum in the United States. President Donald Trump has made reducing the growing number of asylum claims a top priority of his administration, and has implemented various measures to discourage migrants from applying.

However, immigrant advocates argue that sending people seeking refuge back to the region where they fled, even if not to their home country, violates international commitments meant to prevent vulnerable migrants from being returned to danger. The three countries have small asylum offices that may struggle to process a large number of claims, they say.

Honduras President Juan Orlando Hernandez has faced scrutiny over a court filing document related to the upcoming drug trafficking trial in New York of his brother, Juan Antonio “Tony” Hernandez. President Hernandez has denied any wrongdoing. In a speech on Wednesday before the UN General Assembly, Hernandez defended his political reputation against what he called "smears" from "criminals" and others, without outright referring to the allegations against him.

Title: Justice Department's AP Phone Records Investigation Sparks Calls for Attorney General Eric Holder's Resignation

Article:

Speculation is mounting in Washington over the potential fallout from the Justice Department's investigation of Associated Press phone records, with some suggesting it could lead to the resignation of Attorney General Eric Holder.

In an article for the National Journal, Jill Lawrence writes that Holder, who has survived numerous controversies, could be forced to step down due to this latest scandal, which also involves the administration's handling of the attack on the US consulate in Benghazi and the IRS's investigation of conservative political organizations.

Esquire blogger Charles Pierce has stated that Holder should resign, describing the government's actions as "constitutionally abhorrent" and "politically moronic." Dan Kennedy, a journalism professor at Northeastern University, tweeted, "It is 8:42. The AP phone story broke at 7:50. Why is Eric Holder still attorney general?"

The political stakes for the White House are high, with NBC's First Read observing, "The rule of three... means the president's credibility is truly on the line right now."

The controversy over the seizure of the AP's phone records is unique in its bipartisan nature. On Monday, the AP, a major news cooperative, announced that the Justice Department had secretly obtained two months of phone records for reporters and editors in New York, Washington, and Hartford, Connecticut. The government seized records for more than 20 separate phone lines used by more than 100 reporters in April and May 2012.

AP President and Chief Executive Officer Gary Pruitt wrote to Holder, calling the operation a "massive and unprecedented intrusion" into how news organizations do their work. "There can be no possible justification for such an overbroad collection of telephone communications," Mr. Pruitt said.

At a press conference Tuesday afternoon, Holder said he recused himself from the decision to subpoena the AP's phone records, and that the decision had been made by Deputy Attorney General Jim Cole, who is handling the case. Holder said he stepped aside because he had been interviewed in the investigation into who provided information for a May 7, 2012, AP story about a foiled terror plot that targeted the US. The attorney general said the leak his department was investigating "put the American people at risk."

The Justice Department released a statement defending its actions, saying, "We take seriously our obligations to follow all applicable laws, federal regulations, and Department of Justice policies when issuing subpoenas for phone records of media organizations... Because we value the freedom of the press, we are always careful and deliberative in seeking to strike the right balance between the public interest in the free flow of information and the public interest in the fair and effective administration of our criminal laws."

Sen. Patrick Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, issued a statement, saying, "I am very troubled by these allegations and want to hear the government's explanation."

On Monday, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney issued a statement distancing the White House from the investigation. "We are not involved in decisions made in connection with criminal investigations, as those matters are handled independently by the Justice Department."

On Tuesday, however, he offered Holder some support: "The president has confidence in the attorney general."

When Holder was asked about his future last month on the Tom Joyner Morning Show, he responded, "I don't know," when asked if he would stay the full four years of Obama's second term. He added, "I'm happy. I'm still enjoying what I'm doing and still want to be done. I'm still the president's wing man, and I'm here with my boy."

Title: Cruz Announces Carly Fiorina as Vice Presidential Running Mate

Article:

In a move to shake up the 2016 Republican presidential race as Donald Trump moves closer to the nomination, Senator Ted Cruz announced former GOP primary rival Carly Fiorina as his choice for vice president should he win the party's nomination. The announcement was immediately dismissed as a sign of desperation by the Trump team, but Cruz defended the decision, claiming that no candidate is likely to reach the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination and voters should "know what they will get."

Speaking in Indianapolis, Cruz, alongside Fiorina, aimed to counter Trump's narrative that the race is effectively over after the front-runner swept five primary states on Tuesday. Fiorina, in accepting Cruz's offer, expressed readiness to "fight."

The theoretical pairing represents a diverse ticket, offering the possibility of electing the first Hispanic president and the first female vice president. Cruz emphasized that the choice signified trust in Fiorina's leadership abilities, stating, "This is a choice that you are telling the American people that 'This is an individual that I trust and, more important, this is an individual that you can trust to lead this country, no matter what might happen.'"

However, for the time being, Fiorina will hold the position of vice presidential candidate-in-waiting, as Cruz continues to lag far behind Trump in the battle for the GOP nomination. Even Fiorina would have to be elected by delegates at the convention. As for Cruz, he has been mathematically eliminated from clinching the nomination before the convention and is relying on the prospect of a contested convention.

Cruz's selection of a vice presidential candidate in April, while he is well behind in delegates, follows a pattern of somewhat unconventional campaigning, including an early embrace of Trump and kicking off his campaign without first forming an exploratory committee. Fiorina began her career as a secretary and receptionist but quickly rose up the business ranks and was named in 1999 as the chief executive officer for Hewlett-Packard, becoming the first woman to lead a Fortune 20 company.

Trump, who leads Cruz in pledged delegates (954-562), dismissed the notion of Cruz tapping a running mate, stating, "He should not be naming anybody because he does not even have a chance." In a statement later Wednesday, Trump criticized the move as Cruz "only trying to stay relevant."

While most presidential candidates wait until they have the nomination sewn up to announce a running mate, Cruz's selection of a vice presidential candidate in April, while he is well behind in delegates, follows a pattern of somewhat unconventional campaigning. Fiorina's career as a political candidate began when she tried to unseat California Sen. Barbara Boxer during an unsuccessful 2010 bid. Boxer on Wednesday mocked the suggestion of Fiorina as Cruz's running mate, stating, "The best way to describe that ticket is mean and meaner."

In May 2015, Fiorina announced her candidacy for president and quickly became known as a feisty critic of Hillary Clinton and a strong defender of the pro-life community. Planned Parenthood immediately panned Fiorina's Wednesday pairing with Cruz as "the most loathsome pair of anti-abortion extremists in America." Her early debate performances were lauded by many critics, but she never gained traction and suspended her campaign after single-digit finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire. She endorsed Cruz in early March and has appeared often with him on the campaign trail.

When asked about being Cruz's vice president in early March, Fiorina replied, "Let's win the nomination first." Though she eventually threw her support behind Cruz, Fiorina also attacked him when she was still a competing candidate, terming him one of the "ultimate insiders" and calling him "too divisive" in January. She also criticized Cruz for saying "one thing in the drawing rooms of Manhattan and another thing in the living rooms of Iowa."

Title: Education Secretary Arne Duncan Calls for Action on Gun Violence

Article:

In a speech at Washington D.C.'s Neval Thomas Elementary School on Friday, Education Secretary Arne Duncan called for a collaborative effort among school leaders, politicians, Second Amendment advocates, and others to address gun violence in America. He urged for swift and significant progress in reducing gun violence, emphasizing the need for personal involvement.

Duncan, a member of President Obama's task force on gun violence and mental health, addressed the complex factors that led to the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, last week. He suggested that limiting access to high-powered firearms is the simplest and easiest solution to this issue, a point he reiterated by questioning what might have transpired if the shooter, Adam Lanza, did not have access to such weapons.

Duncan, who has witnessed the impact of gun violence during his tenure as chief of Chicago public schools, expressed his concern that Lanza's actions may have had a different outcome if he did not have access to guns. He lamented the loss of 26 lives and the families in Newtown who are now attending funerals instead of celebrating the holidays.

On the same day, the National Rifle Association is scheduled to hold its first press conference since the Newtown massacre. This anticipated address is expected to provide insights into the potential challenges gun-control proponents may face in enacting stricter laws. Currently, gun-control advocates are advocating for the reinstatement of the assault weapons ban, the closing of the so-called "gun show loophole," and limits to high-capacity ammunition clips, similar to those used by Lanza at Sandy Hook.

Secretary Duncan concluded his address by stating that reasonable people should be able to agree on these restrictions.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing: A Study in Contrasts and Political Dilemmas

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Thursday was a complex and contrasting event, marked by respectful treatment of Christine Blasey Ford, the accuser, and a display of anger and indignation from Judge Brett Kavanaugh, the accused.

Christine Blasey Ford, the accuser, came across as deferential, nervous, and deeply concerned with accuracy. Her testimony was specific and emotional, detailing the impact the alleged assault had on her life, including installing a second front door on her house due to the aftereffects of the attack. Judge Kavanaugh, on the other hand, was perceived as an angry and bullying figure, prone to yelling, weeping, and making political accusations.

The Republican senators, all men, were careful to avoid the appearance of grilling Ford, as they had done with Anita Hill in 1991. Instead, a prosecutor from Arizona, Rachel Mitchell, asked many of their questions. They performed a kind of stilted politeness and frequently called Ford "credible." However, they showed little interest in listening to her grave testimony, portraying the hearing's findings as a simple he-said/she-said standoff, and ultimately voting to advance Kavanaugh's nomination.

The hollowness of the proceedings put a fine point on our new political reality. The hearing revealed a world in which norms have changed, and even the Republican party has realized it can't score points by personally attacking those who say they are victims of sexual assault. However, the party is still able to indulge in an old kind of hypocrisy, pretending to believe Ford's words without taking them seriously enough to delay the nomination process.

A day later, on Friday, two sexual assault survivors emotionally confronted Senator Jeff Flake in an elevator, urging him to consider the impact of his vote. The confrontation was raw and painful, and it revealed the real power of women's voices. Shortly after, Flake called for an FBI investigation that is now taking place.

The Kavanaugh affair is a referendum on the political power of women, and as dark as the hearing was, Friday's turn of events offered a bracing reminder: The right knows it has a woman problem. It may not want to listen to the voices on its threshold, but they are only getting louder.

Title: Trump Administration Alters U Visa Policy, Allowing Deportation of Pending Applicants

Article:

The Trump administration has revised its handling of U visas, a class of visa granted to immigrants who cooperate with criminal investigations. The change allows the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to deport pending U visa applicants at their discretion, making immigrants less likely to report serious crimes, according to immigration attorneys.

The revised ICE directive, announced on Aug. 2, allows ICE to grant permission for people to stay in the country as they await their U visas. However, it also permits ICE to deport pending U visa applicants. Applications for U visas can take up to four years, and the government issues 10,000 per year, with no limit on visas for spouses and children of applicants or parents of applicants who are under 21.

The directive states that ICE will review the totality of the circumstances, including any favorable or adverse factors, and any federal interests implicated, to decide whether a stay of removal or terminating proceedings is appropriate. ICE also reserves the right to "exercise its discretion" in determining whether to grant stay of removal requests, but warns that the agency "no longer exempts classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement."

In a statement to a news outlet, an ICE spokesperson defended the change as necessary due to the volume of applications. "As the number of U visa petitions submitted increased, this process became burdensome on both agencies and such determinations didn’t reflect a qualitative assessment of any assistance provided to law enforcement," the spokesperson said.

Immigration attorneys argue that the new directive will have a chilling effect on immigrants who might otherwise report crimes. Eileen Blessinger, a Falls Church, Va.-based immigration attorney, told the news outlet, "By applying, you’re essentially reporting yourself to ICE, but now there’s a risk that ICE might pick you up."

Blessinger also noted that the change piggybacks on another policy change that began about a year ago, when the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services ended its practice of waiving fees for U visa applicants. This change reduced the number of people who could seek out U visas.

Blessinger shared a case where a client, a father of a child sexual abuse victim, was deported twice before but was able to file for a U visa, which was eventually approved, and will be able to stay in the United States and continue to cooperate with the sexual abuse investigation. If he had applied for the U visa under the terms of the new ICE directive, however, he could have been deported.

Another client of Blessinger's is a Salvadoran immigrant and victim of domestic violence who came to the U.S. in 2004 and has been detained in Caroline Detention Facility in Fort A.P. Hill, Va. after failing to appear in court in El Paso, Texas, after receiving a notice to appear that did not include her hearing's date or time.

Cecelia Friedman Levin, senior policy counsel at ASISTA Immigration Assistance, told the news outlet that the new ICE policies impacting the U visa program contravene the purpose that Congress created the protections for. "What we see here with new ICE policies that impact the U visa program is that some of these changes really contravene the purpose that Congress created these protections for," she said.

Kristian Ramos, communications director at the immigrant advocacy group Define American, told the news outlet that the change was indicative of the administration's general handling of long-standing immigration policy. "This administration's reckless changing of long-standing laws has very human casualties," Ramos said. "The client came forward under the auspices that the law would protect her from deportation, and it's incredibly unfair to literally just change the rules on someone who is just trying to get help."

The full guidance for the new U visa policy has yet to be publicly issued by ICE, complicating the process further.

Title: California Teacher Tenure Rules Declared Unconstitutional by Los Angeles County Superior Court

Article:

In a landmark ruling, Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Rolfe Treu declared California's teacher tenure rules unconstitutional on Tuesday in the case of Vergara v California. The ruling, which is subject to an inevitable appeal, could spur litigation in additional states.

Teachers in K-12 schools do not enjoy tenure in the same way as university professors. However, in many states, including California, teachers are afforded a broad array of employment protections often characterized as due process. These protections make it difficult for school officials to dismiss teachers based on performance or for being relatively ineffective.

Judge Treu, citing the landmark Brown v Board of Education case, held that students have a constitutional right to equal education. He further argued that California's system of teacher job security violates this right by having long-term negative consequences for students and disproportionately affecting heavily minority schools.

Teachers unions and their liberal allies argue that Treu's ruling is incorrect, viewing the anti-tenure movement as a thinly veiled union-busting effort. On the other hand, education reformers, who typically advocate for performance-based compensation and job security, largely support the ruling.

The case for strong teacher job security operates on two levels. The more general level is the belief that the American labor market should feature strong labor unions and employment protections. The specific case revolves around the difficulty of moving from the general idea of merit-based employment decisions to the need to find specific operational rules.

Reformers tend to favor using a value-added model that tracks student test scores and measures teachers based on how much their students' scores rise. Critics argue that these value-added models are unstable and unreliable, and that test-based incentive programs may lead to cheating and "teaching to the test."

Proponents note that value-added measures correlate with adult life outcomes. The students of teachers highly rated by VA methods are more likely to attend college, attend highly ranked colleges, earn higher salaries, live in higher socioeconomic status neighborhoods, and even save more for retirement.

The ruling has no immediate consequences, as Judge Treu issued a "tentative decision" in anticipation of appeal. The case will be appealed to the California Supreme Court. If that court rules in favor of the plaintiffs, there will be significant changes in California education. If not, things will continue on their present course.

However, California is only one of 50 states. The success of this lawsuit may encourage reform groups to file similar litigation in other states. Expect more education-related litigation soon.

Title: Mitt Romney's Presidential Campaign: A Look into the Republican Nominee's Journey

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee for president, is experiencing a surge in his campaign following his victories in the primaries of Kentucky and Arkansas, and his upcoming win in Texas. The polls are showing an upward trend for Romney, and he recently completed a two-day tour through Connecticut and New York, where he met with major donors and secured significant funds.

In a telephone interview, Romney discussed his campaign, attributing its success to a growing sense among voters that the country is on the wrong path and a belief that he has proven himself capable. "We went through those 37 or 38 contests and won the must-win states, and in some cases we started off 10 points behind. And we hustled, worked hard, and convinced the voters," Romney said.

Romney reflected on the difference between the America he saw in 2008 and the one he sees now. "A much higher degree of anxiety today. People much less confident in the security of their job, less confident in the prospects for their children," he stated. In 2008, the economic downturn had not yet occurred, and the central issue in his primary was Iraq. Now, the economy is the primary focus.

Before rallies and town meetings, Romney holds private, off-the-record meetings with voters. "I sit down with five or six couples or individuals and just go around the table, and I ask them to tell me about their life. And the stories I hear suggest a degree of anxiety which is not reflected in the statistics," Romney shared. He is struck by the number of people who are employed but in legitimate fear of being let go, and by the number of people who have seen their retirement investments decline.

Romney keeps a campaign journal on his iPad, writing entries every two or three days to remember the campaign and capture "the feelings—the ups, the downs, the people I meet and the sense I have about what's going to happen." He finds joy in the political rallies and town meetings, where he engages with individuals, but views the game of politics as a competition for "old guys."

When asked about his mood, Romney replied, "Depends on the day." He stated that he is unhappy only when he has done something that hurts the prospects for the success of his campaign. He emphasized that his self-worth is not dependent on winning an election.

Regarding historical parallels, Romney stated, "It's 2012." He believes that while history may repeat its lessons, it does not repeat itself identically. He believes the United States is currently experiencing an inflection point, similar to the Civil War and the turn of the last century, where culture, industry, and military strategy have changed. Romney believes America is deciding whether it will follow a path toward Europe, becoming a government-dominated nation with high unemployment and low wage growth, or a path of economic vitality. If Barack Obama is re-elected, Romney believes it will be difficult to change course, but if he is elected, he will usher in a period of economic growth that will surprise the world and America.

Title: Inspector General Report Finds Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Lacked Candor, Violated FBI Policy

Article:

The Department of Justice Inspector General has released a report stating that former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe improperly leaked information to a reporter and lied to his boss, then-Director James Comey, and to FBI agents investigating his behavior. The report could potentially damage McCabe's credibility and impact ongoing investigations.

The report, which has been circulating within the government for weeks, was used to justify McCabe's firing earlier this year, just days before he was set to retire and collect his pension. The Inspector General's report concluded that McCabe lacked candor, including under oath, on multiple occasions in connection with describing his role in a disclosure to the Wall Street Journal, and that this conduct violated FBI Offense Codes 2.5 and 2.6.

The report also found that McCabe's disclosure of the existence of an ongoing investigation, in the manner described in the report, violated the FBI's and the Department's media policy and constituted misconduct. The report delves into several other thorny issues of the 2016 campaign, including an Aug. 12, 2016, call to McCabe from a high-ranking Justice Department official who expressed concerns about the FBI's investigation into the Clinton Foundation.

The House Judiciary Committee Chairman, Bob Goodlatte, stated that his panel is already looking into these matters, and the report provides further evidence of the need to figure out what was going on at the Justice Department. The report is likely to fuel President Trump's complaints about the FBI, the special counsel Robert Mueller's probe into his own behavior and that of his 2016 campaign, and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who is overseeing Mr. Mueller.

The new report is not directly related to Special Counsel Mueller's investigation, indictments against Russian nationals and Trump campaign officials, or the conduct of federal investigators. However, it is expected to fuel President Trump's ongoing criticisms of the FBI and the Justice Department.

The report's findings and the circumstances surrounding McCabe's firing are likely to remain a topic of debate and investigation, with differing perspectives emerging from political figures on both sides of the aisle.

Title: Bloomberg News Imposes Restrictions on Investigating Presidential Candidate and Founder

Article:

Mike Bloomberg, the billionaire businessman and former New York City mayor, has implemented a policy at Bloomberg News that prohibits the news service from investigating him, his family, and his foundation, as well as his Democratic competitors, in order to avoid any perceived conflict of interest. This policy has been met with criticism from some former employees, who argue that it compromises the organization's journalistic independence.

The policy, announced by editor-in-chief John Micklethwait, states that Bloomberg News will continue its tradition of not investigating the founder, and this prohibition will extend to his Democratic competitors because "We can not treat Mike's Democratic competitors differently." This means that everyone from Joe Biden to Bernie Sanders to Cory Booker to Bloomberg himself is off-limits for investigation.

However, the team will continue to investigate the Trump administration as the government of the day. The policy has been criticized as favoring Bloomberg and disadvantaging his rivals, while also compromising the organization's journalistic integrity.

When Mike Bloomberg flirted with a 2016 presidential run, Kathy Kiely, the political editor of Bloomberg News at the time, resigned because of the same policy. Kiely stated that she felt that the organization was compromised as a result of the policy, and that it compromised her as an editor. Megan Murphy, Bloomberg's former Washington bureau chief, also criticized the policy, calling it "ridiculous" and "not journalism."

The policy also affects Bloomberg Opinion, with the two top editors, Tim O'Brien and David Shipley, taking leaves to join the Bloomberg campaign. The rest of the editorial board is being suspended, and the section will refuse to publish any outside op-ed on the 2020 campaign.

Bloomberg News has assigned a reporter to follow the Bloomberg campaign, writing about speeches, policies, and polls. The initial story on the launch stated that the candidate is "offering his own mix of moderate policy stances and experience in business, government, and philanthropy as the way to beat President Donald Trump." The editor-in-chief has stated that he does not want to lay down too many rules, and will reassess the situation if Bloomberg wins the nomination.

This policy has been compared to William Randolph Hearst's use of his newspapers to promote his 1904 presidential bid, but Bloomberg's company dwarfs that early 20th-century enterprise. Other media companies examine their owners or corporate parents with little fuss, with examples including The Washington Post reporting on Jeff Bezos and Amazon, and CNN having to cover Time Warner and now AT&T. It remains to be seen how this policy will impact Bloomberg News' reputation for journalistic independence.

Title: Analysis of Political Loyalty and Tribalism in U.S. Politics

Article:

The articles under discussion explore the concepts of political loyalty and tribalism in the United States political landscape. The first article, published by The Daily Beast, delves into the transformation of Congresswoman Maxine Waters, a figure once labeled as one of the nation's "most corrupt." The piece criticizes Waters for her alleged abuse of office and her recent reception of standing ovations for her sharp attacks on President Trump.

The second article, a column titled "Why Conservatives Still Attack Trump," is written by Dennis Prager, a columnist and radio talk-show host. In this piece, Prager attempts to understand the persistence of Republican resistance to President Trump.

The article on Waters criticizes those who advocate for overturning the Citizens United ruling, allowing state governments to ban political speech, for their hypocrisy in regards to free expression. It also questions the integrity of politicians who have proposed abandoning Fifth Amendment protections to confiscate guns, and those who oppose spying on American citizens based on the sitting president.

The piece on Prager's column discusses his position of "AlwaysTrump," which encourages Republicans to support Trump despite his scandals, in the name of conservatism. The article questions the survival-of-the-nation narrative that underlies the opposition to Trump, and argues that there is no obligation to follow any individual, especially one with malleable principles.

The article concludes by acknowledging the existence of political tribalism, where individuals align themselves with political figures or ideologies, but suggests that the current political climate in Washington is marked by a high degree of unscrupulous behavior from various actors. The piece does not take a stance on the validity of the survival-of-the-nation narrative or the "AlwaysTrump" or "NeverTrump" positions, but instead presents both perspectives in a neutral and factual manner.

Title: Hong Kong International Airport Cancels Flights Amid Ongoing Pro-Democracy Protests; Chinese Authorities Label Protests as "Beginning to Show the Sprouts of Terrorism"

Article:

Hong Kong International Airport, one of the world's busiest airports, suspended all flights on Monday following a large-scale occupation of the main terminal by pro-democracy demonstrators. Chinese authorities have likened the protest to "terrorism."

According to an official statement, the protests "seriously disrupted" airport operations. Only flights that were already boarding or had been cleared for landing were allowed to use the airport's runways. All other flights were canceled.

The city has been experiencing mass protests for over two months, urging democratic reforms and an investigation into police conduct. The Hong Kong government, which is supposed to be separate from communist China's influence, introduced an extradition bill that critics say would threaten the liberties awarded to the city and would allow people to be extradited to face the law in mainland China.

The bill was temporarily suspended following protests. However, the demonstrations have evolved from an uproar over the specific extradition proposal into a more general demand for greater freedoms and a check on the perceived use of excessive force by the authorities.

China on Monday used the strongest language yet to vilify the participants, with the Cabinet's Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office in Beijing saying the protests are "beginning to show the sprouts of terrorism" and constitute an "existential threat" to the population of Hong Kong.

"One must take resolute action toward this violent criminality, showing no leniency or mercy," said a statement from spokesperson Yang Guang. "Hong Kong has reached an inflection point where all those who are concerned about Hong Kong's future must say 'no,' to lawbreakers and 'no' to those engaged in violence."

Earlier Monday, Hong Kong police displayed water cannons that could be deployed in the case of future demonstrations. Amnesty International has warned that the misuse of these cannons within the densely-populated city's confined spaces could lead to serious injuries.

Hong Kong is a former British colony that has been part of China since 1997, but benefits from autonomy, crediting a "one country, two systems" approach. This structure allows the city certain democratic rights that are not afforded to people on the mainland, but in recent years, some people have accused the Communist Party-ruled central government of slowly stripping their freedoms.

Ma Ngok, a political scientist at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, told the South China Morning Post that heavy-handed tactics from police have alienated people.

"They have lost confidence in the police enforcing the law fairly and would question the legitimacy of all their actions," he said. "They no longer think it's reasonable to blindly obey the law when there is no punishment for the officers' wrongdoings."

Title: Iowa's Presidential Field: Two Progressive Contenders Face Potential Vote Splitting Concerns

Article:

In the recent rallies at the Iowa State Fair, Democratic presidential candidates Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders drew large crowds, with supporters chanting their names, waving signs, and cheering at their every pledge. Both candidates share similar stances on issues such as universal healthcare, taking on Wall Street, and raising the minimum wage.

As the two candidates have robust, well-funded campaigns and strong claims on Iowa, which hosts the first Democratic presidential nominating contest in February, some voters are concerned about the potential for a vote split on the left, with the two popular progressives running head-to-head, to the benefit of a centrist candidate like former Vice President Joe Biden.

Sherma Mather, a 50-year-old visitor from Richmond, Virginia, supporting Warren, expressed her concerns, stating, "Of course it concerns me." Early opinion polls have consistently shown Biden in the lead, with either Sanders or Warren in second place.

Adam Green, co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee (PCCC), an advocacy group that supports Warren, described Sanders and Warren as a "1-2 punch" with a "gravitational pull" on the rest of the field.

Twenty-four Democrats are currently competing to secure their party's nomination and challenge Republican President Donald Trump in the November 2020 general election. Sanders and Warren have maintained that they are friends, not rivals, and have so far stayed true to their pledge not to attack each other for political gain.

In Iowa, recent polls show Warren in second place with 21% of the vote, trailing Biden by just seven percentage points. Sanders had dropped to 9% in the state, according to the poll. Sanders' campaign advisers have criticized the poll as flawed due to an alleged undersampling of Sanders' supporters.

Nationally, the situation is better for Sanders, with Sanders and Warren neck-and-neck behind Biden. The most recent ███/Ipsos poll had Sanders in second place by a wide margin over Warren.

Alexis Johnson, a 33-year-old resident of Des Moines, expressed her support for Sanders, stating, "Beating Trump is my top priority as a voter, and I have little enthusiasm for Warren." However, Misty Cornelius, a 38-year-old Des Moines resident with a Sanders tattoo, suggested Warren might be a better choice against Trump, stating, "Bernie has been stigmatized. Warren is a fresh face."

Despite sharing many of the same talking points, the two candidates have noticeable differences in their stump speeches. Warren casts herself as a sort of prairie populist, while Sanders talks more in terms of leading a "movement." There is also evidence that the two do not chase the same kind of voters.

Patrick Murray, the polling director at Monmouth, stated, "While there is ideological overlap, Warren's recent surge has her pulling support away from virtually every other candidate, not just Sanders." Sanders' campaign views Biden as their primary challenge, as both are courting the kind of working-class voters and union voters who gravitated to Trump in 2016.

Biden did little in Iowa to boost his status as a front-runner, making several gaffes, including a sensitive slip-up when he said "poor kids are just as bright and just as talented as white kids" in a speech. U.S. Senator Kamala Harris of California ranked third in the state in the Monmouth poll with 11% support.

Right now, the primary concern of the two campaigns is not to siphon support off the other. Instead, they both want to convince large swaths of voters that a progressive Democrat can win the election against Trump. Many Warren voters, like Mather of Richmond, fear Sanders will not yield if his fellow senator continues to gain momentum.

Title: Trump and Kudlow Dismiss Recession Concerns, Offer Optimistic Outlook on Economy

Article:

President Donald Trump and his top economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, have offered an optimistic outlook on the U.S. economy, dismissing concerns of a potential recession. In a series of interviews over the weekend, both Trump and Kudlow expressed confidence in the economy's performance, particularly in the second half of 2019.

Trump, returning from his New Jersey golf club on Sunday, stated, "I don't think we're having a recession." He attributed the economy's strength to the tax cuts he implemented and the increased spending power of consumers. Kudlow, in interviews on Sunday television, echoed this sentiment, stating, "We're doing pretty darn well in my judgment."

Consumer confidence has dropped 6.4% since July, and a slowing energy sector has been acknowledged. However, Kudlow believes low interest rates will help sectors such as housing, construction, and auto sales.

Kudlow also defended Trump's use of tariffs on goods coming from China, stating that the "China story has to be changed and reformed." This stance contrasts with Kudlow's previous career as an economic analyst, during which he was known for opposing tariffs and promoting free trade.

Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke expressed concerns about the ongoing trade war with China, stating, "This current trade war that the president has entered our country into is not working." He fears it is driving the global economy into a recession and is causing significant harm to farmers across the country.

Last month, the Federal Reserve reduced its benchmark rate, the first such reduction since December 2008 during the depths of the Great Recession. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concern about the consequences of Trump's trade war and sluggish economies overseas.

Breaking with historical norms, Trump has been critical of Powell, placing blame for any economic weakness on the nation's central bank for raising interest rates too much over the past two years. Peter Navarro, who advises Trump on trade policy, shared this sentiment.

Navarro also stated that U.S. consumers are not affected by the administration's trade war with China, though tariffs are taxes paid by U.S. importers, not by China, and are often passed along to U.S. businesses and consumers through higher prices. Kudlow himself previously stated that U.S. consumers and businesses ultimately end up paying the tariffs that the administration imposes on billions of dollars of Chinese goods.

Trump acknowledged at least a potential impact of the tariffs, pausing a planned 10% tariff hike for many items coming from China during the Christmas season. Navarro, however, stated, "There's no evidence whatsoever that American consumers are bearing any of this."

Kudlow was interviewed on NBC's "Meet the Press" and "Fox News Sunday." O'Rourke spoke on NBC, and Navarro appeared on CNN's "State of the Union" and CBS' "Face the Nation." Trump's trade war with China has been a target of criticism by Democrats vying to challenge him in 2020. Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, a Democratic presidential candidate, stated, "There is clearly no strategy for dealing with the trade war in a way that will actually lead to results for American farmers or American consumers." He believes that increasing tariffs will not compel China to change its economic approach.

Title: Justice Department Seeks Stay of Emergency Contraceptive Ruling, Faces Two-Step Review Process

Article:

The United States Department of Justice will appear before a federal judge on Tuesday in an attempt to suspend a controversial ruling that would make emergency contraceptives available to young teenage girls without a prescription in the coming days. The ruling, made by U.S. District Court Judge Edward Korman of New York on April 5, was initially set to take effect on Monday but has been delayed until Friday.

In a letter, Judge Korman has given the plaintiffs until Monday to respond to the notice of appeal filed by the Justice Department earlier this week. The ongoing debate over minors' access to the morning-after pill is testing the loyalty of groups traditionally among the biggest supporters of President Obama, who stated on Thursday that he is "comfortable" with his administration's efforts to find a middle ground on the issue.

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius decided in 2011 to keep age restrictions on the pill in place, and women's rights groups have criticized the administration's decision to appeal Judge Korman's ruling, arguing that access to emergency contraception is suitable for all ages. Pro-life groups, who typically criticize the Democratic president, have cheered the decision to fight Judge Korman's ruling, although they did not approve of the FDA's decision on Tuesday to allow girls as young as 15 to obtain the drug without a prescription, a change from the prior age limit of 17.

The Obama administration maintains that the FDA's lowering of the age was due to an application from the pill's maker, Teva Women's Health Inc., and not related to the pending federal case. However, attorneys from Justice have noted the 15-year-old threshold now covers all the girls involved in the case, a move the plaintiffs' attorneys deemed suspicious.

Judge Korman has indicated he will give the government two chances to put his ruling on ice. "The parties are also advised that, in the event that I deny a stay pending appeal, I will grant a stay to allow the defendants to seek a stay from the Court of Appeals," his letter said.
